THE LOVE AND ARMS OF THE GREEK PRINCES.

OR, THE ROMANT OF ROMANTS.

Written in French by Monsieur Verdere, And Translated for the Right
Honorable, Philip, Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery, Lord Chamberlain to his
Majesty.

HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE

LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper, for Thomas Walkley, and a^e to be sold at

CHAP. I. The wonder that ensued the great battle of Aleppo.
THe night coming on, with a lamentable grief in those which were the
victors, for the loss of so many Princes, by the valor of whom, all
Christendom was so much glorified: and with an extreme amazement of all the
Pagans to see such a flaughter of so many Kings, Giants, and Knights, who had
gathered themselves together for the ruin of the Christian Empire. Amadis of
Greece unwilling to expose his soldiers to the hazard of the darkness of the
night, commanded the retreat to be sounded; whereupon fires were made in every
part of the camp, good Courts of Guard were settled, and the charge of the
watch being committed to the trust of the King Melinda, and him of the I Will of
Magera, (as those which we^e less tired than the rest) all those Princes whom
the heavens had preserved from the fury of the sword, rendered themselves at the
Tent of the Emperor Amadis of Greece: who unable to take the care of Council
upon him, by reason of the multitude of his wounds, remitted it wholly to the
wisdom of Prince Florisell, of Niquea his son; he desiring in some sort to
mittigate the sorrow he was in for the loss of his ^insmen, by the utter ruin
of the Pagans, determined no longer to defer his revenge, and therefore
commanded that Don Rogell should march by the first break of day, with the
Army of the King Melinda, and Olidor his brother, which consisted of thirty
thousand horse, for that purpose. And finding that of so infinite a number of
people, which had followed the Christian Colors, there remained onley 36000.
men; he appointed 4000. horse, and 12000. foot for the guard of the camp, and
securing the person of the Emperor Amadis of Greece. Among which was the
valiant Alastaxerea, Cilinda, wife to Dorigell, of the fortunate Islands,
Gelodan, King of Moldavia, Atletta his wife, the Kings of Sardamira and Catay,
with their wives, resolving to pass on with the Emperor Sheramond, the fair
Salvagesse, Dorigell, the two Cenophales, Gin^ldan, Amanio, d'Astro, Silvan,
Liseard King of Licaonia, Filadard, Prince of Poland, Parmenian of Cyprus,
Ladazan of Numidia, Garmanti the Duke of Laiazga, Anaxand^r, Fl^r^din his
brother, and twenty thousand horse, which remained of so great a slaughter.
Things thus ordered, every man was about to withdraw to his Tent to repose
himself, when as a fearful noise was heard in the middle region of the air,
the claps of thunder did so hideously rore, flashes of lightning followed one
another so close, and the winds contested with such violence, that all men
believed the world was going to return into the first confusion of its chaos.
The Princes as^onished with the strangeness hereof, beholding one another,
expected the issue of this tempest: and believed already that the beavens
having care of their quiet, did mean to take them to themselves, that they
might not over-live the anguish of the loss of so many Princes their dearest
friends. But after a while the wi^des w^^e laid, the noise ceased, and the air
before full of lightning flashes, grew so black, that all the fires which they
had kindled in the camp, to cheer and refresh the soldiers, being
extinguished in an instant, they could not discern at all what the matter was.
This second accident would have made them tremble, if their hearts had been
capable of fear: but having always stood firm before the appearance of the
greatest dangers, they remained with a courageous resolution to endure what God
should please to lay upon them. This darkness having endured three or four
hours, the day drew on, with an universal amazement of them all. For in the
midst of the field where the battle had been found, they saw a building
erected of a strange fabrique. The form thereof was round, divided by sixty
five towers of crystal, which altogether did make a Hall of a portentuous
greatness. Into it there was a passage by one only gate, before the which
stood two great Lions of brass, who seemed as if they had been there placed
to tear in pieces such as should offer to come near it. Two columns were
fixed about ten paces from them, on either side one, whereof each had a Table
hanging on it, in which these words were written.

The Prophecy. The glory of all humane knowledge shall never be known, until
the new Lions shall with their roaring, fill the darkesome Forest: then shall
all the Crows gather themselves together to possess the neasts of the
sleeping Eagles; the earth shall open it self to restore the treasure which it
keeps hidden, and the tears shed for a loss not befallen, shall be
converted into joy.

The other spoke thus.

When the dead shall awake to join themselves with the living, then shall
valor be at her height, and beauty in the supreamest point of her glory.

These Princes as much ravished to see that great field cleared of a million of
bodies, which had been slain there the day before, as with the rarity of the
work, did instantly draw near to the columns, read these Prophecies, and
passing on to the Gate, saw in the first tower, the great King Amadis of Gaul,
armed at all pieces, except his hands, upon one of which he rested his head,
sitting in a chair, in the posture as of one asleep: Esplandian was in the
opposite tower over against him on the other side of the Gate, but not in a
like posture to his fathers, for he was laid along, with his arms acrosse, on
the hilt of his sword, the point whereof reached to his feet: the Emperor
Lisward was in the third tower, in the same fashion as his father; and Don
Silves de la Silve, in the fourth seated as Amadis of Gaul. Upon the same
side, and in the same manner, were Agesilan, Amadis d' Astre, Astrapole,
Fortunian, Anaxartes, Penthasilea, Argantes, Florarlan, Lucencio, Falanges, d'
Astre, Arlantog Arlanges of Spain his son, Lucidamon of Boetia, Florenio
Emperor of Rome, Filisu^l de Montaspin, Zain, Don Flores of Greece, Filin,
Artaure, and Lindamart: and on the other side laid along as Esplandian was,
were Galaor, Lucidor, the Kings of Mesopotamia, and of Traramata, Brimart of
Syria, Don Brunco de bonne mer, the two Giants sons of Planacoldo, Ol^rius of
Spain, Farron the second son of Amadis of Gaul; the kings of Corinthe, of
Magadena, and of Paloman, the Prince of Palomar his son, Agrayes, the Kings
of Mont Libanus, of ^oliemia, Galatia, Pantapolis, and of the Garamantes,
Guillan the Penfif, Don Galdes of Rhodes, Vatliades, Circi^ of Ireland, the
giant Girafer, Stilpon, Talanque, Don Frisas of Lusitania, Faenix of Corinthe,
Albion of Bugia, Astibell of Mesopotamia, Brimart of Syria, Garinter King of
Dacia, Dinerpio, Emperor of Rome, Florestan his son, Brian of Moniasta,
Galvanes, son of Agrayes, Pintiquinestro, and Calafio, who filled the towers
that compassed the whole body of the edifice. This object renewed their grief,
and drew from them some sighs: but being certain of their loss^, and
sufficiently generous to bear all the blows of fortune, they resolved to show
the least resentment thereof that was possible. Nevertheless, desirous to see
what was within the Hall, Florisull drew to the gate, with his sword in his
hand, and knocked at it with the pommell, but was deceived in his hope, for no
word of answer was returned him, and therefore was constrained to retire
himself, with some discontent, for having effected so little in his attempt.
Following his example, Don Rogel advanced, but being no more fortunate therein
than his father, he sheathed his sword, and made room for all those young
Princes, who speeding no better, were upon the point of quitting the place:
when they saw the excellent (...) of Greece approach, that notwithstanding the
advice of his Physicians, forbidding him to go^ abroad, would not excuse
himself from the labor of this adventure, no^ lose the contentment of the
honor which out of it (...) hoped to gain. This brave Prince, despising the
greatness of his wounds, and marching with the same courage that he ever
carried in the most difficult enter prises of his youth, ^et his hand bravely
to his sword, and being come close to the gate, raised his a^me to have
knocked, but seeing that it opened of it self, he presently (...) without any
resistance. As soon as he was in, the g^t^ closed (...), with such a trembling
of the earth, that all these Princes, more (...) then they were before, could
not keep themselves from falling down. Nevertheless th^^r amazement
continuing not long, they rose up again much grieved th^^ they knew not
whether that clap of thunder were a sign of that great Emperors death, or
that his entering into that Hall were for the preservation of his life. See
(said Florisull) how fortune makes her self sport with crossing us thus, but
she must not prevail. We are to be victorious over her malice: and make her
bend under the power of our virtue. Let us then pursue our former resolution:
give ch^^e to our enemies, and not pardon their insolence. They are so
dejected, as they will hardly be able to raise themselves again. At these
words, all men disposed themselves to follow their colors: when as a Damsel
appeared, who making her address to Don Florisull, delivered him a paper which
she had in her hand, and without expecting any answer, immediately turned bridle
and departed. Th^^ (...) at this (...) others, but desiring to know what this
letter contained, they presently environed Florisull, who read these words
aloud unto them. To the Greek Princes: I do not write to you with a purpose
to raise up your spirits, nor to comfort you in your affliction: fortune and
your vert^e have already (...). But to advertise you that the heaven taken care
of your quiet, by the preservation of a treasure of infinite value, which you
shall one day find with so much contentment, that you shall not remember your
passed (...). If I had liberty to speak more freely, I would add to your joy,
(...) power being restrained within these only words, which I n^w speak: you
shall i^ you please malie use of them to keep you from afflicting you^selve^
too (...). In the mean time do not prosecute the design you (...)* The (...)
more complete revenge is not yet come, and the sa^^ will have i^ (...), to ma^e
it a more memorable day. Keep that which you have (...) and (...) things to
time. It is by this prudence that you must live, and I testify the desire
which I have to do you service. Alcander.

This Letter held the Prince a while in suspense, for the name being unknown to
them, they were not sure that this advice was without some practice. Our
enemies (said Dorigell) have invented this trick to retard our revenge, and
having no more strength to resist us, they fly to their tricks; let us follow
our fortune. She prospers such as lay hold of occasions, and they that make
themselves unworthy of her favors, never encounter them according to their
desires. Speaking thus, he had almost persuaded all those Lords to neglect the
counsel that was given them, and to pursue the fortune of their victory: but
Florisell, who was endued with no less prudence than valor, fairly
demonstrating that with precipitation they might too much endanger themselves,
and that matters were to be weighed with more deliberation, staid the fury of
these Princes. It is true (said he) that we may with reason suspect this
counsel, since we know not him that gives it. But when I consider this tomb
wherein all our ancestors do now repose with so much glory, I cannot think
there is any deceit intended against us. Where are the bodies of so many Pagan
Kings, and what honor is done them in their obsequies? I see nothing that can
be to their advantage, and all these wonders serve but to increase our
greatness. The advice that is given us, is very good: let us I beseech you
follow it. And not busying our thoughts with the conquest of Pagan Empires, let
us wisely preserve those estates which heaven has bestowed upon us. For mine
own part I am resolved to take into my care the government of Greece, my
sister Alastaxeree shall command in Trebisond, till the destinies do restore
us the Emperor my Lord and Father: my son shall be resident in Persia, and
Spheramond shall maintain the authority that he has among the Parthians; the
rest of you (my Lords) shall every one retire into the Province, which either
his birth or valor has acquired him. The opinion of this judicious Prince
being well approved of, they left twenty thousand men with the Kings Anaxander
and Floradin, to keep the kingdoms lately conquered in awe, fifteen thousand
with Ginoldan and Amano^ D. Astre; and the remainder being otherwise divided,
Florisell set forth for Constantinople, Alastraxeree for Trebifond, Don Rogell
for Persia, Dorigell for the fortunate Island, Melinde and Olidor for their
kingdoms, Gulodan for Moldavia, Fladard for Poland, Gadard for Hungary, and
the rest in general, as either their affairs or their affections drew them.

CHAP. II. Who Alcander was, his enchanting Don Belianis of Greece, the Knight
of the Sun, King Amadis, and the bravest Knights of their time.
IT is most necessary for the understanding of this our history, that you
should know who this Alcander was, of whom we spoke before, for that thereupon
depends one of the foundations of our work: he came into the world in the time
of Don Belianis, Emperor of Greece, and from his childehood gave himself to
the knowledge of letters, particularly to the secrets of Magic, but with such
earnestness of affection, that having bestowed certain years therein, he
became so perfect an Artist, as he surpassed all those that had traveled in
those studies before him, as well as those that came after him: yet was it not
his purpose to make use thereof, as many do, to the hurt or ruin of any, but
for the glory of Christendom, which he so took to heart, that all his actions
had no other aim, but the preservation of those, whose worth was able to
maintain it at the due height, as you may well judge by the sequel of this
History. Seeing then that Don Belianis, a Prince as virtuous and valiant as
could be named, was somewhat enfeebled by the battle that he had fought before
Constantinople, with Perineo, Sultan of Persia, the most valiant of all the
Pagans that then lived, the Empress of Almayne, Claristea, who might also be
termed the mirror of Arms, and Ariobarcan Emperor of Tartary, he wrought so
powerfully upon the minds of that brave Pagan, and of that valorous Lady, as
admiring the virtue of so gallant a man, they determined to turn Christians,
and become his friends, upon condition, that the Persian should marry the
Infanta of Greece, named Sirenna: which was accomplished presently after his
Baptism. In which holy Sacrament he was accompanied with Salinterne, without
Far, his son, and the bastard of Don Belianis, Polistor of Nubia, and
Polistea de la Selva, whom he had by the Queen of the Garamantes, and had
followed the Pagan colors before they knew Don Belianis for their Father. This
peace and this marriage cheered all Greece, and particularly our Alcander, who
then thought it well and sufficiently supported. But being continually careful
for the quiet of these Princes, he had one day a curious desire to understand
what good fortune was to attend their designs and life; withdrawing therefore
himself from all resort of company, he began to make his ordinary
invocations, and found only by the motion and aspect of the stars, that the
house of Greece was to suffer a total ruin; and that these Princes were
threatened with an eminent death. The knowledge hereof did mightily afflict
him; but carrying a greater mind then to yield to this calamity, he made new
conjurations: the spirits were invoked, and all the powers of Hell were
summoned to appear: nevertheless he saw nothing but signs of death, and
presages of misfortune. Let the stars, said he, be froward, let all the
Devils in Hell conspire together, to subvert the Empire of the Christians, yet
will I change their influences, and overturne their designs. For having
sometimes restored life to those which breathed no more, I may be permitted to
preserve such as are yet in the world. Thus speaking, he enfolded himself in
a cloud, and transported himself into the dangerous forests of the great
kingdom of Martan, near to the Empire of Mexico, where long before he had
built a Castle of wondrous workmanship. But doubting that the charms which he
had set upon it, were not powerful enough for the great purpose he had in
hand, he employed all his skill, which surpassed that of all other men, laid
such strong enchantments upon three divisions of lodgings, that he had built
in a triangular form, as those which should be enclosed therein, should not
grow old, or be impaired in any sort whatsoever; yet not desiring that this
his work should last till the end of the world; for he well foresaw that the
necessity of Christendom, would one day oblige him to suffer it to be
dissolved, ordained that the enchantment should be defeated by the valor of
six the bravest Knights, accompanied with as many the fairest Ladies of the
world. Thinking then that he had done enough, he presently transported
himself to Constantinople: and having talked a while in private with Don
Belianis, he desired him to go into his Chariot, and with him his Son
Belforan, Fortiman of Greece, his grandchilde Polistor of Nubia, Polistea de la
Selva, Policentes son to Perineo, Don Clarinell Don Astrides his son,
Perineo, Furibond the brave Giant, Salintern without fear, Hermiliana, the
Amazon, wife to Don Clarinel, Florisbella, wife to Don Bel^anis, the Princess
Belianisa, wife to Belforan, Sirenna wife to Perineo, and the fair Bergeline
her daughter. This done, having touched the Griffons with a rod that he had in
his hand, they cut the air, with incredible swiftness, and carried him to the
house, which he would have called by the name of the Castle of Treasure. Where
with some tears, he enclosed these Princes in one quarter of the Lodgings,
assuring them that they should be enlarged after certain ages, and at such
time as Christendom should have extreme need of their assistance. These
things being done, his mind might well have been contented, but the exceeding
care that he had to effect his designs, not suffering him to be quiet, he
again turned over his books: And finding, that before the time these Princes
should be disinchanted, certain most excellent Knights should be borne, which
yet should not arrive to the perfection necessary for the putting an end to his
enchantments, he resolved also to preserve them in the same Castle with the
Emperor Don Belianis. For which cause therefore, as soon as the incomparable
warrior, the Knight of the Sun was borne, he was infinitely careful of his
safety, assisted him with his Art without his privity, and knowing that after
certain years, he was threatened with a disastrous end, by the practice of
some traitors, who should murder him one night in his bed, he carried him also
away, as he had done Don Belianis, and with him all the principal Knights of
his Court, who were to run no less hazard; and placing them in the second
division of the lodgings, he reserved them for that furious encounter, wherein
the glory of all Christendom, or the ruin of the Pagans was to be disputed.
The names of those enchanted with him, were, his son Claridiano of the
Sphere, Rosiclere, Claramant, Poliphebo, Don Eleno of Dacia, Rosabell son to
Rosiclere, Clarabel bastard to Rosabel, and Leobant his brother, Besson,
Bramidor the brave Giant, the Empress Claridiana, and the Princess Olivia,
wife to Rosicleere. Their life was pleasant, and the contentment of Alcander
infinite. For as often as he considered, that Christendom should one day
triumph over her enemies, by his assistance, he esteemed himself blessed, to
be so favored by heaven, and determining not to neglect such grace he
persevered in his good desire, whence it came that after certain ages were
past, being in the castle of Treasure, he understood the lamentable loss,
which the Christians were to sustain, and the death of those great Monarchs,
Amadis of Gaul and of Greece, with many others of their blood. Which, for the
reasons before alleged, being desirous to remedy, he transported himself,
the same night as that great battle was fought in the fields of the Sultan of
Aleppo, to the place where so many bodies lay extended; gave an honorable
sepulture to those Christian Princes which were dead, as you have heard in the
first Chapter; and carried away those, in whom he found any hope of life, to
that wonderful Castle, appointing them the third division of lodgings; the
names of whom were; The great King Amadis of Gaul, Amadis of Greece, enchanted
as you have heard, Don Silves de la Selva, Agesilan, Amadis d' Astre,
Astropolo, Fortiman, Anaxartes, Penthesilea, Argantes, Florartan, Lucentio,
Falanges d' Astre, Arlantes, his son Arlanges of Spain, Lucidamor of Boetia,
Floreni Emperor of Rome, Filisel of Montespin, Zayr, Flores of Greece, second
son to Esplandian, Filon King of Sibila, Artaur his Brother, King of Mount
Libanus, and Lindamart of Rhodes. But because there may arise a doubt in this
Discourse, for that all these which I now have named, were enclosed in the
Monument, that appeared in the field of the battle after the darkness was
past, the Reader may remember, if he please, that these, of whom I now speak,
were in a posture there, di^^ering from theirs, who were fully and really dead;
and that the wise man did so order it, to comfort those great Knights, after so
heavy a loss. These Princes then being enchanted with Don Belianis, and the
Knight of the Sun, though they knew it not, Alcander, who would not do a
courtesy to halfes, first healed them of their wounds. And then desiring, they
should not be less happy then the rest, presented them a little while after,
with some of the Princesses they loved, whom he had brought from
Constantinople, to the extreme discontent of those that remained behind.
There was the Queen Oriana, the Empress Niquea, delivered not long before of
a son, whose birth was celebrated by an infinity of fires appearing in the
air; and whom at his Baptism she named Amadis of Trebisond, Diana, Axiana,
the Princess Oriana, wife of Anaxartes, Cleosila, Sestiliana, Radiana,
Oristila, Anaxarea, Theodorina, Belisaura, Claire estoille, Sclarimena, and
Timbria. Having then prepared sovereign baths for them, made with a million of
rare simples, gathered at such time as they were in most virtue, he bathed them
eight days together; at the end whereof King Amadis and his wife seemed to be
but forty years old; and every man as fresh and lovely, as they were at that
age; the Emperor Amadis of Greece, and the Princess Niquea, but thirty five:
Don Silves Agesilan, and the rest, not above thirty.

This done, he carried them all into a fair chamber, and thus spoke unto them:
Mighty Princes, you perceive by the help that you have already received at my
hands, the desire I have to do you service: I will not therefore excuse my
self unto you, for holding you restrained in this manner, since I have no other
end for it, but the augmentation of your glory: All things must have their
course, and the malignant influences of the stars, must have time to pass
over. The day will come, when you will see your offspring with more
contentment then ever; expect it with so much the more patience. In the mean
time I will go from hence to take care for the affairs of those which concern
you nearly. Saying thus, he went out of the door, which shut of it self
with a strange violence, leaving those Princes and Princesses so enchanted, as
they did not remember any thing without that place whatsoever.

CHAP. III. Most of the Prin^^^ of Greece die: Alcander goes to visit the wise
Alquif and Urganda.
THE news of the death of so many Kings, Princes, and Emperors, and the
carrying away of the Queen Oriana, with the rest, which were enchanted in the
Castle of Treasure, was the cause of so much grief to those Ladies that
remained at Constantinople, expecting what would be the issue of that war, as
not able to withstand the violence thereof, they yielded to the necessity of
death, leaving Christendom a world of sorrow for so great a loss. The
Empress Leonine was the first that paid that tribute of nature, but followed
so close by the young Princess of Sardamyra, the wife of Sistra, that the
funerals of the one served also for the other. After them died almost at the
same time, the Empress Arbra, Briolania, the Queen of France wife to Lucidor,
the Queen of Traramate and Mesopotamia, Melicia wife to Bruneo of the good
Sea, Lardenia, Laciana, Gricelarie, Olinde, the Queens of Corinth, Saba,
Bohemia, the wife of Guillan the pensive, the Queens of the Garamantes, of
Pentapoly, Galacia and Ireland, the wives of Girafer, of Vaillades, of Don
Frisus of Lusitania, the Queen of Dacia, the Empress Brisenne, Darayde Queen
of Cores, the wife of Stilpon, and the Queen of Rhodes: who were all interred
in the Emperors great Chapel, with so many complaynts and tears, that
nothing was heard in any part of the City but cries and lamentatio^s. Now
whilst the ceremonies of so many obsequies were performing, Alcander, who had
no care more pressing, then the preservation of those Princes, went in his
Chariot of the Griffons, to the unknown Island, wh^re the wise Alquif was,
with Vrganda, Zirzea, and Zirenna; but not desiring to present himself unto
them without some demonstration of his skill, he in a moment raised such
horrible flashes of lightning in the air, so great an earthquake, as those
reverend old folks seeing so furious a tempest beyond the order of nature,
believed that those thunders were presages of their deaths. So that disposing
themselves to seek the mercy of heaven, which never refuses grace to us, when
with humility we seek it, they fell upon the earth, and lifting up their eyes
they met with a new terror when as they espied the fearful Chariot in which
Alcander appeared, seated with such a majesty, that if they had not been
instructed by the light of faith, that one only God was to be acknowledged,
they had adored him: never so much as dreaming that it was done by art Magic,
or that this encounter could proceed from the skill of any mortal man. For
believing that none in the world was more expert in that art then they, they
could never imagine that any man could find them out in their Island, unless
they pleased to permit it. Alcander reading their amazement in their looks and
motions, would not keep them any longer in pain: Most venerable persons, said
he, be not dismayed to see me here at this present, and in this manner: That
almighty God who has endued you with the knowledge of things above nature for
the good of his people, has imparted to me the same favors which he has
bestowed upon you, and made me no less zealous of his glory and service: I am
not come hither now to trouble you, as you imagine, but indeed to confer with
you about certain things, which shall be necessary for the welfare of the
Princes of Greece, whose virtue has begotten such an affection in me toward
them, as I will not entertayne a thought but for the augmentation of their
glory. I know that you have always infinitely loved them; that your assistance
was never wanting to them; and that without your aid they could not so easily
have endured those labors they have passed through. Wherefore I will endeavor
to recompense you for it; imparting to you certain secrets, that as yet are
not come to your knowledge, and that I know you will not a little esteem: But
because your preservation is no less dear to me then their quiet, I do
desire you all to go with me to a Palace that I have, whither we will carry
with us your Books, and such instruments as are fit for those of our
profession; to the end, that my sabour being added to your learning, we may
the more easily find out what shall most conduce to our design. I cannot
doubt but you may have some cause to fear the undertaking of this voyage in
the company of a man, whom you never heard spoken of, and that you may find
reason to decline it in the incommodity of your age; but the good service I
have done to Christendom, which has not undergone so great a loss as you
believe, and that also I intend to you in your own particular, may oblige you
not to suspect any malice in me: I love virtue too well to be a traitor, and
your lives are with me no less considerable then mine own. Resolve with your
selves then, my dear friends, and make no difficulty in following my advice:
Time will make you know me better, and experience; assure you of my zeal to
that, which concerns the affair I have in hand. How pleasing is rest after
labor, and how sweet is assurance after fear? These good folks, who expected
nothing less then so gentle a language, and that made no great account of
their lives, judging by Alcanders courage, that he had no bad disposition, gave
him as many thanks as the favor he did in visiting them seemed great. It is
most true, said Alquif, that we would never have thought any other could have
outgone us in the knowledge of the secrets of Magic. But your coming hither
has freed us of that error: for this our Island being indivisible to all the
world, and so easily discovered by you, our selves also in a manner bereft of
our judgment in beholding you, we cannot doubt but your knowledge is far
beyond ours. Wherefore without any manner of distrust of you, we do withal
acknowledgement accept the honor of your company, and the offer that you make
of acquainting us with such secrets, as have been hitherto concealed from us.
And to testify unto you that I speak ingenuously and freely, I protest
henceforth to depend wholly upon you, so that if we do hereafter undertake
any thing, it shall not be but by your advice: and if our weak indevours may
be of use to the greatness of your intentions, we will join them to yours,
without expecting of any part in the glory of your actions, but that which
shall redound from having been your servants. Let us go then, when you please,
we will carry with us what shall be requisite; and if you think good, leave
nothing behind us in this Island. No, no, answered Alcander, that shall not
need: The best of your books will be sufficient. Vrganda then having made up a
bundle of them, they all went into the Chariot of the Griffons, that is to say,
Alquif, Vrganda, Zirza, Zirenna, Alquifa, and the young Cassandra, who
afterward by the aid of Alcander, became so perfect in that art, as she much
excelled her parents. The beasts having their load, began to cut the air with
an incredible swiftness, and in a little time arrived at the Castle of
Treasure, which appeared to these Magicians so magnificent, that they had never
seen building equal to it. As soon as they were come thither, Alcander not to
lose time, desired them to put off their clothes, and made them go into those
precious baths, which he had formerly prepared to restore the Princes of
Greece to the most flourishing estate of their age; where after he had kept
them eight days, the wrinkles which covered their faces, were clean defaced;
their limbs enfeebled by a troublesome old age, became firm; their backs
bending under the weight of years, were straightned; their hair whited with
time, changed color; in brief, they found themselves wholly altered from what
they were in the unknown Island. Behold, said then this great Prince of
Philosophers, the first favor I will do to you, that to me seems of no mean
importance: But because we are not assembled here only for our selves, let
us take a little pains, and see how we may hinder the mischief which is yet
to fall upon the house of Greece, by the loss of some certain young Princes,
who are one day to be the strongest pillars of Christendom. I propound this
unto you, though I think it unprofitable, for the ordinances of heaven are
inevitable; howbeit our labor shall not be without fruit; and though we
cannot keep them from imprisonment, yet shall we do somewhat to help and
preserve them among their enemies. This said, they began to make their
conjurations apart, which were not altogether unusefull, as you shall know by
the sequel of this Discourse. That done, Alcander thought good to return his
friends to their Island, not discovering to them the enchantment of the Princes
of Greece. And having desired them to watch as till then they had done, for the
benefit of Christendom, he went away, carrying Cassandra along with him, to
show her all the secrets of Magic, and to render her perfect in that Art.

CHAP. IV. The Adventures of the Greek Princes returning into their Empires.
FLorisel of Niquea, approoving of the wise Alcanders advice, did wholly desist
from the purpose he had of ravaging the estate of the Pagans, thereby to render
his revenge the more memorable; and resolved by break of day to depart for
Greece: ordering Alastraxerea to go unto Trebisond, Don Rogell into Persia,
Spheramond into the Empire of Parthia, Lucendus into France, Dorigell into the
Fortunate Islands, the King Gadart into the Island Megera, Anaxander, Florador,
Melindo, Olidor, Ginoldan, Amanio d'Astre, for their kingdoms, and the rest
whither fortune called them. But fearing lest some new war might break
forth after his departure, he left the moiety of his troops with those, whose
Provinces were surrounded with the Pagans estates, that they might not be
surprised with any new garboyle, and also might preserve the Countries they had
gotten. Matters being thus disposed, they attended the next rising Sun, which
presented to them no less wonder then the day before had done: for that vast
and stately edifice, wherein all those Kings, Princes, and Emperors, were
enclosed, appeared no more, nor was there any thing seen in the place thereof,
but only the plain ground, as it was before the battle. This second loss
had afflicted them, for they receyved no mean consolation in seeing their
parents interred with so much glory, but straightway considered that this was
some new device of that Magician, who had written unto them, they were no whit
dismayed; and taking it for a good testimony of his love to them in that he had
not left those bodies in the midst of so many enemies, they prepared for
their departure with the less grief. The time then of their remoove being
come, all those troops began to march several ways. For Spheramond,
Dorigell, Sylvan, Amanio d'Astre, and the fair Savage, took a way far
different from that, which the others had, determining to spend some time in
seeking adventures abroad. The beauteous Savage seeing her self alone, renewed
her sorrow for the loss of her husband, whilst Silvan traveled with no less
discontent for that of his fair Licinia, of whose death he had heard; and that
Spheramond, Amanio d'Astre, and Dorigell lamented so great a disaster, although
the glorious death of their kinsmen did yield them some comfort. Having thus
passed two or three days without meeting any adventure worthy their
undertaking, Spheramond about the time that the Sun was in the midst of his
course, felt himself so drowsy, that he was constrained to lie down to
sleep, commanding his Squire to let their horses graze. The extreme pains
that before he had taken, and the delicacy of the place, made his rest so
pleasing unto him, as he did not wake till night, nor would peradventure have
done till the next day, if the noise of a Chariot passing by him, had not made
him to rise in all haste; he was about to have called his Squire for to bridle
his horse, but the voice of one that lamented, stayed him for to learn the
cause thereof. Listening then attentively, and looking that way the voice came,
he saw a Chariot pass by him drawn with six great horses, wherein sat three
dreadful Giants, every one of them holding a Lady in his arms; two of the
which seemed to be rather dead then alive; and the third was she that made
those cries and lamentations which he had heard. Just Heaven, said she, will
you not send some succor to these great though miserable Princesses? Or will
you permit them to remain in the hands of these villayns, who questionless
will without respect of their quality strive by force to rob them of what is
most dear unto them? O God! what a loss will Christendom receyve? And you,
brave Princes, how much will it grieve you to hear of this disaster? I lament
your misfortune as much as the death they are going to suffer. This voice being
lost in the air, left nodesse pity then anger in the mind of this Prince: For
finding by this speech that they were Christians of eminent quality, and
thinking also that he had been acquaynted with the sound of that voice, he was
moved with an extreme desire to succor them: So calling his Squire, he made
his horse to be brought him; and quickly mounting upon him, he galloped the
same way that he saw the Chariot take, hoping to reach those Giants in a little
time, and to fight with them at any rate whatsoever. But the night was so
dark, that not knowing which way he took, he entered into a Forest, where
the first that he met with, was a reverend old man, holding a torch in his
hand, who taking his horse by the bridle, said unto him: Valiant Prince, be
not offended if I take the liberty to stay you at this present; For desiring
your safety, as much as my own welfare, I cannot let you pass without
advertising you, that you are infallibly lost, if you ob^^inately pursue the
design you have in hand, and light upon those this night whom you now are
following: The day will be more fit for your purpose, then this darkness:
and patience alone is that must procure you what you now so earnestly wish for:
Enquire not what I am, nor why I meddle thus with youraffayres. It is not yet
time that you should know me, nor that you should thoroughly understand my
intentions, as I do your thoughts. Only alight, and go into this Tent, that
you see here; and tarry for day light to finish your enterprise, which is of
more importance then yet you conceive. I do not know, answered Spheramond,
(somewhat wondering to meet that man in such a place, and at so unseasonable an
hour) how you can be obliged to wish and seek my good, with so much
demonstration of friendship, since I do not remember that ever I saw you
before: But happen what may, I will gladly obey you, my necessity and the time
also advising me thereunto: Thus speaking he alighted, leaving his horse with a
little Dwarf who was there as of purpose, and entered the Tent, which he
thought was the fairest that ever he had seen. Without doubt, said he then,
you love me not a little, that have provided me so magnificent a lodging: for I
did not expect to be so well accommodated to night: But believe it, you shall
not find me ungrateful, if you please to make use of me. Saying so, he went to
embrace this man, but he was no more to be seen: whereat he was somewhat
amazed, yet supposing all this to be done by enchantment, he began to survey
the Tent, and found in one of the corners of it, a Table covered with plenty of
delicate meat, which so whetted his stomach, that he sat him down to
supper; where having well assuaged his hunger, he walked about the Tent, and
finding a bed ready made he laid him down upon it, and fell into so sound a
sleep, that the sun was of a good height before he awaked; and then being
much amazed to find himself armed with new and excellent Arms, his Squire
snoring at his feet, and neither Wood nor Tent to be seen, but a plain, so
large as it could not limit his view: howbeit his wonder ceasing by the
remembrance of such like encounters, when as he was a Knight errant, he jogd
his Squire to waken him. And having not forgotten the adventure that he met
with the night before, nor the discourse of the old man, he quickly got to
horse, and took the first way he lighted upon, wherein he rode till Sun
setting, when as he perceived a Castle before him garnished with twelve
towers, so fair and strong that it was impossible to better them: this
curiosity inviting him to view this building nearer hand he approached to it,
and going about it he was so attentive in observing it, as he could hardly
give over. But seeing night now come on, he took the hammer of the gate, and
knocked very hard: At the noise whereof a Giant appeared upon the Battlements,
who with a hoarse and dreadful voice said unto him: Withdraw thy self,
wretched creature, and come not hither to seek that which all men else are
afraid to find: the gate may not be opened this night, for so are we
commanded, what ever occasion shall fall out; but if thou will tarry till
tomorrow, I will be content to hear what thou have to say: Therewith he
retired himself leaving Spheramond ill satisfied with that his arrogant
behavior. Nevertheless, not being able to quit his longing to know what was
within the Castle, he fell off to certain trees, that were not far off from
it: and commanding his Squire to discharge the part of a careful Sentinel,
with much ado he fell on sleep.

CHAP. V. What happened to the Princes Dorigell, Silvan, and Amanio d'Astre.
DOrigell and Silvan having taken almost one and the same way entertained
themselves with diverse thoughts; the one meditated upon the loss of his
dearest half, and the other on the absence of the fair Cilinda, his wife, to
whom he had left the command of his troops, and the government of his
Kingdom. They were two days without lighting on any adventure, at the end
whereof Dorigell entering into a great field met with a Dwarf mounted upon the
bravest horse that ever he had seen: but himself so misshapen and ill
favored, that he wondered how nature could produce a rational creature with
so much deformity: He was about to question him concerning the occasion of his
journey, but the Dwarf prevented him: For drawing near and saluting him in a
more graceful manner, then he expected, he said unto him; Knight, I marvel
much to see you ride alone through these Launds, which are commonly called The
Fearful, in regard of the strange adventures which do happen daily, by reason
of a Castle situate in the midst of them, belonging to an old Sorceresse,
who does entrap all the Knights that pass this way, finding means to entice
them to her house, where all their valor will not serve to free them from
captivity, if they be not slain in fight. For to that end she keeps there
twelve Giants of a monstrous stature, and so strong withal, as they alone are
able to defeat the mightiest Emperor of the World; You shall therefore, if you
please, bend your course some other way, and not tempt Fortune: For it is no
less honor to eschew with discretion an unresistable danger, then being
engaged to fight courageously. Dorigell more delighted with the discourse then
with the person of this gallant, answered him, Thy counsel might indeed be
useful to me, if I had less respect to my honor, then my life; but do
thou not know that worthy Knights must never recuile for any consideration of
danger whatsoever: that glory is not to be found but in the most difficult
enterprises; and that victory is then most honorable, when it is purchased
with blood. I will therefore follow this way, since fortune has put me into it:
but yet before I part with you, I would entreat you to inform me more
particularly concerning this Castle; and why this Enchantresse does live
there, to work so much mischief to Knights that have not wronged her. You
could not, replyde he, have addressed your self better then to me, at the
least to be satisfied in your curiosity; For I do belong to a man, who is no
less a friend to brave Knights, then this woman their enemy, and one whose
knowledge is as much as hers: She is sister to the King of the Frozen Islands,
that was slain in the late and memorable battle of Aleppo, where all the
Pagan Kings ended their lives, except him of Pentapoly, who saved himself with
six thousand men, which were under his command, for the guard of the Camp.
The desire she has always had to ruin the Christians, causing her often to
turn over her Magical books (in which she is very expert) she foresaw the
general defeature of the Pagans, that should unite themselves for that war;
And for that reason would have diverted her brother from it, assuring him of
his death, if he should be present there: but he preferring an honorable end
before the ill report that otherwise he should have incurred by absenting
himself from thence, would needs make one in that expedition, and was there
slain, as I have related: which did so inrage this old Sorceresse, that she
withdrew her self to these Launds, where by Enchantment she built this Castle:
and for the guard thereof drew hither twelve of the mightiest Giants in the
world; who, without regard to any laws of Chivalry, do all of them commonly
fall upon any one man that presents himself, if the first that encounters him
be not able to defeat him: hoping to surprise in their passing this way some of
those famous Knights of Greece, and with a thousand tortures which she means
to make them suffer, in some sort to mitigate the grief she feels for the
loss of the King her brother. Judge now, I pray you, whether my advice do not
concern you, and whether it be not a good testimony of my love, in desiring
you to retire out of these parts, where you can meet with nothing but
mischief. Thou have, said Dorigell, so fully satisfied me, that I will
confess my self much obliged unto thee for thy labor. Thy counsel I
acknowledge for very good, but yet me thinks my reasons against it are much
better: so that I am resolved to pass on, and see what the heavens have
preordained for me. Speaking thus, he would have put his horse forward, but the
Dwarf taking him by the bridle said, Stay a little, Sir Knight, and permit me
to speak a few words unto you; He that appointed me to be here now, has
commanded me to present you with this horse, and the shield which you see
hanging at my saddle bow, assuring you that you will have occasion to use them
in an extreme necessity. Saying so, he vanished away, leaving the horse and
shield with Dorigell: who not more wondering, then pleased with so brave a
present, gave his own to his Squire; and mounting upon his new horse, found him
upon managing, so ready and light, that he liked him much better then he did
before. Following then his way he rendered many thanks in his heart to him that
had so deeply obliged him: but we will let him go with this sense of the
courtesy done him, and return to Silvan amidst his sorrowful meditations. This
young Knight perpetually thinking on his Licinia, whom death had untimely
ravished from him, was even lost in the anguish of his mind, when as he heard
the voice of one that cried for help: whereupon he turned head, and galloping
mainely away, he came to certain trees, to one of the which he saw a handsome
woman bound with cords, and a young Squire of a promising presence, that held
his sword at her throat to make her confess the truth of something which he
desired to wring out of her. Verily, said he then, speaking to the Squire,
Nature forgot her self when she framed you with any kind of perfection, since
you have so little courtesy in you: Why do you so ill entreat one of those whom
we are all bound to protect? withdraw your self, I say, for believe it if you
were a Knight, I would punish you for so great a villainy. I would, answered the
Squire without being at all dismayed, you had known the mischievous disposition
of this woman, before you had been so moved as you are; for then, Sir Knight,
you would not so readily have engaged your self in her defense. I met with her
this morning, and having conversed a while with her, I perceived by her carriage
that the little beauty Nature has bestowed upon me, had wrought some
alteration in her, wherewith I must confess I was well enough pleased: Not
that I found any thing in her which gave me the least satisfaction, but that
from her love I gathered a testimony of some merit in my self: Our discourse at
the first was ordinary, but as her passion transported her, she at length could
not conceal her damnable intentions, but confessed freely to me that she was
upon her way only to wait for some Knight of quality, for to bring him to be
butchered at the Castle of the Towers, where a thousand sorts of cruelties are
daily practiced. I am a friend to virtue, and would with the hazard of my life
preserve a worthy Knight, so that desiring to prevent her wicked purposes, I
bound her as you see, with a resolution to make an end of her, which I had
certainly done: for the point of my sword having forced her to confess that
her principal plot was upon the Princes of Greece, whose virtue all the world
loves and admires: I determined to let her breath no longer then would serve to
recommend her soul into the hands of heaven: you may now dispose of her as you
please; but I advise you to look well to your self, and consider that you
shall be guilty of all the mischiefs that ever she shall hereafter commit,
since you give her her life, which for her treacheries she justly deserves to
lose. With that immediately mounting on his horse he departed, leaving Silvan
somewhat perplexed: for his reasons seemed so good, and with such appearance of
truth, that he was about to pass on, and leave the Wench in the estate he
found her: But being moved with her tears, and not able to persuade himself,
that so fair a creature could be possessed with so much malice, he commanded
his Squire to unbind her: and forgetting the advice of him that but then parted
from them, he began to comfort her, in stead of representing her vice unto her.
I will never believe, said he unto her, that a woman e^dued with so many
beauties, can be so wicked as was but now reported unto me. Wherefore give over
afflicting your self, and tell me truly the cause why this Squire entreated
you in that fashion. Not to dissemble, said she, this cunning was but too well
disguised. For according to the report of the base villain made of me, you
have reason not to trust me, and to believe that I am the falsest woman in the
world: but the matter is quite otherwise then he has delivered: for as soon as
he saw me, he protested that he was extremely enamored of me; and not being
able (as he swore) to endure the violence of his passion, he besought me to
receive him into my favor, and to afford him some more particular grace; which
having refused him, he took me from my horse, and notwithstanding all my best
resistance, bound me as you saw, threatening to kill me if I did not grant his
desire, whereunto without doubt, I should at the last have yielded, not having
courage enough to suffer death, if you had tarried any whit longer. Behold,
noble Knight, the truth of this affair, which I have freely and simply
delivered unto you, hoping that you will not do a courtesy to halfes, and leave
me without assistance in a Country so dangerous, where I travel without any
acquaintance by the command of a Lady, that is ready to perish for the love of
a brave Christian Knight whom I may not name: having so vowed at my departure
for the reputation of her that emploies me. What cannot the persuasions of a
villainous woman effect? Silvan tasting this discourse far otherwise then was
for his behoof, was so taken with the fair pretext of her reasons, that
casting away the ill conceit he had of her, he determined to accompany her till
she were in some place of safety; So causing her to be set on horseback, he
went along with her toward the dangerous Castle, where questionless he had
been lost, if heaven that took a particular care of him, had not miraculously
diverted the mischief that hung over his head. In the mean time, the gentle
Amanio d'Astre followed somewhat a different way from that of Silvan, being no
less busied with his unquiet thoughts: but he was driven out of his dumps by a
Dwarf, who taking his horse by, the bridle turned him aside, and giving him a
jerk with a wand, said; Knight, take this way, I pray you, and let not the
night stay you: for your retardment would be the cause of perpetual sorrow to
you. Saying so he passed on, leaving Amanio infinitely amazed with this speech,
whereof he would gladly have known the meaning, but finding no means to be
satisfied therein, for that the Dwarf was no longer appearing, he put on his
horse with more haste then before; resolving not to discontinue his travel
till he might see what the end of this adventure would be.

CHAP. VI. The Emperor Spheramond being in extreme danger, i^ relieved by
certain Knights.
SPheramond, not able to rest by reason of the choler wherinto the arrogance of
the Giant had put him, rose as soon as he saw the day appear: and having made
himself ready to fight, drew to the gate where he knocked with more violence
then he had done the evening before, which caused him that already had spoken
to him to look out at a window, and with an audacious tone to say unto him:
Wretched Knight, I thought that sleep and the night would have settled thy
brain; But since thou will needs lose thy self out of humor, do but stay till
I am armed, and I will quickly cure thee of thy madness: with that he angerly
clapped to the window, and shortly after sallied out with so furious a
countenance, as had been sufficient to have affrighted any one less assured
then this Prince, who seeing him come on horseback, with a Lance like a mast of
a ship in his hand, took as much of the field as was necessary for his course,
and encountered him with such fury as having pierced his shield, he made him
with a dangerous wound in his side ^lie over the crupper of his horse: but his
own fortune was not much better; for constrained he was to kiss the earth, as
well as the Giant, not being able to bear the violence of that shock, yet
remembering that he was not laid there to sleep, he quickly got up, and bravely
laying hold on his sword he drew to the enemy; who found himself so astonished
with his fall, as he was not able to stir: whereupon Spheramond was going to
present his sword to his throat for to make him yield up the victory unto him;
but hearing a great noise at the gate, he turned about his head, and instantly
saw two other monsters, like him that he had overthrown, come running toward
him with their Cymitars in their hands, and threatening him with no less then
the loss of his life: This object somewhat troubled him, but immediately
resolving himself, he sheathed his sword in the body of his first man, who was
striving to get up, and straightway mounting on his horse the better and more
easily to defend himself, he made toward them, but they were by that time so
near unto him, as he was constrained rather to think of warding their blows,
then offending them. For the one of them laid upon his shield, and the other
upon his cask with such violence, as but for the goodness of his new arms,
his life had then been at its period: nevertheless he was not much dismayed,
yet thinking that such violent incounters might at length be attended with
death, he resolved to fight with judgment, and to stand careful upon his
guard; making them therefore spend the most part of their blows in vain, he
took so good choice of his times, as he often drew blood of them, not giving a
blow which pierced not the flesh, and put them in doubt of their lives: whereat
they were so enraged, as in stead of striking on his arms, they hewed the
stones in pieces, and filled the ground about them full of clefts. Whilst
their fury did thus transport them, the Emperor not willing to let slip any
occasion that presented it self, took his time when as one of them stooped to
pull his Courtelasse out of the earth, whereinto he had sunk it three foot
deep, and hit him with a reverse so just upon the neck, that he laid his great
head at his feet; leaving his companion much amazed to see himself alone,
covered with blood and wounds, and with little or no power to defend himself
any longer, howbeit he recovered some heart with the sight of three other
Giants, that came out of the same Castle; who having encompast his enemy, began
to charge him with such fury, that not being able to ward so many blows which
bruised his bones, he thought that he must needs fall under such an oppressing
violence, but resolving to sell his life at a dear rate, he defended himself
with such courage, and charged them with such force, that he grievously wounded
two of them, when as the third gave him so insupportable a blow on his helmet,
that he laid him quite void of sense on the crupper of his horse, voiding blood
in abundance at his nose and ears. The Giant, proud of his fortune, followed
him with his sword advanced for to finish the work, when as a great Knight
arriving in the instant charged his Lance against him, and running it clean
through his body tumbled him dead upon the ground. Spheramond who while this
was a doing, had some leisure a little to recover his spirits, seeing himself
so opportunely seconded, clasped his sword fast in his hand, and with an
infinite rage for having been reduced into that estate, he let it descend with
such force upon the first Giant, that he divided his head in twain, just at
such time as he which came to his succor, having dispatched the other against
whom he was opposed, taking a new Lance from his Squire, turned himself
gallantly to receive thirty Knights, that sallied out of the Castle, under the
conduct of three dreadful Giants, who made such a noise as the earth seemed to
tremble under them. The courage of these Knights increasing with the difficulty
of enterprises, Spheramond carried with extraordinard fury addressed himself to
one of the Giants, and discharged a blow upon his arm, with such force as he
sent it together with his sword to the ground. That done, falling in amidst
those Knights, he killed the two first that presented themselves before him. On
the other side, the black Knight (so was he called that sided with him) made
the Giant whom he encountered lose his stirrup, and dealt such blows amongst the
rest, as he laid three of them at his f^^^: but the two remaining Giants held
them so short, that with the assistance of those rascals, which would not
suffer them so much as to breath, they had been in extreme danger of their
lives, if two Knights had not at one time arrived there by several ways, who
seeing a fight managed with so much unequality, presently laid hands on their
swords, and attaching the Giants that exceedingly molested the Princes, charged
them with such furious blows, that they were fain to turn head for to defend
themselves, leaving Spheramond and his companion amidst their other Knights; of
whom they made so great a slaughter, that there remained but two of them alive,
who fearing to lose their lives as their companions had done, threw away their
weapons and craved mercy. You shall (said Spheramond) have it granted you, upon
condition that you put us in possession of this Castle. You may, said they,
enter it freely, and without fear, For you shall find no body there to resist
you, so as Argenea the Mistress of the place, does not frame some new
enchantment to make you purchase it with more danger and pain: howbeit I can
assure you that she is not now in the Castle, she having gone from thence not
long since, (as I conjecture) to find some means from hindering it to be taken.
For her spirits (without) letting her know the time) had advertised her of the
misfortune that has this day befallen us: you may therefore boldly enter in,
and your best course will be first to seize upon the ports for your more
security. This counsel seeming good to the Knights, the black Knight staid at
the gate, *whilst Spheramond searched all about the house. But finding
nothing, he returned presently to view the combat between the two Knights and
the Giants, which continued with so much fury, that it was not easy to
determine what the issue of it was like to be. But ere long they perceived the
advantage on their side that came last. For their enemies had lost so much
blood, as they fell both almost at one instant so weak, that there was no need
of any weapon to make an end of them. Spheramond extremely satisfied with this
victory, lifted up the vizier of his helmet and addressing himself to the
Knight that had first succored him: Valiant Sir, said he, You have so
infinitely obliged me, as I cannot doubt of your affection to me: but to render
the pleasure of your assistance and my preservation accomplished, tell me who
you are, that in recompense thereof, I may hereafter seek out occasions to be
commanded by you. Excellent Prince, answered the black Knight, discovering his
face, I will never acknowledge that you are any way engaged to my arms, in the
least obligation: For your valor alone was able to defeat your enemies without
my aid, yet I cannot but give humble thanks unto heaven for bringing me hither
so opportunely to testify the desire I have to do you service; I am your most
humble servant Dorigell, Prince of the Fortunate Island, and more contented for
meeting you here at this time, then I could have been for the conquest of any
enemies Empire. With these words they embraced, as if they had not been
together in a long time before: and were about to draw toward the other two
Knights to give them thanks for their succors; when as they who knew them,
came to them with all demonstrations of respect: My Lords, said they, give us
leave to kiss your victorious hands, as those which will ever depend upon you:
You see here Amanio d'Astre and Silvan, brought hither by most strange means,
but exceeding happy in that our arrival has not been altogether unusefull to
you. Then unlacing their helmets they would have humbled themselves to
Spheramond, but he embraced them with such expressions of love, as more could
not be. The entertainment of these fowr Knights having lasted a while, they all
entered the Castle: and having shut the gates, they were conducted by the two
Knights whom they had saved to the prisons, from whence they enlarged thirty or
forty Knights; amongst the which were Parmenian of Cyprus, and Ladazan of
Numidia, who determining to seek adventures abroad, had left the Army the
evening before their dislodging: and as their fortune directed them, met near
the Castle of the twelve Towrs; where they were surprised by two of the Giants,
who having astonished them with two blows, enclosed them in a Dungeon, with an
intention ere long to sacrifice them to their Gods, in satisfaction of
Argeneaes revenge. The content of these Princes was not small, in having thus
delivered two of their friends; nor did they take care for any thing more, then
how to find out some one that could dress their wounds. For Dorigell was hurt
in three places, Spheramond very much bruised with the blows he had received
(the goodness of his arms having arrested the edge of his enemies swords,) and
Amanio d'Astre had a slash on his shoulder nothing so dangerous as great; but
instantly they had word brought them, that at the gate there was a Dwarf who
desired to speak with them: Let him in, said Spheramond, his presence will not
affright us; only have a care that he be not followed by any other. For the two
Knights we spared have assured me, that three of the guard of this Castle are
yet abroad, and that it is likely they will return this evening. The Sentinel
then perceiving no body but the Dwarf opened the gate, and from thence he was
brought to the Princes, where at first addressing himself to Dorigell he said,
Do you know me, Sir Knight? Yes truly, said Dorigell, you gave me yesterday the
best horse and the bravest shield in the world; for which courtesy you may ask
of me what you please: and be assured you shall not be refused in any thing
that lies in my power. I do not come hither, answered he, to request any reward
for my service, but to do you some more: Go, I pray you presently to bed,
together with these Princes that are hurt, and I will dress you. For knowing
that your wounds would extremely incommodate you without looking to, I am come
to cure you. You have already done so much for me, said Dorigel, that I will
not now refuse your assistance, neither for my self nor my friends. Making then
three beds to be set up in one Chamber, that the time might seem the less
tedious unto them, they went to bed and were dressed by this Dwarf, who enjoining
them to rest till the morning, went out with Silvan that took upon him the
charge of the Castle, appointing Parmenian of Cyprus, and Ladazan of Numidia,
to keep the watch with twelve Knights for fear of being surprised. But little
need there was of that care; for the day came on and nothing appeared to
disturb them. Now were all these Princes ris^n, as whole and sound as if they
had not been hurt at all the evening before, and much wondering they could not
see their Chyrurgian that was not any more to be found, when as the Sentinel
brought them word that he saw a Chariot come almost to the gate, wherein were
three Giants, and three Ladies, who filled the air with sighs and lamentations:
but that withal there appeared a brave and able Knight that made no difficulty
to set on the Giants, for the relief of those afflicted women. Thereat the
Princes called for their arms, fearing lest that Knight should not be able to
withstand the fury of those monsters: and therefore made all the haste they
possible could. The young Silvan who was first ready, knowing the Giants to be
on foot, went out only with his sword in his hand, wherewith he entertained his
enemies in so rude a fashion, aided by the valiant Emperor of the Parthians,
that followed him, as he made them not only despair of the victory, but stand
in fear of a near approaching death. The Knight whom before they had circled
about, seeing himself so well and beyond his hope seconded, did so gallantly
bestir himself, and charged him that opposed him, with such fury, as the grass
round about him was died with his blood. In like sort, Silvan entreated his
man, and Spheramond gave his enemy not so much leisure as to breath; but the
honor of this combat was so well disputed with them, as they could not vaunt
to have lent any thing but upon very good pawns. He that fought with the first
Knight, despaired of his safety, and defying heaven for being so ill entreated
by one man alone, took his curtelax in both his hands, and discharged so
violent a blow on his adversaries helmet, that he laid him in the dust
altogether deprived of sense. That blow naving given him some hope of victory,
he was going to disarm him, but having in that rage and straining of himself,
spent all his blood and strength, he reeling tumbled down on the other side
with apparent signs of death. Spheramond that had observed the misfortune of
the Knight who^ he thought to be dead, was so transported with choler, that
griping his sword fast in his hand he made it descend with such fury on the
cask of his enemy, as dividing it together with his head in two pieces, he laid
him stark dead upon the earth. Thence presently flying to the Knight, that lay
extended by the slain Giant, he unlaced his helmet, to see if he yet breathed,
and found it was the beauteous Savage, who feeling the freshnes of the air,
immediately opened her eyes: His amazement to see her there, was no less then
his content to find her with some remainder of life; but thinking that she
stood in more need of succor then of complement, he went about to help her up,
when as remembering the combat she had begun, she rose with such force and
agility as made them all to wonder that beheld her; and laying hold of her
sword that was fastened to her arm, she was going to fall furiously on the Giant
that fought with Silvan; but she saw him sink under a terrible blow which he
gave him. I am, said she then, fully revenged of my enemies: but yet I desire
to know unto whom I am indebted for this assistance. To your own virtue, said
Spheramond, which had no great need of our arms. God, said she, What do I see?
and what strange encounter is this? Tell me, my Lord, what good fortune brought
you hither? What Knights are these in your company? and what have your
adventures been these three days? Even such, answered Spheramond, as those
that have rendered you here; we arrived here without any particular design, and
have rooted out of this Country a crew of mischievous fellows: but that which
gives me the most content is, that we fell upon this place so happily for your
safety, and the increase of our glory. These that you see here with me are at
your disposing. Here is Silvan, who showed himself the most forward to do you
service, being the first that sallied forth to your succor. This is Dorigell,
Prince of the Fortunate Island: the third is Amanio d'Astre; and these two
Knights are Parmenian of Cyprus and Ladazan of Numidia, whom we have freed out
of prison. Then he told her all the circumstances of his coming thither, his
combat, and how without the assistance of those brave Princes, he had
infallibly lost his life. This discourse having persuaded them, that all those
occurrences had fallen out by the providence of some Magician their friend, she
was about after she had infinitely caressed those Knights to enter the Castle;
but remembering the women in favor of whom she had undertaken the combat,
although she know not who they were, she desired Parmenian and Ladazan to go
and seek them out; for she had observed that at the beginning of the fight they
fled away from that place: This they undertook most willingly, and did
discharge it so happily, as the same day they returned with unspeakable content
of all the company, as shall be related to you in the Chapter following.

CHAP. VII. Who th^se Princesses were that were f^rcibly carried away by the
Giants: as also the Emperor Spheramonds return into Parthia.
WE have in the preceding Chapter told you, that Argen^^ sister to the King of
the Frozen Island, foreseeing the ruin of the Pagan Princes, withdrew herself
into the borders of the Sultan of Aleppo his Country, where by enchantment she
built that proud Castle of the twelve Towrs, and for the guard thereof drew
thither twelve of the mightiest Giants in all the army, in hope by that means
to surprise some of the Greek Princes, and so to revenge her self. But God
whose providence reaches to every thing, overthrew all her designs, making the
Emperor Spheramond fall with that place, and after him Dorigell, Silvan, and
the gallant Knight of the Bridge, by the procurement of the great Alcander; who
desiring to prevent the mischiefs which this woman intended to Christendom,
and which without all doubt had happened in the loss of Spheramond, did
provide that Dorigell should be met withal by a Dwarf, the Knight of the
Bridge by a Squire, and Silvan by a Damsel, to the end they might be conducted
thither to succor that great Emperor. It remains now that we relate unto you
the new design she had to render her malice the more memorable: As soon as
the building was brought to perfection, she took her books, wherewith she often
entertained her self, and straining her skill to the highest pitch, she found
that the Empress Richarda, and the Princess Rosaliana, her sister, were with
child with two sons, who one day should be the support of Christendom, and
the ruin of Paganism; which did so vex her, as she resolved to destroy them
before they should come into the world: Having sought out then from among the
cunningest of her thoughts, for some subtle invention to bring her desires to
pass, she departed with three of her Giants a little before those two great
Armies came to meet, and embarked her self in a ship, which by the guiding of
three Dwarffes, she caused to sail so shiftly, that in two days she was in the
Empire of Parthia at the foot of a Castle by the Sea side, where by chance the
Empress Richarda with her sister were at that time, to find some diversion
from the grief they were in for the absence of their Husbands: Being arrived at
her desired ^^ort, she made certain Characters upon the poop of her Bark; and
redo^bling her charms, she enchanted her Giants that she carried with her in
such sort, as they appeared in the shape of Spheramond, Amadis d' Astre, and
the Duke of Arbamont; that done, she disarmed their heads, caused them to show
themselves upon the hatches, and commanding two of her Dwarfs to sound a
fanfara to awake the Princesses, she sent the third well instructed with his
message, to advertise them of the return of those Princes. Upon the noise of
the trumpets the Ladies looked out at the window that opened to the sea, with a
great desire to know what the business might be: but unable at that distance
to discern the countenance of these transformed people, they did with some
delight lend an ear to the Music, that seemed to presage some good fortune
unto them: and whilst they thus suffered their souls to be drawn out at their
ears, a damsel came to enform them, that there was a Dwarf desired admittance,
to advertise them of some affair which nearly concerned them: whereupon having
commanded him to be brought in, they withdrew from the window to understand
what the Dwarf would say unto them; who being too well taught for to fail
Argenea in her design, presented himself with much respect: and having made an
humble obeisance with a cheerful countenance he said to the Empress Richard^:
Madam, what will you give me for the contentment which my coming will bring
you? The Emperor Spheramond with his cousin Amadis d' Astre, is at the foot of
this Castle: but because they have in their company a beautiful Princess whom
they chanced to meet with at sea, that will not land this evening, in regard
she desires to visit you to morrow with the more magnificence, they humbly
beseech you not to be displeased with their retardment in saluting you, since
it is against their wills and only to discharge themselves of the promise they
have made to this Lady. They have reason to keep their word, answered Richarda,
who was transported with joy and content; no^ will I render them perjured by
commanding them to come hither. But let me not live if I go not my self to
visit them, though for a penance I serve in the morning to glorify the triumph
of this foreign Beauty they bring with them. Having then caused their horses to
be brought, she went down to the haven accompanied only with her sister, and
one maid, where seeing the lovely face of her Husband, she could not without
some trouble bear the little delay which she was forced to endure, before she
could be set aboard the ship; into the which she was with her company no sooner
entered but the Giants reassumed their former shapes, which did so amaze them,
that with grief to find themselves so woefully abused, they fell down more then
half dead upon the deck; Argenea seeing that which she so much desired in her
power, immediately covered the ship with a cloud, took her way back again with
the same speed she had made thither, and landed at the same port from whence
she had weighed ancor not above five days before. But her house being ten
leagues from thence, she presently caused a Chariot to appear, drawn by six
horses of a monstrous greatness; and having found by her last incantations she
was threatened with a terrible mischief, she willed her Giants to pass on and
to bestow the Ladies in safe custody, whilst she went to consult with a great
Magician, with whom she had formerly been very conversant, to the end that by
the help of his skill she might divert the storm which was ready to fall upon
her; yet all her devices were to no purpose: for Alcander (to whose knowledge
all other mortal men's gave place) having foreseen the mischievous intentions
of this Hagg, had first turned the Chariot somewhat out of the right way to make
it come within the view of Spheramond, to whom also he gave the same day those
excellent arms, by means whereof he escaped death, which was otherwise
inevitable, being to fight with three or fowr of the most able Giants in the
world, all at one instant, assembled all those Princes who had been separated
from the Army into that one place being assured that Spheramond would at length
be unable to resist so many Knights as were to combat him together. These then
were the Princesses which he saw pass by when overtaken with the night, he was
sleeping under the trees, and the very same that were brought to the Castle of
the twelve Towrs, by the Giants, when as those Princes sallied forth to second
the fair Savage, who having met the Chariot followed the Giants to fight with
them, being moved with pity at the lamentations of those Ladies. But it is
time to return to our former Discourse of Parmenian of Cyprus and Ladazan
finding these Princesses under a tree who trembled with fear, alighted from
their horses, and putting off their helmets, that the Ladies might by seeing
who they were, be the better assured, they kneeled down to kiss their hands:
but they were so amazed with the encounter of them, as they were not able to
speak a word; which Parmenian observing, to restore them to themselves he said:
I cannot but much wonder (excellent Ladies) to meet you in these uninhabited
parts, and so far remooved from your own Countries. But you will be no less
amazed when I tell you, that the Emperor Spheramond is at the Castle, which
you see yonder, accompanied with certain Princes of Greece, who are merrier
then the loss they have endured might seem to permit, not knowing as yet of
your being in these quarters. Do not then I beseech you, afflict your selves
any further; those that brought you hither are dead; nor shall you find in that
house any but such as were born to do you service. At these words the
Princesses recovered a little courage, yet fearing such another treacherous
trick, as had been played them before, they made but little show of resenting
that news, and rested as it were in an ecstasy, when Ladazan, who marvailed at
that coldness of theirs thus pursued his discourse: Why how now, Ladies, are
not these news pleasing unto you? and will you not return with us to glad the
Emperor? Verily this carriage of yours does amaze me; nor can I imagine from
whence it should proceed, since all fear of danger is past. Let us go, I
beseech you, without any more delay. Well, let us go, said the Empress
Richarda, who was somewhat the heartier of the three, since you will have it so,
at the worst we can be but once more abused: with that they advanced toward the
Castle, before the gate whereof stood Spheramond with Dorigell and the rest. He
at the first sight knowing them was strangely amazed at so unexpected an
encounter. O God! said he, can I imagine or believe that my fair mistrisse is
here, or can any man persuade me that I am not in a dream? Tell me, Madam, am I
in the Parthian Empire? or is it possible that I should meet you in these
desert plains, which are not near it by three hundred leagues? Certainly I am
so confounded and besides my self, as I dare not embrace you, fearing that you
are here through some enchantment. I should have, replied she my dear heart, a
great deal more cause to be astonished beholding you here, seeing it is not
above six days since you were with me in Parthia: but you did so suddenly
change your aspect, that the pleasure of your sight was instantly followed with
an infinite grief for not finding you any more like unto your self; yet I do not
now wonder any longer at it, for by the way I learned that a Sorceres our enemy
had plotted this treason against us, an^ that she had framed that enchantment
