the laces of it, and made it fly from his head: whereupon there fell scattered
about his shoulders goodly tresses of hair, which declared that it was no
Knight, but a most beautiful Amazon, whose name the Knight would not receive,
though she twice presented it. Those which accompanied her, seeing her
discovered, made themselves known to the Princes of Greece, the one being
Leonidas of Mesopotamia, the other Abi^s of Ireland; and the Amazon, Altaria,
who was very kindly received by the Emperor, and particularly by the Queens of
Guindaya, France, and Lydia, who placed her amongst them after they had highly
commended her. The two Knights in the gilt armor, upon whom all men eyes were
c^st, seeing Alteri^'s combat thus ended, presently advanced, and setting spurs
to their horses, encountered them of the crown so furiously, as one would have
said, that four towers torn from their foundations, by so many whirlwinds, had
shocked together; Fortune was indifferent to them all, for they remained firm
in their seats, and passed their course with so much bravery as made the whole
assembly admire them; but the desire they had of victory, caused them suddenly
to turn head, and then taking new staves, they settled themselves to run the
second time, when as there was seen come into the place, three Knights and a
Giant, of a gallant and a warlike aspect, in the company of the Gentlewoman,
before mentioned, who addressing her self to the Knights of the Crowns, with a
very furious garb that well demonstrated how much she was displeased, thus
spoke: Discourteous Knights, I have brought these with me here, that are more
ready to do service unto Ladies then you have been, and that will revenge the
disgrace you have put upon me. In good time be it, said one of them, we shall
see what they are able to do, provided these Knights here, our opposi^es, will
give way thereunto. Wit that, not entering into further ^iscourse, they made a
sign to their adversaries to prepare themselves, and dislodged at one instant
with such fury, as not able to stand so violent an encounter, they were
constrained to come all of them together to the ground: Choler, and the shame
to be overthrown, in the presence of so great Princes, having suddenly raised
them up, they courageously laid hands on their swords, to try whose the victory
should be: But the four last, that came with the Gentlewoman, advanced, and
interposing between them, said: That they were not to proceed any further,
since the conditions of the justs did forbid the combat with the sword, so long
as there remain any in the place on horsback: whereupon, the Judges being
called, their reasons were approved of, as very just, in regard it was one of
the principal Articles thereof, expressed in these terms:

That if fortune made the encounter equal, and they were all at one time
unhorsed, they might try it out with the sword; but if at the time of their
being dismounted new comers arrived, in number equal to them, the assailants
should take new lances and siding with the maintainers, should all together
make head against the last attempters, that the first might not be defrauded of
their due honor. And that therefore the number on both sides being equal, the
Knights had reason to hinder the combat with the sword, until they had tried
themselves with the lance; it still remaining in their power, to recommence
their combat, in case the last comers were overthrown, but otherwise not. The
Knights in the gilt arms, not desiring to show themselves refractory, since the
Judges would have it so, ranked themselves with those of the Crowns, who took
fresh horses, conceiving by the countenance of their adversaries, that they had
a hard party to deal withal; and placing themselves over against them,
attended the sound of the trumpet for their dislodging. Whilst the questions
were deciding, Alteria, observing those which came last in, knew them for the
same, that had delivered her out of the power of Argenea (as indeed they were
Fulgoran, Prigmaleon, the unknown Knight, and Grandimore, who arriving in
Greece, as I told you in the former Chapter, were drawn to Constantinople upon
the report of the triumphs there proclaimed:) So that turning to Don Rogel, who
sat not far from her, she said to him: Believe it, Sir, you will by and by
receive much contentment in the sight of these eight Knights combat; for if
those two of the Crowns have hitherto rendered themselves remarkable, they in
the gray and black armor are excellent in the supremest degree, and few their
equals are to be found in the world: By their valor the dangerous guards of
the Castle of Argenea were vanquished, and these two younger Princes, with my
self, delivered from a prison, where we certainly believed to find our graves;
but since the trumpets now begin to sound, you will quickly see the proof of my
words. Don Rogell then turning his eye about to the lists, saw them begin their
course at one instant, and meet in the midst of it with such fury, as the earth
seemed to tremble under them; their fortune was equal, for they all lost their
saddles, the unknown Knight remaining wounded by the lance of one of the
Knights of the Crowns, and one of them in the gilt armor by that of the Giant
Grandimore: The shame to see themselves dismounted in the presence of so many
excellent Princes, having suddenly raised them, they began one of the most
furious combats that ever was beheld. Nothing appeared but sparks of fire in
the air, and cantles of armor and shields on the ground. If Fulgoran and
Prigmaleon charged with violence, they felt themselves so closely followed, as
they wondered at the valor of their enemies; nothing was to be heard but
horrible blows, one part laid on load, another was forced to set their knees to
the ground: In brief, this sight might truly be termed the most furious that
ever had been seen between eight persons. Prigmaleon, who had one of those of
the gilt arms to deal with, being mad at the resistance he found from him, let
his sword descend with such rage on his helmet, as he made him recoil two or
three paces with the sight of a million of stars at midday; but he had not time
to glory much of that advantage, for his adversary recovering his spirits, came
and charged him with such force, as his shield being divided in two pieces, the
sword fell so heavy on his shoulder, that he was fain to set one knee to the
ground, to save himself from falling; but quickly getting up again, he rendered
the combat far more cruel then ever it was. In the mean time, Fulgoran and his
adversary entreated one another with the like fury; Grandimor^, and the unknown
Knight, disputed the victory with very much courage; howbeit, they were so
pressed by their opposites, as they had little leisure to think of their
consciences; nevertheless, desiring rather to die then to show any sign of
faintness, they fought two howrs without any advantage to their enemies, who
still resolving to vanquish, redoubled their blows, and so sharply followed
them, that these two Pagan Knights, after another hours combat, fell almost
both at one time to the ground, to the great content of the conquerours, who
having made them confess the victory, helped them up, and delivered them into
the hands of two Chirurgians, which Don Florisell had appointed to be ready,
for the relief of such as should chance to be wounded: The misfortune of these
two Knights, augmented the rage of Prigmaleon and Fulgoran, their blows became
more weighty then before, so as often times their enemies were forced to knock
their chins against their breasts, and to set their kn^es to the ground. But
they had so good a share in those courtesies, that every one was amazed at the
sight of so dangerous a combat, which every one thought could never be ended,
but by the ^eath of them all. And indeed they were so eager as they continued
seven hours without taking of breath, or that any one could discern any the
least sign of weariness or of advantage in them, which so madded them, as
carried by an unusual rage, they all quitted their swords, and grapled
together, hoping by mere strength to get the victory; but little prevailing
that way, they were at length constrained, after they had tumbled on the
ground, sometimes above, and another while below, to rise as by agreement, and
recommence their combat, which lasted till night, no man being able to
attribute the honor of it more to the one then the other. Don Rogell, who
infinitely admired the valor of these Knights, perceiving them obstinately
bent not to give over for all that it grew dark, caused the retreat be sounded.
But their rage not permitting them to hear it, they went on with their
business, and continued battering one another more cruelly then they had done
all the day before: so that Don Rogell was enforced to descend with Spheramond,
and entreat them to part for his sake, showing them, hat the cause of their
contention being so slight, their enmity had no reason to be so bitter; but
they lent a deaf care to all that he could say, so as at last he was
constrained to put himself between them, which so much displeased Prigmaleon,
as turning himself somewhat hastily to Don Rogell, he said in some choler: I
would fain have entreated you to have let Fortune work her will; but seeing
your authority opposes the design of those that combat before you, remember
that it shall not be able to hinder me when I shall visit you with an hundred
thousand men, to require an account of the distaste you now give me. Neither
will I, said Fulgoran, who was as much displeased, promise them better dealing:
for I will once more cover your fields with brave and warlike Soldiers.

Wherefore, Princes of Greece, receive these words for a defiance, and prepare
for a war. But that you may understand who are your enemies, this Knight is
Prigmaleon, the great Emperor of Ethiopia, whom you see in these gray Arms,
and I am the King of Canabea, by which name you cannot choose but know me. Yes,
said Don Rogel, without being any way distempered, we have cause not to be
ignorant of what you are; but it may be time will qualify this heat, and that
little you gained before our walls, perhaps will keep you from pursuing the
second design. But if you be so resolved, we have friends enough not to care
much for your Arms: yet shall not that keep me from entreating you, since it
is now dark night, to take a lodging in our Palace, until you have a little
refreshed your selves after the great toil you have this day endured. That is
ordinary with us, answered Fulgoran, so that your courtesy may well be spared;
wherewith somewhat coldly retiring, they went to their friends, who with more
despite then pain, quickly got to horse: and, notwithstanding they were
shrewdly wounded, traveled till about midnight, that they came to a Gentleman's
house; where, when they had stayed two days, they left Grandimore and the
unknown Knight to be cured of their hurts, and the morrow after they parted
with a promise of meeting at the end of two months, in Natolia, with each of
them an hundred and fifty thousand men, to be in one body transported to
Constantinople. In the mean time Don Rogel and Spheramond, who were not much
troubled with their menaces, addressed themselves to the other Knights, and with
such courtesy entreated them to let themselves be known, as they were content
to satisfy them. Having then unlaced their helmets, they let them see that
those two of the Crowns were Lucendus Prince of France, and D^rigel King of
the fortunate Island. The other in the gilt Arm^ were the valiant Russian of
Media, and the mighty Esquilan of Polonia. You may well imagine the contentment
which the Greek Princes, and especially the Infanta Fortuna, received by the
coming of these Knights, though I do not put my self to the trouble of
relating it. In sum, a thousand caresses were not for born amongst so many
friends, nor any thing forgotten which might serve for the contentment of those
Princes; who, for the present, treading all care of their more important
affairs, under foot, passed two or three days more in tourneys, and all the
delights that could be imagined. At the end whereof that happened, which in the
next Chapter shall be related.

CHAP. XXVI. The adventure of the Pyramide is ended to the honor of the brave
Russian of Media, who is known to be the son of Don Rogel, and the fair
Queen Giranda.
WHilst all things were thus disposed unto pleasure, and Florisell with the
other Princes were sitting in the Palace Hall, there entered four Lions,
carrying a Pyramide of indifferent height, and made after a strange fashion: It
was composed of two several materials, as it was divided into two stories, the
highest being of transparant Crystal, enclosed the body of a young Lady of
most excellent beauty, that seemed to sleep: The lower made of a black Marble,
suffered nothing to be seen that was within it, yet was there a gate to give
passage into it. The beasts being come, with amazement of all that were
present, into the midst of the Hall, by little and little discharged
themselves of their load, and keeping still their places, turned them toward
the company, which so affrighted them, that except the Princes, who could not
be scared, every one was about to shift for himself; when as a Damsel
presenting herself, kneeled down before Florisell, and thus spoke, Excellent
Prince, I do not think that your courage, so often tried with infinite dangers,
can be moved with this wonder which here you see: the Fortunes of men are
various and great, and seldom are they at quiet after an infinity of crosses,
The Gods did seem to promise to the Princess, whom you see enclosed in this
Crystal, unspeakable contentments: for having made her by birth a Princess,
and, as yet you may perceive, beautiful in the highest degree of excellence,
she should, me thought, have been exempted from those misfortunes that attend
our life. But alas! all these attributes of so raised a condition, have served
only to make her miserable; and this ornament of beauty has rendered her in
the estate wherein you now see her, as I will presently inform you. Her father,
a virtuous Prince, being forced to pay that debt unto nature which is due by
all men, left her under the charge of the great Emperor of Guardacia (whose
crown she might one day pretend to, if the Gods should call the 2 daughters
which he now has, and those the fai^est on the earth) and dyi^g charged her
not so much to regard the greatness, as the virtue of a valian^ husband; so
that in a while all the Country knew, that for Agriclea, so is she named, not
a rich but a worthy man is required, that could courageously conserve the
Scepter that should be put into his hands. The ^umour running not only through
the country subject to her crown, but to other kingdoms far removed, came to
the knowledge of a young Giant, an ugly man, and very debauched, who believing
(as many do often flatter themselves) that he had not his match in the world,
presented himself not long since unto her, and offered to maintain, that all
the Knights in the world came short of him in valor: This Princess (who
questionless deserves to be better bestowed) not brooking this his vanity,
somewhat coldly desired him not to tempt his fortune for her occasion. But the
Giant, having too much fancy in his brain, not admitting of that excuse,
presented himself six months together in the lists; where, to speak truth, he
purchased the esteem of a valiant person, howbeit he lost his labor: for
Agriclea, who dyed as often as she saw him triumph over his enemies, and that
could not approve of his cruelty, to the vanquished, one evening when he
troubled her with the discourse of his passions: Fulgosan, said she, for that
was his name, I know not how you can imagine that I should ever love you, since
I cannot find any thing in you that might move me unto it; what likelihood is
there that I should subject my contentment to the kisses of a man so deformed?
or that my delights should depend upon your caresses. The very thought thereof
is distastefull unto me, and if you had had any judgment all, you would have
considered the inequality of our conditions, and persons, before you had
engaged your affection: I here permitted you to combat many times for the
merit of my beauty, I confess, but I have done it rather to win you glory,
then any way to oblige my self unto you: Nor think it an argument of good
will in me toward you, because I was willing to appear courteous, you may
therefore retire your self when you please, and never st^nd on my fathers will
for that which shall always depend on my choice. It is against my mind, that I
pay your service in this sort for persuading my self that you fough not in hope
of reward, I do not present you withany. In sum my own contentment is dearer
to me then yours, nor shall my torment spring from your satisfaction. Brave
Prince, I will not insist upon informing you what rage these discreet and
modest words kindled in the breast of this proud Knight: for you may well
imagine with what impatience he heard them; but going on with my discourse,
will te^l you, that departing with strange menaces, he was seen not long
after to return, accompanied with an Aunt of his, very expert in magic, who
taking this fair Princess by the arm (no body there present being able to
succor her) placed her where at this present you behold her, using these very
words: Thou shall know, Agriclea, that the affection of one that loves, is not
to be despised, and that the difference of condition, dispenses not with the
duty of a well bred soul; thou ought to have loved my Nephew, since thy
beauty was the only sovereign of his thoughts, but having ^eene to
di^acknowledging as to recompense him with injuries, thou shall a long time
suffer that which he now indures: And for that I will not pardon him the fault
he has committed in loving thee with too much fidelity, my pleasure is that he
shall still he follow thee, that shall hear thy lamentations, ^d perpetually
upbraid thee with thy ingratitude. Thus speaking, she made him go in at the
door in the black Marble, which instantly closed of it self; and calling me,
who had always had the government of this Princess in charge: I will not,
said she, deprive you of the office that you have formerly enjoyed, and that
still you deserve, go therefore to the Courts of the greatest Princes in the
world with her, and know that you shall never see an end of your travels, nor
the re-establishment of your Mistrisse into her former estate, until The
bastard Lion be discovered in the blood of this miserable man that I have here
locked up, who shall come out to fig^t as often as any shall knock at the door
with the pummell of his sword. Saying so, she touched the Lions with a rod
which she had in her hand, and made me presently go out with them, willing me
to take no care for the way. Thus have I, excellent Prince, delivered the cause
of my coming into your dominions, where my hope is to see this Princess freed
by the hand of some one of those which render your Court the most glorious, and
the most redoubted in the world. But if it be your pleasure that the trial of
this adventure shall be made in your presence, then I humbly desire that you
will permit that I may obtain a Boon of your Knights, which notwithstanding
shall not oblige any but him that shall undo this enchantment. That shall not
hinder you, said Florisell, from finding that contentment here you desire: and
with all my heart I wish that this fair Princess may in this place meet with
an ease of all her pains; to the furtherance whereof I promise you, in the name
of all mine, that you shall not be denied your request, so as it be in our
power to perform. Hereupon all those Knights, who desired nothing but occasions
of winning honor, were to arm themselves for to begin the trial. The first
that presented himself, was the gentile Perion of Turkey, who knocking at the
Marble gate with his sword, they saw a Knight come forth all armed, not so
great as most Giants, but much exceeding the stature of most men, that setting
hand to a rich sword, advanced his shield against the fury of a blow which
Perion delivered at his head, and at the same instant charging him, made him
perceive, that his valor was extreme, so that the combat began to be both
dangerous and delightful: for if the one showed a rare agility in avoiding his
adversaries blows, the other demonstrated an excessive force. Having battered
one another then above an hour in that fashion, Perion determined to see the
game upon a cast, and with his sword in both hands, to lay upon his enemies
helmet; but he was prevented: for the Giant having discharged an horrible blow
on his head, laid him all along upon the floor, and was going to return into
his prison, when as Florian of Sopradisa advanced; who, to be short, had no
better fortune, no more had Tristor, Florestan, Quedragant, and all these new
Knights, which were all served in the same manner, after they had stood a fight
more or less, according to the proportion of their strengths. The valiant
Esquilon of Polonia would needs succed his companions in their misfortunes, but
not till after two hours fight, and with some hope of the assistants, that he
would carry away the honor of the adventure. His fall having possessed the
gallant Russian with more choler then fear, he drew to Fulgoson with his sword
drawn; whereupon they began to charge one another with such mighty blows, that
the room shook under them, pieces of armor flew about, their shields were
hewn in pieces, and the pavement sprinkled with blood, testified the valor of
the combatants; who bravely disputing for their lives, and the victory, made
all the spectators amazed at it, especially the Greek Princes, who judging
Russians manner of fight both more furious, and more pleasing then any of the
former, exceedingly desired to know him: Three howrs being past away, since the
beginning of the combat Russian grew enraged, and choosing rather to die then
not to overcome in the presence of so many excellent Princes, he delivered a
full blow upon the Giant with such violence, that it divided his body in twain,
to the infinite contentment of the Gentlewoman, and of the fair Infanta
Agriclea, who instantly recovering her spirits, and a great clap of thunder
breaking forth, just as Fulgoson fell, the Pyramid was found in a thousand
pieces, and Agriclea in the arms of her woman, who coming to Russian; Brave
warrior, said she to him, you have this day gained so much honor, as we will
speak eternally of your valor; but you know withal to what your word does
oblige you. I do, said he, ravished with the singular beauty of Agriclea, I
know that I am engaged to you for a boon, and am ready to grant it presently.
The time for it, said she, is not yet come; but you shall, if you please, one
day make good your promise, either at my entreaty, or at the command of this
Princess; with that, a new clap of thunder being heard, they saw Agriclea and
her woman, together with the body of the Giant, and the fragments of the
Pyramid taken away in a cloud, nothing remaining of them in the room, but the
blood that Fulgoson shed, upon the last blow he received; In which, as it had
been in a table of brass or marble, were written these words:

Russian of Media, the son of Rogell of Greece, and of the fair Queen Grianda.
O me! (said Spheramond, who had noted the Gentlewomans discourse, and therefore
was come to look upon that blood, imagining that it was not left there without
some mystery) What a wonder is this? And by what a strange adventure are we
acquainted with a secret of such importance? Come hither brother, said he,
offering to embrace Russian, and give me the first caresses that are due to our
neernesse in blood; you can no longer conceal your self, for your descent is
written here; and my Lord, my Father, has just cause to rejoice to see one of
his race with so much good fortune. Russian, thus suddenly surprised, kneeled
down before his father, and kissing his hands, confessed that he had determined
not to reveal that he was his son, supposing that his valor had not as yet
rendered him worthy of that glory: but since the heavens had thus discovered
him, he thought himself most happy in this adventure, and would endeavor to
honor the name that he carried. I should never have done, if I should go about
to particularize the caresses which Russian received from Florisel, from those
Princes his kinsmen, from the Queens of Guindaya, France, and Lydia, and from
all the Court; wherefore I will not stand upon it, but following my discourse
will tell you, that Russian was not more contented with the honor which he had
gained in this adventure, and with the notice that his kindred had taken of
him, then he was grieved for the departure of Agriclea, whose incomparable
beauty had made a deep impression in his heart: but hoping that time would
furnish him with occasions to see her again, he comforted himself as well as he
might, and labored to find out reasons to quiet his mind.

CHAP. XXVII. The Princes of Greece consult of the war; the mustering of
Fulgorans and Prigmaleons armies; a Damsel carries Russian of Media from
Constantinople.
WIse men forestall the time, and their prudent foresight does often times free
them from dangers. Our Princes more intentive to what concerned them in honor,
then to continue their pleasures, assembled one day together, and calling to
mind Fulgorans and Prigmaleons threats, they consulted of the means they had
to oppose the violence of their forces. Our Empires, said Florisel, as the
principal person in that counsel, are not unfurnished of good soldiers; we
have a number of brave Princes still alive, and our Courts are full of gallant
Knights; wherefore we have no great cause to be troubled with our enemies
coming, so as we take care to hasten our levies in due time; as for our selves,
I am not of opinion that we should stir from hence, since the Governors of our
Provinces, and our subjects, will not be wanting in point of obedience to all
our commands: So that the thing which does most press us for the present, is,
that to dispatch away speedily some Gentlemen, to the Lievtenants of those
countries, which are subject unto us, commanding them to raise as many men as
they may without disfurnishing the places of importance of their necessary
garrisons. This advice being approved of, as the best they might think of,
every one withdrew to expedite the business, and accordingly the same day, the
Emperor Don Rogell sent into Persia, Spheramond to the Empire of the
Parthians, Dorigell to the fortune Island, Lucendus into France, and
Alestraxerea into Tre^isond, Florisel also gave out Commissions for the Empire
of Greece, dispatched Posts to Rome, to great Britain, to Guindaya, to the
Kings of Dardania, Comagenia, India, Samothracia, Cathaya, Poland, Hungary,
Moldavia, and Scotland; and giving order for the fortifying of the Ports and
frontire towns, he rested in expectation of what the heavens would determine in
an affair of such great consequence. Whilst they were thus employed in Greece,
Fulgoran and Prigmaleon were not idle, for having parted with a resolution not
to enter any combat except extreme necessity enforced them to it, they arrived
almost at one instant, the one in the Empire of Aethiopia, and the other in the
Kingdom of Canabea, where the first things they did, was, to send to all their
neighbor Kings, to entreat that they would together with them embrace the
revenge of those outrages, which from time to time all Paganism had received
from the Emperors of Greece: Their request was without any difficulty granted,
for a multitude of Kings and Princes that had not been parties in the former
leagues, determined to join with them, utterly to exterminate the Christian
name for ever. The first that at the motion of Fulgoran arrived in Canabea,
were the great King of Mauritania, with two thousand horse, and three Giants;
the King of Canaria, with the like number of horses and Giants; those of
M^larra, and Tremiscen, with twelve thousand foot, and five Giants; those of
Zaphir, Zambar, and Carthagena, with fifteen thousand horse, and seven Giants;
those of M^loc, ^ramaza, Panonia, Aganazes, and Budomell, with thirty thousand
Archers; the Tamberlen of Moraria, the Kings of Libia, Arcania, Barbary,
Anguly, Argier, Numidia, and Carthage, with four^core thousand horse, and
thirty Giants; those of Bisancia, Marocco, Thunes, Thenery, and and Miramolin,
with fifty thousand foot; and the Kings of T^ll, and Bazana, with fifteen
thousand horse, and thirteen Giants. So that the General muster of these
troops being taken, with those which Fulgoran had rais^d in his own Kingdom,
consisting of ten thousand horse, and eighteen thousand foot, amounted to one
hundred and forty thousand horse, and an hundred and ten thousand foot,
threescore Giants, and thirty Kings, who alone would with confidence have
undertaken the conquest of the whole world with the moity of these troops,
which being embarked with a favorable wind, stood for Natolia, as it was
before agreed with Prigmal^on: who in the mean time took no less care, for
having called his friends together, he put to sea with the Kings of Guine,
Morlavia, B^nazar, Saphotir, Merove, Cyrcia, the Sultan of Cayre, the Princes
of Colidonia, Tergadan, and Ardania, with an hundred and thirty thousand horse,
forty thousand foot, and seven and thirty Giants, whom we will leave to the
conduct of Neptune, that they may have time to arrive, and return to the Greek
Court, which in the mean space had made their preparations for the war, and as
yet had only a body of fifty thousand horse, Florisel having disposed his
inf^ntery in the good towns, as that which was fitter to defend a rampire, then
to fight in field: Whilst all was thus inclining to war, the Christian Princes
sought all kinds of diversions, for the ca^es of those fai^ Queens, who seemed
to have lost the better part of their luster, with the fear of ensuing dangers;
Iusts and Tourneys were not wanting, wherein those young Knights, to their
infinite commendations, appeared as it were in emulation of one another: In
brief, the Court was full of pastimes, and it seemed that the news which was
brought them of the incredible multitude of enemies that were coming to them,
served but to animate them the more. One day when as all the world was
intentive on the Iusts, that Tristor of Sopradisa maintained, in honor of
Alteria, of whom he was passi^nat^ly inamoured, there came in a Damsel, her
hair scattered about her shoulders, her eyes full of tears, and with so sad a
countenance, as she moved as much pity, as desire to know from what mish^p her
sighs and lamentations proceeded. As soon as she drew near these Princes, she
wiped her eyes, and stood a good while viewing them, without speak^ng a word;
But Spheramond, imagining that her grief made ^er so silent: Gentlewoman, said
he, the est^te in which we see you, makes us believe that you are oppressed with
some affliction, and that you desire relief. Speak, and make use of us, for
there is no man-heer, but will gladly contribute to your redress. That only
hope, said she, made me come hither, for knowing that you never refused your
assistance to those that entreated you for it, I am come to crave revenge of a
wrong that has been done me in this countr^y. I traveled by the command of a
Lady, whose principal care does aim at the preservation of a virtuous man, and
in a scarff carried a sword, the fairest that may be found, and at my saddle
bow, an helmet, so rich, that it is not to be valued, hoping erelong to have
met with them for whom these presents were designed: But passing through a
forest, some two days journey from hence, I lighted on a great Knight, who
neither respecting my weakness, nor the little profit that he could reap of
his injurious dealing (for I had told him that neither the sword nor helmet
could serve for any but only those two for whom they were made) seized upon
them, and told me with a harsh voice, that the Destinies had forged these arms
for him, since they were appointed for two of the bravest Knights in the world.
How beir, I besought him to render them back to me, bidding him try and he
should see, that they would be of no use to him; but he r^dely replied, that if
this adventure were not ordained for him, the valor of who so ever it were
could not repair his default; and that therefore I should assure my self, they
should never go out of his hands but upon a strict account; so withdrawing to a
tree that stands by the high ways side, on whose branches he hung the helmet
and the sword, he vowed to tarry there eight whole days, and not suffer any
Knight to pass without trying this adventure: Now you know the loss that I
have endured, and the only cause of my tears, in regard whereof, I demand some
Knight, who by punishing this offense, may make me as joyful, as now you see
me afflicted. Your desire, said Spheramond, appears to me so just, as I will
gladly do you service in it, if you will but give me time to take my arms.
Certainly it seems, my Lord, said Russian then, that you intend to have all the
glory of the world to your self alone; Have you not honor enough already? Or
will a petty adventure add any w^it to the praises that are now given you? Not
at all, your name does sufficiently fli^ abroad i^ every man's mouth, no^ is
there any need that you should labor to purchase more fame: Leave, I beseech
you, the care of this affair to me, and permit me to seek occasions to imitate
your virtue. You shall do as you will, said Spheramond, nor will I ever oppose
so brave an ambition: Go then when you please, but remember to return, I pray
you, and not suffering your self to be carried away with any new fancy, think
that ere long we shall have occasion to employ you. Be assured, said Russian,
extremely glad with the leave he had gotten, I will not, but upon necessity, go
far, and that our enemies shall see me the first in the field; with that, doing
reverence to all those Princes, he leaped on horsback, and left them all much
grieved at his departure: For remembering a number of surprises wherewith they
had been otherwhiles caught themselves, they with reason feared he might be
carried somewhither, where the danger might be greater then to encounter one
Knight alone; Nevertheless, retaining the same greatness of courage which
they ever carried in all their actions, they made no show of any sadness, but
committing the care of his good fortune to heaven, they settled themselves to
behold the justs; where Tristor showed so much valor, as he was commended of
all men. In the mean time, Russian meditating more of his new passion, which he
felt for the fair Agriclea, then of the affair wherein he wa^ employed,
^ravelled with some discontent to the Damsel, who not approving that silence
of his, as if it had testified a kind of faintness in him, she th^^ said: I
will not condemn your humor before I know you better; but I would gladly
understand the occasion of your sadness, to the end I might serve you with as
much freeness, as you have showed courage i^ undertaking the revenge of my
wrong. You must impute it to time, answered he, which does not give us leave to
be always of one temper, and not to any ill disposition of nature. It is a
fault, I confess: for you have enough to divert a troubled mind, but I shall
desire you, not to be offended with it, since I fail not out of malice, and
that I am ready to make aamends for my error. It was not to constrain your
actions, that I set this discourse on foot, replied he, but knowing that the
withdrawing one from melancholy thoughts, does many times oblige a man. I took
the boldness to call you, that you might do better to be merry, then thus to
lose your self in such cogitations. Riding on then in this sort, they past
away the day with many pleasing discourses, and the night in a sound sleep,
though they had no other covering then the trees. But the Sun having waked
them, they pursued their former way, and traveled till noon, when as they came
to the tree where the Damsel hoped to find her gallant, and to make him give
an account of the Arms that he had taken from her: howbeit, she was extremely
amazed when she saw neither the sword nor the helmet hanging on the boughs. I
am most certain, said she, looking Russian in the face, that my grief, as
great as it was, did not take my understanding from me, and that this tree is
the witness of the wrong which the robber did me of whom I now complain, as
well as of the oaths which he swore to tarry eight days for me here. No, I am
not mistaken: for see where the grass is pressed down with the weight of his
body. This is the bough whereon that precious sword hung, and these the same
stones upon which he sat down to try if the helmet would fit his head, yet I
wonder he should be gone, considering how he boasted of his valor;
neverth^lesse, to speak truth, I have no great reason to think it strange: for
could I hope that a thief would stand upon respect of honor, and that he would
prize his faith above his profit; people of that metal use to promise any
thing, and perpetually fail: he is gotten away to hide his booty, and keeping
out of my sight, believes that he shall never be forced to restore it again.
But I am resolved either to lose my self, or to be revenged: wherefore, if you
please, let us go on, and seek him so long till we hear some news of him. I
am ready, said Russian, to do as you shall command me, since your enemy is not
here, let us go and learn what is become of him.

Being about then to depart, they spied a Dwarse so little, that the grass
whereon he lay, covered half of his body. It may be, said the Damsel laughing,
that we may have some notice here of what we seek: let us enquire, sir, of this
little ugly fellow, what is become of the Knight. As I live, said the Dwarf,
rising up in haste, I would not so much as open my mouth to give you the
satisfact^on you desire, did not the worth of this Knight persuade me to it as
much as your injuries dissuade me from it; whereupon turning to Russian, Knight,
said he, will you command me any service? I desire, answered Russian, that you
would be pleased to tell us where we are, and if you have seen any Knight under
this tree. You are, said the Dwars, in the Kingdom of Macedon, this Oak is
called, the tree of adventure; because that ordinarily here falls out one
novelty or other: and the Knight after whom you enquire, is this morning gone
away at the request of a damsel, who has carried him to the guard of the
castle of Love from hence. I am, said Russian, satisfied in few words: but my
friend, you may add one greater obligation yet to that wherein I stand already
indebted unto you by giving me information of the Castle you speak of. I
would, replied he, if it were in my power to satisfy you, but truly, sir, my
curiosity did never stretch so far, only my opinion is, that it is called the
Castle of Love, because there is to be seen in an enchanted room there, that
proud Deity which triumphs over the hearts of lovers, seated upon a throne of
Marble; at the end whereof are two Arches, whereinto no living man could ever
yet enter. Now if you be not contented herewith, and that you ask me why the
entering into that house is forbidden, I will tell you, that as far as I could
gather by the Damsels discourse which carried the Knight away, that it is to
hinder a great happiness to Christendom, predestined to it by the ruin of
this enchantment, which is shortly to come to an end. I could not, said
Russian, be more clearly informed in what I desired to know, so that I will
trouble you no further. Saying so, he passed on with his guide, determining to
go into the Castle, and see the end of that adventure.

CHAP. XXV. Don Rogell by a strange means is brought to the Castle of Love,
and having, with Russian of Media, given an end to the enchantment, they both
remained enchanted under the arches of the (...) of lovers.
DVring the time that Russian was going to the Castle of Love, Don R^gel weary
of the City, had a mind to refresh his spirits on hunting; commanding
therefore the dogs to be brought to the wood, and with some gentlemen getting
to horse, he entered into a Coppice; where, within a while, he saw a St^gge come
out, one of the greatest that ever he had seen. Passion, that often hurries us
after what we desire, made him so run his horse after the Deer, as presently he
had lost his company, and thought they followed him hard; yet none of them knew
what was become of him: for being better mounted then they, he quickly got a
great deal of ground of them, and stopped not, but upon occasion of a new
encounter, as full of danger, as of wonder; he saw coming out of the wood fix
Savages, which carried a great pack upon their shoulders, and two terrible
Giants, that conducted them, with so horrid an aspect, that the only view of
them might have affrighted any heart less courageous then that of this valiant
Prince. But being incapable of fear, he observed them a good while: and at
last was advancing with an extreme desire to know what was in that pack, had he
not withal remembered, that he was without Arms, that therefore reason did
forbid him the committing so rash a part, and that (...) an indiscreet act
would bring him much more blame then commendation. Returning then into the
wood, without any further thought of hunting, but only with a purpose to find
out his people, among whom was (...) Sq^^re, who always carried a complete
armor for him: he made many returns in it with infinite discontent that he was
not then in case to fight: for fearing he should not meet with this adventure
again, he thought himself unfortunate, and carried with an unusual rage, he
determined to turn head, and try his fortune only with his sword; whereas
casting his eye about ^n every side, to see which way he were best to take for
his p^rsuit of the Savages, he spled a green cuirasle at the foot of the tree,
with an helmet and shield of the same color. That fortune, no less expected
then wished for, changing his displeasure into joy, made him instantly alight,
and taking up the cuirasle, with the rest of the Arms that belonged to it, he
armd himself from head to foot. Hereupon being more contented then he had been
of a long time, he speedily remounted his horse; and never thinking of the
discontent his friends would be in for his departure, he traveled so long,
that night came upon him nee^ to the cabbine of a young Shepherd, who received
him with much courtesy, giving him such entertainment as his narrow fortunes
were able to afford. The desire he had to reap the fruit of his labor, not
permitting him to sleep soundly, he gat up by break of day, and proceeded in
his former way, till that about two hours after noon he saw a proud Castle,
before the which two Knights were in fight with very much courage: The nearer
he drew to them, the crueller their combat appeared to be: for the terrible
blows they gave one another, showed an extreme force, and made him think that
the death of them both would perhaps be the end of their combat. Being
delighted with this furious fight, he staid a while to observe the violence,
and adresse, wherewith these Knights struck and avoided the blows of one
another. But hearing a noise on the left hand, he turned suddenly about, and
seeing the Savages and the Giants whom he so^ght for, ready to enter into the
Castle by another gate, far greater then that before which this combat was
begun, he spurred away so hard, that he got into the gate just as the last
Giant entered; who giving him no leisure to inform himself of this adventure,
charged him very furiously with a belief that he should dispatch him at the
first blow. But this Prince, that knew the way to vanquish, lifting up his
shield over his head, b^re off the violence of his sword, that descended
without harming him, and at the same instant made so strange a thrust at him,
that he gave his enemy a deep wound in his side. The other Giant turning about
at the noise of this fight, and seeing his brothers blood, ran immediately at
Don Rogel, who nothing amazed to have two such adversaries upon him, with a
quick change of his ground, avoided a blow which he let fly at his head, and
made another thrust at him, hoping to have as good fortune with it as he had at
the first; but it was without effect: for that meeting with his shield* entered
but a little way. Whilst this combat grew hot, by reason of the Giants rage,
and the government of the Prince, who fought with more judgment then force,
that of the two Knights having endu^ed above three hours, continued still with
all fury that may be imagined between two valiant men, who would rather have
been in their graves, then miss the glory of being conquerours. Their blows
fell alike, heavy and dangerous, the sight of their blood enflamed their
cho^ler, and the resistance which they found from one another, rendered them so
obstinate, as they would not speak of breathing, though they were both in case
to desire it. But me thinks it is time to tell who these two excellent Princes
were, that the reader may no longer be held in suspense; Russian of Media was
one, and the other was Mandajar the proud Pagan, that took the sword and helmet
from the Dam^ell, and afterward was carried to guard the castle of love, as you
have heard in the precedent chapter. Passing therefore from this to the
prosecution of my discourse, you must know, that these Knights ^attering one
another, continued their combat above an hour longer. At the end whereof
Mandajar feeling his enemies sword too often in his flesh, and hoping for no
safety, but in d^sparation took his sword in both his hands, and let drive
with such fury at the Prince of Media his shield, as he forced him to set one
knee to the ground, with an opinion that he would never rise again. But he had
little time to rejoice: for his sword brake in three pieces, and Russian
getting up in an extraordinary rage, made him believe that his death was no
further from him, then till he received the next blow, so that valuing his life
more then his honor, he shamefully turned his back, and not daring to stand
the fury of our Christian, he ran away through the Court of the Castle, at the
very same time when as Don Rogel gave one of the Giants his deaths wound, and
got him into the enchanted Hall, as into a place of refuge, or sanctuary.
Russian following him, and finding one of the Giants in his way, gave him so
terrible a blow upon his head, that he clave him to the very teeth, and
suddenly withal entered the Hall where Mandajar was; who seeing himself
followed so close, went up the stairs, which led to the throne of love: and
taking that copper Idol in his hand, he was going to throw it at Russian, but
was prevented by his sword, which divided his body in two. The Knight was no
sooner fallen with the image in his hand, but a terrible clap of thunder was
heard, which was followed with so thick a smoke, as nothing could be discovered
a good while after: howbeit, an hour being past in that darkness, and the day
recovering its former brightness, the place of the throne was seen to be
strangely changed: for in stead thereof was a fine covered Fountain, of the
same Marble which the two Arches underneath it were framed, which contained a
most clear and transparant water; whereinto Russian looking, beheld the fair
Niece of the Emperor of Guardacia, just as he saw her at Constantinople at
such time as he delivered her from the enchantment, in which she was held for
Fulgoso^^ cause. This object ravished him, and that beauty so pleasing to his
soul, transporting him from the thought of all other contentments, he was
about to discover his love unto her, as if she had indeed been present, when a^
the noise that a man in Arms coming toward him, made, awaked him out of this
pleasing dream, and possessed him with despite and rag^ to be so interrupted.
Rash and presumptu^^^, said he, looking up, and not knowing that it was the
Emperor his father, why come you to trouble my delight, and to divert me from
the greatest pleasure that a (...) may meet with in his life? As I live, I will
chastise you for this insolence, and you shall pay me interest for the content
you have deprived me off. Don Rogel, who knew him by his Arms, could not
forbear laughing* and answered: You have no reason to threaten me: for you
shall never find a Knight more ready to do you pleasure then my self. These
are excuses, said Russian, which will hardly serve your turn, and to think of
satisfying me with words, is to deceive your self, you must therefore provide
for your defense. Nay, said Don Rogel, I had rather yield you the victory
presently: for there is no reason I should take away that life which I have
given you, or that you should bereave me of mine, from whom you hold yours.
Your words, replied Russian, do amaze me: for either you are the Emperor Don
Rogel, and my Lord, or I understand you not. It is true, said Don Rogel,
lifting up his Bever that I am your father, brought hither by the strangest
accident in the world, and infinitely pleased with the honor which you have
gained by the ruin of these enchantments. But pray tell me, what delight was
that from which I hindered you? Your eyes my Lord, said Russian, after he had
modestly excused himself upon his ignorance, will better inform you then my
words. If you please to look into this fountain, which was set here in the time
of the mist, perhaps you will have cause to say with me, that it is one of the
rarest wonders that may be seen: Don Rogel then, more curious then before, went
presently up the steps, and looking into the water, he beheld the fair
Emperesse of Persia his wife, who with a sad countenance declared, that his
absence was not little grievous to her, that loved him so truly; Fair-Mistris,
said he then, it is not without extreme sorrow that I am thus esloigned from
you; But alas! I am compelled to it by the necessity of occasions, that will
not suffer me to enjoy the happiness of your presence, as your felicity seems
to depend on mine: Comfort your self, I beseech you, for a time, the common
Father of all things, will render us that contentment, and our delights will be
the more pleasing after the displeasure of so long an absence; with that
looking down, he espied the sword and helmet, whereof we have heertofore
spoken, hanging over the two marble arches, he had a desire to prove if those
arms were reserved for his glory, but perceiving a Damsel coming in with two
Lions in a lease, he went speedily down to entertain her, and to go the nearest
way, passed under one of the arches, where he presently lost the remembrance of
all things, remaining enchanted, without any will to go out, but for to combat
those which should touch him with their swords. R^ssian, who thought that some
new matter of wonder had made him stay there, straightway entered under the
other, as desiring to participate of his fathers good fortune; but he was also
enchanted in the same sort, and finding a chair there, he sat him down, without
any thought of his Agriclea. As soon as these two Princes were thus arrested,
the Damsel f^stening two iron chains unto two buckles that appeared at the
ends of that frame, and struck the Lions with a rod she had in her hand; which
done, the fountain, seated upon four iron wheels, began to move with the
drawing of the Lions, who were no sooner out of the Castle, but the whole
building sunk into the earth, the Damsel being left in a corniche of the
frame, with the rains in her hand, and the coffer, which the savages had
brought in, between the two arches, but so close shut, that no body could
possibly come to see what was within it.

CHAP. XXIX. That which befell Esquilan of Poland and Perion of Turkey, going
in quest of Den Rogel.
THE Gentlemen, that accompanied Don Rogel on hunting, having made a thousand
turns in the wood without hearing any news of him, determined to return to the
City, believing that they should find him there; but when they came thither,
and found him not, they advertised Don Florisel of his loss, who was very much
grieved thereat, and would certainly have gone himself the same day to seek
him, had he not counted it an unpardonable fault to have left his Empire, and
his people, to the mercy of their enemies, whose coming he every howr
expected, having had intelligence that they were at sea, and might with a fair
wind be quickly there: Determining therefore not to stir, he called Esquilan
and Perion to him, commanded them to get to horse, and to seek Don Rogel four
days, with a charge, that if in that time they heard not of him, they should
not fa^l to return back: These young Princes thinking it an honor for them to
receive this command, went presently to arm themselves, and being well mounted,
traveled till it was late, without meeting any adventure worth the relating;
but toward night they saw a Shepherdess passing by them, who in the midst of
her age, had some lines yet left in her face of a loving beauty, which in her
youth had made her beesteemed: a young Shepherd, handsome, and well
proportioned, followed her, with his eyes drowned in tears: What, said he, fair
Oristea, will you always fly me, and shall my tears never soften that marble
which you have lodged in your breast? Stay, I beseech you, and by my actions
judge of my sufferings, too long indeed for so slight a fault; My sighs do
crave that grace which sometimes you granted me, and which now I have lost,
rather by misfortune, then malice; Do not deny it to this violent affection I
bear you, your quiet, and my contentment depend on your facility in receiving
me at this present, for love having heertofore tied us together with such fast
bonds, I cannot see how ever we should live contentedly in this separation.
That is it, said the Shepherdess, with a disdainful countenance, which
without doubt abuses you; for I am now more capable of hate, then ever I was of
love, neither do you imagine, that my happiness consists in your glory, or my
pain in your misfortune; you are to me me so indifferent, that I will never
have a share in any thing that may be fall you; your excuses therefore, and the
importunities wherewith you thus vex me, are altogether unprofitable: Leave me
then to live with the liberty of my thoughts, and study some artifice with
which you may appease Cloria, who has no less cause to banish you her
presence, and not to love you, then my self. With that she was going away, when
as Peri^^, who was highly delighted with her discourse, and as much desired to
know the occasion of it: Fair Shepherdess, said he, I know not what fault this
young man has committed, but I find his penance very sharp, and your heart a
little to blame, for we do always merit pardon, when we confess our error,
and protest never to offend again. If you have heertofore loved him, you would
doubtless have loved him still, had not some crime of his rendered him
unworthy of your affection; his repentance does blot out his offense, wherefore
you ought to love him as much now, as heertofore you have done, nor think more
of his fault, since his sorrow for it has cancelled it. I should willingly,
answered she, allow of your reasons, if I were less sensible of the grief I am
in, for having been so foully deceived, or could build any assurance on the
oaths of men: but can it be likely I should ever put any trust in the oaths of
a Shepherd, whose humor I too well know to be so inconstant and full of
levity; these tears, which you see in his eyes, are only to reduce me once
more into the captivity wherein his love has for three years detained me; and
his sighs, serve but for charms, to keep my reason from discerning the mischief
which he would bring upon me; I must not therefore regard them, but having paid
for my learning, take my self out a good lesson from his fault, and my
misfortune, to enjoy the happiness of my liberty. It may be you will not
approve (...) discourse, and will say that my humor is too valiant; but I will
let you see, that I have all the reason in the world to handle him in this
sort, and firmly to resolve, either never to love again, or to live no more for
the world, since there is no security to be found in it, so your occasions will
give you leisure to hear me, and that you disdain not a poor cottage for your
lodging this night. Your request is so fair, answered Esquilan, that we are
bound to accept of your curr^sie, wherefore we will wait on you, with a longing
desire to hear the relation of your adventure. Taking then a path on the right
hand, and guided by the Shepherd, who, out of civility, had given over his
sighing and lamentions, they came to a little village, where they were better
entertained by Oriste^, then they could have hoped for from one of that
quality: Their supp^r ended, she caused caused them to sit down under certain
trees, where when her self and Filism^nd had also taken their places, she thus
began: Do not wonder* Knights, to hear me say, that I am nobly descended,
because you see me not in a habit suitable to that condition; Love and Fortune
do often work greater miracles then this; I came into the world, with so
malignant an aspect of the stars, that I cannot with reason say, that ever I
enjoyed any contentment long: My parents losing themselves in that common
blindness of the world, which thinks wealth to be the sovereign good, made me
be called a wife, at the time, when only the title of a child was fit for me;
and at seven years of age married me to a man, whose kindness, in that tender
age, was very unpleasing unto me; but much more when I arrived at years of
discretion, and was able to discern the defects which were in him: Complaining
then, not to those, upon whom my will should in right have depended, (for
hardly should I by my prayers and tears have drawn them to break that which
they had once done) but to them that had the power of justice in their hands;
and demonstrating unto them, that it was but reason to suffer me to enjoy the
rights which heaven bestows on all men that are born into the world, I got
them, after much deb^ting, and with many difficulties, to dissolve this
marriage, and gave me power to choose a husband to my own liking, wherein truly
I chanced very happily, by the possession of a Gentleman, as good and
accomplished a Cavalier as the earth this day bears: But the Fates envying the
felicities which I then began to taste, too suddenly ravished him from me, and
gave me cause to die with him if so I might have done without displeasing the
Gods, who will with absolute power dispose of our days, not permitting us to
shorten them, no more then we are able to prolong them. My tears, and the
continuance of my mourning, sufficiently demonstrated my sorrow, but my
undestanding, and time, the common Physician of our sorrows, having somewhat
eased my grief, I confidered that it was but weakness of spirit so to lose my
self in the anguish of my mind; and finding some ease in my p^tience, resolved
to afflict my self no more so excessively; I lived then with less disquiet
then before: But alas! This happiness was not of long continuance: The proud
tyrant of our souls, Love, would once more triumph over me by the means of this
Cavalier, whom you see here, in this simple habit of a Shepherd, which within
these few days he has assumed, though with a purpose far different from mine:
for I wear it to exempt my self from the c^res of the world, and to seek for
pleasures in these woods; and he without doubt to make me believe that he loved
me in this change of condition, as that of his affection made me hold him
inconstant and perfidious; He was worthy of my love, I do confess, for his
fault shall not keep me from giving him his deserved commendations; but his
light and sickle humor has made him incapable of so good a fortune. He saw
me, and finding (as he pretended) charms in my eyes, came to present his
service to me with so good a grace, that from that time forth it was impossible
for me to approve of the resolution I had taken, never to love again, for fear
of being once more in the danger of the misfortune, which had made me complain
so long; howbeit, good manners obliging me, not to accept him at the first
tender of himself, nor my affection permitting me to reject him with too much
rigor, I made him an ordinary answer, which yet might let him perceive that I
had no inclination to neglect his good will: To what end should I spin out my
discourse, with delivering the particulars of the beginning of our passions?
Our love did so increase, that every body held our marriage for concluded, and
that it would be consummated as soon as the year was expired, which the modesty
of the world allows to the mourning for the dead, and indeed I had resolved
upon it, ^^s I told you but now, had not his inconstancy put him by that
fortune: The faithless man, seeing among the Ladies, which my quality had made
my friends, and that often bestowed visits upon me, a maid called Cloria,
beautiful indeed, and of parts to make the most insensible feel the power of
love, could not refuse to yield her that, which she was able to command from
all those that looked on her; and did in such sort become her sl^ve, as he
scarce remembered that ever he had sighed for me: If he came into my company,
it was with a ceremonious respectivenesse; now he no longer besought me to
quench that fire which I had ^indled in his soul, his lips where unto he was
wont to rivet me, did no more meet with mine; our looks no more incountered
together, I was no more acquainted with his mind, though I did clearly let him
see what was in my heart: In brief, his discourses, being of a strain clean
diffrent from what they had been before, made me suspect* not any ill in him,
(for I was too full of love to think him a villain) but that some mish^p had
caused this change. What ^il you Filismond, said I to him, and why do you
appear so cold? Has any man told you tales to the prejudice of the good
opinion which you had of me? Or do you not think me as beautiful, as for these
three months past you have done? If it be repentance that you have loved me,
which does trouble you, and that you hold me unworthy of your affection, you
are yet in your own power to make a fair retreat, for I will never force your
humor, but rather do my best for your content, nor will I be displeased with
the liberty you shall take to engage you other where, so as the cause thereof
may excuse this mutability in you: Now if you have heard any mis-report in me,
give me leave to clear your mind of any doubts may be in it; and I make no
question, but you shall find me without ^aint, or shame, for any fault I have
committed. I should wrong my judgment, as well as all theirs that know you,
answored he, if I should think you other then discreet; that is not the cause,
Or^stea, of this change in me, no more then my being sorry for that I have
loved you; for you deserve to be served by a more accomplished and eminent man
then my self; but I must accuse mine own weakness, and by confessing my fault,
l^bour to obtain your parcton. I love, but alas! it is not you: (...),
posse^^es me with an absolute power, and that Deity, which disposes of our
affections, is not pleased that I shall have any content in this world, but in
enjoying her: Judge, I beseech you, what my misfortune is, that cannot move,
but by the impulsion of another, and that am constrained to crave favors of
Cloria by your mediation: Verily, I blush for shame, and know well that it were
better for me to seek them in your embraces; but I have not power to dispose of
my self, and can think of nothing, more conducing to my happiness, then your
assistance, which you promise me: But alas! I fear you are not so minded. My
promises are inviolable, answered I, without any show of discontent for his
b^s^n^sse, and it may be, Filismond, Cloria will love you sooner at my
entreaty, then for your services; wherefore, I will go presently to her, to
begin the making good of my word: G^ing out th^n, exceeding full of grief, I
went to Cloria, unto whom I discovered the desires of my waverer, praying her
to have respect to his me^i^, and to the advantage that his affection might
bring her. This discourse of mine, s^emed a fiction to her at first, for she
was not ignorant with what passion Filismond had wooed me; but seeing that I
spoke seriously, and withal found some other pretenses for cause of our
separation; she answered me, that time and my advice should resolve her of this
business, and that in the mean while she would entertain Filismond at my
request. This good news I delivered to my Turn-coat, and though displeas^d with
the office, the next mo^n^ing carried him to his new Mist is; to whom, and in
my presence, he made the same protestation of love, that at other times I had
received of him. O ye Gods! said I, when I heard him, What traitors are men,
and what fools are we to give any credit to their promises? Hark if these be
not the very same speeches that Filismond has used a thousand times to me, all
which the wind has blown away, as without doubt another puff will do these;
he swears only that he may be perjured, whereof I am to make my benefit, grow
wise with my loss, never trust any but my self, and draw my fu^ure content out
of the knowledge of Filismonds treachery. Entertaining my self in this
fashion, whilst these lovers were laying the first foundations of their
affections; the day insensibly slipped away, and night coming on, made me return
home in a strange dist^mper; for, not to dissemble, all my resolutions could
not keep me from wishing, that these new fancies had never come into Filismonds
Head; but being, as then fuller of desp^ght then love, I determined to live no
more in the w^rld, since the lives of those of quality were subject to so many
mutations, and from hence orth only to frequent the woods, where people live
without ambition. This design contenting me best, I took a good sum of
money, and with a wench in my company, who was content to run my fortune, I
came and bought a cottage in this Hamlet; taking care for nothing but to feed
my sheep, and by that employment divert my self from more troublesome thoughts.
Living thus quietly, and pleased with mine own profession, I was at good ease,
till within these fowr days, that Cloria having given Filismond some occasion
of distate, he came to cross my content with his continuali importunities;
thinking that I will change my mind, and consent as easily to his return, as I
did to his departure: But he is deceived, the resenting of my wrong will not
let me endure his sight, and his levity forbids me ever to accept of him again.
You now know, Gentlemen, the cause of his complaint, and my displeasure, which
I think to be just; and that also you will not condemn, when you remember, that
nature and reason both forbid us ever to impose any trust in those which have
once betrayed us. I excuse not my fault, answered Filismond, when he saw that
she had done speaking, and will with you avow, that I do not deserve the grace
that I crave. But, Oris^ea, I must say, that it is yet due to my repentance,
that so you may avoid the name of being cruel: and for that consideration, I
will never cease following you, and perpetually pouring out my tears before
you, in hope that they may one day mollify your heart. And if I cannot obtain
that bliss, I will gladly end my days in the acknowledgement of my error,
and in my desire to do you service. Time, said Oristea, may do that miracle;
but now, because it is the hour of rest, you shall retire your self with these
Knights; who, if you please, may lodge in your cottage. With that, making a
courtsie to the Princes, that were exceedingly delighted with her discourse,
she left them to go with Filismond, who carried them home, where they lay that
night, and the next morning very early getting to horse, proceeded on their
voyage, which they finished without any news of Don Rogel, to the exceeding
grief of Florisel, for that it happened in a time wherein Greece had such need
of his presence.

CHAP. XXIX. The Pagans arrival at Constantinople, with a cruel fight upon
their landing.
THE return of these Princes having brought a general discontent to the whole
Court, and in particular to Don Florisel, who judged the Empire of Greece to be
in bad case, not being supported with those invincible courages which had
rendered it every where redoubtable: but having fortitude enough to endure the
wo^st of fortune, he well resolved not to murmr against God, and to receive
his chastisements as an assured sign of his favor; which was very much
confirmed by the arrival of the forces of great Britain and Rome. The last
commanded by Sclarimond, son to Florenio, and the other by Garm^nt, Ladazan,
of Numidia, Don Sinald^, and G^cilad^r. This succor of twenty five thousand
horse, and ten thousand foot, did somewhat encourage those, which were before
in fear of the multitude of the enemies, and much cheered the Greek Princes.
But their contentment, was complete, when the next day word was brought them,
that the two Empresses of Perfia, and of the Parthians, were in the Port, with
thirty thousand horse, and Fifteen thousand foot. Upon this advertisement,
Florisel, Spheramond, and all the young Princes, quickly madethem ready, and
presently went down to the shore, where no sort of kindest entertainment, or
embraces were pretermitted; Spheramond seemed as if he had been fastened to the
lips of his beautiful wife: But when he saw R^zal^^^^ of Greece, his son,
who with Rozanel d' Astre presented themselves to do their duty to him, he ran
to embrace them with a world of joy to behold them so lovely and well made.
Florisel on the other side* no less kindly entertained the Empress Persea,
wondering at the goodly disposition of Persides and Floridan her sons, whom
she had brought with her. But when he saw that she looked round about, as if
she demanded why her husband was not in the company, he told her, that he was a
few days since gone abroad into the country, with purpose not to make any
long stay. In the mean time Don Lucendus entertained the fair Infanta
Rozaliana: briefly, there was nothing but complements, and still were some
arms stretched out to reiterate their embraces. Those caresses being over,
Spheramond led the Empress Persea, Florisel and Silvan, the fair Ric^arda; and
Lucendus and Dorigel, the Infanta Rozaliana, the young Knights took the charge
of their women, and Rozalmond with the three young Princes his companions,
putting themselves in the head of the troop, marched with an admirable grace,
and were the first that came into the Palace, where the caresses were by those
Queens renewed, with so many expressions of love, that not to be tedious, I
will pass them over in silence. In the mean time Florizel, to whose care all
the affairs were left, made these aids be landed, which he joined to those of
great Britain and Rome. And having given order for the making of strange
trenches to lodge them in, he returned to the City, to continue the pleasures
which the coming of so brave a company had begun. But that lasted not long:
for the next morning they saw the sea covered with ships, and the Princes were
forced to arm, and suddenly to marshall their Soldiers upon the shore, to
impeach the landing of the Pagans. The Emperor Spheramond put himself first
of all in the head of five and twenty thousand horse, accompanied with the
valiant Dorigel, the Duke of Laiazza, Quedragant of Sansueque, and the brave
Florestan of Sardinia. The brave Alastraxerea had the second place assisted by
Silvan, the fair Savagesse his wise, Florian with his brother Tristor, and
Dardanio King of Rhodes. The third Squadron consisting only of twenty thousand
horse, was led by Lucendus, Prince of France, accompanied by the gallant
Esquilan of Poland, Perion of Turkey, Florizart of Taproban, Agrian, Abies of
Ireland, and Frizel of Arcadia. And the last troop of the same number, by the
valorous Florizel of Niquea, who was followed by the two Cenophales, Armond of
Bohemia, Alteria, Malford, Leonida^, and Ladazan of Numidia. The Infantery,
which were only five and twenty thousand men, remained in guard of the town
and camp, under the charge of Garmant, Sinaldo and Gucilador. The shore thus
covered with these Troops in good order, it was presently discovered by the
Pagans, who came on with swelling sails; whereupon Fulgoran and Prigmaleon (who
were joined five days before) gave order to their Fleet to make ready for
fight. Arriving then with incredible fury, in an instant was heard a confusion
of voices, mingled with a dreadful noise of trumpers and drums; and the air
was presently darkened with millions of arrows. The Pagans proud of their
multitude, and thrusting on with courage, under the favor of their Archers,
threw out bridges and ladders to get to the strand. But the Christian Princes,
and those brave Knights, received them upon their lances, made them tumble into
the sea as fast as they left their ships; and not fearing their Archers, who
but very seldom pierced their Arms, put themselves into the water, the better
to make use of the swords. The fight then begun to be very cruel: for the
Giants and the Kings in a rage to see the water died red with the blood of
their men, leaped all at once on land, in spite of all their enemies
resistance, and with them above forty or fifty thousand men. Then was the
encounter very bloody: for as many Pagans as the swords of our Christian
Princes did light upon, found their graves in the sands; and the catholics
had not a much better bargain under the scymiters of the Giants, whereof two
were at this first meeting slain; and with them the Kings of Zambar,
Carthage^^, and Nabagaz^. Prig^^leon and Fulgor^^, who desired to signalize
their valor at their enemies cost, cut in pieces all that they met with; and
followed by a multitude of people which were gotten to land, they had fallen
upon Alastraxerea's Squadron, if Spheramond had not arrested the fury of
Prig^^leon, and Silvan that of the King of Canabea. These four Knights being
thus incountred, began a most furious combat; during the which, Alastraxerea,
the fair Savagesse, Florian, Dorigel, Quedragant, Altaria and Dardanio, were on
the one side gotten together, to take the Giants in hand, while their Knights
made a strange massacre of the Pagans; and on the other side Florizel,
Lucendus, Esquilan, Florestan, Florizart, Leonidas, Melfort, Sclarimond, and
some o^ the most remarkable in the Army, rendered themselves dreadful even to
those proud Knights, who thought that all the men in the world assembled
together, were not able to resist their forces: so that nothing was seen but
dead bodies and horses on the ground. The fight having thus continued above two
hours with horrible slaughter, Florisel perceiving a battallion of three or
fourscore thousand horse, which had landed below the place where they fought,
ready to charge him, caused presently a retreat to be sounded, being unwilling
to engage himself amongst such a multitude of enemies. And falling into the
rear of his Army, with all those brave Knights, he bare off the fury of the
Giants and the Kings, who not enduring the loss they had suffered, charged
themselves like desperate men; but seeing twenty thousand foot advance, which
Don Si^ald^ and Garmant had drawn out to favor the retreat of the Christian
Princes, they made a stand, and rallying themselves together, went in good
order to plant their Army before the town. Florizel having put the greatest
part of his men into the fortifications which he had caused to be made, and the
rest into the town, desired to know what this battle had cost him; and by the
report of the Captains, he found, that seven thousand Christian^ were dead on
the place; but he was advertised by the spies which he had in the ^nemies camp,
that the Pagans had lost two and twenty thousand men, fifteen Giants, and
thirteen Kings; at which they were so enraged, that if it had not been so near
night, they would not have tarried till the next day for giving the assault to
the town; yet necessity enforcing it, they were glad to set a good face on the
matter, for fear of disanimating their Soldiers, promising themselves to do
wonders upon the first occasion, since their Army was now out of feate of the
sea, and that they might fight at large upon firm ground. But they were
beguiled in their hopes: for the Greek Princes, who well knew how to follow
their fortune, and to vanquish as well by industry as courage, gave them a new
occasion of despite, as I will presently deliver.

CHAP. XXXI. The wonderful deeds of Arms that were done both in a sally, and
in the assault given to Constantinople, with the great loss that the Pagans
suffered by an Army newly arrived in favor of the Christians.
THis mighty Fleet of enemies having landed, as has been told you, passed the
night without any rest, being employed in setting up of tents, and making
retrenchments for their security: so that about the break of day the
fortifications being finished, the Soldiers tired with the sea, as well as
with their precedent labor; and besides, pressed with an extreme desire of
sleep, laid themselves down to take a little rest; but they were quickly
rowsed: for the Princes of Greece being infatigable, and ever casting for the
victory, and how to weaken their enemies, having withdrawn to the town for to
cheer up those timorous Princesses, after they had supped, went to counsel;
where the courageous Florisel remonstrating in few words, what benefit would
result from a surprisall of drowsy enemies, determined to get to horse before
Sun rising, and meaning to play his game with as much loss and hazard of the
enemy as he could, he gave order that Spheramond should ^ally forth at the east
port, with ten thousand choice horse, the two Cenophales, the brave Esquilan of
Poland, Perion of Turkey, Florian and Tristor of Sopradisa; that the Prince
Lucendus, with the like number, should fall out of the south port, followed by
Silvan, the fair Savagesse, Quedragant, Florestan, Agrian, Alteria and
Dardani^: and that at the same time he would be in the filled with twelve
thousand horse, in the head of which should be the valiant Dorigel, Florizart,
Frizel Abies, Melfort, Armond, and Leonidas; appointing the Queen Alastraxerea
to be ready with two thousand horse to favor his retreat; as also Parmenian of
Cyprus with the like number to support Spheramond; and Ladazan of Numidia to do
as much for the Prince of France, if the enemies approached to the walls. Things
being in this sort disposed, and direction given to such as were to be of the
party, every one withdrew till the hour appointed, when as they sallied out
with a design to make a strange havoc among the Pagans. The first that began
to stir was the invincible Emperor of the Parthians, who find^ng the enemy
sleeping, and almost disarmed, did such execution on them, as the filled was all
strewed over with dead bodies. Prigmaleon and Fulgoran who were asleep in their
arms, but a great way asunder, hearing this fearful alarm, presently took each
of them ten thousand horse, which they held ready about them for all occasions,
and joining together, went to oppose the violence of these indomptable Greeks,
who bare all down before them, when as a fresh noise on the south side, made
them make a stand, as uncertain which way to bend themselves; but being met
just at that instant, Prigmaleon with fifteen Giants, and twelve Kings, who had
put themselves into his troop, whilst the others took care of drawing the rest
of the forces to Arms, turned to that side where Spheramond acted wonders,
