confused sound of voices, talking together, put him out of his imaginations;
whereupon, he rose up presently from under the trees, where he was laid, and
looking round about he spied Polixena, with seven or eight young Ladies, that
were going to take the air of the garden. O me! said he, How luckily does this
fall out? It seems that love does favor my design, now is the time wherein my
courage must appear; if Polixena rejects me, a resolute death shall free me
from so many pains, which will be far more honorable for me then a languishing
life. This ardour carrying him on, he came to his Mistress, thinking that he
should have his tongue as free as his thought; but after a Good-even, he stuck
fast, and leaving his eyes to discover his passion, he was not able to utter a
word. Polixena, who took this timorousness for a sign of his love, seeing him
in that case, took him by the hand, and said: My Lord, I believe we have
surprised you, for the amaze you are in makes me imagine so much.

Do not wonder, Madam, answered he, at seeing me disordered in this encountering
you, the weakness of my sight is not able to endure the glittering of so many
beauties as I behold. This excuse, said Polixena, is none of the best: for if I
had the power that you speak of, I should indifferently trouble as many as look
on me: but none complains of me save you, and your palenesse declares that it
is some secret malady which you will not have not known. It is true, replied
he all trembling, that a secret grief does consume me. But, Madam, I should
have just reason to blame my want of courage, and to impute all my vexation to
my cowardice, if I should not seek for a remedy when it is in my power to do
it. I have suffered infinitely since I saw you, and the powerful charms of
your eyes have left me nothing that is mine, but my desire to do you service.
You may say, I am too bold, that a greater respect belongs to your greatness,
and that I ought to have endured my suffering without declaring it. But alas! I
do not speak but by the impulsion of a passion that forces me to it. Love has
untied my tongue, which you saw was dumb when you came hither: and that is it
which now constraines me to beseech you, that you will be as sensible of pity
as I am of affection. If I had not given you occasion to speak, coldly replied
Polixena, I should be displeased with this your discourse. Maidens in these
days, and especially those of my quality, do not take a liberty of engaging
themselves without the consent of their fathers; neither willingly permit any
to talk to them of love, for fear of being deceived, and unfortunate by
trusting the oaths of a lover of three days standing. If I receive a command
to look on you with these conditions, you have merit enough in you of power
to make me willing to obey it; otherwise do not expect any kinder language
from me. In the mean time live with less disquiet, and out of this my answer
extract reasons to procure your ease. Therewith she passed on, leaving him much
perplexed; for he found both bitter and sweet equally mixed in her words, and
durst not hope without fear. Nevertheless, being somewhat pleased that he had
revealed his thoughts, he retired quietly to his chamber, and remembering that
towns do ordinarily endure the first assault, that yet will afterward yield
to a persisting beleager, he took paper, and in it wrote these lines.

Prigmaleons Letter to Polixena.
THink it not strange if I show more love then obedience: I am brought to that
extremity that all considerations in the world must give way to the violence of
my suffering. I write this because you have forbidden me to speak to you, and
do crave the same pity of you which you would wish for if you were in the pain
you have seen me; If you judge rightly of my passion, you will not be offended
at this request. Honor does guide it, nor do I desire any felicity, but
according to the ordinance of heaven that may legitimate it: Let not your
refusal then make me desperate, but permitting me from hence forward to call
my self your Knight, give me leave to expect the return of those upon whom you
so absolutely depend.


This Letter, written and sealed, he committed to the fidelity of a Dwarf, who
certainly had a greater spirit then a body, and that could so well choose his
time, as the next morning he found Polixena in her chamber, unto whom kneeling
down, he said: If it were fit for me, Madam, to relate to you what one of the
most completest Princes of the earth does suffer for you, I would recount to
you his sighs, his griefs, his transports, and his disquiets, and letting you
know the miserable estate whereinto despair has reduced him, since you forbad
him to complain to you, I should perhaps possess you with as much pity, as he
has love; but persuading my self that his passion has found reasons enough to
let you see it, I will content my self with presenting this paper to you from
him: Be pleased, Madam, to view it with a gentle eye, and return him so
favorable an answer as may cause him to live contented; you shall tie the
world to you in no mean obligation, by preserving in it so brave a Knight; who,
I assure you, desires nothing so much as the honor of doing you service. I
will not, answered she, be so far an enemy to his content, as not to be
willing to read what occasion he takes to complain of me: wherefore give me the
paper; with that she took and opened it, and having well considered it, said to
the Dwarf: My friend, the answer that I must return to thy master, consists
of so few words, as I need not take a pen in hand to let him know my mind,
only bid him hope, that time bring him content, and that fidelity alone can
procure him that which with so much impatience he wishes? for. It is enough,
answered the Dwarf, I will go tell him that he is happy, and that he is not to
complain any more. So going out with a curtsie that made the Princess laugh,
he went to Prigmaleon who expected his return with a panting heart, and
returning him that answer, he rendered him so contented, that not remembering
himself to be Emperor of Aethiopia, he imbr^ced him three or four times,
ever and anon enquiring of him, if he had observed any coldness in her
actions, or rather love in her words. What, said the Dwarf, coldness? Believe
it, you may be happy if you will, if you be not happy already, me thinks I see
you in the midst of those delights which will bring you to a very paradise. For
having seen that fair hand which touched mine when she took the letter from
me, and imagining that her clothes concealed wonders, I was almost transported
with her. And if the respect of your passions had not staid me, I had assuredly
besought her with some favor to quench that flame which already began to
scorch my heart. But not intending to be a traitor, nor to seek my contentment
with the loss of your quiet, I surmounted those unruly passions, and quickly
withdrew my self for fear that the violence of my desires should make us
commit some error. See, said Prigmaleon, laughing heartily at the grace
wherewith this little thing vented his fooleries. See my Mussardin, assured
proofs of thy fidelity, which I have also observed in other things. But be
confident, that thou obligest not an ungrateful man, and that I will one day
recompense the labor thou tookest in mastering thine own appetite for my sake.
I know well, said the Dwarf, that my affection does highly oblige you; howbeit
withal, I extremely fear that you will not give me the reward for it that I
desire. But I will upon the faith of a Knight, said Prigmaleon, so that I may
do it without prejudice to my love, and that it be in my power. Nay, I will
quickly ease you of that fear, said the Darfe, nor shall you find any friend
more faithful to endeavor the bringing of your wishes to their desired part,
then my self, if you will assist me: for as for Polixena, I will wholly quit
her to you; but I would fain have a place in the good grace of Castibella,
daughter to that peerlesse Diana, who once filled the world with such wonders
of her beauty. It is a rising Sun, that promises great things in her course;
and that to be brief, has struck me dead in the eye. Persuade her to love me,
and settling a good impression on her of my courage (for you know I would rather
dye then be wanting to my occasion of honor) tell her, that my alliance with
her will be for her glory, and that she shall find herself most happy in my
services. So will I never complain of my pains in furthering your
satisfaction, and you shall see how faithfully I will serve you. This is, said
Prigmaleon, almost burst with laughter, the happ^est passage that may be, for
now I shall not be jealous of thee; do thou but labor secretly to purchase the
favor of Polixena for me, and I will do the like to thee to Castibella, who
truly would accommodate thee excellent well if she were not a little too young.
Make not that your excuse, said the Dwarf, true love never stands upon time, I
will stay till years have better ripened her judgment, and in the mean space
will find a thousand ways to make my intentions not unpleasing to her. This
discourse finishing, with certain frisks that the Dwarf made to show his
agility, Prigmaleon returned to his thoughts, where we will leave him to follow
the course of our History.

CHAP. XXXIX. A Damsel arrives at Constantinople with the head of the great
Marand^r, slain by the Knight of the Savage.
EVery one seeking diversions from their cares, the Court seemed not to ressent
the absence of the Princes that were enchanted, because they hoped to see them
delivered ere it were long. When as there came into the Hall a Damsel
reasonably handsome, carrying in her hand the head of a Giant, who beholding
the company a good while, with wonder to see Knights of so brave a presence,
and Ladies of such beauty, enquired very modestly which was the Emperor of the
Parthians. Gentlewoman, answered Russian, to whom she then spoke, he has been
absent from hence some few days, but if your affairs cannot permit you to
attend his return, and that you stand in need of his aid, I will willingly
supply his place, and with a free heart do you service. I am said she, much
bound to your courtesy, but God be thanked, I have here in my hand an occasion
of rejoicing, rather then of complaining; nor am I come hither to crave the
help of any whatsoever, but to present to that Excellent Emperor the head of
the greatest enemy he had, brought to this pass by the incomparable valor of
a Knight, that bears a wild man in his shield, whom I may justly vaunt to be
one of the valiantest men upon the earth, and the Phoenix of those that this
day bear arms. This Knight, meeting with me in the confines of Macedon, could
not pass by me, without enquiring after the cause of some tears which he saw
me shed: I freely told him, that the villainy of a Giant, who had ravished me,
did wring them from me, and that I was going to Constantinople to crave
reparation of that wrong; knowing well that the Princes of Greece did never
refuse their assistance to Ladies in distress, and that particularly I
intended to address my self to the Emperor Spheramond, both for that he holds
the reputation of surpassing all Knights of this age, and that the Giant had
told me, how all the villainies which he then committed, were done by him, in
some sort to revenge the death of another Giant, whom the Emperor had slain,
when as a Knight errant he followed adventures abroad in the world. Without
doubt, then answered this court^ous Knight, you could not make your revenge
more certain, then by referring it to the hands of that brave Prince, who has
with all reason acquired those praises which the wo^ld does give him. But if
you be pleased to make use of me, I shall most willingly employ my self in your
service; It is a long journey from hence to Constantinople, your enemy may
find occasion to get him further off, you will take a great deal of pains in
vain, and not be satisfied in your desire: On the other side, I do passionately
long to demonstrate unto that valorous Prince, how I do love his virtue as much
as other men do honor his birth, and that I will labor so long as I live to
ruin his enemies. To what end should I trouble you with our discourse? This
gentleness of his so wrought upon me, that after I had thoroughly considered
him, and judged him fit for any great attempt, I carri^d him straight to the
Giants Castle, where, to be short, he did wonders: For not satisfied with
laying that foul mass of flesh on the earth, in a very dangerous combat, he
defeated thirty or forty Knights, who were seldom out of that Robbers company;
it was to me an unspeakable delight, to see some arms fly to the ground, some
men cut asunder in the midst, others cloven to the girdle, the boldest of them
stoutly scattered; and the gallantry of this Knight did so please me, that if I
had not acquainted him with the misfortune that by the Giant had befallen me, I
had endeavored to make him love me; but feating to be slighted, I passed from
love to the resentment of his good will; vowing to serve him upon all
occasions, and to that end entreated him to lay some command upon me. I would
not have you, said he, give me so many thanks for a thing whereunto I was bound
by the laws of Chivalrie; but since you will needs oblige me, take the head of
your enemy, and for a further satisfaction of your mind, carry it to
Constantinople, present it to that warlike Prince, and render your grief the
less, by publishing the revenge you have had for it. I shall with a good will,
replied I, undertake that journey, but then Sir, will you be pleased to tell me
who you are, to the end I may know to whom I am so infinitely indebted. See
here, my name in my shield, said he, showing a Savage pourtrayed thereupon, for
a more perfect knowledge of me, at this present, I may not give: Follow on your
way, whilst I go some other where to seek occasion of employing my arms; with
that, not thinking it convenient to be troublesome, I took the head of
Marandor, (for so was the Giant named) and began my journey to this place,
where I am arrived with grief, for that I find not the Emperor of the
Parthians to give him an account of this brave Knight; but, if you please, I
will leave it in your charge to do it, upon condition that I shall at any time
be ready to deserve it of you in all possibly I may. Whereupon, she laid the
head of Marandor on the floor, and making a very humble reverence, immediately
departed, leaving all the Princes extremely desirous to know this so valiant
and brave new Knight: Whilst they were all commending the valor of the Knight
of the Savage, Russian, who still had Agriclea in his memory, could not be at
rest, and would certainly have been gone, had it not been for the desire he had
to see his father and his kinsfolks at liberty: but that respect prevailing
with him, he passed the most part of his days unquietly enough; contrarily
Prigmaleon, who interpreting Polixena's answer to his advantage, felt so many
delights amidst his pain, that he blessed love every minute, being pleased with
the change of his condition, as the cause of all his felicity. If he walked in
the woods or gardens, it was not with any purpose to complain, but to
entertain himself with the contemplation of his good for^une, and to grave the
names of Polixena and himself on the barks of trees: his actions were
altogether amorous. And if he suffered any thing at all, her sole impatience
was the cause thereof; howbeit hoping that time would bring him remedy, he
gently supported the violence of his desires.

Pleasing himself then in this fashion, with the entertainmen of his own
thoughts, and sometimes in the remembrance of his Lady, the time slipped so
sweetly away, that they were insensibly come to the Eve of these Princes
enfranchisement, whereof I will relate you the wonder, when I have informed you
of some occurrents that did precede it.

CHAP. XL. A Damsel coming to Constantinople, carries away Prigmaleon to
combat with Griolani^, surnamed the fa^e Knight: The success thereof.
ALL these Princes being assembled together to consult of the order that was to
be kept for the reception of these enchanted Princes; who, as Cassandra assured
them, were to be freed within two days, they saw a strange D^msell come in;
who, pausing upon the view of so many brave Knights, considered them a while
without speaking a word. But observing that they all had their eyes fixed on
her, and that they were silent, as it were, to give her leave to speak, she
said: Now on my faith, I never saw so gallant, nor fo well shaped men in all my
life; nor do I wonder that this Court is so e^told through the world. But I
would gladly know which is the most amorous amongst you. There is not any here,
said Prigmaleon, to whom the Damsel seemed especially to address her self,
that would not appear to be a lover, and that in regard thereof would not
willingly draw his sword against his companion, if it were to be justified by
Arms. But unable to tell assuredly how far another man's suff^ring extends, I
may confidently affirm, that I am he, who perhaps endures most, that loves
with most passion, as he that has devoted himself to one, who kindles no
ordinary ^^ames, and that to save a thousand lives, would not let any thing
pass to the prejudice of my Lady, the most beautiful that treads upon the
earth. Follow me then, answered the Damsel, to do her service. For yesterday
passing by a cross way, some three leagues from hence, I saw two pavillions
set up, a number of shields hanging upon the next trees, and lances enough to
maintain a passage for three months space, which made me draw nearer to hear
what all this preparation intended; and seeing a Squire issue forth of one of
the pavillions, I made a sign to him that he should come and speak with me,
which in a very civil fashion he did, and told me, that his Mistress, whom he
would by no means name, though I diverse times entreated him unto it, being
passionately in love with one that was called the fair Knight, had engaged him
to maintain a Just in her favor; to which end she was come near unto
Constantinople, in hope that the Greek Princes hearing of it, would come to a
tri^ll with her Knight, whom she held to be the most valorous in the world, as
without question he is the most lovely of all that this day lives: whereby this
warrior should gain immortal praise, and that she should have a sh^re in the
glory which he acquired by his valor, as being the principal cause thereof.
These words begetting a desire in me to see this Knight, I freely went into his
tent, where seeing him with his head unarmed, I indeed observed in him so
pleasing an eye, a beauty so lovely, and so goodly a presence, as I may with
truth aver, that I had never beheld any thing more ami^ble. But that which
exeedingly vexed me, was, to see, that the Lady, in whose favor he had taken
up arms, had not any one of those perfections. Her face was pale and lean, no
charms were in her eyes, no grace in her actions: her stature was defect^ve,
her smiles unbecoming, and her voice harsh and unpleasant. In brief, observing
all this in her, I could not forbear laughing, and withal told that gallant
Knight, how his valor was ill employed, how he should never gain much glory by
his labor, having undertaken it upon an occasion that could not deserve it,
and that being sensible of the injury which he did to all the fair ones that
passed by, rendering them subject to acknowledge the pre-eminence of a creature
so little advantaged by nature, I would go to the Court of Greece, to require
reason for this injustice. And indeed I am now here for no other cause, but
only to carry you with me to revenge the wrong of those that have merits in
them, and particularly of the fair one whom you adore with so much respect and
love. I was never more willing to put on Arms, said Prigmaleon, then now, that
my Ladies beauty is in question. Let us go then, Gentlewoman, and we shall know
ere it be long, if this Knight be as valiant and strong as you think him
lovely. Whereupon having called for a horse, he mounted on him, departed with
the Damsel, and traveled till night, which constrained him to rest under
certain trees, and to sup with the provision which his squire had brought.

When it grew dark, the damsel whom the good grace and convers^tion of the
Knight had made very much in love with him, seeing him withdraw apart from her
to sleep, and not approving that reservednesse which in her heart she called
simplicity, she followed him, and lying down by him said: In faith, I must
complain of your neglect of me, and not forbear telling you that you want
judgment in not making use of time, occasion, and of the good will of a w^nch,
that loves you with p^ssion; what sense were it to pass the night in
languishing, when we may make it full of content? Entertain the good fortune
that presents it self to you, and do not foolishly imagine as the most part of
our Greek Princes do (who are more gloriously proud of their loialty in love,
then of all the great things which they have done in arms) that to afford any
part of your affection to more then one, is in any kind of fault. It is an
error, at which those of little judgment do stumble, and which the more
discreet do laugh at. I will mingle so much sweetness with my kisses, and
such dalliance with my caresses, as you shall with reason think your self happy
in so favorable an encounter. Suffer then our lips to meet, receive my
embraces, and do not disdain a love because it is freely proffered you. Do not
believe, answered Prigmaleon, extremely amazed to see himself thus assaulted;
Do not I say, believe, if I answer not your desire, that it is out of the
consideration of the liberty which you take in discovering your passions: I
know how weak men are when love has resolved to master them, and that it is
not in their power to govern their passions, if once they have submitted them
to the tyranny of so great a power; and yet less then that would I have you
believe, that I entend to follow any man for a pattern of my actions, for they
shall ever depend only upon my own humor: but to tell you freely what is in
my heart, I cannot make use of your good will, because I do infinitely love a
Lady, that permits me not so to dispose of my will, as you, without doubt,
neither could now love the first that should present himself to you. Let this
reason serve for my excuse, and do not, I pray you, call me ungrateful. The
service that I will do you with my arms, shall make amends for this default; in
the mean time if you have a mind to tarry here, I will remove further, that I
may not trouble your repose. Thus it is, said she in choler, that poor
spirits use to excuse themselves. Sleep, since you care more for a nap, then
you do for my life. The Gods who are always just, will one time or other
revenge your despising of me, and make you thoroughly feel the pain that I suffer
by your ingratitude. Saying so, she withdrew under another tree with extreme
discontent, leaving Prigmaleon in no less disquiet of mind: for remembering his
Polixena, from whom he durst not assure himself a better entertainment then
now he had given that amorous damsel, he never could shut his eyes; and in
that trouble he continued, till the sun being risen made him get to horse,
where entering into a forest, that befell him, which shall be deliverd to you
in the next Chapter.

CHAP. XLI. Prigmaleon meets with Melina; she gives him an account of Griolanis
his fortunes, with the issue of the combat between him and the Knight of the
Savage.
PRigmaleon traveling in the forest, under the shadow of the trees,
entertained himself with his ordinary fancies, and thought of nothing less
then the damsel, which still followed him, though it were with much
discontent; and ashamed for having been so refused, when as on the sudden he
heard the voice of a person, who seemed to be much afflicted. Those laments
coming to his ear, put him out of his musing, and made him presently go to a
bush, from whence the noise did come; where at the foot of it he saw a Lady,
that holding a poniard in her hand, spoke these words: Melina it is time for
thee to die, since thy Knight is lost; for thy days would be but anguish, and
every thought of him an insupportable torture, when thou shall remember that
thou were the cause of his death, by putting him upon a business, which could no
way conduce to thy content. It had been much better done to have kept him
still in thy house, amidst a thousand pleasures, then to carry him abroad to
the hazard of his life. But since this mischief is not to be remedied, thy
desire to accompany him, must be without fear; neither must thou shrink from
death to follow him. Lifting up then her hands, she was ready to strike the
dagger into her bosom, if Prigmaleon, who perceived her intent, and therefore
was lighted from his horse, had not suddenly laid hold of her; and remonstrated
that despair was a greater offense, then that for which she so much sorrowed.
Stay Madam, said he, stay your hand, I beseech you, and do not in this sort run
headlong to perdition. The shortest follies are the best; and when you have
well considered that the shedding of your blood, will not restore him to life,
whose death you lament, you will, without doubt preserve it; and believe that
it were better to appease his ghost with some other kind of duty, then to
incense the Gods with a new murder. Alas! answered she, looking upon him, if
you knew the occasion I have to desire to die, you would not now divert me from
this design. I do not doubt, said he, but the cause of your grief is very
important, but yet I say that it ought not to transport you from your reason;
and if you could give your self some relaxation in imparting it to me, you
should do much for my satisfaction, and perhaps not a little for the ease of
your mind. I am content to do it, answered she, letting the poniard go, but it
shall be upon condition, that you shall leave me at liberty to do what I
please, if you find the occasions that I have to be just. Prigmaleon having
promised her not to cross her will, provided he might do it with reason, she
sat down upon the grass, and thus began her discourse. Walking one evening in
a wood near the house, in which I am ordinarily resident, I met a Knight, who
being strayed out of his way, did so courteously entreat me to grant him lodging
for that night, as beside the law of charity, which does bind us not to refuse
our help to those that do need it: I felt my self also forced by the fair
language, and by the grace that he used in his request, to give him my hand,
and to lead him to my house, assuring him that there he should receive the best
entertainmen^ that I could possibly give him. As soon as we were come there,
and that by the light of the torches I had seen his face, I found him so
lovely, and all h^^ actions so pleased me, that not to dissemble, I could not
keep my self from falling in love with him. I then made him to be served at the
Table, and sometimes serving him my self with the strength of my affection, I
so obliged him to my courtesy, that assuredly he did bear me some good will,
which infinitely rejoiced me; but fearing to lose him, as soon as I had gotten
him, my contentment was thereby much weakened: To remedy that doubt, I resolved
to arrest him with my caresses, I mean, to give my self wholly to him without
any reservation at all. Taking him then by the hand, after he had supped, I
went and fate down with him upon the beds feet, besought him to tell me his
name, his quality, and passing from those ordinary terms to those of love, I
made an ostentation, not of my bounty, for of that his eyes could be judge, but
of my birth and quality, eminent enough for the ambition of any Knight, that
were not a Prince; the conveniences that I was Mistrisse of, my estate, my
humor not unpleasing: and briefly, all that came in my head, and which I
believed might serve to make him to affect me; but fearing all these charms
would not be able to stay him, I entreated him to grant me one favor, which I
intended to desire of him.

The entertainment, said he, which I have here received from you, does not
permit me to be ungrateful in refusing you; Madam, you shall have of me all
that you please to command. As for the first point of your desire, I will tell
you freely, that I am called Griolanis, born in Macedon, of parents unto whom
fortune truly has done wrong in not conferring scepters on them for a
recompense of their virtue; I travel through the world to purchase glory, and
raise my ambition beyond the limits of my birth, and should reckon my self most
happy, if I might deserve the greatness of your fortune in possessing of you;
but not thinking it fit to aim so high, before my valor has made me worthy of
so great a favor, I will put off the further treating thereof till some other
time, and in the mean while beseech you to let me freely know what you desire
of me. To have you maintain a justs in favor of me, answered I, exceedingly
satisfied with his discourse, which confirmed my hope, not in this Castle, but
near Constantinople, that the glory of my beauty may flee about, together with
the praise which you will acquire by your noble deeds. Your request, said he,
is so much to my advantage, as I will not fear to entreat you that we may be
gone about it in the morning. This answer having quieted my mind, I brought
him to his chamber, where I left him to take his rest, and having given order
for some affairs of mine, after Sunrising I departed with him, and came to a
cross way not far from hence, where this fair Knight, for three weeks space,
acted wonders, and won such glory, that round about there was no talk save of
him; but the Destinies, envying my content, brought a Knight to us yesterday,
that bare a Savage in his shield, who defied my lover upon the injustice of his
enterprise. Griolanis always accustomed to be conqueror, judging by the
aspect of his adversary, that he was like to be very valiant, to^k the
strongest lance that he had, and set himself over against this his able enemy,
who seeing him dislodge, set spurs to his horse, and incountered him with such
fury, as he laid him on the ground; but Griolanis his blows, being not easily
born, he of the Savage also lost his saddle, and all amazed lay in the dust.
Choler then having quickly raised these two brave warriors, they prepresently
drew their swords, and so stoutly charged one another, that all the wood
resounded with it; I saw their heads continually covered with fire, pieces of
their armor fell to the ground; if one struck with force, the other with
dexterity rebated it; blows followed thrusts, their shields were so hewed, that
but a little of them was left upon their arms, their helmets were all battered,
their cuirasses pierced, and the grass was stained with their blood; as often
as the Knight of the Savage advanced his sword, I grew pale, and lifting mine
eyes to heaven implored the aid of the Gods for my Knight; I was many times
rising to part them, and instantly fell down again with fear and weakness;
briefly, I beheld this combat more dead then alive. Six howrs now being spent
between them in this fashion, and yet no advantage to be discerned on either
side, both quitted their swords, and taking one another about the middle, they
fell to wrestling together with extreme fury; sometimes one was above,
sometimes another; so that having toiled thus a while with incredible despite
to see their victory no more advanced, they by a mutual consent arose, and
taking their swords again, renewed the combat in a crueller and more fearful
manner then before: Griolanis did his part to the height, and well declared
that he was one of the prime Knights in the world: but the Savage was nothing
behind him. So that having continued the fight in this sort, three or four
hours longer, they advanced both their swords, and at one and the same instant
discharged them with such violence on each other, as Griolanis not able to
support the weight of the blow, fell to the ground quite deprived of sense,
just as his enemy staggering did the like. The fall of these two Knights so
amazed me, as I was not able to go presently to Griolanis* but love prevailing
over fear, I at last arose, and being about to unlace his helmet, I saw two
women come riding in a Caroch, who taking them both up, put them into it, and
then immediately going in themselves, without speaking a word to me, went their
ways with such speed, as that, and the astonishment wherein I was, made me
that I could not observe what way they took. But having within a while
recovered my spirits, I made a horse be brought me, and getting up, I put my
self into the wood, and sought them all the night, without hearing any news
of them. From hence proceeds my resolution to dye: for since Griolanis lives
not, what should I do in the world? So holding her peace, she went to seeking
of her poniard; but Prigmaleon fell again to comfort her, and so powerfully
prevailed with her, as in the end she promised him to do no violence upon
herself: whereupon bidding the Damsel that followed him farewell, since the
occasion of his journey was removed, he returned to Constantinople, where we
will give him leisure to relate what he had learned from the Gentlewoman, to
speak of these two incomparable warriors.

CHAP. XLII. What became of Griolanis and him of the wild man after their
combat.
THE combat between these two valiant Knights being ended, as I have told you,
Alcander, in whose power they were, and that desired their preservation, as
much importing the good of Christendom, placed them separately in a palace,
which (by the power of his charms) he made appear in a large plain; and having
rubbed them with an excellent Balsamum, he let them sleep all the night; at the
end whereof, and about the time when the Sun began to gild the earth, Grian
awaking, was strangely amazed to see himself laid in a very rich bed, and not
to feel any pain of his wounds, received in the combat the day before, which he
had not forgotten. O me! said he, casting his eye on every side, and perceiving
nothing but gold and azure, parting a number of excellent pictures that filled
the room where he was. What do I see? Where am I, or who could bring me into a
place of such delicacie? I remember very well, that I fought with one of the
valiantest Knights of the world, and that his sword had pierced my flesh in a
number of places, yet now I feel not a wound, nor can I imagine how we were
pa^ted, nor who could bring me hither: Certainly this is very mavelous! But I
may quickly free my self of all doubt: This stately Palace, is not without
inhabitants, and I shall surely find some body in it, that will inform me how
things have past: Leaping then out of his bed, he took certain clothes that lay
upon a table, and having put them on, he went down into a dainty garden, where
all the excellent flowers of the earth were set in a most strange and
artificial order; he beheld with admiration a multitude of trees, laden with
all manner of fruit, heard with pleasure the music of a million of birds, who
seemed to strive for to render that place most delectable; and viewed with
wonder, a many of fountains, which made a fair lake, wherein a world of swans
did sport themselves: but that which he thought the greatest wonder, was that,
among all these rarities, he found not any one person of whom he might be
satisfied in what he desire^d: In the end, having visited all the allies, he
saw come forth from the other side of the house a Gentleman, so handsome; of so
sweet a countenance, and of so brave a presence, as he believed that nature was
not able to frame such another piece; his carriage exceedingly pleasing him, he
went to salute him, and not knowing him for that incomparable warrior, that had
made him so sweat in his armor the day before, he said to him: Sir, you shall
much oblige me if you will be pleased to tell me where I am, and who is the
Master of this place. Verily, answered the fair Knight, I am in the same
trouble that you are, and being here without knowing how I came hither, was
seeking some body that might satisfy me in what you enquire after. As far as I
perceive, said Grien, our case is much one, and since a like fortune has made
us (not expecting it) to encounter thus, a like means, it may be, will make us
find the cause of it: Yet me thinks I see a man under those trees; let us, I
pray you, go to him, he may perhaps satisfy our desire: The Knight then, who
was no other then Griolanis, looking behind him, spied an old man coming
toward them, of a tall stature, in whose face appeared a Majesty not common
with other men, who when heapproached to them, said: Sir Knights, your meeting
does yield me matchless contentment, for seeing you so kind friends after so
great an animosity, I may with reason esteem my self happy, that I have
entertained you in my house. For my part, said Griolanis, who by those words
knew that this Knight whom he beheld, was the redoubted Knight of the Savage,
that had so late made him despair of his life, I can bear no ill will to this
brave warrior, out of the consideration of our late combat; but if he please to
love me, I shall gladly do him all service. Love you, said Grian, yes without
question I will love you, for it were a crime to hate your virtue; believe it
then that I am wholly yours: Whereupon, they embraced one another with as much
affection as could be desired, which so contented Alcander, that carrying them
into a Cabinet, after he had royally feasted them, with abundance of delicate
meats, he thus spoke to them: Brave warriors, be not amazed at what you have
lately seen; the heavens, that would have you preserved for their glory, made
me yesterday seek to save you in a time when you had little reason to hope for
it; your choler brought you even to deaths door, my care has returned you back
from it, seek not any occasion of difference hereafter; but rather employ those
mighty abilities which God has endowed you with, to the ruin of those that
would overthrow his religion, he will reward your zeal, and you shall see a
happy end of all your enterprises. At these words he vanished out of their
fight, those stately buildings were now no more to be seen, those delicious
gardens changed their form, the Knights found themselves mounted upon their
horses, and armed at all pieces, exceedingly astonished at that which had
befallen them: But not forgetting the counsel that had been given them, they
again protested to love one another eternally; and taking the first way that
came to hand, they went directly to Constantinople, as you shall see in the
Chapter ensuing.

CHAP. XLIII. The Princes of Greece are disinchanted: Rozalmond of Greece
departs with Alcander: the brave deeds of Arms at the Tourney that was made
upon the Knighting of the young Princes.
TEN days being insensibly past away since the enchantment of the Princes and
Ladies of Greece, Cassandra, who knew the time fit for their deliverance,
called together all the rest that were not there enclosed, took Rozalmond of
Greece in one hand, and the fair Polixena by the other, and leading them very
near the Arches, made them cast certain vials upon them, full of a mavelous
water; which donethey heard a multitude of sweet voices, that ravished the
ears of all that were present: whilst all the Court expected the issue of so
many wonders, whilst the cloud was dispersing, and that they began to behold
that admirable fountain, Rozalmond, by the advice of Cassandra, laid hold of a
rich sword, which was found planted between the Arches, and having easily pulled
it out, with the pommell of it struck such a blow upon the enchanted coffer, as
he brake it in a thousand pieces; which were no sooner on the ground, but he
was seen covered with the richest Armor, and of the strongest fashion that was
ever seen: It was made of the bones of a fish that is found in the Atlantike
sea, white as snow, and harder then a Diamond: the joints thereof were overlaid
with precious stones of a strange workmanship; and that which most showed it
self, was the gold, curiously inlaid, and parting a thousand delicate figures.
This being done in view of all that were in the great Court of the Palace,
every one with impatience attended what would be the end of this adventure;
when as they saw four fearful Dragons appear in the air, that drawing after
them a great Chariot, went and took their stand before the Arches, with such
an aff^ighting of the people, that every one for his ^afety was about to run
away, had they not beheld the venerable Alcander on the one side, coming out
in the head of all those Princes; and on the other side Vrganda, a little
before those excellent Q^eens. That object assured all the world, but a new
occasion of astonishment and displeasure, troubled them anew: Alcander,
Vrganda, the young Cassandra and Rozalmond, entered into the chair, and in few
words bidding all those Princes farewell, were carried into the clouds, with
such speed, as no man could make them any answer. Sosudden a departure would
certainly have very much discontented all the Court, if that young Prince had
been in the power of anyother. But every one being assured that those Sages had
not carried him away in that sort, but for his honor, they showed but little
grief for his absence, especially Florisel and the rest of those Princes, who
seeing themselves without wrinkles, and with the same beauty and abilities
which they had when they were five and twenty years old, did view themselves
with wonder, and could not tell how to comprehend such prodigious things. All
men cast their eyes upon the fair Queen of France, who having the same charms
about her, that she had when she was called the Basiliske of mankind, struck
every eye with infinite amazement: they also admired the renewed beauty of the
excellent Queen of Guindaya, of the matchless Alastraxarea, which had for so
long a time kept the Prince of Colchos her idolatrizer, of the fair Empress
of Persia, the peerlesse Empress of the Parthians, and the Infanta Rozaliana
her sister: and in brief, of them all, who had as well as they experienced how
far the power of Alcander* extended. Dorigel and the rest were no less
transported with beholding so great a change in those Princes: they did nothing
but caresse them every minute, they redoubled their kisses and embraces; and
not knowing how to put an end to their complements, spoke the same thing a
thousand times over. All being thus set upon pleasure, the young Princes who as
yet were not knighted, desiring to demonstrate that they were no less joyful
then the rest, presented themselves upon their knees together, all armed in
white armor, before Florisel of Niquea, and by Persides, whom they had made
their spokesman, thus delivered their request. Excellent Prince, it is time
that we should appear in the world as you have done, and by a trial in sport,
give an essay of our Arms, and testify how much we rejoice to see you in that
estate you are in. Be pleased to make us Knights, we are in case to receive
that sacred Order, and determined to fight so well, that you shall not grieve
to acknowledge we are descended of your race. My good children, (said Florisel,
who was highly pleased to see them in that sort) this generous disposition does
so content us, as notwithstanding your youth* I will not delay the giving you
satisfaction. Swear then all of you, with one accord, that you will not at any
time fail to succor the weak, such as are oppressed, but principally women.
When they had all promised rather to dye then be wanting to the duty of a good
Knight, he gave them his benediction, knighted them, and left it to their
choice to receive the sword from the hand of any of the Princesses they best
liked. That done, he turned himself afresh, to make much of his friends, who
seemed to be transported beyond all joy. These new Knights rising from their
knees, with incredible satisfaction, for that they had met with so little
difficulty in their design, went to take a slight repast with the Emperors;
and having fitted themselves with all that was necessary, entered the list,
where Prigmaleon being chosen for the Captain of two hundred Greek Knights* in
the head of whom were Russian, Fulgoran, Esquilan, Florizart, Abies, Frizel,
Leonidas, Armond and Melfort; and Persides with the like number of French and
Persians, assisted by his brother Floridan, Rozanel d'Astre, Lucibel,
Sestilian, Perion, Florian, Tristor, Quedragant, Dardanio and the gentle
Florestan of Sardinia. Upon the third sound of the trumpet they began the
bravest course in the world, Persides, Floridan, Rozanel and the young Prince
of France, brake very gallantly upon the Emperor of Aethiopia, Fulgoran,
Russian of Media, and the stout Polonian. And passing forwards without once
bending in the faddle, for all the encounter of four such famous warriors,
they bravely set hand to their swords, wherewith they began to clear the
ranks, in such sort, as already men fore-judged that with time they would
prove equal with the prime Knights of the world: Every blow that they gave,
laid a man upon the ground, and nothing could have stood before them, if the
same four with whom they ran their courses, had not opposed themselves, and
arrested their fury. The brave bastard of Media having Persides in hand,
charged him with very much force and grace; but his enemy behaved himself so
well, as he was esteemed no less valiant then himself. Prigmaleon, being
opposed to Rozanel, confessed, that he had never seen a man more active, or
more able. And the valiant Princes of Canabea, and Poland, had enough to do to
ward the blows which Lucibel and Floridan laid incessantly upon them.

The honor of the victory being generally disputed by these young Lords,
everyone was highly delighted with their behavior, and more then all the rest,
the Princes of Greece, who observing them with wonder, and infinitely admiring
such ability in tender years, did heartily wish that the honor of the tourney
might be theirs, which undoubtedly had befallen them, notwithstanding all that
Melfort and the rest could do, who by little and little yielded to the blows of
Sestilian, which that day gave great proof of an admirable valor, when as they
saw two Knights enter the field in watchet arms, so gentile, and so gallantly
seated in their saddles, that all men had a good opinion of them; their
graceful carriage drawing the most part of the assistants to observe them, it
was quickly known, by a Savage appearing in a shield of one of them, that they
were the famous Grian, and the fair Knight, of whom such miracles had been
reported. These two warriors seeing that every body observed them with
expectation of what they would do, couched their lances, and taking part with
the weaker side, at the first course laid Perion of Turkey, and Florestan in the
dust; and drawing forth their swords, in a moment overthrew Florian, Trist^r,
and Dardanio, which so encouraged the side that saw themselves so well
assisted, as they had made their enemies to give ground, if Persides and
Rozanel, enraged at it, had not astonished Russian and Prigmaleon with each of
them a blow; these two young warriors, seeing the disorder which these new
comers caused in their troops, charged them with strange fury; but the two
invincible Knights received them so bravely, as every one began to behold them
with admiration: Persides, who remembered the glory that his father had gained
in the hardest enterprises, charged him with such mighty blows, as a man of
less abilities could never have sustained them: But Grian, whom he had to deal
with, that was not to be moved with a little, held him so short, as he made him
despair of the victory. On the other side, Rozanel and Griolanis entreated one
another with a like fury; their swords were perpetually in motion, their
shields fell in pieces, and a thousand flames flew continually about their
heads: If fear of being overcome rendered the Greek Princes strong and hardy,
the desire which the others had of acquiring glory in the presence of the most
gallant warriors of the world, did so inflame their courages, as their blows
seemed lightening which falls from heaven upon the highest tow^^. At length the
combat having lasted above an howr, Grian madded that he met with so strong
resistance, delivered so weighty a blow upon Don Persides his helmet, that he
made his head touch the crupper of his horse; then flying into the midst of the
troops, he met with the valiant Esquilan, upon whose shield he discharged so
^uriously, as he laid him in the dust; and not satisfied therewith, he ran in
among the rest, intending to have used them in the like sort, but that he met
with Griolanis, who having overthrown his adversary, deprived Florizart and
Leo^id^^ of sense, went out of the field with him upon hearing of the trumpet,
which sounded a re^reat: Spurring then together out of the lists, they took the
way to the forest, leaving a wonderful admiration in the Greek Princes of
their valor, and mighty displeasure in the mind of those young Princes, who
had been so roughly handled by them. Four of which, that is to say, Lucibel,
Persides, Prigmaleon, and Russian, presently followed them, with a resolution
to die, or revenge the disgrace they had received.

The end of the first Part.
THE LOVE AND ARMS OF THE GREEK PRINCES.

OR, THE ROMANT OF ROMANTS.

Written in French by Monsieur Verdere, And Translated for the Right
Honorable, Philip, Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery, Lord Chamberlain to his
Majesty.

Tome II.

HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE
printer's or publisher's device

LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper, for Thomas Walkley, and are to be sold at
his Shop at the sign of the flying Horse, near York House, 1640*

CHAP. I. Rozalmond of Greece being carried by Alcanders Griffons, arrives in
the Empire of Gardacia, receives the order of Knighthood from the Emperor, and
is entertained by the beautiful Armazia, for her Knight.
ROzalmond of Greece being carried by Alcanders Griffons (as I have delivered
in the last Chapter of our first Part) divided the air with an incredible
content to behold the disposing of the earth and the seas, together with the
order which nature observed in their situation; If the waters seemed pleasing
unto him in their calm, and under the shadow of a multitude of sails which the
winds drove sundry ways; the earth separated by mountains covered with trees,
by valleies which amiable streams peopled with flowrs, and by plains delectable
in the division of towns and fruits wherwithall they were charged, gave him no
less delight, and left him in a deep astonishment to view over all the
marveilous effects of the powerful hand of God. Two days being sweetly spent
in this manner, Alcander (who disposed of his leisure according to the event of
things which he fore saw by an admirable knowledge) caused his Griffons to stay
in the unknown Island of the sage Vrganda, and alighting with her and leaving
Rozalmond in the Chariot, accompanied with the fair Cassandra, he said unto
him: Excellent Prince, it is time to give a beginning to the wonders which your
valor is to bring into the world, your labors shall be great, but as great
shall be your reward, and the glory you shall reap by them will make them so
acceptable unto you that in stead of being danted with the pains you will every
day seek new occasions to employ your self and render your name more famous. I
will not speak here of the care you are to have of the service of God, knowing
full well that your good education has not been without that instruction, and
less will I recommend those parts unto your memory which a good Knight ought
to be endued withal, the greatness of your birth having naturally given you a
powerful impression of virtue; but I earnestly beseech you not to abandon the
counsel which this damsel your follower shall give you, until such time as
your destiny shall call you to the place where her presence can no longer serve
you: Her parents have always watched for the safety of your predecessors, she
shall continue the same care, and her succor shall be no less importing your
enterprises, then that of her mothers was to the designs of Amadis the Great.
At these words the Griffons extending forth their wings, rose up so suddenly,
that Rozalmond had not time to render the thanks which he thought was due to
the affection of this man: wherwithall undoubtedly he had been much
discontented if Cassandra had not advertised him that so sudden a departure was
not without some secret mystery. Comforting himself then with his
entertainment, three days past away with the same delight as before, at the
end whereof he saw the Griffons, which drew him gently to stay their flight,
and alight down near to a city, the stateliest and most delectable that ever he
had beheld; it being composed of beautiful buildings, framed after another
fashion then at Constantinople, or in the Empire of the Parthians, where he had
been brought up. This ^ovelty pleasing him, his eyes were diversely carried
according to the variety of the objects, which ravished him in such sort, that
he never thought of alighting out of his chariot; but Cassandra taking him by
the hand to divert him from so profound a thought, said unto him; It is no
time, brave Prince, it is no time to wonder at such petty matters, by and by
you will see far greater marvells: only let us enter into the city, and be
mindful to reserve so much power over your self, that you fail in nothing when
you come before an Emperor that is to make you Knight, and are to appear
before the fairest Princess of the world, who will this day triumph as much
over you, as you in time to come shall triumph over the greatest Knights of the
earth. I should fear the encounter of these persons (answered he) if I did not
march under your conduct; but Madam, what appearance is there that I can fail in
your presence, or that my passion should transport me so far as to forget my
duty? I know how to carry my self toward persons of the quality of this
Emperor, and how a Princess of her merit, whom you so highly commend, is to
be admired; so that if I must learn to love, time and my fidelity shall one day
make me expert: in the mean season, I will never be troubled to see her sigh
for another, and reject my services; for if her heart be other ways engaged,
you have charms of power to alter her mind, and to subject her unto me in
despite of her ablest resistance. Your merits can do more (said Cassandra)
then my Art: But not to loose time, give me your sword and helmet, and let us
go on. Then advancing toward the city, they went unto the Palace, before which
they found four hundred Knights all armed, and mounted in such sort, as if they
had been ready to charge some enemy. This encounter amazed them, and they could
willingly have stayed to demand what occasion had assembled them in that
manner; but fearing to offend by this curiosity, they past on, and mounting up
the stairs, came into the hall, where the first object they met withal, was
an old man, high seated in a throne of gold, wearing an Imperial diadem on his
head, having by his side a wife of his own age, and a little below a daughter
so fair, that nature seemed to have employed all the power she had left for to
make her accomplished. Rozalmond who had propounded a world of assurance in his
actions unto himself, beholding a beauty so rare and excellent, made a stand in
the midst of the hall, as if he would have taken time to admire her; but
instantly remembering Cassandra's advice, he continued his pace with a sweet
modesty; and seeing himself at the foot of the throne, he kneeled down, where
with an admirable grace craving the Emperors hand to kiss, he besought him
not to refuse him one boon he would demand of him. You shall have it (said the
Emperor, rising out of his seat for to embrace him, with astonishment at his
so extraordinary feature) and I will never refuse a gentleman of so goodly a
presence as yours, albeit my scepter and my crown were at stake for it. I am
not here to ask riches of you (said Rozalmond) Fortune does give them to us
when we have deserved them, and a man ought to be contented when he is
virtuous, but I am now at your Majesty's feet to obtain the power to employ
these arms upon my back; first, for the service of God, and then for the
succor of those which shall be any ways afflicted: In a word, Sir, I desire
you, if you please to make me Knight, to the end I may in some sort imitate my
Ancestors, who by their worthy acts have acquired immortal glory in the
world. Your demand seems so just (answered the Emperor) that I should hold it
a very great error to deny you; but it grives me not a little, noble Sir, that
I cannot give you so sacred an order with those ceremonies I desire, for having
so just an occasion to be afflicted, by reason of the importunity of an
accident, that now lies heavy upon me, I cannot any way show that joy which
otherwise I would. The silence I every where observe (said Rozalmond) and that
array wherein I beheld some of your people, made me think that you had some
great affair in hand, but I could not imagine, Sir, that your Majesty being so
puissant in friends, in means, in men, could fear any disaster whatsoever:
howbeit, now I learn that the highest are most subject to mishap, and your
affliction makes me say, that the condition of men is miserable, seeing it
depends only upon fortune: the most violent diseases find their remedies, so
shall your grief ere it be long, and time shall restore you to your former
peace. The Gods (said the Emperor, shedding some tears) shall if it be their
pleasures authorize your words and my wishes, and take pity of my suffering,
whilst I comfort my self in that hope. And that you may not complain of me, I
will make you Knight yet before dinner, since you desire it so much. Then
taking him by the hand, he led him to the Temple, where his Gods were
worshipped, and giving him the Oath, he made him Knight after his fashion. All
the while the Ceremonies were in doing, Rozalmond had his eyes firmly fixed on
this beauteous Princess, whom his soul already adored; and perceiving her
looks in like manner to be fastened on him, as amazed at the goodlinesse of his
person, he kneeled down before her, and said; Madam, there is but one thing now
wanting to make me completely happy, namely, that I may receive the sword from
you, who are, in my judgment, the fairest Lady in the world, as I have
received the Order from the greatest Emperor of the earth; this favor will so
encourage me in the midst of dangers, that I shall draw glory out of the most
difficile enterprises. Would to the Gods (said she, amorously sighing) that
this were able to add any thing to your valor; be assured then, Sir Knight,
that your good fortune should begin with mine own preservation, and that I
would give you forces sufficient to draw us out of the perplexity wherein we
are now so miserably plunged; but knowing mine own weakness, and the little
power I have in the world, I can hope for nothing that way: nevertheles, not to
be so far ungrateful, as to refuse you any thing which may become me to grant
you, I will willingly gird you with the sword, and withal humbly beseech the
Gods, that you may worthily employ it, for the glory of their Altars, and the
succor of the afflicted; saying so, she took it from the sage Cassandra, hung
it at his girdle, and presently would have retired; but the love of this new
Knight was more, then to leave her with any distaste for want of an answer: so
that bowing himself, and kissing her hand, he said unto her; Excellent Lady, I
may truly say, that the bravest Knights of the earth never received favors
equal to those you have been graciously pleased to confer on me this day, but
render my content perfect, I beseech you, and permit me to importune you so
far, as to demand why you told me that my good fortune should begin with your
preservation, if you could add any thing to my forces; for it is just, that I
serve you at this time with the sword wherewithal you have armed me, and I
should find supreme glory in the commandment which you should be pleased to
lay upon me, for to undertake some combat, with the title of your Knight. If I
did not value your life (replied she with a delicate blush, and a little
withdrawing her self aside) I should make no difficulty to expose you to the
fury of a man, the most redoubted of the earth; who lately encountering the
Emperor my father in a forest, whither for his pleasure he was gone to hunt,
cut an hundred Knights, which accompanied him, in pieces; and having struck him
down with a blow of his sword, made him promise that I should be the price of
his life and liberty, and that he should marry me within fifteen days; but
desiring to reserve you for an affair less dangerous, if I cannot avoid this,
I will never permit you to engage your self so rashly, and I shall be very well
contented that you will leave this controversy to be decided by all those
Cavaliers, whom you saw before the Court gate when you entered in. I do not
think (answered Rozalmond) that the promise of all the Empires in the world
would be half so dear to me, as the assurance which you have now given of your
fair respect to me. But, Madam, could I merit this grace, or could you ever
regard me, if I should be so base as to leave the glory of your service to
another? That shall never be, and well might you repute me most unworthy of
your esteem, if this occasion should pass over so. My virtue must give me this
treasure, and my valor must make me the lawful master of it; your enemy is a
man, and consequently subject to the same accidents which thwart others; I will
see him, not with those armed troops, but alone; to the end that the reputation
of his defeat may not be divided with others; I most humbly beseech you
therefore not to respect my life, which cannot be more generously employed, and
be confident, that marching for your interest, you will receive satisfaction
from my enterprise. These words pronounced with more then an ordinary grace of
spirit, gave much content to the Princess, who took them for powerful
testimonies of love; but her affection making her apprehensive of his loss,
she was about to have commanded him not to undertake this combat, when as the
Emperor sent for him to sit down at the table, who not enduring to hear the
sighs of the afflicted people amidst his own joy, seeing the meat come in, he
went and kneeling down before the Emperor, said unto him: Mighty Prince, the
honor that you have done me this day, obliges me to take part of your
distress, nor will it permit me to quit these arms until I have employed
them against this barbarous stranger, who thus disquiets you. He is before the
walls of the Town, and it is said, that he has made a vow never to depart
thence till you have performed your promise; let us make good his words, and
permit me to send him to a grave, rather then into the arms of a creature so
divine, from whom he does not merit so much as a look: I am in case to fight,
there is yet day enough, if he have much strength, I do not want courage; make
use, Sir, of a stranger, who has not the honor to be known of you, nor so
much as can tell where he is: If fortune prove mine enemy, you will be the
less sensible of my loss, in regard you know me not; and if the dice chance
to turn, from how much care will you be delivered. The knowledge which I have
(said the Emperor) of the incomparable forces of this warrior, will not suffer
me to permit you the combat with him, and the reasons you bring to persuade me
thereunto, are proper to disswademe from it; for if you undertake a business
out of the only pity which you have of my affliction, have not I much cause to
lament you, if for my sake you should die? Yea, I should bewail the loss of
you more then of a thousand other men, who it may be could attempt the danger
out of the hope of recompense, whereas you propound nothing to your self, but
the glory you expect from your travel: put your self in head of those armed
troops, that they may take assurance from this courage; this way you will much
more endear me unto you then any other. Sir (answered Rozalmond) the Knights of
our country never fight with advantage, at leastwise those who hope for honor
from their actions: your enemy is accompanied but with one Squire, and with
your favor I will carry none along with me but this damsel, who has always
followed me; only in regard I am on foot, permit me to choose an horse in your
stable. Seeing you will have it so (said the Emperor) I will no longer oppose
you, and the Gods I humbly beseech to favor your valor, and return you with
as much glory, as you have justice in this quarrel. This resolution of
Rozalmond, having astonished all the Knights of the Court, who beheld him as a
wonder, seeing with what confidence he went to affront a man, that scorned to
draw his sword against whole troops, greatly troubled the Princess, who
discontented with her fathers consent, would fain have drawn the Knight aside,
absolutely to forbid him the fight, but seeing she could not possibly do it
without discovering her affection, she was constrained to retire, and have
recourse unto tears for the easing of her grief.

CHAP. II. Rozalmond combats and defeats the dreadful Fulmigadan, who would
have married Armazia against her fathers will.
Whilst the Princess bewailed the loss of her Knight, which she held to be
inevitable, he went to find out his rival, with an incredible content for
that he had so suddenly met with an occasion to employ his sword for the
service of a beauty which his soul adored; but he was vexed with himself, for
that he had not been so curious as to demand her, and her fathers name.
Intertaining himself in this manner, the thought of his Mistress, from whose
fight he was not absented, made him fetch some sighs; whereupon, Cassandra
took occasion to say unto him; Ah Sir, did not I assure you that you should see
strange things to day, and you should not come out of the city again with the
same power you had of your self in the morning? You have been but too true
(answered he) for acknowledging my captivity, I may say to you, that now I have
seen the fairest thing in the world: But Madam, Why do you not tell me in what
country we are, the name of this courteous Prince who has made me Knight, and
that of this incomparable beauty, which has left me nothing free, but the will
to serve her? Why what important affair had you (answered Cassandra, smiling)
that hindered you from informing your self thereof? My passion, replied he, may
serve to excuse me for that: and I, said she, was restrained by the respect I
had, not to withdraw you out of the rapture, wherein the object of this
Princess had cast you: but to satisfy your desire, Know that you are now in
the mighty Empire of Gardacia, which is so far distant from the Kingdoms of
Christendom, that they have never heard so much as speak of it: the Sovereign
thereof is this Prince, by whom you were Knighted, valiant in his younger
years, and so redoubted by all his neighbors, that never any one durst offer
to trouble the quiet of his state, but Fulmigadan, the same against whom you
now go to fight: who not being able to look upon Armazia, so is your Mistress
named, without rendering unto her that which is due to her from all men in the
world, found means to surprise her father, and oblige him, by the restitution
of his liberty, to make him master of the felicities, which he imagines to
himself in the possession of a thing so rare: But it is time to leave off this
discourse for another, which touches you somewhat nearer; you are approaching
an enemy so p^issant and hardy, that the Emperor has, with a great deal of
reason, made difficulty to let you go single to so dangerous an enterprise:
howbeit, doubt not but this combat will bring you very much glory, so as you
call to mind the renown which your fathers have acquired in the world, and
that this affair does mainly import you, in regard it so much concerns Armazia,
who if she were in place where she might behold the fight, would questionless
much advantage you; for her presence would exceedingly augment your forces, and
give you far greater courage; wherefore I am minded to request so much of her
in your behalf. Then will you oblige me much more then you think for, said
Rozalmond, but I fear she will not willingly take so much pains. Leave me the
care of that, said Cassandra, and I am persuaded she will make no difficulty at
all of it. Whereupon returning presently to the Court, she went to Armazia in
her chamber, and perceiving some tears upon her cheeks, she said unto her;
Beauteous Princess, I imagine that the pity which you have of our Knight,
makes you lament his loss as inevitable, being to encounter Fulmigadan; but it
lies in you to hinder that mishap, and to make him this day triumph over so
brave an enemy. Would you know how? By not disdaining to appear upon the city
walls; your presence will animate his forces, redouble his courage, and I am
persuaded render him invincible; upon this favor, your own good and his life
depend: wherefore, Madam, seek assurance in his victory, as he will find
glory in your service; you shall not repent any pains you can take to go and
see him fight for you, for I am confident that you will return with more
content then you have grief at this present. I were not worthy to live, if I
would not contribute to mine own safety, answered she; Will my presence avail
this Knight, say you? It is most just that I give him this small satisfaction,
seeing he contemns his own life to save mine; let us go then when you please,
but with this assurance, that for everv drop of blood his enemies sword shall
draw from him, so many tears shall I shed: so being attended by certain Ladies,
she appeared upon the walls just at the time, when Rozalmond, being come to
Fulmigadan, said unto him. Knight, it is time for you to say, that Armazia is
too fair to fall into the power of a man so ill made as your self; she has
sent me hither to free you of the error you are in, that she may one day affect
you, howsoever her father has been constrained by fear to promise the
contrary; but thinking that these words would not be very pleasing unto you, I
am come provided to answer you other ways. What do I hear, said Fulmigadan in
wonderful fury, does Armazia disdain the honor of my favor, and do I see my
self defied by one man alone? O ye Gods! How will I be revenged on her and you
for this affront; but thou, insolent Knight, shall begin the dance for bringing
me so harsh a message. Saying so, he unsheathed a long and heavy Scimiter,
wherewithal he struck at Rozalmonds head, but he observing his action, threw
away his lance, and laying his hand suddenly on his sword, opposed his left arm
to the fury of the blow, which was so great, that it made him bow to the
crupper of his horse with extreme pain; but he presently settled himself again,
and desiring to be revenged, he struck him with such fury, that the Pagan
receiving the blow upon his shield, thought he had been under the ruins of a
tower overthrown by lightning, and indeed he so astonished him, that had it not
been for his horse that carried him away, Rozalmond, who had his sword aloft,
might easily have vanquished and slain him. This first blow amazing Armazia,
inflamed her with the love of this Knight, and m^de her wish that his enemy
might never come to himself again; but seeing him re-settle himself in his
saddle, and with a world of madness make head against his adversary, that
pursued him, her blood congealed in her vains, with the apprehension of so
mortal a blow as the in^initenesse of his choler did threaten, and in truth
the rage of the Pagan was such, that Rozalmonda arms, though the best of the
world, could not have resisted the fury of the blow; but lightly avoiding it,
and making use of the opportunity, he charged full upon the body of Fulmigadan,
which he opened, and gave passage to his blood to issue forth in great
abundance: Thus the battle waxing every minute hotter and hotter, the ground
was strewed with pieces of their armor, the grass was died with their blood,
and the sky enlightened with the fire which sparkled from their helmets, and
the encounter of their swords. If the force of Fulmlgadan seemed monstrous, no
less admirable appeared the address of his adversary, both in abating, and
shifting his blows; briefly, this combat brought a general astonishment, and
every one expected the end of it by some dreadful blow. In the mean time, the
two combatants charged one another with extreme fury, and taking no time to
breathe, so quick were their strokes, that their swords were neverseen but in
the air, or on their armor. Fulmigadan, far more enraged then can be expressed,
and striking with passion, and not with judgment, railed against heaven and
earth for producing a man so puissant and courageous, as to be able to
withstand his force, that made the whole world to shake; and seeing that four
hours were already spent since the combat first began, and yet had gotten no
advantage of his enemy, he gave such desperate blows that made Rozalmond amazed
at his fury; but being no less incensed to see that in the beginning of his
arms, the victory was so long disputed in the presence, and for the
preservation of Armazia, to whom his soul was so far engaged, he resolved
either to die, or suddenly to vanquish; clasping his sword then fast in his
hand, he began to press the Pagan with such terrible blows, that his forces
seemed to increase with his travel, whereat Fulmigadan was so transported with
rage, that he took his Scimiter in both his hands, and discharged it so
furiously upon Rozalmonds helmet, as it made him fall backward upon the crupper
of his horse, casting out great quantity of blood at his mouth, and nose;
whereupon every one thought him to be dead, and the Emperor commanded his
Knights to assail his enemy, who seemed to be all covered over with blood and
dust; but even as the troops were about to march, they beheld Rozalmond raise
himself up, and make toward Fulmigadan with such horrible fury, that he, who
contemned the dreadful thunder of the Gods, began to fear, seeing him arrive
with so much rage, and indeed the blow which he discharged on his head was
such, that it cleaved him down to the very shoulders, overthrowing him stark
dead to the ground. This victory thus generously obtained, brought a world of
contentment to the Emperor, but much more to the beautiful Armazia, who not
able to contain her joy, so published the praises of this Knight, as if she had
neither voice nor speech but for his glory; howbeit, every one thinking that
she did it in regard of the interest which she had in the death of Fulmigadan,
it was not supposed that her love made her speak in that manner, but she could
not possibly contain her self in the excess of her passion; for seeing
Rozalmond come with some wounds upon him, she made it appear that she would be
partaker of his pain, and not enduring to stay till the Emperor had
entertained and caressed him, she went, and with an amorous countenance asked
of him whether his wounds were dangerous. Madam, answered he, I am not so ill,
but that if I were to begin another combat for your service, I would most
gladly undertake it. The Gods, said she, forbid such another accident; you have
done so much this day that your name shall never die in this Empire, so long as
the world does last; but I fear I shall abuse your patience, if I do not permit
your wounds to be visited; wherefore I will leave you, having first entreated
you to make use of all things here, as if you were in your own house: the
obligation wherein we stand engaged unto you gives you this power, and commands
me to seek out the means to show my self acknowleding in particular, which
assure your self I will do; in the mean time have regard to your health; so
with most amourous looks she departed, leaving him more contented with the care
she had of him, then with a Monarchy. The Emperors Chyrurgeons being arrived,
would have dressed his wounds, but Cassandra desiring them to leave that unto
her, she caused him presently to be laid into a bed, and making use of a
precious balm, which she ordinarily carried about her, she willed him to rest
until such time as the medicine had wrought its operation.

CHAP. III. The discourse between Armazia and Rozalmond, the recipr^call
assurances of their loves: his departure from Cardacia, with the extreme
discontent of the Princess, and what were his adventures.
CAssandra leaving Rozalmond to his rest, walked into the orchard, where the
trees diversely ranged, yielded an incredible delight, and devising with her
self what means she might use to get from this Court without giving too much
discontent to these new lovers; she espied Armazia, who being carried with
clean contrary thoughts, was entertaining her self with the pleasure she
conceived to be in the possessing of a man, on whom the heavens seemed to have
conferred all the beauty, comeliness, and valor of the world. Should I not be
happy indeed (said she to her self) if this Knight were born for me, and should
I not have cause to praise my good fortune, if his condition should prove
equal to mine, that so my parents might one day grant me unto him in
recompense of his services? Yes no doubt, and I should think that my content
would surpass all the pleasures of the earth, nor would I envy the very glory
of the Gods: But alas, I am afraid, considering the misery derived unto us from
the fault of the first man, that Fortune has not given Scepters to his being,
and that in regard thereof he will be less acceptable to my father, who erring
with others, will more esteem greatness then virtue, and will make me wretched
in his avarice: Howbeit, I cannot think, that a valor so great, a countenance
so promising, a presence so amiable, and actions so majesticall, may possibly
be encountered in a vile and base person: Virtue delights in the highest places,
and does not communicate her self to such as know not how to acknowledge her;
it cannot be but that his birth does equal his merits, and sure I commit no
fault in loving him: nevertheless, it were not amiss to clear this point
instantly, and so free my self of this unquietness that thus afflicts me;
which may easily be done, for this damsel that follows him will not refuse, I
hope, to give me this satisfaction: I will send for her then, and under color
of informing my self of the fashions of his country, draw her to acquaint me
with that which I so much desire to know; whereupon, turning about to command
some of her women to fetch her unto her, she perceived her declining that walk,
as it were for fear to interrupt her in her meditations; wherewithal being
very glad, she called her unto her, and taking her by the hand, said thus;
Sweet heart, you shall do me a singular favor, if during our walk amongst
these trees, you will first recount unto me who this young Knight is, being the
valiantest that ever bare arms, and unto whose courage we are bound in so
powerful an obligation; and afterward falling upon the fashions of your
Country you will faithfully deliver how the Knights live there with their
mistrisses. Madam (answered Cassandra) I will content you in a few words; Our
lands are happy, because they produce excellent Knights, and most beautiful
women (though I must confess I never saw any that might compare with your
Highness) but that which adds unto our happiness, is the freedom wherein we
live, we know not what suspicion means; the Gallants frequent the Ladies, and
