they tumbled down one in the neck of another; but desiring to bring them on
again by his example, he took a ladder, mounted on it, and presenting himself
on the battlements, grew dreadful to the defendants, who fearing his getting
into the City, gave present notice thereof to the valiant Knight of the Palms;
he forthwith making to the place, where the Giant slew all that he met withal,
discharged so mighty a blow on his head, that not able to abide the fury of it,
he was overthrown to the ground, and there no doubt he had been killed, had he
not fallen upon five or six of his Captains, who were getting up on the ladder
after him, and that were s^^fl^d under the weight of his body. This fall of his
might have discouraged him, had he had less rage, but rising up with a million
of execrations against his Gods, he re-mounted on the ladder, resolving to die,
or enter into the City: But Alcidamant leaving the Knight of the Lions to
oppose him, whilst Mar^diana's Captains defended other places, put himself in
the head of the thousand horse, which he had reserved for that purpose, sallied
forth at a back gate, and giving furiously on the enemies back, so disordered
them, that they began to betake themselves to flight with an horrible
slaughter, all the ladders being in the power of those of the City, with such
grief to Fangomadan, that he would have held himself happy to have been rid of
his life. The assault ceasing, then by this retreat Alcidamant returned
glorious, and was received with such applause, that the people seemed to have
no tongues but for to publish his valor and renown, which gave infinite
content to Mer^diana, who thought her self most fortunate in poss^ssing so
brave and valiant a Knight; and never blushing at her fault, received him, when
he came to the Court, with most extraordinary testimonies of love, which every
one ascribed to the acknowledgement wherein she stood engaged to his
assistance, and the valor he had shown in the fight, wherein there fell three
thousand and three hundred Knights, to the incredible terror of the adverse
troops, (who believed he was some God come down in favor of this Princess
right) so that the brandishing of his sword was more dreadful, then the
lightning which ordinarily precedes thunder. She could have found in her heart
to have kissed him before all the Commanders that environed him, and would
willingly have discharged him of his arms; but referring that office to the
night, she contained her self till every body was gone to rest, when as she
received him into her bed, where their pleasures were renewed with such
delight, that not able to express the thousandths part of it, I must leave it
to be imagined by those who at any time have enjoyed so much happiness.

CHAP. XL. Alcidamant comb^ts the King of Licagena, kills him, and seconded by
the succors of the Island of Silvana, gives so furiously on the enemy, that he
obtains the victory with incredible slaughter.
THE fury of Fangomadan giving no further fear to Merodiana, by reason of the
assurance which she took in the arms of her lover, her content was without
care, and he^ joy without any doubt. On the other side, Alcidamant mingling a
generous fire with the fl^mes of love, desired nothing more then occasion to
fight, that so he might equal his glory with the pleasures which he found in
the embraces of his Mistress: Disple^sed then that Fangomad^n reigned so long,
and that his arms should imbroil the affairs of a people, whom he could not
choose but love for his Ladies sake, he resolved to co^bat him hand to hand; and
to that end, going one day unto Merodiana for to undertake that business by
her permission, he was told that an H^rauld was come to p^^ley with the
Princess from Fangomadan. Let him be admitted, s^id Alcidamant, it may he
brings us good news. Whereupon, the H^^a^l^ entering into the hall, where
Merodiana sat, attended by the most part of her Captains, without whose advice
she would conclude nothing, he said unto her: Madam, the mighty King of
Licagena, my Lord, desiring to end this war, which depends either on his life,
or on the lives of two strange Knights that are here, he defies them both
toget^e^, and will make trial of his person against them, alleging that they
are traitors, that cunning is more familiar with them then force o^ valor,
and that they fight not like good Knights; further he desires, that this combat
may be performed under the walls of the City, to the end you may judge whether
he be not worthy of your love; he permits them to make choice of the arms, and
protests that he will reti^e with his army if he be vanquished, looking for no
harder condition from you, if he defeats them (as he makes no doubt) then that
you are to expect from the sense which he says he has of your neglect, or
rather of the violence of his passion. This speech wrought a strange confusion
in the mind of Merod^ana, who was not ignorant of Fangomadans forces, and that
for any thing in the world would not have exposed her lover to such danger, so
that she knew not what to answer; when as Alcidamant kneeling down, said unto
her: Madam, if my services be of any consideration with you, refuse me not, I
beseech you, one boon, the first that ever I have asked. Knight, said she,
exceedingly troubled, and guessing at his design, I grant it you whatsoever it
be; howbeit, think, I pray you, not only of your own, but of my peoples, and
particularly of my preservation. That is the only care I take, answered he,
and there is nothing so dear to me as your safety. Wherefore (addressing his
speech to the Herald) you may tell your Master, that I was resolved to free
this Country from his tyranny, and that I am infinitely glad he has furnished
me with the means to do it. I will encounter him to morrow under these walls,
with the arms common among good Knights; namely, the Lance and Sword, not with
a companion: for generous and valiant men never fight with advantage, but
single, and with courage enough to make him pay for the spoil which he has
made of this Princess territories. These words bravely pronounced, no less
amazed the enemy then the assistants, who knowing how prodigious the strength
of Fangomadan was, could hardly believe that any one man durst threaten him,
much less present himself before him; howbeit, seeing with what assurance
this valiant Knight spoke, and calling to mind what he had done in the passed
encounters, they beheld him as a wonder, the most part with pity, as if his
death had been fastened to the first blow he should receive from his enemy, and
others with some hope of good success. Merodiana being here with extremely
afflicted in her mind, stood a good while beholding him with an eye that
sufficiently testified the trouble she was in; but doubting that thus she might
offend him, she set a good face on the matter, and speaking to the Herault,
said unto him, Friend, this Knight has given you your answer, which I avow;
and to show the confidence I have in him, I am contented (making no more
account of my estate then his life) that it be comprised within the hazard of
the combat, and that this Island be united to your Masters crown, if he prove
the victor; reserving nothing but the power to dispose of my self according to
mine own fancy, if my Knight be flain. The Herald departing herewith,
Alcidamant kneeled down again, and rendering a thousand thanks to Merodiana for
her good opinion of him, he promised her, by Gods assistance, not to deceive
her hope. Going then to his chamber for to visit his arms, he ^aw a Damsel
enter with a Dwarf, carrying a trunk on his shoulder, who making him a very
low reverence, said, Brave warrior, the learned Nerea, who loves you well,
knowing what is to betide you in your enterprises, has commanded me to give
you this armor, and to tell you, that you should not be troubled for the loss
of the Arms which she caused to be brought in to you in the wood where you were
made Knight, your former combats have made them in case to do you but small
service in the business you have now in hand, which has induced her to
furnish you with these new ones. This is not the first favor she has done me,
said Alcidamant, having no way obliged her thereunto: but you may assure her,
she may dispose of me when or however she pleases. Whereupon, having received
from the Dwarf a green cuirasse, set all over with double hearts, wherein
appeared an A and a T, an helmet of the same, the richest that could be, and a
shield whereon were three Palms, as in the other, he was better pleased then if
he had obtained a Kingdom; howbeit, he marvelled to see them so thin and
light: whereat the Damsel smiling, said unto him, Sir, never wonder at that:
for my Mistress has caused them to be made so of purpose, that you may fight
with the less pain and more ease. But if you dare not credit my words, make
trial of them your self, and see if the strength of your arm and the goodness
of your sword can open them. Here with she vanished away leaving Merodiana no
less amazed then contented; who finding herself at night with her Knight,
could not forbear shedding of some tears at the remembrance of the danger
wherein he was to be the next day: Whereupon our Frenchman taking occasion to
carresse her, told her, that she was not to afflict her self so, nor consider
the disproportion of his body, and that of his enemy, that virtue consisting in
courage rather then in the largeness of limbs, she was not to doubt, but that
love would furnish him with new forces, seeing her life and welfare were in
question. Comforting her thus with sufficient strong reasons, he rendered her
fearlesse, and her hope greater. The time which he could stay with her, being
sweetly past away, he retired to his chamber, and slept two howrs; at the end
whereof the Sun growing somewhat high, he arose, armed himself with his rich
armor, wherein he seemed a Mars: and going to take horse, he was told, that
the forces of the Island of Silvana, amounting to six thousand choice Knights,
were arrived. New occasions, said he, then speaking to the Captains that
followed him, must have new resolutions: this supply comes very opportunely,
and not to let them cool, put them presently in battle array with four thousand
of ours, the rest shall serve to guard the walls, with the inhabitants; but be
sure to commence no fight till the combat between Fangomadan and me be ended;
my companion will take care to dispose of you as you should be. Herewith the
Knight of the Lions being particularly advertised of his design, gave his
Lance that he carried in honor to his Squire, and letting him go, instantly
ordained that which was to be done, and put ten thousand men in order after he
had given notice thereof to Merodiana, who being richly attired, was already on
the walls, for to encourage her lover, and be judge of his valor. I am
resolved, said she, when she was acquainted with the business, in all things to
follow the counsel of the valiant Knight of the Palms; therefore let his
command be executed. The Knight of the Lions seeing his men disposed, and being
very well satisfied with this answer, went out to behold the combat of his
companion; who finding the Giant in the Lists, met him so roughly with his
Lance, that he made him ^lie to the ground, himself remaining somewhat
astonished with the encounter. The Giant seeing himself overthrown, contrary to
his expectation, rose sooner then could be imagined of so huge a mass of
flesh, and drawing out a great and weighty courtelax, struck such furious blows
at his enemy, that the least of them had been able to have cut him asunder, if
he had received it; but having avoided them with an admirable dexterity, he
charged him so bravely both with point and edge, that he amazed both the Armies.

The Giant stormed exceedingly for that he could not fasten one stroke on his
adversary; and casting a thick smoke out of the visor of his helmet, he hindered
himself from seeing where to place his blows: whereas Alcidamant, that fought
with judgment, spent not a minute unprofitably. The first fury of these
warriors having endured above two howrs, the place was covered with the Giants
Arms, which went to pieces whenever the rich sword of his enemy fell upon
them: the blood trickled down from three or four parts of his body; and that
which carried his choler to the highest degree of rage, was, that his
adversaries armor appeared entire. Merodiana beheld this combat with strange
motions; if the Giants courtelax were aloft, she feared the violence of it, and
she rejoiced when she saw it light without effect; she considered the valor of
her Knight, admired his agility in saving himself from his enemies sword,
wondered at the force of the blows which he gave; and above all, took extreme
pleasure in the grace of his fight. Am I not very happy, said she to her self,
to enjoy a Knight the bravest of all that live; and is it not exceeding glory
for me to triumph over him, under whom the strongest Giants of the earth are
constrained to bow? Yes, without doubt, and I do not repent the giving of him
that which he has nobly gotten: would to God Fangomadan were dispatched out of
the way, that my content might be perfect, I would then embrace this gallant
warrior, and in despite of detraction declare before all, that I love him
infinitely. Entertaining her self with these thoughts, she fixed her eyes upon
him, and perceiving the Giant to be more unweldy, and her lover far abler, as
she conceived, then at the beginning of the combat, she was transported with
excess of joy. This while Alcidamant pursued his advantage, charged his enemy
more furiously then before; and observing that Merodiana beheld him, accused
himself for being so long defeating a man in the presence of her, whose favors
had made him most happy. Vexed then then to see the victory so long disputed, he
took his sword in both his hands, and letting it fall terribly on his enemies
shield, he so astonished him, that he made him reel three or four steps
backward: whereupon taking his advantage, he redoubled such a dangerous blow on
his head, that he cleft it in twain, to the unspeakable contentment of
Merodiana and her subjects, who seeing the good Knight of the Lions in the head
of their troops, set forth in good array, and following the Conqueror of the
Giant, who made them way with his sword, they fell so furiously upon the
enemies, amazed with the death of their master, that they slew above two
thousand at the first bout, the rest betook themselves instantly to flight;
where the slaughter was so great, that of seventeen thousand, there escaped not
fully two hundred, who got to the Army of Fangomadans cousin, relating unto
him the absolute defeature of the other forces, with the death of the King;
which put him into such a rage, that drawing all the garrisons out of the
strong places which he held, into one body of an Army, he resolved to affront
the Conquerours, and in their overthrow, revenge the loss of his companions.
Advancing then whilst the two strangers refreshed themselves with the Army,
which commended them to the skies, and especially him of the Palms, whom they
would fain have adored, if he would have permitted it; he presented himself
three days after before Alfarta, where the fight commencing by light
skirmishes, grew so hot upon the arrival of the two invincible warriors, who
were accompanied with eight hundred horse, that they came to a general
battle; in the which the army of these new enemies, greater by the half then
the former, were all cut in pieces by the exceeding valor of Alcidamant and
his companion, who thundering wheresoever they went, assured their soldiers,
made them fight without fear, and so terrified their adversaries, that they
were dead before the swords of these lightnings of war fell upon them. The
enemies being in this manner utterly defeated, the whole Island reverted to the
obedience of the fairest Merodiana; who daily found out new entertainments for
her lover: and having no other care but to please him, held her self the
happiest Princess of the world.

CHAP. XLI. The Infanta Silvana falls in love with Alcidamant, goes from her
Island to Merodiana for to see him, and having found him a hunting, she enjoyes
him by a notable trick.
THE people breathing now in peace after so many troubles, the Companies were
discharged, and especially those of the Island of Silvana, who giving account to
their Mistress of the success of the war, so published the praises of the
Knight of the Palms, and raised his valor to so high a pitch, that the f^ir
Silvana, sister to Merodiana, admiring him, began to seek the same effects
which they endure which are in love. She made them describe unto her his
stature, the proportion of his body, his countenance, the color of his hair,
and the beauty of his face; and considering that Nature had made him every way
complete, she her self kindled the fire which by little and little consumed
her; but passing to the desire for to know what marvells he had done for her
sister, she caused them to recount unto her the manner of his fight, his
courage, his skill, his blows, how he had most valiantly slain the King of
Licagena, and put his armies to flight at the only sight of his arms, which
fully imprinted the character of love in her heart, and made her care for
nothing so much as to find out some occasion to see him, and render him
enamoured of her. O Gods, said she, how accomplished is this knight, if he have
all those parts which report confers upon him! Have I not reason to wish I may
enjoy him? No question I have, he is worthy of my favors, and deserves to be
made partaker of my bed, if he will accept of it. But alas! I very much fear my
sister has already prevented me of that fortune, and unable to resist what I
suffer, that she has given her self to him, bereaving me of the means so to
do. Yes, yes, I doubt it is but too true, for this Knight being every way so
complete, who could forbear loving him? Questionless my sister does enjoy him,
and I am out of hope to see the end of my desires successful; howbeit, the
dice are cast, I am no longer mine own, and this consideration must not stay my
designs; if my sister love him, I may love him too, enjoy him as she does, and
cover my desires with a pretended ignorance of their affections. This amorous
and jealous Princess, entertaining her self after this manner, in the
beginning of her passion, lived with strange unquietness, sometimes she
resolved to send a damsel unto him to desire him not refuse her his succor,
for the delivering of her Island from a dreadful monster, that rendered it
almost inhabitable; and then imagining that her sister would never permit him
to undertake that voyage, because she would not let him go out of her sight,
she was of another mind, and purposed to have him by some other wile; but not
meeting with any, that was not either too long for the impatience of her
desires, or too difficult for any good success she could hope from it, or too
hazardous for to endanger all, she could not draw any resolution out of such
contrariety of thoughts. At length having more affection then to undertake
nothing, she concluded to quit her Island, and to see him at her sisters, under
color of going to congratulate with her for the happy issue of so dangerous a
war, hoping there to find out some invention or other for to bring her design
to pass. Taking along with her then twelve Knights and six damsels, for she
had but an arm of the sea to cross over, she embarked her self, and within
four days after landed in her sisters Island, whom she would not acquaint with
her coming; but mounting upon a delicate nag, she rode along till she came to
a forest, near unto the which, causing certain pavillions to be pitched, she
resolved to pass away the night there. Walking then alone by her self in the
evening, and continually thinking on the means she might use for to bring her
business wisely about, she perceived a huntsman pass by, of whom she demanded
what news there was at Merodiana's Court. I can deliver you no better, answered
he, then that which is reported of the excellency of the Knight of the Palms,
whom it seems has a purpose to become Lord of this Country, whereunto our
Princess will not be much averse, as every one probably conjectures, for there
is nothing at this instant in the world which she regards so much, as the
content of this Knight, with whose conversation she is infinitely taken, she
leads him forth into the gardens and walks, where most of the trees carry marks
of their loves, in a million of characters, graven on their barks; and when the
heat of the day will not suffer them to walk, they withdraw into her chamber,
where the time is insensibly spent in the assurances which they interchangably
give of loving one another eternally. These words were so many mortal wounds
that renewed the grief and jealousy of Silvana, who saw apparent proofs of
that which she had always feared; she scratched her head, changed her color
every minute, many times bit her fingers for anger, and testified (if the
huntsman had well observed her actions) that this news touched her to the
quick; but he whose mind was altogether upon his discourse, went on thus:
Briefly, these so great familiarites induce us to believe that they are
resolved to make a marriage, in consideration whereof, we honor him already as
if he were our Master, carrying no less respect to his commandments, then to
those which come from Merodiana: And to witness the truth of that I say,
assure your self I would not walk thus with a purpose to lie all night in the
wood, if it were not to lodge him Deer which to morrow he means to hunt in this
Forest very early in the morning. But, Madam, time calls me away, wherefore
you must excuse me, if I break off thus abruptly. Silvana being better
satisfied with the conclusion of this discourse, then with the beginning, would
not stay him any longer, but returned to her pavillion; where being arrived,
she called one of her Damsels whom she favored most, unto her, and said,
Falerina (so was she named) out of the confidence which I repose in thee, I
come to impart a secret unto thee; wherein, without any confideration of the
importance of the matter, I would have thee to serve me, not according to thy
opinion, or as reason shall counsel thee, but according to my desire and
fancy. I am desperately in love with that brave Knight of the Palms, of whom
such wonders are reported of late: and whereas I have undertaken this voyage,
it was not as I gave out, to congratulate with my sister for her good success,
but to see him, and to dispose him to love me: to effect the which, a
favorable occasion presents it self, whereby it lies in thee to make me happy
if thou will. To morrow he is to hunt a Stag in this wood; but let us make him
take another way, and find out some invention to draw him hither, where, I
doubt not, but I shall with little diffieultie, obtain what I desire: for I
have beauty enough to make the most invincible man in the world to affect me.
And this may easily be done: for thou shall encounter him at his beginning to
hunt, thou shall humbly demand a boon of him, and withdrawing him from his
company, thou shall conduct him hither, where thou shall find me alone,
accompanied with none but Elania, whom I can dispose well enough to my
pleasure. For I will command my train to set forth by break of day, and attend
for me three leagues hence, and not to stir from that place, till they hear
further from me. Falerina amazed with this speech (for she had always observed
a great deal of modesty in her Mistresses actions) would willingly have replied
for to have reduced her to a better regard of her honor; but perceiving that
the venom had wrought its effect, and that her remedies would be to no
purpose, she promised her no less fidelity then diligence. Sleeping then but a
little, she arose with the day, and getting to horse, placed her self in the
way which the hunters were to take; where she had not continued half an howr,
but she discovered a troop of Gentlemen, before whom she presented her self,
and easily discerning the Knight of the Palms from the rest, she acosted him
with a very good grace, and said unto him, Noble Sir, I know not whether you be
as courteous as you are gallant. Gentlewoman, answered he with a smile, you
shall understand that better if you think good to make use of me. Follow me
then, replied she, and be pleased to exchange the pleasure of your hunting for
a greater adventure, this enterprise will take you up but for one day: and if
these Gentlemen be troubled with your departure, let this promise comfort them,
that they shall see you again to night, or to morrow at the furthest within
Alfarta. Knights cannot limit their return, said he, because they are ignorant
of what will betide them in their adventures; howbeit seeing you assure them of
my return by to morrow, I will not bid them farewell but till then: Whereupon
the Damsel leading the way, he followed her with a mavelous desire to know
whither he was conducted; nevertheless she would reveal nothing till she came
within sight of her Mistress pavillion. Here it is, said she, where you are to
enter for to make satisfaction concerning a wrong that you have done. At these
words the Knight alighting, and thinking that he was to fight, advanced with
his sword drawn, and his shield on his arm; but beholding in stead of enemies,
a most beautiful Lady, who carried a million of charms in her eyes, made a
stand, and being amazed, said unto her, Madam, I am conducted hither for your
service. Yes, said she, reaching him her hand, but not with an intent to make
you enter into combat with any: The commendations which the world gives you,
have begot an extreme desire in me to see you; and to that end I have left my
country, thoroughly satisfied in finding many more perfections in you, then
report delivered. Madam, answered he, you may commend me as you please; but
there is nothing in me which is not wholly at your service: And be assured,
that if I had known your mind, I would have gone to the utmost part of the
earth for to have found you out, rather then you should have taken the pains to
come hither. I shall think it well bestowed, replied she, so as you do not
prove ungrateful, and be not offended with my saying so, till you are
acquainted with my meaning. Sir, I love you, and all the considerations I could
bring for to contain me within the limits of modesty and my duty, have been too
weak against the force of your merits, which having deprived me of all power
over my self, have constrained me to come out of my State, to seek relief in
your pity,. It may be you will despise me, because I present my self thus unto
you; and you may make an ill construction of my carriage toward you: but if
you understand your self well, you will excuse my weakness. Say that I have
reason to love you, and not holding me immodest, will recompense my affection
with the like, as also give me just cause to publish, that you are the most
accomplished Knight that this day bears Arms. Alcidamant, to whom the like
encounters were sovereign favors, seeing such amiable beauty in his power,
did not so much as stand on the considerations which she brought, to render her
action the more allowable; but protesting in what great obligations he was
engaged to her favor, the more powerful in regard he had so little deserved
it, he disarmed himself with all the haste he could; and beginning his caresses
with a kiss, made her a woman to both their incredible contents. After a world
of dalliance, she declared unto him, how she was sister to Merodiana, and
expressing the fear she had, lest his long conversation with her sister, and
their privacie together, might keep him from affecting her, it had somewhat
troubled him, but that he remembered how an understanding lover seldom wants
cunning devices to palliate his designs. Assuring her then, with a thousand
oaths and promises, never to lose the memory of her favors, and to hold her
as dear, or dearer, then her sister, he past away the rest of that day, and the
night following with her, not so much as thinking how Merodiana would take his
absence, and found this content so pleasing, that it grieved him to be deprived
of it. Nevertheless, being constrained to consider what might follow of so
long a stay, he took his Arms, went a little beyond the village where Silvana
had commanded her train to abide, and placing himself under certain trees,
waited till he saw her appear: then advancing into the midst of the high way,
and desiring to give this his new Mistress some entertainment, he sent his
Squire to her Knights, for to tell them, that he would not permit them to pass
without breaking a Lance for their sakes whom they best loved in the world.
This message made the Knights to laugh: for they could not imagine that one man
alone could subdue them, and each of them strove for the first course, when as
one of Silvana's Damsels being got before the rest, returned suddenly to
acquaint them, that this Champion was the Knight of the Palms, so much
redoubted over all the country. By my faith, said then the forwardest of them,
we will not encounter him: for so should we be more foolhardy then he is
valiant. What, said Silvana, that much desired to see how far the valor of
this Knight extended, will none of you run against him? Yes that we will,
answered one, if you would take pleasure in our defeat. Your misfortune would
no way please me, said Silvana, but it would much content me to see whether
that be true which is so published of this Knight; and if you desire to oblige
me, run one course with him. I will obey you Madam, said he, though I am sure
before hand of a fall; howsoever it will be glory to me, that I have run
against the best Knight living: whereupon putting down his Bever, he advanced
toward Alcidamant, who encountered him so bravely, that he made him quit his
saddle, and cast him four or five paces of. I knew well enough, said he, rising
less hurt then was imagined, that I should give my fellows occasion to laugh;
and that I should not resist that incomparable force which is dreadful to the
stronggest Giants upon the earth; but I will be more charitable then they: for
I will let you know, that this Princess which you see, is sister to the
beautiful Merodiana, to the end you may not employ your Lance against her
Knights. You have reason, said Alcidamant, to believe that I will not run
against them, and if I had known you, I had not justed with you; and that you
may not complain of your fall, I am ready to repair that fault when you please.
Whereupon advancing toward the fair Silvana, he saluted her as though he had
never seen her before: and riding along by her, they took the way to Alfarta,
where the fairest Merodiana received them at the first very heartily, never
doubting of the prank which was played to her prejudice; but who can blind the
eyes of a lover? This Lady calling to mind the absence of her Knight, led away,
as she was informed, by a Damsel which was showed to her a little after,
presently suspected, not the matter as it was, but something near unto it,
insomuch that she observed their actions, and therein finding but too much
proof of their love, she grew so jealous, that she could not rest. On the other
side, Silvana was in the like perplexity: for seeing how coldly her Knight
spoke to her in the presence of Merodiana, and marking the amorous looks they
gave one another, it madded her; nevertheless, they concealed their thoughts,
and watched for more pregnant testimonies, to complain upon a sure ground; but
Alcidamant was so discreet, that he deceived them both. My dearest Knight, said
Merodiana sighing when she had him in bed, take it not ill, I pray you, if the
extremity of my passion constrains me to be a little jealous of you, you look
upon my sister with too affectionate an eye; and the care which you seem to
have of her service appears to me more then good will, she is amiable, you
deserve to be sought unto, what may I then think of your familiarity? Too much
I fear for my content; but if you will consider what you owe to so many
carresses which you have received from me, how I undo my self to oblige you,
that regard no slanderous tongue to give you satisfaction, and how I have
freely bestowed on you what was most dear unto me for to please you, I hope you
will not be my ruin, nor impart your embraces to another, seeing no man
partakes of my kisses, but will be pleased to let me only enjoy you, that
seeks for nothing save occasion how to delight you. These words finishing with
tears, made our Frenchman somewhat to repent, who seeking to excuse his fault,
covered it with the name of respect, represented that in regard she was her
sister, he was to carry himself fairly toward her, protesting that he had
never so much as a thought of that which she imagined, he somewhat pacified
her, and interrupted the course of her complaints; after which he was sure to
have the like of the fair Silvana. Dearest love, said she when she could speak
particularly to him. I have great cause to complain, my sister has all your
caresses, she has days to enjoy your company, whereas I have not minutes;
your eyes are always fixed on her, and I but a few glances; if you speak to
me, it is with too much respect, and too little love: what have I done to
deserve so cold an entertainment? or what have I not done to be more kindly
entreated? I have freely given my self to you, but alas! it may be your neglect
proceeds from thence. I have left my country for to see you, and yet I cannot
enjoy that, but another caresses makes you find no delight in my embraces. Now
I would fain know what is the cause of it, she has no advantage of me, we are
sisters, her beauty exceeds not mine (at leastwise I think so) I accompany my
kisses with as much Art as a woman can use, to render them more pleasing; love
you as much, or rather more then she does (for I know that all the affections
of the earth do not equal the violence of my flames) yet I must suffer whilst
another lives contented, and reaps the reward of my travels. Ah, this is great
injustice, carry less respect to persons, and be more equal. If you think
your self obliged by the consideration of your being here with her, shall not I
give you in the Island o^ Silvana the same pleasures which you find here? Yes,
my dearest, I will find out, if it be possible, far greater delights, and so
behave my self that you shall not repent your abandoning her for to follow me.
He that beholds a rock between two seas, sometimes beaten with the one, and
then again with the other, may figure out this Knight between these two
sisters, equally importuned with either of their complaints. He loved Merodiana
very much; Silvana's kisses were of no less power with him, her reasons moved
him, the others sighs found him not insensible, his heart was divided betwixt
them, and taking pleasure in Merodiana's caresses, he met with as much content
in those of her beautiful sister. At length this last speech which Silvana
made, had prevailed with him, had he not called to mind the resolution he had
taken to carry himself in such manner, as he would lose neither the one nor the
other of them. Returning then the same reasons, the same excuses, the same
dissembling, the same oaths, and the same caresses which he had used to
Merodiana, he somewhat appeased her displeasure; nevertheless he could not so
^emean himself, but that there remained so powerful a suspicion in the minds
of these sisters, as converting into jealousy, it made them odious one to
another, though they labored wisely ^o disguise their thoughts. If Merodiana
was alone, she presently imagined that her Knight was in her sisters arms. If
Silvana saw him not, she believed he was in private with her sister, they went
to one another chamber, and met oftentimes in the midway: they were sisters,
love made them secretly rivals. Merodiana observed all Silvanas actions,
Silvana had a continual desire to understand what her sister did; briefly, all
their motions were suspicions, their suspicions strong jealousies, and their
jealousies insupportable griefs. It is not a care of my honor, said Merodiana,
that induces my sister to watch me in this fashion, much less any excess of
affection to me: for I know her thoughts but too well, it must be then the
spite she bears me for crossing her desire; but why should I give entertainment
to a controller of my actions? she is amorous of my Knight, she loves him
passionatly, and would fain deprive me of him, but I will not endure her
boldness; and quietly desiring her to return unto her Island, I shall appear
rather an angered sister then an ill lover; howbeit I will wait a fit
opportunity, and in the mean time use some speeches to her that may make her
acknowledge her fault; but if she prove obstinate, we will part never to see
one another again as sisters; and love, who admits of no consideration, that
will have one regardlesse of times, persons, places, and conditions shall
authorize my resentment. Whilst she entertained her self in this manner,
Silvana did the like. I perceive well enough, said she to her self, that my
sister looks not upon me but with disdain, that she forbids this Knight to talk
with me, and that I expect nothing save displeasure: wherefore I resolve to
return home, howbeit if be possible, I will be accompanied with him, so shall I
be no longer crossed in my desires. He is courteous, he is obliged to me, he will
deny me nothing I shall demand of him: wherefore covering my design with the
pity I take of my people and countries, which every day fall to ruin by the
cruelty of a monster that continually destroys them, I will beseech him to
succor me, like a valiant and generous Knight; and if I can get him once out
of my sisters hands, I will never permit him to undertake so dangerous an
enterprise, but preserve him for my future contentment. Insisting then on this
resolution, as the best she could desire, she said unto him one day in the
presence of Merediana, who commended to every one the assistance which she had
received from him, Sir, you see how your benefits are acknowledged, that
praises are always in the mouths of such as are obliged, and generous Knights
do ordinarily find some recompense in the glory is given to their virtues: If
you had done any thing for me, I should speak of you as others do, and would
raise your name to heaven, holding the world unworthy to retain the greatness
of it. Madam, answered he, interrupting her there, the fault shall not be mine
if you have not the satisfaction to see me combat for your service; do but
furnish me with occasion, and you shall find me ready whenever you please. My
people, said she, afflicted by a cruel monster, reach out their hands unto
you; now advise with your self whether you will oblige me by succouring them.
Most willingly, Madam, answered he, and shall think my self most happy to serve
you in this occasion. We will depart then to morrow, replied she, in the mean
time take order for your journey. Merodiana hearing this discourse, and seeing
a departure resolved so soon, knew not what to say, she would have accused her
lover, but having very great testimonies of his affection, she laid all the
fault upon her sisters malice, whom she blamed in very plain terms, saying
that she ought not to precipitate the days of so brave a Knight, who could not
enter into that combat without apparent loss of his life; but Silvana resolved
the contrary, and caring for nothing but how to draw him from thence, made no
reckoning of her anger. All this night was bestowed in sighs and tears, and
Merodiana a thousand times cursed her sisters coming to see her. I will not let
you go to imminent death, said she, and notwithstanding any promise you have
made my sister, you shall not stir from hence, she is too impudent to be
obeyed, and I knew her coming too well for to leave her the liberty to put it
in practice: but if you be resolved to go with her, be confident that I will
follow you, and cross the pleasures which she expects, as much as she has
done my content. O God, Madam, said he, kissing her most amorously, do you make
doubt of my faith? now truly you do me infinite wrong, for so many oaths and
protestations as I have made to you, should, me thinks, remove this false
opinion out of your imagination, I must go, because I am obliged thereunto by my
promise; but Madam, be assured it shall be to return incontinently again, if I
happen to live after the combat which I purpose to enter into against the
Serpent; and to persuade you to believe what I say, behold your self in your
glass, then think upon Silvana, and you shall find that your beauties being
unlike, that she having less charms then you, less love, and less merit, I
shall never abandon you to follow her: Live contented in the expectation of my
return, and in the mean time permit me to embrace occasions that may acquire my
glory; so shall you testify a true affection to me, and oblige me to esteem my
self happy in your love. These so powerful reasons having mitigated, but not
defaced Merodiana's grief, she slept till morning, when giving him a farewell
kiss, he retired to arm himself, leaving her in tears and sorrow.

CHAP. XLII. The grief which the fairest Merodiana took at the departure of her
Knight, who went with her sister for to combat the monster, that ravagod the
the Island of Silvana, the loves of this Princess and the Knight, and the
danger wherein he found himself in the combat.
SIlvana departing with as much glory, as she left discontent in her sisters
Court, traveled a while between the Knight of the Palms, and him of the Lions,
entertaining him with a world of pleasing talk, howbeit, her passion making her
desire no other ear but her lovers, she many times went and spoke softly to
him, as if she were willing none else should hear her, which the gentle T^oilu^
perceiving, modestly withdrew himself, and left them to the liberty of their
actions and discourse. Then this amorous Lady, more openly showing the joy she
conceived for being freed from a concurrent in her love, rendered the length of
the way so short by a million of oaths to love him eternally, and by as many
complaints against her sisters jealousy, that he found himself almost out of
the wood, before he thought of being in it. The place representing to his
memory the pleasure which he had received at his first acquaintance with
Silvana, he would fain have stepped aside with her for to alight under some bush;
but conceiving that they could not blind the eyes of so many persons which
followed them, they traveled to the sea side, where a ship attended to
transport them over; howbeit, Silvana would not imbark this night, because she
knew she should not have the liberty aboard as in her tents; nevertheless, to
avoid all fear of discovery, she caused her train to be shipped, reserving no
body about her, but Falerina, Alderia, her Knight, and him of the Lions, who
having good intelligence with Falerina, made but one bed with her and the fair
Alderia, which was not more squemish then the other, whilst his companion took
up a place by Silvana's side. The night being spent with many more caresses and
kisses then I am able to deliver, the Knights armed themselves at break of day,
and seeing that a favorable gale solicited their departure, they took their
Ladies by the arm, and conveyed them aboard; whereupon, commanding the Master
to hoist sail, they began to cut the waves, which on a sudden swelling very
high, had exceedingly frighted the women, but that they were cheared with the
presence and speech of the Knights. Howbeit, the storm increasing, the noise of
the waters growing every minute more dreadful, and the night, which rendered
every thing full of horror, arriving thereupon, gave them new fears of
shipwreck; insomuch, that Silvana cast her self into Alcidamants arms, who
desiring to make use of the darkness, without any apprehension at all of the
tempest, he fell a kissing of her, laid his hand on her breasts, and finding
his spirit raised, he caressed her so sweetly, that she vowed afterward, she
never felt so much pleasure in so little time. Whilst they drew their delight
out of a subject dreadful, and full of danger, Troilus entreated Falerina in
the same manner, and making her lose her self in his embraces, kept her so,
till the day and calm weather arriving together, caused them to retire
wonderfully satisfied with the love of each other. The Master, finding himself
near to the Island of Silvana, yet far enough from the place where he meant to
have put in, advertised his Lady thereof, who understanding that it was on that
coast which the monster had ruined, she would with all haste have made from it,
but that she was retained by the Knight of the Palms. How Madam, said he, will
you oppose my glory, and make more esteem of my life, then of mine honor? What
would all the world say, and particularly your sister, whom I left only to
defeat this creature, if I should part hence without seeing it? Not to lie, I
should in a moment lose all the honor I have acquired by so many labors; let
us land a Gods name, or if for your own part you be afraid, permit me to do
that which becomes a good Knight, who will not be wanting to his promise, nor
fail in his duty. Ah, my Knight, said she, with her eyes full of tears, will
you yield more to your own desires then to mine? Have you forgotten how you
have told me a thousand times that you would never disobey any commandment I
should lay upon you? And yet you will now do a thing which infinitely
displeases me, and more cruel then can be expressed, you seek my destruction, in
running headlong to your own. Do but consider beforehand what danger there is
in affronting this monster, the most horrible and dre^dfull that ever was;
whole squadrons of armed men fly at the very sight of him, will you then
undertake this enterprise? I make a dear account (as I ought) of my people, and
country; but you are not of that consideration, as to prefer common men and
lands before your safety; Let them perish, I beseech you, and tempt not the
power of the Gods, to go to meet dangers, which without blame, and wisely, you
may avoid. The glory you aspire unto, is to be found in actions that one man
may bring to pass, not in desparation. But if you will not be retained by the
care of your self, yet at leastwise be moved with my tears, with my sighs, with
the regard of my very life it self, which shall not be long if you persist in
your wilfulness. Madam, said Alcidamant, pardon me, I beseech you, if I say
that your request is unjust, and that you wrongfully complain of me for not
rendering that obedience to your commandments which I ought. You brought me
hither for the good of your people, and now you are offended that I endeavor
to relieve them. I know not what to say to this humor, and although the pity
which you seem to have of me obliges me; nevertheless, it is so repugnant to
my reputation, that I cannot allow of it without infinite blame. You affirm,
that we are to seek adventures which are easy; such will never give us glory,
and therefore we present our selves to those which seem impossible; you think
to divert me from this design, by figuring forth unto me a monster, dreadful
beyond all that ever was; that, Madam, works in me a contrary effect: If an
ordinary Knight could overcome it, I would not vouchsafe to land here for to
fight with it, the difficulty which I meet with in this enterprise, gives me a
mavelous desire to undertake it to day rather then to morrow. Cease then, I
beseech you, from afflicting your self, and restraining these tears, which more
reproach your weakness, then testify your love, command me to march on
courageously, that I may triumph over this terrible enemy under the favor of
your beauty.

Your reasons seem so just, answered she, that I am not able to withold you
any longer from this adventure; but ah! my Knight, when I think how I behold
you crash: between the teeth of this horrible Serpent, or torn in pieces by his
merciless claws, I cannot forbear weeping, when I call to mind how I was the
cause of this your death; howbeit, seeing you are resolved to attempt this
combat, go under the protection of the Gods, my Knights shall assist you. By no
means, Madam, said he: for I will be accompanied with none but my friend here,
and my Squire, that shall only go to know what will become of me. Whereupon
causing himself to be landed with Troilus and Arnides, after he had desired the
beauteous Silvana to stay for him in the same part, they got to horse, and rode
along exceedingly astonished to see all the country round about disinhabited,
a multitude of houses ruined, and trees every where overthrown by the
wonderful force of this formidable Monster. Having traveled certain howrs,
they approached to a forest, entertaining themselves with ordinary discourse,
when as their horses began to snore, prick up their cars, and recoil back,
maugre all the spurring they could use, for to make them advance into the wood.
Never credit me, said Alcidamant, if this beast be not amongst these trees;
whereupon listening attentively, they heard a dreadful noise, with some
horrible hissing, and seeing two or three little trees overturn, they perceived
the monster whom they sought, coming forth with a strange fury: he had the
body of a Dragon, as big as an Elephant, covered with scales of diverse colors;
he had two heads, the one of a Serpent with a three forked tongue, the other of
a furious Lion: his legs were different the one from the other; one of the
foremost had the claws of a Serpent, two foot and a half long, and so sharp,
that they would pierce even steel; the other was armed with the paws of a
Lion, able to crush Iron, and tear armor in pieces; behind he was supported
with two legs of an horse, wonderful great; after which he trailed a tail so
long and strong, that therewith he easily overthrew all the trees which stood
in his way. Alcidamants courage was new put to the test: for beholding a
creature so deformed and monstrous, he marvelled how Nature could produce it in
such a form, and could not choose but fear to fall into the danger of his paws
or teeth, which were in each head a cubit long and more; but assuming
confidence from the glory which he should acquire by defeating this monster, he
desired his companion to retire, and recommending himself to God, he set spurs
to his horse, who staring up with his mane, ran clean away with him, do what he
could to retain him: but at length having stayed him, he quickly alighted, took
his Lance, and making head to the Monster, which followed him with incredible
celerity, he ran it so furiously into one of his chops that stood wide gaping,
as it past into his throat, where it brake, after it had made a very deep
wound; but not able to withstand the violence of the encounter, he was
overthrown to the ground, with such pain, that he thought his body had been all
crushed: nevertheless rising up suddenly, for the Monster was gone on, he drew
out his rich sword, and with a resolute courage waited to charge him as he
should pass by; but considering that his legerity would more advantage him
then his force, he concluded to combat him with judgment, stepping lightly
aside, then when he saw him return with rage, he gave him so mighty a blow full
upon the body, that it was able to have cleft a rock; howbeit in vain: for he
found his scales so hard, as the Sword left no mark behind of the stroke. O
God! said he then astonished, what can I expect from this combat, but the death
which Silvana so many times foretold me to day, Lord assist me, and punish me
not according to the greatness of my sins? Whilst he made this short prayer,
the dangerous Monster spared him not: for presently turning about, he laid hold
on his shield with his Serpents claws, and having torn it from his arm,
labored to bite it in pieces with his teeth, offering at the same instant to
seize on the Knights armor with his Lions paw; but he that with reason feared
these approaches, leapt wonderfully quick a tone side, and grieved to see
himself thus destitute of a shield, he took his sword in both his hands, and
therewith cut his paw sheer off at one blow; whereat he gave so loud a cry,
that it was heard 3 leagues off. Alas! said then the beauteous Silvana, here is
a sign^ of my Knights death; wretch that I was to propound so dangerous an
enterprise unto him, for other wise he had lived, and I might still have
continued happy in the world. Alcidamant seeing this good effect of the stroke
which he had given, was in hope of better, and ^esiring to make use of the
astonishment the Monster was in, gave him another blow on the Lions mane,
thinking to have no worse success then before, but the thickness of his
clotted hair withstanding the pass of the steel, it made him only bow with
his head a little, and so provoked his fury, that making a skip of ten foot
high into the air, the Knight found himself overthrown on the ground; where
this dreadful creature perceiving him to lie, got him between his teeth for to
devour him; and indeed he had already entered them in his live flesh, when as
the Knight being out of all hope of life, advanced his good sword, and thrust
it with such violence into his flank, that he past it quite through his bowels.
The Monster feeling so dangerous a wound, mounted once again into the air,
with such an incredible force, that he lighted ten paces off when he came to
ground, which gave our Frenchman leisure to rise, so bruised with his fall, and
suffering such pain from the hurts the Monster had made with his teeth, that he
could hardly stand; howbeit forcing himself, and drawing new strength out of
his generous courage, he approached the Monster again, who made a most horrible
noise, and by good fortune giving him a thrust just in the eye, ran him to the
very brain, but being surprised before he could retire him, the Monster caught
him with his Serpents claws, and in the pangs of death that tormented him,
dragged him up and down a good while: then taking him between his teeth, as if
he would make a sepulcher for him of his throat, he made way for his blood to
issue out at sundry places, and had without doubt killed him in this sort, had
not the wound which he had received in the belly, caused him to tumble down,
breathing out his last. Alcidamant who had not lost his understanding in this
danger, seeing this monster fallen, had courage enough to rise, and withdraw
aside; but the venom which came forth of the body of this creature, and his
own loss of blood, had not left him long alive, if Troilus and his Squire, who
were not far off, had not come suddenly to his aid. Arnides remembering then the
box which Cassandra had given him when he laft fought with Rozalmond, took it
out of his pocket, and quickly disarming him, anointed him with that balm,
which working a marv^llous effect, brought him instantly to himself again.
Whereupon, the good Troilus gathered a great heap of leaves together, laid him
upon it, and charging Arnides not to stir from him, galloped amain toward the
port.

Silvana, whom love kept always in care, seeing him arrive in that manner, and
believing that he fled from the jaws of the Serpent, was ready to tumble into
the sea, imagining that her lover was in the belly of the monster, and the
words and complaints of a despairing woman were even at her mouth, when Troilus
boording her with a cheerful countenance, said: Madam, be of good cheer, the
Knight of the Palms is alive, and more glorious by the death of the monster,
then ever Knight was by the most dangerous adventure that has been; but you
must know that this victory is bought at a dear rate, for the Knight has lost
most of his blood, and was very near his end; howbeit, he is far better then he
was, by means of an ointment wherewith his Squire has dressed his wounds, so
that now he wants nothing but your assistance, that he may be carried to some
house, where he may be more commodiously looked unto then in your ships.
Silvana, at first, distracted between hope and fear, and that expected nothing
less then so happy a success, hearing that her lover was alive after the
death of so horrible a monster, fell into such an ecstasy of joy, that she
could neither speak nor move: she beheld Troilus, as if she would have said
that she did not believe his report; but observing him to be in good earnest,
she instantly recollected her spirits, and causing her self to be forthwith set
on shore, she commanded some quilts to be made ready; and not able to attend so
long while her train was landed, away she went with the Knight of the Lions;
and being winged by her affection, she alighted within a little after where the
Knight reposed himself; howb^it, understanding that he was asleep, she would by
no means disturb him, but fell to considering of this dreadful creature, which
made her afraid being dead, and admiring the courage of her Knight, who had
made no difficulty to undertake him. Hereupon her people arrived, who thinking
it almost incredible, that one man could kill so great, so furious, and so
formidable a monster, published his praises in such manner, as if they had no
tongues but to proclaim him for the most excellent Knight of the earth. Whilst
every one was thus commending, he awaked, and finding himself better then he
was, he would have risen, seeing Silvana coming toward him, but she, not able
to forbear kissing of him before all the company, forbad him with such a grace,
that he suffered himself to be laid upon the quilts, for to be carried to a
Castle about two leagues from thence, where Silvana purposing to abide some
time, sent her Knights over all the country, to assure the death of that
dangerous Serpent; whereupon, a world of men and women came in ^locks, who
wondering at the valor and features of this Knight, would willingly have
prostrated themselves before him, as the chief of all their Gods, if he would
have permitted such idolatry; but rendering the glory unto God, to whom it was
due, he modestly dismissed them, and was contented that the monster should be
flayed, and that his skin, stuffed with straw, should be set over the principal
gate of the Capital City of the Island of Silvana, whither a little after he
went to the unspeakable satisfaction of the people, who strewing sweet herbs
and flowers in his way, as he passed through the streets, cried him up to heaven
with their acclamations, naming him the Savior of their country, and their
Tutelar God.

CHAP. XLIII. Trasiclea the valourous Princess of Tramazond, hearing the world
talk of the valor of the Knight of the Palms, sends to seek him, the messenger
finds him out, shows him the picture of this Princess, he parts with her from
the Island of Silvana, and goes to meet with her.
WHilst these lovers lived thus without cross or fear, whilst the trees and
gardens were witnesses of their pleasures, whilst they bathed themselves in
their delights, and every day incountered some new way or other to render them
more pleasing, all foreign parts were filled with admiration, and the name of
the Knight of the Palms became so famous, that there was no other talk but of
his valor; the pictures of the monster ran from country to country, his
figure was wondered at, his greatness and force was considered, and every one
held it for a miracle, that one man alone had the courage to affront him,
forces sufficient to combat him, and so much valor as to kill him. Merodiana
having sent Cistenia to observe the carriage of her Knight, was advertised of
this victory, which made her resolve to pass into the Island of Silvana, for
to draw her lover out of her sisters arms; but she lost her labor, for the
Destinies, that meant to dispose otherwise of the exploits and fortunes of this
Knight, would not permit her to see him, for to hinder his happiness, and thus
it was: The fame of the glorious victory, which he had obtained, running from
country to country with pictures thereof, as I have related before, came to
the cars of Trasiclea, the fairest and most valourous, but withal the proudest
Princess of the world. She was daughter to the Emperor of Tramazond, a mighty
Potentate, and that deriving his original from the Sun, found the antiquity of
his house in the race of the Gods, an opinion that rendered this beauty so
glorious, that she esteemed no mortal wight capable of her alliance, nor
worthy of so great and precious a treasure. This Princess then, who despised
men, and ranked her self among the Deities, who thought she deserved Altars,
and that held nothing so glorious nor redoubtable as her arms; hearing the
commendations which every one gave to this Knight, could not believe at first
that he was so strong, so valiant, and every way so complete as was reported;
but having usde the means to have his picture made to the life, together with
that of the Monster which he had slain, she beheld it often with wonder, and
finding nothing to be added to the proportion of his body, and less to the
perfection of his beauty, she said; If the Painter has not flattered this
Knight, he is in my mind the most accomplished under heaven: But that which
most amazes me, is to see him so young, and to hear tell how he has defeated
this Monster, whose figure alone gives terror to the most confident; verily he
is worthy of a place among our Gods, the world may adore him, and if I were at
any time to bow unto the affection of a mortal wight, I should never choose any
other to sort my greatness withal. But good Gods! what do I say, if I were to
bow unto the affection of a mortal wight? me thinks I feel already a new
passion that torments me; and by what I could comprehend from the complaints of
them that have been in love, it must needs be that love whose power has been
so vaunted of, and that means to triumph over me, as over all the rest of
humane kind. For having always disdained to set mine eyes upon any one, I am
marvellously satisfied with this picture, the sight of this warrior pleases
me, and I find such powerful charms in him, that I love him with an extreme
desire to see him. O ye Gods! from whence comes so great a change, Trasiclea?
Where is that spirit which made thee raise thy thoughts to the heavens? Art
thou so weak as to suffer thy self to be vanquished by a man, nay to take
delight in confessing it? Where are those high resolutions of thine, to join
thy self to none but one of the greatest of the Gods, as capable alone to enjoy
the merit of thy beauty? I vow this is a strange baseness in thee, wherefore
altering thy mind, reassume thy former motions. My former motions? why this is
the way to follow my former motions: for there is nothing in the Gods which I
meet not withal in this Knight: behold, here is the best face in the world,
this grace contents me wonderfully, this gentle eye demonstrates an agreeable
disposition, this warlicke countenance a most generous courage, and this shape
an incomparable valor: What shall hinder me then from loving him with such
infinite perfections? Nothing, nor shall I ever be persuaded that I fail in my
choice, since I find in him all that can be wished for in a divinity. But to
what end serves all this, if he do not know my mind? For nothing but to trouble
me, wherefore I will no longer forbear to let him understand that I am resolved
to love him, so shall I be no way accessory to my own suffering. In this manner
did this proud beauty, forcing her natural inclination, conclude to see our
Frenchman; but desiring first to be satisfied, how far his valor extended, she
took her Arms, where with she was as much redoubted as with the charms of her
eyes; and encharging a Damsel with a picture which represented her so well to
the life, that there wanted nothing but speech: she left her fathers Court, and
rode four days together with little or no intermission, till she came near
the Island of Silvana, where she rested her self in a shepherds cottage, that
joined close to a bridge, over the which he was necessarily to pass; and
giving her Damsel, that followed her, ample instructions of her pleasure, as
also assuring her that she should find her in that place, she sent her into the
Island of Silvana for to draw the Knight of the Palms from thence. This Damsel
then proceeding in her journey, traveled three days with much amazement to
hear nothing spoken of but the commendations of this warrior; and being come
near to the capital City of the Island, she met with twelve Damsels, and as
many Knights, whereof one having kindly saluted her, demanded whither she went:
I am going, said she, to see the wonder of the world, the excellent Knight of
the Palms, the Hercules of this Island, and the Mars of the earth, that I may
one day boast I have seen the only rarity of our time. Now believe me, said
the Knight, you do not praise him without cause: for if you had beheld him in
the midst of Armies, as I have often done, when he fought for the beautiful
Merodiana, who is going here in this litter for to see him, you would say more
if it were possible. I have heard, said the Damsel, what he did in the wars:
for it is bruited every where, that in single co^bat he defeated the so
redoubted King of Licagena, and routed his forces with such mavelous valor,
that in an army of thirty or forty thousand men which he had, scarce two
hundred escaped: But it is strange, that neither in all this country, nor of
any one that ever I did meet withal yet, could I never learn what he is
Marvel not at that, said the Knight, these great warriors go always unknown
through the world, nor ever discover themselves, but upon some extreme
necessity. I have known him diverse months together in Merodiana's court, yet
could I never learn his name, or condition, nor do I think, our Mistress, who
questionless has a great power over him, can so much as tell of whence he is.
He is very reserved, said the Damsel; but I imagine that he conceales himself
so, to decline all diversions from his enterprises: howsoever we must conclude,
that he is the prime Knight of the world. This discourse having carried them to
the City, the Damsel followed Merodiana, who was received by her sister with
much show of gladness, though in her heart a thousand times she cursed her
coming; howbeit understanding that the Knight of the Palms was gone a hunting,
and would not return again till the next day, she presently got to horse again,
thinking she should have more liberty to speak with him in the woods, then at
the Court; and informing her self which way he went, she got to the Forest,
where having rode up and down a good while, at length she incountred a place
where the Knight of the Palms, in a hunters habit, was staying to refresh
himself. Sir, said she, guessing by his goodly presence it was he, can you tell
me where I may find the Knight of the Palms, who they say is in this forest?
Gentlewoman, answered he, you see him here before you, ready to do you any
service, if you please to employ him. Why then, said she, my travel is at an
end, and my mind at rest. My Lord, I do not seek you to importune you with any
request, but to let you see a piece, the like, I am persuaded, is not in the
world again: Whereupon opening the box, she presented him the picture of
Trasiclea; which as soon as ever he had cast his eye upon it, so transported
and troubled him, that he staggered as if he had been struck with thunder. Ah!
what a beauty is here, said he, and who would believe that Nature could be so
prodigal in the distribution of her graces? Surely all her treasures are here
assembled, to make this creature perfect; and, questionless, she took the
pattern of her out of heaven. You may well imagine so, said the Damsel: for she
derives her original from the father of the stars; but alas! you cannot
judge of half her perfections: for this piece represents not the grace which
she gives to her actions, and deprives her of the moity of her glory. I easily
believe it, said Alcidamant, but had she less then I behold, it were enough to
force the most insensible soul of the world. Boast then, said she, that you
have seen the rarest thing in the earth, and restore me my picture, for I mean
to take my leave of you, that I may not be benighted before I get me a lodging.
How Gentlewoman, said he, will you so soon bereave me of a thing whereon all my
content depends? Be not so cruel, I beseech you, but let me enjoy the sight of
this Goddess a little longer. By my faith, said she, smiling, I Will make no
bargain with you, until you have sworn to grant me such a boon as I shall one
day ask of you. You shall have all that you can desire of me, answered he. Why
then this picture is yours, said she, and further to oblige you, I will bring
you to the speech of her whom it represents, and place you in her favor. O
God, said he, can I be so happy! Yes that you shall, answered she, and if you
will go presently along with me, I Will not only let you see her ere it be long,
but so work, that you shall receive assurances of her love. I would abandon all
other felicity, said Alcidamant, to undertake this enterprise; wherefore, do
but give me leave to arm my self, and I will wait upon you presently. I Will stay
for you as long as you will, said she, provided you return not again to the
City. Whereupon, Alcidamant setting his horn to his mouth, winded it so loud,
that it was heard of Arnides* Troilus, and some other Gentlemen, who immediately
repairing unto him, were much amazed to see him arm himself.

Gentlemen, said he, and you my noble friend, (speaking to the Knight of the
Lions) I shall desire you to return unto my Lady, the Infanta Silvana, and
excusing me to her, please you to let her know, that the nec^ssity of certain
affairs, which concern the good of this Gentlewoman, will not permit me to go
and receive her commandments, for I am instantly to depart, and that I am not
able to prescribe my return; which nevertheless, shall be as soon as possibly
I can. Herewith, being quite ^ med, he took his leave of them, and followed by
his Squire, he rode away with the damsel, who to make the time seem s^ort,
fell to entertain him with a discourse of the greatness of her Mistress, whilst
Troilus and Silvana's Knights returned to the City. Their news extremely
discontented the two sisters, who having recourse unto their tears,
reciprocally accused each other of so great a misfortune: Their grief was
alike, their complaints were the same, and so was their opinion, that they were
betrayed by one another malice. My Knight unwilling to displease my sister,
said Silvana, has absented himself, because he will not caresse me before her,
though I think he will will return again as soon as she is gone; but I have
great cause to complain of him, for this fear testifies love, and puts me in a
jealousy. The absence of my servant, said Merodiana, gives me no less content
then vexation, it shows both respect and weakness, it makes me suspect some
familiarity between my sister and him, and yet declares that his affection
lives still for me: They have been inward together, I believe it,
nevertheless, I will not impute that fault unto him, for it is a hard matter
for a Gentleman to avoid the surprises of a shameless woman; my sister has
presented her self unto him, occasions tempt men, and make the most resolved to
err; but I must divert this mischief, retire my self, and send to him to come
unto me; he is much indebted to my favors, and I have always known him too
amorous for to fail me. Whereupon, calling for ink and paper she wrote a
letter, such as her passion indicted, and commanding Cistenia not to stir from
thence till she understood of his return, or if his stay were long to seek him
out; she went back to her own Island, leaving no less content by her
departure, then her coming had brought trouble to her sister, who being
confident that she should quickly see her lover again, remained well satisfied.

CHAP. XLIII. Alcidamant combatting the Knight of the Phoenix, near to a
bridge, is set upon by three Giants, whom with incredible valor he slayes, and
then he knows the Knight of the Phoenix.
THE Knight of the Palms traveling with an amorous impatience, found ages in
minutes, and thinking of the sovereign beauties of this Princess, he said: O
God! What Spirit possesses me, and why do I persuade my self that I may obtain
a favor worthy the birth of the greatest Monarch of the world. I know that m^n
ascribe little to merit, and that they look upon the greatness rather then the
virtue of persons; in the mean time I flatter my self, and foolishly presuming
upon that, which I should never hope for, I run to my ruin under the false
appearance of a good: me thinks it were fitter for me not to try this hazard,
and seek a fortune that becomes me, rather then lose my self in this vain
ambition, so should I live at quiet, and out of fear; whereas otherwise, I can
expect nothing butreproaches, for being so much wanting in judgment. But what
is this I say? Why do I travel up and down the world, if it be not with an
intent to equal my fortune with the greatest, and one day to receive a
recompense answerable to my virtue? If I should retire now, I were more to be
blamed for my cowardice then for my presumption, I must pursue the good fortune
which reaches a hand to me, of a mean Knight become a mighty Prince, if heaven
please to favor me, and above all endeavor, with the venture of my life, to
obtain those felicities, which are promised him tha^ shall possess so
incomparable a beauty. Entertaining himself in this manner, and with the
Damsells discourse, three days past away without any adventure at all; but on
the fourth, approaching a bridge, he saw a Knight presenting himself with a
Phoenix in the midst of his shield, sitting his horse in such a comely manner,
of so brave a presence, and so rich armed, that it did him good to behold him.
Now on my faith, said he, turning him to the Damsel, yonder is the gallantest
Knight that ever I beheld; but I doubt, in regard of the desire I have to meet
with no impediment in my journey, that I must be forced to combat with him
before we shall have our passage free; howsoever, if I be constrained to it, I
carry the key at the end of my lance. Herewith, the Knight approaching within a
pikes length of him, said: Noble Sir, I am obliged by the commandment of a
Lady, that soveraignizes over me, to die upon this bridge in maintaining that
she is the fairest in the world, or bring her the shields of all such as shall
pass over it; wherefore I am come to demand yours, and in case you deny it me,
then to wish you to prepare your self to fight with me, though I am very loath
to hinder the designs of so brave a Knight as you seem to be. Verily, answered
he, if the condition of your enterprise did not extend to the glory of Ladies,
your gentle language would peradventure have made me take my shield from off my
arm, and given it you without fighting; but seeing there is question of the
honor of beauties, we must see which of us two is the strongest, for having
been so happy as of late to serve the fairest and most accomplished Princess
of the earth, I cannot leave you in the error you are in, nor suffer any other
to be preferred before her Excellence. We may perchance have one and the same
Mistress, said the Knight of the Phoenix, and she whom you adore, may be her
that I serve. So much the worse for you, said the Knight of the Palms, that
being a just occasion to make us everlasting enemies, for not enduring a
concurrent, the dispatch of you shall free me of all competition, or I shall
leave you without jealousy by my death. Herewith, turning about their horses,
they came to encounter one another with such fury, that the ground trembled
under them; their fortune was equal, and their lances were broken upon each
others shield without any other effect, so as they passed by one another
unmoved, like two strong towers shocked together by the violence of the winds.
Alcidamant being extremely vexed to see his adversary in his saddle,
courageously drew out his sword with an intent to assault him; but he of the
Phoenix desired him to run still until such time as one of them was
overthrown. By my life, said he, wood is too weak for our desires, and the
importance of the quarrel; nevertheless, do as you please; whereupon the
Knight of the Bridge having caused four lances to be brought, each of them
chose that which he thought was the strongest, and taking the field again, they
incountered once more in such a rude manner, both with shields and bodies, that
they seemed to have hit against great rocks; the Knight of the Bridge lost a
stirrup, passing along with some astonishment, and the Frenchman finished his
course somewhat amazed at the valor of his enemy, whom he commended in his
thoughts for the strongest that ever he m^^ withal, next to the incomparable
Knight of the Roses, whom he termed the Phoenix of warriors. Howbeit, rage and
jealousy together made him take up the third lance, wherewithal he resolved
to vanquish, or to die; when as he perceived three furious Giants to appear,
whereof one espying the Palms on his shield, cried out: Mighty Gods, how much
am I bound to thank you for putting the murderer of Fangomadan into my hands,
that I may in^^ict some horrible vengeance upon him.

Herewith Alcidamant perceiving him to make toward him, turned his horse
about, and setting spurs hard to him, ran his Lance so just against this new
comers visor, that he past it quite through his head, sending him stark dead to
the earth, to the infinite discontent of the other two, who charging him both
at one instant with two heavy and terrible blows, made him bend with his
shoulders even to the saddle bow; but raising himself quickly up again, he drew
out his rich sword, and laying at him that first presented himself, he cut his
Shield in two, and gave him a great gash in the arm, whence the blood trickled
down apace upon his armor: therewith presently striking at the others head, he
had cleft him to the brain, if his sword had not turned in his hand;
nevertheless the blow was such, as it astonished him, and forced the blood out
of his ears and eyes. In the mean time the Knight of the Phoenix, who was
advancing to succor him, if need were, observed him with wonder, he was amazed
at his confidence in the midst of such danger, marvelled at the dreadfulnesse
of his blows, but especially admired his dexte^ity in striking, and avoiding
the swords of his enemies, upon whom his never fell in vain: the ground was
strewed with pieces of their armor, the blood issued out of five or six places
of their bodies, and they found themselves so weary and weak, that their
strokes fell not with such fury as at the beginning of the combat; which the
Knight of the Palms perceiving, he discharged so terribly on the helmet of him
that pressed him most, as he clove him to the teeth: and carried with the same
rage, he advanced his sword immediately to strike the other, who in extreme fear
would fain have avoided the blow, but being to slow, he received it with so
great violence, that it divided his body in two pieces, one moity remaining in
the saddle, and the other tumbling to the ground, with such amazement to the
Knight of the Phoenix, who beheld it, that he was lost in the admiration of
these horrible blows. Alcidamant seeing himself delivered from his enemies, put
up his sword, gave thanks to God for his victory, and approaching to the Knight
against whom he was running, when as the Giants assaulted him, he said, Now it
is time for us to decide our difference. I, said the other, who wondered at the
