greatness of his courage, if you were in better case; but the pains you have
taken in this combat, will not permit you to begin another at this instant;
take time to breath and refresh your self, to morrow we will try for the
mastery; to obtain it now, would be no glory to me. In the mean while pass the
bridge, if you mean to get a lodging to night. What, said Alcidamant, shall I
leave a rival behind me? and is it thus that you defend the beauty of your
Mistress? Now as I live, you shall not escape me so: I esteem of mine better
then to testify so little love unto her; your excuses shall not serve your
turn, you must either confess my Mistress to be fairer then yours, or if the
beauty we adore be the same, you shall swear to pretend no interest unto her,
else resolve your self to fight: for I have courage enough to vanqu^sh you
upon this quarrel. Do not too hot, said the Knight of the Phoenix, I have
sworn not to comb^t with you to day, neither upon this nor any other occasion:
you would have me speak for the advantage of your Mistress, I am contented:
for I hold her to be fairer yet then you do, and love her much more then you
think for; but to tie me, by your menaces, not to love her, nor to pretend unto
any part in her favor, I cannot do it, breathing but by her, and for her
content: wherefore I may not promise you an impossibility. Nor may I, said
Alcidamant in choler, suffer you to part from hence, but upon these
conditions: and let me be forsaken at my need, if I leave you till such time as
either you or I be in case not to hurt one another any further. How, said the
Knight of the Phoenix, will you force me to fight against my will? I that I
will, said Alcidamant, or you shall confess before this Damsel, which has
the honor to belong unto her whom I serve, that you utterly renounce all
pretense unto her. Are you so hardy, said the Knight of the Phoenix, that you
dare threaten me, and think to vanquish me in the ease you are in? I know well
enough, said Alcidamant, that you are strong and valiant, the trial which I
have made of you, makes me not doubt, but I had rather die a thousand deaths,
then offend my Lady in any manner whatsoever. It seems you love her much, said
the Knight, seeing death is of less consideration with you, then the loss of
her favor. I, more then you imagine, said Alcidamant, but to what end is all
this discourse? Knight you must satisfy me otherwise then with words, there is
day enough yet to break a Lance, and two have two or three bouts with our
Swords: come, let us dispatch, and be not too backward where it concerns you so
much; this delay does not testify the passion which you say you are in for
her. Well, said the Knight of the Phoenix, who took great pleasure in
Alcidamants choler, I am ready to give you contentment; but it shall not be
before you have told me whether you know your Lady, or what her name is. I am
not so happy, answered he, for I never saw her but in picture. Well, I will do
you a good office then, said the Knight, in letting you know her indeed:
Whereupon doffing her helmet, she discovered an Angelical face; which our
Frenchman beholding, observed it to be the very same that Love had engraven in
his heart. O God! said he, presently alighting, and falling on his knees before
her, Madam, how have I erred in employing my Arms against you, to whose service
alone they are dedicated? ascribe this fault to my ignorance, which may justly
excuse me; and, receiving my vows, be pleased I beseech you, that as your
Knight I may give an end to all the adventures of the world under the favor of
your name. Valiant warrior, said she, being alighted to raise him up, my
greatness, which is more then humane, would not permit me to abase my self so
much as to salute you, did not your virtue render you worthy of that honor:
your valor, that carries your name over all the earth, has made me desire to
see and try you, that so I might know whether the effect be answerable to the
praises which the world gives you; but believe me, you have wrong, in that you
have not altars erected unto you, and your glory placed where it deserves:
howsoever it suffices that you are esteemed of me as you ought to be, and that
I have such an opinion of you, as obliges me not to pardon you, (because you
have never offended) but to grant you the favor to be my Knight. Wherefore I
receive your service and your vows, and do further promise to give you one day
that place in my bed which I had reserved for some one of the Gods, being
hitherto persuaded, that the earth had not a man worthy of that fortune. Madam,
answered he, trembling with joy to hear the sentence of his felicity pronounced
in so sweet a promise: Be sure, that to merit such grace, I will do things
above the power of man; and that in my services, you shall find all that can
be expected from an obliged soul, protesting nevertheless, never to dispense
with my self for the respect which I owe to your greatness. No, no, said she,
love will endure no constraint, and I desire we may live together without
ceremony, that we may with the more sweetness enjoy out conversation. I will
submit to such laws as you shall prescribe me, said Alcidamant, and you shall
see me eternally disposed never to fail against the obedience of your
commandments. That is it which I desire, said Trasielea, in the mean time get
you to horse, and follow me to the Emperor my father; unto whom I will present
you for to be admitted into the number of his Knights. Whereupon Alcidamant
mounting on horseback, after he had very humbly kissed her hands in some
acknowledgement of the grace she did him, rode along with her, and entertained
her with the best discourse his troubled mind would permit him to use.

CHAP. XLV. Alcidamant entertains amorous discourse with the beautiful
Trasiclea, and encounters Rozanel d' Astre in the midst of a wood who relates
unto him his love with Angelea of S^pradisa.
ALcidamant thinking no glory in the world equal to that which he had in the
sight of his Lady, rode on so contented, that he esteemed himself the happiest
man living; he often fixed his eyes on her, and finding her incomparably fair,
whether he considered the delicate features of a perfect visage, or thought
upon the ^orce which she had showed in justing, he conceived her to be that
Pallas whom the Ancients had worshipped: She on the other side, observing a
most extraordinary grace in his actions, an amorous face, a lovely eye, a sweet
disposition, a warlike and majesticall countenance, imagined him to be the God
of battles, whose power and arms the whole universe adored; in such sort that
their content was rec^procall, their glory alike, and their desires common.
Trasiclea beheld the letters which in gold were embossed upon her Knights
Armor, with a great mind to know the mystery thereof. Alci^amant many times
considered the figur^ which he saw in the midst of his Ladies Shield, musing
at the cause that moved her to affect that bird; both of them carried by the
same desire, were opening their mouths to inform themselves of it, and
retained by a like consideration, would not seem too curious. At last Trasiclea
less ^ash^ull, or more amorous, said unto him, Since you are my Knight, you
may not refuse to impart your adventures unto me, to tell me freely who you
are, and for the love of what Lady you have c^used those characters to be put
upon your Armor. It is more then fit, said he, that I should satisfy you
herein: I am a Knight errant, native of the kingdom of France, having no
better fortune then that of my hope, and most unworthy of your greatness, if
you measure not my merit by my love, strangers call me the Knight of the Palms,
and my friends know me better by the name of Alcidamant: As for my parents,
they are noble, but in truth not furnished with great estates, though I may say
without vanity, that Crowns are unjustly wanting to their worth. Touching these
Arms, which were given me by a learned Inchantresse, when I was to combat
Fangomadan; I conceive they were made upon the occurrence of our loves: for
here are the first letters of our names interlaced, a T, which signifies
Trasiclea, and an A, which is as much to say, as Alcidamant, so that I presume
with reason, that all this has been governed by the providence of heaven: But
Madam, I have been long meditating on the device you bear in your Shield, and
do therein find no less a mystery then in these characters: for bearing two
birds which never meet together, as being unique in their kind, I am persuaded
that you would thereby figure your merit, and my love, which separately, or
together, can receive no comparison in the world, nor ever can be incountred in
one and the same affection: for your beauties, which take their original from
heaven, and my love, which is derived from your divine perfections, seem to
make but one person of our two bodies, as these birds are united in such a
fashion, that you think them to be but one, were it not for the difference of
the heads.

I do believe with you, said she, that there is a great deal of mystery in our
encounter, for these arms were given me by a woman, who having told me, that
with them I should receive a wound, whereof I should never be cured, and yet
that the steel of no enemy should ever pierce them, it had dissuaded me from
ever using them, but that she added withal, how this wound should no way
endanger my life, but contrarily, I should find so much delight in it, that I
should bless the time wherein I got it; all which is manifestly made good at
this instant, my hurt being no other then the love wherewithal I am stricken,
which shall not diminish by the knowledge I have of your mean fortune; for
being a Gentleman, virtuous and valiant, I shall affect you far more, then if
you had Empires without virtue, courage, and glory; only live with me as I
have told you, and I shall prize your valor above all the Kingdoms of the
earth, seeing riches and crowns ought not to be the object of a generous
spirit. These lovers entertaining one another in this manner, traveled with
such content, that whole days past away insensibly, so that being not above
five leagues from Tarsipolis, the Capital City of the Empire of Tramazond,
Trasiclea sent Cesarina (such was the Damsels name that conducted Alcidamant)
for to see whether any adventure was befallen at the Court worthy a courageous
undertaking, that their appearance there might be so much the more remarkable.
The Damsel b^ing departed, then these lovers, transported with the excess of
their joy, which made them think of nothing else, lost themselves in a forest,
where they rode so long till they were overtaken by the night, and forced to
rest under the tree till morning, eating, in the mean time, of such prov^sions
as Ar^ides carried along with him, having no other light then that, which
reciprocally shone from their eyes, they supped with more content, then if they
had been separated in the richest palace of the world, with the best and most
exquisite meats that possibly could be had. This small repast being done, they
began to renew their discourse, when as they heard the voice of one that
complained hard by them. Their curiosity thereupon causing them to arise, they
took one another by the hand, and with their helmets on, went softly to the
place from whence the voice came, and heard one speak in this sort: Wretch that
I am! To what extremity does fortune reduce me, bereaving me of the means to
free my Lady, and reserving her deliverance to the valor of some Knight, who
finding her endued with such excellent beauty, may with reason demand her for
the recompense of his labors, and deprive me of that happiness, which I had
promised my self in the fruition of her. What, shall I survive then the grief
of her loss? Never, if I were once assured of it, but my hope in the goodness
of heaven does persuade some relief unto my misery: upon that then, Rozanel,
depend, and let no way be left unsought to succor thy distressed Angelea. This
complaint, closing with a world of sighs, exceedingly moved both Trasiclea and
Alcidamant, who advancing three or fowr paces, presently heard the Knight ask,
Who goes there? We are Knights, answered he, who would willingly bring some
remedy to your grief, and that desire you consider, how complaints do not be
seem a valiant and magnanimous man, seeing there is more glory in suffering,
then in such weak expressions. The darkness and silence of these woods are
very proper, I confess, to represent your sorrows unto you; but I shall desire
you to divert them with our company, to relate unto us the cause of your
misfortune, and afterward to make use of us, if you think us able to succor
you. I know not who you are, replied he, but your pity of my affliction does
testify that you are noble and courteous, wherefore I shall gladly obey you,
and recounting unto you my fortunes, i^brace the generous offers you have made
me. I am called Rozanel d'Astre, son to the valiant Amadis d'Astre, and to the
beautiful Rozaliana the Emperors daughter of the Parthians; I went out of
Constantinople certain months since, with an intent to make my self famous in
the world, in imitation of my father, who in his younger years never met but
with one equal to him in valor; namely, Spheramond of Greece his Cousin; I
traversed many Christian Kingdoms, giving an end to diverse strange adventures,
which I will not here particularize, to avoid ostentation, and traveled thus
glorious, without any other aim then honor; when as that proud tyrant of our
souls, Love, conducted me into the Kingdom of Sopradisa, to triumph over me by
the sovereign beauty of Angelea, Grandchilde to the invincible Amadis of Gaul:
I obtained her favor by killing a furious Giant, who knowing this Country to
be destitute of good Knights, ever since the loss which the Christians
received at the battle of Aleppo, committed mavelous insolences, and would
have married this fair Princess in despite of her self and her subjects, who
would by no means dispose of her without the authority of their Prince, named
Florian, then abroad in travel. This victory having given me all interest in
her, which a modest virgin may accord unto her lover, I lived so contented,
that I did not think fortune was able to cross me: But alas! I was not fully a
month in this felicity, when as to my infinite grief I perceived that our
happiness or unhappiness depend altogether on her. For one morning, I saw
three women enter into the hall of S^p^adisa, with their hair about their ears,
each of them bearing a torch in their left hand, a guilt truncheon in the
right, and viols on their heads, which tumbling down at such time as they had
made a circle in the midst of the hall, there arose such a thick fog, that it
was two howrs before one could discern any thing; at the end whereof, the
beauteous Angelea was not to be found, only near to the Royal Throne, a pillar
was seen, whereon hung a table of brass, with these words:

In revenge of the blood of Alifernes (so was the Giant named whom I killed)
Angele* sha^^ continually burn in a cruel fire, and shall not be freed from
thonce, till the pair without peer deliver her, the beauty of the valourous
Serpent having no less power therein, then the strength of the brave Lion.
Imagine now what case I was in, when I mist the object of my glory and desires;
verily. I was ready to die for grief; and had it not been for the ease I found
in my tears and sighs, it had stifled me; but fortune, that reserved me for
greater miseries, would not suffer me to end so happily. I remained then lying
altogether in affliction, unable to taste the comforts which the people of
Sopradisa offered unto me; and arming my self, I resolved to traverse all the
earth, and seek her even in the very jaws of hell; and accordingly, I have past
I know not how many countries, continually inquiring after the cause of my
mishap; nevertheless, being arrived in these unknown Kingdoms (whither I was
brought by as long and furious a tempest as ever was) without any news at all
thereof, I began to be in despair; when as a Damsel overtook me at the entry
of this wood, and told me that the deliverance of Angelea was nearer then I
imagined; but that the glory of it should not fall upon me, it being reserved
for the best Knight of the world; wherefore she bade me stay some time in this
Country, and follow such as showed themselves sensible of my sufferings; in
which regard, I will leave off afflicting my self, and if you please to accept
of my company, I will wait upon you, and see how propitious heaven will be unto
me in your assistance. Why this is nobly resolved, said Alcidamant, and I
assure you we shall be any way glad of your fair conversation; and therefore,
betaking your self quietly to your rest this night, to morrow as soon as the day
shall appear, we will set forth together, and peradventure we may find that,
which you have so much sought, with all the content you can wish for:
Whereupon, laying themselves down under the trees, Alcidamant caused Arnides to
keep watch, and amorously kissing his Ladies hand, he slept till morning.

CHAP. XLVI. Alcidamant, Rozanel, and Trasiclea leave the wood, Rozanel
delivers Cesarin^ whom three Knights pursued, Alcidamant slayes the King of
Dramir, valiantly gives end to the adventure of the burning Rock with the aid
of Trasiclea, Angelea is recovered, and the enchanted Knight is known.
LOve, and the inconvenience of their arms, not permitting these Knights to
take much rest, they arose with the Sun, and finding their horses, by Arnides
diligence, ready, they mounted thereon, with some amazement to each other;
Alcidamant and Trasiclea, observed Rozanel d'Astre, and seeing him so handsome,
well made, and with a countenance that promised much virtue and good, they were
exceedingly afflicted with his misfortune; on the other side, Rozanel beheld
the mavelous beauty of Trasiclea, whom he thought to be a Knight, and withal
admiring the martial look of Alcidamant, each of them finding something to
commend in his companion; and so they traveled together, till they got out of
the forest by the direction of a wood-seller, who set them in the way to the
City. Entertaining the time then with ordinary discourse, Trasiclea discovered
a Damsel that fled cross the fields to avoid the fury of three Knights that
pursued her. Being much offended with this baseness, she fell a gallopping
between Alcidamant and Rozanel, who desiring to make some proof of his valor
before these Knights, whom he greatly esteemed, he desired them to let him
chaftise these insolents, that went about to outrage women, and not to
interpose in his assistance, unless they found he was too weak for them. We
will do what you please, said Trasiclea, but if you enterprise this to give us
some testimony of your valor, your very countenance does sufficiently assure
us of that. I shall be glad, said he, to maintain this good opinion of yours in
the proof: wherefore, with your favor, I will undertake them single; so that
being not far from those Knights, he cried unto them, Turn about you villains,
and defend you from those that mean to punish this base outrage of yours to
women.

Yes Master fool, said they, hoping to dispatch him quickly before the other
two arrived, we will chastise your insolence, and teach you how to threaten such
as we are: wherewith they all three charged their Lances at him, and incountred
him in such sort, that had he been less strong and valiant, he might have kissed
the ground; but being not so much as once moved with this encounter, he ran his
Lance quite through the body of him at whom he had aimed it; and advancing out
his Sword at the finishing of his course, he discharged it so dangerously on
the helmet of him that was most forward, as he cleft him to the very teeth;
which made the third betake him to the wood, in hope to save his life from the
fury of this warriors blade: but his fortune was little better; for wanting
discretion to avoid Rozanels companions, Trasiclea incountred him so strongly
with her Lance, that she cast him out of his saddle with such mischance, as his
right foot hanging in the stirrup, he was dragged by his horse into the wood,
whither none of them followed to dispatch him, each of them making to the
Damsel, that upon sight of the defeature of her enemies, was returned. As she
came near them, Trasiclea perceiving her to be Cesarina, whom she had sent to
her fathers Cour to learn some news, wondered much at this which was befallen
her, and cried out, Cesarina, how came thou by this misfortune? Through the
insolence of Brandamar King of Dramir, answered she, who in revenge of a word I
let fall, as I past by him, made these Knights pursue me for to do me some
mischief; but that you may be the better informed of all, please you to
understand, that being entered into Tarsipolis, as you had commanded me, I was
much amared at the meeting of novelties worthy your curiofity: for the first
object appearing unto me in the hall, was a burning rock that walks of it self
(at the leastwise one can see no body that conducts it) and stays ordinarily
three days in the Court of a King or Prince in expectation, that some Knight
should make trial of the adventure, which in truth gives as much occasion of
pity as of fear: for in the hollow of the rock, one may behold a very
beautiful young Lady in the midst of the flames, who lamenting with a
million of sighs and tears, entreats for succor, and beseeches all good
Knights to draw her out of the fire, which diverse have undertaken to do; but at
the very instant when they go about it, a Knight all covered with fire comes
out, or if there be many that attempt it together, each one finds such a one
to encounter him, who having given him three or four blows with his sword, or
more, if the valor of the Knights be greater, he lays him all along in the
place, where all his pain is in the heat that he feels, which is not allayed
till such time as his arms be taken from him: and that which breeds the most
wonder, is, that the hall is not any whit the hotter for this fire, which
questionless is not material, and that no body feels the heat but only the
Knights that prove the adventure. This marvel seeming worthy of my pains, I
was upon returning to acquaint you with it; but espying two of my fellows, I
staid a while, and understood by them how all the Court was much troubled with
your absence, especially at a time when your presence was most necessary there
in regard of the interest of your beauty: for the King of Dramir, named
Brandimar, presented himself with intolerable insolency, in the lists of
Tarsipolis, where he maintained, that the beauty of his Mistress surpasses
all others whatsoever, and mads all the world to see him triumph over every one
that undertakes him, having so little right on his side, and from thence
proceeded the cause of my danger: for unable to conceal the anger I was in for
the wrong he did you, by preferring one before you that is not worthy so much
as to look on you, I said aloud as I passed by, that I would go and fetch a
Knight able to remove him from that error, and abate his pride; which put him
into such a rage, that he commanded them to follow me, and do me some outrage.
And this, Madam, is all the account I can give you of this journey. It is more
then I could hope for, said Trasiclea, but I am glad I met with thee so
opportunely, as to free thee from those Knights: Touching Brandamar, I doubt
not but to take such order with him, that either my Lance or Sword shall
determine the punishment of his temeritie. Madam, said Alcidamant, this combat
appertains unto me, and I should think my self most unfortunate if any other
should undertake the defense of your beauty, reserve your self for more
glorious interprises, and permit me to give you some small proof of my love in
this action. I grant it you, said Trasiclea, and shall be very well contented
to see him chastised by your hands. Whereupon doubling their pace, after they
had rendered thanks to Rozanel, who wondered to behold so fair a Princess bear
Arms, they arrived at Tarsipolis; where the first thing they did, was to go
straight way to the Camp to combat the King of Dramir, whereof the Emperor
being advertised, betook him presently to the windows, as much admiring the
gallant carriage of the Knights, as satisfied with his daughters return, whom
he easily knew by her Arms; and that having espied him, went up instantly to
him to do her duty. Your long stay abroad, said he, has extremely
discontented me; but your safe return makes a full amends for it: You will have
more cause to rejoice, Sir, answered she, when you understand how I have
brought you that famous Knight, who has filled all the regions hereabout with
wonder: he that slew the mighty King of Licagena, that with a handful of men
cut his Army in pieces; that killed the monster of the Island of Silvana, and
in my presence three furious Giants, with fingle might had made the greatest
Estate of the world to tremble. What a rich booty have thou got, my daughter,
said the Emperor, if thou can keep him here. He comes with an intent to be
of the number of your Knights, answered she, wherefore may it please you to
afford him as gracious entertainment as possibly may be: for I assure you,
Sir, he merits it more than any other Knight whatsoever. Be confident,
daughter, said he, that I will give him very much cause to abide in my court:
for all my treasures shall be upon him, and my chiefest Princes shall yield him
place. But let us see how he will carry himself against the King of Dramir,
which would prefer a common beauty far before yours, whose excellency only
deserves the title of Divine. Whereupon, going to the windows, they saw
Brandamar fly over the crupper of his horse, and the valiant Knight of the
Palms pass on with an admirable grace. Behold an encounter of the Lance, said
the Emperor, that does not belie the fame which this Knight has acquired in
the world; and if he can manage a Sword as well, our Amoroso shall miss of the
content he expects here. Trasiclea was about to reply, but was retained by
hearkening to her lover, who was alighted, because he would not fight with
advantage, and said to his enemy, that made but little haste in rising, having
been shrewdly shaken with his fall, Why how now King of Dramir, are you no
forwarder in defendidg the beauty of your Mistress? questionless she will
have but little reason to caresse you: up, up, it may be you shall rest in
another fashion by and by. These words, which made all the people fall a
laughing at him, having put him into an extreme rage, he rose as if he had
received no hurt, and drawing out his Sword, went and struck at Alcidamant in a
most violent manner; but he wifely avoiding it with admirable agility
discharged a full blow on his left arm, cutting it off sheer from his body.
Whereat this lame lover being strangely incensed, returned another with all his
force on the Frenchmans Shield, which proving impenetrable, it recoiled in
vain; howbeit nothing abashed therewith, he laid about him most furiously, and
rendered the combat very doubtful; but Alcidamant confidering that he fought
before the Father, and for the glory of his Lady, and disdaining to have the
victory any longer disputed, he advanced his Sword, and let it descend in such
a terrible manner on Brandamar, that it divided him to the very girdle;
wherewith all the assistants were so amazed, as they could not believe that this
blow could proceed from any other then the great God of Battles, and for such
would have adored him, would he have endured such vanity: but sheathing up his
Sword, and going to the Palace, he presented himself to the Emperor, who
received him with all the testimonies of a most extraordinary respect. Sir,
said he, kneeling down before him, the report which runs of the worthy esteem
your Majesty makes of good Knights, has given me the confidence thus to become
an humble suitor that you will be graciously pleased to accept of my service. I
am more contented with your presence, said the Emperor, then with the addition
of another Empire: whatsoever you desire in my Court shall be yours, and my
people shall honor you no less then mine own person. I shall never be worthy
of this favor, said the Knight: But Sir, I will perform such deeds of Arms for
your service, that you shall never repent any grace you have conferred on me.
Then turning himself to his fair Princess, and kissing her hands with
incredible delight, he assured her of the continuance of his vows. This done,
the Emperor would have had him conducted to his chamber; but being moved with
the complaints of that beauteous Infanta which he saw in the midst of the
flames of the burning rock, he besought the Emperor that he would vouchsafe to
entertain himself a while with beholding the trial of this adventure; and
desiring the same from his Lady, he was drawing out his Sword, when as he
perceived Rozanel advancing toward the rock, with the countenance of a man
half bestraught. My noble friend, said he unto him, whither run you thus?
Either to dye with my Angelea, said he, whom I see in that fire, or deliver
her out of her pains. Herewith the Emperor being advertised by Alcidamant, of
the love between this Knight, a great Prince among the Christians, and that
beautiful Infanta which he beheld in the rock, he stood to observe the success
of this enterprise; and saw, that having touched the rock with his Sword, a
Knight came forth of it, whose armor was covered all over with great flames,
and that showing a confident look, began one of the roughest combats with
Rozanel, that could be between two Knights, their blows were mighty, and
according to the extreme fury which Rozanel expressed in his fight, every
stroke he struck, gave an expectation of the end of this combat; howbeit, the
glory being reserved for another, he remained a little after extended in the
place, with an opinion that he should be consumed in his armor; nevertheless,
the heat allayed as soon as he touched the ground, nor was he further tormented
therewith when he was once unarmed, but such was his grief and displeasure,
that he would have thrown himself into the Rock, for to die with Angelea, had
he not been restrained by Alcidamant; who staying him by the arm, declared unto
him the fault he had committed by showing himself so weak.

Wherewithal, being somewhat pacified, Alcidamant drew his sword, and seeing a
man all in flames issue forth as before, he charged him with such fury that all
the hall was full of sparkles. The combat growing terrible, gave a world of
expectation to the beholders, every one looked with passion upon the Knight of
the Palms, who preferring death before the shame of not vanquishing in the
presence of his Mistress, pressed the enchanted Knight so hard, that ever and
(...) made him set his kno^s or his hands to the ground, and as much as he
could declined the strokes of his enemies sword, because he probably
conjectured that thereon depended the force of the charms, and that Rozanel had
resisted longer if his arms had not been heated with the Knights blows;
nevertheless, unable to avoid them all, he received one on his armor, which
beginning to burn him, as if he had lain upon the fire, put him into such a
rage, that taking his sword in both his hands, he discharged it so dangerously
o^ his enemies helmet, that he laid him all along upon the floor, to the great
contentment of the spectators, and especially of Trasiclea, who finding no
less glory in her lovers victory, then if she her self had gotten it, was
going to caresse him, when she perceived a dwarf come toward her from the root
of the Rock, and say: Madam, you are to have a (...) in this adventure, and
(...) to show your self no less courageous then this famous Knight of the
Palms; for now on you alone depends the good or ill of this Lady. Lo here, the
means of her deliverance, said he, presenting her with a violl full of
oderiferous water, enter resolutely into the rock, brea^ this glass upon the
head of the Infanta, and then you shall s^^ the enchantment dissolved.
Whereupon the Emperor stepped forth wit^ two of his Lords to stay Trasiclea,
remonstrating unto her, that there was no trust to be given to sorcery, and
that she would be consumed before she was half way in the Rock; notwithstanding
all which, she went with a da^^^lesse courage through the flames, and broke the
violl over the head of the Princess of Sopr^disa, which was no foo^^r done,
but presently the fire was quenched, Angelea felt no more pain, and the ar^our
of the Knight whom Alcidamant had combatted, lost the color which it had,
himself standing on his feet as well as ever he was in all his life. Behold, my
Lord, said Trasiclea, presenting Angelea to her father, behold the fruit of ^y
courage, I have delivered this fair Princess out of cruel torment, given new
life to this Knight, pointing to Rozanel d'Astre, and shall be the cause of the
happiness of all their future being. You speak most truly, Madam, said
Rozanel, transported with an excess of joy to see his Mistress fr^^ from pain,
you have given us indeed a new life, and have exceedingly obliged us, not to
breathe, but for your service: wherefore please you to command us something,
that we may dispose our selves to obey you. That which I desire ^f you is, said
Trasiclea; that you live long contented together, and that you render your
affections of proof against the power of Fortune. Whereupon assuring them, that
they should receive all the assistance they could possibly desire from her, she
left them to entertain Alcidamant, to whom they gave a world of thanks, and
commanding the Count d'Alcane to see them furnished with money and shipping for
their return into Greece. After they had refreshed themselves a while in
Tarsipolis, she was going to retire with Alcidamant, when as the enchanted
Knight having put off his Helmet, went and kneeled down before him, humbly
thanking him for the succor he had given him. The goodly presence of this
Knight possessing Trasiclea with an extreme desire to know him, she entreated
him to tell his name. Madam, answered he, I am called Florisbel, second son to
the great King of France, who leaving Constantinople a while since, for to seek
adventures abroad, was carried by sea into Cataya; where meeting with no less
attractions in the beautiful Semarimis, daughter to the King of that country,
then my cousin here, meaning Rozanel d'Astre, who as yet had taken no notice of
him, has incountred the Princess of Sopradisa, I set my self to serve her
with that good fortune as she received me for her Knight; whereupon I undertook
such enterprises for her sake, as were worthy the glory of my Ancestors, sent
her two hundred shields, of Knights that I had overthrown at a Just which was
held for to publish her the wonder of beauties: and not satisfied therewith, I
went up and down doing mavelous deeds of Arms under the name of the Gray
Knight; when as one morning I met with 3 old witches, who conducting this
enchanted Rock, laid such powerful charms upon me, that I entered all armed in
it, having no other desire then to withstand all those that offered to deliver
this fair Princess. And this, Madam, is all the satisfaction I can give you
for the present, but not all that you may expect from me hereafter: for I will
seek out occasions to serve both you and this brave warrior that accompanies
you. Trasiclea having courteously thanked him, presented him with the same
favors which she had offered to Rozanel, who by this time coming to know him,
entertained him with a world of kindness, and had therein continued longer,
but that Trasiclea desiring to accompany her Knight to his chamber, so to show
her subjects how she would have them to honor him, caused them to be conducted
to another, giving the fair Angelea three Damsels to attend her, with a charge
to see her extraordinarily served. All things being thus happily disposed,
Trasiclea left her Knight, went and unarmed her self, put on one of the richest
gowns she had, dressed her self wonderful wealthy, and appeared so beautiful at
supper, where the three Knights were set at table with the Emperor, that every
one thought she had some divinity in her. The cloth being taken away, and the
Emperor having discoursed with Rozanel and Florisbel, who then took their
leave of him, whilst Alcidamant was talking with his Lady, every one withdrew
till the next morning; at which time our Princes of Greece having kissed
Trasiclea's hand, and bidden the Knight of the Palms adieu, who would not make
himself known to Florisbel, imbark themselves with Angelea for their return to
Constantinople, where we will leave them for to prosecute our history.

CHAP. XLVII. Alcidamant incountring Trasiclea apart, discovered his passions
unto her, and the answer she made him.
ALcidamant living with unspeakable content in the midst of honors, and the
praises of all men, and no less esteemed, then if he had been the Prince of
Tramazond, had nothing further to wish for, but some more particular favors
from Trasiclea; he had love and impatience enough for to desire them, but too
much respect for to ask them: so that the pain of his fear equalled the
pleasure of his hope. Some days being sweetly past away in walking, familiar
discourses, and solitary entertainments, one evening he espied his Mistress
fitting in the shadow, under certain trees; where, kneeling down before her,
and taking her hand to kiss, he said unto her: Madam, consider I beseech you,
the extremity of my passion by the excess of your beauty; and marvel not, if
unable to support the violence of my desires, you see me in some unreasonable
impatience: I endure all that a poor lover can undergo; and the sight of you,
which should assuage my martyrdom, increases it: for apprehending the felicity
which I am to expect from your more secret caresses, I cannot bear the
retardment of them but with incredible torment. I am too forward, I am too
forward, I confess, and this complaint of mine, which seems unreasonable
(since you have always assured me that you live for me only) may justly offend
you: But alas! that which I feel, will not permit me to be longer contained, so
that I am forced to discover it, for to find some remedy, and that wholly
depends on you, which I beseech you to grant me, if you have resolved to render
me one day happy, and without making me longer to languish, advance my felicity
with your delitious fruition. Sir, answered she, I did not think our
familiarity would have carried you to such insolency, or that my affability
would have made you forget the respect which you ought to have: Have you well
considered that you desire, and upon what conditions do you demand it? Alas!
said he with a trembling, which thoroughly testified his love, and that gave
mavelous satisfaction to Trasiclea, who therein observed that which she
desired in this fear: Madam, do you set down the laws your self, I will
never oppose them, I opened my heart to you, to make you sensible of my
suffering, not to provoke you to displeasure; be not offended then, I beseech
you, with this liberty I have taken: or if it be distasteful to you, command me
to suffer and be silent, and you shall never hear me open my lips hereafter,
but with that very respect which may be used to a Deity. I do not require,
said she in a gentler accent, that you should live after with me: for my
affection will not endure such ceremonies, but you shall oblige me for hoping
for any thing more from me, then what honor will permit me to grant you: for
our conditions being so different, that they may well draw my father to be
otherwise disposed then I am, if he were aware of our determinations; it is
very necessary, in my opinion, to wait the time, when as your services, and my
persuasions may induce him to receive you as his son in law, rather then ruin
them by precipitation; I do believe that this expectation is grievous to you,
and that it leaves you not without much desire, for I judge of your suffering by
mine own; but say, my Knight, will it not be worthy of your pain, and will not
your pleasure taste the sweeter for your enduring? Yes verily, it will be
dearer to you, having gotten it with difficulty, then if you enjoyed it
otherwise. Complain no longer therefore, I pray you, but live with more
content, and give me occasion to love you everlastingly.

Madam, said he, it is no little grief to me that you should find any offense
in my complaints, but since they displease you, be assured they shall never
importune you more, I will suffer with silence, and if the violence of my
passion shall enforce any sighs from me, I will so carry my self that none but
these trees shall be witnesses of them; In the mean time be graciously pleased
to sweeten the bitterness of my displeasure with some more particular favors,
and encouraging me to attend the happiness which you make me to hope for,
permit me to come and visit you in your chamber when all the world is at rest,
that so I may have the content to see you without fear. I will advice with time
upon that, said she, for it is a business that requires good deliberation; but
not to be so ungrateful as to give you nothing, receive this kiss, the first
that ever man received from my divinity forbidding me the imparting of so great
a favor; receive, I say, this kiss for an infallible assurance of my promise.
Whereupon, laying her mouth to his lips, she ravished him with the incredible
delight of so amorous a touch. In this manner did these lovers spend the time,
and lived with such a tranquillity of mind, that never did two find less
distaste in the birth of their affections. If they saw one another, it was with
new assurances of their love, if therein they were hindered by any occasion,
that defect was supplied with letters; Arnides and Cesarina were always
walking with new commissions; briefly, their discourse and conversation was a
very Paradise. This contentment being without crosses, Alcidamant without
jealousy, (because the pride this Princess had esloigned all such as desired
to present her with their service) she without suspicion, not being able to
imagine that ever he will be in any passion for another, their life was rather
divine then humane, and all things disposed themselves by little and little to
render them happy; when as fortune, that takes pleasure in her inconstancy,
would needs let them see that the content of men depends upon her will, and
that their designs do never arrive at a good port without her assistance. Two
storms arose at once, whereof one was like to have overthrown the greatness of
that Empire, by reducing the Emperor and his daughter to the extremity of the
loss of their lives, and the other to have utterly ruined these lovers hopes
for ever enjoying one another. The first happened by the treachery of Drumelia,
Aunt unto Brandamar King of Dramir, slain, as you have heard, upon the quarrel
of his Mistress beauty; and the second through the indiscretion of Cistenia,
whom Merodiana had left in the Island of Silvana, with a letter directed to the
Knight of the Palms, as I shall deliver by and by, having spoken of that which
did precede this misfortune.

CHAP. XLVIII. Drumelia Aunt to the King of Dramir would have betrayed the
Emperor of Tramazond; Trasiclea is led away by cunning, the Emperor is
assaulted by three Giants, falls down hurt: Alcidamant succors him, with
increaible valor, slaies the three Giants, arrives in the wood just as
Trasiclea was ready to be ravished, delivers her by the death of his enemies,
and returns to the City.
DRumelia, Aunt unto Brandamar, unable with patience to endure the death of
this King, whom she held as dear as her own life, had recourse unto magical
books, wherein she was wonderfully expert; and knowing that the Emperor of
Tramazond, upon whom she desired to extend her rage, was too mighty for her to
be revenged of by arms, she proceeded therein with cunning; wherefore desiring
nothing so much as his death, and the destruction of Trasiclea, she resolved to
govern her enterprise with such judgment, that both their ends should arrive
at one instant, so that taking five dreadful Giants, near kinsmen to
Brandamar, she caused her self and them to be carried by night, in a cloud, to
the forest of Tarsipolis, where making certain circles amongst the trees, she
rendered her conjurations so powerful, that the great and formidable Giants
seemed little deformed Dwarfs; seeing them in the estate which she desired for
to cover her malice, she put her self in the midst of them, advertised them
particularly of all that they had to do; and taking the way of the City, she
came thither just as the Emperor was returning out of the Temple from
sacrificing to his Gods. Howbeit, not thinking it fit to present her self unto
him any where but in the Palace, because she would not play one match without
the other, she followed fair and softly after him, giving the people occasion
to laugh, for to see her walk between five such ill-favored creatures; and
coming to the hall, even as Trasiclea entered, she presently advanced toward
her, and kneeling down, with tears and sighs, she thus began: Excellent
Princess, I am reduced to that pass, as it is not possible for a wretched
woman to be more miserable; in so much, that if I do not find some assistance
of your pity, you shall see me cut off the poor remainder of my life here in
your presence, and this poniard in my hand shall second the cruelty of my
fortune, which has lately deprived me of a son, whom I may richly boast to be
one of the best Knights of the earth, rendering him a prisoner in the hands of
a merciless Giant, that loving the same Mistress, which he served, to free
himself of a rival, purposes to take away his life, if he be not speedily
succored: Now the fame which runs of your valor, has induced me to make this
address unto your greatness, with an opinion that I shall not be refused. No
verily, said Trasiclea, that you shall not, for I will serve you most willingly
in this extremity. Madam, said Alcidamant, extremely discontented to see her so
resolved, I beseech you to pardon me if I say, that you promise too lightly; I
am fitter for travel then you, and your divine person is not to be exposed
unto hazard, without more occasion. Leave the care of this to me, and give
your subjects the satisfaction of your presence, whilst I go and dispatch the
affair. Why my Knight, said she smiling, are you not contented with so much
glory as you have acquired in the world already, but that you would bereave me
of this too? Let me entreat you to stay here for to serve the Emperor my
father in my stead, and because it will not be long ere I return, you shall
seek to entertain him in the mean time. Now by my Crown, said the Emperor, I
am also of his mind, daughter, and do not hold it fit that you should
undertake this enterprise, wherein it may be there is more danger then you
think for. Sir, said Drumelia, who was very much afraid that her designs
should be very much discovered, you need not doubt her esloignment, her valor
exempts you from that; and to let you see that I do not venture her person
lightly, as you imagine, I Will stay here my self with you, and she shall be
conducted by two of these Dwarfs, so that in case she return not safely by to
morrow, with all the contentment you can desire, inflict the cruellest
punishment you can upon me. Trasiclea said unto her father, My Lord, there are
so few occasions of glory presented in these quarters, that I cannot without
much wrong to mine honor refuse this same; therefore permit me, I beseech you,
to depart with your good favor, and comfort your self the mean while in the
company of this noble Knight of the Palms. Well, since you will have it so,
said the Emperor, I Will no longer oppose your desire, but I am in some mistrust,
I know not wherefore, and cannot be persuaded that this voyage will be
prosperous. Trasiclea, having thus obtained leave, presently armed herself,
little regarding the suspicion her father had of the enterprise, which she
imputed rather to the imbecility of his age, then to any assured judgment; and
therefore having cast a thousand looks on her Knight, for to bid him tacitly
adieu, she departed with Cesarina and two of those Dwarfs, somewhat troubled
for that she had not the company of Alcidamant: The displeasure whereof, so
took up her thoughts, that never minding her enterprise, she rode on till she
came to the wood, whereinto the Giants were no sooner entered, but they
reassumed their former shape, laid two blows with their heavy maces on the
head and shoulders of this Princess, who thus surprised, fell, and kissed the
ground, with little or no memory at all. The Giants seeing her in this posture,
instantly alighted, bound her with cords, and laying hold on Cesarina, that
seemed more dead then alive, they tied her to the foot of a tree. Whilst this
Tragedy was framing in the wood, a more bloody one was acted in the City:
Drumelia thinking Trasiclea sure enough in the hands of these Giants, desiring
to play her part, touched the three Dwarfs with a wand she had in her hand, and
making them appear with their natural greatness, much amazed the assistants,
especially the Emperor, who going to save himself, received a blow with a
scymiter on his arm, which laid him on the ground, liker to die then to live.
Whereupon, a great rumor arose in the hall, the Courtiers betook them to their
swords by Alcidamants example, who, with his cloak wound about his left arm,
gave one of the Giants so furious a blow on the shoulder, that he opened him to
the very girdle, and instantly ran one of the other two quite through the body;
the third, who made a horrible massacre of the unarmed Knights, seeing the fall
of his companions, in a mighty rage flew at Alcidamant, hoping to cut him in
pieces; but the advised Knight, whose judgment was not overcome with fury,
slipped aside from the blow, and losing no time, gave him a deep and dangerous
wound in the thigh. The Giant, boiling with choler, was not then much sensible
of it; but a little after, advancing his heavy scymiter to discharge it on the
Knight, and stretching himself upon his feet to render his stroke the stronger,
he fell all along, and carried with him more then half of our Frenchmans cloak,
who receiving a light hurt on the arm, did for all that forbear the taking of
his enemies head from his shoulders, and suddenly running to the door, made
stay of Drumelia, who, beholding the miserable end of her kinsmen, would have
saved her self. By my life, said he, you old witch, you shall not escape me so,
your head shall answer for Trasiclea's life; Say, wicked creature, Whither have
thou caused her to be conducted? What, will thou not speak? No, I will be torn
in pieces, said she, before I will discover it; her death shall yet make some
satisfaction for the King of Dramirs, and the inhumane butchery of these his
kinsmen. What a horrible treason is this, said Alcidamant? But the
horriblenesse of thy punishment shall be answerable to it. Whereupon, dragging
her into the hall, he committed her to the custody of certain Knights, whom he
commanded to look well unto her, as they would answer it with the peril of
their heads; and perceiving the Emperor to be come again to himself, and that
the Chyrurgeons assured there was no danger in his hurt, he ran presently to
his chamber, caused himself to be armed with all speed, and mounting on his
horse, gallopped away toward the wood; where at the first arivall, he heard
certain cries, which made him put himself amongst the thickest of the trees, at
one of the which he saw Cesarina tied, and his beautiful Mistress in the hands
of two Giants, who were pulling off her armor for to ravish her. This sight
possessing him with a strange fury, he alighted, and with his sword drawn,
approached these two Colosses, and finding the head of the greatest unarmed,
divided it in two, thinking he was not obliged to use any courtesy to persons
that were not capable of it. The other, grown wiser by his companions
misfortune, laced on his helmet, and cried out: Stand, Caitiff, that I may
revenge the death of a man, whom thou have basely surprised, and let this one
blow be the reward of all thy wickedness. Saying so, he discharged his
curtleax with such violence, that he stunned the Knights arm, making him recoil
a pace or two back; but his wrath increasing, and considering that the safety
of his Lady was at stake, he laid at his head with such a tempest, that albeit
his sword turned in his hand, and that he struck him but with the flat, yet he
sent him dead to the ground, his brains flying out with the horrible violence
of the blow.

That done, he came speedily to Trasiclea, and cutting the cords wherewithal
she was tied, he said, O God! what inhumanity is this, to inchain her that is
able to captivate all the world? Madam, these barbarous villains were not
ignorant of your valor, and therefore the fear of your sword had made them
secure themselves by binding you: But what trick did they use to reduce you
thereunto? They surprised me being in a muse, said she, and with two mighty
blows laid me along; where remaining without motion, I could not hinder them
from binding me: And even as you came, these villains were unarming me, and
threatened to make me serve for the satisfying of their brutish lust; but thanks
be to the Gods, I am freed by your valor: yet I wonder how you could leave the
Emperor, for to arrive here so luckily. How? said he, leave the Emperor? We
have seen strange things within these two howrs. Then he recounted unto her all
that had passed in Tarsipolis, whereat she remained so much amazed and
contented, that she could never commend her good fortune enough, which had made
her the Mistress of so brave and valiant a Knight. Let us go my dear friend,
said she unto him, let us go and release the Emperor out of the care he is in
for the loss of me; and let us think upon the pains wherewithal we may
sufficiently punish this wicked creature that had so cunningly betrayed us. It
were fitter to think of that which I endure, answered he; and if you were as
just as fair, you would leave the care of that execution to the officers of the
Empire, for to undertake a noble resolution to give some speedy end to our
sufferings, nevertheless, seeing you have commanded me to be ^ilent herein, I
will proceed no further, but refer the performance of your promise to your own
gracious pleasure. Why see now, said she, how time begets occasion to content
you: for have you not to day done things able to oblige my father not to deny
you what you so much desire? yes, my Knight, you have, and if you will be
patient, you shall quickly see your self at rest: let not your complaints then
diminish the obligation of your succor, but let me feel the contentment of it
without grief. Whereupon Cesarina being untied, they took the way of the City,
wherein they met with five or six troops of Knights, which the Emperor had
sent for the deliverance of Trasiclea, who seeing her return with the valiant
stranger, (for so was Alcidamant ordinarily termed) and understanding how
matters had past, they raised his praises to such an height, that he was
ashamed of them, and Trasiclea, the most contented on the earth. The speed they
made, having soon brought them to the City, Trasiclea went straight to see her
father, who taking her by the hand, fell a weeping with extreme joy. Do I see
thee again, my dear child, said he, being out of all hope both of mine own
safety and thy life? Ah! how much am I bound to the Gods for so great a grace?
and what do I owe to this brave stranger, who has this day done such wonders,
as never will be forgotten as long as the world endures? Daughter, it is you
that must requite them, I leave you the power to do it, and will no way oppose
whatsoever you shall ordain for his recompense. My Lord, answered she, this
service deserves no less then a Crown; but we shall have time enough to think
of it: our present care must be to look unto your health. I find my self so
well, said he, that the joy of your return surpasses the pain I feel of my
wound: Go and refresh your selves both of you, whilst I take a little rest, as
I am advised by my Physicians. Thereupon those lovers bidding him good night,
went and warmed themselves, and then walked into the hall together for to
behold an infinite company of Bonfires which the inhabitants of Tarfipolis made
in every part of the City for joy of the good success of this adventure;
which done, they both withdrew into their chambers, Alcidamant studying how he
might demand some ease for his sufferings, without offending his Lady, and
Trasiclea what more greater favor she might confer on him, then formerly she
had done, and not contravenne that modesty which a virtuous and discreet maiden
ought to have in her actions.

CHAP. XLIX. The complainis of Alcidamant, Trasiclea's resentment, she
promises to esponse him the next day: Cistenia arrives in the mean time with
letters from Mer^dian^: Trasiclea by wile reads them, becomes jealous,
banisheth Alcidamant, and makes him feel the effects of her displeasure.
ALcidamant dying in his impatience, and finding nothing so grievous as the
command which was laid upon him, not to make any show of his torment, was
oppressed with strange unquietness. He went ordinarily into the gardens, walked
up and down the allies, and getting many times into the orchard, he laid
himself down upon the bank of a little stream which ran along by it; where,
under the shadow of certain trees, his eyes full of tears, he spoke thus: How
I envy your nature, that does not render you subject to the misfortunes which
follow men: you know not what it is to love; insensible of lovers pains, you
mock their sufferings; and never caring for the injuries of time, you let the
seasons work their effects: and now behold, you are beautifully adorned with
green leaves, whilst I am in ma^ty^dome, and with so little hope, as makes my
life a very languishment. Is not this a wonderful misery? Doubtless it is,
yea such as makes me desire to change condition with you, if I might, and wish
my self covered with your bark, therein to spend the time which Love has
allott^d to my pai^, th^^ so I ^ight be freed from the griefs wherewithal I
am surcharged. Carrying himself frequently in this manner, every one marvelled
that he was never seen in the Court, but at such times as he must needs be
present there; yea, and his Lady suspecting something, extremely desired to
know what became of him: Whereupon she caused Ces^^ina to watch him, and
understanding one day that he was in the garden, thither she went, visited all
the alleyes, and not finding him, she past into the orchard, where espying him
to lie under the trees, she stole as near unto him as she could. He was then so
entertained by his fancies, as he spoke not a word; but his silence lasted not
long: for suddenly he said, O Madam! how hard is this commandment? and what may
I hope from the extremity of my passions, if you will not permit me to show
them? Either you love me, or your promises are feigned. If you have resolved to
make me happy by giving your self unto me upon such conditions as honor
allows of, why do you refuse me that now which you will grant me then? you
will say, that respect restrains you: Ah Madam! that is but an ill opinion for
to make lovers languish: and she that admits of such a consideration cowardly,
deprives herself of happiness. I would to God, not that you should feel my
pain (for I will never wish you so much hurt) but that you may know the rigor
of it, that you might see a million of tears in my eyes, and that you might
judge by these infinity of sighs which ordinarily I fetch, whether I can be
without grief to see my self so long delayed from the greatest bliss which a
Knight can hope for in the world, you would then, without doubt, be more
sensible of my endurings, and advancing my felicity, give end to the martyrdom
wherein you had seen me. These complaints moved Trasiclea exceedingly; and had
she not been arrested by that bashfulnesse wherewithal maids are usually
retained, questionless she had made use of time and place to show her lover
that she desired his contentment no less then himself; howbeit, stealing
softly back, she returned into the garden, where considering her lovers
reasons, she sometimes resolved to give him satisfaction, and then by and by
was quite of another mind. At length, having continued a good while in these
extremities, she concluded to make no further difficulty therein, seeing she
meant to take him for her husband. This is, said she to herself, this is but to
defer his contentment with too weak considerations; and so many nights as pass
away unprofitably, seem to accuse me of want of love, I do my self wrong to be
so difficile for mine own content; but I will repair this fault, and living
otherwise hereafter, I will give my Knight no more occasion to complain. This
resolution carrying her back again to the orchard, she began to sing a far off,
for to draw Alcidamant out of his fantasies, who was very much amazed to behold
her, and to be surprised with tears in his eyes; whereupon he took his
hankercher for to wipe them, but Trasiclea staying his hand, said unto him: I
am very glad, my Knight, to see you weep in this sort, not that I take pleasure
in my cruelty, but to make it serve for your content: your complaints which I
have heard, have had the power to alter both my will and mind, so that I am
now resolved to give your services their recompense, to espouse you secretly,
and to let you enjoy all the privilege which marriage can afford you, until
such time as we may dispose my father to receive you more openly. Wherefore be
of good cheer, and prepare your self to come to morrow in the evening to my
chamber, where Cesarina and my Governesse shall be witnesses of the faith you
shall plight me to legitimate our caresses. Thus have I resolved to do, both as
your merit and my affection require. O God! said Alcidamant, falling on his
knees before her, can I, Madam, ever deserve this grace? and may I not well
repute my self the happiest man of the earth? yes, without doubt, I may, nor
do I think that my felicity can be matched with another whatsoever. O blessed
sufferings! what reward are you to have? What fruit do I gather from my tears?
and what treasure have I found in my patience. O the most fortunate Knight
breathing! Do thou promise to thy self not only an Empire, but the
possession of a Divinity? No, no, thou could not, this favor surpasses all
thy hopes by far, and obliges thee never to be ungrateful: neither, Madam,
will I ever be, I will labor to be found worthy of this grace by a million of
services: and the more you have exalted me, the more humbler and more
acknowledging you shall find me; give me therefore, I beseech you, these fair
hands, that I may, upon their beauties, imprint my thankfulness for the
compassion you have been so graciously pleased to have of me. My dearest
Knight, answered Trasiclea, seeing I have promised you an absolute power over
the rest, sure I shall never permit you more to kiss my hands: for purposing
very shortly to be your wife, I am to entreat you otherwise then heretofore:
wherefore now you shall have my lips (saying so she kissed him) wherewithal I
shall desire you to be contented, until our marriage shall authorize you
further.

Hereupon these two lovers taking one another by the hand, walked up and down a
while in the garden; but Trasiclea, to avoid all suspicion that might have
grown by their being met so together, modestly withdrew her self, and left him
with such an ecstasy of joy, that he knew not where he was. Night ensuing
thereupon, he went to see the Emperor, who finding himself healed of his
hurt, and in better state of health then he had been of a long time before,
resolved to hunt the next morning by the break of day; which fitted our
Frenchmans disposition wonderful well, who thinking he should that way pass
the time better then to remain in the Court, promised to wait upon him; and
accordingly no sooner did the Sun appear the next morning, but he got into the
field, where thinking of his approaching happiness, he made his horse to bound
with such a grace, that it amazed every one to see how bravely he sat him:
Then calling to mind his Mistresses amorous words, and considering them
severally apart, he thought no felicity could be comparable to his, nor that he
could ever be subject again to the crosses of Fortune. But alas! she made him
soon know, that our good or ill depend upon upon her inconstancy, and that it
is a great error in men to promise any thing of certainty to themselves in
this world. Whilst he crossed the woods, following the cry of the hounds,
Cistenia, the secretary of Merodiana's affections, left (as you have heard)
with a letter in the Island of Silvana, arrived at Tarsipolis, and going to the
palace, by ill fortune met with Cesarina, and enquired of her for the valiant
Knight of the Palms. Gentlewoman, said Cesarina unto her, is it for the
execution of any enterprise that you seek him? No, answered this unadvised
maid, but only to deliver him a letter, which I believe will be accptable unto
him, coming from one of the fairest Ladies of the world, and that loves him
infinitely. Marry, and he is worthy of it, replied Cesarina; but he is not now
in town: wherefore if you please to rest you in my chamber till his return,
which will be in the evening, you may then speak with him at leisure. I shall
gladly accept of your fair courtesy, said Cistenia, since you are pleased so
far to olige me. Whereupon going into Cesarina's chamber, she set some to
attend her whilst she went unto Trasiclea* whom she acquainted with all that
she had learned of Cistenia. Gods me, said Trasiclea, if we could come by this
letter, peradventure we might discover some extraordinary secret. There must be
some Art used to get it, said Cesarina; but seeing you so desire it, it shall
go hard but I will give it you in your hand ere be long. So leaving her
Mistress, she went and put a little of the juice of Poppy into some broth,
which was prepared for Cistenia, who had no sooner taken it, but that she found
her self so sleepy, as she threw her self presently upon a bed; where Cesarina
perceiving her to be fast enough for waking in haste, searched her Pockets, and
finding Merodiana's letter, carried it with all speed to Trasiclea, who having
opened it, read thus:

Merodiana's Letter to the valiant Knight of the Palms.
IF I had as little affection, as you have sense of the favors you have found
in my imbr^ces I should not only say that you were ungrateful, but I should
seek to be revengedof your neglect, howbeit, considering that you received them
upon promise of rendering them one day legitimate, I will proceed no further
then to complain of you, and to put you in mind of them, for to oblige you
unto a return; and indeed it is more then time, at leastwise if you mean to be
loial, neitherwil my patience suffer you to run thus any longer about the
world, depriving me of the fruits of my love, which if either you have
forgotten, or that your weakness has carried you to other affections, let me
at leastwise know so much, to the end that I may in my death find that only
comfort, which is left to a woman betrayed.


O ye Gods! said Trasiclea, how am I this day bound to you, for the discovery
of a secret of such importance, you show by this your care of me, that you are
mindful of our alliance. Alas! I was going to commit an irreparable fault, and
giving my self to the most disloyal Knight that lives, had made my self a
grief for all my future days. Art thou a deceiver, Alcidamant? Ah! how is that
valor ill bestowed, and how unjust are the Gods in the partition of their
treasures? Thou thoughtest to beguile me upon such a promise as thou made to
that unfortunate Lady, but thou art far from thy reckoning, and the happiness
which I was preparing for thee, shall be for ever withheld. Thou will find out
some reasons to cover thy cunning, but I Will not permit thee, nor do thee the
favor to hear so much as one poor excuse; but banishing thee for ever from my
sight, I will preserve my self from faulting a second time. Come then and take
me away all these preparations which I have made for this wicked man, and thou
Cesarina give me some paper, a Letter is the cause of my good, and a Letter
shall be the occasion of his pain. Whereupon, walking a great pace up and down
her chamber, she remained a good while pensive; but not caring how she wrote,
so as she might express her mind, she framed a Letter, and sealing it up,
commanded Cesarina to deliver it unto the Knight as soon as ever he returned,
but not to receive any answer. Which being done, she fell to walking again; and
every minute finding new cause of displeasure, she rendered her passion and
hatred greater, insomuch that she was more in rage, then ever she had been in
love. Whilst fortune was thus putting all in disorder, Alcidamant returned most
contented, thinking of nothing less then the mischief which was to fall upon
him; and declining the Emperors table, that he might not fail his Lady, he
betook him to his chamber, where within a little after Cesarina presented her
self to him. Beholding her, he was troubled with extreme joy, and thought that
she was come to lead him to the paradise of his delights; but she entering with
a sad countenance, said unto him: My Lord, my Mistress has commanded me to
deliver you this Letter; Alcidamant taking it with a great change of color,
and kissing it, though it were with a strange suspicion, which Cesarina's
countenance had begot in him, he opened it, wherein he read these words.

To the most disloyal Knight in the world.
I Do not write to thee in way of complaint, for thereby I should still show my
love and weakness; but it is to tell thee, that thy wickedness renders thee
unworthy of the favors, which thou had thought to have found in my pity: I
will conserve my self for another, it may be less valiant and brave, but far
more faithful then thy self, and leaving thee in the liberty to keep thy word
with Merodiana, I will take the power to love some otherwhere. Get thee out of
the limits of this Empire, which thou have lost, as unworthy to possess it,
and never present thy self more before me, that thy sight may not renew the
vexation which I am in, to have been deceived by thee.


This Letter, so cruel, and that deprived the Knight of all hope, having
seized him with too sensible a sorrow, made him sink to the ground with such
appearance of death, that Cesarina leaving him in his Squires arms, returned to
her Mistress, infinitely discontented for that she had been the occasion of this
misfortune; and telling her what effect her Letter had wrought, she retired,
betaking her to strange unquietness.

CHAP. L. Alsidamants despair, the effects of his rage, by the defeat of
certain Giants and Knights: he turns Hermit.
WHilst Cesarina recounted unto Trasiclea the success of her message,
Alcidamant, being come to himself, by the diligence of (...) his Squire, made
such strange lamentation, that the most inhumane soul in the world would have
been sensible of his complaint. Ah why! said he, unjust heavens, why have you
made me hope for a happiness with such expectation, to deny it me now upon so
little reason? Ah beauteous Trasiclea! with what weakness are you carried? you
draw my ruin from that which serves for my glory; for despising Merodiana for
you, me thinks, I give you occasion to believe that you have the advantage of
her; yet you make her love, the cause of your hate, and my misfortune. Is this
done with justice? No, no, you are too much transported with passion, and if
you did not refuse me that through anger, which the severest judges in the
world could not with reason deny to the greatest offenders; I should justify
my self before you, and let you see mine innocence with so much truth, that you
could not but condemn this precipitation of yours; howbeit, that I may not hope
for, your forbidding me ever to appear before you again, utterly bereaves me of
the means to let you one day see your error. Ah! this is to testify more
cruelty, then ever you have showed love, and that my punishment does far
surpass the pleasure of my hope. You will have me gone: Alas! Can I do it and
live? I cannot, I cannot, yet it is fit that I prefer your commandments before
my life, I will be gone then, but lament my absence, fair Princess, it deprives
you of a servant, that has never had greater care, then how to honor the
merit of your favor. Whereupon, charging his Squire to go and make ready his
horses, he secretly armed himself, went to the stable door, mounted on
horsback, and dep^rting out of the City, took the first way presented it self,
making incredible lamentation. Behold, said he, how from the supremest degree
of felicity, I am fallen into the abysmes of a misery, out of the which I cannot
get without miracle. Good God! who would have thought, that having but one
tedious minute to pass, for to see my self in an unmatchable glory, fortune
should have found out the means to cross me? I could never imagine it, but to
my cost I perceive, that man cannot assign a time for his good, no more then
for the evil that is to arrive unto him. Ah, Cistenia! How well thou make me
pay for the pleasures thou procuredst me from thy Mistress? How dearly,
Merodiana, do I buy your favors? You say, that I promised to espouse you:
Alas! I had never such a thought, our caresses have been free, and the power of
disposing our selves never parted from us; Why do you say then, that it is time
to render our embraces legitimate? Can I be your sisters friend, and your
husband? By no means, it is a thing whereof you ought never so much as to
think; nevertheless, I endure the pains of your folly, and my banishment
proceeds from your passions; it is unjust, but I must bear it; the heavens have
always had a care of my life, the same regard they will have still of my
actions, if they please, and will assist me with some extraordinary favor,
since that I have a divine power for to make me hope for relief. Pronouncing
these words, he shed so many tears, that he saw not the way which he went,
though the moon shone very bright, in such sort that he crossed through a wood,
more by chance then otherwise, and finding himself, at the break of the day, in
a beautiful meadow, bordered about with numbers of trees, he alighted, let his
horse feed, and laying him down upon the green grass, began to think of his
ill fortune, and was about ^o renew his complaints and tears; when as Arnides
coming to him, said: Arise, Sir, and give over playing the woman, come and
chastise certain Knights that speak ill of Trasiclea, that intend to revenge
Drumelia, to take her from the Emperor, and to work your destruction by
treason. I believe, said he, that thou take me for Alcidamant, that slew
Fangomadan, and the Monster of the Island Silvana, that defeated the Giants on
the wooden bridge, that brought Brandimar to reason, that massacred the guards
of the Sorceresse Drumelia, and that would have made no difficulty to have
combatted a million of armed men; thou deceivest thy self, Arnides, I am but
his shadow, and the weakness of my arm could not fear the meanest Knight that
is. These desire to be righted of the wrong that I have done them, let them use
their pleasure upon me, here is my throat, which I will most willingly offer to
their swords; for loathing my life, I care not what becomes of it. Why this is
spoken like a desperate man indeed, said Arnides; What a glory were it for them
to vaunt in the Empire of Tramazond, that they had overcome you valiantly, and
how might they abuse Trasiclea if fortune should give her into their hands, as
such a thing may be? Now in good faith, this womanish courage of yours
exceedingly grieves me; and give me leave to tell you, that you lose much of
the reputation that you have acquired in the world, and particularly with
Trasiclea, who peradventure is not so much displeased, as she makes show for.
Well, Arnides, said he, I see thou will prevail^ and make me once more, against
my will, to draw my sword. Therewith arising, and transported with sorrow and
rage, he advanced toward two Giants and three Knights, whom he saw at the
other end of the meadow, and never examining the matter any further, charged
the first Giant so rudely, that he made his sword, arm and all, fly to the
ground together. You die, said he, for daring to attempt upon the lives of
Trasiclea, and her Knight, nor shall all your Gods save you from my hands.

Putting this high menace then in execution, he laid two of the Knights, that
showed themselves forwardest, dead on the earth, and striking furiously at the
other Giant, gave him three or four blows, which all drew blood of him;
howbeit, the first having taken his sword into his left hand, began to press
him very hard; but this brave Champion being in the supremest degree of his
rage, overthrew them both in the place with two terrible blows; and seeing but
one Knight, who on his knees begged for mercy, he gave him his life, upon
condition that he should go to Tarsipolis, and presenting himself before the
Emperor, recount the business how it had past. This done, he remounted on his
horse, and riding along, began his lamentation and complaints, to the great
coffeehouse of his Squire, who having eating nothing of a long time, much
blamed these strange humors of his Master in his mind. Whilst Alcidamant was
making thus from Tarsipolis, the Knight of the Giants arrived there, and
presenting himself in the palace before the Emperor was risen from dinner, he
declared what he had in charge; and publishing in the presence of Trasiclea the
moan which the Knight of the Palms made at his departure, it pierced so deep
into the heart of this displeased Princess, of whom the Emperor demanded the
cause of his absence, that she repented hereof a thousand times for entreating
him so cruelly, as to condemn him unheard. This action, said she to herself,
is an infallible testimony that he loves not Merodiana; and in that he obeyes
my command, it is clear that I do him wrong to suspect his loyalty. It may be
that this Lady, vanquished by her passion, or rather by this Knights charms,
which are inevitable, has given her self to him upon some hope of marriage;
but that this Knight has promised her, I cannot think it, he is too noble to
be so wicked; and if he were obliged by his word, questionless he would have
gone to her now, but he has taken a clean contrary way; and howsoever, his
sorrow renders him innocent.

Now, to be offended with him for what is secretly past between them, I have no
reason at all: for their caresses were precedent to my acquaintance with him,
so as he was no ways tied to observe any faith to me; wherefore I condemn my
jealousy, and precipitious carriage toward him, and do protest before my
Gods, to receive him into grace again, if he present himself before me. But
alas! that, I fear, he will not do, but will have more regard to my will, then
the satisfaction of his own desires: howbeit I may quickly remedy that; I have
committed the fault, I must make the amends; and sending Cesarina, who may
easily follow him by the fame of his brave acts, let him know, that I acquit
him as freely as before I condemned him unjustly. Whereupon writing a letter
full of excuses, and giving it to Cesarina, commanded her to repair her error,
and to use some means for to bring back this Knight, who, in the mean time,
