rode on with incredible speed, never regarding the ways, which at length
having brought him to the kingdom of Clariana, he met with a Desert, wherein
the gentle current of a bubbling stream, together with the natural beauty of a
savadge grot, and the shade of certain trees, which seemed to make a pretty
walk from the rock to the water, so pleased him, that forsaking his horse, he
resolved there to spend his days. Living on the fruits that he found there,
and drinking of the water that pearled out of the stone, he lay upon a couch of
leaves, and limiting his walk among those trees, he consumed his time in his
usual complaints, accusing his ill fortune, blaming Trasiclea's cruelty,
adoring her picture which Cesarina had given him in the Isle of Silvana, and
which he had kept as the only relic remaining of all his hopes; and leading
a most solitary life, took pleasure in nothing but his own lamentations and
^ighes, where a while we will leave him, and take some time for to think on
the prosecution of this history.

The end of the Second Part.
THE LOVE AND ARMS OF THE GREEK PRINCES.

OR THE ROMANT OF ROMANTS, Written in French by Monsieur Verdere; And
translated for the Right Honorable, Phillip, Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery,
Lord Chamberlain to his Majesty.

Tome III.

HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE
printer's or publisher's device

LONDON, Printed by John Dawson, for Thomas Walkeley, and are to be sold at
his Shop at the sign of the flying Horse, near York House, 1640.

Amadis of Trebisond, arriving in the Empire of Martaria, saves Floridan of
Persia from drowning: Their Adventures.
CHAP. 1.
AMadis of Trebisond, departing from the Castle of Serpents under the conduct,
and in the Chariot of Cassandra, as was delivered in the four and twentieth
Chapter of our second Part, was somewhat amazed to see himself almost in a
moment above the clouds, where he might well have had cause to fear his
falling into those vast Seas, which he beheld so far below him, or of
suffering the incommodities of an element full of fire, that he felt over his
head, had he not been carried from such apprehensions, by the relation this
damosel made him of the loves and noble acts of that renowned Emperor of
Greece, his Father, and of the prodigious adventures brought to glorious ends,
by the Princes of his blood. Five or six days being past away with these
pleasing discourses, one morning, even as the Sun began to enlighten the
world, he heard a dreadful noise, proceeding from the encounter of the
billows, which the violence of the winds raised sometimes as high as Heaven,
and then by and by cast down to the very center of the earth, herewith awaked
he looked round about to see from whence it came, and amidst the strange
disorder of these enraged waters, he espied a Ship, whose sails were rent all
to fitters, her shrouds and Tackle torn, her Masts blown over board, and
every part of her besides so terribly shaken, and beaten with the fury of the
merciless waves, that having no Guide but the evil fortune of those she
carried, at length she ran against a Rock, that was near to an adjoining
Port, and split in a thousand pieces, leaving some thirty persons to the mercy
of the cruel seas. This object so full of pity moved him very much; and as
he was about to bewail the mishap of them he had seen swallowed up, and to
desire that he could succor the rest which were also ready to perish, he
perceived that the Chariot descended conducting him to the encounter of a young
man, who swimming tugged courageously for his life, with that pitiless
element, making use then of this occasion, that succeeded according to his
wish, he thrust his Arm into the sea, and catching hold of the young man drew
him up into the Chariot, which instantly landing on the shore vanished with its
Guide, leaving them both on the sands very much astonished thereat. Howbeit,
Amadis ever confident, would not seem to be troubled with so sudden a
departure, but turned to his companion, whom for his beauty and comely
personage he much admired, and said unto him. Gentleman, take courage, and be
not dismayed, for now you are out of the power of the waves, nor can this land
you tread upon be so dangerous, though it be unknown to you. I cannot choose
answered he, after he was somewhat come to himself again, but be somewhat
amazed with the late peril I was in; yet Sir, it has not so deprived me of
judgment, that I should not have sufficient left me, to know how much I am
obliged to you for my safety; you have saved my life, which you shall always
dispose of; in the mean time may it please you to permit me to seek out
means to dry my self, for I cannot continue long thus wet without some danger
to my health. Here said Amadis, unbuttoning a coat, which many times he wore
over his Armor, cover your self with this whilst your clothes are a drying,
for I will not leave you till I see you in better case. This Gentleman taking
the coat went presently aside, and having stripped himself, sat down on a
stone, whither not long after Amadis came to him, whereupon wondering much at
his goodly presence in such rich arms, he arose somewhat ashamed to be seen
so half naked, and said. Sir, what may I do to show my self grateful for so
many good offices, which I receive from your courtesy? You may, answered
Amadis, pay all this debt with a few words, and by telling me who you are, and
what occasion brought you hither, you may oblige me as much, as you think you
are engaged to me. Could I serve you, said he, by declaring whom I am, without
doubt I should soon obey your command; but Sir, my name being of so small
consideration in the world, it will import you little to know, and me much to
conceal it, in which regard I shall humbly desire you, to dispense with me
therein, and to be pleased if I only say, that I am commonly called, the
Knight of the Flowers: Touching my arrival in this place, my destiny had
unluckily brought me hither, had I not met with you; for having imbarqued my
self in a Port of Greece, with a resolution to travel the world, in the quest
of glory I sailed very prosperously for three weeks together; during which
time I never combatted but once, and that was with a Giant for the rescue of a
Gentlewoman, whom he had forcibly carried away; presently whereupon the sea
began so to rage, that all the skill and courage the Mariners had were feign
to give way to the violence of this tempest, which continued very near three
months, and by reason we went still before the wind, I cannot be persuaded, but
that we are now on those unknown lands, whereof they of Asia and Europe speak
only by conjecture. These Knights having spent a good part of the day in this
and the like discourse, at length were so called upon by their stomachs, that
arising from the grass where they lay, the Knight of the Flowers with his
clothes on thoroughly dried, and Amadis in his armor, they walked almost two
hours without meeting any one that could direct them the way to the next
Village, in such sort that growing somewhat weary, they laid them down under
the shadow of certain trees, where not long after they fell asleep, but they
continued not so long, for they were awaked with the sound of some Trumpets,
which marched in the head of threescore horse, that were followed a good way off
by four Coaches, environed with three dreadful Giants, and a number of men
unarmed on hors-back. O me! said Amadis, rising up somewhat amazed, what
adventure is this? No very good one for you, said one of that troop, who upon
discovery of them came galloping before his fellows, for landing here without
the license of our Prince, you are to expect nothing but Irons for such your
temerity; By my best hopes, said Amadis, I will not be fettered so easily as
you think for, and if I must die I Will sell my life as dear as I can: Saying
so, he drew his sword, and therewith struck his enemy so furiously, that he
laid him stark dead on the ground: The blow being given in the sight of all
his companions, they presently compassed him about for to take him, but very
active as he was, he lightly lept into the saddle of his horse whom he had
slain, and setting spurs to him charged them home, whilst the Knight of the
Flowers seized on the dead man's shield and sword, wherwithall he overthrew
three or four of them at his feet, ere they could draw one drop of blood from
them; In the mean time Amadis laid about him, broke their ranks, cut off arms
and legs, made heads fly to the earth, divided men and horses in twain, and
rendered himself so dreadful, that the most of them having past by the edge of
his sword, the remainder turned their backs, for to have betaken them to
flight, had they not been retained by the arrival of the three Giants. These
Colosses marvelling to see so great a slaughter made by two men, whereof (...)
one was unarmed, drew out their heavy Simitars, and began to change them with
so much fury, that at the very first bout the Knight of the Flowers was
dangerously hurt on the shoulder, his shield not having been able to resist the
violence of so terrible a blow, which somewhat amazed him, but waxing more
courageous at the sight of his blood, he let drive in such manner at the Giant
that had wounded him, as he cut off his left arm sheer from his body, and
purposing to second his good beginning, he gave him a very dangerous thrust in
the belly, thinking to run him up to the ^ilts, but his sword proving too weak
to pierce his armor, it brake in five or six pieces, to the great astonishment
of the Knight, who now having nothing wherwithall to offend his enemies,
instantly received half a dozen strokes, which overthrew him to the ground with
little or no appearance of life. This while Amadis bestirred himself with an
admirable grace, for beholding himself environed with two Giants, and three and
twenty Knights, that were still remaining of the first troop, he avoided most
part of their blows, and let his own fall with such force, that in less then
an hour the two Giants saw their arms all dyed with their own blood, and
themselves unable to hinder the death of twelve of those that accompanied them,
which put them into such a rage, that their motions seemed to be very thunder.
Wherefore being ashamed, that in the presence of a number of Ladies which were
in the Coaches, one man alone should withstand them, they discharged two such
mighty blows at an instant, the one on the Helmet, the other on the Shield of
Amadis, that he was constrained to knock his chin against the pommel of his
saddle, casting great abundance of blood out of his mouth and ears, but
presently resetling himself, and more furious then ever he was in his life, he
advanced his rich sword, and letting it descend on the head of him he first
incountred, he cleft him down to the very wast: This dreadful blow having
terrified all the assistants, who beheld him with wonder, did but more incense
the remaining Giant; for in the highest excess of his rage, he took his great
Curtelas in both his hands, and thinking to determine this combat with one only
blow, he discharged it so strongly on his enemies Shield, that he divided it in
two, and gave him a greatgash on the arm, whereat Amadis was somoved, as casting
the remains of his Shield over his shoulder, he made such a lucky thrust with
all his force at his belly, that he ran him quite through and through, sending
him stark dead to the ground; wherwithall not contented, he was turning him
about to the rest of the Knights, when as he perceived them to gallop away, and
seek their safety in their flight; which caused him persently to sheath up his
sword, and approach unto the Coaches (where he beheld a many of Ladies in very
great fear) for to comfort and assure them against any doubt they might be in
of him; howbe it he had no more time then to see them, for before he could
speak to them, their Coachmen drove away withal possible speed toward the
City, which he discovered a little on the left hand; and so left him with
extreme displeasure, for so sudden a departure; his soul being deeply engaged
by one small glimpse he had of a Princess, whose eyes contained a million of
charms. This new passion not permitting him to see his Sun thus es^oigned from
him, he was going to run after it; but at that very instant perceiving three
other Giants to appear in the head of four hundred horse, which were come upon
the news of the others defe^^: he made a stand, and holding it to be far
greaterwisdome, and glory to (...) himself, then courage rashly to cast himself
away without reason or sense; he took the way of a mountain fast by, extremely
discontented so to retire, without knowing the name of the beauty that had
captived him; and leaving his companion (whose valor he had much admired) in
the hands of these barbarians. Trotting then along fair and softly, that he
might not seem to flee before his enemies, he rode very near an hour, before
he was overtaken by those that were best mounted of the Troop; who confident of
his overthrow, went to assail him with their swords drawn: But he that never
knew what danger meant, when necessity enforced him to fight; suddenly made
head against them, and without try fling out the time, laid a dozen of them on
the earth; howbeit, fearing to be environed by so many enemies at once, he
slipped into the wood, resolving under the shelter thereof, to attend the pleasure
of Heaven: But he very much marvelled that he was not pursued, and that a
little after he could perceive these Troops close altogether, and return to the
City; the occasion of which retreat and fear, shall be delivered in the next
Chapter.

CHAP. II. Amadis encountering a Shep^^^^d, learnes the name of his Mistress;
his resolution thereupon.
THE retreat of his enemies giving (...) time to breath; he began to think of
the encounter he had made, and taking much content in the confusion of his
thoughts, he laid him down on the grass; where the beauties of his Mistress
representing themselves to his memory, he entertained himself in this manner,
and said. Lord! what a change have I made to day? I affected nothing so much as
liberty, now I wish, and seek for captivity: I was a Soldier, now I am a
lover; glory was the object of my desires, love is now the uttermost of my
ambition: I love, alas! I love, but with little or no hope, and from whence I
can expect nothing but in supportable sufferings. Ah, if I could promise my
self to render her one day sensible of (...), after I had long adored her, why
then I could willingly (...) my self to any misery; but I do not so much as
know her, or if I did know her, I durst not present my self before her, having
jostly drawn her displeasure upon me, by the defeature of her people; What
resolution shall I take then? to dye, rather than seek a rer^^die in despair,
so great a (...), is not to be purchased without great labor; and the pains I
shall take to obtain it, shall never be less dear unto me, then the glory of
the most dangerous adventures that can be. Whereupon arising somewhat
comforted, he mounted on his Horse; and probably conjectaring that he should
meet with no body in the wood, he got him into the first highway that
presented it self unto him, where he had not rode long, but he descried a young
Shepherd coming from the City, whereat he was very glad, hoping to learn some
what of him concerning that which he desired to know; wherefore mending his
pace, he came very near to him, and said. Friend, I prithee tell me where I am.
At these words, the Shepherd who walked with his hat over his eyes; started, as
if he had been very much frighted, and was going to run away; had not (...),
taking hold of his arm; stayed him; and assured him with gentle speeches, that
he would do him no harm. Now in good faith, said the Shepherd, I was never so
a^^ear'd of the Wolf, as I was but now to see my self so surprised by you; for
I believed you meant to have sent me to keep company with them, that past by
the edge of your sword to day. Thy fear was (...), said Amadis, for I am more
ready to help, then hurt the^, but how (...) thou know that I have done all
that thouspeakest of; How do I know it, said the Shepherd, why I come newly
from the Ci^ie, which is all in an uproar; and the slaughter you have made to
day, has so astonished the Emperor, that holding it incredible he is come
forth in person to behold it; The Courtiers tremble at the sight of so many men
slain with such horrible blows, and the courage which you showed in combatting
such dreadful enemies, makes them talk of you, as of some prodigy: You are
known not by your name, (for it is said you are a stranger) but your arms have
been so well noted, that you cannot carry them here without greatdanger;
wherefore I would advise you for your good, either to change them, or to get
you quickly out of this Empire. Out of what Empire, said Amadis? How, answered
the Shepherd, do not you know, that you are in the Empire of Martaria, one of
the goodliest, and powerfullest Monarchies of the world? No verily, said
Amadis, I did not know it; for being arrived here but to day by a strange
accident, I could not have been informed of it, if by good fortune I had not
met with thee; but letting that pass, can not thou inform me who those
Ladies were, which I saw in the Coaches during the combat, and particularly she
in the green? That is said he the Princess of this Empire, and I am persuaded
the fairest of all the women living, she is called Palmirenna, and the other
two were her sisters, named Amplamira, and Archesidella, both of them so
accomplished, as they may well dispute somewhat with the eldest. Thou had
fully satisfied me, answered Amadis, would thou but resolve me of one thing
more; what was the reason, say they, why the Giants and the Knights their
followers, did not assail me in the wood, having so much advantage of me as
they had? The reason was apparent, answered he, for the way which you took was
so dangerous, that it was wisdom for them to retire, as they did. Wherefore was
it dangerous, said Amadis? In regard of a most dradfull Monster, replied he,
which arriving there not long since has made so great a spoil and havoc, as
the Emperor himself will be constrained to abandon Cardana, the capital City
of his Empire, for to reside in some other place. He has sent whole squadrons
of armed men under the conduct of three or four Giants against it, but still
they have been torn in pieces, for the fury of this creature is so terrible,
that the most confident tremble at the very sight of it: He has a body far
bigger then an Elephant, covered with green and yellow scails, so hard as no
steel is able to pierce them; he has two heads, one that casts forth a
million of stinking flames, through the midst of a number of teeth a cubit
long, and the other armed with two very huge horns, whereunto the inevitable
death of all such as dare assail him is fastened; his tail is eight foot long,
so strong and mighty, that with it he overthrovvs all the trees that stand in
his way; briefly, he is so horrible and cruel, that if the gods do not the
sooner put to their helping hand, this Province will shortly be laid vvast,
which were a lamentable thing, being so fertile and populous as it is: But
pardon me, Sir, if I be so bold as to ask of you, how you having been upon
the Mountain of Bears, where his ordinary hauntis, could elcape his fury? for
to speak truth, I hold it a kind of miracle. Heaven, that has preserved me for
his glory, said he, would not suffer me to fall into the power of this Monster:
but leaving this discourse, tell me what is become of the Gentleman that
combatted by me unarmed? I believe, answered he, that he will pay for the
harm you have done, for the Emperor having found him to be living, has
commanded the Surgeons to have a special care of him, reserving him as I
think, for to sacrifice him to his Gods, in regard of the extraordinary beauty
wherewithal he is endued. I hope he shall do better, replied Amadis, in the
mean time not to be ungrateful for thy good information of that which I
desired to know, I will give thee somewhat to relieve thy poverty, therewith he
took a Ring which he had on his finger of great value, and bestowing it on him
made him no less amazed, then contented. Look, said the Shepherd bowing
himself even to the ground for to thank him, how our opinions do many times
bring forth contrary effects, I thought I should have been undone by
incountring with you, and thereby I have found wherwithall to overcome the
miseries of my birth. Sir, your liberality obliges me to have a care of your
safety, pass on no further with these arms, for you shall be sure to meet
with none but enemies whersoever you go, time will best advise you for your
future preservation, in the mean while you shall spend this night if you please
in a poor cottage of mine, where without fear of any danger you may take a
little rest. Amadis seeing it was night, and perceiving the fellows good will
suffered himself to be conducted by him to a Village hard by, whereunto
entering secretly, and leaving the care of his horse to him, he sat him down to
supper, and having fed heartily on a Kid, that was served into the table, he
laid him down, all armed as he was, on a bed, hoping to sleep quietly
thereafter his hard travel; howbeit his new passion would not permit him so to
do, it represented the beauties of his Lady unto him, with the difficulties
which appeared in his love, that so disquieted him, as he could do nothing but
toss and tumble all the night long, at length being fully resolved, I must
hope, said he, instead of complaining and afflicting my self: I fear my
Mistresses, and the Emperors displeasure, in regard of the combat which I had
with their Knights, but I may repair that fault, and give them as much cause to
favor, as now they have to hate me; this Monster that spoils their Territories
must be fought withal; if I prevail, I shall oblige them with a service that
will produce their content, and the good of their people; if I fall in this
attempt it will give an end to my miseries, so that no way it can prove amiss
for me to undertake this Enterprise: Concluding then with himself in this sort
he fell asleep, and so continued till the Sun was of a pretty height, when
arising, and finding his breakfast ready, after he had eaten a little he drew
the Shepherd aside, and said unto him. Honest friend, J purpose to commit a
secret un to thee, but before Ideclare it thou shall swear to me, to do
whatsoever I shall bid thee. Assure your self my Lord, said he, that I will
make little account of my life where it shall concern your interest, only
command, and without any doubt of my fidelity, be confident that I will not
fayl in obeying you. Well, said Amadis, that which I would have thee do, is to
go along with me to the Mountain of Bears, to the end thou may be witness of
my actions, so as if I dye in the Combat, which I resolve to undertake against
this Monster, that destroys so goodly a country, thoushalt be obliged to find
out the beauteous Palmirenna, and shall tell her that the Knight, who slew her
Guard, stuck not to expose his life for the conservation of her people, thereby
to obtain her pardon, for the displeasure she received from his sword; But if
I get the victory, time shall further direct us. Good gods: said the Shepherd,
starting back, what is this you say, have you lost your understanding so far
forth, as to cast you self away? Ah, do not go about Sir, to employ those
forces, which the gods have given you on so despearate an adventure, reserve
your self for better fortune, and seek to escape hence some otherway. Thou
labourest in vain, said Amadis, to divert my resolution, it is not thy counsel
I demand, but a performance of thy promise, say then, will thou follow me? Yes,
answered he, bedewing his cheeks with tears, though it be much against my mind.
Whereupon Amadis road on to the foot of the Mountain, where the Shepherd taking
his Horse of him, commended him to his gods.

CHAP. 3. Amadis defeats the dreadful Monster of the Mountain of Bears, his
adventures afterward.
WHilst the Shepherd was weeping, Amadis traversed the Wood with an undaunted
courage, and calling to mind the glory which his Ancestors had acquired in such
like adventures, he resolved to be no whit amazed with the sight of this
horrible creature, whose dreadful form made every one to tremble at the very
apprehension of it; but when he saw him approach with most furious motions, he
could not be so confident, but that he began to doubt the end of his life;
nevertheless, choosing rather to dye, then show the least token of fear, he
drew out his rich sword, and discharged it full on his enemies body, hop^ng
therwithall, considering the strength with which it was delivered, to have
seen an end of thc combat, but perceiving it to fall without effect, by reason
of the hardness of his scails whereupon it lighted, he was marvellously
astonished; howbeit taking new courage he advanced it again, whenas the horns
of this creature meeting with his Shield, sent him to measure the ground, where
doubtless he lay not long, for knowing it would be his apparent ruin to attend
such another shock in the case he was in, he arose full of rage, and stepping
lightly aside he let his enemy pass by, making such horrible leaps, that the
earth seemed to groan under him, but desiring to make use of occasion, he gave
him so dangerous a blow as he went along, that he cut off half his tail,
though it were vvonderfull big, and covered over with exceeding hard scails,
which put him into such an excess of fury, that returning with incredible
svviftnesse he seized upon the Knights Shield with his teeth, and pulling it
easily from him, notwithstanding all the resistance he made to keep it, he
scrashed it into a thousand pieces whilst he trampled it under his feet. This
generous Warrior, that was not capable of fear, in the greatest and most
evident dangers, and that would not have regarded the glory of his enterprises,
but for the hazard wherewith they were accompanied, not losing his judgment in
such an extremity, suddenly cleared his arm from under one of the Monsters
feet, and thrusting his sword into his belly, ran him up with such force, that
he entered it even unto the very hilts, which made the Monster skip in so
violent a manner, as he lighted a dozen paces off, to the unspeakable content
of ou^ Knight, who neglecting no opportunity, speedily got up with a resolution
to avoid the like incounters if he could, but that he was not able to do, for
the Monster sensible of his hurt, flew madly at him without any regard at all
of his sword, wherewith he had in vain struck him on the head, and getting him
in his teeth overthrew him to the ground, pierced his armor in five or six
places, and died all the grass with his blood; Now was the Knight even at the
last gasp, being almost stifled with the stinking flames that incessantly
issued out of his mouth, but the remembrance of his excellent Mistress infused
such strength into him, that he so strugled with the Beast, as he made him
let go his hold, and at the same instant gave him another thrust in at the
throat, that reached to his very heart. Then it was that this Monster feeling
the pangs of death fell to storming, and making such horrible cries, that they
were heard even to Cardana, the Mountain shaking as if it had been stricken
with a million of thunderbolts: Whereupon the Knight perceiving him breathing
forth his last, retired aside for to kneel down, and render thanks unto God for
so glorious a victory; but being exceedingly weakened by the loss of his blood,
and overcome with the vile sent of the venom, which flowed out of the Monster,
he fell all along on the ground with little appearance of life in him. This
while the Shepherd amazed with the strange noise he heard was mightily
perplexed; Amadis his liberality made him desire to go and see in what estate
he was, but then again he was retained by fear, so as he knew not a good
while what to resolve on, at length his gratitude prevayling he set spurs to
his horse, and crossing the wood arrived at the place where the Monster lay
stretched forth, and weltring in his blood: His horrible figure so terrified
him, that he was upon the point of running back again, but espying the Knight
lying on the grass a little aside, he lighted instantly, and labored so
long, that he found the means to open his Helmet for to give him air; whereupon
Amadis came presently to himself, at which the poor man was wonderful glad, and
fain would have unarmed him, but unable to do it, he thought it best to have
speedy recourse to some other mean, getting up on his horse then, he rode away
to the City as fast as he could drive, where alighting at the Court, without
answering those that demanded of him what he would have; he went directly to
the Emperor, who was talking in the Hall amidst his Courtiers of the strange
noise they had heard, not conceiving from whence it should proceed, and falling
on his knees, even out of breath, he said unto him. Sir, I bring you joyful
tidings, the Monster of the Mountain of Bears is slain by the valiant stranger,
that yesterday did such wonders against your people. O ye gods! said the
Emperor, rising out of his seat, is it possible that so formidable a creature,
whose fury thousands of men, and dreadful Giants were not able to withstand,
should be killed by the hand of a mortal man? verily this report is scarcely
credible. Sir, answered the Shepherd, let me suffer, if I tell you an untruth,
for I saw him quite dead, and will conduct you, if you please, where that brave
Knight lies, still attending the succor of the gods, if man's assistance fail
him, being so dangerously hurt that he cannot live till night, if he be not
speedily provided for. That shall he be sure of, said the Emperor, for so
powerful an obligation, must cancel al other offenses that he has committed
against us, though I believe this combat was undertaken, more by necessity,
then any way to oblige us: Nay, ^eplied the Shepherd, your Majesty may be
pleased to give me leave to assure you that he performed it with a full
resolution to do you service, for before he entered the Wood, he commanded me
to tell the Princess Palmirenna in your Majesty's presence, that he went to
venture his life, to obtain pa^don, for the fault he had done in drawing his
sword against her servants; albeit, that mischance happened by their insolency,
and much against his mind.

That do I grant most willingly, said Palmirenna; and seeing his respect to me
has made him so regardlesse of such a danger, I shall be as sensible of that
good affection, as I would have been of his offense: Wherefore your Majesty
(said she, continuing her speech unto her Father) shall do well to command your
Chyrurgions away before, whilst we go fair and softly after to behold this
miracle. The Emperor very well pleased herewith, presently dispatched away his
Chyrurgions, with a great charge to employ the uttermost of their skill for the
recovery of the knight; and getting into his Daughters Coach, he followed them,
accompanied with all his Nobility, who could not wonder sufficiently at so
prodigious a thing.

But we will leave them (thronging the ways, and striving which should make
most haste to behold this redoubted Warrior; to whom this succor had been
unprofitable, if Heaven, that reserved him for his glory, had not otherwise
ordained of him) for to deliver what arrived to him after the Shepherds
departure. Recovering then by little, and little; he was rising to unarm
himself, when he pereceived a Dwarf that said unto him: Be of good cheer sir,
this action will bring you more glory, than harm; it is true, that your wounds
are very dangerous, by reason the Monsters teeth are venomous; but I have
assured remedies to preserve you, and will do that for your recoverie, which
the experience of the best Chyrurgions in the World would attempt in vain;
only follow me, and let us not decline those which come to seek you, for I
hold it not fit to put you into their hands; not in regard of the Emperor or
his Daughter, who with good reason prefer that which you have now performed,
far before yesterdaies offense, but the Giants death having rendered their
kindred your enemies, all the Princes favor cannot protect you from being
treacherously murdered; wherefore be careful, if you mean to abide here to
keep your self unknown. Saying thus, and and reaching him his hand, he helped
him up with such case; that he remained very much amazed, to find so much
strength in so little a body. Being able then to walk a little, they
descended down the mountain, on that side that looked to the Sea, and entered
both into a Grott, where Amadis was instantly unarmed: that done, he laid him
down upon a bed, which seemed to have been set there expressly for him, and
discovered his wounds to this little man; who having bathed them with a very
odoriferous liquour, and afterward laid certain plasters to them, he covered
him, and willed him to sleep.

In the mean time the Emperors Chyrurgions were much troubled, for being come
where the Monster lay; and missing the knight that had been so recommended to
their care, they were exceedingly afflicted; but especially the poor Shepherd,
who bitterly weeping, cried out. Alas! this is the place where I left him, the
grass is yet wet with his blood, and it is not long since he could be taken
away; surely some god came hither and has carried him to heaven. Ah noble
knight! why was not I here, that I might have participated a little of thy
glory; or if some worse chance has befaln thee, that I might then have run thy
fortune? Hereupon the Emperor arriving, and understanding how the knight could
not be found, he was exceedingly discontented, but Palmirenna much more; for
the matchless valor of this stranger, whereof she had been an eyewitness,
and the extreme peril wherun to he had exposed himself in the combat with the
monster for her sake had so taken her, as she was mavelous sensible of his
loss: howbeit her Father commanded his knights to disperse themselves in the
search of him; she comforted her self in hope to hear of him ere it were long,
and so went to observe the Beast, which seemed still so dreadful, as it made
all the assistants to tremble. O ye gods! said the Emperor, much astonished at
the sight of so horrible a figure; what a courage had he need of, that durst
encounter so deformed a creature, when as being dead it terrifies all that
behold it: Ah incomparable knight, then the which a more valiant never breathed
upon the earth; thou art afraid to present thy self before me, in regard of
one poor offense; but be assured no man shall ever be more welcome to me then
thy self: Go then and seek him out, and place the skin of the Beast stuffed with
straw, on the highest Tower of Cardana, valiant persons cannot be too much
honored. Saying so, he returned into Palmirenna's Coach, where all the way to
the City he entertained her with the praises of this knight, which he thought
could never be sufficient for so transcendent a merit.

CHAP. IIII. Floridan of Persiabeing delivered out of Captivity by the
victory of Amadis, becomes enamoured of Amplamira. The invention that Amadis
uses to see Palmirenna.
CArdana having just occasion to resent the death of this Monster, which in
short time would have rendered it desolate; was replenished in a moment with a
world of bonfires, and nothing was heard but shouts of joy, confusedly mingled
with the music of a million of instruments, in such sort that the Emperor
arriving, thereupon was conducted to his Palace with more magnificence, then if
he had triumphed over the greatest Monarch of the earth. This Prince beholding
his people amidst their content, chaunting his greatness, and the praises of
our Warrior; remembered the Gentleman that accompanied him in the slaughter of
his servants; and being magnanimous, commanded him to his Presence; whereupon
being presently brought before him in irons, he said unto him.

It were unreasonable, that in the e^nesse of a public joy deriv^^ from the
valor of your Companion, you alone should have cause to complain of fortune,
wherefore passing by the displeasure I received from you yesterday; It is our
pleasure that you be freed from these chai^s, and that you have the same power
here of your actions, as you had before your arrival in these parts; provided
that you let me know who the Knight is, and that you likewise conceal not your
own condition.

Mighty Prince, answered he; the generosity of Kings appears always in their
Cl^mencie, and as the cruelty of Tyrants tenders them subject to a thousand
kind of mischiefs, so does mercy assure good Princes, even in the midst of
greatest dangers; being a Prisoner, I expected as much relief from your pity,
as from mine own innocence, for I knew that reason would at length have drawn
you to consider, that I was forced to fight, and that a man cannot commit a
fault in preserving his life with the loss of theirs, that sought to deprive
him of it; howbeit, I acknowledge my self infinitely obliged to your Majesty,
for making me, without languishing any longer in misery; of a slave, your most
humble and faithful servant, in which regard your Highness shall always, and
absolutely dispose of the life you have now given me: And if I do not satisfy
your Majesty's desire, by telling you the name of this Knight, to whose valor
you say that you are engaged in such powerful obligations, be assured Sir,
that it is because I do not know it, not having had the honor of his
acquaintance but since yesterday, that he drew me out of the midst of the
waves; where, by the casting away of the bark which carried me, I was like to
have perished: for my own particular, you behold Sir, a poor Gentleman of
Persia, commonly called the Knight of the Flowers; who, having nothing at this
present, but the honor of the favor, which you are pleased to promise him,
will labor to deserve it by the greatness of his service.

This good will of yours, said the Emperor, does content me, and believe that
you shall have no cause given you to depart from hence; commanding him then to
be accommodated with all that he should need, he appointed him a Chamber, that
opened into the Gardens, and so fell to talk of the discretion, sweet carriage,
and handsomeness he had observed in him, which seemed so extraordinary unto
his Courtiers, that they were wonderfully taken with his rare perfections. He
retired then free from those chains, which might have fettered his hands, but
not from those love had prepared to bring his heart into subjection, for the
excellent beauty of Amplamira, second daughter to the Emperor, having bin
still present before his eyes, all the while that he was in the Hall, had made
so deep an impression in his soul, that he had wholly surrendered it into her
power; But it is time to leave him to the comfort of his deliverance, and to
the pleasing cogitations of his love, for to return unto Amadis.

This generous Warrior having slept very soundly all the night, awaked Just as
the Sun began to appear in the mouth of the cave; and feeling no pain of his
hurt, arose much amazed how it could be possible they should be healed in so
short a space. A more mighty hand, said he, looking upon himself, then that of
a man, has done this miracle, nature has not so great a power, no^ could all
the simples of the earth, gathered in any season whatsoever give so sudden a
cure to such (...) wounds, Cassandra certainly has do^e it, and the Dwarf that
conducted me hither was one of the creatures, which she uses upon her
occasions: be it as it will, I find my self I thank Heaven in cafe to put on my
A^^es; But what is that I say? am I not commanded never to wear them if I mean
to live? Ah (...) what tears will thy beauty cost me, and what pains do I see
prepared for^^e, if I thus wilfully persist in my affection? I cannot come near
thee without danger, nor esloign my self from thee without loss of my life;
what shall I do then to be at rest? or what counsel shall I take in so great
an extremity? Peril has some hope, whereas there is none in death, and apparent
loss is ever worse then hazard: Recourse must therefore be had to that which is
least to be feared, I will see Pa^mire^na, and rather meet with destruction,
then miss the favor which I must expect from her pity.

This resolution carrying him out of the grot with his sword by his side, and
beginning to enter into the way that leads to the City, he perceived something
floting on the sea, and making to the shore. This object arresting him a while,
he straight perceived a little wooden Coffer cast on land, covered with
fear-cloath, and a woman upon it stifled with the waves, whence judging it to
be some of the relics of the former days shipwreck he drew away the body with
a purpose to bury it, and render that last duty unto her being dead, but
desiring first to see what was in the Coffer, he cut the cords asunder with
his sword, and having very easily broken it up, he found in it a Gown of green
Velvet, whose ground was silver, an Head-tyre of the Greek fashion, with a
number of pretty knacks, belonging to women, his curiosity but little
satisfied with this encounter, he took the corpse, and meeting with a pit
made by nature, he laid her in it, and covered her with a little earth, that
done he turned again toward the City, the remembrance of Palmirenna
possessing him with an extreme desire to see her, and began to walk along still
casting with himself what course he might take to have a sight of her without
being known; after much musing he resolved at last to disguise himself;
whereupon calling to mind the Gown he had left behind him, he presently turned
back, and said.

Is it not with reason that Lovers are said to be blind? Fortune presented me
with assured means to free me from the care I am in, yet I neglected them, and
did not conceive they were useful for my purpose: this is that (taking up the
Coffer in his arms, and carrying it into the grot where he had lain) this is
that shall ease me of my pain, I have no hair on my face, nor is it much to be
misliked, so that having this Gown and tire on, I may easily pass for a woman.
Saying so, he stripped himself out of his clothes, put on the green velvet Gown,
fitted his hair under the tire with the assistance of a glass, and admitting
nothing that might serve to set forth a beauty, tricked up himself so neatly,
as he might well have been in love with his own form, had he not been so with
Pal^irenna; Being persuaded then, and not vainly, that he was very handsome in
this habit, he hoped to see a good issue of his design, and thought it long
till he was in the City, that he might be conducted to his Lady; but not
knowing how that might be effected, he began to be troubled anew: howbeit
rememb^ing the Dwarfs advise, he resolved to leave all unto fortune; wherefore
wrapping up his sword, which he very much esteemed of, in some linen clothes
he buried it in a corner of the grot under a little earth, to the end he
might find it there again upon occasion; that done, and little caring for the
rest of his Arms, he left the grot, and taking the most beaten way, he
walked on, still thinking how he might make use of his disguise: whereupon
fortune being more favorable to him then he expected, he heard some coming,
whom he made show, as though he would shun, but desiring nothing more then to
fall into their hands, he suffered himself to be seen, and then suddenly
retiring under the trees, seemed to be much afraid of those he saw, which were
about some six, who setting spurs to their horses came up presently to him where
he was. Beauteous stranger, said one of them that was foremost, and that
marvelled very much to behold so rare a creature, be not afraid, here are none
but such as are wholly devoted to your service, be therefore pleased to declare
what occasion has brought you hither; No other, alas; said he, shedding some
tears the better to beguile them, but my evil fortune, for departing from the
Empire of Greece, for to go unto Sicilia to the Nuptials of a sister of mine;
who was to be wedded to the Viceroy there, I was carried by the violence of a
most furious tempest into this coast, where not far from hence our Ship ran
against a Rock, and was cast away with all that were in her as I believe, my
miserable self excepted, who am reserved I fear for greater misfortune. You are
to hope better, answered this Barbarian, for the Gods have not preserved you
but for happier ends, as shall soon be made good unto you, if you can but love
me, as I affect you. Now by my life, said one of the others, whose heart was as
deeply wounded as his, she would show but little judgment to prefer your
affection before mine, that loves her more, and has greater credit, and
authority to assist her then you. At thesewords, the first giving him a furious
look, they both drew out their swords, and seconded by their companions, who
instantly sided with them, they charged one another so hotly, that in a quarter
of an hour four of them were laid on the ground to the great contentment of
Corazinda (so had Amadis then named himself) who stepping in between the other
two, desired them to become friends, and to tell him the name of the country.
Fair Nymph, answered the one, you are in the Empire of Martaria, commanded by
the best Prince of the world. Lead me to him then, said she, and not hazarding
your lives for so worthless a subject, share that recompense between you, which
your presenting of me unto him may produce. These Knights embracing so safe an
offer, and leaving the dead bodies in the place went away with her to the
City, where arriving at the Court before the Emperor, Corazinda with a sweet
and modest look fell on her knees, and making the same relation to him, which
she had done before unto his Knights, she besought him to have some compassion
of her fortune, not permitting her to be any way injured. Pretty one (said he,
very much wondering at her beauty, and already feeling some secret flames that
began to scorch him) you shall not want my favor, seeing the gods have been
pleased to cast you on my territories; and to show that your arrival here is
acceptable unto me, I will give order that you be lodged near my daughters,
with whose company you may the better pass away the time. Oh! how pleasing was
this saying unto our Warrior, and how easily might one have discerned the
alteration of his soul by his change of color, if one had had the least
suspicion of his sex; verily his desire ^^ew, and he thought it long till h^^
saw himself at the liberty to consider at leisure all the perfections of his
Lady, but remembering that discretion was more then necessary for his designs,
and that he was to govern his actions, if he meant to assure his happiness;
he made little show how much he was transported by this speech, contrarily
bowing himself even to the ground, with the best grace he could use in
acknowledgement of so much favor, he kissed his hand, and raising up himself
again, he very modestly followed him that was to conduct him to his Chamber,
wherein at first he fetched a thousand turns, blessing the good hap, which had
so prospered his desires. In the mean time the Emperor acquainted his
daughters with the acquisition he had made of one of the fairest slaves in the
world. Her eyes, said he, has so many winning charms, that my heart frozen
with a multitude of years, has felt the violence of their beams, her hair
sweetly set forth under a strange Attire, is not to be paraleld, her form is
goodly, nothing can be desired more in a face, most delicate in her skin,
briefly, next to you, who excel in all perfection, she may vaunt her self to
be one of the most beautiful creatures of the earth, judge then whether I can
think upon her without love, and whether it be not an hard matter for him that
shall converse with her to preserve his liberty? without doubt, said
Palmirenna, who had much ado to forbear smiling at this her fathers rapture,
being such as you describe her, she may work great effects, even upon the most
insensible; But Sir, I marvel that you will let her be a slave, seeing she
so deserves to be served? Think not (said he) that I will commit so great ^
fault, whereby I should ^ffend the gods, and my judgment, which forbid me to
entreat her with rigor, she shall have as much liberty as you, but I will
call her the fair slave, till such time as we better understand who she is:
your discourse, said Amplimira then, has possessed me with a great desire to
see her, will you be pleased, Sir, to grant us this contentment. Very
willingly, answered he; for I would have you acquainted with her, and use her
with the respect which I am persuaded she deserves, for her carriage assures
me she is nobly derived: Herewith Amadis being called forth came out of his
Chamber strangely perplexed, he had resolved with himself not to be moved, but
as soon as he appeared in the Hall, and was fallen on his knees, before his
Mistress, who was exceedingly taken with the sight of such a comely person,
he found himself to be so lost, that he was not able to utter a word, howbeit
she that beheld him with a particular good will, which she could not call
love; and that was no less ravished then he, desiring to confirm him, said
unto him. Fair stranger, what ayl you, will you not let us know, who you are,
and from whence you came? Madam, answered he, marvel not if I have not spoken
till now, to give you humble thanks, for the honor you have done me in
receiving me thus, I had no eyes, but to admire the excellency of your beauty,
which certainly cannot be humane; you ask me who I am, why here is before
you a poor Damosel of Greece, the object of the mischances, and misery of the
world, yet not so unhappy, but that she applauds that fortune, which has
brought her hither to enjoy the blessedness of your presence. Arise, svveet
heart, said Palmire^^a, and you shall see that we shall so cherish and caresse
you, as you shall have no cause to complain: Saying so, she stooped, and
kissed him, wherewith Amadis was so transported, as he was ready to sound with
extremity of pleasure, but recollecting his spirits, which were wandering in
this ecstasy, he was going to render the like unto the two incomparable
Infantaes, when as they prevented him with their kisses, after the example of
their elder sister, and not suffering him to kneel, led him by the Emperors
permission into Palmirennaes Chamber, who began to affect him no less then
she did her sisters.

CHAP. V. The life that Amadis led with Palmirenna. Floridans passions for
Amplamira. Amadis and he knows one another.
AMadis his behavior, accompanied with most extraordinary sweetness, made him
to be beloved of all, Palmirenna and her sisters held nothing so dear as his
company, their women idolatrized him, and as his habit beguiled every one, the
Gallants of the Court were as much enamoured of her, as she was of her
Mistress: Tarsander, the Prince of Balivana, Nephew to the Emperor, sighed
often at her feet, howbeit so discreetly, that the Emperor, who
notwithstanding his old years was extremely passionate for her, could never
perceive it: Every one adored her, but he that showed least fear, and most
affection, was Bustrafard the Giant, whose cruel soul delighted more in blood,
then in the exercise of any Gentleness. This Colossus having heard it often
said, that handsomnesse had as much power over the will of a woman, as the
continuance of services that were done her, labored to sweeten his look, which
was most dreadful, caused his horrible rough beard to be perfumed, combed his
hair, that was harder then any horses Mane, painted his swarthy face,
apparelled himself in the richest robes he could get, which made him more
hideous, and omitting no occasion to accost our Gentlewoman, entertained her
with the discourse of his valor, of his wealth, and of the antiquity of his
race; and propounded unto her incredible contentments in the possession of him.
Behaving himself thus in the sight of all the world, it exceedingly vexed
Tarsander, who would willingly have been revenged on him, had his forces been
answerable to his courage; but knowing full well that it would have been in
vain for him to have attempted any thing against him he concealed his mind,
hoping that Corazinda had more judgment, then to suffer her self to be carried
by such an ill favored and ugly beast. Whilst all these gallants dyed for the
love of her, she felt the same passions for the Lady, and because she durst
not sigh but in secret, she spent much of her time alone in the Gardens, where
she entertained her self in this manner. To what end serves this borrowed
disguise, if I have not an heart to crave a remedy, for the extremity of my
grief? I see Palmirenna, it is true, I kiss her hands, and by an excess of
good fortune, she sometimes joins her lips unto mine; but what does that
avayl me, seeing she does it in regard of the habit that I were, not of the
love that I bea^ her? Nothing questionless, but to increase my torment, these
are winds, which in stead of extinguishing my flame, make it burn with the more
violence, and if I take not a stronger resolution, I have labored in vain to
get the possession of so invaluable a g^mme: I must then either quit this
habit, or make another, and better use of it then hitherto I have done, women's
hearts are not without pity, and when Palmirenna shall know that I am a
Knight, she will not advance my death by manifesting it to another. But what
is this I say? will she not have just cause to blame this deceit, and to
banish me from her sight for a punishment of so heinous a crime? yes, no doubt,
and whereas the good will she bore me, whilst she thought me to be of her sex,
might counsel her to do otherwise, honor and decency will fence her to it, I
do therefore ill to yield to my desires, I am more happy then I deserve; for the
longer I suffer, the greater will be my glory. So resolving to be silent, and
leave her remedy unt^ time, she sat her down one day under a tree, upon whose
bark she had graven a thousand characters, where she began to renew her
complaints, when as Palmirenna arriving there by chance with three of her
Ladies, caught her by the arm, and said. What, Corazinda; are you still
weeping, cannot all our caresses make you forget our country? Truly I have
reason to complain of you, and will never believe that you love me so much, as
you say, since you continue so sad here. Think not, answered she, (some what
amazed to see her self so surprised) that I bestow these tears, on the
remembrance of my country, or friends their absence is the least of my cares,
but I grieve for that I cannot profit you by my service, nor advance my self a
whit in the honor of your savor, for loving you far more, and that beyond
all comparison, as I may truly say, then all the Knights of the world put
together can possibly do, I could wish that your eyes should rest no where but
on me, as my thoughts have no other object, then the excellency of your
beauty; I wonder, said Palmirenna, that you should complain thus of me without
a cause, does not my women's jealousy, who are vexed for that they cannot be so
free with me as you are; make it evidently appear how infinitely I love you?
clear your self of this sinister impression, and be confident, dear Corazinda,
that if your content depends on me, you shall live as happily as your own heart
can wish, being resolved to give you, and that most willingly, all that you can
desire of me, provided I may see you no more thus afflicted. Now are all my
sorrows at an end, answered Corazinda, for all the good of my future life is
tied to the effect of this promise, which I hope you will never forget, and to
make my happiness complete, there wants nothing but this; that whereas herein
the Court I am called the fair slave; you will be pleased, that hereafter I may
be called Palmirenna's fair slave. Here at the Princess fell a laughing, and
embracing her, said that it pleased her very well. Some hours being sweetly
spent in such like discourse, which testifying more and more an extreme love,
that gave the Ladies great occasion to marvel from whence the heat of so
powerful an affection should proceed, these two incomparable beauties retired
into the Palace, where the Emperor meeting with them, began on a sudden to
feel that fire burn which the first sight of our fair sl^ve bad kindled in his
breast: Pretty one, said he unto her, having withdrawn her to a window, do not
you think is time yet to case my pain and shall the discretion which you have
sound in my carriage leave you insensible of my sufferings? consider that my
love can make you the happiest Woman of the world, and that your good fortu^e
depends on the pity which you shall have of me, and that if you be inexorable,
you will give me just occasion to accuse your in gretitude, and to retrench
you of those favors, which you receivehere. Sir answered she, (knowing full
well that ^hee was to flatter his grief, rather than incense his choler) my
judgment is not so weak, as to make me neglect the contentment, and advantages
which the honor of your affection does promise me, but do you think, that
having yet sighs in my mouth, and tears in my eyes, to be wayl my captivity,
my esloignment from my country, and the loss of my friends, I can resolve for
any pleasure? verily I cannot, time the common Physician of our miseries, may
alter this peevish humor, and furnish me with other devises, be pleased I
beseech you Sir, to attend your remedy from thence, your delight will be the
greater when I shall give it you without grudging, and not forcing my will you
shall oblige me to comm^nd your gentleness, in the mean while let me obrain
of you, that you will not afflict yourself, and giving me leave to retire from
hence for to avoid the suspicion which may be had of your intent, leave me so
to manage my sorrows with time, as I may be ableere it be long, to satisfy
your hopes. Go my dearest Cornkinds, said be, insinitly contented with this
answer; the gods which have made you to ^air, make you as true. Palmirennaes
fair slave having got off in this manner, went to find on her Lady; but
understanding that she was laid down to sleep, she returned into the Garden,
where having made afewturns, she peceiveda man lying on the grass, under the
shadow of certain trees, who thinking he was not over-heand spoke thus.
Wretched Knight? what can thou expect from thy enterprise, but
insuppottabletonments? thou imaginest that time, and thy services will beget a
liking of thee in this Princess, but thou will be deceived, she will receive
them from thee, as from an ordinary Knight obliged by the liberality of her
father, what will thou do then? will thou discoverthy self for to serve her
openly? thou will not be believed, but say thou were, difference of religion
would serve for a cause to refuse thee; now to leave her is not in thy power,
seeing all thy future content depends on her favor. Powerful love open my
eyes, that I may find out the means to conserve my self, which I fear is even
at an end. Here with bedewing his cheeks with tears, he fetched three or four
sighs, whereof Corakinds, who measured another grief by her own, was so
sensible, that she resolved to comfort him: Whereupon approaching unto him,
she perceived that it was he whom she had taken up out of the Sea, at her
arrival in Marta^ia, which exceedingly rejoiced her, but making as though she
knew him not, she began to discourse of the inconstancy of things here below,
that many times succeed according to our desires, when we least hope for them;
Weak spirits, said she, mayfail, because they are ignorant of the good which
patience brings, bun a generous Knight ought to undertake without fear, and
dare any thing where by he may be able to merit; delight does notraste well,
without some proceeding labor, nor is content pleasing, gotten without pain,
the resolution you have taken to pursue your design, is courageous, and from
whence you cannot but attend recompense, proceed then, and be not dismayed with
the difficulties of our enterprise, Love will favor your desires, and for me I
will most willingly serve you therein to the utmost of my power. O me said the
Knight, who during this discourse had very attentively observed her, either I
am greatly deceived, or I behold one of the bravest Warriors on the earth, in
an habit quite contrary to his valor, diftrust me not Sir, I beseech you, I
owe too much unto your assistance to be any way wanting to your service, or to
disclosethat which you desire should be concealed, wherefore tell me boldly the
occasion of this transformation, which so amazeth me. I did not think, answered
C^razinda, that you could have known me thus disguised, but not to hide my self
longer from you, I confess that I am indeed the same that saved you from
drowning, you marvel to see me in this attire, but you know that love does
greater miracles, I will give you a reason for it by and by, so as you will use
the like courtesy toward me, by declaring truly unto me your birth, and
condition. That will I a thousand times over, if you please, said he, I am
called Floriden of Persia, son to Den Rogel of Greece, of whom peradventure
you have heard, conducted hither by my destiny, and constrained to abide here
for to obtain the favor of Amplamira, the Emperors second Daughter, whose
beauty has so engaged me, that I can never depart from hence without infinite
discontent. See, said C^razinda, embracing him very kindly; how unfortunate
have we bin not to know one another in this strange Country, where the advice
of the one might greatly avayl the other; my name is Amadis of Trebisond, Son
to the Emperor Amadis of Greece, your Fathers Grandfather, drawn hither as you
have seen by a mavelous adventure, and here stayed by the beauty of (...),
for the love of whom I have taken upon me this habit, believing that it would
facilitate the means to see her, and it may be to conduct my designs to a
better Port, then could have been done by my Arms, which I have made odious at
my arrival in this Province, where I am now known by the name of C^razinda,
though of late I am called (...) fair slave. Here with these two brave
Warriors renewing their embraces, infinitely caressed one another; but the fear
of being discovered, counseled them to retire, with a promise nevertheless to
meet every day, and confer of their Loves, at all other times carrying
themselves, as unacquainted; parting then with some grief Floridan went to his
Chamber, musing on the course that he might hold for to speak to his Lady, and
the fair slave to (...), whose absence was so insupportable to her, that she
was almost never out of her sight.

CHAP. VI. Floridan meets with Almerina in the Emperors Garden, their
discourse; Floridan discovering himself, writes to Amplamira.
WHilst Amadis beheld himself in those eyes, which his soul adored, sighed out
his passions, and under the favor of the habit that he wore stole kisses from
Palmirenna's delicate lips, whilst he lost himself at the sight of the two
little unparalled Worlds, that so graced her bosom; and languished in the
desire, and expectation of a greater felicity; Floridan was enraged for that he
could not come to speak unto his Mistress that he might acquaint her with the
secret fire which consumed him; he recounted his sufferings unto the trees,
desired relief from the Fountains, and as if these inanimate things had been
capable of his cmplaints, he besought them to comfort and assist him in so
great an extremity. At length, unable longer to endure the violence of his
desires, he resolved either by death, or the assurance of enjoying of that he
desired, to make himself happy; My tongue dares not discover my thoughts; said
he, my hand then shall do it that office; and if I must dye in this enterprise,
it is better I should do so quickly, then languish any longer amidst such
tormenting passions; Whereupon getting ink and paper, he wrote what love
indicted to him, but having finished his Letter, and not knowing how to convey
it into his Ladies hands, he was troubled afresh, and dispaired of all good
success, howbeit his fortune proved better then he expected, for walking
solitary in the Garden by himself, as he used to do; Al^^^ina (the Earl^ of
Frisoliae's daughter, and the faithful Secretary of Amplamira's thoughts, being
enamored of him, and therefore as much desiring to sp^ak with him, as he did
to talk with his Mis^^esse) came thither by chance, and espying him lying
under a tree, she approached unto him, ere he was aware, where watch fully
observing him, she hoped to have heard something come from him; that might
discover the cause of his ^olitude, but finding him silent with some tears in
his eyes, she presently conceived that her heauty had wrought these effects in
him, the rather because she remembered, that he had always sought occasions to
be present, where she was with Amplamira, this opinion, and her affection
emboldning her, she stepped to him, and pulling up his hat, which he had plucked
down over his eyes, with a smiling countenance she said unto him: How now
Knight of the Flowers, do these tears become the cheek of a valiant man? and
why do you afflict your self in a place where you are so caressed, not
answerably, it may be, to your merits, but as much as may be? come, this
carriage of yours rather befits a Woman, whose weakness is not capable of
generous resolutions, to withstand misfortune, and if you continue to do thus,
you will lose much of that good opinion, which out Courtiers have conceived of
you; a courageous mind seeks remedy for his disease, and never increases it by
cowardice; now if the loss of your friends, or the absence of some Mistress
makes your abode here distastful, the Emprour is a Prince so gracious, that he
will not deny you leave to depart from hence at your pleasure. Alas, said he
(no whit dismayed with this surprise, but resolved to discover himself, since
this encounter had happened according to his wish) my displeasure proceeds not
from the grief of seeing my self esloigned from my Country, since I
voluntarily forsook it, for to travel the world, but I complain for that I am
so unhappy, as I cannot hope for any content whilst I live, unless you will
take some pity of my suffering, I must speak, I can no longer conceal my
thoughts; Almerina, in your hands rests my life or death, I have endured
incredible things before I would resolve to discover my self; and the fear to
offend Amplamira, whom I love beyond all comparison, far more then mine own
soul, has hitherto closed up my lips, but now the violence of my pains so
terribly afflicts me, that I must impart this secret unto you; Sweet Almerina,
have some compassion on me, tell her that which I say, and joining your
entreaties to my tears, render her sensible of my suffering: I am too daring,
it is true, for such an accomplished beauty deserves no less then the
affection of a God, but if her eyes might stoop to a man, my birth has not
made me so mean, but that I may justly equal my self with the greatest of the
earth; now if I may receive a good office from you, be assured that you shall
not confer it upon an ungrateful person, nor ever repent any assistance you
may give me. These words finishing in tears, marvellously astonished this Lady,
who little expected such a discourse, and considering the speech she had
heard, which deprived her of all hope of ever possessing him, shrinking up her
shoulders, she said; O ye gods, now deceitful is the judgment of man, and
with what little assurance may one depend on things of this world; Indeed Sir I
guessed, that Love had drawn forth those tears, which trickled down your
cheeks, and as I was foolish enough to presume a little too much of my beauty,
I verily believed that I was the cause of it, loving you with no less ardour,
then you do your Mistress, but now knowing you better then I did, and no way
doubting of the greatness of your descent, I will quench those amorous flames,
and only reserve such a good will for you, ^^ may oblige you in your
enterprise; wherefore I Will promise to serve you therein with passion, not for
the hope of the recompenses you propound, but for the glory of having done
something for so noble a Gentleman, and to restifie unto you how willingly I
do this, I will presently go about it; Were it not amiss (said Floridan unto
her, after some kisses, and a thousand protestations, eternally to remember so
powerful an obligation) that she saw a Letter, whereby J was resolved to have
discovered my self unto her; It cannot choose but aid our design, said
Almerina, therefore give it me, you shall quickly have an answer of it, and be
confident that if it lie in me, you shall have no longer cause to complain:
Whereupon Almerina departing with some regret, to see all her hopes overthrown,
she went to find out Amplamira in her Chamber, who beholding her with a
troubled countenance, demands of her from whence she came? from learning out a
secret, answered she, of great importance for you: What is it, said Amplamira?
Madam replied Almerina, walking but now in the Emperors Garden, and thinking
of nothing less then Love; I discovered a Gallant the most inamoured that
lives, wot you who it is? That brave stranger, the Companion of him that
defeated the Monster, he lay upon the grass under the shadow of those great
trees, which make a demi-circle at the first door of the walk, and spoke
somewhat loud, not imagining that I was so near him; His first speeches were
nothing but complaints against fortune, that spares no body, and that
ordinarily falls upon the greatest, the better to demonstrate her power; but
passing from that to speak of Love, he fetched some sighs, and then proceeded
in this manner. O ye gods, said he, how fair is Amplamira, but why does not
she know that I love her? I have a thousand times resolved to let her
understand my affection, and a thousand times again has respect shut up my
mouth, fearing to offend her by the overture of my heart; nevertheless it is
necessary that she know it, at least wise if ever I will hope for content, but
how shall that be, dare I be so hardy as to speak unto her? No verily, fear
would tie up my tongue, and the lightning of her eyes would strike me dumb: To
acquaint her with it otherwise, alack I see little likelihood, here I am
unknown; and of millions that in my own country would most gladly serve me,
not one is present to undertake this afair, I must dye then with this regret,
that I have loved the fairest, and most excellent creature in the world, and
durst not publish it. These words being drowned with a sea of tears, he turned
him about, and took a paper out of his pocket, over the which he lamented
anew. How happy would thou be, said he, if thou might be permitted to
touch the delicate hands of my Mistress, and what would not I give then to see
my self in thy place? Doubtless J should not grieve at the loss of so much
greatness as a tends me; and though it should immediately preced my death, I
should be no way sorry for it. What should I say more? All his motions, Madam,
were full of love, he wished a thousand, and a thousand times that he might
be beloved of you; in the midst of this Agony he rose up, and went away,
leaving the paper which it seems he forgot, behind him upon the ground, where
I found it all bedewed with his tears, and which I present here unto you, open
it, peradventure you will meet with the same discourse in it, as I made you but
now. Whereupon kissing the Letter, which Floridan had given her, she delivered
it to the Princess, who made some difficulty at the first to receive it,
howbeit being a little urged by Almerina, but more by the desire she had to
learn who the Knight was, she opened it, and read this which follows.

To the fairest Infanta of Martaria.
MADAM,
I Doubt not, but you will think it very strange, that an unknown Knight
should dare so far, as to be a Suit^r to you for your love, before his
services might induce you unto it; but when you shall consider, that he is
enforced so to do, by the unresistable power of your divine beauty,
questionless you will excuse his presumption, and not think it ^^isse, if he
beg some grace from you, since it is the glory of the gods to grant it unto
the Prayers of m^^: He indures incredible pains, his desires never leave him
in quiet, his heart burns continually in a flame, which your fair eyes have
kindled his little merit, and your greatness make incessant was upon him, he
has no relief but in his sighs; in the which too he finds a great deal of
misery: Leave him not Madam, in the midst of so many Enemies that oppress him,
he will not live but for you, prolong his days for your service; and because
all his felicity depends thereupon, permit in the mean time that he may be
named.

Your KNIGHT.


Is it possible, said (...), that there should be so much temerity in a man! an
ordinary Knight address himself to me! motion love to me! and be a Suitor to
me for some favor? This is an unpardonable insolence, he must be relieved
Almerina, but in an other manner, then he hopes for; return prese^^ly to him,
and tell him, that I am acquainted with his intent, and that it lies in me to
have him most rigorously punished for it; howbeit, being more merciful then
he deserves, I will let him live upon condition, that he speedily void the
Country, and never present himself again before me. Madam, answered Almerina,
pardon me I beseech you, if J do nor approve of this your displeasure, and
justly you cannot lay so grievous a command upon me; he is one of the greatest
Princes now living upon the earth, and to entreat him so unworthily is against
all reason. How do you know, said Amplamira, that he is such as you deliver
him? I learned it by his discourse, answered (...) but without that, the brave
carriage of himself, his fair parts, and the confidence out of which he has
dared to address himself unto you, and most assured demonstrations of an
extraordinary, and high (...), Permit him, Madam, to love you, for I do not
think, th^^ i^ wh^^^ world you can meet with one that is so handsome, and so
(...) of you. That he is valiant you cannot doubt, the death of the A^^^^
(...), whom he slew in your presence, being armed but with a single sword, make
it good, what can you wish for more in a man? verily one of his merit is not
easily sound, and if you let this occasion slip, you will be the first that
will repent it.

Thou pleadest so well for him, said Amplanira, who hegan to feel the first
assaults of love, that I am resolved to over come my self for to affect him;
but at any hand I will not have him know so much. Pish, said Almerina, what
good can this affection do him, if he must be ignorant of it? would his
sorrows be assuaged, would he have less cause to complain and afflict
himself? No, Madam, he must be made acquainted with his good fortune, or else
you must not love him. Why, said Amplamira, would thou have me contrary to
all order, be a Suitor, and demand that of him, which he ought not to obtain
of me without a world of service and suffering. I do not mean so neither,
said Almerina, I only say, that he is to be received favorably, when he
shall present himself before you, and that you do not refuse him the favor ^e
desires, which is to employ his Arms as your Knight. This cannot bet
conveniently done, said Amplamira, for to speak openly with him would not
become me; since he is not known what he is, and for him to come he^her is far
more unfit, for so I might not only give my women occasion to talk, but
peradventure all the Court: what course shall we hold then that it may be
affected? A little thing troubles you, said Almerina; well take you no care,
I Will bring it to a good issue, so as you will leave it to me, and follow my
counsel, only be mindful to know of him who he is, when you see him, that
you do not engage your self inconsiderately, nor repent the loss of your
liberty. This discourse ended by the arrival of Palmirenna, and her fair
slave, who could not endure to be asunder, Almerina get her presently forth,
and found out Floridan, to whom having delivered in few words, that he was to
hope well, and that he should not fail to be the next day at the same place
and time, where she had met with him in the Garden, she returned, leaving him
more contented, then ever he was in all his life.

CHAP. VII. Amadis unable to endure the violence of his desires, discovers
himself to Palmirenna, her answer. Floridan is presented to Amplamira by
Almerina.
THe day beginning to break, Floridan to whom minutes had been unsupportable
hours, got him out of bed, and having apparelled himself in the bravest fashion
he could devise to appear the more pleasing in the eyes of Amplamira, went
down into the Garden, where he walked up and down, earnestly beseeching in his
heart, that proud divinity which triumph^d over his desires that he would
direct his tongue at his encounter with his Lady, and render her sensible of
his pain; but imagining that she could not come so soon, he laid him down under
certain trees, and fell into so deep a muse of his expected happiness, that
three hours past insensibly away, at the end whereof his passion making him
believe, that the leaves driven by a sweet and gentle breath of wind proceeded
from Amplamira's steps, he suddenly rose, and looked a thousand times about
him, howbeit, seeing no body appear, he got into an arbor, covered with
Iasemine, where the fear of meeting with new difficulties in his enterprise,
assailing him, he said.

In vain I attend a felicity that I have never deserved, Amplamira will not
come, and the sweetness of those hopes, which had already placed me in the
supremest degree of glory, will, I doubt, be changed into bitterness, the
hour prescribed me is past, Almerina appears not, what shall I think then of so
grievous a retardment, but that which has always accompanied the evil fortune
of my actions? I see there is no way for me, but to resolve for death, which
yet would be better then a life so full of crosses, at least wise Amplamira
being the cause of it, I shall endure it without grief.

Herewith going out of the Arbor, as if he would have sought for the end of
his days, he perceived that Sun to appear, whose approach he had attended with
so much impatience, which so transported him with the excess of a sudden joy,
as notable to sustain himself he fell on his knees, but so oportunely, that
Amplamira arriving thereupon, by the cunning of Almerina (who had gotten her
down into the Garden, under color of conferring privately with her, about the
last nights Affair) she believed that it was purposely done to obtain that of
her which he had sued for by his Letter. Their amazement being great, they
beheld one another a good while without speaking a word, Floridan trembled,
Amplamira found her self surprised by so unexpected an encounter, and knew not
how to speak to this Lover, doubting to show her self, either too free, or too
reserved; howbeit receiving incredible content, to see him at her feet in such
great humility, and judging by his fear, that he was extremely in love; she
said unto him, with a behavior that testified more Majesty, then good will,
Knight what is it that you demand? That which I can never hope for, answered
he, if you shall consider the excellency of your beauty, the greatness of
your birth, and the merit of your virtues; I wish for a place in your heart,
and that I may be permitted to bear Arms as your Knight. Why who are you,
replied she, that asks so freely what the greatest Prince of the earth could
