not have without infinite labor? Madam, answered he, I will boast more in being
yours, and will draw more glory from your service, then from all the kingdoms
of the world, nevertheless if you will know who I am, it is fit I should obey
your pleasure; wherefore I will declare it to you, but Madam be pleased, it may
be conditionally that no body know it but your self, until such time as it
shall be requisite to have it published in the Court, I am named Floridan of
Persia, the son of Rogell of Greece, Heir to the Empires of Trebisond,
Constantinople, and Persia, of which peradventure you have heard little spoken,
in regard of the dangers which are met withal in traversing the Seas that
separate them from this Country.

Arise Prince, said Amplamira then (lending him her hand with wonderful
content to have learnt that his birth was so transcendent) your greatness will
not permit me to leave you in the state where you are, the kingdoms you speak
of, are indeed very remote from hence; but yet we have had some knowledge of
them, for our Admiral about three years since visited all those coasts, and
at his return recounting a good part of the warlike exploits of the Princes of
Greece, he brought us their names, amongst the which I well remember, how that
which you give to your Father is one; come let us make a turn in this Garden,
and I will tell you my resolution upon the demand, you made me: Whereupon
walking along the allies with incredible content to Floridan, who held and
kissed his Ladies hand, whilst she accepted of his service, and commanding him
to be no less faithful then loving promised to meet him oftentimes in that
place; provided that it might still be with that respect, which was to be
observed to one of her quality; whereunto Floridan having deeply sworn, she
wisely retired to avoid the encounter of any one, and left him better
satisfied, then ever he was in his life.

In the mean time, Love wrought strange miracles, he made Palmirenna in love
with her slave, and possessed her with as much desire as the other; beholding
her continually to sigh, she likewise sighed, and said to her self; O ye gods!
how cruel is my fate to make me feel the same passions for a Woman, as I
should do for a Knight! that which she indures for me, should make me wise,
and keep me from falling into the like inconvenience; what else can I expect
from this desire, but an impossible contentment, and a pain without all hope? I
called thee fool Corazinda, but alas I am a greater, and yet not so, our error
is common, our miseries are equally shared, I can give thee no remedy, nor
can thou bring me any, nature having made us so wretched, as to render us
impotent to our wishes. Why art not thou a man, or why am not I one? So should
we not languish in this sort; for preferring thy merit before the greatest
Crowns of the earth, I would become thy Wife, or I would soon be thy husband;
wherewith looking on her fair slave, who had then the same thoughts, she took
her in her arms, and feeling some thing by chance that women have not, she
joined her lips to hers, with such ardour, as did denote a more then ordinary
passion, whereof our Warrior was so sensible, that he was about to discover
himself, but being retained by the fear of precipitating his felicity, he
contented himself with giving her two kisses for one: upon the continuance of
which, Palmirenna still thinking of the encounter she had made, said laughing
unto him. Ah, Corazinda, nature has done us great wrong, for if you had been a
Knight, we might have lived together with incredible contentment. I Madam,
answered he, so as you would have conferred the same favor on me, which now I
receive from you. Believe me, replied she, that I have wished it a thousand
times of late; whereupon rounding her in the ear, that he might not be
overheard by Crestia, the most intimate of her Women that was by, he said
unto her, Madam, be pleased to remember this speech; the gods that heretofore
have animated a work of Marble, for the satisfaction of a mortal man, may
authorize your wishes, in hope whereof I will instantly go and sacrifice unto
them, for to obtain so infinite a grace.

This said he departed, and leaving a mighty suspicion in the mind of this
Princess, he retired into a room, that was but little frequented; and walking
there a good while, he resolved to discover himself as soon as he could; and
indeed not long after Palmirenna; who was much troubled, coming thither with
an intent to know more of the matter, he met her, and began the discourse,
which he meant to make unto her, with new assurance of his love, when as she
taking him by the hand, interrupted him, saying.

Corazinda, I am not hereto inform my self, whether you love me or no, I have
too certain proofs of that, but to understand the truth of a secret, whereof I
have already some knowledge, your speeches have opened my eyes, and do almost
assure me, that you are a Knight, disguised for some great design, discover
your self freely unto me, if you desire that I should contribute to your
Enterprise, I love you too much, either to reveal it, or to discover you
therein.

Madam, said he, falling on his knees before her, you indeed behold a most
unfortunate Knight, if you stand on the offense he has committed, appearing
before you otherwise then in Arms for your service; but the happiest in the
world, if you shall please to continue those favors unto him, which you have
given to the belief of his sex. Love, who never leaves a Lover, without some
means of relief, having two days after I had to my grief defeated your Guard,
conducted me to the Seaside, made me at the very same time meet with a
wooden Chest, wherein were the clothes that I had on, when I was brought hither
as a slave, and furnished me with the invention to fit my self with them,
imagining as it is fallen out, that I should fall into your hands, and that
Time, or my services might oblige you to love me: I know well, that this so
audacious a part deserves no less then death, whereunto I most willingly submit
my self; but when you shall have considered, Madam, that it will be more blame
to you, then praise, you will preserve him, in stead of seeking his ruin.

It were but reason (answered she somewhat coldly, the better to discover the
greatness of the Knights affection) that I should seek out punishment to
chastise this daring impudence of yours, but being more gently disposed, I will
only banish you my company, with a commandment never to present your self
again before me. O this is too rigorous a sentence, said he, to leave a Lover
with life, Madam. I will go and revenge you of my insolence. Therewith he fell
down in the place with so little color, and motion, that Palmirenna verily
believed he was dead, which put her into such a confusion, as she was ready to
follow him, howbeit taking a little courage to her, she got her speedily away,
and calling Crestia declared what had happened, conjuring her to assist her in so
important an Affair.

This Maid perceiving by her Mistris's speech, that she was deeply in love,
said to her with a smiling countenance. Madam, you are too much troubled upon
so little occasion, have you never heard that love has done far greater
wonders, only tellme whither the death of this Knight will please you, or
whether you desire he should live? Alas, said he, Crestia, do thou not know
that I was never cruelly minded. Enough Madam, answered she, leave the care of
this to me, and you shall see that I will cure you both; saying so, she took a
little water in a dish, and going speedily to the room where Amadis lay in a
swound, she sprinkled it on his face till he came to himself again. Seeing him
then to open his eyes, she said unto him: Verily I did not think you had had
so little heart, as to be discouraged for a word speaking: Up, up, Love is like
to favor you more then you imagine.

Hereat Amadis was going to rise, but he was so faint, that he was not able to
do so, without the help of Crestia, who led him to his Chamber, and having
given him a little preserve to comfort him, she said. Come it is no time now to
dissemble, or to conceal your thoughts from me; I know that which hitherto you
have kept so secret, for the Princess my Mistress has discovered whatsoever
has past betwixt you unto me, I am able to do much for you, but I will never
serve you, unless you will swear unto me by the faith which you owe unto the
order of Knighthood, to acquaint me truly with that I shall desire to know of
you, for thereupon depends all your future good or hurt. Let Heaven show some
strange judgment on me, answered he, somewhat faintly, if I do not tell you
freely whatsoever you shall demand of me. Declare then unto me who you are,
replied she, that if it can be done with reason I may restore you into the good
grace of my Lady, who doubtless had just cause to entreat you, as she did. I
will obey you most willingly, said he; My name is Amadis, son to the great
Emperor of Greece and Trebisond, but the most unhappy Knight breathing, if
having such powerto help me, you take not some compassion of my case, dear
Crestia pass by my little merit, and persuade this incensed beauty to pardon
me, or if so be my death is more agreeable to her, order it in such sort that
I may receive it from her hands, or by her commandment, for it would grieve me
far less, to have it come to me so sweet a way. She shall not be so
rigorous, answered Crestia, let me alone to make your peace, and be comforted,
whilst I take care to render you happy.

So leaving him in his bed, she went to find out Palmirenna, who trembled at
her coming, fearing some ill news of this Knight, whom she infinitely
affected; but seeing her look merrily, she was confirmed, and withdrawing her
to a Window, that jetted upon the Garden, she asked her what she had done.
Much more then you think for, answered Crestia, your Knight is living, and
which is more, I know him for one of the greatest Princes of the world, son
to the excellent Emperor of Greece and Trebisond, of whom our Admiral has so
often spoken since his return. Good gods, said Palmivenna, what is this thou
tellest me? is it possible that he is issued out of so high, and noble a race?
how great an error have I committed to use him so cruelly, I fear Crestia, he
will be too sensible of this affront. Nay rather, said Crestia, it has made
him more desirous to see you, but that he dares not do, because he will not
disobey your commandment, before he knows that you will be pleased with it;
He is in his bed, go to him after dinner, it will give you a great deal of
satisfaction to talk with him.

This Princess, being carried more by her passion, then Crestia's counsel
failed not to visit this sick patient, as soon as she was risen from table, and
perceiving some tears in his eyes, which the doubt of finding his Mistress
inexorable to Crestia's persuasions, had produced, she comforted him with so
amorous a grace, that he presently recovered his former hue, giving her a
million of thanks for the care she took of his health. There needed no less a
Physician, said he unto her, then you to cure so dangerous a disease; but,
Madam, will you never remember my offense? no my Lord answered she, but to love
you the more; for assuring my self that the violence of your affection
counseled you to disguise your self, and that your intents were fair, I find
my self indebted to my good fortune, so as you excuse me if ignorant of your
quality, I have spoken more rudely unto you then was fit. Ah, Madam! said he,
kissing her hand, you kill me with talking in this manner, for you have absolute
power over my life, and may entreat me as you please, at which too I may not
repine: whereupon most ^^orously interchanging kisses they vowed to love one
another eternally.

CHAP. VIII. The felicity of Amadis and Floridan, in the secret Marriages of
Palmirenna and Amplamira.
THese Lovers delighting in nothing so much, as the object of their own
beauties, beheld one another with admiration; Amadis adored her, she
idolatrized Amadis, he burned, she felt no less violent a flame, they equally
desired to see the way to their felicity open, but respect and shame stayed
them from attempting it, at length our Warrior remembering that fortune derides
such as do not rightly use the favor she presents, resolved to go on, and
not make a stop in so fair a course; fixing his eyes then on his excellent
Lady, he said unto her with a countenance that testified a great deal of
passion.

Since it is your pleasure that I shall live, leave me not Madam, in pains,
which length of time, would make most insupportable, let us make use of the
means that are offered us to set our hearts at rest, and not staying till some
evil chance may deprive us of the happiness, which now we may enjoy, let us
break through this fear, that foolishly restrains us; you assure me that I
have more interest in your heart, then all the men besides in the world, I have
sworn a thousand times that I never adored any, but you, and that I will never
sigh for an other, I will reiterate the same oaths, give me the same
assurance, render the effects conformable to your words, and making me partaker
of the glory of your bed as your husband, disdain not to be my wife, upon the
promise, which now I make you before Heaven, and your faithful Crestia, to
espouse you solemnly at Constantinople, or as soon as we shall have disposed
your father thereunto.

Why dearest Lord, said Palmire^^^, (that was possessed with no less powerful
desire, then he) I have as much affection as you, to wish our present content,
but pardon me, if I tell you freely that I am to be more careful of my self;
I have heard of a thousand misfortunes occasioned by the inconstancy of men, I
may fear the like; and when you were absent from me (as the fortune of war*
might many times carry you abroad) I should still be in doubt, that you were in
the power of some other beauty.

Ah Madam, said Amadis, shedding tears, and deeply sighing, which he knew was
of mavelous force to constrain the heart of a Woman, have I not cause to be
exceedingly grieved, that you will rank me thus amongst the worst of men?
Unworthy, and dishonorable spirits may offend so basely, but a man whose aim
is reputation, will never fall into so soul a fault; I may fail, but never so
much, and say I should be tempted with some such desire, have not you
wherwithall to make me sure; look but only on your eyes, and there you shall
find charms, able to arrest the most fickle humor in the world, and to assure
your fear: These considerations Madam, are cruel; and if you desire to see an
end of me, do but continue firm in the mind you seem to be in.

Your grief does much afflict me, answered she, nor will my love endure to see
you suffer thus any longer; wherefore I am contented to espouse you this
evening, but I will have my sister Amplamira, whom I hold most dear, to be
present with Crestia, at the vows and oaths you shall make, never to have any
other Wife but me. Madam, answered he, infinitely transported with joy, I am not
able to give you thanks worthy enough for the greatness of this grace, but I
will serve you so faithfully, that you shall never repent the conferring of it
on me, I am wonderfully well contented, that the Princess Amplamira may be
with you, for I hope ere it be long to do her the like good office. Why, said
Palmirenna, will you give her an husband? Madam, answered Amadis, the excess
of my happiness will not permit me to conceal any thing, how important
soever, from you, I will acquaint you with a very great secret, but with
condition, that you will be pleased to assist me to bring it to pass. The
Knight of the Flowers, whom you know, is my Nephew, son to Rogel of Greece,
Emperor of Persia, he is passionately in love with your sister Amplamira, and
by the means of Almerina, he has lately had access unto her, in such sort, as
I believe she will not refuse him, if you will present him unto her for a
husband, let one and the same time consummate these marriages, the knowledge you
have of a Lovers pains, together with my entreaties, may persuade you unto it,
but when you shall consider, that it is for your sisters good, you will be
carried to it with more affection. Verily this is strange, said Palmirenna, and
sure this day is fatal for the happiness of our house; my Lord, let us send
for this Knight, and know of him how far he has proceeded with Amplamira,
afterward we will dispose of the rest.

Crestia having order then to seek out Floridan, these Lovers remained alone,
to Amadis, unspeakable content, who feeling himself much pressed by his desires
would fain have entered into the possession of his felicity, but Palmirenna she
wing him how near it was to night, he was constrained to command over his
appetite, and have a little patience, the rather because Crestia arrived then
with Floridan, who going to Amadis, after he had kissed Palmirenna's fair
hands, he said unto him; what occasion, Corazinda, keeps you thus in your bed?
Nay, said Palmirenna smiling, call him boldly by his name; we have found out
his tricks, and which is more, we know your greatest secrets, does Amplamira
love you, and can you hope for any thing from your services? Hereat Floridan
blushed, and was so dismayed, that he could not return her a word, he beheld
Amadis laughing, and perceiving Palmirenna take no less pleasure in seeing him
so transported, he could not tell whether it were a dream, or no: At last
gathering his wits together, and concluding with himself, that all was
discovered, he answered her thus. Madam, you have so surprised me, that in good
faith I scarce know yet where I am; for that which you desire to understand of
me, concerns me so near, that I could rather dye, a thousand times, then
confess it any other where; but desiring to give all obedience to your
commandments, and satisfaction to the friendship of this Knight, I will not
stick to acknowledge unto you, that the Princess Amplamira wishes me well, and
that she has declared how she is pleased with my servitude. That is enough,
said Palmirenna, our danger will be brought to a good port, Sir follow me, and
be not troubled with the captivity wherinto I will put you, it shall not be but
to make you relish your liberty the better.

Going forth then with Amadis, who had made himself ready, she went into her
Cabinet, where she shut up Floridan; and seeing her sister come, she caused all
her women to leave the Chamber, retaining none but Almerina, and her trusty
Crestia, that done she took Amadis by the hand, and addressing her speech to
Amplamira, she said.

Sister I have prepared you for the marvels you shall behold, for being most
assured how much you love me, and that I may trust to you in all occasions, I
hold it unnecessary to use many Ceremonies with you. Love, whose power is
unresistable, unable to put me into passion, for any of those many Princes,
which heretofore have sighed for me, has possessed me with so much for this
slave, that not to lie, I was reduced to the uttermost of despair, thinking
that my affections was mad and impossible, but my good Genius having opened
mine eyes, I came this morning to know, that the habit she wore, was usurped
for the love of me, and that it covered the body of the valiant Knight, who
cleared this Province of the danger it was in, by the death of that dreadful
Monster, which would have rendered it desolate, this has induced me to resolve
(after I had learned of him that he was the son of the renowned Emperor of
Greece) to make him this day my husband, whereof I desire you should be
participant, as well to testify the trust I repose in you; as to entreat you
to be a witness for me, that I do not receive him into my bed, before he has
taken a solemn oath to espouse me publicly in his Empire, or here in our
fathers dominions, if we can dispose him thereunto: do that then (continued she
speaking to Amadis) which is to be done on your part, to the end that the
caresses, which you shall receive from me, may be without blame.

Madam, said Amadis then, I protest before heaven, before this excellent
Princess, and before these faithful Ladies, never to have other Wife, then
you, and to espouse you solemnly, whenever you please, as now I do espouse
you. Saying this, he took a rich Diamond from off his finger, and put it on his
fair Mistresses, who giving him an amorous kiss, called him her husband and
Knight.

O ye gods, what have I seen (said Amplamira, almost lost in the wonder of
these things) and what may not one believe, concerning the power of a divinity
that works such strange miracles? A woman changes her sex, a slave becomes in
an instant Lord of Martaria, and I have for my brother and Sovereign, the
Prince of Greece, whom but even now I beheld to be a vagabond Girl. Verily I
am lost, and must needs believe that these things are done by enchantment: Is
not all this an illusion sister? or do you not tell it me to make sport with me?

No indeed, said Palmirenna, I have spoken nothing but the truth, and therefore
you must be assured that this Prince here, whose name is Amadis, is my Lord and
Husband. It is fit then, replied Amplamira, that approving of your choice, I
acknowledge him for Sovereign of Martaria, and that I kiss his hands in token
of the homage which he is to expect from his Subjects. Madam, said Amadis; it
will be more glory for me to be your Brother, then your Lord, wherefore you shall
do me a favor, to let me have yours to kiss, by way of humble thanks, for the
consent you are pleased to give unto my good fortune, for a beginning whereof I
entreat you not to refuse me one boon I shall demand of you. My Lord, answered
she, I have no other will but yours, and therefore you may easily obtain
whatsoever you shall desire of me. Confer then (replied Amadis, stepping
suddenly to Palmirenna's Cabinet, and presenting Floridan unto her) confer
then, Madam, the same grace on this Knight, who is my Nephew, as I have
received from your Sister; the Empire of Persia attends him, and the merit of
his person deserves it from you.

O ye Gods! (cried Amplamira again, and moreamazed then before,) what second
wonder is this? must I be of the party too? That you must, Sister, answered
Palmirenna straight, if you desire your own good, for this Knight being one of
the handsomest, greatest, and most accomplished Princes of the world, you
cannot fall into a better hand. I receive him then with all my heart, said she,
but I would have the consummation of this Marriage deferred for a while. Ah,
Madam, said Floridan, be not less kind then your sister, nor give her the glory
of loving better then you, how miserable should I be, to sigh whilst others
live happily amidst their delights: Behold me with an eye of pity, said he,
kneeling down before her, and consider that time may make an end of me with
grieving. Arise, said she, joining her lips to his, my love and your merit have
overcom me. Herewith, Floridan having sworn the same to her, which Amadis had
done unto his Lady; she took a Ring of him, and accepted him for her Husband.
That done, they departed one from another, after they had concluded to keep
this affair very secret, and to leave unto Amadis his habit, and name, under
color whereof he lay with Palmirenna without suspicion; and so getting to bed,
they appeased the violence of their desires, wherein let us leave them for to
see what resolution Brustafard took, being wonderful passionate for the love
of the fair slave.

CHAP. IX. Bustrafard maintaining the j^^sts, for the love of Palmirenna's
fair Slave, is vanquished by Floridan.
WHilst our Lovers sought for delights in their kisses, for sweetest
satisfaction in their embraces, and whilst they met with unexpressable raptures
in the height of their pleasures; Tarsander sighed out his sufferings, and
Bustraf^rd was lost in the excess of his passion. This Giant, who presumed so
far, as to be persuaded, that Palmirenna's fair Slave would adore him, as soon
as she knew that he loved her, was much abashed at not finding her not sensible
of his flame, but seeking to flatter himself in some sort, he laid the fault on
the modesty which Maidens do always retain in their actions, and said that it
was discretion in her, to conceal her thoughts, howbeit perceiving that time,
and patience did but increase his desires, he resolved to board her, and so
know whereunto he should trust; yet considering with himself, that it would be
fit for him to oblige her first, by some remarkable service, to the end the
might have no excuse, if she would not affect him, he presented himself before
the Emperor one day, when as Palmirenna, her Sister, the fair Slave, and the
most of the Lords, were in the great Hall, and kneeling down, he said unto him
with a voice that might have dismayed the most confident.

Mighty Monarch of Martaria, I have often heard it said, that Love was the
author of all Gentillesses, and thereof you may now see an example in me, that
loath to let your Court be in idleness, am resolved to put it in exercise, so
as your Majesty will be pleased therewith all; for I will maintain for three
days together, against all comers, both with my Lance and Sword, that next
unto these three excellent Princesses, who admit no comparison, G^razinda is
the fairest Maid that lives; and that of all the Knights of the earth, I am
most worthy of her favor. This speech which drew laughter from all the
Assistants, made our fair Slave to blush, who answered him with a smile;
Knight, be well advised upon that which now you propound, the performance whereof
carries more difficulty with it, then you think for, and the injustice of
your cause may deny you the victory, which otherwise were most assured to the
force you have. I never fear that, answered he, for on so just a quarrel, I
would undertake to vanquish the gods. But what do you hope from this enterprise
of yours, said she unto him? Much honor in having served you, answered he, and
more contentment in enjoying of you, being most assured that my valor will
induce you to love me, if my affection cannot. But what if you happen to have
the worst, replied she? You may then, answered he, recompense my Vanquisher
with the favors I have desired from you. Your enterprise does so much oblige
me, said she, that not to be ungrateful, I will submit my ^elf to the
conditions you have propounded. Go then, so as it may stand with his Majesty's
pleasure, I will be the prize of your victory. O ye Gods! said Tarfander to
himself, what is this I hear? my hopes are at an end, nor can I wish for any
thing now but death, which I will seek for at the point of my rivals Lance. Ah!
Corazinda, how unadvised are you voluntarily to engage your self in so
loathsome a captivity? do you think to find delight in the bed of such an ugly
fellow, or any sweetness in the kisses of such beastly lips? you will curse the
time that ever you were so light of your promise, for had you done it with any
hope, there had been comfort yet, but alas! your misfortune is remediless, the
whole Empire has not a Knight able to resist the force of this Giant, so that
of Palmirenna's, you will become Bustrafards slave.

Whilst this Lover complained in this manner; Bustrafard having easily obtained
permission to Combat, went and armed himself, leaving the Courtiers not so much
marvelling at his vain craking, as at Corazinda's rash promise, who turning her
fair eyes to Palmirenna, said unto her: Excellent Mistress, do not ye think that
I had reason to entertain this gailant? No marry do I, said Palmirenna, who
seemed to be discontented with this accord, you have been a great deal to rash,
for since you are mine, my Will ought to be a Law unto you. Why, Madam, said
Corazinda, do you repine at my good fortune? Now on my faith, said Amplamira,
who could not forbear laughing, there is no body here that will envy you the
content of so sweet a servant. Howsoever I shall have this advantage of you,
replied Corazinda, that my beauty will do wonders, whilst you shall not be so
much as spoken of.

This discourse having redoubled their laughter, the Princesses led Corazinda
in triumph to the windows, where she and Palmirenna placed themselves together
for to be hold the carriage of this valiant Lover; who in the mean time being
very richly armed, appeared in the field with such a daring confidence, as no
body durst undertake him. Howbeit not very long after, a big Knight arived in
the Lists, who addressing himself unto Brustafard, said, Giant, I come not
hither to dispute with Corazinda for the glory of being one of the fairest
creatures in the world, for my estimation of her is as great, if not greater
then thine; but to abate thy pride, which persuades thee, that no other Knight
besides thy self is worthy to serve her. Now by my best hopes, said the Giant,
somewhat netled with his speech, I find thy body too little for so great an
attempt; nevertheless being here to receive all comers, I hold it fit to give
thee content. Saying so, they turned about to take the field, and charging
their Lances, they met in the midst of their course with such fury, that the
big Knight having broken very bravely in the midst of his Enemies shield, was
overthrown with his horse to the ground; the Giant passing on somewhat
astonished at so violent an encounter, howbeit setting himself well in his
saddle, he returned presently with his sword in his hand, but seeing the Knight
not stir, he caused his Squire to pull off his Helmet, and so discovered to all
the Court, that it was the amorous Tarsander, who (...) spaire had made to put
on Arms, with a resolution to die, or be revenged on his ryval; the fall of
this young Prince, who had no other hurt but his amazement, was so sensible to
the Emperor, that had he not feared the anger of Brustafard, and his Brothers,
which was dreadful to all his neighbors, the Jousts had been at an end, but
concealing his displeasure, he sent his Physicians to his Nephew, who was found
more touched with despi^e then harm.

In the mean time the Giant, with no other but his first Lance overthrew the
King of Arbales, the Duke of Corzan, the King of Calizant, the Marquis of
Bonport, the Duke of Plemond, and the Earl of Modiance, brave Knights, and that
had acquired much glory in the adventures of the world.

These Warriors so easily unhorsed, retired with extreme discontent, and not
long after the Emperor seeing no more appear, returned likewise into his
Palace, where he demanded of his Daughters what they thought of the Giants
designs. We think, answered Palmirenna, that there is more folly then courage
in it, for it is an unprofitable labor, in regard we are persuaded that
Corazinda will never yield her self up into the power of so ugly, and
il-favoured a thing, if his valor should happen to make him triumph over all
that oppose him. O Madam, said Corazinda, do not judge so amiss of a Maidens
promise, for why should not I love him? I find no defect in him, his hair is
not yet clean white, the perfuming of his beard takes away the ill savor of
his flat nose; he affects me much, I should be very ungrateful then, to let
him consume away without succouring him. I but, pretty one, said the Emperor,
speak you in good earnest? That I do verily, answered she, laughing with
Palmirenna at the Emperors fear; for if some valiant Knight do not ds-ingage
me, I may not be worse then my word, though it be in my choice whether I will
love him or no. Now in good faith, said the Emperor, drawing her aside, you
will much wrong your self, to prefer his satisfaction before mine. Why Sir, said
Corazinda, can you think I am so base-minded? believe it he shall never draw
any favor from me, and if I entertain such an opinion in him, it is but to
make sport; the honor of your affection is dearer to me then my life; and if I
do not satisfy your desire, yet assure your self, Sir, it is out of the
consideration of a thing which you will allow of hereafter.

This discourse finishing by the arryval of Brustafard, who came gloriously in
with the spoils of the vanquished, which he placed at the feet of his Mistress;
every one talked of this love til supper; where Palmirenna, and her Sister
Amplamira, would not be present, to have the more liberty to caress their
Lovers in private: Commanding a Table to be covered them in Palmirenna's
chamber, they sat them down all four; being attended by none but their
Secretaries, and falling to speak of Brustafards enterprise; Amadis entreated
Floridan to combat him the next day, which questionless had been most
insupportable to his Amplamira, had she not been persuaded that Amadis would
not have exposed him to such danger, if it had not been to have given him the
greater reputation in the Court, wherefore arming her self with patience, she
permitted him to undertake it, and perceiving it to be bed time, she secretly
retired with him, leaving Amadis with Palmirenna, without any suspicion of her
women.

The night being sweetly past away, Floridan arose, and desiring Amplamira to
be present at his combat with Bustrafard, he went to the King of Arbales, with
whom he had contracted some friendship; and being accommodated by him with all
that seemed necessary for his enterprise, he mounted upon a lusty Horse, and
appeared in the Lists at such time as the Giant having overthrown the King of
Arisdan, the Marquess of Rocque, and the Count Cordena, with an intolerable
arrogance, challenged the Knights of the Court to combat with him altogether,
the brave countenance of this Warrior, that managed his Horse in a most gallant
manner, having turned the eyes of all the assistants upon him, especially of
Amplamira, who beheld him with motions of love and fear, he approached unto
Bustrafard, and said.

Knight, your insolence does so distaste me, that I resolve to be of the number
of those whom you have driven out of the field, or cure your brain of the
distemper, wherwithall Corazinda's beauty has infected it. I had thought,
answered he incholler, that others example would have made thee wise; but
sincethou wilt needs be lost with them for company, accuse thine own folly for
it. Charging his Lance then with more fury then at any time before; he met
Floridan in the midst of the course, whose Shield being unable to resist the
violence of so strong an encounter, was pierced in such sort, as the staff
passing under his arm, had almost put Amplamira besides her self, out of the
opinion she had, that it was run through his body, but seeing her Lover in his
saddle, and his enemy on the ground, with a dangerous wound in his side, and
judging by the shouting, and clapping of the peoples hands, who thereby
testified the contentment they took in beholding that proud mass of flesh
overthrown, she grew somewhat confident, and prayed unto her gods, for to give
her Knight the same honor in his combat on foot, as he had had on horseback.

In the mean time, the Giant full of rage arose with strange blasphemies; and
in regard his enemy was alighted, because he would not fight with advantage, he
advanced his sword, and thinking to divide him with the first blow, he let it
fall with such force, that questionless the effect had answered his
expectation, had not Floridan, seeing it coming, warily avoided it, letting
him then cleave the air, and the ground in vain, he discharged so furious a
stroke on his Helmet, that he made him knock his chin against his bosom,
carrying away to the very skull, all that his blade met withal. O ye gods!
said the Emperor, what a horrible blow was this? doubtless this Knight is one
of the valientest of the earth; and if he continues in this sort Corazinda will
have power to bestow her favors on some other.

Whilst the Emperor was saying this, the Giant, that did not believe he could
have found so much strength in one man, staggered a little; but instantly
recovering himself with an incredible rage, he began to deal such desperate
blows, that every one looked each minute to see the Knight cut in pieces;
howbeit he avoided them with such quick agility, and gave him so many wounds,
thatall which beheld him cried out, that the very God of battails used not more
grace in his fight, nor more violence in his strokes. Some hours being spent in
the heat of this Duel, the Giant would have retired, to take a little breath;
but Floridan, who was vexed to be so long in vanquishing before his Mistress,
pressed him so hard, as he was constrained to defend himself, and renew the
combat, charging one another then with greater fury, then at the beginning,
they delivered a world of blows, whereof one chancing to light on Floridans
shoulder, gave him a wound more large then dangerous, which put him into such
choler, that taking his sword in both his hands, and advanting it with an
intent to cleave him asunder, he perceived a great Knight, accompanied with two
dreadful Giants, entering the Lists, who came gallopping in for to part them,
but in vain; for Floridan having his sword aloft, let it descend in such
terrible force on Bustrafards head, that notwithstanding he struck but with the
flat, he sent him to the earth, casting great abundance of blood out of his
mouth, and ears; whereupon leaping into his saddle, he made head to the Giants,
who this while were wondering, that so furious a blow should proceed from the
hand of an ordinary man; howbeit, seeing that they stirred not, and guessing by
their countenance, that they were not come to assault him, he retired to the
King of Arbales, who received him with incredible content, leaving Bustrafard
to the care of his brothers, that grumbling vowed to take a cruel revenge of
this affront.

CHAP. X. Don Rifantes, Prince of Cabilla, Brundemor, King of Corcutan, and
Rozagant, King of Alfanar, demand leave to maintain the beauty of the
Princesses of Martaria, the success of their Enterprise.
FLoridan's hurt being less then his desire to see Amplamira, he stayed not
long with the King of Arbales, but went in all haste to the Palace, where the
Emperor received him very graciously, and infinitely commended the adresse and
valor, which he had showed in the combat; he was amongst his friends, that
caressed him, he heard himself most worthily spoken of by all the Courtiers; yet
was he not satisfied, for not daring to speak unto his Lady, all the honor
that was done him, was but so much torment; wherefore resolving to withdraw
himself, in hope that Amplamira would do the like, as he was about to depart,
he perceived the Knight and the two Giants, of whom we spoke before, to enter
the Hal, who gravely marching along, advanced toward the Emperors throne:
That curiosity, which always accompanies the minds of men, making him stay for
to know who these strangers were, he followed them close, and saw that falling
all three on their knees, the Knight spoke thus.

Great Monarch of Martaria, the reputation you have of being as gracious, and
magnanimous a Prince, as any is in the world, has drawn hither Don Rifantes
the Heir of Cabilla, Brundemor King of Corcutan, and Rozagant King of Alfanar
to obtain two things of your Majesty, the which you may grant with this
assurance, that they shall not be requested of you, but for the good of your
estate, and the glory of your Crown; The first is, that we may be permitted to
maintain both with the Lance and Sword for three days together against all
Comers, that the beauty of these three excellent Princesses your Daughter,
does surpass that of all other Women living; and because the effect of our
valor ought to preceed that of the second, to the end you may willingly accord
unto it; we will forbear to speak of it till such time as you have seen the
power of our Arms.

Brave Prince, said the Emperor, rising out of his Thron to embrace them, the
pains you have taken, so much obliges me, that I gladly condescend to both of
your demands: my Daughters do not deserve that your Swords should be employed
to recommend them in the world; nevertheless, since you will do them so great
an honor, you shall find the Lists ready against you please, and my self
disposed to refuse you nothing which lies in me to grant. This is as much Sir,
said Don Rifantes, as we can desire from you, so that if your Knights have
Mistresses, we shall not want work; departing then, notwithstanding the
Emperors entreaty to have them lodge in the Court, they caused a rich Pavilion
to be set up in the place where Floridan had demeaned himself so valiantly
against Bustrafard, and there attended the coming of some Assaylant.

The Arrogance of these Knights growing odious to all the Courtiers, especially
to our Lovers, who were confident what their second design would be, diverse
Knights went to arm themselves for to combat them, of whom Floridan would have
been the foremost, had not his Lady absolutely commanded him to forbear, until
the Chyrurgions had taken order with his wound.

The place being on an instant covered with a world of people, six Knights
presented themselves, whereof three seeing Don Rifantes, and his companions ready
mounted, set spurs to their horses, but with such misfortune for them, that
they were all three overthrown to the ground, their Adversaries not so much, as
seeming to be any whit moved with so furious an encounter; Their fellows
exceedingly vexed at this accident, put themselves presently in their places,
with some hope to revenge them, howbeit their fortune was nothing better,
receiving such cruel falls, as made all the assistants talk of their enemies
extraordinary force, who returning to their station in a most proud manner,
were persuaded that they had terrified all the Court from attempting them
again; but they were not long in that mind; for Tarsander appeared in the
Lists, accompanied with the the Marquess of Bonport, the Earl of Tranates
Son, the Marquess of Rocque, the Duke of Corzan, the Prince of Balivana, a
young Knight but very valiant, and courageous.

These six Warriors furnished with strong Lances, planted themselves just
against the Giants, who at the sound of the Trumpet dislodged with such fury
against Tarsander, the Marquess of Bonport, and the Prince of Balivana, that
they broke their staves into a thousand shivers, leaving the three Knights so
shaken, that the least touch in the world had infallibly carried them to the
earth; howbeit resetling themselves, they took fresh Lances, and returned
against their enemies, who vexed to see them still in their saddles, incounterd
them so rudely, that they were constrained to fly over the Cruppers of their
horses, to the extreem discontent of the Duke of Corzan, who advancing then
with his companions, received the same disgrace as the former, and that at the
very first course.

These six of the best Knights of the Empire, being so easily vanquished, not a
man more presented himself, so that night approaching, the Emperor was fain to
retire, marvellously commending the valor of these strangers, but particularly
that of Rifantes, who having nothing so great a mass of flesh as the rest, yet
had showed as much force, and more address. All the evening being employed in
this discourse every one withdrew. Floridan into Amplami^a's Cabinet, who
charged him not to combat til the last day, and Corazinda with Palmirenna; that
having caressed one another, with as much demonstration of affection as could
be desired in two Lovers, they fell at length to talk of these Insolents, and
resolved, if their design were to demand them of their Father (as it was to be
presumed) that Amadis should then feign himself to be an Amazon, and should
get the Emperor to give him the order of Knighthood, to the end that seeing
him sight he should have no suspicion of his sex, which being concluded without
any difficulty they slept til morning; when as they were wakened by the sound
of the Trumpet, which led those great Knights into the Lists. Whereupon making
have to be up, they repaired a little after to the windows, and observed that
the strong Knight Lorgades Prince of Grizolia, the Emperors near kinsman, who
arrived but the night before, being accompanied with Rodamans and Arbalion,
Bustrafards brothers, were ready to charge their Lances against the Prince of
Cabilla.

The gallant demeanor of this Knight, and the unmeasurable corpulencie of
Rodamans, and Arbalion, that opposed the two Giants, no less dreadful and
great, persuading them, that the course would be worth their sight, they leaned
together close by the Emperor, where they had not been long, but they saw
those furious Warriors set forth, who meeting in the midst of the course
broke all alike, without so much as once moving in their saddles. Now by my
life, said the Emperor, this is one of the bravest incounters that ever I
beheld, and questionless Lorgades has justly acquired the name of a very good
Knight, since he is able to withstand Rifantes, but let us see what will ensue.

Here with the two Knights having taken fresh Lances spurred away, and
followed by their companions that carried Masts of ships, they broke again with
extreme fury; Lorgades losing his stirrops, was in danger of falling, had he
not caught hold on the Horses mane; Rifantes passed gallantly on, though
somewhat astonished; Arbalion and Rodamans were overturned upon their Horse
cruppers; Brundamor and the King of Alfanar did but how a little with the
violence of the shock; the Assistants remained all amazed with so furious an
encounter, and exceedingly desired, that the insolence of the strangers might
be abated, howbeit in vain; for these three valiant Champions transported with
an excess of rage to find so much resistance before Princesses whom they
adored, dislodged the third time, and encountered their enemies with such
violence, that Lorgades and his friends were laid in the dust, which so filled
the Victors with arrogance, that after two hours rest, no Knight appearing in
that time, they went and presented themselves before the Emperor, where on
their knees again Don Rifantes spoke to him on this manner.

Sir, I think that by this you have good experience of the force of our Arms,
and the greatness of our courages; wherefore we desire you will be pleased to
grant us the boon now, which yesterday you promised us. I have told you, said
the Emperor, that you shall dispose of all that is in my power as I my self, do
but ask, and I will most willingly grant it you. Sir, continued Don Rifantes,
you have then three sons in Law, Palmirenna is for me, Amplamira for the brave
King of Corcutan, and the Infanta Archisidella for the King of Alfanar.

The word of a King, answered the Emperor (a little surprised) ought doubtless
to be irrevocable, but Princes, you must understand, that in matters of such
high importance, I am to take the advice of my people, since all my authority
depends on their good will; besides, I must know whether my Daughters
affections, which cannot be forced without tyranny, may be accommodated to my
commands; I will propound this Affair to my Council, speak particularly with my
Daughters about it, and draw them, if I can, to receive this honor from you,
after you have performed the conditions of the Jousts which you are to maintain
all day to morrow.

Whereupon embracing them (though much against his heart) he withdrew into his
Cabinet to resolve so difficult an Affair, leaving diverse several passions in
the minds of them that remained in the Hall: The Princes of the Empire were
troubled; Palmirenna, and her Sisters were exceedingly displeased, Floridan was
mad with spite, and jealousy, but every one was amazed at the fury of the
fair Slave; who with eyes sparkling fire, addressed her speech unto Rifantes,
and said, Prince of Cabilla, thou think that Palmirenna is already in thy
power, but thou will be deceived, for be assured, that in satisfaction of the
distaste thou have given her, I will draw the blood out of thy body, even to the
last drop; and if I might combat now, as the Women of my country that are bred
up in Arms use to do, I would let thee languish no longer, but to morrow will
come.

Saying so, she depaated in a rage out of the Hall, leaving all there in wonder
at her speech; the Knight and Giants excepted, who laughed her to scorn, and
causing a Nag to be brought her, she rode toward the grot, where she had left
her Sword, being soon got thither, she found not the Arms which she had left,
but others enamelled all over with green and red, so rich and curiously
wrought, that she was much amazed at them, howbeit conceiving that Cassandra
had done this miracle, she would lose no time, making them up then in a bundle
with incredible content, she took her Sword that was fairer then ever it had
been, and remounting on her Horse, she rode to Cardana, where she came in time
to free Palmirenna from a great deal of fear she was in for her.

From whence comes my Corazinda, said she unto her, kissing her on the
forehead? from seeking out means to be revenged of these giants insolence,
answered she, wherefore Madam, look here. Saying so she undid the bundle, and
made them all marvel to see such rich and fair arms. Then you are resolved
Corazenda, to fight, said Palmirenna? But alas, how can you escape the fury of
their swords, which are so dreadful to the valiantest Knights that are. Madam,
answered Corazinda, I am not only resolved to fight, but to dye a thousand
times over, rather then let you fall into the power of a man so unworthy of
your greatness and merit, do but get the Emperor to give me the order, and you
shall see me cut out work enough for your enemies.

Ah Corazinda! said Amplamira, is it possible that being so delicate and fair,
you should have the strength to subdue such mighty men? I cannot but wonder
much at your courage, but withal I do no less pity you. Madam, answered
she, If I dye, it shall be with a great deal of content, since it is in the
service of so high, and excellent Princesses, but these arrogants ^hal pay
dear for their victory, and never do me the honor to love me more, if to
morrow I do not make them change their note; the Knight of the Flowers will
assist me, that is enough, only let us go and rest us a little, that we may
take the Emperor early at his rising in the morning. Herewithall the company
parting, she got to bed with Palmirenna, who mingling tears, with the kisses
that she gave her, testified her fear; but being comforted by her Lover, she
ceased to afflict her self, and slept till day.

CHAP. XI. The horrible Combat between Don Rifantes with his Companions, and
Palmirenna's fair Slave, the Knights of the Flowers, and of the
Flower-de-Luces. The end thereof.
AMadis and Floridans jealousy not permitting them to take much rest, they
arose with the Sun, and being covered with their Arms, wherein Amadis carried
so gallant a presence, that even with the opinion of his Sex, he made all the
Princesses Ladies in love with him; they entered into the Emperors Chamber,
where kneeling down, he said unto him; Mighty Monarch, I doubt not but you
marvel to see me in this equipage, and that at first it seems strange unto
you, to behold a Maiden slave at your feet, to receive that order from your
hands, which makes men Knights, and that gives them power to fight in Arms,
but when you shall be pleased to remember that the earth produces women
courageous, and strong enough to dispute the honor of a Combat with the
valiantest Knight in the world, you will cease to wonder at it, and being moved
with your Daughters tears, who justly fear to fall into the power of these
arrogants, which without any desert will have them whether they will or no, and
in whose company they cannot promise themselves an hour of contentment in
their whole lives, you will make no difficulty to give me this sacred order,
under the favor whereof I hope to set them free.

My dearest Corazinda, said the Emperor, much amazed at her discourse, but
more yet to see her so gallant, in such rich Arms, I believe that you have a
disposition gentle enough to be sensible of the tears which my Daughters shed
not without cause, nor do I doubt but your love does make you despise the
greatest dangers for to set them at rest, but sweetheart, your strength will
not correspond to this height of courage, and of one evil which is not yet
arrived, I should make two inevitable ones, if I should condescend to your
request, in which regard I may not satisfy your desire, for it would grieve me
to see you so cast away. I shall have reason to complain of you then, answered
Corazinda, and be assured Sir, that I will remember this refusal of yours,
which notwithstanding shall be no hinderance to my design, being resolved to
demand that honor of mine enemies, if this valiant Knight of the Flowers, who
is to second me in my enterprise, will not do it for fear of displeasing your
Majesty.

Whereupon arising in choler, she made as though she would be gone, when as the
Emperor constrained by his Daughters entreaties, stayed her by the arm,
saying; Be not angry, Corazinda, for believe me, it was only pity of you, that
restrained me from giving you content; you would be a Knight, why be so in the
name of all my gods, whom I heartily implore, to render you as valorous, as you
are fair. Saying so, he laid his hand upon her head, blessed her after his
manner; put her on a pair of golden spurs, and kissed her on the forehead,
left her to take the rest of her Arms from the hands of his Daughters, who
presently environed her, and were going to lead her to the field in triumph,
when as there was a Knight seen entering into the Hall, armed in azure Arms,
tall of stature, bravely disposed, of a very goodly presence, and mavelous
fair of face; who at the first sight knowing Amadis and his companion, was
about to embrace, and caress them, had not the Prince of Persia stayed him with
a wink of his eye, which made him instantly conceive that he was to forbear;
advancing then in a majesticall manner, he set one knee to the ground before
the Princesses, and addressing his speech to Palmirenna, who went foremost, he
said unto her.

Madam, if strangers may speak without offense, take it not ill, if being
unknown to all here, I dare ask of you, to what Enterprise you conduct these
two Knights, with such a train of Women? We are going to expose them to very
great hazard, answered Palmirenna, and to confrom them with three most
redoubted Knights, to the end they may revenge us of some insolence they have
offered unto us, I will accompany them then, if you please, said the Knight,
that so the party being equal, their danger may be the less; but I would be
glad it might be by the commandment of one of you. Apply your self then to me,
said Archesidella, for these two being my Sisters Knights, it is reason that
now you should be mine, seeing I have no less interest then they in the
quarrel. Madam, answered he, ravished with her beauty, which from henceforth
enthralled his liberty, I expected not so great an honor, but you rendering me
worthy of it, I will endeavor to deserve it as long as I live; whereupon he
took her hand and kissed it, in token of his servitude, and placing himself by
her, he followed the rest to the field, where all the world was in an uproar for
the death of the gentle Knight Lorgades, who desiring to try his fortune again
in other arms then those he wore the day before; was slain by the King of
Alfanar: but the tumult ceased by their arrival, and the grief which the
Emperor conceived, for the loss of so valianta Gentleman, was somewhat
appeased by the sight of his Corazinda, who having very much caressed Lucibel
of France, (being that Knight which so lately arrived, and unto whom she had
also in few words discovered the whole secret of this Affair) mounted upon a
strong and mighty Courser, she went unto the Prince of Cabilla, unto whom she
said.

Don Rifantes, behold I am come hither to make good the menaces which I made
unto thee yesterday, wherefore bethink thee of thy evil life past, and call
upon thy gods. Saying so, she turned about to her companions, who had planted
themselves just opposite to the Giants, and rendering all the world amazed at her
gallant demeanor, she stood still, until such time as the Trumpets made them
dislodge all six with such fury, that the earth seemed to tremble under their
horses feet.

These Knights being of the best on the earth, their encounter was mavelous;
Rifantes made two or three turns with his horse in the dust, the Giants were
carried to the ground, wounded both in their bodies, the Princes of France and
Persia, being unable to support the violence of so terrible a shock fell a
little after, with extreem discontent to be unhorsed before their Mistresses,
Corazinda alone remained in her saddle, to the incredible satisfaction of
Palmirenna, and the Emperor, who being no less joyful, then astonished, did
infinitely commend the valor of this Amazon.

In the mean time our Warriors equally transported with rage rose up, and
drawing out their swords, began one of the most outrageous combats that ever
had been seen in this Empire; the Giants whose motions were exceeding
dreadful, gave most horrible blows, and such as promised nothing less then
death; but our Princes were so active, and dextrous, as they avoided the most
part of them, and warded the rest with such force, that they left no hope of
prevailing to their enemies, who feeling themselves hurt every minute, made such
a terrible noise, as put all the Assistants in a mighty fright. On the other
side, Rifantes and Corazinda (who scorning advantage, had quitted her Horse)
entreated one another far worse, jealousy animated their strokes, and as often
as their swords were aloft, they fell with unexpressable fury, the place was
strewed with their armor, fire flew continually about their heads, they set
their knees and hands to the ground, and the rage wherewithal they assailed
each other, was so great, that the most confident Warriors of the assembly,
were some what touched with fear.

Two hours being spent in this sort, the violence of Brundamors, and Rozaganss
blows, began to relent, contrary to our Knights, whose strength increasing with
their travel rendered their swords more dreadful, which so madded the Giants,
that Rozagant taking his Curtelas in both his hands, discharged it with such
force on Floridan, that having divided his Shield in two, and given him a great
gash in the arm which sustained it; he made him set his knees to the ground,
where questionless his life had been in no little danger had he permitted the
Giant to redouble upon him; but getting up instantly, much ashamed that this
accident was befallen him before Amplamira; he struck the Giant with such
unaccustomed fury on the shoulder, that he cleft him to the very girdle,
sending him stark dead to the earth, to the great astonishment of Brundamor,
who having wounded Lucibel in the thigh and head, courageously disputed the
honor of the combat, when as this Prince extremely vexed, to see his arms dyed
with his blood, lent him so terrible a blow on the arm, that he made it
together with his Sword fly to the ground, and instantly redoubling a furious
thrust, he ran him quite through and through; so making him to breath out his
last.

These Giants being dispatched thus, to the incredible content of the two
Infantaes, who rejoiced to see their Lovers victorious with life and honor;
every one cast their eyes upon the furious combat, between Corazinda and
Rifantes, which was most fearful; for Rifantes mad at the slaughter of his two
Cosins, laid about him so desperately, that a Warrior less strong and
courageous then our Amadis had fallen under his fury, but he no less enraged to
find so much resistance in one man; and in a quarrel where Palmirenna's
happiness, and his own were in question, returned him such an exchange, that
his body was wounded in nine or ten places; howbeit choosing to dye a thousand
times, rather then make the least show of discouragement; he maintained his
party with mavelous valor; and at length being in the supremest degree of
rage he resolved to set up his rest upon one only blow; wherefore taking his
sword in both his hands, he struck Amadis so dangerously on his Shield, that
having parted it in twain, the point thereof light upon his shoulder, and hurt
it, making him withal to stagger in such manner, that he was fain to set one
knee to the ground to save himself from falling; but suddenly arising with
unspeakable fury, and gnashing his teeth for anger, he advanced his rich sword,
and let it descend with such violence on Rifantes Helmet, that if it had not
turned in his hand, he had cleft him down to the teeth; nevertheless the blow
was so rude, that he fell all along quite deprived of sense, and casting out so
great abundance of blood at his eyes, mouth, and ears, as without doubt he had
been quickly dead, had he not been instantly succord. Immortal gods, said the
Emperor, what a blow was this! Thunderbolts fall not with mightier force: Ah
Corazinda, had Heaven made thee a man, thou would have been the prime Knight
of the world.

Saying thus, he abandoned the window to caresse the two Knights, and his
Amazon, who keeling before the Princesses demanded their hands to kiss, but
they beholding them so besmeared with their own blood, abated much of the joy,
which otherwise they would have had for so important a victory, and not willing
to entertain them longer, they sent the Knight of the Flower De-luces, (so was
Lucibel called) into Floridans Chamber, where Amplamira, and Achesidella, who
held herself happy in meeting with our Frenchman, would fain have been present,
for to have taken care of their wounds; but knowing that such liberty was unfit
for them, they left the Physicians to visit them, and followed Corazinda into
Palmirenna's Chamber, who not able to forbear weeping at the sight of the
precious blood, which she saw flow from her hurts, she had been lost with
grief, if the Chyrurgions had not assured her, that there was no cause of fear,
comforting her self then with the hope of her speedy recovery: she caused every
one to void the room, for to leave her to her rest, and passing into her
Fathers Chamber, to discourse with him of the valor of the strange Knights;
and of her fair slave, who had filled every one with admiration at the wonders
she had performed, she learned that Don Rifantes being come again out of his
swound, had caused himself, together with the bodies of the Kings of Alfanar,
and Corcutan, to be carried aboard his Ship, for to return into Cabilla, with
furious resolutions, to be the death of an hundred thousand men, in revenge of
the affront which he had received. Let us give him leisure then to arrive in
his country, to muster up his friends, and subjects, and our Princes time to
recover of their hurts, and entertain themselves with their Mistresses, who
failed not to meet them every day, and let us come to the excellent Knight of
the Roses, whom so long we have left.

CHAP. XII. Rosalmond having quitted the combat with Alcidamant, at
Cassandrae's entreatie: enters into the Duchy of Bonnemar, his adventures
there.
THE combat between Rosalmond, and Alcidamant receiving such an end as was
delivered in the five and thirtieth Chapter of our second part. The
incomparable Knight of the Roses traveled on so vexed to have met with a man
that was able to arrest the fury of his arms, as he was overtaken by the night
before he had so much as thought of the place where he meant to lodge; seeing
it grown dark then, and himself fast by a Shepherds cottage, he resolved to
alight, and stay there till the next morning, as he did, with more rest and
content then he expected: for the Shepherd amidst the services which he did
him, ever and anon told one tale or another, that insensibly he forgot the
occasion of his displeasure; and in that humor casting himself upon a bed, he
slept till such time as the sun being of a good height, raised him to continue
on his journey, wherein he spent six hours, and met not with one living soul
that might inform him of the name of so desert a Country.

At last having discovered a Castle, stately and fair enough to invite him to
observe it nearer, he made to it with a resolution to refresh himself there, if
the Master of it were so courteous as to give him entertainment: Wherefore
knocking at the gate, it was a good while ere any one would speak to him; but
continuing still knocking, he perceived a young Maid, who looking out of the
window, asked him what he would have? Gentlewoman said he, I am a Knight
errant; that not knowing where I am, would willingly learn it of you, let me
therefore obtain of you that the gate may be opened. You may not hope for that,
answered she, for we admit no body here. Truly I shall have great cause then
said he, to publish the discurtesie of the place, however let me know the name
of it. Herewith a very fair Gentlewoman in mourning showed her self at a window
hard by, and said unto him: Sir what is that you would have? Madam, answered
he, I would fain have been let in, to refresh my self a while, but being denied
it, I know not how to desire it of you again. Sir, said she, very modestly, be
not offended at it, for it is not done but upon great occasion; howbeit you
shall enter, your demeanor does forbid me to suspect any harm from you. Saying
so, she caused the gate (which instantly was shut again) to be opened, and
descending into the Court for to receive him with more honor, she showed him
so good a countenance, that he could not forbear saying to her. Madam, to speak
truth I find so much difference between this gracious entertainment, and your
Mayds answer, that it much amazes me. Sir, answered she with tears and sighs, I
have not lived hitherto without knowing what is due to the honor and
assistance of good Knights, nor has this house ever been shut against them;
but the strange misfortune which has befaln me of late, has constrained me to
seem less courteous then I am; I Will tell you the reason in few words.

This miserable beauty whereof you yet behold some relics, maugre the
injuries of time, and the discontents I have undergone, having rendered me the
Sun of this Duchy of Bonnemar, wherein we are adjacent to the great Kingdom
of the Island of Silvana; I saw all the great Lords of the Country sigh at my
feet, and amongst the rest, two cousins of the Prince thereof, the most
disloyoll man that lives: Now the knowledge that I had of the many vices
wherwithall they were infected, no^ permitting me to give them a good look; I
made choice of the Marquess of Valombre, so is this place called; and finding
him courteous, valiant, and handsome, I married him publicly, which begot so
great a despite in the minds of those two cousins, that from thenceforth they
conspired his death, and my undoing: and indeed three years after our marriage
they surprised him in a wood, and taking him without other Arms, then his
sword, they most inhumanely butchered him; wherewithal not contented (alas my
hair stands an end to think of it) they went to Marcandon Duke of Bonnemar, a
man apt to commit any kind of villainy, and persuaded him to take his pleasure
of me, in such sort as he arrived here with the two murderers; where to make
short, they mingled the complaints of seeing my self ravished by them, with the
tears which I shed for the loss of my Husband, whom I had buried that day.
This wretched fact being perpetrated, they made themselves masters of the
house, and keeping me three days together with a dagger at my throat, if I
offered to resist, they glutted their beastly appetites, and leaving me in the
sorrows befitting so mighty an affliction, they went away without any fear of
their resentment unto whom I appertain, that far from seeking any revenge,
durst not so much as receive me into their houses, dreading the fury of this
brutish and tyrannical Duke, who has set such sure Guards on all the
passages, as I should try in vain to escape away unto the Queen of Sylvana, to
avoid his further cruelty; or to seek out some powerful person, that might do
me justice for so odious an insolence; judge now, Sir, whether I had not cause
to lock my self up as I did.

You had indeed, Madam, answered Rosalmond, but I wonder that the people will
endure the tyranny of this barbarous Prince; well, I will see him; and I
promise you by the order which I have received of Knighthood, never to part
from this country, till I have fully revenged you. Oh Sir, said she then, take
heed how you venture upon an enterprise, where the danger is too apparent; for
he himself is very valiant, his Cousins that always accompany him, are strong
and courageous; and he never stirs abroad, but with a great train of soldiers.
All that is nothing, said Rozalmond; God fights still against the wicked, his
death is absolutely resolved; and if you will permit one to conduct me even now
to the place of his abode, you shall soon see his head at your feet, in
satisfaction of this crime. I may not suffer you to part from hence to day,
said she; to morrow do what you please.

Saying so, she led him into a Chamber, to unarm himself, and from thence into
a fair Garden, where having discoursed of the miseries that follow the
licentiousness of a vicious Prince, they went to a table furnished with very
good meat, wherwithall havit, well satisfied their appetite, they heard a great
knocking at the Gate. Ay me, said she with a pale and frighted countenance, the
Murderers of mine honor are come. Yes Madam, said a fellow, that in a mighty
fear came running in, it is the Duke of Bonnemar, and his companions. O Sir,
said she, turning her to our Warrior, have some pity on me. Madam, answered he
with a mervellous confidence, be not dismayed, but think that Heaven has sent
them hither, to receive the punishment their wickedness has deserved, only
give me time to arm my self, and then let the Gates be opened a Gods name; yet
so as presently upon their entrance they may be shut again, that they may not
escape me.

Whereupon going instantly to his Chamber, whilst Artander ran to the Stable, he
put on his arms, and finding his Horse ready he vaulted into the saddle,
commanding the Gates to be opened, where they were still knocking very hard;
which being done, the three cousins entered in great anger, when as Rozalmond
having his sword aloft, discharged it so furiously on Marcandon, (who had been
so well described unto him, as he knew him from the rest) that having cut off
one of his arms, he sent him to the earth under his Horses belly, to the
extreme discontent of his cousins, that giving him two blows at once, the one
upon his Shield, and the other upon his shoulder, made him bow even to the
Horses crupper; whence rising in a rage, he struck him that was next him with
such force, that he divided him in two, wherewith the other was so terrified, as
he turned about to have fled away, but finding the Gates shut he fell to beg
for grace. Villain, said Rozalmond, dare thou speak for mercy in a house that
has no Master by thy treason, and before a woman, whom thou have wickedly
ravished? I should be guilty of the mischiefs thou would do hereafter, if I
should spare thee now, wherefore take this; and so advancing that dreadful
blade, which never found resistance, he cleft him down to the shoulders, and
being yet more unwilling to pardon Marcandon, whom he saw getting up, he went
and tied him to an Horses tail himself, and causing Artander to mount upon him,
he made him to be dragged up and down the Court so long, till his brains flying
out, his soul was sent to Hell.

Having taken this so horrible a revenge, Rozalmond commanded the Dukes Squire
to be locked up till the next day, and returning into the Hal the Lady
Marquess with tears of joy fell down and embraced his knees, unable to speak a
word; whereat being ashamed he raised her up, and desired her not to use such
submissions unto him. I have done nothing, said he, but what I was obliged unto
by the order of Knighthood, which was given me upon condition to employ my arms
for the service of such as were oppressed, and particularly for Ladies,
wherefore you are no way bound unto me; so unarming himself he talked with her
about advertising her friends of what had past, and then got him to bed with a
resolution to depart the next morning very early, as he did to the exceeding
grief of the Lady Marquess, who would fain have stayed him longer.

Taking the next way then that he met withal, and entertaining himself with
the remembrance of the valiant Knight of the Palms, whom he so mortally hated,
and of his Armazia, whose absence was very grievous unto him, he arrived about
evening at a Town, where finding it fit to lodge that night, he was entertained
by a rich fellow, that having no other children, but one daughter, a very
handsome Maid, endeavored to make him the best cheer he could, but without
doubt it had been the last lodging that ever he would have had, if Love that
reserved him for the contentment of his Lady, had not rendered his Hosts
Daughter passionatly in love with him.

This Town being under the obedience of Marcandon, the inhabitants were
immediately advertised of his death, and understanding that the Knight, which
was lately come thither, was the man that had slain him; they assembled
together in an instant, and arming themselves with Halberds, Pitchforks,
Swords, and Iavelings, they resolved to kill Rozalmond; but considering with
themselves that they should not be able to resist him, if once he set hand to
his sword, they concluded to surprise him in bed, and unarmed; whereupon they
sent one to the Masters of the house where he lay to advertise him of their
enterprise, that he might contribute thereunto on his part, and in the mean time
fearing some resistance, they dispatched one in post to a Garrison, thereby to
acquaint them also with it.

The man, that questionless was sorry for his Princes death, though his vices
rendered him odious to all good folks; and that on the other side was very
unwilling to betray his Guest, which had trusted him, was much distracted with
this message; nevertheless fearing lest the people would kill him, if he
should not show himself zealous to revenge their Lord, he received one of them
into his house, and because Rozalmond was in his Chamber, ready to go to bed,
he thought it the best course his Daughter should go up, and under color of
seeing whether he wanted any thing, that she should steal away his Sword; but
she, that to dye would not see him harmed, being come into his Chamber, she
told him in few words, how much she loved him, and the danger he was in.

Rozalmond exceedingly surprised with her relation, answered her briefly thus;
Sweet heart, your love does infinitely oblige me, and it shall assuredly be
recompensed as it ought, in the mean time wear this for my sake; saying so, he
drew a rich Diamond from off his finger, and presented it unto her, and forth
with arming himself, he sent her down furnished with an excuse. Alack, said
she, seeming to be vexed; you will not do what you desire without difficulty;
the Knight is indeed on his bed, but he has neither quit his Arms, nor his
Sword, which he holds in his hand, so that I have lost my labor. What shall we
do then, said the Master of the house, to him that accompanied him? why burn
him in his chamber, answered he, if we cannot surprise him. Will you so (said
Rosalmond, who was stolen down upon them) I Will take an order with you presently;
whereupon he lift up his Sword, thinking to strike the slave; but he that had
no mind to endure the blows, fled suddenly out of doors with the good man of
the house and gave the alarm unto his companions; they running to the cry that
he made, fell instantly to charging of Rozalmond, who put fourteen, or fifteen
of them to the sword, whilst Artander was sadling his Horses, upon which in
despite of this rabble, they mounted very seasonably; for at that instant two
hundred Knights arrived from the Garrison, which with a terrible noise assailed
him furiously on all sides, but this Warrior that was always most confident
in danger, flying in amidst these troops, began to make so great a slaughter
that all the streets ran with blood; he cut off arms and heads, cleftmen down
to the girdle, and quartered them in such sort, as the valiantest of the
company wished themselves within their Walls again; nevertheless being ashamed,
that one man alone should disorder them in that fashion, they speedily rallyed
themselves, and laid so many blows on him at once, that he had much ado to
sustain them; at length they killed his horse under him, but he was not long
on foot, for making a rampart of the dead bodies, under the favor whereof, he
retired always fighting to his Squire, who was got aside from the press, and
leaping on his horse he charged his Adversaries afresh with such fury, that he
laid threescore at his feet, some cut off by the middle, others cleft down to
the teeth, and the most of them opened even to the very wast, which put the
rest in such a fear, that they took the benefit of the darkness of the night to
escape away; Our Warrior then finding no more resistance, and seeing Artander
well mounted upon one of the slain Knights horses, he took the contrary way to
that where his enemies were gone, and rode till it was day, that he discovered
the Sea.

CHAP. XIII. Rozalmond arriving in the Island, of Silvana, defeats the Guards
which the Queen had established to arrest Alcidamant; his meeting afterward
with Merodiana, and departure from her.
OUr Knight finding a Ship ready according to his wish, embarked himself
therein, never regarding for what place she was bound; and being wholly taken
up with the thought of his dearest Armazia, he was carried along for two days
together with a prosperous gale, but the Sea (that seldom continues long in
one state) began to swell, and rage, in such sort, that the distraction, and
noise of the Mariners, which labored in vain, made him quickly get up to
assist them, howbeit the fury of the waves being extreme, his force that could
do much in Combats availed him naught, for the Vessel beaten on all sides,
sometimes carried up as high as the clouds, and by and by thrown down to the
Center of the deeps, no longer received direction from the guiding hand of the
Pilote, and having all her sails, and tackle torn, expected nothing but some
violent gust to sink her utterly.

Floting three days in this desperate manner, every one shut his eyes, that he
might not behold this horrible death, when as heaven giving care to the prayers
of the Parthian Prince, who during all this danger never changed countenance,
calmed the waves, and drove the Ship into a Port of the Island of Silvana,
where he caused himself to be set ashore, giving praise unto God in his heart
for his goodness in drawing him out of the danger of so dreadful a tempest.

Getting to his Horse then armed at all points, he rode into the Country,
which seemed very pleasing and delightful unto him, and traveled till two of
the clock in the afternoon, when as he met with a house very stately built,
whereinto entering to refresh himself, he perceived the gates to be suddenly
shut upon his back, and thirty Knights making head against him, whereof one
advancing before the rest, said unto him; Knight, we are here to make you to
render your Sword, or to oblige your self willingly to accomplish whatsoever
the Queen of Silvana shall command you. Good Knights, answered Rozalmond, will
never be enforced to promise any thing, much less be disarmed by their enemies
without fighting, wherefore I am not resolved to give you any thing that
appertains unto me, till you have dearly bought it. We must have your head
then, replied the Knight, wherewith drawing out all their swords, they fell upon
Rozalmond, who little moved at it, flew in amongst them, and with the very
