first stroke sent him dead to the ground, that had menaced him, to the
exceeding grief of the rest, who thinking to defeat him easily, pressed him in
such sort, as he knew not well where to bestow his blows, nevertheless
cutting off now an arm, and then an head, he had soon laid a dozen of them at
his feet, and was ready to deal so with the rest, when as two dreadful Giants
appeared in the Court, who making a little stand to observe this Warriors
confident fight, were amazed to behold two men with two strokes, extended on
the earth, the one cloven down to the girdle, and another brayned with the flat
of his Sword.

These horrible blows making them think, that at length their Knights would
have the worst, they presently set forwards, and advancing their heavy
Scimitars, they discharged them so dangerously on him, that they forced him to
knock his chin against the pommell of his saddle, which so incensed him, that
raising himself up in rage, he took his Sword in both his hands, and therewith
struck one of the Giants with such violence on his shield, as he divided it in
two, sending his arm withal to the ground, and redoubling on the secoed, who
with reason feared the tempest of that Sword, hit him so rudely on the helmet,
that he made him reele three or four paces back; whereupon perceiving the
Knights had run his Horse into the belly with an Halbard, he quit his saddle
instantly, and flying in amongst them, covered the ground with three or four
of them, before the Giants were come to themselves again, both of them
returning then with incredible fury, they began to charge him with such
terrible blows, as he was many times constrained to bow with his knees,
nevertheless he fought so courageously, and so often drew blood from them, that
they had little cause to brag of any advantage; but being resolved either to
vanquish or dye, one of them took his Scimitar in both hands, and displaying
all his force, struck so mainly at his head, that if he had not wisely avoided
the blow, it had questionless been his death, howbeit leaping very lightly
aside, he let it fall upon the ground, whereinto it entered up to the hilts, and
taking hold of opportunity, whilst the Giant was drawing it out again, he
discharged his Sword so dangerously on his Casque, that he cleft him to the
brains, overthrowing him with a noise like to that of a Tower whose foundation
say^es; the other which had but one arm, and very little blood left, thinking
that his companion had been stricken with lightning, would fain have saved
himself by flight, but he was so weak, that at the very first step he fell down,
breathing out his last.

Our Warrior seeing himself freed from these Colosses which had exceedingly
troubled him, was going to set upon the rest, when as he perceived a Lady
coming in, mavelous beautiful, and followed by two and twenty Knights
richly armed, with a Giant far greater than the former, who addressing her
speech unto him, said; Knight, persist no further in this Combat, but put
yourself into my hands, if you love your life. I know very well, that your
valor makes you confident; for the slaughter I behold here may persuade you,
that you can courageously pass through any danger whatsoever, but I am able to
oppress you so with multitudes, that you must needs fall at last; besides, the
Guards of this place were not established here for you, but to surprise a
Knight, who though he be not so tall, yet is no way inferior to you in valor
and strength; sheath up you Sword then, and follow me with this assurance, that
you shall receive no displeasure here.

Madam, answered he, much amazed to behold so rare a beauty; I will gladly
submit my self to your power, for so sweet a captivity can not be but most
pleasing to me; and would I had spent more blood then this which is in my
Armor, that I had met you at the gate of your house, neither should I then
have been in the state I am in, nor you have had cause to complain for the loss
of your people, for yielding all obedience to the merit of fair Ladies, and
principally of those of your quality, I should freely have granted whatsoever
you had demanded; but their insolence having constrained me to draw my Sword, I
secured my self by their deaths, wherwithall I am now infinitely displeased,
because it may be an offense unto you, which I shall labor to repayr by all
the best services my uttermost ability may be able to do you.

I perceive, said she, laughing, that I shall have as much ado to overcome you
with courtesy, as my Knights have had with their Arms, wherefore I will debate
no longer with you, but let us walk to a Chamber, that your wounds may be
visited. I think they are so slight, Madam, answered he, that they need no
great looking to, howsoever your commandment shall wholly dispose of me.
Whereupon causing his Squire to unarme him, he discovered a small hurt on his
shoulder, and another somewhat greater, but one more dangerous in his thigh,
which the Chirurgions having dressed, he got him to bed, where he continued till
the next morning; when as he arose, feeling little or no pain, for to present
his service to the fair Princess, who being wonderfully well satisfied with his
goodly personage and behavior, entertained him awhile with ordinary
discourse; and finding him no less witty, then he had showed himself before
valiant, she led him into the Garden, where she freely discovered to him the
secretest of her thoughts, telling him that she was Queen of the Island of
Silvana, and that the Guards of this place were set to apprehend a Knight that
carried three Palms in his shield.

Truly, Madam, said Rozalmond then, I do not marvel now at your assembling of
so many Knights, and strong Giants, since it was to arrest a man, whose like is
hardly to be met withal in the world: why, replied the beautiful Silvana, Do
you know the Knight of whom I speak: Madam, answered Rozalmond, I neither know
his name, nor original, but all the earth is acquainted with his valor; and
would to God he were here now, that we might finish a Combat, which has twice
already reduced us to the extremest peril of our lives, without discerning to
whom the honor of it was justly due: whereupon relating all that had past at
Constantinople, and afterward upon the confines of Florertan; he gave her
mavelous contentment, to hear the praises of this Knight so published by his
greatest enemy. Verily, answered she, you have a great deal of reason to speak
well of this Knight, who has done miracles in this Kingdom, Combatting, and
killing a Monster, the hugest and most formidable, that ever nature produced,
but far more in my sister Merodiana's state, where the most redoubted Giants of
the world, have past under the edge of his Sword in the head of a mighty Army,
which the same day was cut in pieces by the sole virtue of this Knight, and not
by the multitude, or force of our soldiers, the Enemy being at the least
three for one.

But, Madam, (said Rozalmond, who was somewhat vexed, to hear so much glory
given to his Adversary:) if this Knight has done so much for you, why will you
expose his life to the hazard of the fury, and multitude of your men, which
sure were but an ill acknowledgement of his services. O that is a secret, said
she, which may not be imparted, I will have have him if I can, not to put him to
death, for I would sooner consent to mine own ruin, but to oblige him to keep
his faith. Your eyes, Madam, said Rozalmond (who then ghest at her disease) will
more prevail with him then your Arms, and he will sooner be constrained by your
beauty, then by your Giants; in which regard you are to procure rather by
gentleness then force. That course have I held already, said Silva^a; but,
alas! to no purpose, another has captived his heart, so that I am out of hope,
unless some disdain from his Mistress, shall make him think of me: Verily, said
Rozalmond, I hold him as ungrateful, as valiant, since he has broken his word
with you; and be assured Madam, that I will fight with him again upon this
quarrel, whenever I can meet with him; and if fortune favor me, I will bring
him back to you. Your good will does much oblige me, answered she; but if you
desire to do me a pleasure, forbear the execution of your intent, for the
Combat between you, could not be determined without an irreparable loss;
wherefore if you have any compassion of my suffering, rather counsel him to
remember his vows, the favor which he has received from me, and making him
sorry for abusing them, represent unto him, that my Crown, one of the richest,
and bravest of the earth, may arrest the ambition of any Gentleman, how great
soever he be.

This speech was finished with tears, but being comforted by Rozalmond; who
promised to use his best art, and all the arguments he could think upon, to
give her desire content; she dried her eyes, and returning into the Hall, she
sat down to dinner with him, entreating him a little after to make some abode
in her country, whereunto he having willingly assented, she carried him the
next day to the Capital City of her Kingdom, where she did him all the honor
she could possibly devise; sometimes entertaining him with Masks and Shows,
and at other times with Iousts and Tournaments, wherein he so behaved himself,
that Merodiana being advertised thereof, requested him to come and see her.

Leaving Silvana then in much grief for his departure, he went unto her
sister, who insensibly forgetting Alcidamant, was so taken with the beauty and
comeliness of this Prince, that she took no greater care, then to render her
self more amiable with the grace of clothes, and dressings (though nature had
made her excellent that way) for to win him to love her; but he that had a
constant soul, and that was wholly given up to his Armazia, was nothing moved
with her passion; howbeit fearing lest his faith at length might waver by the
continual pursuits of this beautiful Queen, who questionless had charms of
power to captivate the heart of the coldest affection, he resolved to depart;
wherefore one day taking his leave, which he had very much ado to obtain, he
got him to Sea, leaving so good an opinion of his valor in the Kingdoms of
these two sisters, as he was of no less esteem there, then the famous Knight of
the Palms.

CHAP. XIV. Rozalmond landing in the Kingdom of Clariana, arrives by fortune at
Alcidamants Great, he laments over his arms believing him dead, and afterward
incountring him they become friends.
Rozalmond having wisely avoided the danger of Merodiana's allurements rode all
the day with a resolution to travel into Gardacia, for to know whether time
had defaced him out of Armazia's affection; but fortune that meant otherways to
dispose of his actions, deferred the effect of this his intent, and caused him
to make another voyage more profitable, and necessary for the good of
Christendom: Being imbarqued then in a Ship; the wind which should have carried
him one way, drove him quite contrary another, and brought him upon the coast
of the Kingdom of Clariana, where the Pilot for fear of a threatened Tempest,
making some stay, he would needs go on shore to see the country, and
accordingly, getting on his Horse he spent two days, without meeting of any
adventure, whereupon purposing to return to the sea, he discovered a Brook,
whose sweet murmr invited him to alight under certain trees, that grew all
along the banks thereof, and cast a very pleasing shadow, causing his Horse then
to be tied, so as he might have the liberty to graze, he walked so long up
against the course of the stream, that he found himself at the bottom of a
Rock, whereinto there was a pretty large entrance, which gave him a desire to
approach it, for to see whether there were any thing within it, worthy the
employment of his courage: but he was marvellously abashed, to behold a little
Cross set up a good height under a tree; for considering that this mark made
glorious by the death of the Savior of the world, was not so much as known
amongst these idolatrous people, he was no less amazed thereat, then at some
prodigy; howbeit finding some consolation in the hope he had to meet with
Christians there; he was passing in, when as a new occasion of astonishment
arrested him; for at the foot of a tree he discovered a Cuirace, an Helmet, a
Shield, and other the arms appertaining to a Knight.

This Encounter possessing him with no less curiosity, then the former had
done with wonder, he went presently and looking upon the Shield, which was
almost covered over with rust, he perceived it to be that famous Ensign of the
three Palms, made glorious by the honor of a thousand combats, most
generously performed by Alcidamant; and assured himself that these were the
arms, which he had found invincible through the courage of his enemy. Virtue
that can do all in all with a noble spirit, having changed this Warriors mind
in a moment, he could not forbear shedding of tears, at the sight of so sad a
spectacle. Ay me, said he, kissing those Arms, with a great deal of
reverence, how do I find you in a state most unworthy of your greatness; why
do you no longer cover the body of that valiant Knight, which so much honored
you? You were odious to me always heretofore; but now, alas, I pity you as
much as I have formerly hated you, and as the world suffers a most irreparable
loss in you, so shall I grive eternally, that you should remain thus of no use
hereafter.

Whereupon laying all the pieces one upon another, he took that excellent Sword,
which was gotten at the Castle of Serpents, and that had shed many drops of his
blood, and having hung it on the bough of a tree, he forth with passed into the
Grot, in the midst whereof he incountred a bank of green turfs, raised in form
of an Altar, upon the which he beheld the portraiture of a Lady so exquisitely
fair, that he esteemed her no way inferior to Armazia for perfection; he
continued a good while observing her by the assistance of a Lamp that was
burning there, but desiring nothing more, then to meet with one that might tell
him some news of this Knight, whose death he greatly feared, he went on and
visited every corner of the Grot, where finding nothing but a bed of leaves, he
returned forth incontinently, and was going to fetch a walk under certain
trees, when as he espied a young Hermit in a long Gown of gray, that was laid
upon the grass as it seemed to take some rest; howbeit his grief not
permitting him to be silent, he brake out thus.

Who shall hereaf^er rely upon any thing in this world, since I, that had but
one poor minute to pass for to see my self Master of a felicity that is not to
be imagined, was so suddenly cast into the extremest of misery? and who is he
that at any time shall be in pleasure, that can promise to himself never to
taste of the pain which shall follow it, if I am now reduced to utter despair,
that had in my hand what might have satisfied the ambition of the most aspiring
Spirit? Verily, man has nothing less assured, then that which he thinks is in
his power; and when fortune smiles upon him, it is then when she means to undo^
him. But alas! from whence proceeds my misfortune, excellent Princess, it is
from you, that once was the object of all my desires as now you are the subject
of all my sufferings? yes certainly, if I would accuse you of weakness, and
say that you ought not to have condemned me without hearing (...) first, since
th^^ grace is not (...) the greatest off^nder that is: And yet not so if I
consider, that you might dispose of my will with more powerthen my self, I am
now faulty only inappearance, but I should be so indeed by complaining, the
respect which I owe to your greatness, not permitting me to (...) against you,
(...) offending you, wherefore you have not done (...) to (...) me from your
presence, since I have not merited the grace to enjoy that happiness. Shall I
lay the fault then on my destiny, or rather on (...)'s passion, who thinking to
oblige me has undone me? Ah beauteous Queen, how dearly do I buy the favors
which you have done me. I will remember your kisses, but it is with extreme
grief, for that I have lost ^ar sweeter by your means: Why were you not less
loving, or more contained, so should not the world have taken notice of your
want of government, neither should I have now seen my self thus languishing in
this desert place, nor lamented my cruel and untimely end; howbeit I accuse
you unjustly, it was no malice in you, but chance, and without condemning my
self, I cannot say that your love is the cause of my misery, since I sought it
with so much care; live then exempted from the reproach of my death, before
which, if yet I may be permitted to desire any thing, fairest Princess of
Tramazond, know that I have suffered most innocently, and that I dye without
grief, seeing it is to do you service, and by your commandment.

Herewith holding his peace, he turned him about toward Rozalm^nd, who being
come very near him; and that was not desirous to appear so soon, retired a
little to observe his face, which seemed to have been fair, but then so pa^e
and wan, that it made him shed some tears again to behold so great a Knight
reduced to so pitiful an estate; howbeit not able to let him be any longer in
pain, he approached for to comfort him, when as Alcidamant making two or three
turns upon the grass, thorough the violence of his grief rested close at his
feet: making use then of this occasion, that sorted according to his desire, he
took him by the arm for to raise him, but he that felt himself touched,
incontinently start up, and stepping two or three paces back, observed him a
good while without speaking a word, at length seeing him of so goodly a
presence, and covered with such fair arms, he came toward him, and showing a
great deal less fear, then at the first, he said.

Verily the sight of you did much amaze me, for this being a desert place, and
having never seen any person here, but a poor Shepherd, that every week brings
me a little bread to sustain me withal, and some oil for the entertainment of
a Lamp, which incessantly burns in a Grot hereby, whereinto I retire my self a
nights, I little expected the arrival of so accomplished a Knight as your
self; but you are very welcome to those poor provisions I have, only if it may
not be importunate to demand it, you might do me a singular favor to let me
know, who you are.

Noble Sir, answered Rozalm^nd, your encounter gives me no less contentment,
then you seem to have in mine; I am a Knight errant, that knowing you better
then you think for, and that but to day very much loving you, takes the liberty
to tell you, that you greatly wrong the world to deprive it of you, for the
satisfaction of a fickle and ungrateful woman, who wanting judgment to make
esteem of you according to your merit, does not ^^ compense your services as
(...) ought, the life you lead is unworthy of that courage, which you have so
often showed in the extrea^est dangers; change it S^^, I beseech you and
consider that in the case you are, you can hope for nothing, here you languish,
here you will dye, your Mistress she knows it not, or if she do she laughs at
is, from which neglect draw so strong a resolution as to despise her, onto
render you more happy by the knowledge of the alteration of her mind* it may be
she is as much troubled as you, inform your self, and leaving to play the woman
any longer return into the way which leads men to glory.

All this cannot move me, said Alcidamant, for you know not the respect a Lover
ought to carry to the commandments of his Lady or else you would not condemn
me for that I do, which is nothing but what her pleasure and my obedience
require. It is true that in all likelihood I should be better in the world,
where I might be useful for the assistance of some afflicted persons; but
shall I do so when it is not pleasing to her, whom I will prefer before all
that is under heaven. No verily, I must absolutely comform my self to her will,
she desires my death, and I will not avoid the occasions of it: As for that you
allege, how it may be she repents the miseries she has made me to suffer, I
can never believe it, for then she would have let me understood so much.

Does she know said Rozalmond interrupting him there, that your despair has
reduced you to this desert? without doubt she does not know it, answered he,
but my good genius would lead them hither that should come to seek me, if she
had any mind to see me again. Look now said Rozalmond, how extravagantly you
speak, and how your judgment is lost in the confusion of your thoughts, or with
the affliction that oppresses you, what likelihood is there that one may find
you out in this place, whither fortune alone can address those that stray out
of their way?

Be not, I pray you, so wilfully bent to end your days wretchedly here, rather
live for the service of your Princess, and labor to make your innocence
appear unto her, in stead of bestowing your time unprofitably in sighing out
your sorrows amidst these trees; your virtue which to day has begot a desire
in me to do you service, contrary to the resolution which formerly I had taken
for to purchase your ruin, makes me to use these words, therefore be pleased
that I may be your Physician since you are so sick, and accept of the good
counsel I give you for your better remedy.

Why now, we are come just to the point I desired, said Alcidamant, for setting
aside the reasons, I could oppose yours with, touching my purpose to dye here,
clear me in that particular, where you say you never loved me till to day. I
believe indeed, said Rozalmond, that you do not know me yet, because I want my
Shield; but if you call to mind the combat we had together at Constantinople,
and afterward upon the frontiers of Florertan, when we were parted by
Cassandra, you will quickly understand the meaning of the speeches I have used
to you; then you were the object of all the anger that a man could have against
another which disputed the glory of Arms with him, but finding you in so
miserable an estate, I was so sensible of your misfortunes, as I could not be
more for any that should arrive unto my self, so that now I love you far more
then I hated you before, and do also humbly beseech you to change your mind in
like manner, and to esteem of me no less, then of the faithfullest servant you
can have.

O me, said Alcidamant, what a happiness is this in the midst of my
unhappiness, to have my pains thus aslayed by the presence of the excellentest
Knight of the earth; Ah Sir! I will no longer complain of my misfortune, and
the content of this encounter is so dear unto me, that I will pass by all
remembrance of the cause of my sorrow for to caress you, if not as much as I
would, yet as much as I can. Herewith embracing one another with a great deal
of affection, they contrac^ed a friendship, which never ended, but with their
lives, and some other (...) having past betwixt them, they both returned into
the Grot, where Rozalmond desiring to speak of the cause of ^is retyrement, for
to withdraw him from it, demanded of him whether that which he saw there was
the picture of that rigorous beauty for whom he suffered so.

You behold indeed, answered he, the pleasing features of her face, you may
here likewise judge of the delicacie of her complexion; but not of the grace she
gives to her motions, nor of the powerful charms of her eyes, for there nature
far surpasses the art of the Painter. Whereupon without further entreaty he
discoursed unto him his whole life, and especially all that had past at
Tarsipolis, after he met with Trasiclea, which was very acceptable to the
Knight of the Roses, who alleged all the reasons he could any way devise to
diswade him from so sad a retyrement; but perceiving that he spa^e to no
purpose, and that his resolution was as firm as the rock wherein he lived, he
bethought him of another course to be held with him.

You are too wilfully set, said he, upon your own misery; nevertheless, being
persuaded that you do all things with judgment, I intend, because I will enjoy
your company, which I hold so dear, to pass my days here with you, and never
to return again into the world, after I have dispatched one voyage for an
enterprise, whereunto my faith has engaged me; I may not limit my return, in
regard we cannot dispose of time, nor of accidents that befall us, but I swear
unto you by the order of Knighthood, to come hither again, as soon as possibly I
can, so as you likewise promise me, not to depart from hence upon any occasion
whatsoever.

Dear Sir, said Alcidamant, it were most unreasonable to confine you so without
cause, continue still in the world, whereof you are now the wonder, for it would
be far more content unto me, to know you in delights absented from me, then to
have you here lead a languishing life; as for me, I am accustomed thereunto,
and be assured I will never abandon it for any cause whatsoever, since I do it
not at your request. This is as much as I desire, said Rozalmond, you shall see
me again sooner then you are aware, to which end I will be gone to morrow by
break of day, that I may give the speedier dispatch to the business I have
undertaken. So calling Artander, who was all this while with the horses; they
sat them down to supper with no other delicasies then a little bread, and
afterward laid them to rest upon a few leaves, where they remained til the next
morning, when taking their leaves of one another with tears, Rozalmond rode
away toward Tarsipolis, from whence how he was diverted, shall be related
hereafter.

CHAP. XV. The Adventures of Rozanel, and Florisbel, after their departure out
of Tramazond.
ROzanel departing from Tramaxond with Florisbel, and the beautiful Angeles of
Sopradisa, sailed fifteen days with all the content that a Lover could have in
the company of his Lady, not meeting any adventure worthy of his courage, but
on the sixteenth day they discovered two Ships fast grapled together, in one of
the which was a Giant with some thirty, or forty soldiers, and in the other
one Knight alone, of a reasonable big statu^e, who with his Sword in his hand,
defending the entrance into his Vessel, sometimes charged the Giant, and
sometimes the Soldiers, whereof ever and anon he overthrew one or other of them
into the Sea; the valor of this Knight giving them great satisfaction, and
being moved with a Gentlewoman that called upon the Gods for succor, they
joined the force of their Oars to the wind, and in a little time caused their
Barque to board the Knights, whereinto entering with fury, they presently
dispatched seven or eight of the most confident of the troup; and in regard the
Knight had received three or four deep wounds, from whence he had lost much
blood; Florisbel desired him to retire, and leave him to combat the Giant,
whilst his companion dealt with the rest of that ^^bble, but his heart was so
good, that he made no other answer, but gave his enemy two such cruel blows,
as with the one he wounded him very dangerously in one of his thighs, and with
the other made a great gash in his shield arm, which Florisbel observing, and
unwilling to stand idle, he drew to his friend, who never let fall his Sword
without killing a man, and making no less havoc, in a short time laid all that
remained at his feet: mean while the Combat between the Giant and the Knight
continued with mavelous rage, howbeit with so much advantage on the Knights
part, that they looked every minute to see that Colossus tumble into the water,
when as Rozanel casting his eye aside, espied a Knight, very little less then
the Giant, rush out of the Hold; who leaping into the Barque where Angelea was,
cut the Cables that fastened ^it to the other Vessels, and was putting to Sea
with so rich a prize, had not he suddenly advanced, skipping in then almost
as soon as he, and carried with extreme cholor, he gave him so strong a blow
upon his Helmet, that he made him set both his knees to the Deck, where he
stayed not long, for rising full of rage, he began to charge Rozanel in such
sort, that he was somewhat amazed arit; nevertheless seeing himself before his
Mistress, whose safety was in question, he became so furious, and so well
employed his force, that with three blows he first sent one of his arms into
the Sea, and then laid his head at his feet, to the unspeakable contentment of
the fairest. Angelea, who coming to caress him, asked him whether he were not
hurt? Madam, said he, kissing her hand, I feel no wound, but that which I have
in my heart; I am very glad of it, answered she, for as for that, I will ere it
be long give it such a remedy, as you shall have no cause to complain.

This short amorus passage rejoicing Rozanel not a little, he would have
returned to the other Ships, but a violent wind suddenly arising carried him
away, do what the Mariners could, to his infinite grief, for leaving his
friend so in the Giants ship, who unable to support his Adversaries strokes,
fell at length under the tempest of one of them, which divided his head in
twain; wherwithall Florisbel had been exceedingly satisfied, but for his
separation from his friend, nevertheless holding it vain to afflict himself for
that could not be helped; he turned him to the Knight to applaud him for a
victory, so gloriously obtained; but the stranger beholding him without his
Helmet, went to him with open arms, and embracing him, said; My noble friend,
how happy am I in this encounter? and indeed from whom could I hope for
succor, but from you? make me partaker, I beseech you, of your Adventures; and
tell me by what means you came so oportunly to deliver me out of the hands of
mine enemies.

Verily, said Florisbel, who then knew him to be Sestilian the Prince of Spain;
I am no less amazed at my meeting with you, then you are at my arrival here; I
complained of fortunes cruelty, for the loss of Rozanels company, whom the
winds have carried away, but now she has fully made me amends with your
presence; come let us go in and visit your wounds, we will talk at leisure
afterward of our fortune; whereupon entering into a Cabin, Sestilian got him to
bed, where the Gentlewoman of whom we spoke before, being very skilful in
Chyrurgerie, dressed his wounds, promising to render him well in fifteen days
at the most, to which end she advised him to betake him to his rest, but he
would by no means hear speak of sleeping till Florisbell had related the
enchantment of Angelea, the manner how he himself was put into the Rock, and
their deliverance effected by the valiant Knight of the Palms, and the
Princess of Tramazond, which very much satisfied this young Prince, who for his
part likewise discovered unto him, all that had befaln him since his departure
from Constantinople; Entertaining themselves in this sort, they passed away
certain days with great content; during which time, Rozanel and his Angelea
sailed with a prosperous wind, and at the end of two and twenty days, arrived
at a Port of great Britain, to the incredible joy of his beautiful Mistress,
who being set on shore, and meeting with an ancient Knight, she desired him to
inform her how the world went at Court.

Madam, answered he, all things go well there, and since the decease of our
great King, we have not seen such magnificences, as are now preparing at
Windsor, for the Celebration of the Nuptials of Tristor the young Prince of
Sobradiza, who within this four days is to be married to the fair Amazon,
Alteria the Queen of California's Daughter, there will be gallant Jousts, the
Tournament will be no less delightful, the rather in regard of the arrival of
diverse young Princes, which have met here by chance, and whom Garmant the
Viceroy of this Country labors to honor as much as he may, this, Madam, is
all the news I can deliver. It is more then I expected, answered she, having
given him many thanks, and so going to Rozanel, she acquainted him therewith,
and to testify the truth of her affection, she counseled him to post away to
Windsor, that they might be there before her Brothers Marriage, and take one and
the same day to render their desires contented, getting instantly to horse
then, they used such diligence, that the next morning they arryved at the
Court, where Garmant, Don Sinald^, Tristor, Alteria, and all the Lords which
were then present, received them with as much honor, as if they had been the
Sovereigns of this flourishing Kingdom.

Sometime being spent in complements, in the recital of the enchantments of
Angelea, and of that which past about her deliverance; Rozanel that dyed with
the impatience of his sufferings, in few words discovered unto Tristor the love
he bore his Sister, and desiring him to consider by himself how dear time was
to Lovers, he besought him, that the same day which he had designed, for his,
might make up their happiness, whereunto Tristor gave so good an ear, that he
went presently, and imparted it to Garmant.

This affair then being easily resolved upon, they were led all four the next
morning to Church, so richly attyred, that their beauty struck every one with
wonder, especially that of Angelea, on whom the eyes of all the world were
fastened. The Ceremonies being finished, and dinner done, all the Knights of the
Court went and armed themselves for to Joust with Quedragant, Agrian King of
Scotland, and the gentle Abies of Ireland, who meeting together in great
Britain, desired to come unknown to the Court for to honor the Marriage of
their friends. Let us pass by this Solemnity till we have seen Clarisel of
Guindaya, and his fair Shepheardess.

CHAP. XVI. Clarisel of Guindaya, and his fair Shepheardess, having given an
end to the adventure of the Torments of Cardoran and Lindorenna, depart from
Bellombre at their request.
CLarisel, and his fair Shepheardess living with incredible satisfaction, and
having nothing else to complain of, but the aversness of Fortune in advancing
their delights, continually gave one another new assurances of their loves, and
so passing away their time happily, they met ordinarily at the Rivers side,
whose waters served them for a glass, when their fair eyes did them not that
office, sometimes under the Sallows that bordered the Meadows, and often
retyring into the Wood, to sigh out their passions, they engraved upon the
barks of the Trees so many enterlaced characters, as they gave every one
occasion to wonder at such marks, of so sweet, and unparalelled an affection,
the same whereof running all over France drew so many Ladys and Knights to
Bellombre, that every house there, was full of strangers, which were stricken
with no less marvel then coment, at the incomparable perfections of these two
persons.

These Lovers then having one day driven their stocks into the great and long
walks, that separated the Wood of fur trees, Clarisel sighing at the feet of
his delicate Shepherdess, was about to represent his marryrdome unto her, when
as they espied a Damosel, coming before a Litter which was followed by a great
many of Gentlewomen and Knights, who addressing her self unto them, said.
Gentle Shepherds, the glory you have gotten, by loving more truly then all
others besides in the world; has made me forsake the Court of France, whither
fortune had conducted me of late, to repair unto you for the succor of two
enchanted persons, the History of whom is very lamentable, and that loving one
another most entirely, were conducted to the State, wherein you shall behold
them, by the malice of a Sorceresse named Orgelia.

This Megera, going upon a time to invoke her spirits in a wood, incountred
with Cardoran, Earl of Garaman (a country adjoining to the famous Kingdom of
Corolandaya) and finding that in him which might strike one in love, she left
the business wherabout she went, and arresting him, entertained him first with
ordinary discourse; but a little after told him most impudently, that she was
no longer her own, that his beauty had ravished her; and briefly that a violent
passion enforced her to offer her self unto him. Cardoran, who carried a noble
mind, hearing this speech, and seeing that the eyes of this Sorceresse had no
other charms, but such as were fit to captivate a Devil, had much ado to
forbear laughing, but desiring to appear as courteous, as she had showed her
self shameless, he told her that he was very sorry for the harm she had
received against his will, and modestly excusing himself upon the fidelity
which he owed to his dearest wife Lindorenna, he walked fair and softly away;
whereupon this woman, enraged to see her self so despised, took hold of his
arm, and said unto him. Cardoran, remember that no man scorns such as I, but
that repentance accompanies his offense, you have kindled a fire in my heart,
and will not quench it, burn eternally in the like flames, or at leastwise

Until such time as you have found out the excellent Dove, and the royal
Gerfaulcon under a disguised Plume. Herewith taking her Girdle she knit it
about his arm, and tying him to atree that was close by, she presently raised a
fire full of brimstone under him, wherewithal his Horse was so frighted, that
he flew away from his Master, leaving him suspended by the arm, and making such
grievous lamentation, as all the Woods about resounded therewith.

This me thinks was so cruella revenge, as might well have satisfied the anger
of any furious woman, but she that would not have Lindorenna exempted from
torment, because Cardoran had neglected her for her sake, caused her to be
advertised by one made for that purpose, of that which this wretched Gentleman
suffered; whereupon she instantly dislodged with me, hoping to succor him by
some means or other; But alas, as soon as she was come to the tree, she
suddenly with her husband, not perc^iving by whom, was put into a Litter, where
they now remain in the same sire that borned them before.

Of this their misery, I was so sensible, that I began to tear my hair in an
outrageous manner, when as the wicked woman coming to me, struck me with a
wand that she had in her hand, and so imposing a silence to my complaints,
advised me, if I desired the good of these unfortunate Lovers, to carry them up
and down till I could meet with such as could deliver them from so horrible a
torment, the which I have now done five years together, but to no purpose, for
of all that presented themselves thereunto, they always wanted either courage
or fidelity, the two things required for the undoing of this enchantment.

Opening the Litter then, and showing them Cardoran, and Lindorenna amidst the
flames, which made a very dreadful noise, and that burned them, without
consuming any part of their bodies, she thus pursued her discourse. Their
deliverance consists in two points, in the perfection of a pure and unspotted
love between two persons, and in the confidence to go and kiss them amidst
these flames; now see gentle Shepherds whither your Love which is talked of, as
of a miraculous thing, or whither the compassion of the pains wherein you
behold them, can induce you to free them.

I am well assured, replied Clarisel, gently turning himself toward his
Miralinda, that my love being without all defect, and as great as possibly may
be, I cannot be wanting to the succor of these afflicted couple, but now it is
that you must open your heart, and here satisfy the truth of those
protestations, which a thousand times you have made unto me. Why Shepherd
(answered she smiling) do you yet doubt of my faith? Verily, I have just cause
to complain of you; but not to give you the glory of loving better then my
self, I will defer the disputing of this matter, until I have demonstrated
by the contempt of this cruel fire, that I feel one in my soul far more
violent and great: Saying so, without any fear at all of the flames, she
courageously laid her lips on Cardorans, and therwithal taking him by the hand
raised him up so easily, that she struck all the assistants with wonder, who
beholding Lindorenna in the same estate by Clarisels confidence, filled the air
with a million of acclamations in the praise of these two Lovers, at whose feet
Cardoran and Lindorenna presently threw themselves, being every way in as good
a disposition as they were before their misfortune, desiring them to give them
their hands to kiss in acknowledgement of so remarkable a benefit.

Our condition, answered Clarisel, does not permit us to receive this duty from
you; wherefore be pleased to arise, and command us any other thing, if you think
us yet useful for your service. Gentle Shepherd, said Cardoran, the honor
which I have done you, I rendered to your virtue rather then the habit you
wear, on which I do not much stand, but since you are so courteous, as to
oblige us twice, I most humbly beseech you to grant me one boon, and this
beautiful Shepherdess another to my wife; for thereupon depends the
consummation of our bliss.

Demand what you will, said Clarisel, for I am so much yours, as not to deny
you any thing you shall desire of me, and be assured this fair Shepherdess
will be no more difficill in whatsoever this Lady shall be pleased to command
her. No verily (said Miralinda, who was no less satisfied with the proof she
had made of her own love, then with the knowledge she had of her Clarisels
fidelity) I have had as much courage, and I will be as liberal as you. We must
depart then from henceforthwith, said Cardoran, for to go unto ^^ Enterprise*
where your presence will be very avayleable, and n^cessary for me. You shall be
obeyed, said Clarisel, for I am persuaded that we are carried from hence by a
special providence from Heaven, that is working o^^ good, so that we will
dislodge as soon as I have armed my self. By my faith, said Mascarin, you shall
have my company then, though (...) you had r^^^er be without i^, for the beauty
of those ^^eld^ would be odio^^ to me, were the fun of it once gone.

Herewith all that were present fell a laughing, our Miralinda excepted, who
thinking more of the Journey she had promised, then of the fooleries of ^^is

As soon as they had overtaken them, one of those Knights went strait ^o

CHAP. XVII. Clarisel narrowly escaping shipwreck, lands in great Britt^in,

CLarisel and his company being bound for the county of Garaman, sailed with a

dreadful and cruel death, the horror of the danger augmenting by such
prodigious accidents.

Miralinda more dead then alive, was in her Shepherds arms, that nothing moved

subject to the fury of a pitiless Element, the rest landing in like manner.

CHAP. XVIII. The Massacre that was made by the dreadful Giant Zorobalan at
the Io^sts at Windser, Clarisel a^^iving thereupon, after a dangerous Combat
kills him.
THE Nuptials of Rozanel and the fairest Angelea, of Tristor and the virtuous
Alteria being celebrated, all the Knights of great Britain were in the field,
the people filled the scaffolds, Quedragant, Abies, and the gentle Agrian of
Scotland were in the Lists, and the Trumpets began to sound a charge, when as a
Gentlewoman with two Knights appeared before a Wagon, wherein lay the body of a
Giant, whose head was divided in two; at the sight hereof every one came
thronging to it; and especially Garama^^, Don Si^ald^, Rozanel, and Tristor,
who very much marvelled at the greatness of the blow which they beheld, saying
that the Knight, from whose hand so violenta storm fell, must needs have a
strange and extraordinary force.

The Gentlewoman desired she might be brought before the Prince of Sobradiza. I
am he, said Tristor, will you have any thing with me? Gentle Prince, answered
she, here is one of your greatest enemies in case to conspire no more against
your person, as he had done with a brother of his, far greater and more
formidable then he, who purposes to be present at this assembly, to revenge
upon you the death of Albadan, whom your Grandfather, King Gala^^ defeated in
the quarrel, that Gandalac, had with him concerning the Rock of Galtares, the
handsome Shepherd (one of the best Knights of the world) sends him to you, with
this advise, that you take heed you be not surprised by that dangerous enemy
the surviving brother. Gentlewoman, said Tristor, I am infinitely indebted to
the good will and valor of this Knight, as also very much to you for the pains
you have taken in coming hither, which I will labor to acknowledge before you
depart from hence, touching the advice you have brought me, it shall not be
neglected, and if the Giant come, I doubt not but he shall find some here
courageous, and strong enough to arrest the fury of his arms.

Whereupon, retiring with an exceeding desire to know so brave a Warrior, he
caused the Wagon with the body to be fet in a corner of the Lists, and placing
himself in the window, he perceived eighteen Knights come marching in three
troops, the foremost whereof was conducted by Aristander, Duke of South Wales,
who was passionatly in love with Flori^^a, the daughter of Garamant, Duke of
North Wales, and desired to show his valor for the maintenance of her beauty;
the second by Orad^rt, Earl of Gloucester, who was no less affected to
Theiphila, the daughter of Don Sinaldo; and the third by Orian, Duke of
Norfolk, who had no other Mistress but glory.

These three Champions, being each of them accompanied with five of the best
Knights of great Britain, ranked themselves according to their arrival in the
place, and just opposite to Quedragant, Abies, and Agrian, stood Aristander and
two of his troop, who at the sound of the Trumpets dislodged very bravely, and
broke his staff upon his adversaries Shield, without so much as moving
Quedragant, that incountred him so strongly, as he made him lose his stirrops,
whilst his two Companions were unhorsed by Abies and Agrian: Aristander
extremely vexed for that he had done so little with his first staff, took
another that was bigger and stronger, ^^^ing to recover his honor at the
second course, nevertheless he and his Horse were both overthrown to the
ground.

These three being dispatched in this sort, the rest presently advanced, and
ran very gallantly, but fortune was no more favorable to th^^^, then to their
Companions, for they were all laid on the grass, and constrained to give place
to Gradart, who at the third course against Agrian helped to fill up the number

so much that these eighteen of the best Knights of great Britain being
defeated, they were conferring the prize on the Challengers, when as a Giant
presented himself so huge, and of so terrible an aspect, as frighted all the
assistants, those warlike Princes excepted, who choosing out good Lances

acquired: howbeit, they never used them, for the great Giant having discovered
the body that lay in the Wagon cried out with a horrible voice: Immortal gods?
who could deal thus with my brother, since all the Knights in the world
assembled together were not able to withstand him; Ah dogs, you have surprised
him treacherously, but you shall all dye in satisfaction of so foul a crime;
Saying so he charged his Lance against Quedragant, and passing it through his
Shield and Arm, flung him half a dozen paces over his Horses crupper, then
suddenly returning discharged two such terrible blows on Agrian and Abies, that
having wounded the one dangerously in the thigh, and the other on the head, he
laid them both in the dust, from whence flying in amongst the rest he cleft
Gradart down to the wast, and never rever regarding upon whom his Sword
lighted, he began to make so great a Massacre of Men, Women, and Knights, that
he had overthrown thirty at his feet before Rozanel and Tristor, who had
speedily armed themselves, could come forth.

The Ladies shriked at the windows, the people fled away, the slaughter
continued, and the place was almost empty, when as a Knight of a very goodly
presence arrived, accompanied with two Gentlemen unarmed, a Shepherdess, whose
face was covered with a vayl, and certain Damsels richly clad, who beholding
the havoc that the Giant made, drew forth his Sword, and discharged it with
such violence on him, that he was forced to knock his chin against the pummell
of his saddle, which so rowsed the fury of this Monster, as raising himself up
full of rage, he thought to have divided his enemy with an horrible blow that

In the mean time the combat continued very terrible, the ground was st^ewed

Not long after, when as Clarisel, Qu^dragant, Abi^s, and the rest were* cured

let them understand his name, his country, and parentage.

If it were to do you any service, brave Prince, answered he, be confident, I
would make no difficulty to obey you, but knowing that it will little avayl
you, and that it much imports me to conceal it, I shall humbly beseech you to
excuse me, only be assured that the greatest glory I desire to have in the
world, is to be a Shepherd* for the love of this Shepherdess.

Judging by this speech that he would not discover himself, they importuned him
no farther,, and labored to give him the best entertainment they possibly
could devise for to stay him amongst them; but loath to lose time, he took his
leave a little after of all these Princes and Ladies* as also of Florimond and
Clarislea, who likewise returned into France, and imbarking himself in a Ship,
that Garament had provided for him, he sailed toward the Islands of Corolandaya.

again in the head of their squadrons, with such a ruin of those they
incountred, as their people resuming new courage, spoke of nothing less then a
retreat: how beit these Princes, being as advised, as valiant, put them
presently in good order, and retired with them into their Trenches, in despite
of so many enemies having with incredible pains sustained the fury of those
that pursued them.

This so prudent, and courageous a retreat was much admi^ed of the enemy,
which commending the extreme valout of the fair Slave, and of the two
strangers, lamented the loss of fourteen thousand men, three Giants, and that
of the King of Ircassia, who was s^ain by the hand of the Prince of France,
nevertheless understanding that their Adversaries fortune was little better,
and that they had left nine thousand men, two Giants, and the Duke of Plemond
on the shore, they did not much afflict themselves, but went and planted their
Camp before Cardana, resolving to put all to fire, and sword, especially
Arastron, Brizardan, and Rifantes, who being marvellously incensed, would have
sent a Challenge (notwithstanding the danger of their wounds) to the three
Knights, that to their great grief were mightily incensed by every one, but the
King of Cabilla, relying more on these three Warriors, then on the rest of his
Army, would by no means permit them, so as they continued keeping of their Beds
ten or eleven days together; during which time our Champions having no less
need of rest, both sides prepared all things necessary for the Assault, and
defense of the City, whereat the fair Princesses were much troubled, but the
presence of their Lovers confirming them, they showed more affection then fear,
principally Archesidella, who being acquainted by Amadis of the quality of the
Prince of France, received him likewise for her Husband.

At length our Warriors perceiving all the field covered with Soldiers ready
for the Assault, they went and besought the Emperor, that nothing might be
ordered, but by their counsel, and presently thereupon caused threescore
thousand foot, to enter into the Town, which they divided into four
squadrons, commanded by the King of Arbales, and Miriana of Calizant, and of
Carderia, and then going with three Giants into their Trenches, they drew out
thirty thousand Horse, which they equally divided into three bands, and so
sallying out in three several parts they left the Kings of Balivan, of
Merlian, and of Grizolia, with fourscore thousand to guard the Camp, favor
their retreat and succor the Town if need were.

The Enemy approaching the Walls, began a most cruel and furious assault, the
great Sultan of Aralafia, Rifantes, and the proud Arastron, mounted first,
followed by fifty thousand men, but they were so valiantly opposed by the
four Giants, by the Kings, the gentle Knight Tarsander, and the forces that
were under their command, which remained in the Town, as the ditches were full
of dead bodies, whereat notwithstanding they were so little abashed, that it
seemed rather to augment their courages, in such sort, that their followers
carried by their example, behaved themselves so manfully, as the City was in
danger to have been forced, had not the Fair Slave appeared in the head of ten
thousand Horse, who entering furiously amidst the enemies troops ran a Giant
quite through and through, overthrew six Knights, before she brake her Lance,
and thundering amongst the rest with her Sword, she so cleared their ranks,
that she easily made way to the Walls, where incountring Don Rifantes with
thirty thousand Horse, which he had suddenly assembled, she gave him so
mighty a blow on his Helmet, that she laid him on the crupper of his Horse,
utterly derived of his senses.

This blow having terrified the enemies, they were ready to have betaken
themselves to flight, had not the proud Pagan arrived thereupon, followed by a
great multitude of Soldiers, who with a dreadful cry falling upon our
Warriors troops, began to make a terrible slaughter, in the nick whereof
Lucibel coming in, charged them a flank so furiously, that he cut off four
thousand of them. Brizardan seeing the confusion they were in, forsook the
Wall, and went to the succor of his companions; but Floridan having surprised
his men in disorder, put a number of them to the sword, nevertheless the
Sultan, being an excellent Commander, quickly reduced the most part of them
into order, and then addressed himself to run against Floridan, who observed
his coming, incountred him so furiously in the carriere, that they were both
overthrown in the dust, where our Knight had been in danger of ending his
days, under the horses feet, if the valor wherewith the Giant, that
accompanied him, arresting his enemies, had not given him leisure to remount on
his horse, which Brizardan could not so soon do because of the Giant,
nevertheless, being at length relieved by the assistance of those about him, he
drew out his sword, and began to make so cruel a massacre, that all the world
flew from before him.

In the mean time the valourous Corazinda, and the brave Prince of France did
things worthy of eternal glory, they killed, they cut off arms, and heads,
they cleft men down to the wast, and rendered themselves so terrible that the
very glistering of their swords, put the most confident in fear, howbeit their
number being too small to resist the fury of all these troops, which came
flocking together for to invest them, they retired in despite of so many
enemies, after whose example Floridan did the like notwithstanding all that the
brave Sultan of Aralafia could do; who understanding that his three Giants
were slain, with seven and twenty thousand men, and the Kings of Gallona and
Urban, the Emperor having lost but eleven thousand, he would have cast himself
in the Sea, had not the King of Cabilla wisely remonstrated unto him, how it
was but a trick of Fortune, that oftentimes opposes our desires, and will not
suffer us to triumph, but when she pleases, making a virtue then of
necessity, though it were with mavelous vexation, he resolved to determine
the business with one set day, whereunto having persuaded the King of Cabilla;
he sent accordingly to present the Emperor to battle, who relying on the
justice of his cause, and on the supreme valor of the fair Slave, and of the
Knights of the Flower-de-Luces, and Flowers, accepted of it to be fought on the
third day after, but at no hand would yield to any Truce during the time, and
that by the special advise of those Warriors which had undertaken an
enterprise, whereof you shall see the effect in the Chapter following.

CHAP. XX. The wonderful feats of Arms performedina sallie made by
Palmirenna's fair Slave, with the end of the General Battle, where all the
Emperors Forces were defeated by the unexpected arrival of the King of the
cruel Island.
TWo days being impatiently past away by the King of Cabilla's friends, who
attended but the third for to be revenged of the outrages they had received,
our Christian Princes considering what advantage the surprise of a careless
Enemy does bring, resolved to mount on Horseback about midnight, when as the
Moon might facilitate their design, and accordingly having each of them made
choice of two thousand approved Knights, they sallied out at three several
Gates, and with very great silence marched even to the enemies Sentinels, who
drowned in sleep, were soon put all to the Sword, a free passage being thus
opened to the Emperors troops, Palmirenna's fair slave entering first with
incredible fury, made so great a slaughter, that in a moment all the field was
covered with dead bodies.

The brave Sultan, and the proud Arastron, that were fast asleep, hearing the
dreadful noise of Arms, and the cries of thousands, which were yielding up the
Ghost, lept suddenly out of their beds, and finding four thousand Horse, that
were ever kept ready in reserve for all occasions, began to make head against
this invincible Championess, who overcame all, when as a new uproar arising
from the East side arrested them, not knowing well which way to take;
nevertheless being too courageous to be amazed with any alarm, they instantly
divided their forces, whilst Rifantes and the King of Filzandria, separately
caused the rest of the Soldiers to be armed, and marching bravely on, began a
most cruel bickering; for the Knights of Martaria desiring to imitate their
gallant Leaders, performed their parts most valiantly, and meeting with
terrified enemies made havoc of them every where.

On the otherside those two Thunderbolts of war, the great Sultan of
Aralafia, and the proud Arastron bestirred themselves with mighty loss to their
Adversaries, but Lucibel arising thereupon, flew in amongst them with such
fury, that above two thousand of their men were laid dead on the ground at the
very first brunt; and lustily pursuing his advantage he had cut eight or nine
thousand of the rest in pieces, had not Rifantes come presently in with thirty
thousand Horse, upon the sight of whom our Warriors, that wisely managed
occasions, rallied themselves altogether, and retyring in good order, so
mightily incensed those three valiant Pagans, that in a rage they followed them
with all their Cavalrie, hoping to thrust in with them into the City; howbeit
the King of Arbales arriving with eight thousand Horse, and four Giants charged
them in such manner with the assistance of the three Princes, and their troops,
which suddenly turned head against them, that rendering their designs vain, they
forced them to retire with the loss of nine thousand men, having left but
seven hundred of their Knights in the place, which were slain upon the first
encounter, whereat the Pagans were so infinitely enraged, that they could hardly
attend the rising of the Sun to put their Army into battle array.

In the mean time our Princes being come to the Town were reserved with strange
acclamations, and having somewhat refreshed themselves in Palmirenna's Chamber,
whither the beautiful Amplamira, and her excellent sister repaired to them at
the break of day for to give them skarfes, and to entreat them not to run into
unnecessary dangers, they went incontinently to the trenches where the Emperor
resolved to sight, and command the Battle in his own person, having learned by
his espials, that the King of Cabilla had an intention to do the like.

His Forces then being by the advice of the fair slave divided into three
Bands, the Vantguard consisting of twenty thousand Horse, and five and twenty
thousand Foot was given to the Kings of Arbales, Arisdan, and Carderia,
together with the Knight of the Flowers, and a Giant; the rereward of a like
number to the Kings of Grisolia, Metlina, and Ca^ilant, with the Knight of the
Flower de-Luces, and the Emperor reserving the main battle for himself,
wherein were thirty thousand Horse, five and thirty thousand Foot; the Duke of
Bonport, three Giants and the fair Slave, left the Marquis de la Rocque, and
the Count Vadian to guard the Town, the King of Mariana, in the Camp with
fifteen thousand men, and to the gentle Knight Tarsander, and the young Prince
of Balivan, he consigned four thousand light Horse to serve for wings unto the
Army.

All things being thus disposed of, they marched out of their trenches in good
order to encounter their enemies, who showing no less zeal to fight, then
advisednesse in marshalling of their Troops, followed Rifantes that led the
Vantguard with thirty thousand Horse, and forty thousand Foot; this valiant
Chieftain conceiving that a good example was the best exhortation could be made
to encourage the Soldiers, setting sputs to his Horse, charged his Lance
against the King of Arbales, but Floridan seeing him set forth, parted at the
very same instant, and meeting him in the midst of the course broke his
staff very bravely, and received this Enemies Encounter, without so much as
once being moved in his saddle.

Both Armies herewith animated, a most dangerous conflict was seen in an
instant, the King of Arbales ran the King of Astramer quite through and
through, and overthrew him dead to the earth: The King of Carderia his
Companion, was by the King of Fortan cast under the Horses feet, where at
length he was stifled: The Martarians considering that the safety of their
Prince, their lives, and their liberties were in question, fought desperately;
The adverse part trusting to their numbers, carried themselves courageously, so
as all was in confusion, nothing was seen, nor heard, but bodies extended on
the ground, and the cries of dying men, which filled the air with their groans
and lamentations; Floridan seemed a Thunderbolt, death was ever tied to his
sword, Rifantes made such havocke* that way was given him whersoever he went.

The blood (...) along instrea^^, and every thing h^ng in suspense, when (...)

Brizardan, Arastron, and Rifantes did wonders, but our Knights so behaved

many enemies, especially of the Giants of the new Army, that hoping to enter
with them spurred on for life, but our three Champions being in the Rear, with
each of them a Lance in his hand, incountred them with such force, as they ran
them all three quite thorough and thorough, sending them dead to the ground, to
the infinite discontent of Arastron, who seconding them, had some part in their
disgrace; for Corazinda unable to endure his insolence, gave him so terrible a
blow on his helmet, that he cut off half his cheek, and so astonished him
besides, as if Rifantes had not presently come in to his aid he had fallen from
his Horse.

The horrible blow having arrested those which pursued them, the three Knights
had leisure to enter into the Town, where was strange lamentation made for so
great a loss, which amounted to seventy two thousand foot, and fifty seven
thousand horse, besides the Kings of Calizant, Merlina, and Carderia, and
repayring to the Emperor, who was very sensible thereof, they in some sort
comforted him by remonstrating, that it was but a chance of fortune, which
might soon change her copy, as much to their advantage; this done they went to
their Ladies, which infinitely rejoiced to see them return safe from the fury of
so bloody a Battle, and having assured them against all fear, they got them
instantly to the trenches, from whence they drew all the forces that were
thereinto the Town, the better to resist the assaults of their enemies, which
in the mean time caressed Alfer^ax the dreadful Giant of the cruel Island, who
brought them this succor, by means whereof they had obtained the victory,
though dearly bought, having lost nine and forty thousand Horse, threescore
and five thousand Foot, five Giants, the Kings of Astramer, Zamblan, Corniban,
Alarmir, and Langican, but comforting themselves with the hope of easily
forcing the Walls, in regard they had yet fourscore thousand men remaining, and
understanding that the Emperor had not a quarter so many, they resolved not to
let their Adversaries rest in quiet, but to give them an assault within two
days at the farthest, howbeit this design was interrupted, as you shall hear
by and by.

CHAP. XXI. The King of Cabilla sends Ambassadors to the Emperor, a Peace is
concluded; the Princesses of Martaria are granted in marriage to Rifantes,
Brizardans Meridoran, the Princes of Greeces resolution thereupon.
THE Prince of Cabilla's love being of more power then his spite, to have been
vanquished before Palmirenna, councelling him not to suffer the total ruin of
an Empire, the Crown whereof he hoped to enjoy, he went unto Brizardan, that
kept his bed by reason of some wounds he had received from the fair Slave, and
extolling the beauty of Amplamira, and Archesidella unto him before the King
of Filzandria, that was present there, after he had freely acknowledged his own
passion for the Princess Palmirenna, possessed them with no less affection to
these two excellent Infanta's, then that which he bore to his Mistress, in such
sort, as having ^ad some discourse upon this subject; they resolved to send
Ambassadors unto Cardana conceiving that the bad estate of the Emperors
affairs would make him willingly accept of the conditions they should propound.

Having then taken the advice, and consent of the King of Cabilla, that that
desired nothing so much as the contentment of his Son, they dispatched away the
Duke of Fransacra, and the Marquis of Robanara, fully instructed with what they
were to say, who appearing before the Walls with a trumpet, were presently
admitted in, and conducted to the Emperor, unto whom the Duke of Transacra
spoke in this manner.

Mighty Prince of Martaria, fortune has showed you that she favors your
enemies, and that it is in their power to deprive you of your Scepter when they
please, nevertheless she at this instant presents you with means, not only to
conserve you, but to make you more redoubted then ever you were; you know the

vali^nt Sultan of Aral^fia, and the riches of the puissant King of Filzandria,
make use of their good desire, to rendery on their Father-in-law, and do not
endure the ruin of so godly an Empire as yours is, their suit is advantageous
to you, and the possession of your Daughters will give them more satisfaction
then your estate, think that they will be so many Pillars, whereupon your
greatness may firmly rest, and consider that it is better to caress them as
your children, then to see them the enemies of your Crown; This is the business
of our Embassage, whereunto be pleased to return us a speedy answer, to the end
that either we may conclude an absolute peace with you, or resolve for a
continuance of the War.

My Lords, answered the Emperor very gravely, I am not ignorant of the
virtues, and quality of these three Princes which have sent you hither; but
having hitherto defended my self from their violence by the assistance of my
friends, it is reason that I take their counsel in so important an affair,
wherefore repose you here a little I pray you, whilst I advise with them
thereupon.

So passing to the Council Chamber, whither his Daughters, with the Kings of
Arbales, and Grizolia, Corazinda, and the Knights of the Flowers, and
Flower-de-Luces, being sent for, he propounded this demand, whereupon diverse
opinions were given; some drawn with the resentment which they were to have of
the outrages received from them were wholly against it, and others carried by a
better consideration of what was most convenient for the good of the State,
were altogether for it, so as they could not come to any resolution at at all,
when as the Emperor, being desired to deliver his mind, made it appear, that
he would not be very difficile to sign this accord, for remonstrating that his
(...) were spent, that these mighty Princes were his neighbors, and that
their alliance, would render his Crown most secure against all attempts
whatsoever, he restified that he had no greater desire then to see a Peace
concluded, and his Daughters in the power of those which demanded them, whereat
the fair Slave was so enraged, who perceived the utter undoing of her self, and
her cousins involved in the Treaty, that rising up with sparckling eyes, she
could not forbear saying to him;

Sir, I wonderat you, that in the midst of all your Subjects you are afraid;
what will the world say when they shall hear, that after such insufferable
outrages, you could so soon, and easily be persuaded to forget them? Do you
fear that your Daughters being so accomplished, and beautiful, shall never
meet with Princes so great and valourous, as these which now present them
selves? Sir, I know some, that yield not to them either for merit, or birth,
and from whom you may have more assistance, and content, then you hope for from
these. They threaten you with a continuance of the War, are not your Walls all
entire, and do not they know to their cost, that it had been determined
otherwise, had not Fortune showed her self what she is? she has done her
worst, and therefore is not to be further feared, nor shall this arm, wherein
hitherto you have found safety, ever be wanting to your succor, provided your
resolution be more generous; at leastwise understand from your Daughters,
whether they like of these matches, and do not more then the gods, which leave
us a power over our own wills.

Sweetheart, answered the Emperor, I verily believe that the love you bea^
me, ma^^s you speak with ^uch passion, (...) that it touches my particular,
when I talk of an accord with these Princes, but you do notknow how the
affairs of a King are otherwise treated of, then those of a private man, the
good of my State has counseled (...) to that which I say, my Daughters must
conform themselves to my pleasure, and therefore I command them to prepare
themselves for these Nuptials, whereby those mischiefs may be declined which
otherwise would arise, should I wilfully pers^stin this War.

These words ^o resolutely delivered, having drawn all the rest to his opinion,
except the beautiful Princesses, which spoke not but with their tears, the
Ambassa^^ours were called in, and so satisfied, with the promise which the

The Ambassadors being returned then with all the content they could desire, a

of Filzandria trickt up themselves, and de^iring to enjoy the happiness of

notwithstanding their Fathers presence, could not choose but show their

Howbeir these Princes willing to ^latter themselves, and hoping that time or
necessity would beget affection in them, they departed a little after, so
pressed with the desire of tasting the felicities, which the fruition of
theirincomparable beauties did promise, as they humbly besought the Emperor,
that their happiness might not be deferred but for a day or two at the most,
which having been promised them, the Emperor returned to his Daughters, who
thinking to move him to pity, fell on their knees before him, and with tears

Husbands most incapable of love, and under whose power they could expect
nothing but constraints, but all could not move him, for resolved to see the
consummation of these Marriages he commanded them anew, to prepare themselves
thereunto within two days, which commandment was so harsh unto them, as they
would quickly have made an end of themselves, had they not the hope they had to
find out some means by the counsel of their Lovers to avoid this mischief,
persuaded them to prolong their lives a while.

Having sent for them then as soon as it was night, they shut themselves up with
them into a Chamber, where lovingly joining their lips unto theirs, the tears
trickled down their fair cheeks, whereby Amadis too well knowing their grief,
said unto them; Ladies, complaints are vain, nor will weeping do any good, you
love us, the favors we contin^ally receive from you, assure us of it, but yet
you are to give ^^ further proof thereof, vex not your selves at the cruelty
of a barbarous Father, who without the regard of your content will subject you,
to men you cannot love, France, Persia, and Greece, are Countries goodly enough
to invite you without sorrow to abandon the ingracefull Land, thither let us
go my excellent Mistress, and make no difficulty to follow us, I have a way to
carry you hence in despite of all that would oppose my my enterprise, so as
you have sufficient courage, and love to undertake it with us.

Alas! my dearest Lord, answered Palmirenna, this is all that we can wish for
in the world, declare unto us the secret of so difficult an affair, you shall
find us most resolute, and if there were occasion to take away the lives of
these deteshed Lovers, be assured that I would be the first to let out the
heart-bloud of Rifantes, Amplamira, and Archesidella, testifying no less
courage and affection for the contentment of their Lords, Amadi^ continued his
discourse in this sort;

Afflict your selves no longer then I beseech you, but when the time comes,
dress you in the bravest manner you can, for to be led to Church, in which
instant of time, Floridan and I will come into the Hall, in unknown Arms,
whilst Lucibel shall attend us at the gate adjoining to the Haven, and under
color of obliging you by some promise to descend into the Court yard, for the
deliverance of two enchanted Lovers, whom I will feign to be enclosed there in
a Coach, you three shall go into it; that done, six Horses shall gallop away
with you to the Sea side, where we shall find the Prince of Frances Barque,
which to morrow we will cause to be made ready for that effect.

This enterprise seems wonderful difficult, said Palmirenna, for you will be
in danger of exposing your selves against the power of all these Kings, and the
Emperor together, howsoever we will cast away all considerations, for if you
dye in the execution thereof, we will not survive you a minute, wherefore be well
prepared, and we will follow you infallibly. This resolution being taken, they
got them to bed, where with infinite content they lay till morning; when as
Lucibel sent for the Pilot of his Barque, who promised him that it should be in
a readiness against the time appointed.

This horrible blow having mightily terrified the Emperor, and the King of

rest to enter with them into their Barque, they three, and their Ladies, got
aboard first, and as Grian was going to follow them, the Cable breaking that
held their Barque, she was carried away to Sea, whether they would or no, to

who thought they should know the Princes of France, and Persia; howbeit there
being no remedy, they imbarqued themselves with the redoubted Knight of the
Salvage, and his Brandimanda in their Vessel, with a resolution to follow, and
overtake the other, but they were disappointed of their purpose, and driven
otherwhere.

CHAP. XXIII. Amadis his Ship being driven by a tempest to the Isle Du-bois,
two Leagues from Cardana, the Lovers are betrayed by a Merchant, and being
ready to fall into the hands of the Emperor of Martaria, they are miraculously
enchanted.
WE evermore find some cross to our content, and the sweetest delights have
some intermixture of bitterness; These Princes went on betwixt joy and grief,
esteeming themselves happy to be at the mercy of the winds, rather than of a
salvage, and cruel Emperor, but were no less troubled with the absence of
those brave Champions, to whose valor, and courage, they did owe their lives.
Those matchless Princesses did like wise simpathize with them in the like
passions, exceedingly joying at their happy escape from so desperate an
enterprise, but sorrowing no less at the number of their Lovers hurts, which
for want of a skillful Surgeon in the Ship might prove dangerous.

Howbeit Amadis bethought himself of a box of precious Balm, that he found in
the Grot, where the Dwarf dressed his wounds after his conflict with the Monster
of the Mountain of Bears, which instantly he caused to be sought out and
delivered it to his fair Mistress, who refused to entrust any other then her
self with his cure, and attendance, and therefore being laid down with the
other Princes, his associats, Palmirenna filled his wounds with that so
precious ointment; which having done, not without some tears and kisses, she
presented the Box unto her Sisters, who performed the like office unto their
Lovers, and so having shut the windows, withdrew themselves, and left them
asleep.

Mean while the Sea growing high and boystrous, overmastered the Pilots, and in
despite of their art, and industry, drove them back toward the place from
whence they were departed: they not able to withstand their destiny, were in
the end enforced to strike sail, and to comply with the present necessity;
Driving along then with the current, they came to the Isle Du-bois, two small
leagues from Cardana, the Mariners not knowing what Country it was awakened
the three Princes, who found theselves whole and sound, to the no less joy and
contentment, then wonder and astonishment of the Ladies: now, because the Sea
being rough, and the Harbor exceeding open, there was no safety in the Ship,
they persuaded the Lovers to go ashore, to which they willingly assented, in
regard they thought themselves out of the reach of Fortune, and far enough from
Martaria.

Not long after, as they walked on, they espied a stately House, where they
resolved to rest themselves until the weather grew more calm; Coming
therefore to the Master of it (a rich Merchant) he gave them very courteous
entertainment, but soon after taking notice of their persons, and being
thoroughly acquainted with that days passage, which already was grown public,
allured with hope of reward, as also thereby to shun the Emperors displeasure,
he resolved with himself to discover their arrival unto him: Dissembling then
his intent, and masking his countehance with cheerfulness, the better to avoid,
all thought of suspicion, he stayed till supper was ended, and the said lovers
were retired to their Chambers, at which time he speedily went to Cardana,
where being brought to the Emperors presence, he fell at his feet, and spoke
in this manner;

Sir, the affection I owe to your service, as your most faithful subject; has
brought me hither for discovery of a secret of no small importance: The Sea
has enforced your Daughters, with them that stole them away, to land in the
Isle Dubois; They are in my house, and you may easily have them in your power
without running the hazard of trying anew the fury of their Arms, for I left
them in bed more disposed to sleep; then to fight, where I am confident they
may be surprised without danger.

Immortal gods I said the Emperor, how welcome are these news to me, and how
much do I owe unto their providence, that restores my honor to its first
glory, by affording me the means to right my self for the outrage done unto me;
Ah traitors, racks and torments, shall not be wanting to your insolence, and I
shall take so horrible a revenge, that after-ages shall ever speak of it; And
you, impudent and disobedient Daughters, who have preferred the inticements of
strangers, before the grave admonitions of a Father, be confident that your
punishment shall be proportionable to your offense; You shall find how
powerful the resentments are of a Father, and a Prince thus provoked. Friend,
said he, speaking to the Merchant, thy sidelitie deserves no little recompense,
whereof thou shall be most assured, but to secure this business, fetch me hither
the Captain of my Guard. Then walking in his Chamber after a strange manner,
and with gestures, both of head and hands expressing much passion, he expected
the Captains arrival, under whose command having reduced all such Courtiers,
