as he could gather on a sudden, he departed suddenly with nine hundred Horse,
and about two in the morning arriving at the Isle Dubois, he invested the
Merchants house on all sides without the least noise. The Emperor, who much
desired to surprise the Lovers in bed, where they lay embracing each other,
nothing dreaming of this treason, caused the doors to be opened very softly;
and advancing forwards, he espied a woman with her hair discheveled, bearing
two burning Torches in her hands, who on an instant having encompassed the
house, incountred him just at the Gate, upon the which having made certain
figures, the air was suddenly all on a fire, infinite, and most terrible claps
of Thunder were heard, and a shower of Hayl fell with such violence, that above
five hundred Knights were killed therewith, so that the Emperor, and the rest
were enforced to seek shelter in the neighboring house, to avoid the fury of
the storm, which having continued above two hours, ceased at the rising of the
Sun, that presented to their view, not the Merchants house, whose body was
found covered with Serpents, that devoured him, but a great Tower of Crystal,
divided into three stories; at the foot whereof lay two Lions, so fierce, and
terrible, that none durst come near it. This noveltie having bred a great
desire in the Emperor to behold it nearer, he (...) it, seeing the Lions
stirred not out of their place, and the first thing he espied, was a Table
hanging, wherein these words were written;

Prophecy.

THe Paradise of Love, shall last until the enchanted Lions dye, by the claws
of the strongest Lion in the world; then shall the glorious prisons l^se their
pleasures, the Doves shall be invisible, and the angered Cock shall burst to
vomit his poison, living after the recoverie of his treasure, for the glory of
an unknown Altar.

These words, too mystical to be understood, having detained him for a while,
he perceived in the bottom of the Tower, as in a Tomb, Arm^lina, Orestia, and
Melia, who seemed to slumber; in the first stage Palmirenna, with Amadis, in
the second Amplamira with Floridan; and above that, Archesidella with Lucibel,
all six in bed, kissing each other so amorously, and using such other
expressions of love, as if they had no witnesses of their actions, which so
enraged him, as tearing his hair, and beard, he cried out: O ye Gods! Am I not
the unhappiest Prince of the earth? I have seen my power abated by three
Knights alone, this day a greater affront is presented to my view, and I am
become a spectator of that which I cannot behold without shame; who could not
be mad, and burst with rage at this? Come soldiers, break me this Tower in
pieces, and let us be avenged of these robbers, and impudent queans, in spite
of all Enchantments.

Hereupon thirty, or forty of the stoutest, and most resolute of the company
stepped forth, and with hammers thought instantly to have broken the crystal in
pieces, but the Lions forthwith rushing upon them, made so quick a dispatch,
that the rest hoping for no better usage, quitted the place to the proud
Arastron, who having before disdained to pursue those Princes with so much
inequality and advantage, ambitious of glory, advanced immediately toward the
Lions, with whom he fought so valiantly, that having with a most furious blow
stricken down the greatest, he was about to have dealt so with the other, when
as on a sudden three Centaurs of a mavelous bigness issued forth, and
discharging their massy clubs on him all at once, laid him all along on the
ground, to the unspeakable grief of the Emperor, who fell into such a passion
of fury, and uttered things so extravagant, that had not the Kings of Arbales
and Grisolia endeavored to comfort him, he had undoubtedly become frantic, but
these Princes gravely remonstrating unto him, that it was a sign of their gods
displeasure, which punished him for the violence he would have offered to his
Daughters wills, who had just cause to despise such deformed persons, he
commanded Arastron to be taken up, that immediately came again to himself, and
retired to Cardana, so exceedingly grieved, that death would have been far more
acceptable to him then life.

In the mean time the Emperor hoping, by the valor of some excellent Knight,
the said Enchantment might receive a period, he proclaimed throughout all his
Territories, and the Kingdoms adjacent, that whosoever could give an end to
this adventure, he should have the Crown of Martaria for his reward, judging
his daughters disobedience a sufficient cause to disinherit them. This moved
sundry Knights from diverse for^aign parts to repair thither, allured with the
promise of an Empire, but none could ever approach the Tower with that intent,
that was not straight-ways torn in pieces by the Lions, insomuch that the
cruelty of those untameable beasts being no less notorious, then the Emperors
promise, no Knight could be found that durst undertake so dangerous an attempt.

CHAP. XXIV. Griolanis arrival in Corolandaya, his combat with the Guards of
the P^rt, he is entertained by the Queen, and accepted for her Knight.
GRiolanis carried with a longing desire to see the real beauties of the
excellent Princess of Corolandaya, whose Picture he evermore kept about him,
grew impatient of so long delay, but having past five weeks with a prosperous
gale, and without the least interruption of his intended voyage, he at last
arrived at one of the Ports belonging to his fair Mistress, to the unspeakable
joy and contentment of his Conductresse, Arlandria, who using her wonted
freedom, said unto him. Sir, I make no question, but the power of your arms
will easily prevayl over our ablest Knights, yet if you will follow my advice,
use no other then that of your beauty, to captivate our Queen, who for your
sake will break her wonted custom, and will never permit you to hazard your
life for to win a place in her favor; will you give me leave to advertise her
of your arrival? Yes, Lady, replied he, you shall do me a singular courtesy
to assure her, that ever since I first had the honor to behold her Picture, I
have burned in continual flames, and that I have no greater ambition, then to
let her know how infinitely I affect her; but withal I must desire you not to
go about to hinder me from incountring her Knights, the forbearance whereof
would convince me of weakness and cowardice; for should I present my self
before her in any other manner, then victoriously I should give but her too
just occasion to deny me that, which must be the sole reward of my virtue;
wherefore set forward presently, if you think good, for to morrow I will enter
into combat with the chief Knights of the Port; I never expected other answer
from you, said Arlandria, neither did I think you would judge my advice
honorable, and therefore not to molest you any farther, by urging my former
proposition, I shall in obedience to your commands let her know both your merit
and affection.

Having spoken thus she presently got to Horse, and used such diligence, as the
next day ^he came to Agrica^t, the Capital Town of Corolandaya, where going
straight unto the Palace she fell on her knees before her Mistress, who making
very much of her, demanded what wonders she had seen in her voyage. Madam, said
she, they are such, that should I undertake to give you a particular relation
thereof, you would hardly be induced to believe them: I bring you the names of
two hundred brave Knights manfully overcome by Silvion, and of threescore and
twelve Princesses besides, over whose beauty yours has most justly tryumphed;
but which surpasses all, I have brought with me the fairest, stoutest, the
most courteous, and most lovely Knight in the world. The Prince of Argilles,
though he were rank't with the best, by reason of that extraordinary prowess,
which renowned him every where, yet compared with the valor of the Champion,
whereof I speak, was but as a common man, whose actions being no less full of
sweetness, then of courage, makes him so amiable, that he steals the hearts of
all that behold him.

The praises thou give this Knight are so great, said Adelazia, that I
suspect thee to be in love with him. Alack, Madam, said Arlandria, such flowers
are too precious for my wearing; neither do his affections stoop so low, for
as he is the most accomplished Knight that is, or ever was, so has he made
choice of the most absolute and peerless Mistress in the world. Do thou know
her, said Adelazia, that felt some unaccustomed motions? Yes, Madam, answered
she, you are the Sun which he adores; and your beauty is it alone that ever yet
could captivate his soul. How can that be, said Adelazia, since he never saw
me? Your Picture replied Arlandria, has wrought that miracle, nor could his
passion be more, had you employed all the charms of your unresistable looks on
him: On shipboard his eyes were perpetually fixed thereon, he kneeled, he spoke
to it, and as if it had been sensible of his sufferings, he craved some
asswageme^^ of his torments: To be short, it is impossible for any man to give
greater testimonies of an affection, then what I have seen in him during this
voyage.

This fair Princess willingly harkening to these discourses, and pleasing her
self with the thoughts of her new love, longed very much to see the effects
answerable to the high commendations which this Damosel had given him; but lest
her carriage should discover her mind, she kept on her former gravity; howbeit,
desiring to continue this talk, she said unto her. Verily, these speeches of
thine have bred a kind of desire in me to see him; for it is scarce credible,
that so many perfections should concur in one man: But tell me, is he come
hither? Nothing less, Madam, answered she, he is yet in the Port of Carican,
and it may be now combatting with your Guards, for he is resolved not to
present himself before you, but as a worthy Knight should do, that renders
himself esteemed by his virtue. I was never a friend to cruelty, said Adelazia,
and the shedding of humane blood was always abhorred by me, nevertheless I
would willingly see him fight, thereby to judge impartially, whether his valor
be correspondent to thy praises.

Madam, answered this Maid, you have the best opportunity that may be, I doubt
not but he will make a quick riddance of all such, as this day shall dare to
encounter him, since the Prince of Argilles, who came far short of him, has
been able to do it, wherefore if you please, you may see him amongst the
Knights that guard your Ports, but for your better satisfaction, if you go
forth to morrow into the fields, and under pretense of walking will take the
way he intends to come, you shall soon behold him make through your Troops,
since he may not arrive at your presence without forcing his passage, then
shall you know that all I have said comes far short of his valor and merit.
Nay, said Adelazia, I may do far better, for it being too-great a cruelty to
expose one only Knight to the fury of so many, I Will exempt him from that danger,
and shall rest satisfied if I may see him break five or six staves, against a
dozen of the ablest of my Kingdom; and to this end I shall appoint them a
rendi-vous under the great tree of the Fantosmes, which is not much out of his
way. By this way I shall both content my self, and secure his life and honor:
Truly, said Arlandria, (who perceived this tenderness to proceed from love)
you show yourself no less wise then beautiful, for to speak troth I have
often wondered how you could be so cruel, as to admit no Knight to your
presence upon easier terms, then the price of his blood; keep you still in this
mind, and in the mean time advise with your self what entertainment you will
give him.

Hereupon in most humble manner withdrawing her self she left the Queen much
troubled with the blow she had given her, who calling to mind the speeches of
her Damosel, which represented unto her thoughts, as well the valor, as the
beauty of the Knight, remembering withal how he had behaved himself to and
before her Picture, spoke thus to her self. If this Knight be such as he is
described unto me, I shall never be able to be Mistress of my self, since the
bare fame of him has begotten so earnest a desire in me to see him: But what a
weakness do I show to be thus overcome by the first motions of a passion that
assayles me? And what will the world say of me when it shall be knownthat I
have so suddenly changed both my mind and purpose? I shall be counted very
fickle, and one that is not able to govern her affections. And yet not so, but
in regard that virtue is always to be beloved, they will rather judge that I
have reason to affect him, and that it is not possible for a woman to resist
such powerful charms: I will therefore show him favor, and since I am
accountable to none, but the gods for my actions, I Will put the Scepter of
Corolandaya into his hand, if I find him worthy of that grace.

This Princess yielding up her self in this sort unto Loves Dominion, (from
which no creature living is exempted) was insensibly enamoured, and this little
spark grew suddenly into a flame, when as a Soldier diverting her thoughts
delivered in few words the wonders Griolanis had performed at his first entry
into that Kingdom. Madam, said he, your Guards of Garicana^e forced by the
valor of the most puissant and ablest Champion in the world; And since that
combat was full of prodigies, I may not rob you of the contentment you will
reap by hearing the particulars thereof related: This morning he presented
himself with an headless Lance, and forced seven Knights to quit their
saddles, ere it brake in shivers, thence rushing through the rest with the flat
of his sword only, he sent fifteen or sixteen of them to the ground, and this
with that force as needed not the help of a second blow; Truly, Madam to
relate unto you with what address and dexterity he seartered the rest in less
then a moment is impossible, for in despite of their weapons, which left not
so much as the least impression upon his armor, he made his way like
Lightning, and forced his passage through all oppositions, with no less
violence then a Thunderbolt when it lights upon a Steeple: And to be short, he
has won the day without shedding one drop of blood, whereat your Knights being
amazed, who judged this proceeding of his over mild and gentle, toward those
that had withstood him, they demanded the reason thereof, wherein he expressed
no less courtesy, and sweetness of disposition; then he had courage and
valor. Sirs, said he, since we all have one Mistress, it were unfit for me to
harm those whom she protects, my chiefest ambition being to win her favor, and
maintain her Sovereignty: And if I have taken up Arms against you, necessity
has enforced me thereunto, since there is no other way to serve her, or to be
admitted into her presence.

These speeches, wherein this fair Queen took mavelous delight, being as
bellows to kindle the flame that began to scorch her, she felt within her self
such violent desires, as made her wonder at this sudden and unexpected change,
but dissembling her thoughts, she began to extol the prowess and courtesy of
our Warrior, whose fame and renown had so filled the Court, that most of the
Knights resolved to combat him. Adelazia then having spent the night in
confused and restless thoughts, in the morning a number of Knights were espied
upon the way of Garican, whereof the Queen having had notice, she arose
immediately, but could not be ready time enough to see the beginning of the
fight, nevertheless word being brought her, that the stranger was in the midst
of her Knights, she hastened away, and arrived there just as Griolanis having
dismounted three of them, so terrified the rest with the violence of his
Encounter, as he put them all in disorder.

These redoubted, and yet courteous blows, since he struck only with the flat,
bred in her a wonderful content, and no less astonishment, when she observed
his manner of fighting, his Sword guided by judgment, lighted with violence,
his motions were furious, and that which not a little delighted her, was to see
him keep firm in his saddle, in despite of so many Incounters, neither could
she sufficiently admire to behold two and fifty Knights already laid on the
earth, and the^fore desiring no greater testimony o^ his valor she advanced
toward him, who quickly discerning what impression he had made in her soul,
alighted suddenly from his horse, pulled off his Helmet, and falling on his
knees took his Sword by the point, and presenting her with the handle: Madam,
said he, it is in your power to triumph over me, as I have done over your
Knights, neither shall I reap less glory by this victory of yours; then I have
done by their defeat: This Sword, which if you please shall never be employed
but in the honor of your service, shall serve as a witness that I willingly
submit to your power. Madam, let the tender I make thereof be acceptable unto
you, and let me hope that you will one day take pleasure in seeing it employed
to maintain your excellency throughout the world.

The Princess being ravished with the sight of so beautiful a face, whose
charms were no less powerful to captivate a Ladies heart, then the majesty
thereof to work upon a Soldiers courage, did observe and behold ^^ with strange
motions, trembling with the very violence of her pa^sion, but forcing her self
with the consideration of so many persons as attended her, she replied.

Brave Knight, I cannot refuse the glory you give me, not despise this
dreadful Sword, since you present it me, as the merit o^ my beauty,
nevertheless I return it you, with this assurance, that I shall ever highly
esteem the service thereof; but left I should prove ungrateful for the pains
you have taken in accompanying my picture, let me tell you, that you are most
welcome to my Country, where I shall endeavor to give you an entertainment
worthy your merit. Hereupon she took him up into her Coach, and went toward
the City, no less satisfied with his personage; then her Knights astonished at
the valor he had showed in the Combat.

The fame of this warlike achievement having spread over the whole Town, the
Ladies and Gentlemen stocked together in the streets, who beholding the
admirable perfections of this Knight, gave him such excessive praises, as he
himself was much ashamed of; on the contrary, Adelazia was exceedingly pleased
therewith, esteeming her self incomparably happy in his company, so that she
resolved to admit him for her Knight: howbeit to keep her self within the
bounds of modesty she gave him to understand, that his sole virtue was the
cause of her respect to him, by no means discovering the love she bare him:
Having therefore entertained him with ordinary discourse, she brought him to her
Palace, where having lodged him most stately, she sent him very rich and
sumptuous apparel, wherein he afterward appeared so lovely, that all the
Ladies were enamoured of him, and the common sort amazed to behold so many
accomplishments in one Knight.

A few days being spent in passions, restless thoughts, discourses, and
assurances, Adelazia not able to conceal her affection any longer, led him to
a fair garden, where she could not be overheard by any body, and thus spoke
unto him. Knight, I know it is impossible for me to requite the pains you have
taken in my behalf according to your merit, but desire any thing within my
Kingdom, and it shall be granted you as readily, as you can demand it. Madam,
said he, I was never covetous of gain, honor has been the only object of my
enterprises, and if you please to accept of my service, I shall value that
favor of yours far above all the Kingdoms of the world, but if you will deign
to be so liberal, as to bestow where you are no way obliged; then, Madam, look
not upon my want of desert, make me your Knight, and permit me under the favor
of your beauty, to try all adventures whatsoever; you may justly condemn me of
rashness, but Madam, remember that our enterprises are glorious when they are
high, and that it is far more honorable to fall with courage, then fail
through cowardice. Knight, replied she, did I not prize your virtue above all
worldly greatness, I could not but take offense at the freedom of your
discourse, in regard of the respect which is always due to such as resemble
me, howbeit loving your perfections, and flattering my self with the conceit,
that my beauty has prevailed over you, I shall willingly pardon the passion
that troubles you; and believe that it proceeded only from a desire to work
your content: You are desirous to be my Knight, I admit it, but consider what
obligation this draws upon you, you are no more at your own disposing, your
love must be faithful and sincere, and your will wholly subject unto mine.

Alas! said he, these conditions (...) happy, Madam, you shall never find me
without love, fidelity, respect, and obedience; henceforth I renounce all the
power, which hitherto I have had over my self, and wholly surrender it into
your hands, dispose of me as you please, your commands shall be a law unto me,
which for no occasion will I ever disobey. Begin then, replied she, to give me
some testimony of this your protestation, and tell me freely, and truly, who
you are, and whether you were ever in love before, for it were unfit for me to
have an unknown servant.

Madam, said he, (trembling with joy, that he had obtained his desire) it is
very meet I should satisfy your demand. I am a Knight errant of the Kingdom
of Macedon, near unto Greece, who have no other fortune then that of my hopes,
and sword, and most unworthy to behold you as a lover, unless you will
vouchsafe to stoop so far, as to weigh the greatness of my services and
affections, with that of your beauty; My name is Griolanis, my Parents noble,
and eminent, but Scepters, Madam, are wanting to their merit, which to my grief
I fear, considering the difference of our conditions, will be too just a motive
for you, to reject the humble tender of my service: As for any other Mistress,
believe me, Madam, and I swear it by the sovereign power of these your eyes,
whose beauteous splendour I adore, that my soul was never sensible of the
allurements of any beauty that ever yet I saw. Your word suffices without
swearing, replied she, and I am exceeding glad to be the first object of your
vows, and so consequently to be free from competitors; For what concerns our
conditions, that shall put no difference betwixt us, since fortune does not
always confer Crowns upon such as have best deserved them, and seeing you are
a Gentleman, both valiant and virtuous, I shall esteem better of you, then if
you possessed whole Empyres without courage, or glory; This Kingdom is
spacious enough to limit our ambitions, only carry your self with respect
until time shall produce a happier change; And so parting equally satisfied,
they went to supper; after which, having recreated themselves with dancing,
each withdrew himself until the morrow.

CHAP. XXV. The brave Jousts that were held at the Court of Corolandaya, and
the issue of a most wonderful adventure that happened there.
GRiolanis spending his time in most incomparable delights, highly favored by
his Mistress, bonoured and respected, as if he had swayed the Scepter of
Corolandaya, wanting nothing he could desire, but the fruition of that
happiness which love does yield: his impatience was great enough to make him to
require it, but the doubt of displeasing his Mistress, would not suffer him to
move it, in so much as the torment of his fear was no whit inferior to the
pleasure of his hope.

Twelve days were insensibly spent in confused thoughts, in raptures, in sighs
and moans, till the Knight, unable to withstand the flame that consumed him any
longer, was about to seek some rest in the confidence of his words, and by his
tears to work his Mistress to a compassionate regard of his sufferings, when
behold, there comes into the Hall a fair and comely Damsel, who falling on her
knees before Adalazia, said unto her; Beauteous Princess, the fame which is
spread abroad of the incomparable valor of the strange Knight, that resides in
your Court, has bred an extreme desire in four of the most warlike Princes now
living, to maintain here two days together, that the Mistresses they shall
bring, are the fairest in the world; The first is the valiant Armoran, Caliph
of Paran, who leads with him the fair Alarina, Infanta of Zizima; The second
is the mighty Grinaldo King of Pergaza, with Marselia, inheritrix of Corangia;
The third Falemond the brave Duke of Cardambes, with the gracious Philotea,
Princess of Oriana; The fourth Crisander, the warlike Duke of Marsingues,
servant to the most lovely Elymena, Daughter to the King of Filamonna; They
will begin with Jousting, neither shall it be lawful for any to use his sword,
whilst they are able to keep their saddles, now what answer will you please to
make us?

That which their merits may expect, replied the beautiful Queen, they shall
find hearty welcome, and if any endeavor of mine may requite the honor they
intend to do me, it shall not be wanting unto them. Hereupon the Damsel
taking her leave in most humble manner, departed, leaving the Courtiers
somewhat troubled, for knowing what reputation those Knights had acquired
abroad in several adventures, especially Almorand, and Grinaldo, esteemed the
best Warriors of all the neighboring Provinces, they very much doubted, that
they should not be able any longer to maintain the glory of Corolandaya, unless
it were by the valor of Griolanis, who coming close to his Mistress, spoke
thus softly unto her. I have reason to thank Love for affording me occasion to
serve you, and to purchase your beauty the just estimation it deserves; These
Princes come hither fraught withglory through the numberless enterprises they
have most courageously achieved, and the Ladies that accompany them, hold the
victory of their beauties most sure in the force of their mighty arms; but,
Madam, having justice on your side, I dare promise without ostentation, to
bring them in triumph unto you, and to make them acknowledge you to be
incomparable, so that to the right of my cause, you would be pleased to add
but the obliging me by some favor.

It would be unreasonable, replied she smiling, to refuse ought that lies in my
power, since beauty is in question, which by our sex is had in highest
estimation tell me therefore freely what you desire of me. Two things, said he
trembling, would infinitely satisfy me; The first, some Scarre of yours, that I
might wear in the Combat; The other, that in commiseration of my sufferings,
you will permit me to come to your Chamber, when your women are asleep, that so
I may with more liberty represent unto you, the violence of the flame that
consumes me. Ah my Knight! answered she, you do not consider how nearly this
request of yours concerns mine honor, the grant whereof when it comes to be
divulged, would make me odious to my people. Alack, said he, such a fear befits
not your Majesty, you may do much more then that without caring what eyes, or
speeches pass upon your actions, but if it be your pleasure to see me languish
in my pain, I shall submit to your will without opposing it, or repyning at my
torment, yet withal youch^afe to consid^^ that when I am brought to
extremity, I shall be unfit for remedy. Well, said she, I Will rather overcome my
self, then give you the least cause to complain of me, to morrow you shall have
your desire, but upon condition you will not be too importunate, and that all
your actions shall be governed with respect. Madam, replied he, half
transported with joy, my passion shall never make me abuse the freedom, which
you are pleased to grant me, nor shall you ever repent this grace you have
conferred on me.

But a sudden noise in the Courtyard having put a period to their discourse,
they presently looked out, and saw four Knights in very good equipage, with
each a Lady in his right hand of excellent beauty, and richly appareled, who
lighting off their horses, turned their faces toward the Windows to salute the
fair Adelazia, that returning them the like again, sent to entreat them by the
Marquis of Beltamir to take a lodging in the Palace, which they modestly
refused, intending not to visit her till after the Jousts: Two rich Pavilions
being set up, the Knights entered into the one, and the Princesses into the
other: The rateliers were stored with Lances, the shields of these four
Princes were placed near to the Barriers, that whatsoever Knight came in,
might by touching thereof make choice of a party to joust withal; close by hung
the Pictures of those beauteous Ladies, which were to be the prize, and reward
of the Victor; This done, four gallant Horses were brought to the Pavilion of
the said Princes, who sitting ready armed, expected the arrival of some
Adversary.

This glorious Equipage having bred an extreme desire in most of the Nobility
of Corolandaya, to encounter these strangers, twelve Knights came forth on the
sudden, at the sight whereof the Challengers getting to horse, the Trumpets
began to sound, and the Knights to spur on so lustily, that incountring each
other in the midst of the course the Defendants were dismounted, without so
much as stirring the Challengers, which at first did much increase the good
opinion of their valor, but much more when they saw the other eight reduced to
the same estate, ere they brake their first staves.

These twelve retyring with more grief then hurt, were seconded by the Marquis
of Beltamir, and the Count of Pandolia, two of the most renowned and noblest
Lords of that Island, and Suitors to the Infantaes of Falangia, near of kin to
the Queen; whereupon the people began to hop^ for better success, but the
Marquis attaching the valiant Armorand, and the Count the brave Grinaldo, they
were shamefully overthrown at the second Encounter, and after them fourteen of
the hardiest Knights of the Kingdom, insomuch that the Challengers being left
alone, Adelazia withdrew her self, exceedingly praising the valor and address
of the said Warriors, who had deservedly acquired unto themselves so great a
reputation in the world.

The evening being spent then in discourse, every one betook them to their
rest, but Griolanis longing to see the day in which he might combat, and enjoy
again the sight of his Mistress, could sleep but little, so that rising with the
Sun he resolved to be the first within the Lists, thereby to prevent the
strangers from dismounting any before his arrival, but considering with
himself how necessary it was for him to have his (...) a (...) of the Combat,
he went to her Chamber all armed, his Helmet and (...) excepted. Here I am,
said he as he came in, ready to avenge the insolence of these Knights that so
much wrong your beauty, Madam, will you give me leave to encounter them? Yes,
my Knight replied she, but the day being long enough for that business, let
others begin. Then calling for a most rich scarf she tied it cross his
Corsle^, which so much transported our Lover with joy, that he thought himself
in a Paradise of pleasure.

Returning then all due thanks and acknowledgement for this her favor they
espied nine Knights arriving, who were all dismounted at the first Encounter,
and after them the Marquis of Farlantes, and the noble Admiral of Corolandaya,
both brave Warriors, and the most renowned of that Kingdom, which made the
Spectators adjudge the victory to these strange Princes, when as Griolanis
having leave to descend, appeared within the Lists with a most martial
countenance, and very richly armed, to the unspeakable joy and admiration of
his fair Mistress, the Spectators forthwith changing of opinion began to clap
their hands, in token that all their hope rested in that Knight, but which
delighted them most of all was the sight of Adelazia's Picture, that he brought
in, and placed above the strange Princesses, with no small ceremony and respect.

This extraordinary act of his made the four Challengers think, that it was the
valiant Knight, which had filled the whole Country with amazement, so that
they exceedingly admired his brave and gallant demeanor, but hoping to make
his glory an accessory to their former triumph, they called for fresh horses,
and the strongest Lances they could meet withal, in which manner they
expected to see what he would do.

The Duke of Cardambes being to come first in play, because Griolanis had
touched his Shield, he presented himself with a most undaunted countenance, and
at the third sound of the Trumpets he put on with that violence, as at the
first Encounter his Lance flew into a thousand shivers, together with his
adversaries, who met him so strongly, that he made him lose both his stirrops,
himself passing on so unmoved, that all the world applauded him. This put
Falemond into such passion, as calling for a stronger Lance, he began to run
afresh against our Knight, but with far worse success then before; for being
dismounted with the violence of his adversaries blow he fell to the ground
hereft of his senses, to the exceeding joy of all the multitude, especially of
Adelazia, who thought her self the happiest Princess on the earth, in enjoying
so handsome and so valiant a Knight.

This done, Griolanis went straight to Elimen^'s Picture, and removing the
same, placed it beneath his Mistrisses, to the great content of all the people;
but Crisander succeeding Falamond, with a resolution to revenge his ill
fortune, ran against Griolanis with that fury, as he made him lose one of his
stirrops, himself being so terribly shaken with the Encounter, that he was
forced to take hold of his horses mane to uphold himself; Taking therefore a
second Lance, and breaking it to the very handle, he was so furiously
incountred, that both horse and man fell back to the ground in danger to have
been bruised in pieces.

He that had then beh^ld the Spectators, might have observed most different
passions, the beautiful Queen of Corolandaya expressing a most unspeakable
delight in her actions, and the fair Infanta of Filamonna, together with
Philotea, exceedingly grieving, the people full of acclamations and shouts of
joy, and the two remaining Knights bemoaning the ill fortune of their
associats, who nevertheless hoping to revenge them, the stout Grinaldo
advanced forwards, and setting spurs to his horse in a most violent manner
(after that Griolanis had set Philotea's Picture below his Mistresses) was as
bravely incountred, and though their Lances flew up into the air, yet sat
they fast and unmoved: This furious Encounter giving mavelous contentment to
all that were present, the two Knights called for new Lances, and meeting with
greater strength each brake his staff upon his enemy, Griolanis bowed a little
with the force of the blow, but the other was so stund, that he had much ado
to save himself from falling, wherewith he was so vexed, that calling for a
stronger Lance he charged him the third time; but so unfortunately, that his
horse falling upon him bruised his leg very sorely; at which fight the
beauteous Princess of Corangia was much displeased, and yet far more, when as
she saw her Picture taken down and placed with the rest, which served for the
glory of Adelazia's triumph; nevertheless reposing much confidence in the
valor of the great Caliph of Paran, she suppressed her grief, and caused her
Lover to be taken up, who showing more courage then hurt gat quickly on his
feet, avaunting (the better to excuse his fall) that Griolanis was the prime
Knight of the world.

In the mean time Armorand and having taken a resolution, either to vindicate,
or follow his friends misfortune, set spurs to his horse, and made three of the
bravest, and most furious courses, that ever was seen in Corolandaya, whereby he
acquired unto himself the repute of one of the ablest Warriors on the earth,
but Griolanis combatting for the honor of his Mistress, incountred him the
fourth time so dangerously, that he cast him clean over the crupper of his
horse, laying him along for dead.

The victory being thus gloriously achieved, he gave Alarina's Picture with
the rest to his Squire, and taking that of his Mistress down himself, with no
less respect and ceremony then before, he carried it to the Palace, laying the
others at his Ladies feet to her unspeakable joy. This done he descended to
welcome the strange Princes, to whom he seemed so accomplished and courteous,
that notwithstanding their received disgrace they could not choose but love him,
telling him withal that the world did him much wrong in denying him Altars;
whereupon, having embraced one another with many testimonies of affection,
Griolanis was going to the Princesses Pavilion, which exceedingly desired to
see him, when as there appeared four misshapen Dwarfs, who carrying each of them
a great Pillar of Jasper, advanced to the midst of the place, where making a
stand all together, the Pillars stood up of their own accord, and instantly
made an Arch, on the top whereof a little Cupid was seen holding a Garland of
Roses in his hand, at the bottom was a winding stair by which one might ascend
unto him, and upon the tops of of the said Pillars were those four deformed
creatures, which with Instruments in their hands began to play so melodiously,
as ravished all hearts and ears that heard them. These prodigious spectacles
striking all the assistants with amazement, Griolanis and the strange Princes
espied a small Table hanging at the Cupids feet, where they read these words:

J will not part with this Crown, but for the glory of a faithful Love. By all
my gods, said A(...)d, I Will be the first that shall prove this adventure, for
since I was never conscious to my self of any want of love to my dearest
Alarina I am persuaded this occasion is offered of purpose to mitigate my
grief, for having bin overcome in the quarrel of her beauty: Thereupon he
called for his Helmet, and unsheathing his sword, he drew near to the stairs,
upon which having made but one step, he felt himself charged with so many
blows, as he was forced to set both his knees to the ground, but rising thence
in a rage he behaved himself so manfully, that he gat up to the fifth step,
where the violence of the blows being redoubled, he was stricken down to the
earth, deprived of all sense, to the unspeakable grief of the beautiful
Alarina, who loving him most dearly was much troubled with this his disaster.

The valiant Crisander, no whit discouraged therewith, advanced next, but
notwithstanding his best endeavor to out-goe him, he could reach no higher
then the third step, where he found no better success then his companion, and
soon after Falemond and Grinaldo, who got up as high as the fourth: Whereupon
Griolanis casting his eyes toward his Mistress, that was then courteously
entertayning the strange Princesses, and comforting them for the misfortune of
their Lovers; drew forth his sword, and pressed on with such violence, that
without any stay he gat up to the sixth stair, but there found such resistance,
as was able to discourage another; nevertheless the contemplation of his
Ladies presence, before whom he chose rather to die* then any way to yield, so
revived his spirits, that (...) his forces, and redoubling his blows, he
ascended to the ninth (...)* but there found himself assaulted with such
strange violence, as he was ^ain to fall both on his hands and knees to save
himself; howbeit calling to mind; how un^^^thy he were of his Mistresses
favor, if he remained in that posture, he soon reassumed new strength, and
began so to lay about him, that he gat up to the last step, where his invisible
enemies forbear to strike him any longer, and that very seasonably, in regard
he was quite out of breath, and unable to subsist any longer.

The meditation of so glorious an adventure breeding in him an extreme delight,
by reason of the singular proofs he had given of an extraordinary affection, he
came near the little Cupid, and laying hold on the Crown of Roses, and offering
to pluck it away, his hand and arm were on a sudden so (...) unto it, as he
could not possibly withdraw them: Whereupon the fair Princesses, conceiving
immediately that the said Crown was reserved for one of them, stepped forth.

The first that ascended, was the beautiful Princess of Corangia, on whose
head Cupid and Griolanis set the Crown, which rendered a most excellentodour,
but taking it off presently again she was forced, not without shame and grief,
to give place to Phi(...), who finding no better entertainment made way to
Alarina, on whose head it remained somewhat longer, but at last was constrained
to withdraw to her unexpressable (...) with their misfortune, refused to
succeed them, whereupon the unparaleld Adelazia presenting her self, Cupid and
Griolanis fell on their knees before her, and instantly rising up again they
left the Crown on her head, which they had no sooner done, but the music
ceased, and with a most terribleclap of Thunder all vanished away, the said
precious flowers excepted, to the great ama^ement of all the Spectators, who
were astonished at the variety of such prodigious fights; Grionalis and his
Mistress remained full of joy and coment, postposing all worldly glory to their
present estate: The strange Princesses on the other side repined at the honor
which that excellent Queen had acquired, and wished themselves at home;
nevertheless seeing no remedy, they thought it best to extol and magnify her
with the rest of the company, and upon her entreaty were persuaded to go into
the Palace, where they were entertained with a most sumptuous supper, and a
Hall accompanied with all pleasure and delight.

CHAP. XXVI. The dreadful Enchantment of Griolanis, and the fair Adelazia.
THE hour of rest being come, all those Princes retired themselves unto their
Chambers; which were prepared for them; but of all most willingly the beauteous
Queen of Corolandaya, who mindful of her promise to her Lover, that seemed by
his passionate looks to crave some special favor a^ her hands, sent all her
women to bed, retayning only Arlandria, to whom being laid down, she spoke in
this manner. Dear Arlandria, I may no longer disguise my thoughts, the
confidence I have ever reposed in thy trust has bred a resolution in me, to
reveal unto thee at this present a secret of no small importance: The Knight
whom thou broughtest with thee, has captivated my soul with his beauty, my
love to him is beyond imagination; and to be short I am resolved to make him
King of Corolandaya; but since I have not yet disposed the affections and good
will of my subjects thereunto, and that undoubtedly he suffers much, for want
of liberty to impart himself unto me in public, I conceived it most fit to
show him some favor; In confidence therefore of his love, whereof the Crown of
Roses purchased me by his valor, is a proof sufficient; I have made him a
promise to entertain him this night in my Chamber, on condition, that he shall
have due regard to the greatness of my quality, and show the same respect in
his actions, which he would do in the eye of the whole world. As soon therefore
as every one shall be retired, being him to me.

In troth, Madam, said Arlandria, I marvel not that you are sensible of his
pain, for so amiable is his person, and his perfections such, as it is not
possible for any, not to wish him well; but Madam, will you give me leave to
tell you freely what I conceive? Most willingly, replied she, for since I
entrust thee with my secrets, I may not reject thy advice. I exceedingly
wonder, said Arlandria, how you can resolve to let him languish so long, and
satisfy your self with a bare discourse, since you are minded to make him your
Husband; It is to lose time, Madam, which hereafter you will repent, and all
this artifice, that is but the tormentor of man's felicity, serves to no
purpose; Not that I would persuade you to proffer him that, which must be the
reward of his most earnest suite, but Madam, being persuaded, as it is most
probable, that the height of his affection will not rest satisfied therewith,
I would counsel you not to show your self over-modest, and difficult. Nay,
said Adelazia; I mean not to resolve on any such thing, do what you are
bidden, and leave the rest to me. I will not contest with you, Madam, replied
Arlandria, only be pleased to remember, that Lovers observe time, place, and
persons, and look to make use of occasion, and fortune, when they are presented.

Hereupon going forth, she left this beautiful Queen full of strong passions;
Her affection persuading her to follow Arlandria's advice, and her modesty
forbidding her to entertain any such thought: Amidst this irresolution, she
waited the coming of her brave Knight, who considering with himself, that
opportunities are often lost through want of resolution and courage, and that
Lovers speed best, when they are somewhat daring, he kneeled down before his
Mistress, and in a most trembling manner taking her by the hand, he sixth his
lips thereon a good-while, and so not being able to utter his mind in words, he
fetched three or four sighs, wherewith that fair Queen, who took no small
delight to behold his respect in his fear, and his love in his silence, was so
affected, that growing impatient of his suffering, she thus spoke unto him;
Well, my Knight, is this all you have to say to me? Ah! Madam, replied he, my
heart is overcharged, and wants words to ease itself: What would you have me
say? Madam, I expect some favor, show it me as to your Husband, since you have
thought me worthy of that honor.

These words being uttered in such a sort, as did plainly discover a most
extraordinary passion wrought such effects in that excellent Princess, that
unable any longer to contain her desires, or to withstand the charming tears of
her Lover, thus said unto him; Verily, your perfections have no less power
over me, then your Sword has had over all those whom it does encounter; Get
you up, and swear unto me before this Damsel, that you will never marry any
other but me. Madam, said he, lifting up his eyes to heaven, and putting his
hand within hers, I swear unto you in the presence of God, whom I adore, and of
your faithful Arlandria, that I will marry you solemnly whenever you shall
please, and will never long after other beauty, and if ever I break this oath,
let heaven execute its fiercest vengeance on this head of mine.

This oath having satisfied his Lady, he straightway threw off his doublet on
the Table, and transported with joy, he got immediately to bed to her, where
they fell to mutual imbracements, to the incomparable delight, and
satisfaction of each other: Adelazia's lips were fastened to her Lovers, and his
no less amo^^os^y fixed on hers, she by the light of two Tapers that burnt fast
by, my^ed her self in his eyes, and he quite lo^^ himself in the contemplation
of their secret beauties which he beheld; To be short, a thousand blandishments
entertained them with fresh delights, until the heat of those fires being
cooled, they sought out new desires in their passions, which redoubled their
pleasure in such manner, as the night feeming but a moment, the day forced them
to part with much regret, and far less satisfied then before, nevertheless
assuring themselves they should not want meetings, since their love was
reciprocal, Griolanis stole away leaving his Mistress to her rest, where she
continued till noone, at which time she got up fully contented, that she had
met with so lusty and gallant an Husband. Thus loving each other entirely,
their minds were at quiet, their affections without disturbance, their visits
frequent, their discourse wholly taken up with the mutual assurances of their
affections, and their whole life so incomparably pleasant, as they might justly
have boasted their happiness before any Lovers whatsoever.

But envious fortune, which takes delight in crossing of our pleasures, and
bringing us in subjection, could no longer brook so happy, and so blisfull an
estate; for Maxiana, the great Inchantress, Aunt of Silvion, Prince of
Argilles, whom Griolanis flew in the quarrel of Adelazia's picture, as is
specified in the ninth Chapter of our second part, desirous to know what state
her Nephew was in, took her books, and conjuring up her spirits, had notice of
death, and of all that passed in Corolandaya; whereupon growing furious, she
prepared whatsoever charms her art could afford, and so transported her self
into Corolandaya, where she arrived three days after the secret Marriage of
these Lovers, and just at such time as they were all in dancing, and every one
standing by his Mistress.

This Sorceresse entering into the Hall with a burning Torch in her hand,
followed by three Maids all dischevelled, and carrying certain monstrous, and
hideous Serpents, came to the beauteous Wife of Griolanis, who stood quivering,
and thus spoke unto her; It is time thou should smart for the death of the
Prince of Argilles, since thy cruelty occasioned it, and that he which slew
him, should share with thee in the torment, His beauty made thee infringe a
Law, which proved fatal to thet unhappy Prince; Undergo therefore jointly, a
due and direful vengeance for it. Saying so, she threw her Torch on the
floor, which presently filled the Hall with as dreadful a flame, as all the
spectators astonished therewith, betook them to their heels, Griolanis only
excepted, who with his fair Mistress, standing fast, and unmoved, by virtue of
the Charms, were forth with environed with a terrible fire, and six horrible
Serpents, that seized on them, began to gnaw, and tear their faces and
breasts, with a cruelty no whit inferior to that of the flames, which made
them break forth into such doleful lamentations, and cries, as was easily
heard all over the Palace.

Ay me! said Adelazia, that such variety of delights, should be followed by so
great a torment, and that the glory I found in the fruition of such valor, and
beauty, as was in Griolanis* should now be turned into grief, by the cruel
usage of such Furies; Envious fates, what had I done, or this courteous Knight
committed, worthy of such hard measure? Ah I Griolanis, the loveliest of
mankind, the pains I suffer, you see is great, but far greater are yours to
me, then my own; your misery it is which I bewayl, and not mine, but since I
cannot succor you, be persuaded to patience.

Dearest Lady, replied Griolanis, it is your martyrdom, and not my torments,
that draw from me these complaints; for how is it possible I should behold
these wonders of nature perish before mine eyes, and not accuse the heavens of
injustice? The Prince of Argilles fell by my sword, it was most fit I alone
should rue it, yet are you made to parta^e in my sufferings, as I did in your
favors, neither does their cruelty rest here, I am made the spectator of your
misery: Hellish f^end, thou ought to have powered out thy spite and malice
on me, and have spared that beautiful face, those two little worlds of love,
that delicate skin, and not to scorch those fair eyes, the perfection of the
whole world; for mine own particular I could willingly endure thy revenge, were
it crueller, and never complain; but woe is me, thou art insensible to my
moans, and are more merciless then the Tiger; thou delightest in the horror of
a thing, which might mollify the very stones: Thou think to triumph over my
valor and courage; alas! thou art deceived, I will cut these Furies in a
thousand pieces, and then must thou look for no better usage at my hands.

With these words he laid hold on his Sword, and whilst he thought to kill
those Serpents, he ran her through the body, and laid her grovelling as if she
had been dead; But she instantly getting up, and plucking the Sword out of her
bosom, thrust it into Griolanis breast, being led by the same desire, to rid
him of such troublesome creatures, and preserve him from being devoured, which
rendered the spectacle most doleful, and worthy of all compassion. But this
divellish Witch took unspeakable delight in it, and was so well pleased to see
them two butcher each other in so cruel a manner, that having remained there
above half an hour, she quitted that hell, which she named, THE MARTYRDOM OF
GRIOLANIS AND ADELAZIA; and meeting Falimond, Crisander, Armorand, and
Grinaldo, who moved with the Lovers doleful cries, were hastening to their
succor, she resolved to make use of them in the execution of her designs. You
shall serve, said she, to further my enterprise, whefore I command you to
defend the passage to these wretches, against all such as would come to their
rescue, for which purpose striking them all with a wand that was in her hand,
she so enchanted them, as they remained fixed with their Armor on, like to four
Towers, before the gate of the Palace Court, dreaming of nothing but to combat
whomsoever should appear before them.

These Princes were a guard sufficient to have prolonged this Enchantment,
nevertheless, this old Hag desirous, if possible, to make it last eternally,
raised up at the stayres foot, a most hideous Serpent, fifteen foot long, with
a most terribl^ Monster, as big as an Elephant, having the head and breast of a
dreadful man, the arms hairie, and great as a tree, with a very keen axe in
his hand, the back parts resembling a Bears, his paws were arm^d with crooked
claws a cubit long; and to render the enttry more difficult, yet she caused
Griolanis arms to be brought, which she placed at the Hall door with such
powerful Conjurations, that she made them have the same motions, and adresse,
as if the Knight had been in them, adding moreover all that ever she could
devise to make the (...) invincible: the spectacle having somewhat satisfied
her, a Pillar appeared before the gate with a Table, hanging thereon wherein
these words we^e written.

Prophecy,

AProach not hither, unless thou be the most valiant in the world, for these
Enchantments shall never cease, until the excellent Turtle, and the dreadful
Lion, issuing out of the same Prison encounter each other within the flames*
Then the strayed blood shall be known, beauty shall resume her former glory,
and the punishment of a Law violated shall be converted into pleasures and
delights.

And so hyding her self in the midst of a cloud, with her three attendants, she
became on the sudden invisible, leaving behind her plenty of tears and
lamentations, and a Town full of doleful, and confused cries, but especially
of Alarina's, Elemina's, Philoteas, and Marselina's, whose griefs for the
loss of their Lovers no comfort could assuage; Howbeit considering that tears
were unprofitable, and that other means of succor were to be sought out, they
returned to their Countries with a resolution to send throughout the world in
the search of the bravest Knights to anull this Enchantment, which example was
followed by Adelazia's Damsels, whereby it came to pass, that the fame of
this enchantment being spread abroad, there came from all parts a great number
of Knights to Corolandaya, for to undertake the deliverance of the said Lovers.

CHAP. XXVII. The Giant Gorgophon being sent Ambassador to Gardacia from
Moranteon, Sultan of Circassia, steals away the beauteous Armazia; he is
driven into the Isle of Corolandaya, and proves the Adventure of the martyrdom
of Adelazia.
THe renowned beauty of Armazia, Princess of Gardacia, having filled the
whole world with admiration, so inflamed the heart of Moranteon, Sultan of
Circassia, that without the possession of so rare a creature, he thought he
should never pass his days in quietness, willing he was to see her, and
become a suitor to her Father for her, being persuaded that the consideration
of his power and greatness, above other Pagan Princes, would soon procure him
what he desired, but fearing lest his extreme deformity might breed a contempt
of him in the Princess, being of ill shape, of a Salvage countenance,
flat-nosed, bobber-lipt, hollow-eyed, corpulent and crooked, he conceived it
much better to treat the match by Ambassadors, then to alienate her affection
by the view of his defects; Having therefore considered all his Subjects, and
finding none fitter for that employment, he sent Messengers to Gorg^phon,
Colonel of the Giants, who lived in the redoubted Island, not far from his
Kingdom, desiring him to r^pai^ unto him about a business of great importance,
which he was to impart unto him. This Giant the greatest then living, the
strongest of all Pagans, the most terrible and furious amongst men, being an
intimate friend of the Soldans, went straight to Circassia, where being
arrived, and nobly entertained; after a world of Ceremonies and Caresses,
Moranteon thus spoke unto him.

I am persuaded you cannot be ignorant of the power of that little god, which
challenges a right over all men living, and since your self have felt the
power of his Scepter, you will not find it strange to see me from military
exployts, and the love of my people, to settle my affection on a woman; I shall
therefore tell you freely, that the Princess of Gardacia is she that
captivates my soul, and that without the fruition of that blessedness, which
he only can expect that shall enjoy her I cannot possibly subsist: I have a
strong confidence in your love, and it is in your power exceedingly to oblige
me, by undertaking a voyage to the Emperor her Father, to demand her in
marriage, declaring unto him, that the Crown of Circassia is a purchase
sufficient to satisfy his Daughters vastest desire and ambition; Your
presence, together with the fear of disobliging us, will make him seriously to
consider the demand, ere he give a denial: But in case he should prove so
averse, as to return an answer not suitable to our desires, spare not to let
him know our resentment, and that his indiscretion will cost him no less then
the loss of his Empire.

Well, said Gorgoph^n, I intend not to amuze my self, with giving you other
testimonies of my love and friendship, then by the careful managing of the
charge committed to my trust; Armazia is yours, and though her Father should
prove so proudly insolent, as to reject the honor you do him, you shall not
be put to the trouble of raising an Army, I Will cut him into a thousand pieces,
and bring away his Daughter in despite of all his subjects: Let nothing
therefore disturb you, but prepare your self to receive us, as if we were
already coming.

And so causing a ship to be made ready, he imbarqued himself with a young
Giant that attended him, and with a favorable wind in few days arrived in
Gardacia, where getting a shore he went toward Parmonda, the place of the
Princes ordinary residence, but understanding that the Emperor and his
Daughter were gone to hunt in a Forest there by, he caused a country fellow
to guide him thither, and came just as they were uncoupling the Hounds.

The Emperors Knights seeing these two dreadful Giants appear on the sudden
were extremely dismayed, and imagining that they had a purpose to assault them,
they prepared themselves for defense, though they were mightily terrified with
their furious countenances; nevertheless choosing rather to dye a thousand
times, then leave their Prince and his Daughter in extremity, who trembled in
the midst of them, they began to advance, when as Gorgoph^n testifying in his
carriage, that he had no intent to do them any harm, said unto them. Forbear
foolish Pigmies, for I could soon make an end of you if I meant to fight, but
being come hither for another end, you shall not at this time feel the thunder
of my Curtelas: Which of you is the Emperor? I am he, answered Aliander, all
pale and wan with fear, would you have any thing with me (...) Mighty Monarch,
said he, the gods resolve to augment your glory and g^eathesse, so as you will
make use of the good they intend you: You behold ^^^g^phon, Colonel of the
Giants, Lord of the redoubted Islands, and ^ervant to the great Sultan of
Circassia, who has sent me to let you know, that he very much desires to be
your Son in law, and that it lies in you to make Armazia the happiest Lady in
the world, by joining the Crown of Circassia, to that which she hopes from you,
this offer if you will not embrace, then prepare your self for war: Now let me
hear what answer you will return.

Valiant Warrior, replied the Emperor, who did not look forsuch gentle words,
the Prince of Circassia honors me very much, in seeking my alliance, and no
less am I obliged unto you for the pains you have taken in coming hither, to
let us understand his desire, whereunto I should presently consent, if I could
without blame pass by theregard, which I owe unto a people that render me
great by the obedience they yield me, but I am first to consult with them about
it, since there is question of giving them a new Prince, in expectation whereof
if you please to repose your self a little with us, we will do you all the
honor we may.

This answer having marvellously contented the Giant, who could not
sufficiently admire the beauty of Armazia, which already triumphed over his
liberty, they went on hunting, wherein with much delight they spent above two
hours, during which time G^rgophon entertained himself in the corner of a Wood
in this manner. What, said he, can I affect Armazia, after I have once demanded
her for the content of another? or rather should I leave her to the hope of any
whomsoever, seeing she may serve for mine? She is too fair, I have too much
love, and without treason to my passion, it is not fit for me to speak
otherways, but for mine own content; yet what will the Emperor her Father say,
if he should hear me speak in this sort, and what cause would the Sultan have
to complain of me for depriving him of a beauty that was done to his merit?
They would both wonder at this change, and questionless they would exclaim of
me, but what is that to me? I am to love my self more then others, and if the
Father of Armazia do not satisfy my desire, I carry that by my side which
shall procure it me: And if Moranteon will not be contented with another
Princess, whereof I will make him Master ere it be long, I shall not much
care; for neither am I his subject, nor do I fear his power, if he assayl me I
will defend my self, and were he mightier then he is I will soon make him
quiet: The Emperor then must be frighted with menaces, if fair means will not
prevayl.

Whereupon getting to horse, he went to seek out Aliander, when as he heard the
Forest resound with cries, complaints, and a very dreadful noise, so that
advancing forwards he met with nine or ten Knights flying away as fast as they
could drive, of whom not being able to learn the cause of their fear, he went
on til he came where a great and furious Serpent was devouring one of Armazia's
women, and promising no better entertainment to that incomparable beauty, which
with fear was fallen down under a bush with her cousin the excellent Agriclea.
The desire he had to oblige this fair one by some service having made him
suddenly to approach he drew out his Cymetar, and giving his horse, that by no
means would come on to his compani^^, ^e discharged so mighty a blow on the
body of this creature, as might w^ll have divided an Anvile, but the scales
wherewithal he was covered, being impenetrable he did but ^ow a little with
it, nevertheless it forced hi^ to quit his pray, for to make head against the
Giant, who ^o w^it dismayed, gave him another full on the head with such a
prodigeo^^fall, as made his brains fly out in five or six places, sending him
dead to the ground.

This dangerous enemy being in case to hurt no body any more, Gorgophon went to
Armazia, and finding her in aswound, he took her up in his arms for to recover
her, howbeit considering that he should never have a more a favorable
opportunity he remounted on his horse, after he had set Agriclea behind his
companion, and making away with incredible speed he got to the port, where his
ship rode, into the which he embarked himself with his rich pray, so joyful
for having brought his designs to such an happy issue, as he would not for all
the Crowns of the world have exchanged the content he was in.

This while the Emperor and his Knights, grown somewhat more confident,
returned to the succor of Armazia, but not finding her, and beholding the
Serpent slain in that sort, they imagined that none but Gorgophon could give
that dreadful blow, whereupon they concluded that he was gone toward the
City with the Princess* and the beauteous Infanta of Clariana, so that with
this opinion they left the Forest, but not long after they met with two
Saylors, who acquainted them with all the business, and assured them that the
two Giants were at sea with the Princesses. At this news some ran to the ships
for to pursue them, others fell to crying out, and complaining in such manner,
as nothing was heard but strange lamentations.

On the other side Armazia and her fair cousin were in as bad a case, for
coming to their senses, and beholding themselves in the power of those hideous
Monsters they presently dissolved into tears, and took on most grievously,
being fully resolved to cast themselves into the sea, which doubtless they had
performed, if Gorgophon, qualifying his proud and barbarous humor, had not
assured them that they should receive no displeasure. Madam, said he, to his
fair Mistress, before whom he was on his knees, moderate these sighs and tears,
Gorgophon is not so cruel as you, think he is, nor will he ever have any thing
from you, but what what you shall be pleased freely to grant him, time shall
acquaint you with his merits, and the good office he did you, snatching you out
of the jaws of that Serpent, where your death was inevitable, shall be followed
with so many services, that it may be you will judge him worthy of some favor.

This speech bringing a little comfort to these afflicted Ladies, they wisely
resolved to make use of the power their beauties had gotten over these Giants,
and to entertain them kindly, to decline the violence, which they exceedingly
feared from them, in regard whereof the excellent Armazia answered him thus.
Giant, if you carry a mind noble enough to observe these promises you have made
us, we may in time dispose our selves to wish you well, but if you offer to
force us in any thing, be con^ident that our deaths shall prevent your cruelty,
and that we will never want courage to rid our selves out of the world:
Further, if you desire any way to oblige me, do not carry me to Circassia, for
the Sold^n being so deformed, as it is reported unto me, I shall never endure
to come near him; you merit me thinks far more then he; wherefore keep this
good fortune for yourself, and deserve it more by respect, then by your
services.

Madam, replied the Giant (transported with extreme joy at this answer, which
Armazia reserving her self for Rozalmonds content, had made of purpose to hold
him in hand, hoping by some accident or other to get out of his power) Madam,
be assured that I will dye a thousand deaths rather then do any thing shall be
distasteful to you, I will gladly attend all the time you shall please to
ordain for my suffering, in the mean while we will go to the redoubted Islands,
of which I am Lord, where the power of all the Monarchs of the world shall
never take you from thence, being able enough to conserve my self, and defend
you; But Madam, in sign of the grace that you promise me, permit me to kiss
these more then delicate hands. Most willingly, said Armazia, who desired to
acquire an absolute command over his will, and I think my cousin will show no
less favor to your companion, saying so they tendered them their hands, which
these Giants kissed with so much ardour and affection, as they had much ado to
contain themselves from passing further, but that they were restrained by the
hope they had of enjoying all quietly, wherefore being marvellously
contentented they fell to discourse with these Princesses, and in this sort
were carried by the wind, which rising very high drove them by the will of
heaven, that would not permit the undoing of these two incomparable beauties,
not into the redoubted Islands, but into the Kingdom of Corolandaya, where the
fame of Griolanis and Adelazia's enchantment possessing them with a mavelous
desire to see it, they landed there, and the next day went to Agricant with
some hope for those Ladies to meet with some redress of their miseries.

The fire which showed very horrible out of the windows, and the lamentation of
those unfortunate Lovers, having moved Armazia to pity, she turned her to
Gorgophon and said unto him; Sir, if your valor can give these poor wretches,
any relief you shall do me a most acceptable service to succor them. Madam,
you have said enough, answered Gorgophon, for if they were in the hands of all
the Devils of hell I would go and fetch them out, since you have commanded me
unto it; whereupon having laced on his Helmet, he made bravely to the door,
where the four Pagan Knights charged him very rudely all at once, but nothing
abashed therewith he gave Falemond so dangerous a blow on the head, that he
extended him on the ground (from whence by the force of Enchantment, he stirred
not til after the combat) but presently feeling two mighty strokes on his
Helmet laid on by the gentle Armorand, and the strong Grinaldo, he turned
toward them with such fury, that if the charms had not hindered his Curtelass
from drawing blood of them, he had cleft Grinaldo to the teeth, nevertheless
the blow which he discharged on his shield was so violent, as it laid him along
by his companion, to the extreme discontent of Armorand, and the gallant
Crisander, who suddanly charging him made him recoyle two or three steps back,
wherewith he was so incensed, that with his two first blows he overthrew them
both on the floor: That done, he advanced toward the stayres, and no whit
dismayed either with the Serpents fearful hissing, or the dreadful howling of
the Monster, which made at him with horrible rage, he went to encounter them,
and began one of the most terrible combats that ever was seen; He sustained
(...) incredible courage the blows which the Monsters cutting hatchet laid off
his shield, his Curtelas was always deseending on the Serpent, and finding
himself so shrewdly pressed by two such mighty enemies, he fought with such
unreasonable fury, as made all the houses round about to shake.

This b^ckering having lasted almost two hours, the Monster advanced his
mighty arms, and discharging a thundering blow at the head of Gorgophon the
combat without doubt had been terminated, if warily observing the coming of
this tempest he had not lightly slipped aside, letting that dangerous steel
enter into the earth, which flying out of the Monsters hands, he fell down
instantly thereupon altogether without vigiouror force, whereat Gorgophon was
exceeding glad, for thinking he had then no more to deal withal save that
huge Serpent, he valiantly opposed his shield to him, but he presently saw a
Knight descend, covered all over with fire, who giving him a cruel blow on the
head, made him set his hands to the ground, and straight way redoubling another
on his cuirace, laid him all along on the earth, from whence he was suddenly
carried, not knowing by whom, beyond the outer gate of the Palace.

Hereat, when he came again to himself, he was so mad, that he made a vow
never to depart out of the Island before he saw the end of the adventure, and
because (said he, full of rage and despite) that the destinyes have not
reserved it for me, I will combat first with all such as shall present
themselves to prove it; Whereupon he caused Armazia, and her cousin to be put
into a little tower which was hard by the Gate, under the guard of the Giant
that accompanied him, and compelling those of Agricant to set him up a rich
Tent, he lodged himself therein, protesting anew, not to suffer any to try the
adventure before they had combatted with him, whence it came to pass, that
being endued with extreme forces, he vanquished in the space of a month above
forty Knights, which came from all parts thither; But let us give him time to
fill the world with the renown of his valor, and to garnish the walls of
Armazia's Tower with shields, whilst we discourse a little of Rozalmond.

CHAP. XXVIII. Rozalmond arrives in Martaria, undoes the Enchantment of the
Crystal Tower, delivers Amadis, Floridan, and Lucibel, with their Mistresses;
they are afterward driven into C^rol^ndaya and prove the adventure of
Adelazia's Martyrdom.
FOrtune does ordinarily cross the designs of men, Rozalmond having left
Alci^^mants Hermitage, with a resolution to go unto Tramazond, sailed for two
days together with a prosperous gale, but but upon the appearing of the third,
the wind grew high, and so contrary, as the Mariners were constrained to turn
their sails, and comply with it; Being carried then by the ordinance of
heaven, he continued a whole week and better, in some danger of shipwreck, but
at the end thereof the rage of the Sea being well allayed, he came to coast along
by the Isle Du-bois in the Empire of Martaria, where the Tower of crystal, in
which Amadis, Floridan, and Lucibel, with their Ladies were enchanted,
possessing him with a mavelous desire to know what it was, he caused himself
to be landed, and going to the place, by fortune he found the Emperor newly
arrived there with a Pagan Knight, who more audacious then strong and valiant,
was come thither with a purpose to combat the Lions, howbeit his courage, that
contemned the greatest dangers, when he was in a chamber, proved so abject at
the sight of those furious creatures, as he would not so much as touch his
sword, remonstrating unto the Emperor, that to undertake a Combat, where death
was so assured, was nothing else but rashly to cast away his life.

Which observed by out Warrior, that could not choose but laugh at the Pagans
boutade, he approached to the Tower, whereupon beholding written in letters of
Gold; The Paradise of the Princes of Greece; he fixed his eyes attentively upon
them, and presently knew not Amadis, whom he had never seen, but Floridan and
Lucibel, whereat being wonderfully glad he was in doubt whither he should
deliver them for to render them again to the world, or leave them still in a
place so full of bliss; nevertheless, considering that a Prince owes more to
his glory, then his pleasure, he resolved to employ all his strength for to
bring this enchantment to an end, whereupon he was going to draw out his Sword,
but desiring first to inform himself of the cause of so sweet a captivity, he
returned to the Emperor, and setting one knee to the ground, he said unto him;
Great Monarch, I could be willing to undertake the finishing of this
Enchantment, so as your Majesty would be pleased to declare the story of it
unto me. That were to renew my sorrows, answered the Emperor, notwithstanding
I will satisfy you in few words.

The Sea, that many times brings strange Vessels into these coasts, having one
day landed two Knights not far from hence, they were incountred by some of my
men at Arms, who more insolent then I would have had them, set upon them for to
make them my prisoners, but being very valiant, they defended themselves with
such courage, as they left thirty or forty of them, together with two Giants
dead in the place, and which is more, one of them retired into a wood thereby,
in despite of certain troops that came to succor their friends, the other,
who fought unarmed, remained behind so wounded, that he was fain to be carried
to my Palace, where I committed him to my Chirurgions care, reserving him for a
sacrifice to my gods, but I quickly fell from that resolution, and set him at
liberty in acknowledgement of the service his companion did me two days after
by killing a great and dreadful Monster, which spoiled all the Country, and
considering the exceeding valor he had showed in the combat against my people,
I began to affect him very much. In the mean time I caused the other Knight to
be sought after, that I might recompense him for so great a benefit, howbeit he
would never present himself in Arms, whether it were that he feared my
displeasure, or that he had some other design, as we have conjectured since,
but disguising himself in the habit of a woman, he caused himself to be brought
hither as a slave, and to make short, being endued with a most rarebeautie he
appeared so amiable, as my Daughters could not to endure to be without his
company, especially Palmirenna, who was to succeed unto my Crown, had not her
bad life given me just cause to dis-inherit her; To tell you all that passed
between them I am notable, but so it was, that mistrusting no practice amongst
them, I left themto so great a liberty, as Amplamira, the middlemost of the
three that you behold, being made acquainted with the secrets of her eldest
Sister and her Slave, yielded to the affection of that strange Knight, unto
whom I had given his life; and the third, which would show no more obedience
than the rest, became passionately in love with the Knight whom you see there
in the upper part of the Tower with her.

Nature that obliges us to the care of our childrens well-doing, having
persuaded me to bestow them richly in marriage, I made choice of the heir of
the mighty King of Cabilla, the valorous Sultan of Aralafia, and the King of
Filzandria, to support my Crown with their greatness: but being upon the point
of leading them to Church, this Slave with the first Knight coming armed at
all parts, under color of succouring two unfortunate Lovers, which they said
were at the Court-gate in a Coach, they caused my Daughters to go thither, who
being intelligent with them, got suddenly into the Coach, and galloped away
with that speed, as they were instantly out of sight, whereof being exceeding
sensible, I commanded them to be pursued, when as this Slave lifting up the
Vizier of his Helmet, told me, that he was not a woman as I had believed until
then, but a Knight named Amadis, Prince of Greece and Trebisond. At these words
some of my Knights advanced for to stay him, howbeit he laid him that first
presented himself, dead at my feet with a blow of his fist, and discharging his
Sword on the Helmet of a very valiant Gentleman, called Meander, who arrived
but that morning, he cleft him down to the shoulders, and so departed like
lightning for to follow the Coach. To what end should I relate all things in
particular unto you? briefly they got to the Seaside after they had slain
above six hundred Knights, and with the assistance of three or four Knights
errant, that came thither by chance, they imbarqued themselves in despite of a
thousand Knights, which endeavored to arrest them.

Away they sailed them, as they hoped with a prosperous wind, but the gods who
never suffer so foul a crime to rest unpunished, drove them the very same day
into this Island, where having invested them with four thousand Knights I had
taken them in their beds, and executed some horrible vengeance on them, if I
had not been prevented by the arrival of an old Sorceresse, who unexpectedly
appeared with a flaming Torch in her hand, made certain circles, and muttered
diverse obscure words, which were no sooner uttered but there fell so cruel a
storm of huge Hayl-stones, as above five hundred of my Knights were knocked
down therewith, and my self constrained to fly for shelter to these houses you
see, from whence after the sky was cleared again, I beheld this Tower erected
in the place of the house wherein they were; Now judge, Sir, whether this be
not a strange affliction unto me, and whether I have not reason to wish them in
my power, for to wash away the affront they have done me with their blood.
