Mighty Prince, said Rozalmond, (who had been much delighted with this
discourse) the Heavens do sufficiently testify by the care they have taken of
these Knights, that they do not approve of the revenge you desire, I could
give you better counsel, if your Majesty could be pleased to accept of it:
These Knights, of whom you speak, are all Lords of a quality, nothing inferior
to yours, of whom the first according to report, is son to the mighty Amadis
of Greece: the second, whom I know very well, is Heir to the Sovereign Monarch
of the Persians, and the third is Nephew to the great King of France; seek not
their ruin then for an offense they have done you, compelled thereunto by love,
but receive them like a gentle and merciful Father, and if you wish for their
deliverance, let it be to rejoice with them in their alliance, which shall so
secure you, as all the Princes of Paganism shall not dare to look on you, but
for your service; If therefore you can carry a mind inclined to pardon, then I
am ready to undertake the restoring of them unto the world, if not I will never
be the instrument of their destruction by putting them in your power.

You amaze me, said the Emperor, in telling me that these three Knights are
such great Princes, in which regard I blame not my daughters so much as I have
done, but my resentment will not permit me so lightly to pass by such enormous
an offense. O but you must Sir, replied Rozalmond, at least wise if you will
appear as generous, as I know you are, and in the assurance thereof I will no
longer defer this Enterprise.

Whereupon drawing out his rich sword, he advanced toward the Lions, which
rose with fury, and at the first onset discharged so mighty a blow on the leg
of him that was next him, that having cut through all the hair, he gave him a
great gash in the flank, whilst the other fastening his claws on his Shield,
labored to tear it from his arm; nevertheless he bravely resisted him, and
desiring to lose no time, he struck him so strongly on the paw, that he sent it
divided from his body to the ground, which made him roar most dreadfully, at
the noise whereof Armelina, Orestia, and Melia, which seemed to be asleep at
the foot of the Tower, presently start up, and transforming themselves into
horrible Centaurs, flew all at one instant on Rozalmond, who was therewith
marvellously troubled, not knowing well where to bestow his sword; the Lions
pressed him with their claws, the Centaurs showred blows on him with their heavy
clubs, and thinking to avoid the fury of the one, he fell into the rage of the
others, howbeit nothing dismayed he laid with such violence at the body of one
of those Lions, as he cut him in two pieces, and turning withal toward a
Centaur, he struck him so dangerously on the head, that though his Sword
lighted flatling, he overthrew him to the earth, where instantly changing her
shape, she reassumed that of Almerina, who began to slumber as before, which
made him resolve not to strike the Centaurs any more with the edge of his
Sword, turning all his fury then against the remaining Lion, that had plucked
his Shield from his arm, he ran him so lustily into the belly, as he laid him
dead by the other.

Being very glad at the defeat of these enemies, and the recovery of his
Shield, he made head afresh against the Centaurs, which so laid upon him, that
he felt himself bruised all over with their heavy strokes, nevertheless he
avoided them as well as he could, and at the length found the means to fasten a
blow with the flat of his sword full upon the body of one of them, wherewith
being overthrown she reassumed her former shape, and so did the other not long
after, who abandoning her horrible figure, took the form of Orestia again, at
which our Warrior very much rejoicing advanced to the Tower, and with the
pummell of his sword, he knocked the Crystal with such force, as it brake
into a thousand pieces, making so great and dreadful a noise, that the Island
being covered over with a thick Fog, shaked for two hours together, at the end
whereof the Sun receiving its former light, neither the crystal Tower, the
Lovers, nor the ship wherein Rozalmond came were to be seen, only a Pillar
appeared in the midst of the place, upon which Rozalmond read this inscribed.

Vrganda to the Emperor of Martaria.

GReat Monarch, wonder not if thy daughters, destined to the Princes of Greece,
follow the way of their glory, thou shall one day go and find them in
Corolandaya, whither now I conduct them, for to have thy share in the
contentment of their Nuptials, and to bow after their example before unknown
Altars.

Well Sir, said Rozalmond, did not I tell you that Heaven had taken the defense
of these Knights in hand, and that therefore you should not wish their
destruction? It has miraculously delivered them from your power, that they
might not be subjected to your displeasure, will you still persist then in
opposing the ordinances thereof, and not consider that they are your children,
which fly from you that they may not leave you the regret for having followed
rather the motions of a Tyrant, then a Father?

Without doubt, answered the Emperor, (and caressing him as if he had been his
Son) your reasons are such, as I am resolved to yield unto them, but let me
entreat you to stay, and refresh your felfe here a while with me, and withal
to let me know who you are* Sir, replied Rozalmond, I have such important
affairs, as I may not well sojourn here above a day at the most, yet to obey
you I will make it up two, and to testify unto you how much I glory in the
honor of your favor, I will tell you that, which for some particular reasons
I would otherwise conceal from all the world, and will freely confess unto
you, that I am Rozalmond of Greece, son unto Spheramond, Emperor of Parthia,
and very near of kin to those Princes, whom I desire you to call your children.

Noble friend, said the Emperor, embracing him a new, I am more contend with
this encounter of you, than with the acquisition of a Monarchy, I am not
ignorant of the glory your Fathers have gotten in the world, and yet I am
persuaded that you surpass them far in valor, wherefore I shall make a dear
account of the honor of your alliance, so that with all my heart I forgive my
daughters, and will go into Corolandaya, since they are to be there, in
assurance whereof you shall see (during the two days, which you promise to
abide here) what Bonfires I will cause to be made in Cardana for joy of their
marriages, which at their return shall be renewed all over my Empire: Whereupon
he returned to the City with Rozalmond, who was entertained there with a world
of magnificense and triumph.

In the mean time Amadis, Floridan and Lucibel were sailing on the Sea, so
infinitely satisfied with the free enjoying of their Mistresses, as they past
away eleven days insensibly; at the end whereof they arrived in Corolandaya,
where the mavelous enchantment of the Queen having arrested them, they
resolved to prove the adventure, and accordingly Lucibel and Floridan having
been after a long and dangerous combat vanquished by Gorgophon (more by the
advantage of an armor and shield, which Diabolion the Inchanter had given him,
as to one that he held to be the firmest Pillar of Paganism.)

Amadis putting on his good arms, and presenting himself in the place ran
against the Giant with such force, that incountring in the midst of the course,
they were both of them carried so rudely to the earth, as they remained a
pretty while astonished; nevertheless indignation having raised both with
equal fury they drew out their swords, wherewith they began so cruelly to cut
one another, that in a moment the ground was all strewed with pieces of their
armor: Gorgophon, who thought there was not a man in the world able to resist
the fury of his Curtelas, discharged most dreadful blows, but our Warrior
knew so well how to decline them, and to make him such sharp returns, that the
combat became most terrible, their arms were al dyed red with blood, and as
often as their weapons were in the air, every one looked to see their heads
thundered in pieces, Gorgophon beheld Armazia, Amadis cast his eye on his
Palmirenna, wherewith they were so animated, that the horrible effects of their
rage drew pity from all the assistants: Four hours being past since the
beginning of the combat, Gorgophon enraged, for that he had no advantage of his
enemy, took his Fauchion in both his hands, and advancing it he let it descend
with such violence on Amadis his shield, as dividing it in two it opened his
arm that sustained it, and forced him to set his knees to the ground, which so
incensed our Knight, that rising up in a mighty chafe, he discharged such a
stroke on his Helmet, as made a wound two fingers deep in his head, and
constrained him withal to stagger in that sort, as he had much (...) keep
himself from fal^ing* but being (...) by shame, (...) the fight with such
honor, that caused all the Spectators to tremble.

In (...) of them possessed with equal fury, after six hours (...), and
without taking of breath, they (...) their sword^ (...) in their hands, and at
one (...) discharging upon each other with most strange force, Gorgophon with
the violence of the blow fell down backward from his (...) to the (...), quite
deprived of all sense, and his casque so full of blood, that (...) he had been
(...), had not the Giant his companion sp^^dily (...) him; on the other side
Amadis not able to support the fury of that which he had received, dropped
presently after to the earth in like manner, with so little appearance of
(...), that Palmirenna tea^ing her hay^, began ^o (...) his death, but his
Helmet being suddenly opened, he came straightway to himself agai^e, and was
carried to the Marquis of Belt^^^^'s house; where the Chyrurgions having found
his wounds to be very dangerous, promi^^d notwithstanding to cure him in a
month, and Gorgophon in six weeks.

CHAP. XXIX. Rozalmond (...) with Trasiclea, leads (...) Alcidamants (...), her
regrets upon his arms, their (...) and Reconciliation.
Rozalmond having been three days in Cardana, most magnificently honored, and
entertained, departed with infinite discontent to the Emperor, who to testify
the esteem he made of him, conducted him in person to the port, where with many
protestations of service and friendship out Knight embarquing himself, put
forth presently to sea, and ^ayling with a prosperous gale toward Tramazond,
the remembrance of his Armazia, of whom he had not heard any news since he left
her, representing itself unto his mind, helped him to pass away the time with
many sweet and pleasing thoughts. Beauteous Mistress, said he to himself, you
have reason to forget my services, and to engage your self under the power of
another, since I have absented my self so long from you to follow the world,
and yet I am so confident of your virtue, that in stead of fearing a change in
you, I will believe that you attend me with very great impatience, and that you
still conserve me that part in your heart, which heretofore you have promised
me, in regard whereof I swearby that incomparable beauty of yours, not to
undertake any other adventure, but to return instantly unto you, as soon as I
have drawn the excellent Knight of the Pal^^ from that hermitage, where the
best of his days is so unbef^^^ingly (...).

Having past eleven or twelve days with a favorable wind (...), at length he
arrived in the Kingdom of Claricana, where the (...) having assured him that
his shortest way to Tarsipolis, was to go^ thither by land, he caused himself
with his Squite and horses to be set (...), and traveling along, in three days
together he met with no adven^^^e, but at the end thereof, and at such time as
the Sun was in the midst of his course, he perceived a Knight coming out of a
Forest, whereinto he was entering, who bearing a Phoenix with two heads in his
shield, sat with such a grace on his Steed, and wore such brave and rich Arms,
being all covered over with azure and gold, as he had a mavelous desire to
know him, and to try whether he were the same he seemed to be; whereupon fair
and softly advancing he desired him to break a Lance with him for the beauty
of his Mistress, but this Knight returning him no answer, nor so much as taking
any notice of him, rode on as his horse pleased to carry him, which at first
somewhat netled Rozalmond, thinking he ought to have been more courteous,
howbeit observing that he went hanging down his head, and that may be he was in
some deep muse, whereby he was detayned from hearing him, he followed on the

Jealousy, false jealousy, how many tears will thou cost me, and what pains
do I see prepared for the punishment of so great a fault? Ah my Knight! I
should have been more temperate in mine anger, I should have heard you before I
had forbid you my presence, and should have considered that I was too rashly
displeased with that which proceeded our acquaintance; had I been more advised,
or less curious, we should at this present have lived contented, a thousand
pleasures would have accompanied our delights, and not caring much for this

for another.

These words finishing with sighs marvellously a^^^ed Rozalmond, who could not

Declare then unto me who you are, replied Rozalmond, That is it, answered the

Being first obliged by promise, said ou^ Warrior, it is reason I should

O Madam! said Rozalmond, lighting presently from his Horse for to render her

Valiant Warrior, answered she, discovering her face, the more civilly to

Madam, replied Rozalmond, (vaulting into his saddle, with much wonder at such

^^^^nesse for it.

Brave Palms (continued she throwing her Helmet on the ground, and unbuckling

Whereupon rising up with Rozalmonds help, she went as far as the Grot, where

This poor Hermit, coming softly along in regard of his weakness, perceiving

Well, Madam, said Rozalmond then, (wonderfully well contented with that which

That done, they returned all three to the Grot, from whence Rozalmonds Squire

caused the Palms to be taken out of his Shield, and a burning rock upon an
Hermitage, to be painted in stead thereof, for which cause he was always

Alcander to the valiant Knight of Greece.

EXcellent Prince, if you consider, that virtue and greatness do not exempt

necessary for your grief, in a resolution to receive all things patiently from

This Letter giving him more consolation then fear, he fell to the meat before
him, and then laid him down on a bed, for to rest and refresh himself, after

In the mean time Alcidamant and Trasiclea, carried by the remembrance of the

it.

Saying thus, he advanced his heavy Scimitar, that was twelve foot long, and

These horrible blows much amazed the fourth, but seeing five more of his

WHilst Rozalmonds and Russians wounds were inhealing, twelve days past
insensibly away, at the end whereof the Vessel of the Sun staying close to a
rock, on whose top, a great smoke appeared, Alcidamant and Trasiclea, armed at
all points, leapt on shore, and passing under certain trees, they traveled
above an hour without incountring any thing, but a very great silence over
all, whereupon concluding that this was some Desert, they turned toward the
ascent of the rock, and began to mount it with pain, in regard of the weight of
their Arms, when as they perceived a huge fire from whence that smoke which
they had seen proceeded; The curiosity, that had made them leave the Ship,
carrying them on, they saw a woman on her knees before the fire, who lifting up
her hands to heaven, seemed to beg for something with her prayers; they would
fain have heard her complaints, before she should have discovered them, howbeit
they could not approach to her so softly; but that she discryed them, whereupon
rising up, she was going to run away, when as Alcidamant catching her by the
arm, said unto her; Gentlewoman, be not frighted with our presence, for we are
come hither rather to do you service, than any hurt. Knights, answered she,
having been a twelve month, or more, in this Desert without seeing any body,
truly I was afraid at the sight of your Arms, but since you have so well
confirmed me, let me know I pray you, what you would have with me, to the end I
may give you satisfaction therein, if it lie in my power. That which we desire,
said Trasiclea to her, is that you would tell us why you kneel thus before
this flame, what is the cause of your complaints, and of your retreat into this
Desert place. That were to renew my sorrows, answered she, but I take such
delight in the rehearsal of my misery, that I shall be as ready to relate, as
you are willing to hear it.

This fire, which but testifies the same, that has long consumed my heart,
serves for a sacrifice to the ghost of noble Clarismon^d, one of the loveliest
Knights that was in all the Kingdom of Filamon, whose body is buried under the
ashes of this fire, that every day is renewed by me just at this hour; his
death is as strange, as the history of our loves, which not to abuse your
patience, I will recount unto you as briefly as I can. This Knight, a great
friend to one named Martander, being taken with that little beauty, wherewith
it pleased heaven to indue me, showed himself so desirous to be in all places,
and companies, where I had occasion to be present, that by his looks and
carriage, I easily came to know he was in love with me, howbeit being then, I
may well say, blind, because I did not consider his merit, I could not by any
means affect him, but contrarily carrying some particular good liking to
Martander, that cared not for me, the sight of him did very much displease me;
I found fault with all that he did, and the more he labored to serve me, the
more was I incensed against him. His suit then being troublesome unto me, I
resolved to let him understand, that he much dis-obliged me, by soliciting me
in that manner, and accordingly taking occasion on a time, when he besought me
to carry a gentler mind, and to have some compassion of his suffering, I told
him how my actions were the images of my thoughts, how I had showed
sufficiently, that I did not love him, and how in vain he expected relief from
me, for if I would give my self to any one, Martander should have more power
over me, then all the Knights on the earth.

Hereat Martander, who was then present with Clarismond, gave me many humble
thanks for the election I was willing to make of him; but, Madam, said he,
being Clarismonds friend, I may not receive the honor of your favor, which
would be better conferred where it is due, then on me. Some months passing
away, Clarismond obstinate in his suit, I in my hate to him, and affection to
Martander, these two friends plotted together how to deceive me. You may do me
a most friendly part, said Clarismond one day to Martander: Parmolina, (so is
this miserable called that speaks to you) loves you with passion, and when you
please, you can prevail with her to grant you any thing, serve me faithfully,
I beseech you; feign as much love to her, as she bears you, and labor to
obtain of her that she will spend one night with you, upon promise you may make
her, of rendering her kisses legitimate; the dark keeps all things unknown, I
will go to her in your stead, and so by this means you shall save my life, which
otherwise cannot long continue.

Martander, who to help his friend would have made no difficulty to have gone
even into Hell, most willingly undertakes this affair, comes to me, and
craving my pardon for his so long neglect of my affection, in such manner
counterfeits the motions of a man transported with love and impatience, that I
verily believed he was thoroughly taken; his sighs very much grieved me, the
vows that he made never to adore any but my self, exceedingly contented me, I
was sensible of his passions; what should I say more? There was naught resting
to render us the happiest Lovers in the world, but the fruition of our desires,
whereunto he labored to arrive for the satisfaction of his friend; but finding
dangerous obstacles therein, by reason I lay always in my Mothers chamber, in
a bed apart by my self, I could not resolve to run such hazard; nevertheless,
what could not the tears of a Lover, or of one that seemed so, effect in the
heart of an amorous Girl?

At length I past by all respects, and promising him to leave all our doors
open, I sent him away so contented, as he seemed not to envy any felicity
whatsoever: Midnight then being come, I received Clarismond in mine arms,
thinking it was Martander, and losing my self in his embraces, I little thought
of this change of persons, insomuch, that the next day I spoke to Martander, as
thinking I had acted that with him, which I had done with Clarismond, and as
for him, he carried the countenance of a man so infinitely pleased, as it was a
fortnight before I knew by what cunning I was deceived, because we durst not
speak but very softly, in regard of my Mother; howbeit Clarismond not enduring
to taste his delight any longer under the coverture of another, discovered
himself one night, as we were in the midst of our pleasure, and freely
confessed to me, that he was constrained to have recourse unto wiles, since he
could not other ways prevail: I will not tell you how much I was astonished
at this discourse, nor what error I was then about, to have run into by crying
out, as though I had been ravished by force, but to proceed, I will assure you,
how instantly changing my mind, with the consideration that the matter was past
remedy, I loved Clarismond a thousand times more than ever I had done
Martander, and began to have Martander far more, than ever I had done
Clarismond, unto whom, (excusing my self upon the weakness of my judgment,
which had not permitted me to choose the better party,) I protested so much
love, and gave him such testimony thereof by my most kind usage of him, and
caressing of him anew, as he thought himself happy in disclosing this trick
unto me.

But now see what sport love makes with men, Martander hearing Clarismond
continually talk of the unspeakable delight he enjoyed with me, began to love
me most passionatly, and preferring his affection before his friendship, he
began to vow and protest that truly unto me, which he had dissembled before,
hoping that the passion I had been in for him, was not yet quite extinct. I am
not able to express what infinite content I received to behold him sigh at my
feet, and rejoyeing to see him languish through his own fault, I told him that
my Mothers in-disposition detained me from receiving him a-nights, as I was
wont, but at length no longer to abuse him, I plainly said unto him, how I very
much wondered to hear him desire a treasure which belonged unto Clarismond,
and knowing well enough that he possessed it, I could hardly believe he could be
so wicked, as to seek to bereave him of it; At this speech he was so
confounded, that he was ready to dye with grief, and indeed he lay three weeks
sick upon it, at the end whereof being unable any longer to endure the yiolence
of his desires, it came into his head to crave the same favor of Clarismond,
which he had received from him; Laying before him then the peril of his life,
the imbecilitie of men that forced him to violate the laws of friendship, the
power of that proud divinity, which uses to triumph over those hearts that
go about to resist him, the merit of my beauty, and briefly all that he
thought could serve for his enterprise; he put Clarismond into a strange
perplexity, his love, and the resolution he had taken to marry me, forbad him
to yield unto the unjust request of this friend, nevertheless, choosing rather
to dye than be ungrateful, he concluded to deprive himself both of his life
and happiness together Insomuch, that having promised to give him satisfaction
in the very same manner, as he had received it, he drew this Lover from his
bed, and came a little after to see me, but without so much as speaking a word
of what ^ad past between them, howbeit having observed some extraordinary
sadness in his countenance, and not knowing any just occasion he could have
for it, I began to suspect this practice, in regard whereof I purposed not to
admit of Clarismond any more, but upon safe terms, nevertheless making no
show of it, I promised to entertain him as I used to do.

Night being come then, I left only the outward door open, shutting those fast
within, and standing close at a window, that looked into the street, first I
heard (...) very (...) ear, because they made (...) I could hear Clarismond
say, farewell dear friend, the (...) happy than I am. Having spoken in this
manner, away he (...) going to ou^ house, who finding the (...) return with far
le^^hope, than he came.

Being marvellously (...) with (...) of this business, I was much incensed
against Clarismond, and (...) to (...) him soundly for his fault, though I was
fully resolved to (...) him, but alas! he gave me no opportunity to do so; for
never appearing again before me, he advertised me by a Letter, that wa^ brough^
me the next day, how through grief and despair he was gone to end his days in
a Desert.

This sad and sudden departure of his derived from the excess of his love to
me, cast me into a dangerous sickness^, which questionless had carried me out
of the world, if my hope with meeting with Clarismond again, had not made me
desire to live, but my love to him restored me within a little after to my
health, when hearing no news of him, careless of mother and friends I forsook
my country, and seven months together traveled from place to place in the
search of him, at the end whereof coming to this Rock, I found my Clarismond
clothed in a long Hermits Gown, who hearing me (...) how I had beg^iled
Martander, was so overcome with joy, as he dyed suddenly in my arms. O! who can
express the sorrow I was in then* Let it suffice that it cast me into a

(...) my last in this very (...), where ^e so unfortunately expired.

Behold, noble Knight, the cause of my grief (...)* which I earnestly beseech

to admit of my (...).

Seeing you are so minded, said (...), we will ^orhear (...) ^ouble you any
further, and (...) of your lamentable case, we will commit you to the

(...).

Whereupon descending the hill, and going toward the Seaside, they incountred
with four (...) Knigh^^, the foremost of which, bearing a Salvage in his (...)

your (...), until such time, as we may (...) as some h^bitabl^ place; we

Noble Sir, answered (...), which you behold there is so (...) for bringing you
with us, (...) if you please. Being gotten (...) to the Prince of (...) at the,
(...) their Helmets (...) Giv^ (...) your hands to kiss, for here is Florisbel
of the star, and Don Sestilian of Spain, your servants, with the redoubted

and the fair Amazon, his Lady Brandimanda: At these words Rozalmond rising up
in his bed most kindly entertained the Princes of France and Spain, and with no

goodly presence those four Warriors were marvellously astonished) together

CHAP. XXXII. The dreadful combat between Rozalmond, and Gorgophon, for the
deliverance of Armazia; The wonders that Alcidamant performed in bringing the
Inc^antment of Griolanis and Adelazia to an end.
CErtain days being sweetly spent in the pleasure, which might well be
expected from the conversation of so many excellent Knights, the Vessel of the
Sun made a stay in one of the ports of Corolanday^, where all those Princes
disimbarking themselves, were very much amazed to see sixteen Salvag^s come out
of the ship, the first eight having each of them a mighty courser in his hand,
and the others, eight staves so strong and stiff, as they seemed to have been
made for some important design; being presented with these horses and lances,
each of them lept into his saddle with many thanks to Alcander for this care of
them, and marching two and two, they took the way that led to Agricant, being
resolved to prove the adventure of the martyrdom of (...) and Adelazia.

After they had ridden then about one hour, they arrived at the Royal Palace,
where Rozalmond had but newly laced on his Helmet, desiring to be the first at
the essay of the adventure, (...) as he heard a woman speaking to the whole
Troop in this manner. Stay, said she, brave Knights, and if you have as much
valor, as your presence does promise, leave not a poor afflicted Damosel in
this prison, combat you altogether that Colossus, which you see there, for her
deliverance, since his extreme forces will not suffer him to be vanquished by
one single man, the gods will recompense your pain^, and I (...) one day
acknowledge this service of yours. At these words; (...) ^^ king round about,
perceived two Ladies of a mavelous beauty, sta^di^^ ^^ the (...) of a little
Tower, toward whom being advanced* so (...) and (...) them of their
deliverance, he presently discerned ou^ of (...) ^o be (...) (...), which so.
So (...) like (...) over his liberty! O wonderful! said he, being no less
transported with fury (...), is it possible that I should find you in this
(...) M(...)? You shall quickly see the outrage that is done you most horribly
revenged; here is the Knight of the Roses, that having served you heretofore
against the redoubted (...), will likewise free you out of the hands of
Gorgoph^^; whereupon turning him to A(...)t. Dear brother, said he, I am now in
the supreme degree of my glory, since I have met with Armaria, dispatch the
Giant that keeps her imprisoned, whilst I go and chastise the insolence of the
Ravisher of my excellent Mistress.

Noble Sir, said Russia^ then, which likewise knew the beautiful Jnfanta of
Clariana his Lady (whom he had disinchanted at Constantinople, when as he gave
an end to the adventure of the Piramides, as has been related in the eight and
thirtieth Chapter of our first part:) Noble Sir, leave me this combat I beseech
you, for I have no less interest in the deliverance of these incomparable
Ladies, than the gallant Prince of Greece, as for your self you cannot want
employment, if you please, in the trial of the adventure. I would always give
more to your merit, answered Alcidamant, go then and render this good office
to your Mistress, whilst I seek to know whether the release of these Lovers be
in my power.

Whereupon casting his eyes on Rozal^^^^, and Gorgophon, who carried with
equal rage were then set forth, he saw them meet like two clouds violently
rushing together in the midst of the air, and pass by one another like
lightning, without so much as being once moved in their saddles by their
Lances, which were broken in a thousand shivers: By this furious encounter
guessing at the exceeding force of Gorgophon, he stayed to observe how they
would entreat one another with their swords, their two first blows very much
amazed him, for their shields were divided in twain, and their blades fell with
such violence upon their Helmets, as they were constrained to bow with their
heads, even to the very arson of their saddles* from whence arising so full of
choler, that it terrified all the people which beheld their combat, Rozalmond
discharged such another terrible blow on Gorgophons head, as it made him see
many more stars then there are in the sky, but he returned him an answer
nothing less cruel and dangerous, for he received so mighty a stroke, that
having loft one of his stirrops, he staggered as if he had been deprived of
judgment; nevertheless shaming to appear any whit inferior to his enemy
before the grea^est Knights of the earth, he quickly resetled himself in his
saddle, and began to charge the Giant very fiercely, who nothing abashed fought
so well, that he showed himself to be one of the best Knights in the world.

The field was strewed all over with pieces of their armor, the blood g^shed
out in many places of their bodies, and so dreadful were their blows, that all
the houses round about resounded therewith. The noise which proceeded from the
combat of these Warriors, and that of Russian of Media, with the other Giant,
being little less cruel, drew a world of people thither from al parts, and
amongst others the three Princesses of Martaria, with their Lovers, who very
much wondering at the fury of this Knight, admired the dexterity of the Grecian
Prince, who mad for that he could not vanquish his enemy took his sword in both
his hands, and let it descend so dangerously on Gorgophon, that it gave him a
great gash on the shield-arm, whereat the Giant was so incensed, that
discharging a full blow on his shoulder with all his might, he entered his
Fauchion two fingers deep into his flesh, and making him lose his bridle and
stirrops so astonished him, that if his horse by carrying him away had not
prevented his enemy from seconding the former with another stroke, doubtless
he had been in great peril of his life.

Alcidamant, who was still looking on this combat, seeing this horrible blow,
and knowing how far Rozalmonds forces extended, admired G^rg^phon more than
before, and was very much afraid that his friend would not come time enough
again to himself, but on a sudden he beheld him resettle him in his seat, and
fly upon the Giant with such fury, as made all the assistants to tremble; and
indeed the blow which he discharged on the crest of his Helmet was so
dangerous, that though it could not cleave it by reason of the Enchantment,
wherewith Di^boli^n had framed it, he overthrew him on the crupper of his
horse, casting such a deal of blood out of his ears and mouth, and his arms
and legs hanging in that manner, as all the world believed he was dead;
nevertheless he was seen a little after to raise up himself with such extreme
rage, for that he was so ill entreated by one man alone, that Rozalmonds
friends were in some fear of him, howbeit our brave Champion no whit dismayed
courageously presenting his face unto him, they renewed the combat with more
horror and cruelty then at first.

In the mean time Russian of Media, who had not so puissant an enemy to
encounter, discharged five or six blows together on him, with such a mighty
force, that he laid him breathless at his feet, and seazing on a key that he
carried about him, he presently opened the door of the Tower, mounted up a
little pair of stayrs, and kneeling down before the Ladies, almost transported
with joy, he said unto them. Beauteous Princesses be pleased to give me your
hands to kiss, in recompense of the beginning, which I have given to your
releasement, and descending with me come and assure the victory to the valiant
Knight of the Roses, that is now fighting for your deliverance. Sir, answered
Armazia, who was not a little contented to hear that her Knight was there; I
may not permit you to kiss my hands, being so exceedingly obliged unto you, as
I am. Command then this fair Jnfanta to do me that favor, replied he, seeing
I have the glory to be her Knight. My Knight, said Agriclea, since when I
beseech you? since I freed you from the Enchantment, whereunto you were reduced
by Fulgosons Aunt, answered he, for then you did me the honor to avow me for
your Knight, and to say that my service should always be agreeable unto you.
Ah my Lord, said Agriclea, pardon my ignorance I pray you, for truly I did not
know you, but I shall be ready to amend this error. Whereupon giving him her
hand, rather as it were to raise him up, then for any other end, she suffered
him to kiss it a thousand times, and so descending all three they presented
themselves before these Warriors, who at the sight of Armazia became so
furious, Gergoph^^ to see her delivered after such hope of enjoying her, and
Rozalmond to continue so long without vanquishing in her presence, and for her
quarrel, that they discharged at one instant two such terrible blows upon one
another, at they were ready to pitch with their noses on the ground;
nevertheless being retained by shame and anger, they redoubled their mortal
strokes, and finding new force in their rage, they hewed one another for four
hours so cruelly, that all men wondered how they could endure so long, for
their arms being all covered over with blood, the end of their lives was every
minute expected.

This while Alcidaman^, being confident that the victory would undoubtedly rest
on the Prince of Greece, whose courage augmented with time and danger, and
desiring not to remain idle, he presented himself before the Palace gate, with
a resolution to prove the adventure of Adelazia, and accordingly seeing his
passage defended by the four Princes, he drew out his rich sword, and warding
himself with his shield, he discharged so rude a blow on Armorand, that if the
fury of his blade had not been arrested by enchantment, he had cleft him down
to the teeth; nevertheless the blow was so violent, as it made him set both
his knees to the ground, but being diverted from further prosecuting his
advantage on him by three dangerous blows received all at once from the
others, he suddenly made head against them, and laid so terribly on Falemonds
Helmet, that he sent him to the earth quite deprived of judgment, as also
Grinaldo, whom with another stroke he overthrew in like manner.

The misfortune of these Knights having marvellously incensed the other two,
they discharged both at once so strongly on his head, as they made him reele
three or four steps backwards, with a million of lights before his eyes, whereat
he was so mad, that gnashing his teeth for anger, he delivered two such blows
successively on Arm^rants and Crisanders Helmerts, as he laid them senseless at
his feet.

In the mean space the fight between the Grecian Prince and Gorgophon, having
lasted above six hour^s, was most terrible, for shame and jealousy equally
anim^ting them, they employed all their skill, and strength to become
victorious; Rozalmond was enraged to meet a man able enough to dispute with him
for his M^stresse, and the honor of a Combat, whereunto all his glory was tied*
and Gorgophon, the most audacious Giant of the earth, bitterly s^orming,
uttered strange blasphemies against his gods, and me^acing the very heavens,
seemed as though he would divide them with his Curtelas, which oftentimes
lighting on Rozalmonds Arms, always carried some piece thereof along with it,
his own being in no better estate, under the sword of his enemy, who being in
the supreamest degree of rage, resolved either to dye or vanquish.

Returning then out of an astonishment wherein he had been reduced by a most
horrible blow of Gorgoph^ns, which had overturned him on the ^^^pper of his
Horse, he parted with such fury, as all the assistants terrified there with,
began to ^^^mble, and displaying all his force, he discharged so unmea^urable a
blow, full on the crest of Gorgophons Helmet, that if he had struck with the
edge, he had divided him to the wast in spite of all Diabolions charms, but
his sword turning in his hand with choler, the flat fell so dangerously on his
head, that thinking he was smitten with a thunderbolt, he fell in a swound to
the earth, making a noise like that of some mighty Tower, which the wind has
hurled out of its place.

At this b^ave stroke, Ar^^^zia marvellously rejoicing, advanced toward her
Knight, who suddenly alighting fell on his knees before her, and said; Madam,
be pleased that this small service may repair the fault, which I have
committed in abandoning you so long. Alas! my dearest Knight, said she with
tears of joy, and grief, to see him so bloody all over, let us not speak, I
pray you, of pardon, for I find my self so happy in meeting you thus, that I
can never remember any misery past; come let us go and visit your wounds, and
know what we are to hope for of your recoverie. Madam, answered Rozalmond, I
feel they are dangerous, but yet not so much as to make you to fear, or keep
me from rejoicing with my friends for the good success of mine enterprise;
whereupon perceiving Amadis, Floridan, and Lucibel coming to him, together with
the Princesses of Martaria, to give him thanks for their deliverance out of the
crystal Tower, he went and caressed them withal the kindness that might be,
and so did Armazia, Trasiclea, Brandimanda, and the fair Infanta of Clariana,
who were no less amazed at the excellency of their beauties, than they were
to see them every way so accomplished.

Some time being spent in these salutations and compliments (and Gorgophon
freely suffered to be carried away by certain of his servants to his Ship,
where a little after being fetched out of his swound, he was so mad, for that
he had been vanquished, as they had much ado to keep him from killing of
himself) Rozalmond hearing that Alcidamant was upon proving of the adventure,
he went where he beheld him engaged against the Serpent, and the Monster.

This invincible Warrior seeing himself delivered from four of his first
enemies, and looked upon by so many excellent persons, most courageously
boorded those two creatures, and desiring to display the uttermost of his
forces, he discharged his Sword with such violence upon the Serpents head, that
though it could not pierce the hardness of the scales, yet it made him stoup
to the very ground, presently whereupon being laid at by the Monster, he
dexterously declined the blow of his axe, which fell in vain upon the floor,
The first fury of those horrible beasts being in this sort avoided, Alcidamant
finding that the astonishment wherein the Serpent was, gave him opportunity to
perform something the mean while upon the Monster, he took his sword in both
his hands, and slipping by the danger of a second blow from him, he let it
descend with such strength, on his left arm, which was as big as a tree, that
he cut it sheere from his body.

This lucky stroke animating him to do better, he turned to the Serpent,
thinking to avoid his fury as before, but he was so surprised, and incountred
with such force, as he was laid all along in the dust, where this creature
running on him, labored to seize on his Helmet with his teeth, in which
danger, still retaining his judgment, he ran him up into the belly, that made
him make a mighty skip into the air, by means whereof our Knight had leisure to
arise, but being scarce well upon his legs, he received so great a blow from
the Monster, as he was constrained to set both his knees to the ground, where
shame and danger not suffering him to continue long, he got up again so full of
rage, that casting his shield on his shoulder, he discharged with such fury on
that monstrous creature, as having incountred the handle of his axe, and cut it
in two, his sword fell with that tempest on his head, that it cleft him down to
the wast. O heaven! said Rozalmond, what a dreadful blow was this, and who can
be able to resist the thunder of such a mighty arm? Questionless this Warrior
is the nonparil of the earth, unto whom all the world has reason to give place.

This speech, which Alcidamant heard, having rendered him infinitely courageous,
he let fall an horrible stroke on the Serpent, that came leaping toward him,
and watering the floor with the blood that issued from the wound in his belly;
never thelese, having not so much as made any print on his scales, he was
enforced to step suddenly aside for to give him way, and was ready with his
sword aloft to have smitten him on the tail, when as he perceived a Knight all
on fire, come out of the Hall, who presently gave him so mighty a blow, that
it made him stagger, and in that manner amazed, as he knew not in what world he
was, howbeit instantly recovering his spirits he became so enraged, that
beholding the Serpent raised on his two hinder feet for in fall upon him with
all the weight of his body, he ran him with so mortal a thrust into the flank,
that he overturned him on his back, where leaving him amidst the pangs of
death, and making such horrible cries, as all the place shaked therewith, he
turned to the enchanted Knight, and began to charge him with so much force and
agilitie, as though he had not fought all the day before, nevertheless he
endured strange pain, for the fire which covered the enchanted Knight so
heated him, that he thought he was consumed in his arms; but what will not a
valiant man suffer, that would dye a thousand times, rather then forgo the
honor of a difficult enterprise?

He employed all his force, and delivering his blows with no less strength,
then when as he divided the body of a Giant, he charged the enchanted Knight so
terribly, that he forced him to mount up the stayrs again, which exceedingly
encouraging our Warrior, he followed him, redoubling his horrible blows, till
he came up to the top of the stayres, where his enemy returned him such a
stroke on his Helmet, as made him fall on his knees, ready to tumble down all
the steps, but staying himself on his hands, he arose full of fury, and
discharged his sword with such violence on the Knight, as it extended him on
the earth, where Alcidamant going to unlace his Helmet for to take off his head
in satisfaction of his anger, he perceived that they were empty Arms without a
body in them, at which he would have very much marvelled, had he not been well
acquainted with the power of Magicians, wherefore being very much moved with the
lamentable complaints of Griolanis and Adelazia, he made no further stay, but
burst open the door with the pummell of his sword, and no whit regarding those
horrible flames, which appeared all over the room, he went directly to the two
Lovers, hoping to carry them easily from thence; nevertheless, he was fain to
undertake a new combat, the Serpents which devoured them, flew upon him, and
winding themselves about his legs, they labored to overthrow him to the ground.

This new difficulty, far more troublesome than dangerous, having held him a
good while without knowing how to free himself from these creatures, he let go
his sword, and closing his hand, he knocked them down with his fist; that
done, a phantosme presented it self before him, which borrowing a thousand
figures one after another, labored to affright him; but he that could not be
moved with any danger whatsoever, having cut the ay^e in vain with his sword,
discharged it at length on the shoulder of a furious Bear, that was catching
him by the throat, which being divided in the middle it appeared to be the body
of the sorceresse Maxiana separated in two parts, that no sooner touched the
floor, but a most horrible Earthquake arose, accompanied with thunder and
lightning, and so dreadful a noise, as it seemed the very Palace would have
sunk into the center of the earth.

This noise, earthquake, and confusion, having continued a long time, there
entered into the Court a middle-aged woman, followed by a g^llant Knight, and a
most beautiful Shepherdess, who with the grace of her habit, which was of
white Taff^^a, fastened together in sundry places with sparkling Rubies, was
thought to be one of those Nimphs so adored in the Forests; whereupon, every
one giving way to these three persons, that Woman took a Vial out of her
pocket, and presenting it to the Shepherdess, said aloude; It is you
Miralinda, that must lend the last assistance to this enchantment, you have
heretofore contemned the fire that burned Lind^renna, fear not then the flame
that torments Griolanis, but enter into this room where you will discover a
secret very much importing you, and breaking this Vial on the Armor of the
Knight, who has performed such incredible wonders for to come unto these
unfortunate Lovers, you shall find your self, before you are either lost, or
sought for.

This Shepherdess then, who was no other then Miralinda, that was come thither
with Clarisel, and Urganda the unknown, without whose help this enchantment
would never have been ended, ascending the stayrs, entered courageously into the
room, and finding Alcidamant extended fast by Griolanis and Adelazia, who
seemed to be dead, she brake the Vial upon his Armor, which was no sooner
done, but the air began to clear, the fire to be clean extinct; and the two
Lovers as sound and fair as ever they had been, rose up with the same judgment
they had before their torment, and assuring themselves that their deliverance was
effected by the valor of Alcidamant, and confidence of Miralinda, who had upon
her head the crown of Roses, which Adelazia had gotten in the adventure of the
triumph of love, they kneeled down to thank them for their assistance, but they
not enduring such submission, presently lifted them up, just as Urganda, that
was not yet known, came in with Clarisel, Rozalmond, Armazia, Trasiclea, Gri^^,
Amadis, Palmirenna, and the rest, whom Griolanis and the fair Queen of
Corolandaya, caressed in that manner as is not well able to be delivered,
wherefore I will pass it over in silence, to tell you that an hour being spent
in these compliments, during the which Urganda being known, and very much
honored by all those Lords, she desired them to give her audience, whereupon
she said unto them.

Incomparable Princesses, and you most excellent Knights, ye have indeed great
reason to rejoice at the presence of one another, because the whole world has
nothing so rare and precious as you, howbeit I will add somewhat yet to the
glory of your contentment. Fair Shepherdess, said she to Miralinda (who
rendered all those Princesses amazed at her mavelous beauty) give me that
Crown of Roses, and remember the speech I used to you, at your ascending
hither, that you should find your self, before you were either lost, or fought
for: You believe that you are Daughter to Armedor, a Shepherd of Bellombre,
behold your descent in these three Roses; so presenting the Crown, which she
held in her hand, to all the company, they discerned these words written about
it; Miralinda the the Daughter of the Marquis of Monteclare. O! Is it possible
said Alcidamant, that I should meet with a Sister here of such value* Come and
let us embrace my dearest Miralinda, for I am Alcidamant your brother, and son
to the Marquis of Monteclare. Hereat Miralinda being very much amazed, was not
able to speak a word, but at length better recollecting her self, she fell on
her knees before Alcidamant, and with tears of joy said unto him. My Lord, this
is a lucky day for me, and how much do I owe to my good fortune, which has
made me known to be the sister of so great a Knight! Ah Madam, continues she,
addressing her speech to Vrganda, how wonderful is yourskill, and what can you
wish from me hereafter, which I will not most willingly give to your service?
you have drawn me from out the lees of the people to raise me in this manner,
but I will abase my self whenever you shall please for to testify that I
will never forget so powerful an obligation. It was not I alone, said Vrganda,
that knew the secret of your birth (though no body now could discover it but I
this wicked woman, whose body you see here divided in two pieces, had foretold
it in this Pillar, which is standing yet before the Palace gate, for this is
her Prophecy.

The Prophecy.

WHen the excellent Turtle, and the redoubted Lion, coming forth of one
prison, shall (...) in the flames, the strayed blood shall be known, beauty
shall reassume her former luster, and the punishment of a vielated Law shall
be converted into joy.

The intelligence of these words is it not now clear? are not you that
excellent Turtle? and this famous Knight, is not he that redoubted Lion, both
come from one womb, which the Inchantresse figured by a prison, and out of your
own knowledge do not you see the strayed blood recovered? But let us pass
farther, Beauty shall reassume her former luster. Is not that true by the
deliverance of this brave Knight, and of the sovereign Lady of this Kingdom,
who are now as much in their luster, as ever they were, and the torment they
have suffered, is it not changed into delight? Certainly you now know the
verity of these obscure words, and no man can doubt but you are descended of
that illustrious race, which produces such worthy and generous persons.
Embrace then again this valiant brother of yours, and further call to mind how
when he was knighted by Don Clarisel, a Damosel advertised you from the learned
Merea, that you should not make difficulty to girt on his sword, for you should
one day more esteem of the knowledge of him, then of the possession of an
Empire.

Hereat Alcidamant and Miralinda well remembering all that Vrganda had spoken,
and embracing afresh, their caresses were renewed, Adelazia, Trasiclea,
Palmirenna, Armazia, (...), Archedidella, Brandimanda, and Agriclea gave
Miralinda a thousand kisses with such content to Don Clarisel, that he was even
ravished with joy, to see his Shepherdess so exceedingly honored; Night then
being come, Adelazia having caused her Palace to be adorned with her choysest
furniture, assigned to those excellent Princes the chiefest part of it, and
remained with those beauteous Ladies in her own ordinary lodgings.

CHAP. XXXIII. The brave Turnament that is held at the marriage of Rozalmond,
Alcidamant, and those other Princes of Greece.
VRganda having closed up Rozalmonds wounds in a night, all those Princes,
which infinitely desired the accomplishment of their happiness, assembled
together, and resolved to take one and the same day for the consummation of
their content, but having no less care of their Ladies salvation, then of
their own satisfaction, they concluded in representing their pains unto them to
set before their eyes the vanity of their Idols in the greatness of that
Almighty God, who vouchsafed to shed his most precious blood, for to restore us
unto the way of grace, from which we were strayed by the revolt of our first
parents: Entering then all with this design into the room where the Princesses
were, they persuaded them to go and walk into the Gardens, and there separating
themselves into several walks, and each one taking his Mistress by the arm,
spoke so passionately and effectually for himself, as he easily prevayled with
her, to resolve upon the third day following, for the celebration of their
Nuptials.

This first point being determined according to their desires, they began to
talk unto them of the excellency of the Christian Religion, of the mystery of
the Trinity, of the Incarnation, Death, and Resurrection of the Son of God,
of the mission of the Holy Ghost, of the Institution of the Sacraments, and
showing them the Heavens and the Sun, they drew them insensibly to the
knowledge of the Creator of them, which could not be but far more perfect and
excellent, in so much that being assisted with the love they bore them, they
were soon induced to be baptized, and accordingly the same day Adelazia sent
for three Christian Hermits, which she had suffered to live in her Kingdom, by
whom being yet better instructed in the chiefest Articles of the faith, the
Temple of those Idols, she had formerly adored, was cleansed of a number of
several Images, whereof three or four being beaten to pieces by our Knights,
confirmed them further in the belief that they were of no power.

Time and desire then pressing our Lovers, and making them hasten every thing.
These Princes received the first Character of Christians, Armazia conducted by
Alcidamant, who was her Godfather, Trasiclea by Rozalmond, Palmirenna by
Florisbel, Adelazia by Amaais, Amplamira by Clarismond, Brandimanda by
Floridan, Archesidella by Sestilian, and the fair Agriclea by Griolanis, which
being performed they returned to the Palace, leaving those good fathers in the
Church for to instruct the principal persons of Corolandaya, who after the
example of their Sovereign cheerfully embraced this new Law, believing by what
was showed them, that it was much better than that which they had so long a
time professed.

Mean while our Lovers, thinking of nothing but the day, which was to place
them in the supreme degree of their glory, prepared most magnificent apparel,
and especially the Ladies, who desiring to make a demonstration of all their
beauties, omitted naught that could add any thing to grace themselves withal.

Nothing was heard but Violms, Haubois, consorts of Instruments, and voices,
all the shops of the City were shut up, the people made bonfires, and
preparations for Masks, Plays, and Feasting; from all parts of the Kingdom
arrived Knights and Ladies, that came to celebrate the deliverance and nuptials
of their Queen: Briefly, all things were disposed to delight, and the third day
seemed no less tedious to the people, then to those valiant Princes, who at
length beholding it appear thorough their windows, were incontinently attyred
most richly, and so entered all into the presence, whither those Princesses
repaired not long after like so many Goddesses.

Many sweet and amorous discourses passing between them, Rozalmond in a suit
and cloak of blew velvet, embroydered with gold and pearl, placed himself on
the right hand of Armazia, whose Gown was of the same color, and Florisbel on
the left: The brave Alcidamant followed him in a dublet of white satin, his
hose and cloak of crimson velvet, enriched with an embroyderie of gold, pearl,
and stones, being on the right side of the beautiful Trasiclea, attyred in the
same colors, whom Don Sestilian held by the left hand: Amadis was the third
with his fairest Palmitenna, and the Marquis of Beltamir, having his cloak and
hose of black velvet, powdered over with silver oes, amongst the which a number
of sparkling diamonds being aptly placed, gave a mavelous luster: Clarisel of
Gunidaya was the next in a dublet, hose, and cloak of green satin wrought al
over with gold and silver, having the incomparable Miralinda, betwixt him and
the Count of Pandelia, in a Gown of white satin, cut upon carnation taffea,
and all set with great diamonds. After him went Floridan with his Amplamira,
and the gentle Marquis of Cardana, apparelled both in purple satin most richly
embroydered: Griolanis and the most beauteous Adelazia followed them,
accompanied with the King of Bronzartes, near kinsman to the Queen, so set with
stones, as every one was amazed at the riches of their clothes: Then marched
Lucibel, and the fair Infanta of Martaria, Grian and Brandimanda; Russian, and
the delicate Agriclea, assisted by the chiefest Princes of the Kingdom, and so
sumptuously apparelled, as they had no cause to envy their companions.

This excellent troop at length arrived at the Church, where the Hermits having
sung Mass, they were married together with all the ceremonies requisite in
such cases: That done they returned to the Palace, and there dinner being
prepared with all the state and magnificence that might be, they sat down
attable in the same order as they went to Church.

Having been entertained then with all the most exquisite and choysest meats,
that water, land, or air could yield, they resolved to make a turnament, wherein
a thousand selected Knigts should be divided into two bands, one of them to be
led by ^^zalmond, that was to be seconded by Amadis, Clarisel, Floridan,
Luci^el, Sestilian, Florisbel, and Russian; and the other by Alcidament, who
was to be assisted by Grian, Grielamis, Trasiclea, Brandimanda, Armorand,
Grinaldo, Crisander, and Falemond, who being disinchanted by the valor of
Alcidamant, would by no means depart before the solemnization of the nuptials
of these Lords.

Now dinner being done, and a thousand Knights ready within the Barriers, the
Princes went and armed themselves, and a little after appeared in the place
like so many gods of Battle: The Marquis of Beltamir, and the Admiral of
Corolandaya being placed, as the Judges in their scaffolds, and the trumpets
sounding from all parts, those two troops, wherein the glory of all the
Knighthood in the world was assembled, began to set forth, and those two
invincible Champions, Alcidamant, and Rozalmond, charging their Lances one
against another, incountred with such fury, that the earth even trembled under
their horses feet, their staves were broken into a thousand shivers, and yet
they not so much as moved in their saddles, passed along like two Rocks
standing firm against the violence of an enraged flood; Amadis and Grians
course was performed with as much grace and force; Griolanis and Clarisel ran
against each other with like fortune; equal was the honor between Trasiclea,
and Floridan, betwixt Brandimanda and Lucibel; but Grinaldo was unhorsed by the
gentle Russian of Media; Armorand and Sestilian were both overthrown to the
earth, so was Crisander by the valiant Florisbel, and Falemond dismounted him
against whom he addressed his Lance; In the meantime the two troops being
incountred, above two hundred Knights were laid on the ground, who withdrawing
aside for fear of being trampled under the horses feet, there began almost
pleasant bickering: Alcidamant and Rozalmond put all in confusion, their swords
fell like thunderbolts whersoever they lighted; Amadis overturned all that he
met withal, Grian left not a Knight in his saddle; Clarisel flew about like
lightning, Griolanis seemed a fury, Floridan, Lucibel, Russian, and Florisbel
did wonders as they went, Trasiclea, Brandimanda, Armorand, and Grinaldo, who
were horsed again, made no less an havoc; briefly, the victory hung equally
balanced every where, and upon the sole force of the Chieftains depended the
content of the turnament.

Rozalmond jealous of Alcidamants glory, Amadis of Grians, and Clarisel envying
the honor which Griolanis acquired, went and assailed them all at one time,
and began one of the bravest combats that ever were seen amongst six Knights,
Rozalmonds, and Alcidamants blows were tempests, those of Amadis and Grian had
little less fury; and when one delivered a terrible stroke, he was sure to be
presently paid again in the same money; now was Alcidamant overturned on the
crupper of his horse, by and by Rozalmond was stricken down to the pummell of
the saddle; Amadus and Grian knocked their chins against their breasts;
Griolanis and Clarisel lost their stirrops; Trasiclea, Brandimanda, and the
Pagan Princes valiantly sustained the fury of Russian, and his companions; and
the Knights animated by the example of their Leaders, maintained themselves
still upon equal terms, in conclusion this turnament wherein no blood was
drawn, yielded a most delightful spectacle: Alcidamant and Rozalmond wearied
with one another horrible blows, Amadis, and Grian amazed at each others
strength, Clarisel, and Griolanis vexed for that neither of them could prevayl,
separated themselves all at one instant, and began to fly in again amidst the
troops, when as they saw thirteen most dreadful Giants appear, mounted on such
great Horses, as their heads seemed to touch the very clouds.

The sight of these Collosses possessing them with a new resolution, the Troops
rallyed together, whilst those eleven courageous Princes, accompanied with
Trasiclea and Brandimanda, got suddenly sharp Lances, and placed themselves
most opposite to those thirteen Giants, with whose desormitie the Ladies had
been very much troubled, had not Urganda laughing, made them confident of the
valor of their Knights.

These Monsters then approaching, with each of them a great Mast in his hand,
all those Princes set spurs to their Horses, and dislodging with fury, went to
encounter them in the midst of the race, with good hope to be revenged of the
interruption they had brought to their sports; but their staves being broken as
slightly, as if they had been Reeds, they were marvellously astonished to
behold those horrible Giants, changed in an instant into thirteen little
Dwarfs, which marched before a Chariot, wherein Rozalmond knew Cassandra, with
the most beautiful Penamonda of Greece, his Sister. O my dearest friend I said
he addressing his speech to Cassandra, how much am I joyed with the sight of
you, but how comes it that you are thus accompanied with my sister? My Lord,
answered she, I do not bring her without good cause, she comes to congratulate
with you, for your good fortune, and to go along with you about a sevennight
hence in an adventure of very great importance. Both you, and she, are most
heartily welcome, replied Rozalmond, and I am very glad that she is here to
keep my Armazia company.

Hereupon the Princes alighting from their horses, went and saluted the young
Princess, who ravished them all with the wonder of her beauty, which no less
amazed the Ladies, that came presently down to her, than she was carried with
admiration at the sight of so many graces as were assembled in them.

A good while being spent then in complements, these Lords and Ladies were
ready to ascend the Palace, leaving the ending of the turnament to another
time, when as they descryed two hundred Knights richly armed, following a
triumphant Chariot, wherein sat an old man on a golden Throne, with an
Imperial Crown on his head, and a young Lady at his feet: This so stately an
equipage drawing every one narrowly to observe them, Palmirenna perceived that
it was the Emperor her Father, and her cousin Agiliana, the King of Arbales
Daughter, whereat both she, with Amplamira, and the French Princes wife were so
troubled, that they were ready to sink down in the place, whereas contrarily
Rozalmond, who knew his mind well, went straightway with Griolanis unto him,
and bid him very welcome to that Court; The Emperor presently knowing that
valiant Prince, and understanding that Griolanis was King of Corolandaya,
instantly descended from his Chario^, and exceedingly caressing them, demanded
whether these Tryumphs were not for the celebration of the Nuptials of
Palmirenna, and her Sisters. Great Monarch, answered Rozalmond, they are indeed
this day married, and so is also the Daughter of the mighty Emperor of
Gardaci^, whom it has pleased heaven to bestow on me, as likewise that of the
Sovereign Lord of Tramazond to this invincible Warrior, showing Alcidamant
unto him, together, with the Queen of this Country, the Princess of Clariana,
and the fair Brandimanda, Lady of the Amazons. Now verily, said the Emperor, I
praise my good fortune for conducting me hither so opportunly for to have a
share in this your joy and solemnity; But where are my Children, that they do
not appear before me? Sir, answered Roz^lmond, the fear of your displeasure,
for the fault they have committed against the authority of a Father and a
Sovereign, no doubt keeps them away, but assuring my self that you have freely
pardoned them, I will present them straightway unto your Majesty, whereupon
Amadis holding Palmirenna by the hand, Floridan Amplamira, and Lucibel
Archesidella, they fell on their knees before the Emperor, so ashamed, as they
durst not look him in the face, but he having very much caressed them, and
testified that these Princes alliance did infinitely content him, they rose up
for to entertain Agiliana, whilst the Emperor, admiring the excellent beauty
of the Ladies, went and saluted them with all the courtesy that might be.

These compliments done, they returned all to the Palace, where the Emperor
being very honorably lodged, left his Neipce Agiliana in the hands of
Palmirenna, or to say better of Don Sestilian of Spain, who having never made
trial of the power of love subjected his freedom to the merits of this
beautiful Infanta, remaining her Knight, by the consent of Palmirenna. Supper
time come, and the Tables sumptuously covered, all the Lovers were set as at
dinner, where they began to discourse with the Emperor, of all that had past
the day before, who taking great delight in the sight of this brave company,
beheld them one after another, and fixing on Amadis, he could not choose but
tell what passion he had been in for him, when he thought him a Wench, which
made them all to laugh, especially Palmirenna, that then called to mind, the
pleasure she enjoyed at that time, under the disguise of Amadis his sex, but
Supper lasting too long for these Lovers, they rose and went to Dancing, the
better to entertain the Emperor, who knowing the impatience of their desires,
caused them to be lighted severally to their chambers, where we will leave them
gathering the fruit of their amorous pains, with such delight, as may be better
imagined, than expressed.

CHAP. XXXIIII. The mavelous adventure that happened in the Court of
Corolandaya, and the strange end thereof.
THe night having been too short for the desires of these Lovers, especially of
Rozalmond, Alcidamant, and Clarisel, who till then had never tasted the
pleasure of their Ladies chaste embraces, they all met together in the Hall, and
for diverse days together continued their joy with such contentment, as Fortune
seemed unable to cross them, but that inconstant Goddess, which always mixes
bitter with the sweet, changed the face of all their delight, and so overthrew
the hope of this Court, that without the particular providence of heaven, all
the glory of it had been lost in a moment.

One day as all this princely company were discoursing together, there entered
into the Hall a young Gentlewoman with her eyes full of tears, and of so sad a
countenance, as moved all that were present to pity, in one hand she had a
very rich sword, and her left arm sustained one of the goodliest Shields that
ever was seen: As Soon as she was advanced to the midst of the Hall, she for a
good while observed all those Lords and Princesses, ravished as it were with
the sight of so rare an object, and finding that there was a general silence
over all, in expectation of that which she would say, she demanded for
Griolanis, and the beauteous Queen his Wife. Here we are said they, making
toward her, Gentlewoman, will you have anything with us?

Great King, answered she, falling on her knees before him, it is not without
reason that every one talks of you, as of the prime Knight of the world, and
that the beauty of this incomparable Queen, whom the gods have given to your
merit, is preferred before all other on the earth, for now I see more than
heretofore I could believe; I am come hither to obtain one boon of you, and of
this fair Princess, refuse me not, I beseech you, nor let me be the only
afflicted woman living that fails of succor from you. Gentlewoman, answered
Griolanis, if I am able to do any thing for you, you may speak freely, for I
will most willingly grant whatsoever you shall desire of me, and so I think
will the queen my Wife. Yes verily, said Adelazia, I will promise her any thing
she will ask.

I could expect no less, replied she, wherefore Sir, be pleased to Arm your self
presently, but you shall use no other Sword nor shield, then these most
excellent ones which I have brought of purpose for you, and come both of you
along with me, you to combat a Giant that has ravished me, and she to deliver
a servant of mine detained in the charms of an old Sorceresse, which torments
him for disdaining her affections. It is no small displeasure, said Griolanis,
to leave such good company, but since we are obliged by promise, we will follow
you instantly, whereupon causing his Arms to be brought him, he took leave of
all those Princes, who were exceedingly grieved at their so sudden departure,
and finding in the Palace-yard the Gentlewomans coach with six lusty Horses,
he and his Wife entered into it, and were carried away with such speed, as they
were instantly out of sight.

The whole Court being very much troubled with this adventure, every one spoke
diversely of it, and some of the Knights were already of opinion to follow after
them, when as Urganda, and Cassandra, coming from making their Conjurations
cried out; To Arms, Knights, to arms, and suffer not Griolanis, and his Wife to
be so wretchedly cast away, they are betrayed by Lestrigond, Neipce to that
Maxiana, which the other day was cut in pieces, and if they be not rescued
before night, you shall never see them more.

At these words the Hall was presently empty, the Knights ran all about through
the Palace, and the astonishment was every where so great, that no body took
care of comforting the Ladies, which were mightily afflicted, whilst all the
Princes were arming themselves, and their Squirs were making ready their
horses, whilst the people were running to the Church to pray unto the new god,
whom they adored, for the safety of their Sovereigns.

Griolanis and his Wife being swiftly carried away, arrived at a Forest some
three leagues from the City, where the Knight alighting out of the Coach at
the sight of two dreadful Giants, drew out the Damsels rich Sword, and with
greatfury discharged it upon one of them with an expectation to see him lie at
his feet, but it broke into an hundred pieces as that very first blow, nothing
remained in his hand but the bare hilt, whereat he was very much amazed, but far
more when as he beheld his Shield fall all to fitters, as it had been glass,
with the stroke of the other Giant; for all this danger yet being no way
dismayed, albeit he thought he was betrayed, he caught up a great arm of a Tree
to defend himself, but those two horrible Collossos delivering two terrible
blows both at one instant on his Helmet, laid him all along on the earth, where
with cords, which they had ready for the purpose, they bound him hand and foot,
and so carrying him to the Coach, where Adelazia was, who tearing her hair
filled the air with her shrieks, they instantly galloped away as fast as they
could drive.

In the mean time Rozalmond, Alcidamant, and Grian, being sooner mounted then
the rest, rode away with such speed, as in less than an hour they arrived at
the Forest, where unluckily taking a wrong way, they rode up and down seeking
in vain for Griolanis, and his Queen, who at length met with a big Knight,
bearing two Bears in his shield, which moved with the cries of the Lady, first
of all cut asunder the harness of the horses that drew so rich a prey, and then
sheathing up his Sword, he charged his Lance so furiously against the Giants,
whom he saw making toward him, that he ran one of them through the shield, and
arm, overthrowing him to the ground, but being scarce able to support the
violence of both their incounters upon him at once, he had much ado to keep
himself in his saddle, nevertheless he re-settled himself well again, by that
time the other Giant had finished his course.

This fortunate beginning possessing Griolanis with some hope, he would fain
have got out of the Coach to have succored the Knight, in regard he beheld the
ove^thrown Giant, and the other set both upon him together, but finding no
means to unbind himself, Adelazia being also in the same case, he was ready to
burst with grief, whilst the combat grew very cruel and dangerous: The Knight
of the Bears, who had not been used to lose blood, feeling a great gash on his
left arm, discharged his sword with such fury upon him that seemed to be most
eager in pursuing him, as he cut away a good piece of his Helmet, together with
one of his ears, the point lighting upon his shoulder with that force, as it
overturned him on the crupper of his horse, whereat the other mightily incensed
struck the Knights shield so rudely against his head, that he made him knock
his chin against his breast.

This terrible blow rather animating, than any way discouraging the Knight of
the Bears, he took his sword in both his hands, and let it descend with such
fury upon his shoulder that struck him last, as he opened him to the very
waste, overthrowing him to the earth with a noise like of that of a Pyne, which
the violence of the winds has torn up by the roots, wherewith the remaining
Giant, being more en^aged then afraid, thundered in such sort on the Knights
Helmet, as made him knock his chin against the pommell of his saddle, quite
deprived of sense. O! said Grialanis, (as much vexed with this, as he was glad
at the former blow) that I should be thus unable to revenge my self on this
Giant, who has unfortunately reduced this brave Knight to such an estate, as
he will not be able to deliver us; whereupon striving with all his might, but
in vain, to break his cords in sunder, he descryed a gallant Knight come
gallopping to them, whom by the devise of his shield, he knew to be the
valorous Princess of Tramazond, which so assured him of their liberty, as he
shouted for joy, with the noise whereof the knight of the bears coming out of
his trance resetled himself more furious than a Bell bai^ed with a company of
dogs, and fearing lest the Knight that he saw approaching, should bereave him
of the honor of the combat, he turned him to the Giant which pursued him, and
discharged so cruel a stroke on his arm, as he sent it together with his
Curtelas to the earth, and giving him no leisure to bethink himself, he made a
thrust with such force at his belly, as it ran him quite through and through,
chasing his soul to hell, there to receive the punishment of his wicked life.

In the mean while the fairest Trasiclea arrived, who having with wonder
observed the valor of this invincible Warrior, to her altogether unknown, and
beholding Lestrigond save her self by flight, she unlooses the two Lovers,
which presently went to the Knight of the Bears, and gave him all possible
thanks for their deliverance. I have not done any thing, said he, but what a
good Knight is bound courageously to undertake for the succor of the
afflicted; wherefore there is no thanks due unto me for it, but if you think
yourselves any way obliged unto me, acknowledge it by telling me who you are.
Noble Sir, answered Griolanis, that was as much taken with the beauty of his
face, as with the force of his arm, I am called Griolanis, and this fair Lady
is the Queen of Corolandaya, wherein you now are, both of us this day most
wretchedly betrayed, and no question had served for the satisfaction of our
enemies malice, without the assistance of your valor. Is the enchantment then,
replied the Knight, wherein you were retained brought to an end? Truly I am
very sorry for it, not in that you are freed from the torment you suffered, but
in regard I arrived not time enough, to try whether the honor of that
adventure, for which I have made a long Journey hither, would have lighted on
me.

Now who is that fortunate Knight, which has acquired such glory? The Husband
of this excellent Princess, answered Griolanis (poynting to Trasiclea, whose
exquisite beauty the stranger much admired) named the knight of the burning
Rock, that formerly bore three palms on his shield. Verily, said the strange
Knight, I do not marvel at it now; for that brave Warrior, being
incomparably the best Knight I have known, it was likely that no other could be
able to carry it from him. Ah Madam, continued he, kissing Trasicleas hands,
how happy are you in the possession of so renowned a Knight. It is the greatest
bliss I have in the world, answered she, but Sir, I could wish it were
accompanied with the knowledge of you, for the brave act, which you lately
performed, obliges so many of us together, as I cannot be without this
curiosity. Madam, answered he, as it is my extreme good fortune, that you
desire to know me, so I must humbly beseech you for some reasons to excuse me,
if I do not obey you herein for the present.

Trasiclea perceiving that he desired to conceal himself, importuned him no
farther, and causing Griolanis and Adelazia to mount upon one of the Giants
horses, they all rode on toward Agricant, and on the way they met with
Rozalmond, Alcidamant, and Grian, who beholding Griolanis and his wife safe
from all danger, went and embraced them, with such demonstration of joy and
affection, as if they had not seen them of a long time before, and desiring to
be informed of their deliverance, they showed them the valiant Knight of the
Bears, to whom Rozalmond addressing himself, said. Noble Sir, shall we not
have the honor to know you? That you shall, answered the Knight, for being
altogether your servant, I may by no means conceal my self from you;
whereupon suddenly alighting, and lifting up the vizier of his Helmet, he
