discovered himself to be Persides, brother to Floridan of Persia, whereat
Rozalmond was so exceeding glad, that he held him a great while embraced in his
arms, and then left him to the entertainment of the rest, who after many
compliments, having related unto him all that had past in Corolandaya, they all
got to horse, and rode to the City, where after the return of all those which
were gone in the quest of Griolanis, there was such joy for that so dangerous
an affair had (beyond all hope and expectation) so prosperous a conclusion,
that nothing was to be seen but bonfires, tryumphs, and feastings.

CHAP. XXXV. All the Princes depart out of Corolandaya, some to go to the
Castle of Treasure, and the rest to return into Martaria.
THE arrival of the gentle Persides of Greece, and the happy deliverance of
Griolanis and Adelazia, filling all the Court of Corolandaya with joy, the
Emperor of Martaria, persuaded to the embracing of the Christian religion,
resolved to be baptized, and to make chois of those two Lamps of war,
Alcidamant, and Rozalmond, for his Godfathers, which was performed with all the
state and magnificence, that so short a time would afford: And such were the
delights and pleasures of this Court, as it seemed to be an earthly Paradise,
but who knows not that there is not any content of long continuance in this
world? for fortune interposing her envy, Brandlmanda falls extremely sick,
whereat every one very much grieving, begins to fear some greater misfortune,
which accordingly was not long in coming.

Vrganda, seeing them one day all assembled in the hall, caused silence to be
made, and then spoke thus unto them. Brave Princes, if you esteemed more of
delight then glory, I should not now tell you that it is time for you to betake
you to your arms, first for the honor of that great God, whom we adore, and
then for the conservation of those Empires, which are under the obedience of
your Parents; The care that I have always had to maintayn them in greatness,
having made me the last night to consider the aspect of the Stars, and the
motions of the Moon, I discovered some presages of a mighty misfortune toward,
and all the signs which I observed were so many thunderbolts, ready to fall on
Christondome, whereupon turning over my books for to come to a more particular
knowledge of the mischief, that so I might prepare a remedy for it, I found
that the storm is raised by the instigation of Idalcan, Emperor of Melly, who
being infinitely displeased, for that he was vanquished by Silvan, at such time
as Fulgoran and Prigmaleon covered the fields of Greece with an innumerable
multitude of soldiers, stirs up all Paganism, together with Falanzar, great
Emperor and Caliph of Siconia, his near kinsman, in revenge of that affront,
taking a slight occasion in the first place, to ruin the Empire of Ethiopia,
(whereby he will commence his conquests) upon the alliance which Prigmaleon,
who possesses it, has made with the Princes of Greece, changing his Religion
for to have Polixena, the daughter of Don Florisel of Niquea.

The Posts run up and down, and their league is like to be so great, that most
of the Princes of Paganism, and of the bravest Knights that worship Idols, are
shortly to assemble, for to bring an incredible number of people into the
field, in which regard I have resolved to dispatch away Cassandra, presently to
advertise Don Florisel thereof, to the end that drawing all the Christian
Princes to his party, he may labor to repel the tempest, which is to fall on
Ethiopia; I know that the loss will be great on both sides, but if I be not
much deceived, these Infidels shall not get out of so dangerous an enterprise,
in any better sort then they have done at other times, for

The Prophecy.

THe Lions, that diverse ages have been shut up for their own good, being free
from the chains which so long a time has detayned them, shall then come
forthroaring so dreadfully, that the Crows, unable to make use of their wings,
shall be torn in pieces by the claws of these resuscitated beasts.

In consideration whereof it is most necessary, that fix of you dissoldge to
morrow, to give an end to the enchantment of the Castle of Treasure, situated
in the dangerous Forests of the great Kingdom of Martan, near adjoining to the
Empire of Mexico, a most difficult adventure, but upon the achievement whereof
assuredly depends the happiness or ruin of Christendom. You shall be the
first, said she to Rozalmond, that shall be engaged herein, as having most
in^erest in the business, you shall be accompanied with Am^dis, with Clarisol,
with Alcidamant, with Grian (who shall not defer this voyage for his wives
sickness; the care of whose recovery I will take upon me) and with the brave
King of Corolandaya. You shall carry all these fair Princesses your wives along
with you, who will stand you in no little stand, and because the vali^nt Knight
of the Salvages wives keeps her bed, in her place we will send Penamonda of
Greece, of whom I hope he will have no less regard, then of his own life.

Madam, answered Rozalmond, if we did not know that the proudest buildings are
soonest stricken with lightning, and that fortune makes greatness the object
of her tyranny, we should wonder to see such flourishing Empires, as are now
under the protection of a Cross, subject to the menaces of a ruin, but being
well assured of the inconstancy of the things of this world, and that God will
chastise his people that take no care to serve him, weverily believe that the
rage of these infidels might soon overthrow our glory, if we should not be
assisted from heaven, and with your skill; wherefore we will most readily
prepare our selves for the Enterprise which you have propounded, since it is of
that importance you speak of, and not staying till to morrow we will dislodge
instantly if you please. It will suffice that you depart at the time I have
appointed, replied Vrganda, so that I would have you take order for your
affairs, whilst I turn over my books, and see whether I may be permitted to
succor you in any sort.

Going then from the hall to her Chamber, she left the company astonished at
such unwelcome news, but the greatness of these Champions courages not
permitting them to fear any danger whatsoever, they turned them to the Emperor
of Martaria, who desiring to appear a Christian, and to show the Princes of
Greece what esteem he made of their alliance, told them that he was resolved to
return into Martaria, as soon as ever they were gone, and raise fifty thousand
horse, for to pass into Ethiopia, under the conduct of Persides, Lucibel, and
Sestilian, who was very glad of this occasion, that he might not be so soon
separated from the beautiful Agiliana, his Mistress, who acknowledging the
merits of this young Prince loved him very dearly.

This zeal of the Emperor obliging the Grecian Princes, they rendered him a
thousand thanks, and protested he should never find them unmindful of so great
a favor. On the other side Griolanis, seeing that he was suddenly to depart,
gave out Commissions to leavy twenty thousand foot, under the leading of the
gentle Russian of Media, and of the Marquis of Beltamir, Brandimanda being
resolved to join twenty thousand Amazon horse unto them, which she sent to have
raised in her dominions, attending her recovery in Corolandaya.

Whilst our six Warriors were preparing themselves, Cassandra flew away in a
Chariot, which was never wanting to her designs, and all these Princes began to
feel the displeasure of so sudden a separation; Agriclea sighed for the
departure of Armazia, the Jnfantaes of Martaria, for that of their sister the
fairest Palmirenna, and the mirth of the Court was suddenly converted into
tears.

The next morning then, Vrganda assembled all these great Knights in the hall,
whither she caused six complete armours to be brought, all of them so rich and
strong, as they amazed every one, and presenting them to the six Knights, which
were engaged for the Enterprise of the Castle of Treasure, they presently
quitted their own arms, and put on them, and as they were about to take their
leave of the Emperor, a little Dwarf entered in, followed by a very handsome
Squire, who beholding all these Princes without their Helmets, went and fell at
the feet of Alcidamant with tears of joy in his eyes. O my Lord! said he unto
him, how haypy am I, that have found you out thus, when least I hoped for it,
do not refuse to own me, I beseech you, but grant me the honor, as formerly I
have been, to continue still to be your servant. That thou shall, my dear
Arnides, answered Alcidamant, for I will not turn thee away now, as I did whenI
was anHermit, but how did thou know that I was here? My Lord, replied he,
when you commanded me to leave you to the liberty of your sad thoughts, and
return into France, I could not endure to quit you so, wherefore I retired to a
Village some three miles off, from whence I went once a-week to your Hermitage,
but because I would not displease you with the sight of me, I came into your
Grot at such times, as I knew you were making your accustomed complaints abroad
under the trees, and judging by the continuance of the Lamps burning; that you
were still alive, I stole away again softly, by which means at length finding
you departed, I betook me to travel up and down, hoping that one day I should
meet with you; and hearing of the wonders which have happened in this Court of
late, by good fortune I came hither. I commend thy affection as much, as I am
well pleased to see thee, said Alcidamant, thou art come very seasonably,
wherefore prepare to be gone with me instantly.

This short discourse ended, the Dwarf approached to Amadis, and said unto him;
My Lord, do not you know me? No verily, said Amadis, for I do not remember that
ever I saw thee before. Why thus it is, answered he, to do service unto such
as you are; can you call to mind the Grot in Martaria, whither I led you, when
you had defeated the Monster of the mountain of Bears? Ah! my little Bastinel,
said Amadis unto him, I must now confess my fault, thou art he indeed that
healedst me in a night. It is true, answered the Dwarf, that I am he who cured
your wounds in less time then you speak of, but you never think of the
recompense which you promised then to give me. Ask what thou will, said Amadis,
and I will grant it thee. Why then, said Bastinel, I desire nothing but the
favor, to be either yours, or the fair Princess of Martaria your Wives
Squire. Verily, said Palmirenna, that for all her sorrow, to part with her
Father and Sister, could not choose but laugh, I will entertain thee most
willingly, and me thinks it were better for thee to be with me, then my Lord
Amadis, for so thou shall be sure to lead a quieter and pleasanter life. Be it
so then, said Bastinel, but, Madam, it shall be upon condition that if I fall
in love with any of your fair Maids, you shall not be offended with it.

Hereat every one fell a laughing, especially Mascarin, Miralinda's little
Lover, that pressing through all the company, fell to caressing of Bastinel, and
had much increased the mirth, if the sage Urganda had not urged the departure
of these Knights, who addressed themselves to the Emperor for to receive his
commandments. He having embraced them, left them to take their farewell of the
rest, which was not done without many tears shed by these Princesses, that were
to accompany them, howbeit considering that this separation was but for a
further good, they went and seated themselves in a magnificent Chariot, which
with eight excellent Horses Adelazia had prepared, and attended by these
Princes mounted upon their Steeds, took their journey toward the great
Kingdom of Martan. Two hours after, the Emperor imbarqued himself, with his
two Sons-in-law, Persides and Lucibel, for to return into Martaria. Let us
leave them traversing the Land and Seas, to speak a little of the Pagans
resolution, who assembled with a design, to abate the greatness of the
Christians, and range tham to the adoration of their Idols.

CHAP. XXXVII. The Emperor Falanzar, Caliph of Siconia, solicited by Idalcan,
Emperor of Melly, assembles all Paganism; the resolution they take to make
war upon the Princes of Grease, with the general muster of their Army.
MEn that are generous, have nothing so tender as their honor, which they
cannot endure should be any way touched without some great resentment thereof:
Idalcan Emperor of Melly calling to mind the slaughter of the Kings, and of a
flourishing Army, which he had conducted to Constantinople for the succor of
Prigmaleon, and being no less grieved for having been vanquished in his own
particular, by Silvan, the son of Don Silves de la Silva (as has been related
in the five and thirtieth Chapter of our first part) he resolved once more to
employ all his Friends, and to Arm all the world, rather than want the revenge
of so outrageous an affront. To this effect he dispatched away Courriers to
diverse parts, as soon as he was arrived in his Empire, desiring all the Kings
and Princes adjoining to his Country, to repair unto Falanzar, great Emperor,
and Caliph of Siconia, his near kinsman, for to deliberate of certain affairs,
much importing the glory of Paganism.

These dispatches made, he commanded all his Captains to come before him, unto
whom he delivered commissions for the raising and arming of threescore thousand
men, and departing instantly thereupon, he went into Siconia, where his rage
furnishing him with reasons able to persuade very much, he so incensed Falanzar
against the Christians, that he resolved to set up his rest on this quarrel,
and to revenge his Kinsman at the cost of all the Pagans.

Bethinking him then of those which might best serve his enterprise, he sent
away messengers to the furious King of Grifalara, to Brufaldar, King of
Gedrosia; and to the valourous Artogant, Sultan of Francapa; to Marmaran, Sophy
of Bultera; to Brizardan, Sultan of Aratifia; to the grand Salvage; to the King
of Russia; to Gronfalin of Moreda, King of Facea; to Gorgophon, the redoubted
Colonel of the Giants; to Marcelian, Emperor of Medra; to the proud Caliph of
Francapia Antomedon; to Fierastron, King of Balivan; to Asturion, the strong
Sultan of Brutacon; to Furcamond, King of Martan; to Moranteon, Sultan of
Circassia, whom afterward he reconciled to Gorgophon about the carrying away
of Armazia; to the King of Cabilla; to Palamedes, King of Cassandria; and
briefly to all the Princes from whom he could hope for any assistance, in such
sort, that at the end of two months, there were in person at his Court,
together with the Kings of Mauritania, of Tremizen, of Zamphara, of Zambar, of
Cartagena, of Aganezes, of Angali, of Numidia, of Bisaura, of Thunes, of
Teneri, of Miramolin; of the Isle of Till, of the Tragonites, of Zanfara, of
Calizan, of Morlavia, of Nazamor, of Siziphala, of Tingafort, of Barnagas, of
Monomatapan, of Arginare, and of Cornata (all which came at the request of the
Emperor of Melly) an hundred and thirteen Kings, Emperors, Caliphs, Soldans,
and Sovereign Princes, from whose valors great wonders were to be expected.
All these great Lords being by Falanzar assembled in a stately and spations
Hall where he had caused so many Thrones to be erected, and perceiving a
silence over all, he spoke in this manner.

The Oration of Falanzar Emperor of Siconia, to the Pagan Potentates.
MIghty Princes, I have troubled you so far, as to assemble you here for to
represent two things unto you, which are of great consequence for us. The glory
of our Altars much abated by the insolence of certain petty Princes of Greece,
and the little resentment of the outrages, we have a thousand times received
thereupon; It is more then time, me thinks for us to rouse up our selves, to
appear more zealous in the service of the gods, more sensible, and less
daunted for some passed losses, which have fallen upon us by the indiscreet
managing of our designs, and by our neglect of taking hold of occasion, when
it has been fairly presented unto us. We have suffered them to grow great,
for which they mock us; nay, that is worse, are so vain, as to threaten to come
and share our Crowns with us at their pleasure, to put us all to the sword, to
force our people to acknowledge their Dominion, and to render all the earth
subject to their command. Is not this a vanity too insupportable to bear, and
shall we endure to have them come and seek us in our houses, for to deprive us
of our Wives, our Lands, and our liberties? Verily it amazes me, that all
Paganism being replenished with mighty Emperors, Callphs, Soldans, Princes,
and excellent Knights, no man would never yet speak of overrunning these
insolents, and not leaving them so much as a foot of ground, upon which they
might tread as Masters; For mine own part, I am resolved to exhaust all my
treasures, put all my subjects into Arms, and not to leave a soldier in all
the Empire of my Cousin of Melly (who has far more cause to complain, and
speak as I do) for to march into the Empire of Ethiopia (whose Prince has of
late played Bankerupt without gods, for to allie himself with their enemies)
and utterly to subvert it, to the end that in some sort discharging the duty I
owe unto their providence, which have made me Lord of a great people, I may not
draw their displeasure upon me, so that if your zeal be like unto mine (as by
your countenances I am persuaded to hope;) you will not stick at the
consideration of the pains you are to suffer, but will cheerfully go to the
Empires which are destined to your valo^rs, and appropriating the Crowns thereof
unto your selves, you may in such sort receive some kind of satisfaction for
your labors; Now if you apprehend the dangers which are oftentimes incident to
these troublesome undertakings, remember that you shall do no more than my
self; I will always ^arch with you in Arms, I will encounter the enemy
courageously, and ever being the first at blows, I will still be the last, if
I may, to retire. Behold, great Kings, the Emperor of Mellyes designs,
together with mine freely discovered, let us now understand your minds, to the
end we may know from whom we may expect to be succored in so just and glorious
an enterprise.

It is usual with men to differ in opinion upon the proposition of any matter
whatsoever: The most part of these Princes, and especially they which desired
to seek for glory in blood and slaughter, found this design to be generous,
howbeit the rest, who weighed all things with a more mature deliberation,
thought it not fit to be embraced. Falanzar required a general advice, but
because they could not speak all at once, every man cast his eye upon the King
of Cabilla, a man of age and experience, and desired him to answer for them
all, who after he had often refused to deliver his opinion before so many
Emperors and Princes, that were far more eminent in greatness than himself,
at length spoke in this manner.

The King of Cabillaes answer to Falanzar.
GReat Monarch, the Design you propound is very generous, full of zeal for
the glory of our Altars, and for the honor of our Crowns, but it is no less
difficile than great, and when I consider the mischiefs that follow Wars,
whereof the event is ever doubtful, I neither can authorize, nor will counsel
you to follow it. You attempt most redoubted enemies, that were never beaten,
either abroad or at home, all together, or apart, and that know so well how to
manage their affairs, as they will make an Elephant of a Rat, and so favored
of Fortune, that when a man thinks them at the lowest of the wheel, he shall
be sure to find them on the top. Our Predecessors have many times covered the
fields of Greece with an infinity of men; Have they thereby abated their
greatnes^e? Nay, ^ather they have augmented it, and their own defeat has
served to render them more more glorious. If you will call to mind the mighty
assemblies which the progenitors of the great Duke of Muscovy, that now hears
me, have heretofore made, or that furious voyage of Aleppo, where it was
believed that all the earth would tremble at the very sight of our Standards,
but not to go so far, if you will consider that here are now present, many
Successors of a number of Princes slain in these last expeditions, rashly
undertaken for the King of Canabea, who at length proved to be their Kinsman,
and for the young Emperor of Ethiopia, whom love has turned enemy to his
own gods, without doubt you will not so lightly precipitate year selves, nor
forsaking the rest you so quietly enjoy, will you go and seek out travells,
whose recompense is but ill assured; the Descent to hell is easy, so is not
the return, we may carry a million of men into their Territories, but how many
of them can we say, that we shall save from the fury of their swords? I know
that revenge is sweet, but I condemn those that desire it, when they are not
able to obtain it. Nor d^e I speak this, because I misdoubt the valor of our
Knights, and of so many Giants as we have, whose forces are extreme, but figure
(...) your selves I pray you, Prigmalion, Fulgoran, and the brave Bastard of
Media, in the heads of an hundred thousand Horse, cutting our squadrens in
pieces; represent unto your selves Florisel of Niquea, Don Rogel of Greece,
Spheramond Emperor of the Parthians, as three furies amongst our Troops, and
fifty Princes of their blood, nothing inferior to them in valor, overthrowing
all that ever they meet withal; besides, have you not heard of those two
invincible Champions? Alcidamant and Rozalmond, whose blows are no less
violent then lightning; Ask of the mighty Gorgophon, who has seen and
encountered them in arms, what is to be expected from their fury; Demand of the
redoubted Brizardine, Sultan of Aralafia, and of the brave Arastron, whom here
you behold, or rather of me alas! Demand I say what they think, and what I
believe concerning the valor of a young Amadis, who in the Empire of Martaria,
that went disguised in the habit of a maiden Slave, they are witnesses of his
force, and for my part I can tell to my ever lasting grief, that his blows are
so many tempests, under the fury whereof I have seen Rifantes, who might justly
vaunt himself to be one of the best Knights of the world, cleft down to the
shoulders; but to go further yet, what think you of the famous Knight of the
Salvage, who fills all the earth with wonder, or of a young Shepherd called
Clarisel, before whom the strongest Giants have fallen, are not they to be
feared? Or will the Jncounter of the valiant King of Corolandaya, and a
thousand more that I could name, whose swords would be so many thunderbolts, on
the heads of our friends, leave you in assurance of victory? Verily me thinks
J see our Soldiers already tumbling into the Sea at the landing of our ships,
I see them some cut off by the middle, others divided in twain, and all of them
bathing in a River of blood; Wherefore J will never conclude for war, ^or
counsel you to be Author of their destruction, for it is a greater glory to
preserve, then to conquer a people. Hewbeit, if they should prove so a^dacious,
as to come hither, for to see how our Crowns would become their heads, then
would J speak no longer of rest, but would be the the first in the field, and
let the world know, it was not the fear of death made me produce these
reasons, which I have delivered to persuade you, that a certain peace is
better than an uncertain victory.

This discourse very powerful, and maintained with the experience of things,
having put them all in suspense, every one began to consider the consequence of
this design, when as Roussardan the furious King of Grisalara, rose up, and
casting a disdainful look on the King of Cabilla, turned him to Falanzar,
saying.

GReat Emperor of Sciconia, the advice which the King of Cabilla gives you, is
indeed very fit for him, that prefers his pleasures before glory, but most
pernicious for a Prince, that desires to render himself greater by his own
virtue, than by the possession of States, and I wonder that so many excellent
Knights, wherewith this place is replenished, could all this while endure such
prating, as has done nothing but undervalew us; he b^asts the power of our
enemies, as if ours were less, and measuring every ones arm by his own,
which is unable to support more then one Scepter, would persuade us that those
of the Christians are stronger, and their swords better edged than ours, but we
should prove as cowardly, as he to bel^^ve him, and it would for ever hereafter
be a shame unto as, if we should n^w retire upon so unworthy a consideration: I
agree with him, that the effect of War is doubtful, nor will I deny but that
some of their Knights are strong and valiant, but where should we seek for
honor but in dangers, and what shall crown our work, but the difficulty of our
enterprise? That is it which must renown us, and the rememberance of the passed
wars, ought to work a contrary effect to that he speaks of, not to increase
our fear, but our courage, for obtaining that which our Predecessors could not
obtain to, we shall join the glory of their actions to ours, and tryumphing
over those that have vanquished them, we shall fill the world with the praises
of our valor, for mine own part I will join my forces with yours, and I
believe there are few here but will do the like.

What cannot the persuasions of a valiant man do with active spirits? All
those Kings, the most part so inclined of themselves, and the rest in imitation
of them, rose up and protesting for the war, marvellously rejoiced Falanzar,
who having assured them that he expected no other from the greatness of their
courages, gave them infinite thanks, and particularly caressed Roussardan, the
Grand Salvage, and Gorgophon; whereupon he let them depart with a promise of
return within three months, at which time there appeared in the playns of
Siconia; first, fourscore thousand Horse raised in the dominions of Falanzar,
whose Imperial Ensign carried two silver Doves in a field azure; threescore
thousand of Idalcans subjects, the Emperor of Melly, who bore a Gerfalcon
crowned: Thirty thousand the followers of Artogan, Sultan of Francapa, that
carried three Escallops in a golden field: Thirty thousand in the head, whereof
marched the Cornet of Marmaran, Sophy of Bultara, with three Griffons, struck
all through with one sword; Thirty thousand under the conduct of the furious
King of Grifalara, whose Arms were two Lions in a chayn, held by the force of
one hand; Thirty seven thousand that came from Aralafia, whose Sultan carried
three Roses, separated by a broken cheveron; Forty thousand followed Armandor,
the great Duke of Muscovy, who bore three Eagles in a sky; Twenty thousand were
led by the brave Moranteon, Sultan of Circassia, having three Bears in a silver
field: The Grand Salvage conducted fifteen thousand, with his son Furiander,
Tipheus, the huge and dreadful Giant Burcandor of the Rock, and Bucarquant his
brother, two of the strongest and valiantest Giants of the earth: Gorgophon
followed them accompanied with thirty Giants, and twenty thousand men; Next
after marched Marcelian, Emperor of Media, bearing two fishes argent hanging
at a line in a field gueles, with five and twenty thousand, two and twenty
Giants, Argantor, Lizart, Bronta^or, and Borald the stout, most redoubted
Knights, and of great esteem in Arms; The stately Caliph of Francapia,
Antomedon carrying a Panther tied in a silver chayn, appeared in the front of
sixteen Giants, and twenty thousand Knights richly armed; The strong Astrurion,
Sultan of Brutacan, having an Ape between three Wolves, followed next with two
and twenty thousand men, Margenio, Fiortan, Brandimart, and Plaiartes,
excellent Warriors; After him Policastaleon, King of Zeilan, a valiant Pagan
bearing a Siren in the midst of a troubled Sea, conducted fifteen thousand
very brave Horse, fourteen Giants, with the gallant Alceus, Astrenion the
glorious, and Cariander the hairy; The redoubted King of Baleon, Fierastron
bearing a bloody sword in his Cornets, marched with five and twenty Giants, and
twenty five thousand men, then Gronfalin King of Pacea, presented himself with
twelve thousand Horse, and fifteen Giants; and last of all marched the valarous
Brufaldon, King of Gedrosia, bearing a great many of Ermines in a Cressant,
with seven and thirty Giants, and two and twenty thousand men, well appointed.
After the Muster of this Cavalery, which amounted to five hundred thousand
Horse, and more; all the Infantry advanced, conducted by the Kings of
Mauritania, of Tremisen, of Zaphir, of Zambar, of Cartegena, of Aganazes, of
Budomel, of Moraria, of Arger, of Angali, of Numidia, of Bizaur, of Thunes, of
Teneri, of Miramlin, of the I Will of Till, of the Tragenites, of Zanfara, of
Calisan, of Morlavia, of Nazamor, of Siziphalt, of Tingefort, of Barnagas, of
Monomatapan, of Arginari, and of Cornate, which being composed of four hundred
thousand men, and an hundred Giants, gave infinite content to Falanzar, who was
by an unanimous consent elected General of all those Troops, which amounting
to nine hundred thousand men, and upwards, were imbarqued speedily, and put to
Sea, where we will leave them sailing with a prosperous wind, and turn to see
what our Christian Princes will do, being advertised by Cassandra, of such a
dangerous expedition against them.

CHAP. XXXVII. Cassandra arriveth at Constantinople, to advertise the Grecian
Princes of the mighty Army the Pagans had brought into the field, to march into
Ethiopia; the resolution they take thereupon.
CAssandra posting as nimbly through the clouds, as a Bird, whose wings had the
assistance of a favorable wind, arrived in two days at Constantinople, to the
great content of all the Princes there, and especially of Don Florisel of
Niquea, who caressing her, demanded what good news she had brought them of
their children, and of the health of Arquiffe and Vrgand^? Sir (answered
Cassandra) my father and my mother were never in better estate, nor more
disposed to your service, Amadis of Trebisond, Rozalmond, Clarisel of Guindaya
your son, Persides, Floridan of Persia, Lucibel of France, and Russian of
Media, have got so great a reputation, performing daily such wonderful
exployts, that they are deservedly accounted the bravest Knights of the earth:
It will not be long before you see them here, accompanied with their wives, the
fairest Princesses alive: Your son enjoyes the incomparable Shepherdess of
France, Miralinda, the excellent luster of whose beauty has filled the world
with amazement, whose virtues do^ far exceed her birth, though that cannot be
denied to be most noble, she being daughter to the Marquis of Monteclare, one
of the first houses of France, and Sister to that invincible Knight of the
Palms, of whose valor your self have been sometimes a witness; Rozalmond is
the only favorite of the matchless Armazia, Princess of the great Empire of
Gardacia; Amadis of Trebisond, shall succeed the Emperor of Martaria, by the
enjoying of Palmirenna, heir to a multitude of fruitful and flourishing
Provinces: Lucibel and Floridan of Persia, shall marry the two sisters of that
Princess; and gentle Russian having taken to Wife the fair Agriclea, is
possessrd of the Crown of Clariana.

Dear Lady (said Florisel to Cassandra) it is no less content to me to hear
my Son is that renowned Knight, of whom all France, and Great Britain as speak
of some prodigy, then that my Brother and Nephew have gained the Empires of
Gradaria and Martaria, for I value the merit and wisdom of Miralinda at so
high a rate, that I esteem no less of her, than of the greatest Princess
alive. And believe it, when they shall present themselves unto me, I will not
fail to receive them with a hearty entertainment.

Without doubt (replied Cassandra) you can do no less, neither can you choose
but rejoice at the happy event of these things. But Sir, it is most necessary
that I should a little disturb the quiet, and content you now enjoy, and impart
unto you a secret which I fear will find but a bad welcome. All the Pagans are
up in Arms, at the instance of Idalcan Emperor of Melly, who not long since
received an overthrow in this place, and so great is the number of the forces
they have assembled, now ready to fall upon Ethiopia (because of the alliance
the Emperor Prigmaleon has lately made with you) that unlesst it be assisted
by some peculiar providence from heaven (who never suffers his to perish for
want of succor) you cannot easily prevent their ruin: I know very well the
greatness of your courage will contemn this danger, but take heed what you do,
for all other Armies that you have seen assembled heretofore, are nothing in
comparison of this, where so many brave Knights will be ready to encounter you,
that the force of your unconquered Armies, and of your friends, were never more
useful, and necessary than now.

Let them come when they will, said Florisel, we will be prepared for them, and
I hope to give them such entertainment, as shall well abate the fury of their
pride; and the rather, I make no doubt if you will assist us a little with some
effect of your skill. Sir, answered she, you must expect succor from heaven,
and your own valor; the assistance of my skill can afford you none, unless I
should raise the dead, and bring them to fight for your safety; but I perceive
you do not understand these words, nor can I speak in plainer terms till the
Destinies give way unto it: think only upon those things which a good Captain
ought to put in practice for the annoying of his enemies, and being seconded by
Fortune, who is always your friend, make them know that you are still
invisible.

You have advised so well, answered Florisel, that if you please to go and try
what entertainment our Ladies will give you, I will in the mean time deliberate
thereupon; so leaving her with Sidonia, and the other Princesses that
accompanied her (to whom she was forced to make a particular relation of the
loves and adventures of Amadis and Clarisel, and to describe the beautiee of
Armazia, Mirglinda, Palmirenna, and her Sisters.) He caused a^l the Princes
then present at Constantinople to assemble in the Council chamber, where he
spoke to them in this manner;

Sirs, I did not call you hither to resolve whither we ought to make a War or
no, since necessity enforces us thereunto, but to consult with you what means
we had best use to oppose the violence of so mighty an enemy, as is now ready
to fall upon us: It is a matter of no small consequence, our eternal glory, or
absolute ruin depending thereupon; Wherefore I am of opinion, our states having
so long a time enjoyed peace, and being now furnished with a multitude of brave
soldiers, who desire nothing more than opportunity to show themselves so, that
it will be the best way to employ our Subjects, our Allies, and all our
friends, and to raise as many men as possibly we can, without taking from such
garrisons as shall be necessary in important places, so to prevent the
insolences of our enemies, and cause that desolation, which continually waits
upon War, to fall rather upon their own, than our Territories. They aim at
Ethiopia, wherefore (said he, addressing himself to Prigmaleon) my advise shall
be, since that Empire receives your Laws, and acknowledges your Sovereignty,
that you depart suddenly with such forces as I will send along with you, that
you employ all the friends you can make in these parts, that you cause your
Ports, and Frontier Towns to be fortified with all diligence, and that you
manage your affairs with such discretion, that you may be able for a while to
withstand the assault of so fur^ous an Army; In the mean time we will hasten
your succor, and cut out so much work for these Insolents, that perhaps it may
prove the last design they shall ever undertake against us.

This oppinion meeting with no opposition, was equally received of all, as the
most profitable; so every one retired to consider of his charge. Florisel gave
out Commissions for the speedy levying of fifty thousand Horse in Greece, sent
certain Gentlemen to Don Rogel, to Spheramond; to the Queen of Alaxtraxerea, to
Lucondus King of France; dispatched his Courriers to Rome, to Germany, to
Sardinia, to great Britain, to Guindaya, to the Kings of Dardania, of
Comogena, of the greater Indies, of Samothracia, of Lydia, of Cataya, of
Poland, of Hungary, of Moldavia, of Ireland, of Scotland, of Turkey; in brief,
to all the Princes of his acquaintance; entreating them to meet him with their
forces at Constantinople, as soon as they possibly could.

He having made all these dispatches, and being taught by experience, that the
wisdom and foresight of men do oftentimes exempt them from eminent dangers, he
caused Prigmaleon and Fulgoran to depart in a small Flyboat, which cost the
fair Polixena his Wife many a tear, who was forced to stay behind him; and four
days after he sent the valiant Esquilan of Poland, in whose virtue he was most
confident, with him the two Cenophales, Rosanel of Astrea, who was then in the
Court with the fair English Lady his Wife, ^lorian, Tristor, Perionaf Turkey;
Quadragant, Agrian, of Scotland; Abies of Ireland; Dordanio, Florisartus,
Leonidas of Mesopotamia; Armond of Bohemia; and Melford, in the head of fifty
thousand Horse, commanding them to repair with all expedition to Saba, the
chief City of Ethiopia; and to acknowledge Prigmaleon for their General,
until such time as he should be there himself in person.

In the mean space whilst these troops were advancing Prigmaleon and Fulgoran,
at the Sea, had the benefit of afair wind, but we seldom arrive at our desires
without some crosses, for on a sudden the Sea begins to swell, and waxes so
rough, that the Mariners foreseeing a violent tempest, were forced to cast
Anchor at the edge of a rock which made the point of a little Island, where
these two Knights dis-imbarquing themselves to decline the trouble of the Seas,
advanced into the Land, commanding the Pilot to wait their return.

The Island seemed to be very delightful, by reason of the abundance of Trees
planted in a handsome order, upon the sides of little pleasant hills, and
shadowing the crystal Rivolets, which environed the fruitful Meadows: As they
were discoursing of the wonders of God, the Creator of all those things that
presented themselves to their view, they espied a beautiful young Lady coming
toward them, who ever and anon tearing her hair, uttered these sad and strange
complaints; Alas! said she, must the fire consume so sweet a face, and can a
woman's rage be the cause of so great a disaster! O ye gods! let this day
produce some miracle, and if ye will preserve me alive, deliver this Knight
from so cruel a death.

These words disposed the hearts of the two Princes to a sensibility of
compassion, so that drawing near to her, Fulgoran spoke in this manner; Lady,
may it lie in our power to do you any service in this so pressing an
affliction? Yes, without doubt, replied she, and the pains you take, will be
most honorably employed, in saving from death a most deserving Knight, one of
the most amiable the eyes of man ever beheld; if you please to walk forward,
I Will give you the whole relation, for I fear, if we should make any stay here,
we should come too late to relieve him.

This Knight arrived three months since in this Island, which is called the
deceitful Island; It was his ill fortune to fall into the hands of Gargaracia,
a Giantesse, none of the largest in the world, but the cruellest that ever was,
for taking pleasure in shedding of man's blood, she continually entertains a
multitude of Ruffians in a Castle, who either by surprisall, or force, seiz
upon all the Knights that pass this way, and cast them into prison, from
whence she brings out some of them once a year to facrifice to her Idols;
This young Gentleman, I say, being arrived here, encountered twelve of her
Soldiers, which thinking presently to lay hands on him, were charged with such
an undaunted valor, that ten of them being cut in pieces, the other two betook
themselves to their heels; this Knight pursuing them with too much confidence,
came at length before the Castle gates of this Gyantesse, who making use of me
for the better accomplishing of her treasons, caused me to descend to appease
his anger, and to entreat him to take the benefit of the Castle to refresh
himfelf in, and to be assured that he should not receive the least wrong there.

His ill fortune enduced him to believe me, so that he presently followed me
in, and unarming himself, he showed me so rare a beauty, that to say the truth,
I began a little to feel the power of love, which bred in me such an extreme
sorrow, that I had been the means to imprison him within those cruel Walls, as
at the same instant, I had set him at liberty, by causing him to retire, if
Gargaracia had not then entered with a design, rather to take from him his
life, than to give him any courteous entertainment; but the ravishing charms of
his looks overmastering this bloodthirsty humor, she forthwith became
passionatly amorous, resolving to spare him for the satisfying of her filthy
lust, and shamelesly embracing him, she let him know, that her intent was to
make him happy, by vouchsasing him a part in her own bed.

At those words the Knight taking a full view of her, and seeing her face
furrowed with wrincles, her eyes sunk into her head, her grisly knotted hairs,
blobberd-lips, flat nose, accompanied with all the marks of ugliness, could
hardly forbear laughter, nevertheless considering that there might be danger
in provoking her, he made this reply, that his faith obliging him to be ever
true to the affections of a certain Lady whom he loved, he humbly besought her
not to take it ill, that he could not embrace the honor she was pleased to
offer him; How, said she, in a great rage, do you slight me thus, knowing that
you are now in my power? believe me you shall repent it at leisure. Then laying
hands on him, she called twenty of her servants to her, by whose assistance
having fast bound him, she cast him (to my great grief) into a dark Dungeon,
purposing to infflict daily upon him insufferable torments; but her passion of
love bearing a greater sway than that of anger, she called me to her at break
of day, and telling me that the nights rest had not freed her from those
unquiet thoughts whereto the beauty of the young Knight had subjected her, she
desired me to visit him, and to advise him to live in her favor, otherwise he
must expect no mercy.

This command suiting with my wishes, I presently took a Torch in my hand, and
went down to the place, where I found the Knight bound, who perceiving me
coming toward him, demanded if I brought him the first news of his death,; to
whom I answered, that my coming was not to afflict him, but to let him know,
that in my opinion he could do much better, to give way a little to my Ladies
passion, then to submit himself to her cruelty; she is preparing, said I,
horrible torments, avoid them, I beseech you, since you may, and be not so
cruel to your self, as to become your own Murderer. How, replied he, yield to
the affection of such a Monster! Lady, if this be the end your discourse ayms
at, I must needs let you know you loose your labor; she thinks to affright me
with the threats of punishment, and I am resolved to endure them all even to
death, than in the least measure to satisfy her desires. You are then said I,
either very faithful, or else too wilful in your opinion; Neither the one nor
the other, answered he, for I cannot acknowledge my self guilty of any
wilfulness, in refusing the embraces of an old carcass, the very sight
whereof is a terror to me: neither do I decline them to keep my affections
entire to any Mistress, my soul as yet being free from subjection to any beauty
whatsoever, and if I did to her use this diffimulation, it was only in hope to
escape by that means out of her hands, but since that and all other shifts
fail me, let fortune dispose of me as she pleases. You refuse her then, said
I, because she is not beautiful. Yes, answered he, for that only reason, but
if I should desire to have any interest in her, I could wish for my own sake to
see her deformities changed into your perfections.

Upon these words (to acknowledge the truth; and my own weakness) those first
sparks of love, which his sight only had before kindled, did so inflame my
heart, that laying aside the consideration of modesty, which ought never to be
separated from a young Lady, I ran hastily and embraced him, promising him
withal, to deliver him upon any conditions, though never so dangerous: Then
leaving him somewhat comforted with the hope of escaping, I went to seek
Gargaracia, to whom I reported that the Knight began to speak a more pleasing
language, and that without doubt, her courteous entertaynment would prevail
much more with him than her cruelty; wherewith she being not a little
satisfied, gave me commission to conduct him into a Chamber, whereof she her
self kept the key, to whom notwithstanding I had access twice a day, faining
continually some excuse or other, by means whereof I enjoyed sweetly the
embraces of this young Knight, still keeping Gargaracia in a firm opinion, that
she should ere long have the full fruition of him, so that we led a life full
of content and happiness, in the midst of misery.

But that improvident passion, which blinds the eyes of all Lovers, ruined us
also, even then when we had invented a way, how to escape and save our selves:
for I going this morning to visit him, and forgetting to make fast the doors,
left a passage open, through which Gargaracia espied us, in the hight of such
amorous dalliance, as Love uses to suggest unto those, whose hearts she has
already united, which put her into such a rage, that forthwith she advanced
toward us, intending with her strong boisterous hands to bind us both, had she
not been prevented by the Knight, who with his first blow struck her to the
ground, with a resolution to strangle her, had she not suddenly called for
succor; I saved my self among the Soldiers, who being ignorant of what had
passed, sought not at all to stay me, and so crossing these fields, used the
best diligence I could to fly from thence, to the end that I might not again
fall into the hands of that pitiless woman, and to see if it might be my good
fortune to meet with some charitable Knight, that would undertake the rescue of
this poor Gentleman, who questionless by this time is very near the flames,
for the cruel Hag supposing fire to be the extremest of punishments, has
taken order that he shall be suddenly cast into it.

Fair Lady, said Fulgoran, comfort your self, and be assured of the Knights
safety, if we can but arrive soon enough to find him living; then putting spurs
to their horses, they presently came before the Gates of the Castle, where they
saw thirty soldiers coming forth to lead this Knight to the fire; whom
Fulgoran knowing to be Cilinder, the son of Dorigel, King of the fortunate
Island, of whom there had been no news heard since he received his order of
Knighthood at Constantinople, he pressed toward him with an incredible
violence, and cleaving down to the girdle five or six of those that encompassed
him, put the rest into such a fright, that on a sudden they all left him, which
Fulgoran perceiving lighted from his horse to unloose the cords wherewith he
was bound, deeming the force of Prigmaleon alone, sufficient enough to cut the
rest of the rascals into a thousand pieces; and indeed this noble Warrior made
so great a massacre amongst them, that in half an hour, he laid eighteen dead
at his feet, which Gargaracia seeing to her great grief, and hoping to fare no
better than her Champions, cast her self immediately into that fire, she had
prepared for Cilindor, who presently knowing Fulgoran and Prigmaleon, gave them
a thousand thanks for his deliverance.

Gargaracia being consumed, Cilindor delivered, and none else appearing to
oppose the designs of these Knights, they caused the prison doors to be all
opened, where they found the Giant (...) and the unknown Knight, their
especial friends, with forty or fifty more of their acquaintance, whom after
they had saluted, they asked by what accident they were fallen into the hands
of that cruel woman; by the most villainous treachery in the world, answered
(...), for arriving both together here, and being courteously received we were
led into a Chamber, where drinking of wine mingled with Poppy, which was
presented unto us, we fell into so sound a sleep, that we were ^asily bound and
carried into this Dungeon, where we lay above eight hours before we awaked.
Thanks be to the gods, said Prigmaleon, who appointed us to arrive here so
opportunely for your deliverance; Come let us quit this melancholy place, and
we will relate unto you at leisure, the occasion that brought us from
Constantinople; then committing the care of the Castle to Milcana, Cilinders
Mistress, who received but little joy with it, being ready to take leave of her
servant, without hope of ever seeing him again, they took their way toward
thesea, which at their return they found calm, and promising a quick passage
into Ethiopia; where they being arrived, Prigmaleon assembled his Council,
caused Saba to be very well fortified, laid strong Garrisons in the most
important places, and joining fifty thousand other Horse, to those which
Florisel sent him, who arrived three weeks after, he expected without fear or
amazement the fury of his enemies.

CHAP. XXXIX. The arrival of the Pagans in the Empire of Ethiopia, the cruel
fight where with all the Grecian Princes entertained them at their landing.
THE Christian Princes having no greater object, than the honor of God, the
glory of the world, and the preservation of those Empires they possessed,
prepared themselves immediately upon the receipt of Don Florisels Letters, and
levying Forces out of each particular Kingdom, they brought to Constantinople,
the bravest troops that ever was beheld; First came Don Rogel with thirty
thousand Horse, and twenty thousand Foot; the excellent Emperor of the
Parthians, with twenty thousand Horse, and twenty thousand Foot; Don Lucendue,
with thirty thousand Horse, and ten thousand Foot; Alastraxeret, with twenty
thosand Horse, and ten thousand Foot; Derigel of the fortunate Island, and the
fair Cilinda his Wife, with twelve thousand Horse; Melind^^ of Clotona, and his
wife Casti^^a, with fifteen thousand horse, his Brother Olid^r with the Queen
of Castora his Wife led fifteen thousand Foot; Silran and his Wife eighteen
thousand Horse; Amenia of Asre, fourteen thousand Foot; Anaxander King of
Dardania, twelve thousand Horse, and eight thousand Foot; Fl^^idan his Brother,
King of Comogena, eighteen thousand Foot; Gel^dan, and the valiant Arletta,
fifteenthousand Horse; Oriander, King of Sardamira, seventeen thousand Foot;
Galard, King of Megera, eight thousand Horse, and six thousand Foot; the King
of Catay, nine thousand Horse, and seven thousand Foot; Liscard, King of
Licaonia, twelve thousand Horse; Rozafar of Austria, eleven thousand Foot;
Gadard King of Hungary, ten thousand Horse, and eight thousand Foot; Filadart,
King of Poland, eight thousand horse, and ten thousand Foot; Ladazan of Nudia,
and Parmenian of Ciprus, five and twenty thousand Foot; From Rome there came
fifteen thousand Horse; From Germany fifteen thousand; from Guindaya eleven
thousand; and besides all these, Don Florisel had raised thirty thousand Horse
in the Empire of Greece.

These Troops which amounted to the number of three hundred thousand Horse, and
two hundred thousand Foot, being all speedily imbarqued; Florisel and the other
Princes of Greece, took their leaves of the Ladies, who with tears conjured
them to have a special care in the preservation of themselves, amidst so many
dangers as they were sure to encounter; and so getting aboard, they caused the
Mariners to hoist the sails, which the wind presently began to fill with a
favorable gale.

In the mean time the Enemies innumerable Army were upon their voyage at Sea,
sometimes driven forward violently with the threatenings of atempest, sometimes
again arested with the stillness of a calm; so that five weeks after they were
shipped in the Empire of Siconia, they discovered the strong Walls of Saba, and
appeared in the view of the Christian Princes there, who endeavoring by the
best means they could to prevent their landing, fortified the shore with fifty
thousand Horse, under the command of Prigmaleon, Fulgoran, the two Cenophales,
Perion, Quadragant, Florestan, Cilindor, Florian, and Tristor, which being
perceived by the Pagans, who made thitherwards with full sails, they presently
ranged their Ships in the best order they could, for the dis-imbarquing
themselves without confusion, and advanced till they were near enough to begin
the charge with Bows and Pikes.

Roussardan, the terrible King of Grifalara, Gorgophon, the Graund Salvage,
Furiander, and fifteen Giants which had the command of the foremost Vessels,
arriving with an incredible fury, there was heard even in a moment a confusion
of cries, mixed with the hideous noise of the waves, and the shrill and loud
sounds of Drums and Trumpets, the air being clouded as it were with a
multitude of Arrows, which flew both from Sea and Land, a man could hardly
discern neither the sands that were covered with dead bodies, nor the waters
all dyed red with the blood of those that fell therein.

The Pagans being confident as well in their numbers, as their valor, and
advancing courageously, without any fear at all of the Christians shot, began
to place their Bridges and scaling Ladders, to the end that they might win the
bank with less difficulty; But Fulgoran, Prigmaleon, the Cenophales, and the
other young Princes that assisted them, did so stoutly repulse them, that as
many as adventured to quit their Ships, they tumbled into the Sea, so that in a
short time the waves were covered with such a multitude of dead bodies, as
those four proud Pagan Knights not enduring to behold so miserable a massacre
of their people, on the sudden with their Giants, and a hundred thousand men,
leapt on shore in spite of the Christians resistance, and fell to it pell
mell, with such incredible violence, that a man might perceive more men fall
than blows; all those those that stood in (...) way, he cleft down to the wast,
Gorgophon cut them in pieces; F^ri^nder and his Father made such havok, and
their Fanchions were so terrible, that every one shund them like so many
furies; on the other side Fulgoran, Prigmaleon, the Cenophales, Perion, and
their companions, made so great a slaughter, that the most part of the Pagans
cast themselves into the water, to avoid the furious execution of their swords;
In this manner the battle waxing hot, so many fell dead on every side, as was
most dreadful to behold; Fulgoran and Prigmal^on being incensed marvellously,
at the sight of so great a slaughter, which proceeded not so much from the
multitude of their enemies, as from the force and valor of their Leaders,
being accompanied with the Cenophales, and making themselves way with the death
of all that opposed them, they in an instant charged them with such fury, that
the fierce stroke Ro^ssardan received from Prigmaleons sword, made him knock
his chin against his breast, Gorgophon bowed his knee underthe violence of
Fulgorans blow; the Grand Salvage with F^riander his son, were staggered by the
weighty blades of the two Ge^ophales, and of the Giants two were slain by
Cilind^r, and P^rion.

But into what a rage were these proud Pagans driven at the resentment hereof?
they rowsed up their spirits again, and became more furious than Tigers, and
raising their weapons into the air, they let them fall with such a tempest upon
the Christian Knights, that Prigmaleons shield was cleft in two pieces, with a
hurt on his arm, Fulgoran wounded on the shoulder, and the two Cenophales were
forced to stoop with their hands to the ground to save themselves from falling.
These fearful blows would have utterly astonished men of less valor and
courage, but having begotten more fury than fear in the spirits of these
invincible knights, they began again to lay about them so fiercely, that these
four arrogant Giants, who thought the earth could not produce men of sufficient
power to resist them, plainly perceived that the overthrow of their enemies
would prove a matter of more difficulty, than they expected.

In the mean time whilst this tempestuous fight lasted, between these eight
Combatants, Quadragant, Tristor, Florian, Florestan, Perion, and Cilindor
rallied their troops, but so far had the Giants and their assistants gained
the field, that notwithstanding the valor of those Knights, who made heads and
arms fly about, and cut down and killed all that came in their way, the
Christians began to retire, when in the instant there arrived the valiant
Esquilass of Polonia, Grandimore, the unknown Kninght, Agrian, Fl^^isa^t,
(...), Frisel, Abies, Armond, and Melfort in the head of thirty thousand Horse,
who suddenly pressing into the midst of their enemies troops, then confused and
in disorder, slew above twenty thousand upon the place, and doubtless all the
Pagans at that time on the shore had been put to the sword, if the haughty
Antomedon, accompanied with Marisgelf, thirty Giants, and threese ore thousand
men, had not speedily encountered the Christians, amongst whom with the very
first blow he cleft Florizartus of Trapobana, down to the wast: on the other
side his Giants made such a Massacre, that the first ranks being all broken,
the other betook themselves to flight, to avoid the fury of their devouring
swords; which so much incensed the valiant Esq^it^^ of Polonia, that he with
Grandimore, the unknown Knight, and the rest of the young Princes that
accompanied him, being all well appointed with good Lances, at one charge ran
nine of the Giants quite through and through, and after that behaved themselves
so bravely against their enemies, that they were wonderfully amazed thereat.

Nevertheless the valor of the other Giants being no whit abated, and the
number of the Pagans being excessively great, questionless the Christians had
been discomfited, if fourscore Vessels passing without suspicion through the
midst of the enemies fleet, had not very opportunely disembarqued forty
thousand men, who falling suddenly on the Pagans, which were deceived with an
opinion, that they were part of their own forces, they put them marvellously to
rout, under the conduct of two excellent Knights, which at the same instant
encountering with Brandafidel, King of Brutaxia, a mighty Giant, and Brandimart,
King of Parmonda, they past their Lances quite through their bodies, so
astonishing the rest of that party, as the Christians had leisure to rally
their troops, and to make a handsome treaty, and yet not without very much
difficulty.

Prigmalcon and Fulgoran, who were no less discreet than valiant, seeing the
honor of the Christians recovered by the unexpected arrival of this Army,
would have retired with their troops, but Roussardan, Gorgophon, the Grand
Salvage, and Furiander were so enraged, that they met with such a forceable
resistance, as they began to redouble their blows with more strength then at
the first, which put our Greeks into so much fury, that Prigmaleon uniting the
whole strength of his body into one stroke, which he laid on Roussardans
Helmet, he gave him a dangerous hurt on the head, wherewith he was so
astonished, that he knew not what world he was in, and Fulgoran following his
example, wounded Gorgophon very dangerously in the thigh, by which means having
very happily the leisure to releeve one of the Cenophales, who being unable to
withstand an heavy stroke lent him by the Grand Salvage, he had fallen at his
Horses feet, had he not been sustained by him; Furiander in the mean time had
received a sore hurt on the arm by the other Cenophales.

These astonishing strokes putting the Pagans into the extremity of rage; they
addressed themselves again to be revenged, threatening no less then death with
their tempestuous swords, but the Princes who well understood they were
accomptable for the people under their charge, and that knew the safety of the
soldiers consisted in the preservation of their Leaders, retired to their
troops, leaving the Pagans in despair of having that revenge upon them they so
much hoped for.

The Christians having thus prudently made their retreat, they desired to know
the names of the Commanders of the new Army, and finding that it was the brave
Russian of Media, with the beautiful Amazon, Brandimanda, (who departed from
Corolandaya, by the advice of the wise Vrganda, before the others were in the
field) gave them a million of thanks, and especially to Brandimanda, whose
matchless beauty, joined with that invincible prowess, whereof they had so
lately experience, they could never sufficiently admire, then causing the
Amazons to be led into a quarter a part, and the Soldiers into the trenches,
they conducted them to the Palace, where disarming themselvest they found every
one hurt except Russia, Brandimanda, the valiant Esquilan, Cilindor, and
Leonidas of Mesopotamia, who with Alteria was left in the Town, if need were,
to make good the retreat: Prigmaleons hurt was on the arm and head, Fulg^rans
on the shoulder, the Cenophales in two or three places, Grandimore on the left
arm, by the sword of the proud Giant Antamedon; Perion and the rest in diverse
parts of the body; notwithstanding which, they had some cause to rejoice for
the loss the enemy had, amounting to the number of threescore and seventeen
thousand men, three and twenty Giants, and the Kings of Brutaxia, and
Parmondia, as they understood by their Spies, besides those that were hurt, in
the number whereof were Roussardan, Gorgophon, the Grand Salvage, Furiander,
Antomedon, and the valiant Artogant, Sultan of Francapia, with a multitude of
common Knights.

But when they bethought themselves of the loss of the gentle Florizartus of
Trapobana, and of thirty three thousand men, that remained dead in the field
(the greatest part whereof perished rather by the sword of the Giants, than the
multitude of the soldiers) they could not believe that Fortune had much
obliged them, by the advantage they had gained; nevertheless, putting on a
brave resolution, they comforted themselves with the hope of some other
succors; and so placing trusty Sentinels in all places requisite, they went
to refresh themselves with a small repast.

Afterward, those that had escaped without hurts, assembled themselves in
Prigmaleon and Fulgorans Chamber, who would by no means lie asunder, where it
was resolved that Russian and Brandimanda, with each of them a troop of ten
thousand Horse should sally upon the Enemy two hours before day; whereupon
they went to repose themselves for a while. In the mean time Falanzar enraged
at the massacre of so many of his men, and for the loss of his Kings and
Giants, by so small a number, environed three parts of the City, and causing
great Trenches to be cast up, and covering the field with his Soldiers for
the space of two miles round, he promised to himself that he would gain the
Walls at the first assault, seeing all his Giants should have now elbow-room to
bestir themselves; but his opinion deceived him, as you shall see in the
Chapter following, and made him conclude, that the end of his enterprise would
not prove so feasible as he expected.

CHAP. XXXIX. The brave feats of Arms performed in a Sally by Russian of Media,
and Brandimanda; the furious assault given by the Pagan Princes unto the Town,
which being reduced to extreamitie, is marvellously relieved.
THis mighty Fleet of the Enemies having gained the Shore, the night was almost
wholly employed in making of Trenches, and setting up Tents, and Pavillions; so
that it being near that time of the day, which chalengeth a kind of security
over all things; the Soldiers annoyed with the Sea, wearied with their late
travels, and importuned by sleep, betook themselves all to their rest, being
confident that the Christians durst not so much as once peep out of their
Walls; But they like brave spirits, who thought there was no glory equal to
that which was gotten in the midst of dangers, and hating all rest which might
be accompanied with disgrace, had no other design than continually to be
pulling some feathers out of their enemies Wings, whereby they might stop the
fury of their flight; they rose presently after midnight, and arming twenty
thousand of their best, and lustiest Horses, they divided them into two Troops,
whereof one was commanded by Russian, Cilindor, and Leonidas; the other by
Esquilan, Brandimanda, and the fair Alteria; and so sallying out at two
several Ports, they advanced softly toward the Pagans till it was break of
day, which affording them light to discover their Sentinels all asleep, they
presently cut their throats without any noise, and so falling aboard with the
rest, who were in no better estate to make resistance, they began to commit so
great a slaughter, that the ground was covered over with dead bodies, before
the Alarm was taken in the Camp, Russian, Cilindor, and Leonidas, over-runall;
Soldiers they cut in pieces, Knights they cleft down to the shoulders; Tents
and Pavilions, they turned upside down; and meeting with little or no
opposition, they made a strange havoc.

Falanzar General of the Pagan army, who lodged not far from the place where
they first fell on, easily hearing the fearful cries and groans which came
from his men, as they were dying, rose up immediately, and finding Brufaldar
King of Gedrosia, Brizardan the redoubted Sultan of Aralafia, with Moranteon,
Sultan of Circassia, he gave them thirty thousand men to resist the fury of
their enemies, whose number he conceived to be fifty thousand at the least, and
so ran speedily himself through all parts of the Camp, to put the rest in
battle array.

These three proud Pagans, who had not been at the last nights service,
cheerfully embracing this charge, began presently to march forward, and being
conducted by the noise which continually increased, they forthwith encountered
the Christians, and plainly perceiving the smalnesse of their number, divided
their troops with an intent to environ them, and to charge them on every side,
but those valiant Knights not affording them the leisure to put their Design
in practice, broke through them with such a tempest, that the blood ran along
the ground in little rivers, which put the incensed Pagan Brufaldor into such a
fury, that turning his horse upon Leonidas of Mesopotamia, he gave him so
violent a stroke on the shoulder, that his sword notwithstanding his Arms, made
way to his very waste, dividing his body into two parts; which so displeased
Russian, who saw the sad effect of the blow, that clasping his sword fast in
his hand, he returned the Pagan such an exchange, as cutting his shield in two,
he gave him a great gash on the arm, and so quiting him he flew upon Moranteon
Sultan of Circassia, wounding him very dangerously on the shoulder, and
perceiving Brizardan grapling with his friend Cilindor, whom he doubted might
be too weak to fustain so strong a charge, he made toward them with an intent
to discharge full on Brizardans head, but Torismond the valiant Pagan prevented
his blow, by giving him such a smart stroke on the arm, as made his sword fall
out of his hand, and yet without any other harm, save only a slight hurt,
which put him into such a choler, as suddenly taking hold again on the handle
of his sword that was fastened with a riband to his wrist, he let it fly in such
sort at his Adversary, that he cut him almost in two pieces, sending him dead
to the ground.

In the midst of these hurliburlies, the brave Esquilan entering on the other
side of the Camp, struck no less astonishment into the minds of those that
encountered him, than the other had done before; no resistance could withstand
the fury of his sword. Brandimanda seconded him with equal heat and courage,
and the gentle Amazon Alterea followed them both so close, that she seemed to
threaten no less a ruin than the former.

At this new alarm Falanzar, Idatcan Emperor of Melly; Armandor, King of
Russia, with Fierastron the proud Giant of Balivan, advanced themselves in the
head of forty thousand men; but the fear of those that ran away, having put
their soldiers which they led into disorder, the Greeks charged them with such
fury, that more then six thousand of them were beaten down; the greatest part
whereof were stifled under the horses feet. The unpleasing sight of this
accident had driven Falanzar into despair, but that he earried too generous a
mind, for to harbor so base a guest, wherefore meeting with Esquilan, he
discharged so terrible a blow on his Helmet, as he made him knock his chin
against his breast, being very much astonished at the mighty strength of this
Pagan, but grinding his teeth together for anger, he advanced his sword, and
let it descend with such a rage on this Caliph, that he overthrew him on the
crupper of his horse, casting out great abundance of blood at his mouth.

In the mean while, Brandimanda and Fierastron, Iaalcan, and the gentle
Alterea, charged one another home, and made a quick exchange of most
fiercestroaks. But Esquilan who would not afford them any leisure to rally
their troops, and who judged that to be no fit season for him to be a spectator
of a single combat, let fall on Idalcan Emperor of Melly so furious a blow,
that he cut his arm sheere from his body, and at the same instant with another
which he laid on Fierastrons headpiece, he quite deprived him of his senses;
which being done, he put his men into good order, and following the example of
Russian, who took the way that led into the City, he made an honorable
retreat in spite of threescore thousand Horse, and fourscore Giants, which
came in the pursuit of them.

This courageous, and prudent retreat, and the death of the Emperor of Melly,
that ensued two hours after, with the great slaughter of their men, which
amounted to the number of thirty nine thousand, the Christians having left on
the place but five thousand six hundred, having enraged the Pagans, they
resolved every man of them to dye on the place, or else that very day to win the
City, which together with all the Christians therein, they would consume to
ashes, in satisfaction of so great a loss.

Their Troops then being ranged, and every Captain having received order to
charge his Company, with the carriage of a certain number of scaling-ladders,
the Army was divided into three bands, each consisting of one hundred and
fifty thousand men; Falanzar led the first, with the which was Brufaldor King
of Gedrosia, the proud Knight Arastron, generous Alceus, Marisgolf, that
terrible and mighty Giant, twenty Knights of the best repute in the whole Army,
and threescore Giants: The second was commanded by Astrurion the great Sultan
of Brutacan, the good Knight Armorand, Brizardon Sultan of Aralafia, fifty
Giants, and twenty two other Knights, who had purchased a great renown by
dangerous adventures: The third by Marmaran, Sophy of Bultara, with King
Armandor, of Russia, of the Giants race; Palamedes, King of Cassandria, the
redoubted Tipheus, Barcandor, fifty Giants, three and twenty Knights, of no
mean esteem, and Broncaldion, King of the Arcofibrats, who had the leading of
twelve hundred Elephants.

The christian Princes who slept not in the mean while, seeing these
presumptuous preparations, put threescore thousand Knights into the Town, and
so furnishing the walls with abundance of pitch, sulphur, boiling oil, stones,
and other necessaries for their Enterprise, made up three bands; the first was
conducted by Russian with Cilindor, the second by Esquilan with Algantas chief
General of Ethiopia; and the third by Brandimanda with Alteria, who lodging
themselves close under the walls, with a resolution not to appear before the
enemies had almost gained the top, expected the coming of their troops, which
hearing no noise at all in the Town, were persuaded that the Christians were
all asleep; whereupon they presently fastened their scaling Ladders, which their
Giants and other Knights of the best spirits first ascended, to give
encouragement to the rest to follow them; but on the instant they perceived
fifty thousand men, who with a sudden tempest of stones, oil, pitch and
sulphur, overturned all those that were then upon the Ladders, and began to dam
up the Moat with dead bodies, then the assault became most violent and cruel.

The Giants enraged to see their Companies lie grovelling on the ground, the
Ladders broken, ten thousand Soldiers massacred, as it were in a moment, began
to grow careless of their lives, they got upon the wall, and fell to grapling
with the Christians, fighting rather like furies than mortal men, there were
scarce any that durst oppose the violence of their swords, unless it were
Russian, Esquilan, Brandimanda, Alteria, Cilindor, and some few of the
valiantest, who perceiving the favor the wall afforded partly in sheltring
them, and annoying their enemies, delivered such blows on the Pagans, as for
the most part carried death along with them. Russians represented a
Thunderbolt, overturning as many Giants and Knights as it lighted on, neither
was Esquilans or (...)'s much less terrible than it; but the Pagans, the
greater the number of the Christians were which they perceived on the
Battelments, the more resolute they began to be, and caused a multitude of
Pioners to sap the walls; the Arcofibrats approached with their Elephants, and
the nearer they advanced, the more blood was spilt, and the more fell dead to
the ground, the Elephants being got under the walls, they quit their bows and
arrows, and fell to handy strokes: Their Cymitars lighted with such a weight on
our soldiers, and the Combat grew so cruel, that there was nothing to be
heard amongst them but cries, and pitiless groans, which did so encourage the
Giants, who met with little or no resistance, that three of them adventured to
scale the walls in spite of all those that opposed, and began to make a
terrible massacre amongst the Greeks, whose sudden flight giving Russian to
understand the extremity of the danger, he and Bandimanda ran thither with all
speed, and encountering these three Colosses, the first whereof was Arginassus,
of the cold Desert, he saluted him so rudely on the head with his sword, as
cleft him down to the shoulders, and gave the other such a thrust in the belly,
as ran him up to the hilts.

In the mean time Brandimanda animated with the like desire to revenge; had
made a shift to make a separation between her adversaries head and his body;
the vast trunks of these three Giants being taken on the instant, and thrown
from the walls, struck such an amazement into those that followed, that their
hasty and eager desire of entering the City was soon abated; In the mean time
the Elephants being ranged on the other side, and their Castles manned with
stout and courageous soldiers, there was instantly a bloody encounter, but the
Christians pouring down boiling oil upon those mighty creatures, caused a
sudden confusion, for as soon as it began to pierce their skins, they quitted
their stations, ran violently into the body of their troops, broke their
Battalions, and were the cause of the death of above two thousand soldiers.

Amongst the rest they overthrew Barcandor of the Inhabitable Rock, who was in
no small danger of being stifled; nevertheless being speedily rescued by his
brother, he received no other hurt, but the astonishment he was in by his fall,
which rendering him more furious than ever he had bin in his life before, he
caused a Ladder to be fetched, and being accompanied with the dreadful
Tiphe^s, Bucargant, and other Giants, he went to place it with a resolution,
either to dye or force the wall, howbeit perceiving a great piece thereof
falling down, which buried above four hundred Knights, he quitted his
Enterprise, and drawing out his great curtelas, he and his companions entered
the Town, together with six thousand Pagans more, which began to make so great
a slaughter, that doubtless all had been lost, had not Russian, Brandimanda,
and the brave Polander opportunely come in with ten thousand fresh men, who
seeing their safety or utter ruin to be then in question.

At the very first onset they cut off three thousand Knights; nevertheless
Tipheus, Bucargant, Barcandor, (...), Bulti^d^r, and the other Giants fought so
furiously, that they be^e^t them almost of al hopes of preserving their lives,
Esquilan being wounded in three or four places, Russian in the arm and the
thigh, and Brandimanda by the force of two cruel strokes, which she received
on the head, from the hands of Tipheus, and Bultendor, lying senseless, if not
breathless, on the ground; but at the instant Prigmaleon, Fulgoran, the two
Cenophales, Grandimore, the unknown Knight, Perion, Tristor, Florian,
Florestan, Abies, Quadragant, Dardanio, Florisel, Agrian, Armond and Melfort
hearing the rumor of it, and well knowing the peril the Town then was in, ro^e
presently, and with their Armies marched to the place of Combat.

These seventeen brave Warriors beholding the extremity their friends were in,
never felt the incommodity of their wounds, but set upon the Giants with such a
fury, that at the very first encounter they massacred the greatest part of
them; and now the Christian troops renewing their courage at the presence and
valiant example of these renowned Princes, made a speedy slaughter of seven or
eight thousand men, the Giants themselves being all cut in pieces, except
Armandor, Palamedes, Tipheus, the two brothers of the Inhabitable Rock, and two
and twenty others, who persuading themselves that they were yet strong enough
to take the Town, began a fresh charge upon our Christian Princes, but their
resistance was so brave and courageous, as the greatest part of the Pagans ran
upon their own deaths.

Marmaran Sophy of Bultara, Tipheus, Barcandor and his brother Bucargant, being
the whole number that remained alive, who considering that policy, was no
less requisite to men of Arms, than courage, made their retreat with a
resolution to bring new forces to the fight, and so at length to weary the
Christians, which presently causing the breach to be repaired, and Brandimanda
to be carried to the Palace, they made haste to the aid of Cilindor, and the
fair Alteria, that were scarce able to make any longer defense against the
violence of Falanzar, who yielding a noble example to the rest of his
soldiers, with Brufaldor, Arastron, Alceus, and some few others, had wel-nigh
forced the walls; but the coming of these Knights did much abate the fury of
the Giants, twelve whereof at their first arrival fell dead to the earth,
nevertheless the wall being very low on that side, where Astrurion the mighty
Sultan of Brutacan gave the assault, they could no longer have made good the
Town, if on the sudden certain Courriers had not come to advertise Falanzar,
that above four hundred thousand Christians were newly landed, and in array to
fall upon their troops.

Wise men make use of all advice that is given them, so Falanzar conceiving
that this news did much import the safety of his Army, caused Marmaran
presently to retire from the Walls, and joining his own troops with him, they
made a body of three hundred thousand men, and wheeled about with his forces to
the Seaward; howbeit not thinking these sufficient, he sent unto Marcelian
