Emperor of Media, and to Fierastron, to repair thither with two hundred
thousand more, that had not yet fought, and so making in this manner two mighty
squadrons; they expected to see what resolution their Enemies would take, who
were commanded by Florisel of Niquea, by Rogel, Spheramond, Alastraxerea, and
other Christian Princes, which were very desirous forthwith to charge the
Pagans; but Florisel whose valor was well tempered with experience, and
discretion, would by (...) give way that they should the^ engage themselves,
both because the night d^^w on, and that they were also wearied with the Sea,
and especially for that he knew not what condition his friends were in, but
withal to let them see, that what he did, was more out of experience then
fear, he caused his men to advance, till they came even under the Walls, before
which having caused Trenches speedily to be made for the safeguard of his
soldiers, he pitched his Tents and Pavilions, during which time the Pagans did
not so much as make show of stirring.

In the mean while the Sultan of Brutacan having received no order to make his
retreat, was persuaded to follow his good fortune, and entering the breach which
he had made, to put himself into the midst of the Town, but finding a greater
resistance from the Princes and Soldiers within, then they had from the walls,
there began a most fierce and bloody combat; The Giants advanced bravely,
making way with their swords, and their Soldiers taking courage from their
example, followed as resolutely, making a vast and terrible slaughter; whereof
Brandimand^ being advertised, and finding her self prettily recovered, she
thought it a dishonor to dye in her bed; wherefore she took six thousand men,
reserved for an extremity, and meeting with Cilinder and Alteria, who had
retired for a while to refresh themselves, they fell on with such a fury upon
the Soldans troops, that at the very first encounter, above four thousand of
their Enemies, and fourteen Giants were cut in pecces, which so incensed the
horrible Cressamagrant, that advancing his dreadful Faulchion, he let it fall
with such a violence on Frizel of Arcadia, that it cleft him down to the
shoulders, and laid him dead at Prigmaleous feet, who in a great rage requited
the Pagan with such another, as cutting his leg from his body, he fell to the
ground with a noise like thunder.

These dreadful strokes giving equal courage to both parties, the fight waxed
more furious than at any time before, and if the enemies could at once have
made use of all their forces, without doubt they had carried the Town, but the
breath being but equal, the Christians though but few in number were able to
withstand those that would enter, so that they held them play until night,
which drawing on to the great grief of Astrurion, it made him bestow his blows
with the more violence, amongst the which one lighted so boisteroufly upon
gentle Abies of Ireland, that it cleft him almost to the girdle, whereat
Fulgora^ was so enraged, that taking his sword in both his hands, he discharged
such a blow upon the head of the great Sultan, as turned him over and over, and
doubtless he had quite made an end of him, had not fourteen Giants, that were
retyring carried him off.

The City being thus delivered from so tedious and cruel an assault, they
employed a multitude of Labouters to repair the breaches, and caused the
bodies of Frizel of Arcadia, and Abies of Treland to be carried to the Palace,
the loss of whom had been much more grievous uno them, but that they were
comforted with the assurance of this new succor, which they understood
proceeded from the Emperor Florisel of Niquea, that was accompanied with many
other Christian Princes their friends, whom they went to visit in their
trenches, before they could so much as lay aside their Arms, where many kind
salutations passing between them, they related the danger the Town had been in
all that day, the loss of Frixel, Florizartus, Abies, and Leonidas, and the
whole story of all that had happened since they departed from Constantinople, and
so for that present they departed with a resolution, to take a full revenge of
their enemies.

CHAP. LXI. The furious Battle between the Pagan and Christian Princes; the
conclusion thereof, with the number of the dead.
THE rage of the Pagan Princes, who had lost in this assault threescore and
seven thousand men, three and fifty Giants, with Fiortan, Brontaiar, Argantor,
and Lizartus, all worthy Knights, not suffering them to take any rest: Falanzar
gave order for the interring their dead, and assembled his Captains together,
to whom he spoke in this manner. Mighty Princes, I see no reason why we should
be discouraged, though fortune has not favored our designs, we have lost
Soldiers, Giants, and many persons of quality, rather by the difficulty of
scaling the walls, than by the valor of our enemies, but now we have a fair
occasion to revenge our selves, and to repay with interest the displeasure they
have done us; we may now give them a day for all, and this Grecian Army newly
arrived, will rather further, than any way hinder our designs; let us offer
them battle, they are hardy enough to entertain it, and we powerful enough to
obtain the victory, the advantage is ours on every side, we have a multitude
of brave Knights, the meanest whereof will make the strongest of our enemies
sweat for it, our Soldiers are more in number, and no whit inferior in
courage, they shall be assisted by a multitude of valiant Knights, who are able
to astonish even the whole world, so that we shall undoubtedly revenge our
former losses; It is true, that for the present the one half of our bravest
Knights are confined to their beds, by reason of their wounds; I hold it
therefore convenient to give them some respite for their recovery: In the mean
time let us enquire, whether this may agree with the consent of our friends and
allies.

Great Monarch, replied Marmaran, Sophy of Bultara, the proposition you make,
is so good, that there need no reasons be urged for the authorizing your
opinion, and I dare assure you, that it agrees with the desire of the whole
Army, let us then if you please send to our enemies, and demand a truce for
eight days, that in the mean time time we may put every thing in good order,
and to give the King of Grifala, and the rest of our friends leisure to recover
their strength, that they may be the better able to do you service: Hereupon
Polidarchus King of Amazia, was entreated to take the charge of delivering this
message to the Christian Princes, which being willingly undertaken by him, he
went presently to Don Florisel of Niquea, presented him with a bloody Gauntlet;
and demanded seven days of Truce, he appointed the eighth for the set battle.

We know not how to deny our Enemies, answered Florisel, when they invite us to
fight, I accept of the battle on the same day that you demand it, and desiring
to be more courteous, then you have been violent, coming hither to seek the
ruin of our Empires, without any provocation at all on our part, are content
to ratify the Truce for the term required by you. Pilidarchus being thus
returned back, every man prepared for the battle; they used all the skill that
could be, for the recovering of those that were wounded, and the Captains
diligently employed themselves in advancing the courage of the Soldiers, for
on the victory of this furious day, the ruin or glory of all Christendom, or
Paganism depended.

Seven days then being insensibly past away, Prigmaleon, Fulgoran, Russian,
and their Companions, having quit their beds, met with the rest of the
Christian Princes to consult of their affairs, where they all agre^ing to
submit themselves to the prudence and direction of Florisel of Niquea, he
ordered it all in this manner.

The number of the whole Forces consisting of three hundred thousand Horse, and
two hundred thousand Foot, without counting those which Prigmaleon had in the
Town, for the manning of the Walls, he divided into four troops, each containing
seventie thousand Horse, and forty thousand Foot; the first was commanded by
Prigmaleon, Fulg^an, Russian, the Cenophales, Esquilan, Brandimanda, and all
the young Princes that had been their assistants in the former Combats.

The second was commanded by Spheramond, Alastraxerea, Melindus, Clidor, his
Wife Cassiana, Amanio of Arestrea, the Duke of Laiaze, the King of Cataya, his
Wife Crothea; Galard, King of the barren Island, with Rozafar, and the King of
Lacaonia.

The third was commanded by Don Rogel, Lucendus, D^rigel, Silvan, the fair
Salvage his Wife, the valiant Silverin of the Desert; Gadart, King of Hungaria;
Filiard, King of Polonia; Oriander, King of Sardamira, his Queen Oronsa;
Parmenian, of Cyprus, and Garmantes.

The fourth by Don Florisel of Niquea, with Anaxander King of Dardania;
Floridan, King of Comogena, his brother; Troilus, the renowned Knight of Savoy,
and twelve young Princes, upon whom he had that day conferd the order of
Knighthood, with all the magnificent Ceremonies the Camp could afford: Every
thing being thus ordered, every man retired to visit his Horse and Arms, with a
command to be in readiness at break of the day.

In the mean while the Pagans slept not, for knowing of what importance the
issue of this battle would be, they armed themselves with a resolution to
redeem their honor, though they paid their blood for it: being advertised of
the course the Christians had taken in ranging of their Troops, they held it
best to observe the same order, and not to think of reserving any part,
persuading themselves that it would be more difficult to rout their troops,
being united than separated; and so they divided their whole Forces, consisting
of eight hundred thousand into four Bands.

The first whereof was commanded by Roussardan the furious King of Grifalara, a
man of a Gyant-like nature, with grifly hair, a face covered with black
patches, an ugly flat nose, and ill-fashioned legs, but withal so valiant,
that next to Gorgophon, and Bravorant, King of Morimont, there lived not a
braver Pagan upon the whole earth; his Associats were Moranteon, Souldan of
Circassia; the grand Salvage, Furiander his son; Artegant, Souldan of
Francapia; the proud Arastron; Gederion, King of Arginaria; Furcamond, King of
Martan; Aliodorus, Torismond, Arciles, and Teliander; all brave Knights, with
threescore Giants.

The second by the valiant Marmoran, Sophy of Bultara; Bravorant, Gorgophon,
Marisgolfus, Salander, King of Balsandria; Polidarchus, King of Amazia;
Giracond, King of Toriana; Don Margenio, Rindar, Brandimart, threescore Giants,
and Broncaldion King of the Arcofibrats, who would no more make use of his
Elephants, because in the preceding assault, they had occasioned so great a
disorder.

The third by stout Astrurion, Sultan of Brutacan; with the haughty Antomedon,
Caliph of Francapa; Brizardan, Sultan of Aralafia; Marcelian, Emperor of
Media; Rodomart, King of Fortan; Asmorian, King of the upper Indies; Bemond,
King of Java minor, diverse other Knights of quality, and threescore Giants.

The fourth was reserved for Falanzar, great Emperor, and Caliph of Siconia,
with the King of Russia; Anaxamena, the valirnt Amazon his Wife; Palamedes,
King of Cassandria; Fierastron, the redoubted Giant of Balivan; Polecastaleon,
King of Zeilan; Brufaldor, King of Gedrozia; the dreadful Tipheus, Barcandor,
Bucargant, and threescore Giants; In the mean time Mambrinian King of
Fornascia, with the Kings of Zamber, of Saphotir, of Siziphalt, and fourscore
thousand men guarded the Camp.

All things being thus resolved upon on both parties; the day of Battle was
expected, which being come to the great content of both the Armies, to whom all
delay was insupportable; the Pagans began to draw their men out of their
Trenches, much astonished to see themselves prevented of their Enemies, who
already had possessed themselves of the field, and there stood in battle array.

The first that appeared on the Pagans side, was the furious King of Grifalara,
who marching in a glorious, and most magnificent manner, under a multitude of
Standards, whereon were represented two Lions chained together only by the
force of one hand, caused the charge to be sounded.

At the same instant Prigmaleon, (who thought no Oration could so animate his
Soldiers to behave themselves bravely, as to give a sudden testimony of an
undaunted courage) gave the Signal to his troops immediately to join: most
violent was the encounter of these two brave Warriors, who saluted each other
so boistrously, that their Lances bounded into the air in a thousand slivers,
Fulgoran and the Grand Salvage fell to the ground, the one hurt on the left
arm, the other on the breast; Russian of Media, and the proud Knight Arastron,
broke their Lances very furiously upon each other, and yet past on unmoved,
like two rocks in the midst of the Sea. The two Cenophales, and Grandimor,
running against Furiander, Artegant, Sultan of Francapia, and Moranteon, Sultan
of Circassia, received such an astonishment from each others encounter, that
all six remained for a long time sensslesse; Gedereon, King of Arginarea, was
overthrown by Esquilan, Brandimanda passed her Lance through the body of a
Giant, three other Pagan Knights fell down dead at the feet of Perion,
Cilind^r, and the unknown Knight, and so many Cavaliers fell to the ground on
both sides, that the field was full of horses that ran up and down masterlesse,
Lances were broken in pieces, sword blades flew into the air, and the Battle
waxed so hot, that the dust was all tempered with blood; Roussardan, the Grand
Salvage, and the proud knight Araston, cut down all they met withal, making
head and arms fly about, which bred such fear in the Enemies, as they were no
less terrible to them than thunderbolts.

On the other side, Prigmaleon, Fulgoran, Russian, Brandimanda, Esquilan, and
the two Cenophales, who disdaining to employ their Swords upon common persons,
charged the vastest Giants with so great a fury, that in an instant, three and
twenty of them lay breathless on the earth; when as Arastron, Roussardan, and
the Grand Salvage, marching in the Front like so many torrents sweeping all
before them, let fly with such a violence upon Quadragant, Agrion of Scotland,
and Dardanio, that they cleft them all three down to the teeth; and seeing that
Prigmaleon, Russian, and Fulgoran, (having dispatched the mighty Brucalan, with
Arbadan and Pandarus his Brothers, by the force of three terrible strokes which
sent them dead to the ground) had made way into their Troops massacring all
without mercy, that gave them any opposition, in great rage they clapped spurs
to their horses, and making toward these three Knights, they discharged three
such dangerous blows upon them, that had not their Arms been of the best in the
world, they had without doubt added them to the number of the dead;
nevertheless, these rough salutations that humbled their chins to their saddle
bows, did nothing else but incite them to a sudden requital, which they
returned so bravely, as there was little cause left them of boasting, and so
there began the most dangerous Combat that ever man beheld between these six
Knights.

On the one side the Giants made huge massacres; Esquilan, Brandimanda,
Grandimore, and the Christian Princes, bestird themselves lustily on the other,
and their brave example made the courage of their men, supply what they wanted
in number; so that above threescore thousand Knights being slain both parts,
the victory remained as yet doubtful.

Whereupon the Pagans impatient of delay, caused their second Battalion to
advance, which being led by Marmaran, Sophy of Bultara, accompanied with those
incomparable Warriors, Bravorant, king of Morimont, Marisgolfus and Gorgophon,
Colonels of the Giants, gave so fierce an assault upon the Christians first
Squadron, that they had cut them all in pieces, if the Emperor Spheramond had
not opportunly opposed their fury.

By this time the ground was all covered with dead men, and the confusion so
great, and crpes so loud, that a thousand claps of thunder would not have been
heard amongst them: Bravorant, Gorgophon, and Marisgolfus, having addressed
their Lances against Galard King of the Barren Islands, Alvida his Wife, and
the Duke of Laiaret, they ran them quite through the body; and so did in like
manner to five or six more, before they brake; but great was the slaughter they
made, when as they hod drawn out their great and heavy Fauchions, for the
Lightning falls not with more violence, than did their blows, which meeting
with no resistance sufficient to oppose them, they strewed all the ground with
dead bodies.

Spheramond having encountered Marmoran, Sophy of Bultara, they both brake their
staves upon each other, and so pressing in amongst the multitude, they slew as
many as had the ill hap to come within their reach, Alastraxerea made such
havoc amongst her enemies, that every one fled from her, as from some deadly
contagion; Melindus, Clidor, and Amiano of Astrea, did no less wonders; But
the Enemies were so mighty, and Bravorant joining with Gorgophon, made so
bloody a massacre, that this second Squadron in spite of the best resistance,
Spheramond, Alastraxerea, and the Grecian Princes could make, had been utterly
routed, if Florisel wisely foreseeing that the flight of those forces might
cause a general ruin of the whole Army, had not opportunly given order to the
young Cavaliers that he had armed the day before to advance: who desirous to
season their first undertakings by some memorable testimony of their valor,
made so fierce a Sally upon the Giants, that with their Lances they overthrew
twelve of them to the ground, then laying their hands on their swords, they
began to do such strange things, that the Greeks recovering, as it were, a new
courage, gave their enemies so furious a charge, as they made them begin to
startle; nay, almost to betake themselves to plain flight.

Nevertheless being detayned by the only valor of Braverant, Gorgophon, and
Marisgolfus, and the brave Sophy of Bultara, who resembled so many furies, they
continued the fight so stoutly, that the blood made large Rivers through the
midst of the fields; the earth was covered with the bodies of those that were
already slain, and the air filled with the groans of those that were then
dying: Spheramond wheresoever he passed carried death on his sword; Bravorant
and Gorgophon ran up and down raising mountains of dead bodies, Marmoran and
Marifgolfus appeared like lightning: Alastraxerea, Melindus, Clidor, Cassianus
met with no resistance, unless it were from the Giants, who did often times as
well as their fellows taste the keenesse of the Christian blades; In brief it
was a spectacle full of such horror, as the like has seldom been beheld by
the eye of man, and the slaughter so indifferent, that it was heard to say to
which side the victory did most incline.

The Pagans who could not endure to be idle, whilst their Companions were busy
in the pursuit of glory, marched up with their third sqadron, conducted by the
valiant Astrurion, Sultan of Brutacan, Antomedon the proud Caliph of Francapia,
Brizardan, Sultan of Aralafia, and Mercelian, Emperor of Media: These vast
troops led by such proud and mighty Commanders, fell on the Christians with
such fury, as promised no less then utter ruin at the very first onset: But
the Emperor of Persia seconded by Lucendus, Dorogel, Silvian the fair
Salvage, the noble Silverin of the Desert, Gadard, King of Hungaria, Filadart
of Polonia, Oriander and Oroncus charged them so fiercely, that made them
quickly turn their faces to defend themselves from the cruelty of their weapons.

This brave Prince encountering Antomedon with his Lance, ran him through the
shield and arm; yet not without great danger to himself, for from the Giants
Lance he received such an encounter, as tumbled him upon the crupper of his
horse, ready to have fallen to the ground, if he had not been upheld by some of
his followers.

Thus the third Squadrons falling to it pell mell, there continued a most
cruel battle; the valiant D^rigil did deeds worthy of himself, following the
brave example of his father, who held all the enemies in admiration to see him
alone act such wonders, the noble Silverin of the Desert stopped the fury of
Brizardan, and behaved himself so bravely against him, that by those that saw
him, he was judged no whit inferior to the best Warriors of the world,
Lucendus sent Marcelian Emperor of Media, to keep company with the dead;
Filadart, Gadart, and the Princes that followed them fought with so much
courage and vigor, that in a moment they covered the fields with the
slaughtered carcasses of their enemies.

In the mean time Don Rogel and Lucendus seeing the great massacre made by
Antomedon, and the mericilesse Sultan of Brutacan, immediately assaulted these
two proud pagans, who were almost ready to swim in christian blood, shed by
their own swords, upon whom they bestowed a couple of such violent blows, as
Antomedon was laid flat upon the crupper of his horse, the blood gushing out at
his mouth and ears, and the great Sultan received such a stroke from Lucendus,
as rendered him in little better case then his fellow; These terrible blows,
which probably should have been the cause of the Christians victory,
contrariwi^e exposed them to extreme danger, for these two great Warriors
recovering themselves again, and taking their swords in both hands, advanced
with so eager a desire of revenge, that meeting with Filadart of Polonia, and
Gadart King of Hungaria, they fell upon them with such a tempest, as the one
was cleft down to the shoulders, the other to the girdle, which being soon
perceived by Don Rogel, he made with his best speed toward Antomedon, upon
whom he discharged so furiously, as he quite dismounted him, and put him in
great danger of being trampled under the horses feet, but being suddenly
releeved by his friends, he was by them immediately carried to his tent.

The retreat being known of these two mighty men, it gave a fresh supply of
courage to the Greeks, Rodomart King of Fortan, Armositan King of the upper
Indies, and Tarsides King of Pergazus, perished by the swords of Silvan the
fair Salvage his wife, and Dorigel; and fifteen Giants being insta^tly slain by
the other christian princes, the pagans began to give ground, when in the nick
arrived Falanzar, with the redoubted King of Balivan, the dreadful Tipheus,
Bucargant, Burcandar King of Russia, Palamedes King of Cassandria, the
excellent Knight Artogant, and the incomparable Alceus; and on the other party
Don Florisel of Niquea, with his troops, who mingling themselves in a furious
fight with those Pagans, caused on the sudden such a general confusion, that
the earth, the air, and the Heavens seemed to be but one, and the same thing;
for the Leaders some of them were no less terrible than so many furies, others
begat an stonishment in those that had the ill hap to encounter them, equal to
that of thunder and lightning, and the Soldiers animated by the example of
their Captains fought with so much courage and cruelty, that nothing was to be
seen but blood and slaughter.

Falanzar charged Florisel with an incredible fierceness, who was no whit
behind hand with him in the requital; Roussardan, Gorgophon, and Braverant
threatened such a ruin where they went, that the very glittering of their swords
frighted the faint-hearted to death; neither were Spheramond, Prigmaleon, and
Fulgoran less terrible to their enemies than they; the Grand Salvage,
Furiander his son, Marmoran, Brufaldor, and Policastoleon charged the
Christians through and through, till they scarce left a rank unranked:
Silverin of the Desert, Russian, Brandimanda, the Cen^phales, and Brandimore
did as much to the Pagan troops.

In brief these mighty Armies sustained by the valor of the Princes that
commanded them, had as yet gained little advantage of one another, which
raising Bravorant, Gorgophon, and the proud Knight Arastron, to the utmost
extremity of rage, they fell all three with such a violence upon Don Rogel,
Florisel and Spheramond, that they beat them all down to the ground, where they
made no long abode, though they were much astonished, but be took themselves to
their feet again, and on the instant made themselves such elbow room, that
except these three mighty enemies, who pressed upon them with a mad kind of
fury, none durst come near them; nevertheless diverse others of the Pagan
Champions coming also to assail them, the three Princes were in danger to
have made a glorious end of their days, had not Prigmaleon, Fulgoran, Russian,
and Silverin, seeing them in this necessity, come in to their aid, and let fly
at these three mighty Pagans with such a force, that they had almost lost their
saddles, and so affording leisure to the Christian Knights to supply themselves
with the next fresh horses they met, they began to cover the earth anew with
dead bodies.

These fearful blows adding rather anger than fear to the bold Pagans, they
rose up more furious than ever they had been before, and not finding those that
had put them into this disperate plight, they fell upon Oriander, Atletta his
wife, and Parmenian of Cyprus, dealing such mavelous strokes, that two of
them were cut in two pieces, and the third cleft down to the teeth, so the
battle waxing more bloody on every side, every thing appeared so full of
horror, that the Sun appeared as it were mourning, for the expense of so much
noble blood, obscuring his face behind a cloud.

The Pagans sounded a retreat, and the Christians rallied their disordered
troops, to the great grief of Gorgophon, Bravorant, the Grand Salvage, Arastron
and Roussardan, who seeing their own wounds, and dispairing of a present
victory, retired to their Tents, and the Christians part into the Town, and
part into their Trenches, where being at leisure to number up their losses,
which amounted unto two hundred and threescore thousand men, besides the King
of the barren Island, and his Wife; the Kings of Hungaria, of Polonia, of
Licaonia, of Moldavia, of Sardimira, of Cataya; the valiant Lady Arletta,
Parmenian of Cyprus, R^zafar, Quadragant, Agrian of Scotland, Dardanio, of
Rhodes, and the gentle Armond of Bohemia, they had a just cause of lamentation;
but seeing that their chief Leaders were preserved, and that it was in vain to
murmr at the chastisements of a mighty God, they comforted themselves, and
causing their wounds to be searched, which they found to be dangerous enough,
they all betook themselves to their beds, except the valiant Esquelan of
Polonia, that was much afflicted with the death of the King his Father;
Cilindor and the twelve new Knights, whose brave feats of Arms performed that
day, had acquired them an immortal fame;

On the other side, the Pagan Princes had no less cause to mourn, and repine
at their sad fate, having lost an hundred and sixteen Giants, T^rism^nd,
Arcilles, Celiander, Gloridian, Celianis, Panizell, Armelion, three hundred and
forty thousand men, the Kings of Fortan, of Gianazana, of Salberna, of
Pergarus; the Emperor of Media; Polidarchus, king of Amazia; Bemond, king of
the lesser Iava, the king of Sisiphalta, of Zambar, of Cartagena, of Maramor,
of Argocana, of Zaphotir, and almost all the rest were confined to their beds,
except Falanzar, (who had received only one slight hurt in the arm by the
sword of Florisel,) Palicastaleon, Fierastr^n, and Brufald^r; but not
withstanding these losses, they desiring to appear invincibles they made no
show of discontent in their countenances, lest thereby the courage of the
Soldiers might be abated, and to give a testimony of the care they took for
their dead, they sent immediately to demand a truce for twelve days, which
being granted, and agreed on both parties, every man sought out his
acquaintance to perform unto them the last office of a friend.

The Christian Princes were solemnly interred; and the bodies of the Pagans
burned, as their custom was; which being done, Falanzar gave Broncaldion, King
of the Arcofibrats a party of fourscore thousand men, with order to surprise
Goraxa, and Zeiden, two of the strongest Cities of Ethiopia, supposing that the
remainder of his horses, which amounted to the number of three hundred, and
threescore thousand was powerful enough to give an absolute defeat to their
enemies: And now let us leave them bewayling their losses, and devising new
stratagems for the ru^ing of the Christians, and let our discourse return to
those Knights, which are departed from Corolandaya, to go to the surprisall of
the Castle of Treasure.

CHAP. XLII. Rozalmond, Alcidamant, and their company arrive at the dangerous
Forests of the great Kingdom of Martan, the carrying away of the Princesses,
and the adventures of Rozalmond, inextring of the Castle of Treasure.
ALcidamant, Rozalmond, and the other Princes that left the Court of
Corolandaya, to go to the Castle of Treasure, having been three and twenty
days upon their way without any adventure, that might yield them either trouble
or content, they entered into the dangerous Forests of Martan, and continuing
on their Journey, at length they arrived at a place, where they met with ffoure
several ways, and there being overtaken by the darkness of the evening, they
purposed to attend the morning light, wherefore alighting from their horses
they fate down together upon the gra^^e, and causing such meat to be set before
them, as their Squires had provided, they began to feed as heartily, as if they
had been feasted at the tables of the Emperors of Gardacia, or Martaria, the
Knights needed no lights, the place being illuminated by the fair eyes of
their Mistresses, and those excellent Ladies did not a little comfort
themselves with the protection which their company gave them assurance of from
all disasters that might occur.

The short collation being ended, the Squires retired to their horses, which
were feeding not far off, and the Ladies overcome with the heaviness of sleep,
laid themselves down under the next adjoining trees, environed with the
Princes, who rested at their feet, to secure them from any danger, that uncouth
place might produce.

Their past travel caused them quickly to fall into a sound sleep, and so
continued till midnight, when as six dreadful creatures laying hold on the
Ladies stole them from amidst the Knights, wherewith they being wakened, and
crying out with such a shrill voice, as quickly pierced the ears of their
Champions; they rose up full of amazement, which was immediately converted into
fury, as soon as they perceived the Centaurs run through the thickets of trees,
laden with such precious burdens; their grief for this theft allowing them no
leisure to look for their horses, they made after them on foot with the best
expedition, conducted only by the woeful cries of those they sought to rescue,
and so leaping over hedges and ditches, with a far nimbler swiftness, than
those unto whose feet despair has added wings, they wandered to their great
grief till break of day.

When Rozalmond being on the top of a Mountain, saw one of these Monsters
standing in the mouth of a cave, and grasping in his rude arms the beautiful
Armazia, which spectacle ministering unto him no small content but much more
fury, he doubled his pase, and was not far behind him, when he drew his sword
and entered the cave, with an assured confidence that his first blow should take
his head from his shoulders, but the place was so dark, that after he had
advanced three or four steps, he could see neither Centaur nor Lady;
nevertheless being directed by the complaints, which he well understood came
from Armazia, he fell to running with no less speed, then if he had been in
the plain field, enjoying the favor of the sunbeams to direct him, and
finding the vault still larger and larger, he made no stay till he came to the
brink of a violent Torrent, whose swift streams made so loud a noise, that
there seemed to be some dangerous precipice before him, these dreadful waters
taking from him al hopes of passing further, he turned back and sought up and
down the Vault for the Centaur, when on a sudden he heard the voice of Armazia
on the otherside of the Torrent, which with many a heavy sigh uttered these
words; alas shall I meet with no relief, and must I perish by the violence of
this Monster, who goes about to force me, help, help, noble Knight or Armazia
is lost forever.

Rozalmond hearing these pitiful words, transported with rage, throws
himself into the River, whose waves tossing him for a while, to and fro, at
last they landed him in a Hall of a stately Palace under ground, so amazed, as
if his senses had utterly forsaken him; howbeit his spirits being a little
revived, he rose up and walked a turn or two up and down that obscure room, and
would have gone further, if he had not there discovered the Centaure, who with
a great club in his hand came to assault him; this fell object did rather
rejoice, than affright him that was incapable of fear, so that he charged this
Monster with so fierce a blow, as he thought would have divided him in two,
whereat he being little or nothing astonished, let fall his merciless club
with such a might on Rozalmonds arm, as almost deprived him of the use thereof.

The fury of this Knight growing to extremity, (he being now about a piece of
work of the greatest importance that ever he undertook, namely the redemption
of her that was dearer to him than all the world besides, the combat began to
be most dangerous, the Centaure avoided the strokes of his adversary with such
a skillful nimblenesse, as he was seldom or never there with touched, and
returned his so dexterously, and with such a force, that poor Rozalmond was
oftentimes constrained to make use of his hand and knee to save himself from
falling: Oh God, said he, am I come hither to fight in such manner, as I shall
not be able to rescue Armazia from the cruelty of this Monster? why did not
these waters that I passed rather stifle me, or the rocks beat out my brains,
than that I should escape both, and live to see my Wife, my only comfort
ravished from me, and I want the power to relieve, or revenge her? give me a
resolution either to deliver her from him, or my self to death, since all my
quiet and happiness depends on her safety; whereupon beholding the Centaur
with knit brows, eyes sparkling out fire, and gnashing his teeth, all evident
tokens of an enraged soul, he let his sword fly with such a tempest at his
head, as cleft him down to the shoulders, overthrowing him to the ground with
such a noise, as seemed to threaten the ruin of the place.

This fortunate blow rendered him not a little contented, but he was forthwith
marvellously astonished, to see such a multitude of Sepents arise from the
blood of this Monster as covered all the room, but advancing with his sword
that never failed him, he cut half a dozen of them that were the forwardest to
assault him in pieces; which begat a greater wonder, for these twelve pieces
were transformed into twelve furious Lions.

Then was this incomparable Warrior in no small straight, for (being environed
and assaulted by all these Lions, and feeling the Serpents twining about his
legs, whereby he was so encumbered, as he had scarce any power to stir) he knew
not from which to defend himself, nor upon whom to bestow his blows; he often
lifting up his sword above his head, attempted to let it fall again with no
less force than would have cleft down a Giant, but the Lions being terrified
with the glittering of his blade, instantly with their paws seized on his arm,
and so prevented the blow: In brief, he knew not what course to take, but was
so full of rage, that he could almost have found in his heart to have converted
his fury to his own ruin; nevertheless, calling to mind his Armazia, and
somewhat comforting himself with the remembrance of his wonted courage, and the
happy success which he ever had in all difficult enterprises, he resolved to
quit his sword, and clenching his fist let fall his Gantlet upon the head of
one of the Lions with such a force, as sent him dead to the ground, which
giving him hope of the like defeat upon the rest, he laid about him so
furiously with both hands, that it was not long ere he sent the rest to keep
company with the former.

These dangerous enemies being dispatched, he would willingly have taken a
little breath, but the cruel war which the Serpents still continued against
him, offered him no leisure, so that he laid his hand again on his sword, and
prepared for the slaughter of these troublesome creatures; howbeit remembering
that from their pieces had sprung such fierce and ravening creatures, he let it
hang at his arm, and griping these Serpents in his hands, he strangled them all
one after another, but with so much pain and labor, that he was fain to fall
upon his knees, not being able to support himself any longer on his legs, this
victory which had made him sweat more than ever he had done in any Combat in
all his life, giving him some hope of a lucky end, he sat him down on the
ground, where not staying so long as to take breath, he suddenly arose, and
going to a very fair Damsel, which he saw come out of the cleft of a Wall,
with an opinion that it was his dearest Armazia, he said unto her, ah Madam,
what care and pains has the loss of you cost me, but I hold them all well
bestowed, since they have been able to serve you, and that I find you living,
after I had utterly despayred of your safety.

My Lord, answered she, how glad am I of meeting with you thus, but that I may
be a assured it is you, pull off your Helmet, that so by the light of your fair
eyes, I may be cleared of all farther doubt. I never disobeyed you as yet,
replied he, wherefore I will bare my face, that you may know I am not here by
any enchantment; whereupon going to unlace his Helmet, a woman catching him by
the arm, said unto him, Knight, what mean you to do? take heed of discovering
your self, for otherwise you will never get out of this place; who are you,
said he, stepping a pace or two back, that counsels me to displease my Lady, by
the neglect of her command? and observing her a little better, he continued
saying, O me! what do I see? Sweet Cassandra, what is it has brought you
hither now? Only the care of saving you, answered she, for if you give credit
to this fantosme that represents unto you Armazia, you shall never see her
again, and shall with your self lose all those excellent Knights that
accompanied you out of Corolandaya, together with the glory, and greatness of
all Christendom.

At these words Rozalmond staying, cast his eyes upon the former Damsel, and
acknowledging in her face the very favor and beauties of Armazia, he was
strangely distracted, for it grieved him to have any other will, then such as
his Mistress pleased, and on the other side, he was assured that Cassandra loved
him, and that her skill was most admirable, in so much that he stood looking
very wistly on them both, without speaking one word, when as she that seemed to
be Armazia, said unto him, how now Knight? Do you more regard the speeches of a
Sorceresse that means to deceive you, than of your Wife? do you not perceive
this to be the face which you have so often adored? are not these the very
clothes I had on at the time of our cruel separation? Verily I have great
cause to complain of you, and to say that your love was but dissimulation,
bethink you therefore, whether you will believe me, or no, for be assured if you
refuse to give me your Sword and Helmet, I will return into Gardacia, and never
look on you more.

Madam, answered Rozalmond, (who began to suspect her, and that knew well
Armazia loved Cassandra, better than to speak ill of her) you may be confident
that I will never prefer any thing on the earth before your contentment, but be
pleased to consider, that men are subject to a thousand dangers, and that I
should not be in case to fight, if any new enemies should chance to arrive,
whilst my arms were in your hands, and what good will they do you? Let me
alone with them, I beseech you, for to serve you; and to withdraw you out of
this Cave with less danger; It imports not you much to see me now, but much it
concerns me to keep me as I am, wherefore you shall have that content, as soon
as we shall be in any place where the Sun may assure me that I am in the world.
Uncivil Knight, answered she, thou shall presently feel how much thou have
displeased me, saying so, she took upon her, the form of a most hideous
Fantosme, which with a burning Torch in her hand, began to charge him so
furiously, that her blows seemed to be so many thunderbolts, falling on his
head and shoulders; he looked about for Cassandra, but perceiving her to be
gone, he laid hold on his Sword, and giving a thousand, and a thousand strokes
in the air without hitting any thing, he was so weary, as he was constrained
to rest himself against the Wall, where this Fantosme came, and making most
villainous faces, and with most dreadful howlings, assailed him again, giving
him such terrible blows, that another less strong and courageous would have
fainted under them.

Five hours being spent in this Combat, the Knight that saw nothing because
the night was very dark, but by the eyes, and Torch of the Fantosme, desiring
to free himself from so great a vexation, flourished with his sword all about,
and cutting the air as before, five or six turns up and down the room, at
length by chance met with an entry, wherinto he was no sooner entered, but the
Fantosme vanished away, and left him in such darkness, that every step he
made, he was in fear of falling into some precipice; whereupon he stood still,
and leaning upon his Sword, rested himself for half an hour in that manner, at
the end whereof being wonderful desirous to see a period of this adventure, he
went on groping with both his hands, until about the break of day, he
discovered a very stately Court, full of most admirable Pictures, and lymited
with three great bodies of lodgings built triangle-wise, of which the Walls
being curiously covered with Porphirie, Jasper, black Marble, and Crystal,
cast so bright a luster, that he stayed the more exactly to observe the
workmanship of it.

Nevertheless advancing presently forward, he past in at a Door which he saw
open before him, and had scarce set one foot within it, when as he felt two
such terrible blows discharged on his Helmet, as he was fain to kiss the
ground, from whence suddenly arising, he espied two dreadful Giants, each of
them holding a mighty club aloft in the air, and ready to fall again upon him,
if lightly leaping aside he had not avoided them; his fall, and the sight of
these great Colosses having stirred up his courage, he took his good sword in
both his hands, and with it struck one of the Giants in such manner, that
having divided his iron club in two, the point thereof light so rudely on his
shoulder, as he was forced to set his knees and hands to the ground, and going
to second the former blow, he was prevented by the other Giant, who gave him so
cruel a stroke between the neck and shoulders, that it made him (...) against
the Wall, but he quickly recovering himself, let drive in such sort at him that
wanted a club, as he laid him ^lat on the earth, which presently opening,
swallowed him up, and straightway closed again.

Being thus rid of one, he turned him about to the other, and thinking to avoid
his thundering club which was descending upon him, he was so surprised, that he
was constrained to slide under the Giants arm, and s^i^^ on his body; then
might be seen a most dangerous wrestling, the Giant took him fast by the
shoulders, and gave him such twitches, and terrible heaves, that he had many
times like to have overthrown him, howbeit refuming new courage in hope of
acquiring immortal fame by being victrious, he put the Giant so many ways to
it, and so often showed him such tricks as are practiced in wrestling, as after
two hours travel, he extended him on the floor, which instantly swallowed
him up, as it had done the other.

These two dangerous enemies being thus dispatched, our Warriou^ looked about
him, to see whether there were any more to combat with, but perceiving none
appear, he went to observe those excellent Pictures, where he beheld Amadis of
Gaul, Amadis of Greece, and other Princes of their blood, together with the
glorious feats of Arms performed by them in their life time, so lively
represented, that he had been lost in the contemplation of them, had he not
been directed by the sight of the five Knights entering into the Court together,
out of five several doors.

CHAP. XLIII. The mavelous exployts of Alcidamant, before his entrance into
the Castle of Treasure.
THE day appearing to Alcidamant, upon the top of a Mountain, after he had made
a thousand and a thousand turns, discovered unto him a Centaur of a prodigious
greatness, that carried away Trasiclea toward the mouth of a cave, from
whence issued huge flames of fire, which making him forget his former pains,
he began to run more lustily then he had done all the night before, and
traveled so long, till he approached the said cave, which seemed to be another
Mount Aetna, where the Centaur making a stand, threw Trasiclea into the midst
of the flames, and advancing his mighty club, he let it descend with such a
tempest on our Champion, that he was fain to set his hands to the ground, for
to save himself; but transported with extreme fury, and desiring to be
revenged on the Monster, for precipitating his Mistress in that manner, he
returned him so terrible a blow, as he made him stagger five or six paces
backward, wherewith the Centaur marvellously incensed, discharged so terribly on
his helmet, that he thought the ruins of some Tower had fallen upon him;
nevertheless being in the (...) of (...), he took his sword in both his hands,
and therewith stri^ing at this (...), ^^coun^^ed his club first, and b^at it
with such violence against his h^^d, that it overturned him into the midst of
that dreadful Fur^^ce.

Then it was when this Warrior seeing himself alone, without hope of taking a
greater revenge for the death of his Lady, which he believed was reduced to
ashes, that he began to cry so horribly, as made all the valleys about resound
therewith; his actions were nothing but expressions of madness, and all his
motions so full of rage, that the most confident Giants would have trembled at
the sight of him. Why stay I any longer, (said he laboring to pluck off his
Helmet, that he might tear his hair in pieces) wretch that I am, why stay I
any longer, to make an end of my self in any sort whatsoever? my Mistress is
not in the world, what should I do in it then? no, no, I must leave it, dye
the same death that she has done, and join my ashes to hers: saying so, he
^lung his shield to the ground, and casting his eyes by chance toward the grot
with such piercing sighs, as if his soul would every minute have parted from
his body, he perceived a little Pillar, where beholding a table hanging, he
approached unto it, for to read these words.

Jf thou have courage enough to pass these (...), thou shall recover the
Treasure, which thou beleevest is l^st. O me, said he, more contented than ever
he had been furious, am I permitted yet to hope, and can the safety of my
Mistress consist in my adventures? away with all regard and fear of danger, and
let the world see that my soul does burn with a far more fierce and glorious
fire; whereupon taking up his sword and shield, he went on and threw himself
into those horrible flames, wherein having continued above a quarter of an
hour, without feeling any heat at all, he found himself in a meadow environed
with inaccessable Rocks, saving one only overture which appeared in the form
of a door, whither addressing himself he perceived three monstrous fowls come
out of it, the least whereof was as big as an Ox, which striking at him with a
most dreadful noise, laid him all along on the ground, from whence fear and a
desire to meet with his Lady, having quickly raised him up again, he took his
sword, and (...) when these creatures were returned with their former fury, he
hit one of them so luckily, just on the joint of the wing, that he cut it off,
which caused that dangerous creature to fall to the ground, where becoming
more (...) by the sight of his blood, he r^^ upon him with a m^^vellous force,
but the Knight presenting the point of his sword, stroke him to the heart; and
so sent him dead to the earth.

In the mean time the other two be^^ing their mighty wings, stooped to him, and
catching him in their tallon^, carried him up into ^^e air, where by his fall,
or the fury of these Mon^^ers he could have expected nothing but assured death,
had he not for^^^^tely met with the ^elly of one of them, where into he past
his sword almost to the (...), by which means the p^ngs of death wherein he was
made hi^ un^oo^^ his hold, and let our Knight fall in such a grievous man^^^,
that he verily thought all his bo^es had be^^e bro^e^ within hi^* nevertheless
^^^ing the other (...) toward him, he presently got up, yet not so soon, but
that having first caught him by the Helmet, he lift him up above two foot from
the ground, howbeit finding him too heavy for his hold, he quit him, and
forced him to fall again upon his hands, where suddenly returning, he hit him
with his hooked beak so ^udely on the shoulders, that the club of a mighty
Giant could not more cruelly have bruised his flesh.

This Champion desiring to vanquish his enemy, who by no means would now come
within the reach of his sword, struck at him a thousand and a thousand times in
vain; where-with-all being very much wearied, and finding how that was not the
way to prevail, he held his sword close under his shield, and watching the
Monsters next stooping to catch hold on it, he thrust up his hand with such
fury, that he ran him quite through, and through, laying him dead hard by him.

This trouble some combat, which had lasted three hours, being gloriously
finished, he sat him down on the grass, where the remembrance of his Mistress
not permitting him to stay long, he arose and made toward the Grot, and in
pursuit of his good fortune entering into it, he felt so many strokes upon his
shield and Helmet, that he had much ado to keep himself on his legs; howbeit
standing stiffly to it, and covering himself well with his shield, he laid about
him with his sword, though he saw no body upon whom he could fasten a stroke,
yet feeling that he found resistance, and that his blade did encounter Armor,
now he gave a downright blow, then a thrust, and bestirring himself with
mavelous fury, he still made way; notwithstanding, the more he advanced, the
more was he pressed by his invisible enemies, which so belabored him, that to
his remembrance he never endured so much pain in all the combats he had fought
before; his courage that never knew what danger meant, and that sought for
glory in the greatest difficulties, made him redouble his blows, and go on in
despite of those he did not see, till he saw himself freed from so furious a
charge.

One would think now that our Knight had a great deal of reason to rest
himself, but the desire he had to find out his Mistress, made him go on
without any stay, till he came to a great door, against the which he ran so
forceably with his foot, that it flew open, and gave him entrance into a very
spacious room, where at first sight he was taken with much wonder, for in the
midst of it a crystal Coffer appeared, bordered about with twelve burning
Torches, and twelve huge Pillars that supported the whole edifice, out of the
which on a sudden issued as many dreadful Salvages, with each of them a mighty
club in his hand, who straight way assailed him on all sides, but he received
them in such manner, that at the very first blow he laid one of them on the
ground in case to do him no harm any more, and flying in amongst the rest, he
cut off three more almost by the waste; whereat the others being nothing
dismayed, laid upon him like eight hammers upon an Anvill, wherewithal he was
so terribly battered, as his very bones seemed to be broken within his flesh,
nevertheless hoping for no worse success than he had found in his former
dangers, he bestirred himself with such fury amongst them that he ran up one
to the hilts, cleft another to the girdle, and the third had both his arms,
together with his club sent to the ground.

This so sudden an execution encouraging him to do better, he valiantly
pursued his good fortune, but coming to want breath, he went and leaned
against one of the Pillars, that so he might have them all before him to fight
withal, presenting them his shield on the one side, and the point of his sword
on the other, he attended the approach of these furious and cruel creatures,
which in stead of assaulting him, fell to make such horrible cries, that the
very room shaked withal; by this means having opportunity to rest himself,
he continued about half an hour in that manner.

But pressed with desire to see the end of so many marvels, he advanced toward
these Salvages, that with their clubs were ready to receive him, and resolving
either to dye, or vanquish, he cast his shield behind his back, took his sword
in both his hands, and discharged it so dangerously upon one of them, as he
divided his body in two, cleft another down to the shoulders, and so terrified
the rest, that they began to run all up and down the room, to avoid the fury of
his blade; nevertheless being at last overtaken with incredible pains, two
were overthrown dead upon the place; and the last threw himself upon the great
coffer of Crystal, where by signs he would have begged for life, but
Alcidamant was in such a rage, that without taking heed to what he did, he gave
him so mighty a blow, as having cut him in two pieces, the point of his sword
fell so rudely on the coffer, that it broke it into a thousand pieces;
whereupon there instantly ensued such a terrible clap of thunder, that our
Warrior fell down upon the floor quite void of judgment, where having lain
some two hours, as it were in a trance, he arose without so much as feeling
the least weariness of his passed labors, and beheld instead of the coffer, a
guilt Cuirace enameled with red and green, and garnished in many places
withgreat Diamonds, which rendered a mavelous luster, so excellent, and of so
high a value, as all the richest and bravest Arms that ever he had seen were
nothing in comparison of this, hard by was a most stately Helmet of the same
metal and color, as also a shield with the same device as was in his own;
the desire he had to possess himself of these Arms pressed him so far that
he was about to quit his own, for to put them on, but fearing some trick or
enchantment, he began to consider them with wonder, and to observe them so
narrowly, as he perceived a scrole within the Cuirace, wherein this was written
in the French tongue.

Alcidamant make no difficulty to take these Arms, for they are due to thy
merit, and above five hundred years before thy birth, they were made for theeby
the most excellent Magicians of the earth. Verily said he then, I have no
reason to make any further doubt, for my name that is here written, and the
devise of the shield may well assure me; therewith doffing his own, he put on
that excellent armor which he found so fit for him, that he was confident, it
was made for his service; whereupon being armed at all points, he looked round
about him, and perceiving a large Alley, he entered into it, hoping to crown his
designs with a happy concsiluon.

CHAP. XLIV. What happened to the gentle Clarisel of Guindaya, before he entered
the Castle of Treasure.
C Larisel of Guindaya, bing mightily vexed at the carrying away of his fairest
Miralinda, ran up and down so long, till he discovered a woman in the hands of
three Giants, who leading her tied with cords, made her go very hastily along;
the violence of passion which beguiles the eyes of men, and that represents
things unto them quite otherwise then they are, persuading him that it was his
beautiful Shepherdess, he cried out, O ^^ is it possible that I should behold
her most inhumanely bound with cords, which might captivate all the world? Ah
Madam, these villains, shall not long continue the wrong they do you, for I
will punish them so cruelly, that if all the Giants on the earth were assembled
together, they should learn what it were to lay hands on a creature of your
merit; stay wicked wretches, and do not thus tire so inestimable an
excellence, stay I say, or else be sure that I will cut you into a thousand
pieces; whilst he uttered these words, love and fury lending him wings, he ran
with all his might, and made such speed, that within less then half an hour
he saw himself upon the bank of a great pool, and so near those three
Colossus, as he had the means to discharge a blow on the Helmet of him, that
went hindmost, with such fury that he cleft him down to the teeth.

At the noise of this terrible stroke, and the fall of that Giant, the other
two that were before drew forth their heavy Fauchions, and charged our valiant
Warrior so rudely, as they made him reel very much astonished three or four
steps back, but instantly calling to mind, that the safety of his Mistress was
in question, for whom he would have fought with all the world together, he
instantly recovered himself, and returning to his enemies, he began to shower
most horrible blows upon them, both one after another; nevertheless they
pressed him in such manner, and their strokes were so heavy and thick, that if
the arms he wore had not been framed by Vrganda, without doubt he had been in
very great danger.

This Combat having continued two hours with strange fury, the Giants were
covered all over with blood and wounds, and Clarisel began to grow feeble, by
reason of the incredible travail which he had endured all the night long; but
drawing new forces from the greatness of his courage, and the hope he had of
delivering his fairest Mistress, he took his sword in both his hands, and with
mavelous agilitie passing by two horrible blows, that descended upon him at
one instant, he let his sword fall with such violence upon the shoulder of one
of them, as he opened him to the very girdle, which possessing him that
remained with more rage than fear, he discharged on our Warriors shield with
such fury, as having beaten it against his head, he made him knock his chin
against his breast, and set his knees to the earth, where desiring to overthrow
him quite, he abandoned his great Curtelas, and taking him between his mighty
arms, he gave him three or four terrible twitches: nevertheless, the Knight
being in spite of him risen up again, settled himself well on his legs, and
laying very fast hold on him, he began to bustle very strongly with him, and
put him so to it, as he left him without hope of easily overcomming him.

This dangerous wrestling having continued an hour and better, to the
exceeding discontent of Clarisel, who was vexed to the heart, that he could not
prevail, he became so furious, as making use of all his force, he thrust the
Giant in such sort, that not able to make him let go his hold, they went both
to the ground, where desire of vanquishing animating them alike, they tumbled
up and down so long together, till they fell both into the Poole, where being
separated he knew not how; our Warrior felt himself pulled by the feet, as if
he should be drawn into some precipice, and indeed he found himself in a Cave,
where treading on the carcasses of men, he was marvellously astonished, for
that he perceived not the water to be any longer over his head, nor how he came
there, for casting his eye round about, and perceiving neither Window nor
door, he knew not what to think, nor say, at his being in so dark and hideous
a place, from whence he had little hope to get out.

Nevertheless, being incapable of fear, he went groping by the walls some
twenty or thirty paces, when as he chanced to hear most dreadful hissings,
whereat making a stop, he espied a furious Serpent of an unmeasurable
greatness, which scraping up the earth, stared upon him with two terrible
fiery sparkling eyes, able to terrify any other less confident than our
Knight, who being lighted by those two horrible torches, quickly presented his
shield to the claws of the Monster, and being guided by his good fortune, he
thrust him so just in one of his eyes, that his sword entered three fingers deep
into his head, which caused him to make such strange leapes and cries, that all
the place round about trembled again; and provoked by the smart of his wound,
he flew with such fury at Clarisel as overthrowing him to the earth, he set his
teeth, and claws to his shield, breaking it as easily in pieces as if it had
been glass, and not contented therewith, he plucked so violently at his Helmet,
as if he would have disarmed him, for to devour him, when as the Knight full
of assurance and judgment in the midst of such danger, gave him so sore a
hurt in the belly, that feeling himself touched in this manner, he made a skip
up to the very roof of the Vault, and so suffered the Knight to arise
suddenly, which was to good purpose for him, in regard that the dangerous
creature lighting down presently made at him with such rage, as he could not
possibly choose but have gone again to the ground, had he not warily declined
him, wherefore retiring aside with more agilitie than his weariness seemed to
permit, he let him pass by like lightning, and desiring to make use of
opportunity, he discharged so mighty a blow full upon the body of him, as might
well have divided an Anvile in sunder, howbeit his sword returned without
effect, his scales being so hard, that it did not so much as make any dint in
them, which at first somewhat amazed him.

Nevertheless being ever most confident, where most difficulty appeared, he
resolved to strike him no more in vain on the back, but to try his belly, and
accordingly when this furious Serpent returned, he courageously attended him,
and beholding him raised up on his tail, he thrust his sword so strongly at
his breast, that he ran him up to the very hilts, yet could not that keep him
from being overturned again to the earth by this terrible creature, which in
the pangs of death so crushed him with his claws, and the weight of his body,
as he thought he should have died before he could have cleared himself, but
the greatness of his courage would not suffer him to continue long in that
manner, for quickly ridding himself of so heavy a burden, he withdrew into a
corner of the Grot for to let the Serpent dye, which stormed so horribly, as
the Cave seemed to fall into ruin.

Half an hour being past with this dreadful noise, a general silence
succeeded, whereby Clarisel judging that the Monster was dead, followed the
wall as before, so long till he felt a door, upon the which having bestowed
all his strength, both with his feet, and the pomell of his sword, he brake it
open, and then entered through it into a spacious room, along the which he
perceived thirty very fair Damsels coming who courteously saluting him, he
was encouraged to say thus unto them; Ladies, the honor you do me, does very
much oblige me, but you would add much unto this favor of yours, if you would
tell me any news of an incomparable beauty, which was most unfortunatly stolen
from me in a certain Forest here by. We will give you this content, answered
one of them, but Knight, it must be upon condition that you promise us what we
shall demand of you. If it be in my power, answered Clarisel, assure your
selves, Ladies, you shall not be denied; That which we desire is, replied she,
that you put off your Helmet and kiss us one after another in way of
salutation as the manner is, and that also you will lie with each of us one
whole night together. Your demand, answered Clarisel (exceedingly offended with
this sha melesse speech) being repugnant to the faith which I have plighted to
my Lady, be pleased to dispense with me if I do not satisfy your request,
which in plain terms seems not very honest unto me. How now, wicked wretch,
said the Damsel, do you reproach us to our faces, after you have violated
your word to us? come sirs, lee us make this insolent Knight see that we are
able to revenge our selves when we are wronged; Here with they all of them took
out rods from under their coats, and environing the Knight, began to whip him
so cruelly, that their blows which fell upon his Armor, were no less weighty
than the clubs of the strongest Giants of the earth.

Our Champion seeing himself entreated after this manner, was marvellously
abashed, for though he had his sword in his hand, yet durst he not use it
against them, because they were women; on the other side feeling all his body
battered with multitude of strokes, he was mightily vexed, and could not tell
what to do; for as soon as he avoided the hands of some of them, he found
others presently at his shoulders, and how to get from them he knew not, in
regard they had planted themselves so close together, round about him, that
they stood as strong as a wall; in the mean time their battery continued, and
the Knight found himself in worse case then he was, under the dreadful blows
of Zorobalan, and his brother in great Britain, so that being constrained to
resolve upon somewhat, he held his sword over his head, and running with his
shield against them in a strange fury, he suddenly laid five or six of them on
the ground, which making him way to advance forward, he labored to gain a
porch that he beheld on his left hand, but the rest presently overtaking him,
he fell into his former suffering; whereupon doing as he did before, and having
thereby overthrown a dozen more of them, he got nine or ten paces forward,
where feeling the violence of those blows, to be far greater than at the
beginning, he became so incensed, that rushing forth with all his force, he
passed to the entrance of the porch, in despite of them all; where thinking
himself safe, because they were vanished away, he perceived a Knight in black
Arms make toward him, who without telling him wherefore, saluted him with so
terrible a blow on his shield, as made him set one knee to the ground, which so
enraged him, that taking his sword in both his hands, he discharged it with
such a tempest on his helmet, as made him fall all along, believing that he had
made an end of him; nevertheless, he saw him rise up instantly again, and make
at him with a strange fury, as if he would be thoroughly revenged, but viewing
that dreadful blade aloft in the air, he recoyled to the end of the porch,
where Clarisel having stricken him with all his strength, he sent him to the
earth, which swallowed him up with a most fearful noise, leaving our Warrior
amazed at so many wonders, and exceedingly contented to behold a very stately
Court, toward which he addressed himself with an assured hope to see a
successful issue of his Enterprise.

CHAP. XLVII. The mavelous adventures that befell Amadis of Trebisond, in the
enterprise of the Castle of Treasure.
NEither bushes, trees, nor thorns being able to arrest Amadis, whom the loss
of Palmirenna had made desperate he ran without intermission, until the Sun
grown somewhat high, discovered unto him a spacious Lake, whose further bank
was bordered with a number of magnificent Palaces; the opinion he had, that he
might there hear some news of those Centaurs retreat, possessing him with a
desire to pass the Lake, he coasted so long till he met with a Boat,
whereinto entering, he began with the oars to make way through the water; the
Lake was very calm, and the wind blew with a gentle gale; but at the third
stroke of his oars the waves began to swel and encounter one another with such
rage, as the little skiffe was now carried up as high as the clouds, and by and
by thrown as low as the center of the earth; so sudden and dangerous a tempest
having somewhat amazed the Knight, he labored to surmount the fury of the
waters, and rowing with incredible strength and skill, he kept his Bo^^ steady,
when as a multitude of monstrous fishes ran with such violence against it, that
it was five or six times ready to overturn; the hazard he was in of drowning
was much; nevertheless trusting in the mercy of Heaven, he left mastring the
waves, and fell to combat those creatures with his oars, he struck one, beat
down another, turned him on every side, now stepped forward, then again retired;
besides the Lake was so terrible rough, as he could not stand upon his legs;
but ever and anon was on his knees; briefly, he endured such fearful payns,
that he wished himself a thousand times in the midst of six such Monsters,
as he defeated at his arrival in the Empire of Martaria, rather than be
constrained to deal with these aquaticall horrors, which in the mean time so
tossed the poor skiffe from one to another, that after they hade made it caper,
I know not how often up to the very sky, they turned it over and over, casting
our Knight into the midst of the proud waters, which incontinently swallowed
him up, being unable by reason of his armor to swim for his life.

Then it was that he verily believed, that the end of his days was come,
wherefore assuring himself that the bottom of the Lake should be his
Sepulcher; he bestowed his first thoughts in bewayling his eternal separation
from his Lady, and his last in repenting his sins; but he was marvellously
astonished to find himself in a round Hall very sumptuously built, and
sustained with twelve huge Arches, in the midst whereof he beheld a dozen of
Monkies making such ill-favored faces, and playing such gambals, as
notwithstanding the height of his displeasure he could not choose but laugh;
howbeit this contentment lasted not long, for he presently perceived those
little creatures transformed on a sudden into so many furious Bulls, of a
prodigious greatness.

This unexpected metamorphosis, counselling him to draw his sword, he began
with it to stand upon his guard; when as they all ran together at him with such
rage, that instead of overthrowing him to the ground, they hurled him up into
the air, and then so tossed him with their horns from one to another, that he
made ten or eleven turns before ever he came to the ground; whereby, though
his armor could not be pierced, his flesh and his bones were mightily bruised:
The Knight seeing himself blanketed in this sort, thought he was in no less
danger, then when he was on the water, and was exceedingly grieved for that he
could not make use of his strength and valor; but the most courageous
resolutions are ordinarily found in the greatest dangers, he took hold of one
of these Bulls horns, and settling himself on his back, clasped his sides fast
with his knees and legs, caught up his sword that hung at his wrist, and
setting spurs to him, made him serve in lieu of an horse to combat the rest,
advancing his sword then, he discharged it so dangerously upon one of them,
that he divided him in two, and continuing such horrible blows, laid four of
them on the ground within less then an hour, the rest with dreadful
bellowings so butted him on the thighs and back, that he was in extreme pain;
nevertheless choosing rather to dye than not to vanquish, he so bestirred
himself amongst them, that he extended the rest of the eleven dead at his
feet; and because that, upon which he was, troubled him infinitely by not
giving him leisure to alight, he took his sword in both his hands, and let it
descend with such force on his head, that having cleft it asunder, he sent him
to the earth breathing out his last, himself being cast five or six paces off
by the violence of the beast in his pangs of death.

This dangerous combat being finished in this sort, our Warrior sat him down
upon one of the dead Bulls to take a little breath, but the extreme desire he
had to meet with some one that might tell him news of what he sought for, not
permitting him to take much rest; he got out through a very little door, and
found himself under a rock, from whence issued a very clear Fountain, by the
which having espied Palmirenna sitting, he made toward her with incredible
joy, but she perceiving him coming, rose suddenly up and began to run away, as
if the fear of some mischief had made her fly from the Knight, who much
amazed knew not what to say to it, but imagining that she did not know him, he
followed after her, crying as loud as he could,

Alas! Madam, why do you fly me, and what fear you from me, that do not
breath, but for you? do you not see that I am your slave, or to say better,
that man whom you have made happy by the possession of your favors? stay, I
beseech you a little, and be assured that I am here to preserve you against all
the world, rather than to hurt you, and consider that these my arms, are the
very same which I put on for your service, when we undertook this voyage with
your friends: Do you fly from me still Palmirenna? what may I think of so
great a neglect, but that you have forgot your so many vows, and that ever you
loved me? Palmirenna I am your Amadi^, why do you run from me then with such
cruelty? whence comes this change? Alas! tell me; stay and let me know
wherein I have offended you, that so I may with my death make satisfaction to
your displeasure.

Whilst our Warrior with tears and sighs entreated thus in vain, he still
mended his pace, and running with all his might, was even ready to catch
Palmirenna, when as he perceived four Bears come out of a thicket, whereof
one seizing her, made away with her into the Wood, which put him into such a
rage, that he discharged his sword with that force on the foremost of them, as
having cut off both his paws, the point of it fell so furiously on his
shoulder, that it sent him dead to the earth.

This blow succeeding according to his desire, he was going to set upon the
rest, but being first laid hold on by them, he was overthrown to the ground;
where keeping him down under their cruel claws, they began to set their teeth
to his Armor, thinking to devour him very easily; but our Knigh^ making use of
his judgment, by little and little dis-ingaged his left hand, and drawing
forth his Poinard, he struck it so far into the belly of one of these Beasts,
that having reached his heart, he killed him outright, where with the third
being the more enraged, caught the Poinard between his teeth, biting it in
pieces, assailed the Knight afresh, who finding but this enemy to encounter
with, got up first on hisknees, and then rising all together, took him in his
arms, and laying him on his back stabbed him three or four times up to the
hilts.

The Bears being thus dispatched, he could have found in his heart to have
rested himself, but considering the danger his Lady was in, he flung into the
thicket, where he made a thousand turns without meeting any body, or finding
any way to get out again, at length after two hours travel, he discovered
three frames of building in triangle erected with mavelous art, to which
there was no passage, but by a long ally, that appeared on his left hand
wherein he went along until he came to a gate, and finding it shut, he knocked
twice or thrice, as hard as he could drive, whereupon he perceived one of the
most hideous, and dreadful Giants that ever he had seen look out of a window,
who with a hoarse voice, and in an arrogant manner said unto him; Wretched
Knight, what would thou have? Come thou to seek for death which all
others so decline? I would wish thee to be gone, and not to trouble me thus,
lest I come down, and cut thee into a thousand pieces. Audacious Giant,
answered Amadis, thy very look assured me of thy insolence, which moves me not
a whit, only descend, and open me the gate, we shall then see whether thou art
able to do that thou so much braggest of.

At these words the Giant having clapped too the Window, as if he were in a
mighty chafe, came down a little after, and showed so big to Amadis, that he
wondered how nature was able to frame so huge a mass of flesh, nevertheless
insensible of fear, he gave him with all his force ^ most terrible blow, that
cutting his shield in two, constrained him to recoile five or six paces
backward, howbeit this Collossus quickly recollected himself, and with a
mighty Fauchion began to deal such horrible blows, as the least of them had
been able to have cleft him down to the teeth, if ever he had stood them, but
avoiding them all with admirable address, he so mightily charged him both with
point and edge, as it had been a matter of great wonder to any that had beheld
the precedent labors which he had undergone all the day before; The Giant
stormed for that he could not fasten a stroke on him, and casting forth a thick
smoke at the vizier of his Helmet, hindered himself from seeing where his blows
should light, so that his Curtelas falling incessantly on the ground, had cleft
it in fourteen or fifteen places, which put him into such infinite excess of
rage, that every thing about them trembled with the very sound of his horrible
roaring.

Three long hours being spent in the first fury of this Combat, the Giant
began to grow weary and weak, and our Champion perceiving his advantage over
him, charged him afresh, but seeing him dispute the victory still with him, he
took his sword in both his hands, and struck his enemy so dangerously, as he
gave him a great wound in the arm, making him to reele withal; whereat he was
so mad, that resolving to determine the Combat, he also took his heavy
Scimiter in both his hands, and making as though he would strike on the one
side, discharged with such violence on the other, that Amadis being surprised
therewith, fell tumbling five or six paces off voyding a great deal of blood
at his mouth; This dreadful blow having showed our Warrior how dangerous it
was to receive the like, he arose so strangely transported with rage, that this
Colossus, who did not think any thing in the world was able to strike him with
the least touch of fear, began to apprehend the fury of his enemies sword,
which descended with such a tempest on him, as it opened him to the very wast,
sending him stark dead to the earth. Having performed this to his infinite
content, he lift up his eyes to heaven to give thanks for the assistance he had
received, and wondering much at the strangeness of those things he had lately
seen, he approached to the Gate, which being open, permitted him to behold a
stately Court all plastered with Porphyrie, ^^per, black Ma^ble, and Chry^^all;
whereinto let us le^ve him with an extreme desire to enter, and let us speak of
the (...) which befell Gri^^ the Salvage, and Gri^l^nis.

CHAP. XLVIII. The Mervails which happened to Griolanis, and the Knight of the
Salvage before their entrance into the Castle of Tr^asure.
THe grief wherein Gri^lanis and Grian the Salvage were, having made them
travel six hours with incredible pain, they met together coming out of
athicket, exceedingly vexed for that they could not learn any news of the loss
they had made; hereupon having rested themselves a little, they took the first
way that presented it self unto them, in which they went so long, till they
encountered certain very high walls, at the fight whereof they were wonderful
glad, hoping to hear somewhat of that they sought for; having walked then about
half an hour, they perceived two Damsels upon the battlements of the walls,
unto whom Griolanis addressing himself spoke in this sort. Gentle-women, if
you be as courteous, as fair; tell us whether you saw any Ladies, which were
