forceably carried away from us the last night in a Forest hereby. Knights,
answered one of them, we could soon let you see them you ask for, if you were
in this Garden; but the way to come hither is so difficult, that you shall not
be able to obtayn that contentment, if you be not the prime Knights of the
earth.

Gentlewomen, said Grain, it were a vanity for us to be persuaded that we were
any of those, the best in the world; but thus much we will promise that we will
with courage undertake, that which a Knight may perform; and to come where you
are, though we should pass through hell to it; wherefore we desire that you will
be pleased to show us the way. I know not, said the Damosel, whether your
actions will be answerable to your words; but to give you cause to adventure
your selves, look here, said she (showing Penamonda of Greece, and the gentle
Adelazia at one of the cranies tied with cords) these I think are those you
seek for, they shall continue in this estate, until you free them from their
bonds, and save them from greater punishment, which they are to suffer, if your
valor be wanting to them at this present: What, said the King of Corolandaya,
equally seized with joy and grief, shall we want courage in such an
Enterprise? Be assured, Gentlewoman, that we will be chopped into a thousand
pieces, rather then fail in their need, only do but tell us where we may get
in; Through a gate faid the Damosel, which you shall find about an hundred
paces from hence; the same shall show you two ways, let each of you take that
where into his fortune shall direct him, without returning for my consideration
what soever.

Here upon these two valiant Champions advancing forward, met with the Gate the
Damosel spoke of, and courageously entering into it they discryed two little
paths, the right Griolanis took, and Grian the Salvage the left, which lead
him to a cave, where a number of lighted torches hanging on the top of the
roof, plainly discovered the ground unto him, so covered with the points of
swords, pikes, halbards, and partisans standing upright, that was impossible to
make a step without treading on the sharp steel, which somewhat troubled him
at the first; nevertheless being ashamed to make a stop at any difficulty,
having been so charged to the contrary by the Damosel, he stoopst down to pull
them up, as the best mean to pass along; but just as he took hold of an
Halberd it sprung out of the earth, and hit him with such violence on the
breast, that it turned him over and over; where withal being much incensed he
arose, set his foot in the void place, where the halberd had stood, and feixing
with each hand the point of a sword, felt himself hit as before, with so great
force, that he had again been overthrown, had he not stood stiffly to it.

Having then room enough to place both his feet, he was going on to do as he
had begun, when as a mighty noise suddenly rising, he beheld all those points
to come out of the ground, the torches in an instant exringuished, and without
seeing any body, felt himself charged with such a tempest, as he was a long
quarter of an hour on his knees, being enforced to bow under an infirmity of
heavy blows laid upon his shield, his shoulders, and his head; but choosing
death rather than to fail in his enterprise, he arose in a rage, began to cut
those pikes, partisans, halberds, and swords asunder, and by little and little
gayning ground, sometimes flung his blade furiously about his head, then gave a
downright, and by and by a cross blow; briefly, he skirmished in that manner,
as if he had had a thousand Knights in head against him. This dangerous combat
having continued above two hours, with so much pain and labor, as a Knight
less strong and valiant, could not have endured it; he met with certain
steps; upon the first whereof having but set his foot, this so terrible a
charge ceased, which gave him leave to fit down on the second step, so much out
of breath, that he was feign to lift up the vizier of his helmet to take in air.

This while Griolanis was no less perplexed, for he likewise came to a cave
full of lighted torches; but his adventure was far more pleasing than Grians;
for he found the ground covered with exceeding fair women, which lay stark
naked so close one to another, that he was of necessity to tread upon their
bellies if he would pass on, whereat he was no less abashed, then his
companion had been at the sight of the pikes and halberds, so as he remained a
pretty while in suspense, not knowing what to resolve; and that which put him
more into confusion was to hear these women, who one after another said thus
unto him. Cruel Knight, what mean you to do? will you add unto our misery,
and not contented to behold us in a torment, far worse than death, will you
increase it by treading on our tender naked bodies? be moved with our tears,
take another way we beseech you, and perform your enterprise without our
pain; could you be contented to remember another day, that you have been the
destruction of an hundred Gentlewomen which never offended you? The remorse
whereof questionless would torture your conscience, nor would you ever look
upon a woman, but it would extremely grieve you, to think that you had been
wanting in pity to them.

This speech very much disquieted Griolanis, and he was upon the point to have
quit them, and undertaken his Companions way, had he not called to mind that
his Lady would then remain eternally in bonds, and that he had been advised to
pass on notwithstanding any consideration whatsoever, wherefore thinking that
he might without hurting these women, pass along by lifting them up one after
anotheer, he took the first by the arm, and set her on her feet, which was no
sooner done, but she gave him so terrible a blow with her fist on his Helmet,
that in his opinion a thunderbolt could not have hit him with more violence;
How now Gentlewoman, said he, is this the recompense of my good will? forbear I
pray you, and let me deliver your fellows: wherewith not able to appease her,
that still continued beating him, he resolved to spend no more time in words,
but took up the second, by whom he was entreated as by the former, and so
proceeding to lift up those that were next, he received so many blows on his
head, breast, and back, that he had much ado to keep himself on his legs:
nevertheless, what is not feazable for a valiant man, that desires to draw his
Mistress out of so grievous a captivity, as that wherein he had seen his
Adelazia? His courage augmented with difficulties, and though his flesh and
bones were all battered and bruised, yet he labored so long, that he rendered
the passage free, and had no sooner set his foot on the first step of a pair
of stayres that he beheld before him, but immediately these women vanished,
leaving him in rest, whereof doubtless he had as much need as Grian.

These two Warriors then having sat awhile arose, and going up a matter of
twenty steps entered just both together into a stately garden, and meeting at a
Fountain, where they were about to have refreshed themselves with a little
water, they perceived a kennell of hounds of diverse colors, coming along
behind two huntsmen, whereof one of them said unto them in an arrogant manner;
Wretched Knights, who brought you hither without my permission, and how dare
you be so bold, as to meddle with the water of my Fountain? be sure that you
shall pay for your presumption; go, said he, speaking to his Dogs, fall upon
these audacious fellows, and devour them in satisfaction of their crime;
whereupon these two valiant Warriors turning about to defend themselves, saw
no Dogs, but fifty or threescore Tigers, that having environed them, flew upon
them with strange fury, some bit them by the legs, some seized on their
shields, and some hung on their backs, briefly they were so close pressed by
them, as at first they were not able to use their Swords, but breaking from
them in a mighty rage, they began to deal such desperate blows, that in less
than an hour they had laid twenty at their feet, whereat the rest becoming
more cruel, assaulted them in such manner, as if their arms had not been of
the best in the world, these troublesome beasts had drawn blood from them, in
an hundred places, but turning back to back, and renewing the fight with
incredible courage, within two hours they made an end of the rest; howbeit
they were so weary, that they were constrained to fit down and rest them, where
with wonder they observed how all about the Garden there were Statues of Marble
placed, of several colors, so well done, as they wanted naught but speech,
and that the Fountain with most admirable art, sent forth water on every side;
the desire they had to know wherefore all this cost was bestowed there not
permitting them to rest any time, they arose, looked round about them, and
descrying no passage out, they resolved to compass the Wall till they met with
one.

Griolanis went one way, and Grian another, wherein being ravished with the
mavelous things they encountered, they were an hour before they could
compass it, at the end whereof, and at such time as they were not far from one
another, they met with two great Pillars, upon either of which, was a Table
hanging, where in the Greek tongue was this written;

Knight, if thou will pass into the Castle of Treasure, and find that which is
lost, cut down this Pillar, and be not dismayed at the difficulties thou shall
meet with in the alley. These words having showed the Knights how they should
bring their enterprise to pass, they with their Swords laid at these Pillars,
which at the very first blow going to pieces with a most dreadful noise, out
came two Salvages upon Griolanis, and two furious Lions on Grian, who seizing
on him with their paws, labored to pull his shield from his arm, but our
Warrior discharged such a blow upon one of them, as he laid him dead at his
feet, and a little after ran the other up to the hilts; in the mean while
Griolanis more courageous than ever he had been in his life, out of hope which
he was in, to find out his Mistress after this Combat, had cleft one of the
Salvages down to the waste, and cut off the other by the middle; that done,
they entered into one of those alleys, which ended in a large Court of a most
Sately Castle built trianglewise, and going along they felt themselves so
terribly pelted with a shower of stones poured down upon them from a number of
great trees that were planted on each side, as notwithstanding they warded
themselves well with their Shields, they had much ado to get unto the
threshold of two Gates which gave entrance to the Palace, the walls whereof were
all of Porphyrie, Jasper, black Marble, and Crystal.

CHAP. XLIX. The adventure of the Castle of Treasure is brought to an end,
whereupon all the Princes depart for Ethiopia.
WE left Rozalmond diverted from contemplating the excellent Pictures, that
were in the stately Court of the Castle of Treasure, by the arrival of five
Knights, which presented themselves all at one instant out of five several
doors: Now let us tell you, that they were the incomparable Alcidamant,
Clarisel of Guindaya, Amadis, Grian, and Griolanis, who having gloriously
surmounted the difficulties, which they had encountered, as appeared by the
precedent chapters, entered with their swords drawn, being much amazed at their
unexpected meeting thus together.

Hereupon these Princes having caressed one another, and made particular
relations of the strange adventures that had befallen each one in this
Enterprise; they resolved all to pass on, and beholding three great pair of
stayrs, they were going to ascend them two and two together, when they
perceived an old man with a great deal of Majesty present himself; his habit
was black and long, his beard white, his hair confusedly spread upon his
shoulders, in one hand a book, and in the other a golden wand, every one
observing him; Amadis knew him to be the Prince of al Philosophers, the great
Alcander, a special friend to the house of Greece, whereat being wonderfully
glad, he went immediately and embracing him, said. Oh father, how happily have
we met with you, for to free us of a care that mightily troubles us; we have
lost that which we most esteemed in the world, so that if we be not relieved by
you, we are like to be the wretchedst Knights living.

Excellent Princes, said this honorable old man, after he had saluted them
with a great deal of reverence, you have reason to be pleased with this
encounter of me, seeing I am more your servant, than all the men besides in the
world; but it is I that have the greater cause to rejoice at your arrival,
having attended you here an hundred years, since I first gave beginning to the
enchantments of this great Castle; you have this day done such wonders as no
other Knights could perform, which will make your valor to be spoken of
eternally, and the difficulties which you have surmounted are so great, as they
will hardly be believed, but infinite will be the praise for so many brave
actions, and the profit which will redound thereby to all Christendom, that
could not subsist without the end of this adventure, will render you so
recommendable, that you shall be the object of future ages marvel: You do not
know what good you have done; wherefore it is fit that I declare it, to the end
that you may be the more courageously prepared for the labors you are yet to
undergo.

You shall be the means of reviving the great King Amadis of Gaul, the
excellent Amadis of Greece, Don Silves de la Silva, Agesilan, and thirty
Princes more of their blood, withdrawn by me out of the number of the dead, at
the great battle of Aleppo, and hitherto conserved safe by my skill, as also
the unparragoned Knight of the Sun, with Claridian, Poliphebo, Rosicler,
Clarimant, Rozabel, Helen of Dace, Claridiana and Claribel, whose mavelous
acts have filled the world with amazement; and moreover the invinsible Belianis
of Greece, Belforan, Fortiman, Dolister of Nubea, Polista de la Silva,
Policertes, Don Clarinel, Astridea, Periana, Furibond the brave Giant,
Saliverna without fear, and Hermiliana, being all such valiant, and
accomplished Knights, that I have labored by my enchantments to keep them
alive, until such time as Christendom by their assistance and yours, may
triumph over the greatest number of enemies, that ever yet assaulted it: Is not
this greater good, than can be expressed in words? without doubt it is, and be
assured that the fame which you shall acquire hereby, shall ever live in the
memory of men.

Touching the trouble you are in, for the carrying away of the Princesses your
wives, clear your minds of it, for they have been all this while, as now they
are, safe from any such violence: the Centaurs, which you saw, being only fanto
smes, that I caused to appear unto you, knowing full well that you would never
have precipitated your selves, the one into a dreadful flood, amidst the
horrors of a fearful darkness, and the other into an horrible Furnace; and
briefly, that you would never have undertaken such almost impossible things as
you have achieved, had not the hope of recovering your Ladies, made you
contemn such wonderful dangers; and for that only consideration did Vrganda
cause them to come along with you, whom you shall meet with again, as soon as
you have finished the adventure, which now consists alone in forcing these
Princes, that I have named unto you out of the rooms, where they are enchanted,
but without employing your swords on them, or drawing drop of blood from them,
which will not be effected without very great pains, but I am sure it would
grieve you to leave so glorious an Enterprise in so fair a way.

Ah father, said Rozalmond, how strange and mervellous is this, that you have
recounted unto us, we thought that all these excellent Princes had been
converted into dust long ago; howbeit, seeing they live we will most gladly
render them unto the world if it be in our power, you say it will not be done
without much labor, why we are resolved to undergo any whatsoever; wherefore
be pleased, but to show us how we may get to these rooms. Then Alcandar having
appointed Rozalmond, and Don Clarisel, for the deliverance of Amadis of Gaul,
and Amadis of Greece; Alcidamant and Griolanis for the Knight of the Sun;
Amadis and Grian for Don Belianis, he caused them to ascend three several
pair of stayrs, whilst he himself remained walking below in the Court.

These six Warriors, more glorious than ever they had been in all their lives,
in regard of their undertaking of the most glorious enterprise, which had at
any time been spoken of in the world, being gotten up to the top of the stayrs,
found the doors there fast shut, but having easily heaved them off the hinges,
they entered all with their Swords unsheathed, and their bodies well covered
with their shields, where knowing what to do, Rozalmond seized on Amadis of
Greece, and Clarisel on the great King of the Gauls, with a resolution to
carry them forth: but these two strong and valiant Princes began to resist them
with such fury, that with good reason they had been esteemed in former times
for the prime Knights of the earth. Amidst this their dangerous wrestling, Don
Silves, Amadis d'Astre, Agesilan, and the rest fell upon them, and with their
swords showred such an infinity of blows upon their shields, that it made them
almost despair of effecting their enterprise, howbeit calling to mind the
great Alcanders words, they stood stiffly to it, and thrust those two great
Knights along with such force, as at length they set them out of the room,
whither they instantly returned to lay hold on Don Silves and Agesilan, who
troubled them no less than the others; nevertheless, they were likewise born
forth, and after them all the rest, but with so much pain and labor, as
questionless these two Warriors had never prevailed, had they not been
prepared thereunto by Alcander.

This while Alcidamant and Griolsnis, Amadis and Grian, were no less moiled,
for the great Knight of the Sun, and the brave Poliphebo his bastard brother;
Belianis and Belstoran, so stoutly withstood them, and were so assisted by
their Companions, as they were almost out of hope of carrying them forth; but
Alcidamant pushed the Knight of the Sun along with such fury, that with much
adoc he got him out of the door, Griolanis having done the like with Polipheb^,
Am^dis with Belstoras, and Grian with Belianis, they returned so often unto the
room, that in the end they carried them all forth, which was no sooner done,
but there was heard a thousand, and a thousand claps of thunder, accompanied
with such dreadful flashes of lightning, as it struck all these Knights to the
ground quite deprived of their understanding, in which estate having remained a
pretty space, Alcander by virtue of a certain Water brought them to their
senses again, when as they perceived all those goodly buildings to be vanished,
and themselves in the Garden through which Grian and Griolanis past at first,
(which was not made by Enchantment) so amazed, as they knew not what to say or
do; but Alcander coming to them spoke thus.

Excellent Princes, now am I in the height of my content, and beholding you
thus resussitated, as it were from death, I am notable to express the
greatness of my joy. You may very well remember, said he, speaking to Don
Belianis, the many good offices which I have heretofore done you, and how being
desirous to preserve you from a mischief that would have fallen on you and
your friends, I carried you from Constantinople to this place where now you
have been an hundred years; You cannot likewise forget, continued he, turning
himself to the valiant Knight of the Sun, that for to deliver you from the
conspiracic of certain Traitors, which were to have murdered you, and yours,
whilst you were in your beds; I put you into a Chariot, and conducted you
hither to decline the bad influence where withal you were menaced; And I doubt
not but you, said he, casting his eye upon Amodis, and his kinsmen, are
mindful yet of the service that I rendered you, when as I took you up from
amongst so many thousand dead bodies, at the furious battle of Aleppo, and
that having cored your wounds, I then saved your lives, in regard whereof I will
not go about to make any excuse for having retained you here so long, since it
was for your preservation, and for the glory of Christendom, that by your
assistance shall triumph over her enemies, only I would desire you to be
friends, and not to stand upon the possession of Empires, which you had, that
are to remain in the hands of those that now hold them, for the Crown of China
is reserved for you, said he, speaking to the Knight of the Sun, and that of
Mexico attends Belianis of Greece, which are Empires great and mighty enough
to take away the memory of others, so as having no cause to be troubled at this
change, you may all prepare your selves with courage for those bloody wars,
whereby the honor of the Cross shall be maintained in its excellency, and the
Altars of the Pagans overthrown.

But now it is fit that I should let you know, who these six brave Warriors
are, unto whom you are obliged for your deliverance. The first is Rozalmond,
the son of Spheramond of Greece, your grandchild speaking to Amadis; The
second, the incomparable Alcidamant, now Emperor of Tramazond; This is Amadis
of Trebisond, your son, said he, to the Emperor of Greece; This is Clarisel of
Guindaya, son to Florisel of Niquea; This other is the valiant Grian the
Salvage; and this last is Griolanis, the gentle King of Corolandaya. Upon this
speech the Princes of Greece understanding that three of these Knights were of
their children, embraced them with so much affection, that they shed abundance
of tears for joy; In the mean time Alcidamant, Grian, and Griolanis,
complemented with Belianis, the Knight of the Sun, and the rest.

These Princes having thus caressed one another, the Queen Oriana, the Empress
Niquea, Diana, Pentasilia, Claridiana, Olivia, Florisabella, Bellianiza,
Sirenna, Bergelina, and the other Princesses of Greece, that had been
enchanted, as you have seen in the first Chapters of our first part; being much
amazed at each others beauties, fell to kissing, and embracing one another; but
all these Ladies, and the Princes, were almost lost in wonder at the sight of
Armazia, Miralinda, Trasiclea, Palmirenna, Penamonda, and Adelazia, which were
brought in by Cassandra, immediately upon the ending of the Enchantments of the
Castle of Treasure; then it was that their joys were renewed, that these
Warriors were not able to express their gladness for the recovery of their
Wives whom they had bewailed as lost; that Amadis embraced Armazia, Miralinda,
Palmirenna, and Penamonda, that he humbled himself before the excellent
Princess of Tramizond, and the beautiful Adelazia, that the Knight of the Sun
and Belianis marvelled how nature could produce creatures so rare, and that
Claridiana, Florisbella, and the rest, did them all the honor they could
possibly devise.

These welcomes, these complements and rejoycings having endured two hours, and
more, Alcander leading them into a long and spacious grot, made them a
sumptuous collation, at the end whereof placing himself in the midst of
them, he declared unto them in few words the furious war that was in Ethiopia,
as also the harm that might redound to all Christendom, if they made any
longer abode there, and then made fifty excellent white armours to be brought
in with red crosses, both before and behind; and having presented them to these
Princes, and to the fair Amazons, Trasiclea, Claridiana, Pentasilea, and
Hermiliana, together with an Horse and a lance to every of them, he caused
them to be armed with all diligence; which was no sooner done, but that two
great Chariots appeared in the air, drawn by four strange creatures; Into one
of them he made all the Princesses to enter with Cassandra, who carried them
to the I Will of Corolandaya, and bestowing himself in the other with all these
Princes and Amazons, to made toward Ethiopia, where they arrived within three
days after, he perform the wonders which shall be related unto you in the
Chapters following.

CHAP. L. Amadis of Gaul, and his companions arrive in Ethiopia, their
resolution to pass through the Enemies Camp; Rozalmond and his friends being
separated from them, surprise the strong Fort of Zeilan.
ALcanders Chariot having made way through the clouds for two days together;
the great Fowls that drew it abated their flight, and lighted on the ground at
the entrance into a Forest, where the reverend old man causing them to
descond, said unto them. Brave Princes, you are now arrived in Ethiopia, where
you are to employ your valor and awaken those forces, which have been so long
time asleep; here you shall meet with the valiant Florisel of Niquea,
accompanied with all the young Princes of Greece, their Allies, and three
hundred thousand men, although he has in the precedent battails lost two
hundred thousand and above; but the number of the Pagans is so great, that
notwithstanding the slaughter of four hundred thousand men cut in pieces by
the Christians, they have yet above five hundred thousand remaining, besides so
many excellent Warriors, as your presence is more then necessary at this time
to arrest the fury of their Enterprises; I refer all to your wisedoms, take
this way which will lead you directly to the enemies camp, and managing your
fortune wisely, give her occasion to favor you; These six Warriors, the
Authors of your deliverance shall follow you ere it be long, but they are
first to perform an enterprise of great conse quence, to which end they must
take this path of the left hand.

Having spoken this he mounted into his Chariot, and was instantly carried out
of sight; whereupon these Princes dividing themselves to the great grief of
Alcidamant, that was feign to part from his Trasiclea, they began to march
several ways. Rozalmond and his companions having traversed the Forest,
which was not very long, met with a Peasant, that discovering them would have
fled away; but Clarisel having staid him, asked him why he was afraid? Alas!
answered he, I have more cause then would I had, for I doubt you are some of
our Princes enemies, who lie in wait here for some surprise; but surely you
will loose your labor, for your troops have so ravaged all about Zeidan, that
every body is fled into the woods and mountains here about, for fear of falling
into your hands, I only am the unfortunate man, who going to give advice unto
our Emperor of taking in of that Town could not decline your encounter. Honest
friend, said Clarisel unto him, thou art much mistaken; for we are Christians,
and such as would willingly serve thy Master, who is a friend to the Princes of
Greece. I would advise you then, said he, to advance no farther forward, the
fields are all covered over with an hundred thousand men, which after the
surprise of Zeidan, have laid siege to Goraxa, one of the strongest Towns of
this Empire, and all the riches of the world could not ransom you out of their
hands, should they once lay hold on you, which were great pity, for by your
countenances you appear more than ordinary men. God a mercy friend, said
Clarisel, laughing, for thy good opinion of us, howsoever we do purpose not to
follow thy counsel; so letting him go they consulted together about the
course they should hold, and resolved to go straight into Zeidan, faining
themselves to be Pagans, cut the Garrisons in pieces, and so restore that
strong Town into Prigmaleons possession.

Riding on then, after an hours traveling they presented themselves before the
Gates, which were presently opened unto them, the Pagans never imagining that
six Knights being enemies durst hazard themselves amongst eight thousand men,
that kept the place; Nevertheless Rozalmond which marched foremost, seeing
himself within, drew out his sword, cleft the first to the teeth, and flying
among the rest, left his companions to follow his example, who desiring to show
as much force and courage, began to make such a slaughter, that threescore lay
dead at their feet, before the Town took the alarm; but the hurt men running
up and down with fearful (...), two thousand came suddenly in, which falling
furiously upon them, thought to make an end of them in a trice; but these
incomparable Warriors, that would not have been afraid of all the world
together, went and met them with such confidence, as made the most courageous
amongst them to tremble, they ran up and down like lightning, and keeping close
one to another, they slew so many, that it was a most dreadful sight to
behold, all the streets were covered with dead bodies.

The noise increased, the number of the enemies augmented, and from every part
came soldiers hurrying in, which rendered the confusion more horrible. An hour
being spent in the fury of the first fight, during the which sixteen hundred
men had been massacred, all the rest began to fly, when as six Giants appeared
with three thousand men, who seeing so much blood and murder, could not
believe it was done by the hands of six Knights alone; howbeit perceiving their
people to fall at their feet, as often as the swords of these Knights
descended, they advanced all with such an excess of rage, as the fire flew out
of their eyes: Our Princes, who perceiving rightly, that the victory consisted
in the death of those six Colossus, beholding them arrive with fury, incountred
them with the like order, and desiring to display the uttermost of their force,
in regard it so concerned them, discharged upon their helmets with such a
tempest, that Rozalmond and Alcidamants opposites were cleft down to the
girdle, and the rest to the teeth, which put such a terror into their
followers, as they labored to save themselves by flight, but the Inhabitants
of the Town rallying themselves, and finding them in disorder charged them so
rudely on the other side, that their fear increasing, they were all cut in
pieces, four hundred only excepted, who betaking them to their heels, fled
to the gross of their Army, and there so published the wonders which these
Knights had done, that they believed them to be Devils.

Whilst these six Princes were cried up to heaven in the Town by the people;
who promised to maintain themselves for the time to come, by the favor of
their Walls and Fortifications; Amadis of Gaul, and his Companions having
marched two days together, and one evening discovered the enemies Camp, were
marvellously astonished to behold so many Pavillions, and Tents; that at first
they wished for Alcanders Chariot to carry them into the City; but being
courageous enough to make their passage thither with the sword, they resolved
to attend the break of day, so that they might surprise the Enemy asleep, and
accordingly they entered into a little thicket, where having taken a little
rest, they arose, and advancing toward their Enemies, they entered pell-mell
amongst them with such fury, that above five hundred men lost their lives in
less than half an hour; the Tents went to ground, Pavillions were
overturned, and the massacre continued with such horror, as the Sun seemed
loath to appear, because it would not be spectatour of so cruel a butchery.

The famous Amadis of Gaul pressed through them like lightening, Amadis of
Greece thundered every where, the invincible Knight of the Sun overrun all
like a torrent; Belianis of Greece carried himself like a fury, the four
excellent Ladies, Trasiclea, Claridiana, Pentasilea, and Hermiliana did
wonders, Belstoran, Rosicler, Claramant, Poliphebo, Don Silves, Fortiman of
Greece, Amadis d' Astre, and ^he rest cut off arms, cleft men in two, hewed
Knights in pieces, and nothing appeared before them but went to the ground; the
uprore increased; the whole Camp put themselves in Arms, the Christians were
amazed, and could not imagine from whence so great a disorder should proceed,
were it not from the Army of Martaria, that was every day expected; briefly all
was in confusion, and the Commanders not able to be informed by those that fled
of the cause of this tumult, knew not what to resolve upon; nevertheless,
Falanzar a prudent and courageous Prince, advancing with Brufaldor King of
Gedrosia, Roussardan the furious, Bravorant, King of Morimont; Marisgolf, the
grand Salvage, and Furiander his son, encountered these fifty redoubted
Warriors, and seconded by twenty thousand Horse, thought to vanquish them very
easily, but Amadis of Greece, the Knight of the Sun, Amadis of Gaul,
Rosiclere, Poliphebo, Belianis, and Belfloran, having arrested the fury of
these seven proud Pagans, that were persuaded they could carry all the world
before them, the rest flew in amongst their troops so courageously, that after
they had past two and thirty Giants by the edge of the Sword, they put them to
flight with an incredible slaughter.

In the mean time the Combat between these fourteen Knights became most
horrible and cruel, howbeit our Pinces not meaning to stay till the whole
Camp were in arms to invest them, having valiantly dif-ingaged themselves out
of their hands, drew toward the City, but encountering the proud Knight
Arastron, who came accompanied with Marmoran, Sophy of Bultara; Brizardan,
Sultan of Aralafia; Gorgophon, (...), the great Caliph of Francapia; Moranteon,
Sultan of Circassia; Fier^s^on, the redoubted King of Balivan; Barcandor, and
Bucarguant, their pastage thither grew more difficult than they expected;
nevertheless, Trasiclea, Don Silves, Amadis d' Astre, Claridiana, Claridian
her son, Claramant, Forti^^^, and the gentle Doliftor of Nubia opposing
themselves to these nine Warriors, there began a most cruel and furious fight
between them, whilst the rest had much ado to save them from an hundred
thousand men that came in from all parts, and questionless they had been in
great danger, if Florisel of Niquea, who imagined that they were some valiant
Knights that labored to pass unto his Camp, had not suddenly issued forth
with thirty Princes of Greece, and fifty thousand Horse, which falling
furiously on these disordered troops, overthrew so many to the ground, as it
was almost covered with them.

Then it was that those brave Champions hearing Grecia cried on all sides, took
new courage, and flying amongst the Pagans, made so great a slaughter, that if
Falanzar had not caused his Forces to retire, his Army had been in danger to
have been cut in pieces, although he was assisted with two hundred Giants, but
this prudent Monarch, and his followers after his example, having quit the
combat, which they had with Amadis of Gaul, and his friends, the Christians
had liberty to return to the City; where that great Amadis of Gaul, with
Amadis of Greece, and Don Silves being discovered; Florisel, Don Rogel, and the
other Princes of Greece, were so confounded, as they remained a good space
without speaking a word, believing that this succor proceeded from the art of
Alquif or Urganda, and that those personages were no other than Fantosmes, but
being cleared from that, by the speech of these great Princes, who declared
unto them how they had been preserved in the Castle of Treasure, and delivered
by Rozalmond, Alcidamant, and their Companions, together with Belianis and the
Knight of the Sun; whom they made known unto them; Florisel, Don Rogel, and
Spheramond, were ready to swoun for joy; they fell on their knees before their
Grandfathers, embraced Don Silves, Pentasilea, Amadis d' Astre, Agesilan,
Fortumian, and the rest, and with much honor caressed the Knight of the Sun,
Don Belianis of Greece, and their companions.

My Lord, said Florisel of Niquea, embracing the knees of Amadis of Greece, am
I so happy as to behold you again? I never thought it possible, and when I saw
you enter into the crystal Chamber of Cenotaph, where you were enchanted, I
verily believed that the clap of thunder which brake forth at that instant, was
the sign of your death; But how true, O great Alcander, was your prediction
then, and now I understand the meaning of those secret words you wrote unto me,
as also the Prophecy you left at Constantinople; for the Crows, which were to
assemble to possess the sleeping Eagles neast, are with out doubt these
enemies that lie about our Walls; and now I see that Prophecy fulfilled which
said, The Earth shall open to render forth the treasure it concealed, and the
tears shed for a loss not suffered, shall be changed into gladness; The truth
hereof is unquestionable, and the excess of my content past all expression.

Florisel having said thus, Prigmaleon, Fulgoran, and Russian, made themselves
known to the new comers; and Silvan having with a thousand embraces received
Don Silves, and the fair Pentasilea, his mother, some hours were spent with
incredible rejoicing, at the end whereof, and just as they were sitting down at
a table; a soldier entered, who as a most prodigious matter, delivered that
Zeiden had been recovered by the valor of six Knights alone, who in one day
had slain six Giants, and seven thousand five hundred Knights that guarded it;
look said Amadis of Gaul, here is new occasion of joy, which doubtless
arrives unto us by Rozalmond, Alcidamant and their companions, who are said he,
speaking to Florisel, the best Knights of the world; my Lord answered Florisel,
I have seen them in fight, and must thereupon conclude, as you have done;
Herewith sitting down to dinner, they were served in great state, with all the
exquisite meats that possibly could be had, where we will leave them and return
unto the Pagans.

CHAP. LI. The Pagan Princes present the Combat of an hundred, to an hundred
unto the Christians, they accept of it; the forces of Martaria, with the
assistance of Rozalmond, and his friends, defeats Artogants Army, that besieged
Goraxa.
WHilst the Christian Princes were drowned in pleasure and gladness, the
Pagans much more vexed at the hardiness of these incomparable Warriors, which
were able to repress their fury, then at the loss of three and thirty
thousand men slaughtered in their Camp, were at the supremest degree of rage,
but desiring some way of revenge, they assembled in Falanzars tent, who
demanding their advise upon the consequence of another Battle, with a
proposition to send for Artogant and his Army; but Bravorant, King of Morimont,
the most redoubted Pagan of the earth, rising up with Gorgophon, that bit his
fingers for spite to have met with enemies able to resist him, he said unto
him with a carriage that testified his rage.

Great Monarch, when I consider that our troops are less by half, than they
were at our arrival here, I cannot choose but marvel, either at our
misfortune, or at our enemies well managing of their wars, their cunning is
more than their courage, their men are better than ours, and it is too evident,
that numbers have stood us in little stead in our enterprises; wherefore I hold
it not fit, nor will I counsel you to hazard the honor of Paganism, and the
greatness of our hopes any more on the weakness of the arms of such a
multitude of soldiers as we have, which ordinarily fail us in our occasions,
and are the means to make their Captains lose the glory, which otherwise they
might obtain, knew they but how to obey and fight: You have here two hundred
Knights, as valiant as any the earth does bear, the meanest of which would make
the most valorous of our enemies to faint, embrace this as the best course,
propound a combat of an hundred to an hundred, and in that manner decide our
differences: The Grecians are rash enough to undertake it, trusting in the
force of thirty or forty amongst them, whom they not a little value, but I am
confident that you will this way obtain the victory, whereof we are else like
to fayl, if by past success we may probably conjecture of that which is to
come. Your advice is such and so good, answered Falanzar, that I resolve to
follow it, if the rest of these Princes here are of our opinion.

Mighty Emperor, said Gorgophon then, proceed on boldly, for I will undertake
that not one of this assembly, but is desirous to spare the blood of so many
men, as infallibly would be spilt, if we should be so wilful as to meet the
enemy once more in open field; wherefore cause a challenge to be drawn, as soon
as you please; and let the conditions of the combat be, that you shall be Lord
of this Empire, if the victory be ours, or that we will dislodge with all our
troops, and leave it still in their possession if fortune shall favor them.
This said, all the Princes rising up, as it were to authorize Gorgophons
speech, Falanzar sent this which follows, to be presented to the Grecian
Princes, by Gedereon, King of Arginaria.

The great Emperor, and Caliph of Siconiaes challenge to the Princes of Greece.
THE pity which we have of our people, and the horror of so many dead bodies
that we have seen lying in these fields, inducing us to prefer their welfare
before our own fafety, does oblige us to conserve it with the hazard of our
lives; In which regard we have sent to present you with a combat of an hundred
Knights against alike number of ours, so to determine all our differences with
the victory of the one, or the other party; consult with your courages and
forces, and let us know whether the world does commend you with reason: The
King of Arginaria, our Ambassador, having absolute power from us to dispose of
the conditions of this fight, you may take his engagement for all our
combattants, and send us a like assurance of your parts.


The excellent King of great Britain, unto whom all the rest of the Princes
referred themselves, having read this challenge, turned him to Gedereon, and
said. King of Arginaria, you may behold the answer, that is to be returned you,
in the countenances of these Warriors, which are here assembled, there is no
need of further advising with them about it, they testify sufficiently, that
their desire, and yours, is one and the same; wherefore not to hold you longer
in suspense we say, that we are contented with the number you have chosen, and
with the conditions you propound for the possession of this Empire, though you
have no right at all unto it, but if our ill fortune takes it from us, we have
three or four others to recompense our Son Prigmaleon withal; whereupon the
Emperor of Aethiopia having protested to perform whatsoever Amadis had agreed
unto, the Secretary was called to write this.

The King of great Britains answer to Falanzar Emperor, and Caliph of
Siconia.
WE are no less tender of our people than you, and your resentment that way
seems so just unto us, that never sticking at the right you have to claim the
Crown of the Empire, we are very well contented to set it upon the end of a
Lance before the Judges of the Combat, which you demand, and whereunto We
agree, to be performed betwixt our two Camps five days hence, with the same
assurance, as you have given us; And because the election of the Arms is in Us,
We choose those which are usual with Knights Errant, and in the mean time We
will make a truce for four days.


The King of Arginaria returning with this answer, all the Pagans were
marvellously astonished at the name of Amadis of Gaul, whom they thought had
been dead long before, and understanding that he was the chief of them that had
made way through their Camp with so great a slaughter, they believed that so
many Princes were resussitated to torment them eternally; nevertheless, their
own pride persuading them that the earth could not contain men that could
resist them; Falanzar caused a List to be drawn up of those that were to
Combat, and never going about to give them reasons, for to render them the more
courageous, he sent them away to their Tents, there to take order that their
Horses, and Arms, might be well fitted for this furious fight. Let us give
them time to make their preparations, and recount the brave actions performed
by the Martarians: You may remember that the Emperor of Martaria being made a
Christian, departed from Corolandaya, with Persides of Greece; Floridan of
Persia, Lucibel of France; his Sons-in-law, and gentle Sestilian of Spain,
servant to the fairest Agiliana, Princess of Arbales, to carry succors to the
Princes of Greece.

This great Monarch desiring to manifest his zeal to the glory of the new God
which he adored, and the esteem that he made of the Princes of Constantinoples
alliance, being fortunately arrived in his own Empire, made forth Commissions,
caused an hundred thousand Horse, and threescore thousand Foot to be levied,
bestowed most part of the Infantrie in five or six Frontier Towns, and levying
twenty thousand Horse, and thirty thousand Foot, under the conduct of the King
of Arbales his Cousin, to withstand all attempts of his neighbors, if they
should chance to stir in his absence, he resolved in person to conduct an Army
of fourscore thousand Horse into Aethiopia.

Having then accodingly imbarqued them with his Sons-in-law, and himself, he
was carried with so prosperous a gale, that having run along by the coasts of
Guinea, Cephala, and Calicut, in seven and thirty days he arrived within three
leagues of Zeiden, where informing himself of the state of the War, he
understood that Artogant, the Sultan of Francapa, being separated from the body
of the Army, held Goraxa very straightly besieged with great likelihood of
carrying it, in regard it could not be succored without much prejudice to the
Christian forces, whereupon putting his men in battle array, he marched toward
Goraxa with a resolution to charge the enemies, and accordingly, finding them
prepared to receive him, for that Artogant had been advertised of their
descent, he caused Lucibel and Sestilian to advance with thirty thousand
Horse, who incountring six Giants in the head of forty thousand men, they
charged their Lances so luckily, as two of the Giants were run through, and
through.

The encounter of these first troops was very furious, and so many Knights were
overthrown, that within less than half an hour, the ground was all covered
with them; Lucibel and Sestilian, having broken their staves in the bodies of
the two Giants, began to disorder the Pagans, and overturning all that came in
their way, they filled every part with such fear, as the soldiers flying from
the tempests of their swords, declined them more than they would have done the
pestilence; On the other side the four Giants enraged at the death of their
companions, made so great a slaughter, as was most lamentable to behold: In
this sort the fight became most cruel and bloody; and every minute so many men
fell, that in the field was nothing but heaps of dead bodies. Two hours being
spent in the heat of this first conflict, and the victory as it were hanging
in equal balance, there arrived six Warriors from Zeidens side, who
understanding by an hurt soldier of all that had past, they fell in amongst
the Pagan troops, and began to make such a massacre of them, as they were no
less dreaded, than all the Army besides; they cut off arms and heads, cleft
men down to the waste, divided Knights in two, and the fury wherwithall they
fought was so great, that they alone seemed able to destroy all the Pagan host.

The Giants perceiving this disorder, went and ran all four together, with
such confidence against those six incomparable Warriors, as if they would
easily have laid them in the dust, but they were so rudely incountred, that two
of them had their arms, swords and all, sent to the ground, and the other two
were cleft down to the teeth. Then it was that the Pagans, beholding so sudden
a defeat of those four Colosses, in whom they had placed all their hope,
betook them to flight, ready to be cut all in pieces, had not the Sultan of
Francapa come in to their succor with ten Giants, and threescore thousand
Horse; The arrival of these new forces having restored their courages, they
turned head against the Christians, and began to lay about them with incredible
valor, but the Emperor of Martaria approaching with Persides, and Floridan,
the fight began to be so hot and violent, that the face of the whole field was
covered over with slaughtered carcasses, and the air sounded nothing but cries
and lamentations of dying men; The Giants did wonders, they cut and hewed down
all before them, and keeping themselves still close together, they made such a
miserable havoc whersoever they went, as it was a spectacle of incredible
horror.

The Martarian Emperor desiring to show that he was a Christian, ran without
fear into danger, being guarded by the thundering swords of Persides, Floridan,
Lucibel, and Sestilian, who always accompanied him, and the slaughter was so
great wheresoever they past, that the Giants being unable to arrest their
^^ying people, advanted to encounter them, and charged them with such fury, as
Sestilian and the Emperor were overthrown under the horses feet, where
doubtless they had been stifled, had not Persides, Lucibel, and Floridan kept
off the enemy, till such time as their followers had taken them up, and carried
them out of the press. This while the three Princes were in much danger amidst
so many Giants, and being oppressed on so many sides, they had little hope of
escaping with life, when as those six Champions that came from Zeiden
incountring upon that place, fell in with the Giants, and discharged their
swords all at one instant with such a tempest, that six of them sunk down dead
at the feet of the three besieged Princes, who knowing those six incomparable
Warriors to be Rozalmond, Alcidamant, and their companions, were so far
encouraged, that clasping their swords fast in their hands, they delivered
three such horrible blows, as three of those Colosses fell downdead on their
fellows.

The Pagans nevertheless being nothing dismayed, stood very stoutly it, after
the example of the Sultan of Francapa, who that day rendered mavelous proof of
his force and courage, in so much that the Pagan Army being resolutely bent to
fight it out, were within three hours cut al in pieces, six thousand only
excepted, which with Artogant saved themselves in a wood, leaving the Christian
Princes with the loss of thirty thousand men, whereof they were not much
sensible, the rather for that the Emperor and Sestilian were well recovered of
their hurts. Having continued then some time to bury their dead, during the
which Rozalmond and his friends had recounted the deliverance of Amadis of
Gaul, and of so many enchanted Princes, with all that had past in that
adventure; The Emperor raised his Camp, and marched on toward Saba, being
somewhat perplexed with thinking how he should get to the City, by reason of
the enemies lying round about it, but having learned of certain Courriers, who
had been sent to seek Alcidamant, and his fellows, for to be of the number of
the Combattants, that there was a truce between the Pagans and them, he quietly
advanced without any impeachment to the gates of the City, where all those
great Princes did the Emperor of Martaria so much honor, and so caressed
those excellent Knights, that came along with him, as cannot well be expressed
in words; wherefore I will pass it over, and relate the combat betwixt the
Christian Princes, and the Pagan Kings, for the determination of their wars.

CHAP. LII. The dreadful combat of an hundred Christians, against so many
Pagan Princes; the end thereof, with the bloody slaughter of all the enemies
troops.
HAd not the hope of an horrible revenge in some sort mittigated the
displeasure, which the pagans conceived upon the advertisement of the defeat of
Artogants Army, by the Martarian forces, they would have been even mad with
rage, but attending the day appointed for the combat, with much impatience,
they comforted themselves in the confidence they had to put all the Christians
to the sword, when as they should be disfurnished of their Commanders,
whereunto they were the more assuredly persuaded by the arrival of the fairest
Azamandra, who came unto the Pagans Camp, with a very stately equipage.

First of all there marched in excellent order fifteen thousand Amazons richly
armed, and mounted on Unicorns, whose furniture was all guilt over; a little
after, but at some distance, rode nine other Amazons with golden Crowns on the
top of their helmets; then followed a tryumphant Chariot, carried upon twelve
great wheels of Ivorie, and drawn by twelve Unicorns, as white as snow, which
being fastened together with golden chayns, were guided by twelve little Dwarfs,
apparelled in cloth of gold; the Chariot was of a mavelous fashion, the
length of it was fifty foot, the breadth fifteen; a sumptuous Pavilion enameled
with red and green, covered the top of it; the two sides were two Arches,
whose roofs were enriched with a world of precious stones; against the back of
it was a throne all set with diamonds, which sparkled round about in a
wonderful manner: Therein sat Azamandra, armed all over save her head and
hands, with such a majesticall beauty, as amazed all that beheld her; thirty
Trumpets environed this Chariot, continually sounding with an admirable
consort, nine Amazon Queens followed close after, and a good way off marched
fifteen thousand Amazons in the same order as the first.

This excellent Princess was received with all the honor that possibly could
be done her, especially by Falanzar, who being stricken in love at the sight of
so rare a creature, kissed her hands, and said unto her. Madam, I must believe
that the gods have inspired you to come hither, for to comfort us with your
presence, after so many losses as we have received: Great Prince, answered she,
it very much grieves me, that I have been so slack in bringing you this
succor, which now proves altogether unprofitable, in regard of the accord that
you have made with your enemies; but if there remains a room yet in the number
of the hundred, which you have chosen for the combat, let me entreat you to
give it me, that I may testify the desire I have to serve our gods, and to
make trial of my self against the Princes of Greece, who are every where so
cried up with incredible applause. Madam, replied Falanzar, it were a grievous
sin methinks to expose so precious a Jewel, as your incomparable self, to the
hazard of Arms; nevertheless, since you desire it, we will by no means oppose
your pleasure, whereon we will all of us absolutely depend; You shall tomorrow
then have the prime place, and so many Princes as you behold here, shall but
second the greatness of your courage.

Having said so, he with the most part of the Pagan Kings conducted her to her
quarter, and leaving her there, to refresh her self, and pitch her Tents, he
assembled all his Commanders to his Pavillion, where having briefly
remonstrated unto them of what importance the next days fight would be, he
desired them to permit him to dispose of the order that was to be observed in
so dangerous an affair: wherefore having chosen fifty of the strongest Giants,
that were still remaining in the Army, he nominated fourteen of the best Knights
Errant of all Paganism, whose names shall be delivered hereafter, thirty two
Kings, and four Amazonian Queens, with Azmandra, for the Combat. On the other
side Amadis of Gaul, upon whose care the Christians altogether relied,
entreated the Emperor of Martaria, seeing his age did exempt him from the
exercise of Arms, that he would be pleased to be Judge of their Combat,
whereunto he having condiscended, he ordained that Gelodan, Atletta his Wife,
Astibel and Timbres of Egypt; Oriander, the King of Catay; the Queen Castora,
and Parmenian of Cyprus, should be for the guard of the Camp; as also to see
their men might still be in readiness for all kind of accidents, then finding
that the rest of the Princes there assembled, amounted to the number of an
hundred, he commanded them to be all prepared against the next morning, which
at length appearing, to the equal contentment of both parts, our Christians
heard Mass, and disposed of themselves, as men fitted for another world,
whilst the Pagans to render their gods favorable, offered a thousand
sacrifices unto them.

That done, the Emperor of Martaria, and the King of Argosan, Judge for the
Pagans, having begirt the Barriers with four thousand men for the surety of
the field, and the Trumpets being placed, the Pagan Kings presenting themselves
first with incredible confidence; The beauteous Empress of the Amazons marched
foremost clad in such rich Arms, that the Diamonds upon them dazzled the eyes of
all the spectatours; then followed Falanzar, Brizardan the Sultan of Aralafia;
Marmaran, Sophy of Bultara; Policastaleon, King of Zeilan; Mambriman, King of
Fornacia; Furiander, son to the grand Salvage; Asturion, the stout Sultan of
Brutacan; Alceus, the generous; Artogant, Sultan of Francapa; Bacarguant; the
proud Knight Arastron; Brufaldor, King of Gedrosia; Moranteon, King of
Circassia; Bravorant, King of Morimont; Gorgophon; Roussardan, the furious King
of Grifalara; Antomedon, Caliph of Francapia; Typhaeus the dreadful; the
gentle Knight Armorand; Fieraston, King of Balian; Marisgolf the great; the
horrible Giant Bramanaldon; Pandaro the stout; Radamant, the inexorable, and
fifty Giants; After whom went Gedereon King of Arginaria; Gronfalin, King of
Facea; Meliander, King of Russia; Armorand, Palamedes, king of Cassandria;
Asmorian, King of the superior India; Salander, Giracond, Brandimart,
Raiartes, Boraldo the strong; Broncaldion, king of the Arcofibrats; Rindar,
Artilian, Cariand^r, Argilles, ^^dismond, and Alarban.

These hundred Champions, selected out of the best of all Paganism, being
placed by the Judges, the invincible King of great Britain arrived with the
rest of his fellow Knights, in a most brave and gallant manner: Trasiclea,
Claridiana, Alastraxerea, Hermiliana, and Pentasilea, entering first into the
Lists, were by the Emperor of Martaria, opposed against Azamandra, Tomiris,
Zenobia, Anaxamena, and Neophona; and Amadis of Gaul set himself against
Falanzar; Belianis of Greece, against Brizardan; the Knight of the Sun against
the most valiant Bucarguant; Amadis of Greece, against Fu^iander; Florisel of
Niquea, against Mambriman; Don Rogel, against Asturion the strong Sultan of
Brutacan; Spheramond, against Policasteleon; Don Silves, against the generous
Alceus; Claridian, against the proud Knight Arastron; Poliphebo, against
Brufaldor; Rosicler, against Radaemant; Claramant, against Pandaro the stout:
Rozalmond, against the redoubted Bravorant; Alcidamant, against the great
Gorgophon; Amadis of Trebisond, against Roussardan the furious; Clarisel of
Guindaya, against the grand Salvage; Persides of Greece against the dreadful
Typhaeus; Floridan of Persia, against Antomedon the proud Caliph of Francapia;
Amadis d' Astre, against Artogant; Russian of Media, against Barcandor;
Fulgoran, against the gentle Knight Armorand; Prigmaleon against Marmaran,
Sophy of Bultara, and the rest just opposite to one or other of the Pagan side.

These two hundred Knights, the choice of the whole world, being placed, as
aforesaid, the Judges parted the Sun between them, and commanding the Trumpets
to sound, they let them dislodge with such fury, that the earth trembling under
the Horses feet, it made all the assistants look pale with fear: The renowned
Amadis of Gaul having incountred Falanzar, just in the vizier of his Helmet,
overturned him on the crupper of his Horse, himself passing along unmoved;
Amadis of Greece, and Fariander, were both overthrown, and at one instant
recovered their horses again; Florisel of Niquea ran Mambriman quite through the
body, sending him dead to the earth; Policastaleon and Spheramond, met without
any advantage; Bravorant, Gorgophon, Roussardan the furious, the grand Salvage;
Antomedon, and the dreadful Typhaus, having incountred Rozalmond, Alcidamant,
Amadis of Trebisond; Clarisel of Guindaya; Grian, and Griolanis, in the midst
of the course with strange fury, their staves flew about all in shivers, and
passing along like lightning, and unmoved, they seemed to have run against
rocks; Brizardan and Belianis, tumbled down wounded; Bucarguant lost his reins
in his encounter against the Knight of the Sun; Arastron and Claridian, were
both of them much astonished; Marmaran lost his Stirrup, Prigmaleon tottered in
his faddle; Don Silves and his Adversary, the generous Alceus, were both
overturned on the cruppers of their horses; Russian of Media, ran Barcandor
into the shoulder, and was himself hurt in the arm; Fourteen Giants were slain
by Rosicler; the brave Poliphe^o, Claramant, Agesilan, Falanges, Astrapalo,
Fortunian, Anaxartes, Dorigel, Silvan, Amanio, the two Cenophales, and
Grandimor; and at this first encounter, Filin, Artaurus, Zair, Lindimart,
Florarian, and Lucencio, were overthrown dead to the ground by those against
whom they ran.

The fury of Lances being over, all these Knights drew their swords, and
mingled themselves one amongst another, except Bravorant, Gorgophon,
Roussardan, the grand Salvage, Fieraston, and Marisgolfe, which would not quit
Rozalmond, Alcidamant, Amadis of Trebisond, Clarisel, Grian, and Griolanis,
between whom there was one of the most horrible combats that ever was seen
under the cope of heaven: The Christian Princes did wonders, the Pagans ran up
and down like famished Lions, the field groaned under the violence of so many
Warriors blows, and the two Armies were equally terrified with the fury of
their Combattants.

The Amazonian Queens, having had equal fortune with their Lances, charged
one another very valiantly in a quarter, aside by themselves; but the fight
between Bravorant and Alcidamant, Rozalmond and Gorgophon, and the other eight
was so dreadful, that men shut their eyes, not daring to behold it; the strong
Bravorant displayed his force, gave Rozalmond most terrible blows; but having
the prime Knight of the earth to deal with, he was followed so close, as he
had no leisure to think of any thing, save how to defend himself. Gorgophon
thundered upon Alcidamant, Roussardans strokes fell like lightning on Amadis,
his shield; the grand Salvage charged Clarisel with incredible force;
Fierastron made Grian sweat drops of blood; Marisgolfe would not suffer
Griolanis to take any rest; the dreadful Typhorus hammered continually on
Persides helmet; the great Caliph of Francapia, put Floridan very dangerously
to it; nevertheless the Christian Champions demeaned themselves so well, as it
was impossible to ascribe any advantage to their enemies.

Bravorant enraged to meet a man able to arrest the fury of his Arms,
discharged his sword with such violence on Rozalmond, that having divided his
shield in twain, the point of it lighted so rudely on his helmet, as it made
him knock his chin against his breast, with an opinion that all his teeth were
broken to pieces, which so incensed out Warrior, as advancing his sword he let
it descend with such a tempest on Bravorants head, as he overturned him on the
crupper of his horse, voyding blood out of his mouth, and ears, and so besides
himself, that his horse carried him up and down the field for dead; but
suddenly resetling himself in his saddle, he became so mad, as thinking to fly
upon Rozalmond, who with another blow had cut a Giant in two, he discharged his
great curtelas so terribly on Lucendus, Prince of France, that he cleft him
down to the shoulders, and finding Don Flores of Greece hard by him, he gave
him so deadly a blow, that he sent half his body to the earth, wherewith yet
not contented he lift up his arm to have stricken Don Rogel behind, when as
Rozalmond observing the ruin of those two blows, set spurs to his horse, and
discharged his sword with such fury on this audacious Pagans helmet, that it
pared it away, to the very hayr, carrying a piece of his ear along with it,
whereat he was so enraged, as taking his curtelas in both his hands, he let
down at Rozalmond with such force, that if his armor had not been of the best
in the world, his death had undoubtedly followed.

On the other fide Alcidamant and Gorgophon entreated one another with no less
violence, this proud Infidel cursing heaven, for making one able to oppose his
Arms, took his mighty Fauchion in both hands, and therewith so struck
Alcidamant on the head, as not being able to pierce that rich helmet, which he
got in the enchanted Castle of Treasure, he made him to knock his chin against
the pommell of his saddle; this horrible blow rather awaking his courage, than
any way amazing him, he rose up, and g^ashing his teeth for very anger, he ran
him with his sword into the thigh, and instantly redoubling on his helmet, he
overturned him on his horses back with a great wound on his head: Thinking him
then to be dead, he flew in amongst his enemies, where meeting the horrible
Bramanaldon, who had newly sheathed his curtelas in one of the Cenophales, he
lent him so deadly a blow on the shoulder, that he cleft him down to the waste.

In the mean time Gorgophon being come to himself again, and most strangely
incensed with the bad usage he had received of his adversary, flew like a
tempest amongst the Christians, cleft Florenio to the teeth, struck Filizel de
Montespines brains out, and in his fury meeting with Lucidamor of Boetia, he
divided him in two pieces; then incountring with Amadis of Greece, who having
newly killed a Giant, came from astonishing Furiander, he let drive at him with
all his might, hoping to lay him in the dust with the rest; but this excellent
Emperor, having scarce his match in the world, sustained his blow, and
striking him with that heroical strength, which tryumphed over the Giants of
the Siclades Island, he gave him a dangerous wound; in the mean time the
invincible King of great Britain, having separated Falanzars head from his
body, ran up and down with Agesilan, Falanges, Astropolo, and Fortunian, giving
assistance to such as stood in need thereof; Prigmaleon on the other side
behaved himself most bravely, against Marmoran, so did Russian of Media,
against Barcandor; Fulgoran against the gentle Knight Armorand; Don Silves
against the generous Alceus; the Knight of the Sun against Bucarguant; Belianis
against Brizardan, and all the rest sought so well, that four hours were spent
before it could be discerned, to whom the victory would incline; but Rozalmond
and Alcidamant seeing it was time to display the uttermost of their forces by
some remarkable blows discharged with such force, the one upon Bucarguant, who
had left the Knight of the Sun almost senseless, and the other on Barcandor his
brother, as they cleft them down both to the teeth, and continuing in this
rage, Alcidamant cut the Sultan of Circassiaes head in pieces, and Rozalmond
the King of Gedrosiaes.

The death of these four mighty Pagans, being accompanied with the slaughter of
sixteen Giants, and of Al^rban, Danizel, Argilles, and Rodismond, the number of
the Infidels began to diminish, which perceived by Bravorant, Gorgophon,
Roussardan, Fieras^on, Marisgolfe, the grand Salvage, Antomedon, Typheus,
Marmaran, and the proud Knight Arastron, they discharged such horrible blows
upon their enemies, that having hurt them all very dangerously, they fell in
with such fury amongst the Christians, as the valiant Anaxartes was cut in
pieces by Brav^rant, Argantes; Emperor of Germany, by Gorgophon; Lind^^^^t
King of Rhodes, by Roussardan; Olidor of Siramque by Fieraston, Anazander King
of Dardania, by Marisgolfe; Floridan his brother, by the grand Salvage, the
remaining C^nophale by Antomedon, Lisc^^d King of Siconia by Typh^^s, Grandimer
by Marmoran, and the gentle Dorigel, Lord of the fortunate Hands by Arastron,
wherewith the Princes of Greece were so displeased, as Rozalmond, Alcidamant,
Amadi^ of Trebisond, Cla^^sel, Grian, Grio^^^^, (...), ^er^ides, Clarid^an, and
Bel^^^^ having incountred them, vowed never to leave them, till they had
revenged their deaths; whereupon the combat renewed with more cruelty than
before, wherein Arlanges of Spain, Arlantes his son, Cassia^^s, and the Duke
of La^azo were likewise slain.

But Amadis of Gaul, Amadis of Greece, Florisel of Niquea, the knight of the
Sun, Rosicler, Poliphebo, Don Eleno of Dacia, and Lucibel of France joining
together, began to run over the field with such rage, that having laid nine
Giants dead at their feet; namely Radamant the cruel, the strong Pandaro,
Razartes, Coriander, Artili^n, Gedereon King of Arginaria, Rindar, Broncaldion,
King of the Arcofibrats, and Meliander, the rest were cut in pieces, together
with Artogant, who dyed by the hand of the Knight of the Sun; so that of the
hundred Pagan Knights, there remained no more but the mighty Bravorant,
Gorgophon, Roussardan, the grand Salvage, Furiander Typhaeus, Antomedon,
Fierastron, Marisgolf, Marmaran, Arastron, Brizardan, Policastaleon, Astrurion,
Sultan of Brutacan, with whom Don Rogel had fought all day without any
advantage, the generous Alcaeus, and the gentle knight Armorand, who by no
means enduring any speech of rendering themselves, combatted like desperate men,
but having continued fighting almost two hours after the rest, they were fain
at length to fall at the feet of their enemies, more void of blood, than of
courage.

The Victory being thus gloriously obtained, the Judges went and parted the ten
Amazons, sent them out of the field with equal honor, and causing those
sixteen famous Pagan knights to be conveyed into the City, that their wounds
might with the more care be looked unto; the Christian Princes were marching
out of the Lists in triumph with the Emperor of Martaria, who greatly rejoiced
at their good fortune, when as they perceived the Enemies troops ranged in
battle array, under the conduct of the great King of Ma^ritania; Zazifalt, and
Monomatapan, to make toward them for to refcue the Pagan knights out of their
hands, whereat being marvellously incensed, they put themselves in the head of
their Squadrons, and fell in upon them with such fury, as the Pagans wanting
valiant and skillful Leaders, began within less than an hour to betake
themselves to flight; whereupon our Soldiers were so encouraged, that
imitating their renowned Commanders, they made such a terrible ma^saere, as the
ground for four leagues about, was covered all over with dead bodies; and that
which rendered the defeat yet greater, and more horrible, was the Sea, which
hemmed them in almost on every side, so that since the Creation of the world so
great a slaughter was never seen, for of four hundred, and three score, and
sixteen thousand men, the remainder of so prodigious an Army, scarce fifteen
hundred escaped, and that by the benefit of the night.

The Christian Princes seeing themselves absolutely victorious returned into
the City, where they found that they had lost of personages of mark;
Lu^^nd^^, Anax^^tes, Argantes, Emperor of Germany; Melindus King of Cloton;
the Cenoph^^es, Flo^aria^ of Thrace; Luceneio, L^cid^mor, Flor^nio, Emperor of
Rome; Filizel of Montespin; Don Flores of Greece; Zair, Filin, Artaurus, (...),
of Rhodes; Arlanges of Spain, Arlantes his son, Dorigel of the fortunate
Islands, Gol^^^ his Wife; young Leod^^^^, the valiant Tr^il^^, Grand^^^^, the
Duke of (...), Floridan of So pradiza; Perion of Turkey; Florestan, of
Sardinia; Cassianus, Anaxander, King of Dardania; Floradin, Gelodan, Prince of
Moldavia; Alettha, Oriander, King of Sardamira; Oroncius, Alvida, the Queen
Castora; the King of Catay, Rozaphar, Parmenian of Cyprus; Garmantes, Don
Smaldo, and Tymbres of Egypt, whereof some were slain in the Combat, the rest in
the battle; much were they grieved for their deaths, and with many tears did
they lament them, but they were comforted, for that they dyed in the bed of
honor, and that also the principalls had been preserved from the fury of so
bloody a day, for which having rendered humble thanks unto heaven, they gave
order for the curing of the wounded, and solemnizing the Funerals of the
deceased, with all kind of pomp and magnificence.

CHAP. LIII. The Pagan Knights are delivered; Alcidamant, Amadis of Trebisond,
and Rozalmond are crowned Emperors of Tramazond, Martaria, and Gardacia; The
separation of all these Princes.
THE Pagan Knights being mad with rage for the slaughter of so many Kings, and
valiant Giants, that had kept all the world in awe, but much more for that they
were vanquished by their enemies, would not suffer the Chirurgians to dress
their wounds, desiring rather that a speedy death might free them from the
misery of a long expected captivity, which being declared unto the King of
great Britain, he went the next day to visit them, and knowing that whatsoever
he should do, would be authorized by the Christian Princes, having found them
all in a room together, he said unto them.

Knights, I imagine that if fortune had favored your designs, and that we had
been in your power, as now you are in ours, you would have taken pleasure to
have made us suffer unworthy things for the satisfaction of your revenge, but
we will let you see, that the Princes of Greece are gentlier disposed, that
they love not slaughter, nor blood, neither do at any time shed it, but when
as they are obliged thereunto, either for the maintenance of the order of
Knighthood, or to defend themselves from such as do assail them: your despair
has made you decline the remedies, which we would have given you for the
healing of your wounds, you shall go and seek them where you please, to which
end we set you freely at liberty, whereby also we desire you should know, that
we never did, nor will fear the greatness of your arms; If you shall be
sensible of our courtesies, and shall at your return contain your subjects in
peace, we shall be very glad of it, if otherwise it shall not much trouble us.
Whereupon having formerly commanded a ship to be rigged and victualled, he
caused them to be carried aboard without attending any answer, letting them go
to Gorgophons Island wonderfully amazed to find such courtesy from enemies,
that had been so exceedingly outraged, howbeit all this could not work upon
their hardened hearts, for they resolved to be revenged at any rate whatsoever,
and once more to turn the world upside down.

This affair being then expedited, Amadis accompanied with seven or eight of
the Grecian Princes, that kept not their beds, went to visit the beautiful
Emperesse of the Amazons, and did her so much honor, as she repented the
employing of her Arms against them. Sovereign Prince, said she after a most
gentle manner, I would not believe, that you and yours were every where
invincible; nor could think that the applause, which the world gave you, were
justly due to you, but having seen incredible effects of your matchless
valor, and found a generosity in you, not common to other men, I say the world
does you wrong, not to erect Altars unto you; wherefore I beseech you to pass
by that which I have done against you, and to honor me so far, as to place me
in the number of the truest friends you have. Great Lady, answered that
magnanimous King, and bowing himself for to kiss her hands, I do no longer
lament the loss we have sustained, seeing we have gotten so fair a thing, as
your most excellent self; your desire does very much oblige us, and the
performance of your commandments, shall always be our uttermost ambition.
Hereupon having entreated her to take a lodging with them in the city, she and
the Queens her followers were conducted by him and the Princes thither, and
were brought to Trasicleas Chamber, where all the other Princes were assembled,
by whom being infinitely caressed, both sides stood amazed at each others
beauties.

Shortly whereupon it grew to be a very great court; for Cassandra arriving
from Corolandaya, with all those excellent Ladies, of whom we have spoken
heretofore, and all the brave Knights being recovered of their hurts made up
such a royal presence, that it much astonished this fair Emperesse; but when
as Rozalmond, Alcidamant, Amadis of Trebisond, Clarisel, and Griolanis,
presented themselves for to kiss her hands, she was so ravished with the sight
of their goodly personages, and gallant demeanor, as she could not forbear
saying openly, that now she had seen all that the world had of most rare, a
praise that blushing made these Princes protest they would serve her eternally.

Whilst all was thus in joy, and triumph, and that the Princes were talking of
their own departure, and dismissing of the Christian forces, two ancient
Knights entered into the hall in mourning weeds, which looking round about, at
length went and kneeled before Trasiclea, who presently knowing them, demanded
what news they had brought from Tramazond. Very bad, Madam answered one of
them, for being to acquaint you with the decease of our Emperor, we are
assured that natural affection will make you rather lament his death, than
rejoice to see your self Mistress of his Scepter, which now does attend you,
and your faithful subjects wish for nothing so much, as your presence to
appease certain troubles, arising from the ambition of the great Lords, that
strive for the government of the Empire; wherefore we most humbly beseech you,
in tender compassion of your poor people to resolve upon as speedy a departure
thither, as convenience will permit.

At this speech Trasiclea dissolved into tears, and so bewailed the loss of
her Father, that it pittyed every one to behold her; but after they had for a
while given way to her sorrows, the Princes endeavored all they might to
comfort her, especially Alcidamant, who desired her to consider, that the
condition of all men was infallibly to dye, so that by degrees having assuaged
her grief, the King of great Britain propounded the coronation of her and
Alcidamant, which two days after was solemnized on a scaffold, erected for that
purpose, where in their richest roabs, Alcidamant and she two days after
presented themselves on their knees, before Amadis, the Emperor of Martaria,
Belianis of Greece, and the Knight of the Sun, who with many ceremonies set
two Imperial Crowns on their heads, and caused them to be placed on two
Thrones, where all the Princes that were present went and kissed their hands,
except the Emperor, Amadis of Greece, Florisel of Niquea, Don Rogel, and
Spheramond, which kissed them on the cheek.

All these solemnities being finished, Alcidamant and his Lady descended from
their Thrones, when as the Emperor of Martaria causing silence to be made,
spoke thus. My Lords, the age wherein I am, more proper for rest, than for the
cares that wayt upon Kings, advises me to lay them all upon the Princes, which
it has pleased heaven to bestow on my daughters; wherefore said he, taking
Amadis of Trebisond, and Palmirenna by the hands, let these be placed in those
Thrones, as Emperors of Martaria; as for Floridan he shall be King of Orgalia,
and Lucibel of Cleogena, two states that hold of my Empire, whereupon taking the
Crown from off his own head, he delivered it unto Amadis of Greece, who with
Florisel of of Niquea, Don Rogel, and Spheramond, crowned Amadis of Trebisond
in the same manner, as they had done Alcidamant.

This done, the two new Emperors marching foremost with their Ladies were
conducted to the Palace with more magnificence than can be well expressed, and
the feast was far more sumptuous than at any time before, during the which, all
the young Princes waited upon Alcidamant, Amadis of Trebisond, and their wives.
The rest of that day, and eight days after, were spent amidst incredible
contentments; at the end whereof every one preparing himself for his departure,
Florimond of Canabea (that at the suit of Rozalmond had been sent Ambassador
to the Emperor of Gardacia by Spheramond, for to advertise him of Armazia's
deliverance, and to desire him, that he would be pleased to bestow her in
marriage on his Son) returned with this report, that having been marvellously
caressed by that great Emperor, he had noly approved of the match, but had
resigned, and sent his Crown to Rozalmond; whereupon the former Ceremonies were
renewed, and that brave Knight was Crowned by the two new Emperors,
Prigmaleon, and the renowned Amadis of Gaul; Feastings, and tryumphs were
likewise revived with as much, or more magnificence than before, to the
unspeakable joy of all these Princes, and especially of Fortiman of Greece,
Belianis grandchild, who unable to behold the excellent beauty of Penamonda,
Rozalmonds Sister, without adoring her, began to breath forth a thousand
amorous passions, whereof we will speak more at large in our fourth part.

These delights continued fifteen days together, during the which, the
Christian Army had been dismissed, and sent away, all these Princes separated
themselves with many tears; Amadis of Gaul, Amadis of Greece, Don Silves,
Clarisel of Guindaya, the valiant Esquilan of Poland, and the beautiful
Empress of the Amazons, who would needs accompany them, went with their Wives
to Constantinople; Florisel of Niquea into Trebisond with Falanges,
Alastraxerea, Agesilan, and his fairest Diana; Don Rogel with Persides, and
Fulgoran into Persia; Amadis d' Astre to the Empire of the Parthians, where the
fair Infanta Rosiliana, was ready to expire with joy at his arrival;
Fortunian into France with Florisel; Rozalmond, Russian, and Silverin of the
Desert into Gardacia; Amadis of Trebisond; Floridan and Lucibel with their
Father-in-law into Martaria; Alcidamant with Trasiclea, Grian and Brandimanda
to Tramizond; Griolanis and his beauteous Adelazia to Corolandaya; Prigmaleon
remained in Aethiopia, until such time as his Subjects were somewhat better
assured; The Knight of the Sun* and Belianis according to the great Alcanders
directions, set forth with their kinsmen toward China, and the Empire of
Mexico; And all the other Christian Princes embarquing themselves, set sail
for their own Countries, where we will leave them to enjoy all the happiness
of peace for to finish this third Volumne, in the sequel whereof shall be seen
the adventures of Don Belianis, and of the Knight of the Sun, together with a
continuation of the mavelous acts of Alcidamant, Rozalmond, Clarisel,
Persides, and other young Knights of Greece.

FINIS.
